column2: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- Duquesne University today conferred six honorary degrees at the close of its diamond jubilee exercises. Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York extolled the medieval traditions of philosophy and learning as a bulwark in the fight against ignorance.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay said today he sees no need or excuse for the Government to dictate to the oil industry on the "pressing problem" of imports.

J. Norman Lewis, the lawyer engaged to represent the major league baseball players in their dealings with the club owners, said yesterday he planned to press the fight for revision of the pension fund.

Since Milton H. Biow, chairman of the board of the Biow Agency, testified last week at the trial in San Francisco of Arthur H. Samish, the lobbyist, there have been many rumors of possible repercussions.

There was not one hackneyed piece of vocal music on the program that Margaret Roy assembled for her debut recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Obviously a program-maker determined to avoid the usual Italian-German-French-American progression, the young contralto went to early English composers, Respighi, Pfitzner, Stravinsky, Britten and contemporary French composers for her material.

News that the East German Communist Government has stepped up greatly its efforts to jam the American radio station in Berlin, RIAS, was to be expected after the recent history of events in that area. For years RIAS, has been a major thorn in the side of the East German Communists and their Soviet masters, the source of honest news, timely warnings and general encouragement for millions of East Germans.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 12 -- Industry's assistance to schools of higher learning will insure academic freedom and provide the means of raising productive capacity and the standard of living. This, in turn, is the best guarantee for preservation of the capitalistic system, according to the theme set forth in the Industry- College Conference attended by seventy-five leading educators and industrialists today at the Greenbrier Hotel here.
The Ballet Theatre Foundation will start a fund drive with a special ballet performance at the Metropolitan Opera House on Dec. 27.
Net income of the Celanese Corporation of America and domestic subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year was $9,121,974, equal to 95 cents a common share.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 12 -- Yugoslav Army leaders challenged today the Western powers' thesis that Italian help was essential to adequate defense of southern Europe against possible aggression from the east.
Eleanor Steber, Metropolitan Opera soprano, presented a song recital at Town Hall last evening. The event was a benefit for the Manhattanville Neighborhood Center, Inc.

ALBANY, Nov 12 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy declared today that he had evidence that Communist agents had infiltrated the huge General Electric plant in Schenectady and had gained "a complete picture" of the work there, including secret Government projects.

The men who make movies and musical comedies have long since discovered how much we all enjoy looking behind the scenes of the theatrical world, how full of curiosity we are about the real people and the mechanical devices which produce for us impersonations and illusions seen through the proscenium arch upon the stage.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Frank Leahy said today that, health permitting, he intended to continue as Notre Dame's head football coach for the remainder of a contract extending through 1955.

Former President Hoover's latest "task force," in the study of Government reorganization he is directing, will take up federal policy in the handling of water and power resources. Admiral Ben Moreel, retired, who will act as chairman, has a group of twenty-four advisers, a number of them well known to the general public, to help him.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 12 -- It was apparent from Vice President Richard M. Nixon's reception on his arrival in Korea today that the Korean Government hoped to use his three-day visit to convince him that the war must be resumed here.
The city is going to ask farmers about the price of milk.

The Brooklyn College president, Harry D. Gideonse, announced yesterday that he would delay action on the proposal that the Kingsmen drop intercollegiate football, "because of the enthusiastic support for its continuation by the students who have played on our team."

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 12 (UP) -- United States Davis Cup stars, led by Capt. Billy Talbert of New York, won easily today in their opening round matches of the New South Wales tennis championships before a crowd of about 1,000 at White City Stadium.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- Wage increases to go into effect Dec. 1 in the automobile industry will prevent reduction in retail car prices, L. L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said today.

The Pantepec Oil Company, C. A., a Venezuelan corporation, announced yesterday completion of arrangements for the acquisition of a 50.5 per cent stock interest in the Manabi Exploration Company, Inc., from Canada Southern Oils, Ltd.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Col. Earl Blaik is not at all hopeful about the outlook for the Army football team in Saturday's game with Pennsylvania at Franklin Field, Philadelphia. As he expressed it today, "it will take something close to a miracle for a squad such as we have here to beat Penn."
Two new colors were shown yesterday in the mid-season shoe collection at Delman's Fifth Avenue salon. Wedgwood blue and "polar bear," the latter a delicate off-white, were featured.
Edyth Totten, who was well known here during the Nineteen Twenties as a theatrical producer, died yesterday at City Hospital, Welfare Island. Her age was 68.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- United States officials in Bonn again emphatically denied today that the Foreign Operations Administration had any plans to restore the German iron and steel combines that were broken up after World War II.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The Senate Banking Committee said today that no hearings had been held on the nomination of Harry Dexter White as United States director of the International Monetary Fund.
An application requesting permission to abandon Manhattan's Christopher Street Ferry was filed in Washington yesterday by the railroad that operates it.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov 12 -- A controversy over denominational cooperation that has been simmering within the Protestant Episcopal Church for many years broke out into the open here today. It was promptly smothered, however, when the House of Bishops tabled a resolution calling for public censure of the Right Rev. Henry Wise Hobson, Bishop of Southern Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This ended a period of several weeks in which sales fell below comparable weeks of 1952, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board.

Final plans for the construction of a new high school in Queens were approved yesterday by the Board of Education. It will be the second city high school to be built since the post-war construction program was undertaken in 1946, and the first to be erected in Queens in more than ten years.
For angrily refusing to accept a summons for parking in a restricted area while having a midnight snack, Dr. Moses Einhorn, a 57-year-old stomach specialist, spent Wednesday night in a Brooklyn jail.
The Grace Line announced yesterday the election of Ted B. Westfall as vice president and Thomas F. Kavanagh and Capt. Bligh Parker, as assistant vice presidents.
F. A. Strovink has been appointed Eastern regional manager of the paper chemicals department of the American Cyanamid Company succeeding A. C. Bate, who has retired.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 12 (UP) -- The Air Force dropped some security restrictions today and let it be announced that the United States had the most powerful turbojet aircraft engine in the world.

Applications for temporary work during the Christmas rush next month are being accepted at the Post Office, but the number of "temporaries" will be reduced sharply this year, according to Acting Postmaster John H. Sheehan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, appointed today Henry Parkman Jr., a Boston lawyer, as assistant to James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner for Germany.

THE bluebird weather has not made the duck hunters in this area as unhappy as might have been expected. Reports from Long Island Sound, Peconic and Great South Bays, and even Barnegat Bay indicate that the bags have been very satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The way the Harry Dexter White case stands now, everybody concerned has lost something, except maybe the enemies of the United States. The results of the case to date are about as follows:

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Two leading Europeans told the United States Commission on Foreign Economic Policy today that the cooperation that brought European recovery should be extended to a wider scale embracing both sides of the Atlantic.

An increase last week of 364,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. On last Saturday supplies were 143,732,000 barrels, compared with 143,368,000 a week earlier and 121,374,000 a year ago.

MONTREAL, Nov. 12 (UP)--The Montreal Canadiens, with Maurice Richard scoring two goals, made it nine in a row without a loss on home ice as they downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 4--2, tonight before 13,920 fans at the Forum.
Investors of low and moderate income now have a new way in which they may invest their savings in the stock market.
New borrowings by wholesale and retail trades were a major influence in a $7,000,000 expansion in New York bank loans to business during the week ended on Tuesday.

J. Roy Gordon of Copper Cliff, Ont., vice president and general manager of Canadian operations of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., has been elected a director of the Toronto General Trusts Corporation.

ALBANY Nov. 12 -- The New York State Federation of Women's Clubs passed a by-law today requiring all its affiliates holding membership on a per capita basis to join the General Federation of Women's Clubs.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- "Fantastic" is the term applied most generally here to the move to subpoena former President Truman by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Several of the country's leading authorities on constitutional law were unanimous yesterday in holding that former President Truman had no constitutional ground for declining to comply with a House of Representatives committee subpoena calling him as a witness in the Harry Dexter White inquiry.

Kyle Rote was drilled in A-formation tailback assignments yesterday as Coach Steve Owen continued to tinker with the attack of the New York Football Giants in preparation for Sunday's game with the Pittsburgh Steelers at the Polo Grounds.
Tentative plans for the development of a new $10,000,000 campus for Harpur College, now at Endicott, N. Y., were approved yesterday by the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Since no delver into the archives has yet discovered that a Congressional subpoena was ever before issued to a former President to give testimony concerning his acts while in office, Representative Velde of Illinois has made history. And so has Harry S. Truman in declining to render the accounting demanded by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

A 79-year-old New Yorker, Harry Clinton Eva, who conducts the Home for Homeless Boys in the Bronx, received yesterday the Lane Bryant Annual Award for volunteer service to his community in 1952. The City Manager Advocates of Brookfield, Ill., received a similar award for group effort.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -- The corporate name of Monogram Pictures Corporation was changed officially to Allied Artists Pictures Corporation by vote of stockholders at the annual meeting held today at the studio here. Steve Broidy, president, also announced that the stockholders had voted approval of the board of directors' proposal to amend the company's article of incorporation to increase the number of shares of $1 par value common stock from 1,000,000 to 1,500,000.

A lucky Manhattan finder became keeper of a $10,000 platinum bracelet yesterday, but he must share his prize. It was the most valuable piece of jewelry in recent years to be turned over by Frank Leuci, Police Property Clerk at 400 Broome Street.

CANTON, Ga., Nov. 12 (UP) -- John S. Wood, former chairman of the House of Representatives Un-American Activities Committee, said today the committee was preparing to give the Justice Department evidence for a perjury case against Harry Dexter White when Mr. White died.
The widespread belief that there is a direct cause and effect relationship between overweight and coronary heart disease was challenged here yesterday.
The need for improved rail transportation in the metropolitan area, especially between New Jersey and Manhattan, was emphasized yesterday at a public hearing on transit and traffic problems.

Charles (Lucky) Luciano, who figured in the Wicks controversy in Albany yesterday, is an Italian-born gangster who, in the Nineteen Thirties, headed New York vice and narcotics rings and spread his control over a wide range of rackets in the East Coast underworld.

Longshoremen flocked to register with the Waterfront Commission yesterday, in the wake of the decision of Joseph P. Ryan's International Longshoremen's Association to end its boycott of the bi-state pier reform law.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (UP) -- A Federal judge ruled today that the National Football League could continue to restrict television broadcasts of games only in its teams' home areas but could not interfere with any other telecasts or any radio broadcasts of its games.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Behind-the-scenes efforts of the Republican National Committee succeeded today in forestalling any move in the House of Representatives Un-American Activities Committee to try to cite former President Truman for his refusal to respond to its subpoena.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 12 (AP) -- King Ranch's Script, under a waiting ride by Warren Lane, came from next to last to defeat six rivals in the $4,500 Virginia Horse Breeders Purse, which topped today's program at Laurel Race Course.

Following are the texts, as supplied by The Associated Press, of a letter by Former President Truman to Representative Harold H. Velde rejecting a subpoena and of a statement issued in Washington by Mr. Velde, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities:

DALLAS, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The man who filed a $12,000,000 damage suit against organized baseball said tonight that a Federal judge's lifting pro football's restrictions against broadcasting would help him win his case.

When the virus of poliomyelitis is photographed with the aid of the electron microscopic globules that look like golf balls are visible. Are these to be regarded as the virus? It was impossible to answer, because the virus was never pure and because some of the contaminants were also globules. Drs. Howard L. Bachrach and Carleton E. Schwerdt of Dr. Wendell M. Stanley's laboratory in the University of California have resolved all doubt.

AS a war waged by a coalition draws to its end political aspects have a mounting importance. In Washington especially longer and wider views should have prevailed. It is true that American thought is at least disinterested in matters which seem to relate to territorial acquisitions, but when wolves are about the shepherd must guard his flock, even if he does not himself care for mutton.

Dividends paid to United States policyholders by life insurance companies may reach a record $850,0000,000 in 1953, the Institute of Life Insurance announced yesterday. Such a total would be nearly $85,000,000 more than policy dividend payments in 1952, an increase of 11 per cent over last year's $765,921,000.

SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 12--On the theory that the best way to prevent communism is to give the people something more attractive, the Government of President Oscar Osorio is pushing forward with a bloodless social revolution to develop a middle class in El Salvador.

Former President Harry S. Truman called on Americans last night to preserve their freedom against "onslaughts by demagogues" and against fear and hysteria "being manipulated in this country today purely for political purposes."
HONOLULU, Nov. 12 -- The eleven airlines operating on the North Atlantic route have unanimously agreed to preserve the present scheduled air cargo rates until next April 1.

GREENSBURG, Pa., Nov. 12 (AP) -- An automobile careened off the Pennsylvania Turnpike into the side of a restaurant at the new Stanton interchange near this community today, killing Rabbi Lazars Veiler, 57 years old, of Brooklyn, N. Y., and injuring his wife, Rosa, and the driver of the auto.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country on the Harry Dexter White controversy, as gathered by The New York Times:

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer said in a statement published here today that "any withdrawal of American troops in Europe would be viewed from the Russian side as a success for their policies."

STEP inside 2 Broadway at Bowling Green and you go deep into yesterday. There are eleven hydraulic elevators operated by steel-cable hand-pulls, cherry wood finish all about, soaring ceilings, Kidderminster carpeting in gloomy executive chambers and ancient portraits and marble busts of former presidents and of founders of the New York Produce Exchange, which had the place built almost seventy years ago as the last word in urban architecture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Commission on Foreign Economic Policy has completed its research staff with the appointment of seven economists who will specialize in designated fields. Four others were named recently.
For the second time in the last few weeks, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway stressed on Tuesday in a public speech the dominant role of the foot soldier in war.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- West Berlin's coalition Government, which has confronted the surrounding Communists with a united front since the split in 1948, fell apart tonight.
OTTAWA, Nov. 12 -- Opening Canada's twenty-second Parliament, Governor General Vincent Massey said today that world peace was still too far removed to allow Canada to relax her defense effort.

Today's installment of the Churchill Memoirs comes with startling aptness in this period when we are arguing about the attitude of American officials toward Russia in the halcyon days of friendship. Sir Winston makes a charge whose implications are weighty, considering his position and the proof that he can offer that he saw Russia as the next enemy at a time when Washington officials were either indifferent or uncomprehending.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 12 -- Brazil is reported considering offers for trade with Iron Curtain countries, including the Soviet Union, and possibly a renewal of diplomatic relations regardless of what the United States may think about it.

ABOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Nov. 12 -- President Eisenhower was en route tonight on a goodwill visit to Ottawa. Before leaving, he announced the formation of two joint agencies designed to strengthen the ties between the United States and Canada.
The American Civil Liberties Union criticized the House Un-American Activities Committee yesterday for sending subpoenas to former President Truman and others.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Conservatives retained their parliamentary seat for Crosby, Lancashire, in a by-election today, the vote indicating virtually no change in the political climate since 1951.
Directors of the United States Gypsum Company voted an extra dividend of $1.50 a share and a quarterly dividend of $1 a share on the common stock yesterday, both payable on Dec. 14.

Evidence that Italian craftsmen still produce fresh and original designs for the home is apparent in a small collection of objects that recently arrived from Italy and is now on display at Lord Taylor. Among the accessories on view are objects made of brass, wood and pottery.

Dr. Jonas E. Salk, the discoverer of an anti-polio vaccine to be given next year to at least 500,000 American children, offered yesterday to assume "personal responsibility" for the safety of the inoculation.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 13 -- United Nations and Communist diplomatic representatives will resume full-scale talks at Panmunjom tomorrow in an effort to lay the groundwork for a Korean political conference. The sessions have been in recess a week while staff advisers from the wto sides met to try to arrange the agenda for the talks.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- The Republican State Executive Committee voted unanimously today to support Governor Dewey's demand for the ouster of Senator Arthur H. Wicks as Majority Leader and President Pro Tem of the State Senate. His offices make him the Lieutenant Governor, in effect.
Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan and other Police and Correction Department ofcials visited yesterday a toyland hideaway that would make the eyes of every youngster in town bulge with envy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has called off construction of an explosives processing and assembly plant on the Spoon River, eighteen miles east of Macomb, Ill. The cost of the project had been estimated at $26,000,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Following are excerpts from a statement made before the Security Council today by Abba S. Eban, Israeli representative, and an outline issued by Dr. Charles Malik, representative of Lebanon, as the substance of his remarks:

OKINAWA, Friday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Manager Leo Durocher and a former pitching star, Fred Fitzsimmons, came out of playing retirement long enough yesterday to take the field for one inning during a 16-0 pasting the barnstorming New York Giants handed the Okinawa interservice All-Stars.

The autumn fiesta for the benefit of the home and foreign missions will be held next Thursday afternoon and evening in the church house of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street.

The Silver Star Medal was presented posthumously yesterday to Pfc. Murray Lichtman of Jamaica, Queens, for outstanding gallantry in Korea. Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, First Army commander, gave the medal to the hero's mother, Mrs. Anna Lichtman of 150-07 Eighty-eighth Avenue, Jamaica, at a ceremony on Governors Island.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will propose a complete overhaul of the set-up of the United Nations staff, including elimination of the rank of Assistant Secretary General.

The Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., is concentrating on cutting its operating costs, Allan A. Ryan, chairman of the concern, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting here. The cost of manufacturing and selling has risen much faster than have the prices that it was thought the market could bear, he explained.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 12 -- Adlai E. Stevenson told 1,000 Young Democrats here today that the Republicans would lose next fall's Congressional elections because the people had had their fill of "slick talk and foolish promises."

NEARLY eight years ago when "Over to You: Ten Stories of Flyers and Flying" was published it was apparent to the lucky few who read it that its author, Roald Dahl, was an extraordinarily promising young writer. An Englishman of Norwegian parentage, he had fought in the Royal Air Force. He wrote about pilots and war in the air with emotional sensitivity and dramatic power.

It is certainly to be hoped that the city has overcome the worst hurdles in the path of constructing the $20,000,000 Coliseum planned for Columbus Circle. It is now up to all interested parties to buckle down and give Robert Moses all the support he needs in pushing aside any new barriers he may encounter in making this long- needed improvement a reality.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A maximum advance in soybeans was the signal for active buying in the grain pits here today. Substantial upturns were registered in both corn and wheat, with the gains smaller in rye and oats.

A banking syndicate headed by Blair, Rollins Co., Inc., and Cohu Co. are offering a new issue of 100,000 shares of $10 par value convertible preferred stock of Eastern Industries, Inc. The company manufactures traffic control equipment, pumps and mixing equipment used in the chemical, petroleum and other industries.

The inability of top-grade bonds to maintain the price levels touched at the peak of the recent rise in Treasury securities seems to be intensifying a slowdown both in the mood and the pace of market activity. The Armistice Day holiday falling in midweek accentuated the lull.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The recent rise in stock market prices tailed off today. Profit-taking eliminated the gains made in the morning and most markets closed with small losses.
A new concept of blending synthetic textile yarns has been developed.

The sweet potato harvest this year presents a bright picture far consumers, with the yield estimated at 21 per cent above the small crop in 1952. Arriving in good supply from New Jersey, as well as the South, "sweets" are now very reasonable in price-- about 10 cents a pound or 3 to 4 cents a serving.

JEAN CARROLL, the sardonic impressionist, is essaying a situation comedy on Wednesday evenings at 9 o'clock over the A. B. C. network. The show has the germ of a serviceable, if familiar, idea but at the moment suffers from lamentable execution.

Another step in the affiliation of the Hospital for Special Surgery with the New York Hospital was announced yesterday. Samuel S. Duryee, president of the New York Society for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled, which maintains the Hospital for Special Surgery, has been elected a trustee of the Society of the New York Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--During the week ended Nov. 11, member bank reserves decreased $149,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Aluminium, Ltd., large Canadian aluminium producer, reported lower net earnings for the first nine months this year despite higher sales. It said a sharp increase in capital cost allowances had contributed to the profit decline.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Kid Gavilan, the whirlwind puncher from Camaguey, Cuba, is set to defend his welterweight championship of the world tomorrow night. He will risk the crown against Johnny Bratton of this city in a fifteen-round contest at the Chicago Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The Justice Department denounced as "nonsense" today the contention of Owen Lattimore that he had been indicted on perjury charges because of his political beliefs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The United Mine Workers said today that former President Truman "was and is a loyal American" and decried Republican efforts to "rake over the ashes" of his Administration.

The Dixie Cup Company, manufacturer of paper cups and containers, is offering to holders of its common stock 152,465 new shares of $50 par value convertible preferred stock for subscription until Nov. 30 at $50 a share. A syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Hornblower Weeks is underwriting the transaction.

The Elinor Morgenthau New Dramatists Workshop will begin its third season tonight and tomorrow night with showings of Henry Misrock's "God Had Seven Days." Plays will be given this year for the first time in the American Academy Theatre, formerly the Anta Playhouse.

A policy-holder in the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States began a Supreme Court action yesterday to compel the state to take corrective steps against alleged legal violations by the company.

Although seven years have gone by since Jose Ferrer first appeared in "Cyrano de Bergerac," it seems like yesterday at the City Center where he is playing the part again. The romantic Rostand swashbuckler is one of the grand theatre pieces, and Brian Hookers version carries the gasconnading flavor of Rostand over into the English language.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee closed its twelfth plenary session today apparently as far from a meeting of minds on a global cotton agreement as it was when the parley began on Nov. 2.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The National Production rate during the third quarter of this year was slightly lower than in the second quarter, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WOOD-RIDGE, N. J., Nov. 12 -- Curtiss-Wright Corporation is building its huge turbo-compound engines here on an "automated" assembly line that lets human fingers touch the product about as seldom as in the case of packaged breakfast food.

Following are the texts of the two questions addressed to Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina by the Senate Internal Security Committee Wednesday and of Governor Byrnes' reply to them yesterday as supplied by The United Press:
Beginning this morning and continuing past midnight on Saturday, the fiftieth anniversary of the American Power Boat Association will be celebrated at the Hotel Roosevelt.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Dr. Manuel V. Ordonez, attorney for the newspaper La Prensa, was released today after two months in police detention, his associates said.

MADRID, Nov. 12 -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, said today the North Atlantic treaty powers had made "amazing progress" since his last visit to Western Europe and Mediterranean bases eighteen months ago.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Jimmie Dykes knowingly put himself on the spot today as first manager of the Baltimore Orioles by declaring "I don't think we need much help to make a real contender."

Three trucking industry representatives met for an hour and thirty-five minutes yesterday with Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley to talk over the "no standing" rule to be enforced on five major cross-town streets on Dec. 1.
A special call of all pending personal injury and death actions on the Trial Term calendar of the Brooklyn Supreme Court will be held Monday in an effort to relieve the court's congested calendar.

Last season the Knickerbockers defeated the Warriors in all ten games between the clubs. Last night the New Yorkers proved they are still the masters of the Philadelphians when they conquered what was supposed to be a vastly improved Quaker City team. The score was 81 -- 65.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 12 -- Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. announced today that he was appointing his long-time friend, Adrian P. Burke, as Corporation Counsel.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 12--The Iranian security forces, with clubs, gun butts and scattered shots, today smashed a well planned major effort by the Communists and extreme nationalists to challenge the Government.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Lagging payments to the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency have compelled the agency to reduce its 1954 program for helping restore Korea's economy, Lieut. Gen. John B. Coulter, the agent general, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives bowed tonight to former President Truman's refusal to testify before it. No effort will be made to enforce the history-making subpoena the committee served on an ex-President and no motion will be made to cite him for contempt of Congress.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Following are the texts of a resolution unanimously approved today by the Republican State Executive Committee dealing with the attempt to oust Senator Arthur H. Wicks as Majority Leader and President Pro Tem and a reply by Senator Wicks.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Gen. Charles deGaulle violently denounced today United States pressure on France to ratify the European army treaty.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Marty Marion denied today he has a "defeatist attitude," the reason given for his dismissal as manager yesterday by the Baltimore Orioles, and said he hasn't agreed to settle on his contract "for one nickel less than $35,000."

In a letter entitled "Weather Chain Evaluated" which you published on Nov. 4 a group of meteorologists at New York University very properly protested the recent decision to withdraw American ships from the North Atlantic weather ship network of the International Civil Aviation Organization.

PARIS, Nov. 12--Premier Joseph Laniel told the Council of the Republic today that France was not seeking an unconditional surrender of the Communist-led enemy in Indo-China and would be happy to find "an honorable solution" to the conflict.

Two works unknown to the musical public of this city were presented by Mr. Mitropoulos and the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, with John Simms, pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall. These were Philip Bezanson's Concerto for Piano and Orchestra, given its first performance anywhere, and Louis Aubert's Fantasie for the same instruments, composed many years ago, though the program annotator did not tell us exactly when, but heard for the first time in New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration today declared sixteen counties in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts disaster areas as a result of the snowstorm, high winds and tides of last Friday.
Larger net sales but smaller profits were reported by the International Nickel Company of Canada for the nine months ended Sept. 30.

Women headed by Mrs. Averell Harriman are furthering plans for the performance of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" on the night of Dec. 10 at the Martin Beck Theatre for the benefit of the Women's Trade Union League. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is honorary chairman of the benefit committee.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 12 -- Bao Dai, Vietnam's Chief of State, still is in Dalat continuing consultations upon a policy toward France. He has been putting off his interview with nationalist delegates from North Vietnam (Tonkin) and is seeking to avoid acceptance of all the nationalist conditions.

WALTER KOPPISCH never did realize on all his potentials during his four football years at Columbia and death snatched him away last week at the early age of 52, his potentials still unfulfilled. He was a great star on weak teams and the wonder of it was that he was able to attract the attention of Walter Camp as an all-America halfback.

Harry S. Truman's letter to Chairman Harold H. Velde of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, rejecting a subpoena to testify, was read aloud here yesterday by the former President in a setting reminiscent of his historic White House news conferences.

Taking up complaints that some of the trade activities of the fish business here are much too "fishy," inflicting losses running into untallied millions of dollars, New York's Department of Investigation has put out an exploratory net with hopes of a big haul.

PANMUNJON, Friday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The United Nations commander, Gen. John E. Hull, said today he would "absolutely" press for release of all anti-Communist North Korean and Chinese war prisoners by Jan. 22 if the long-delayed Korean peace conference fails to start by that date.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that he was seeking a sound farm program to serve all the people, rather than "patchwork remedies."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The opening session today of the House of Representatives investigation of the Social Security Act was devoted entirely to "the emerging global nature of social security."
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Kenya's 30,000 white settlers called today for strict immigration, land tenure and education laws to maintain British control over the colony.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 -- The church demand for conformity to the ideal that marriage is a lifelong union has often been characterized by an "unrealistic blindness" to marital problems, it was charged today.

Proposed legislation that would bar the city and regional park commissions from enacting highway rules that would conflict with state law was endorsed yesterday by a majority of traffic safety experts.

Recent stories given, to the press on the question of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions and Moral Rearmament are of vital interest in relation to our basic concepts of freedom. The nature and violence of the repeated attacks on Moral Rearmament raise two questions: Who is so concerned? And why?
Stocks gave an inconclusive performance yesterday. The New York Times combined average dipped 0.20 point but more issues rose than fell and seven of the ten most active closed higher on the the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Navy, will leave late this month for a three-week inspection trip to the Far East. Mr. Anderson plans to leave Nov. 28 and return to Washington Dee. 13.

Stormy Atlantic weather has caused higher fish prices this week-end, according to the Consumers Service Bureau of the city Department of Markets. The catch of salt water fish has been light to moderate all along the coast. Several popular fish have advanced in price.
LINDENHURST, L. I., Nov. 12 -- If Adam V. Richter can navigate the legal shoals ahead, fishermen in the Great South Bay area next summer may not have to return to shore to satisfy their appetite.
Stores can expect increased volume in women's apparel for spring but only if they work for it, retailers were told yesterday.
A Sanitation Department worker who played Good Samaritan in a street accident has declined a $15 gift from the man he helped, suggesting that the thank-offering go to the Red Cross instead.
YONKERS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- In a race that saw the lead change several times, Sandy Fingo came on in the stretch to win the Millwood Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Hornblower Weeks, 65-year-old brokerage and investment banking firm, announced yesterday that it was acquiring the business of Scatterty Jones. New York cotton brokers, effective on Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller tonight told the National Council of Negro Women that technical assistance programs in health, education and welfare are helping the free nations build spiritual strength.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Governor General of Pakistan called on President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today as interest mounted in the possibility of a United States-Pakistani defense arrangement.
Navy, with two strong football platoons, will invade Baker Field tomorrow for its game with Columbia.
Harry S. Truman declined yesterday to comply with the subpoena served on Tuesday on behalf of a House committee investigating the Harry Dexter White case.
Senator William F. Knowland said here last night that the Communists should be told they would get no extension of the repatriation talks with Korean war prisoners beyond the Dec. 24 deadline.

" The White Hell of Pitz Palu," a revised version of the 1930 German production directed by G. W. Pabst, will open today at the New York Theatre. Sequences from the silent classic are utilized in the film, and newly produced scenes starring Hans Albers, Liselotte Pulver and Adrian Hoven have been added.

Lieut. Col. James Arthur Reilly, U. S. A. F., retired, who was assigned to the division of Army Air Forces materiel and supply in World War II, died on Wednesday of a heart ailment at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A lack of understanding by insurance underwriters of the specific problems of companies they help protect was described today as the "most serious weakness" of the insurance business.
The High Tide Stable's Full Brother, a 3-year-old Sky Raider gelding, took the mile and a sixteenth allowance race that served as the feature at the Empire-at-Jamaica meeting yesterday.
I respectfully submit that D. A. B. misunderstands the fair-trade laws if he believes, as his letter in The New York Times of Nov. 5 implies, that they are aimed at destroying price competition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--The departure bonds of some 1,500 stateless aliens who came to this country in 1947 and 1948 from Displaced Persons camps in Europe will be canceled under a new policy announced today by the Department of Justice.
Sentimental touches characterize the redecorating of the eight model rooms in the Beacon Hill Galleries now on view at Airman's.
High school students will pay 10 cents instead of 15 for a round trip on the subway and elevated lines beginning Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday were 747,868 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

In accordance with a mandate of the State Constitution a special committee of the Legislature has submitted its recommendations for reapportioning legislative districts among the various sections of the state. These are to be acted upon at a special session of the Legislature which Governor Dewey has called for next week.

HARTFORD, Nov. 12 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors was asked today to set Dec. 10 as the date for a hearing on the state Democratic party's challenge of the constitutionality of the law changing the boundary lines of the state's thirty-six Senate districts.

Your lead editorial agrees with the statement of President Eisenhower that the issuance of the subpoena to Mr. Truman was an obvious abuse of discretion and propriety; that any impugning of Mr. Truman's loyalty and devotion to country is an absurdity. Two columns away you speak of the California election as indicating that there has been no trend to be discerned in the recent voting.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Israel's "crippling short - term indebtedness" can be met only "with increased support from American Jews," David Ben-Gurion, Israel's outgoing Prime Minister, warned in a cabled message here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Two actions to promote food labeling of aid to the several million people in this country on low-salt diets because of high blood pressure or some types of heart disease were announced today by the Food and Drug Administration.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Nov. 14 -- The chief United Nations and Communist diplomats, here to arrange a Korean peace conference, settled their agenda today.

A four-story junior high school at 330 East Twenty-first Street and a ten-story apartment house for 103 families at the southeast corner of Sixteenth Street and the Avenue of the Americas were among plans for new buildings and alterations filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Commerce Department will submit to Congress recommendations for charging fees for use of the Federal airways.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- An independent committee of nationally known scientists reported today that AD-X2 was without merit as a battery additive.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Corporate insurance buyers were advised today to apply the same yardsticks in buying insurance that financial institutions use in buying capital stock.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Although its majority was reduced by almost a third, the Conservative party held on to a second parliamentary seat in a by-election in the north of England today.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 13 -- A ballet team that escaped from behind the Iron Curtain by taking a subway ride in Berlin arrived here today aboard the Holland-America Line's flagship, the Nieuw Amsterdam.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 13 -- Officials of the Vietnamese Government were outwardly worried today about French Premier Joseph Laniel's statement that France would welcome a diplomatic end to the fighting in Indo-China and would not necessarily seek unconditional surrender.

The Randolph Trading Corporation, operators, purchased the fifty-three-family apartment house at 1900 Belmont Avenue, the Bronx, from clients of Abraham Alpert, lawyer. It was sold for cash over mortgages totaling $157,500. Rubin Nason and Murray Adler were the brokers in the sale and title insurance was furnished by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The price of milk to consumers in the metropolitan area may be reduced by one-half cent a quart in December, according to a plan evolved yesterday by Dr. Charles J. Blanford, Milk Marketing Administrator.

Testimony by former Corporation Counsel John P. McGrath and his client, Mrs. Mabel Satterlee Ingalls, was barred yesterday at the trial of Frank Smith, accused of shooting Sol A. Rosenblatt, lawyer, on March 6, 1952.

The local office of the New York State Extension Service in Marketing alerts us to the fact that we have entered the period of "pork bargains." The meat so associated with the sauerkraut, applesauce and sweet potatoes of fall is usually cheapest from November to February.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and prices declined 4 to 10 points.

OTTAWA, Nov. 13 -- Making his first state visit to a foreign capital since his inauguration, President Eisenhower, with Mrs. Eisenhower, received a warm official welcome and an enthusiastic popular one when he arrived here this morning from Washington.
ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- While uniform rules of the road are desirable, enforcement is the master key to highway safety, a legislative committee was told today.

Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers have engaged three well-known theatre personalities for their next venture, "Dear Charles," the Alan Melville adaptation of the Marc-Gilbert Sauvajon comedy, "Les Enfants d'Edouard."

The Times Square area, which once New Yorkers could be proud of and pleased to show to millions of tourists annually, has become to an unfortunate degree a garish jungle of flea circuses and penny arcades, tin-horn auctions and open-front "novelty" bazaars, shooting galleries and junky gift shops.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Average primary market prices registered no change in the week ended Nov. 10, and remained at 109.9 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A fractional increase in average prices for farm products was offset by a small decline in average prices for processed foods; all commodities other than farm products and processed foods showed no change again this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Following is the text of Associate Justice Tom C. Clark's letter to Representative Velde refusing to honor a subpoena by the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives:
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Blame for dumping oil off Fort Lauderdale, Fla., last February has been placed on four crewmen of a tanker operating out of Philadelphia.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 13 -- Cornell arrived at Hanover this afternoon and worked out on Memorial Field in preparation for its clash with Dartmouth tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The United Mine Workers of America demanded today that Clarence B. Randall be removed as chairman of the Commission on Foreign Economic Policy.

Shipments of refined copper to domestic consumers last month were the largest since June. But mine production rose sharply and stocks of refined metal in the hands of producers increased to its greatest tonnage since early 1950.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 13 -- Industry is beginning to realize that it wants more in a college graduate than the "infallibility of a mechanical man," Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Pennsylvania State College, asserted here today.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The economic and the military security of the nation depends upon what happens to the American farmer, Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, told the eighty-seventh annual convention of the National Grange today.

Roy Campanella, the picture of health and athletic fitness, called on Vice President Buzzie Bavasi at the Dodgers' offices in Brooklyn yesterday and, among other things, reported enthusiastically on Don Newcombe and Joe Black.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Archivists here are examining a new batch of controversial and occasionally libelous letters written by Thomas Henry Huxley, the great nineteenth-century biologist and defender of the Darwinian theory of evolution.

A one-story factory occupied as a garage and automobile repair shop in Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by Anthony Prudenti and Joseph Pirrello from Dominico Saponaro. The building is on the north side of Fiftieth Avenue, 250 feet east of Fifth Avenue, and runs through to the south side of Forty-ninth Avenue.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Princeton University's varsity basketball team will play twenty-four games against sixteen opponents this winter, it was disclosed today by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- An official of the European Coal and Steel Community said today it would act to annul private agreements to fix prices of steel products exported from the community if the agreements were not abandoned.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Reports that the Government is sounding out industry on the opening of limited trade with Communist China were repeated today by a Chrysler Corporation executive.

MANILA, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The New York Giants arrived by air today from Okinawa for a two- game series here. The major leaguers are slated to meet tomorrow night an Oriental team composed of stars from the visiting Mainichi Orions and a local selection.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said today at a news conference that although some "support" troops were being gradually recalled from Europe there would be no change in the combat strength in that area.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 13 -- One of the most even Yale-Princeton games in their 80-year football rivalry is forecast for tomorrow, with the twice-beaten Tigers seeking to clinch their seventh straight Big Three championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The reasons for keeping secret the Federal Bureau of Investigation reports on the late Harry Dexter White are expected to be explained by the Attorney General when he testifies Tuesday before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today withdrew a previously announced requirement that farmers must be in compliance with all basic, acreage allotments for their farms to be eligible for price support on any one basic commodity.

J. Russel Sprague resigned yesterday as Republican National Committeeman from New York, a post he had held since 1940. He explained he was doing so because of attacks upon him for his ownership of stock in the racket-ridden Yonkers Raceway.
Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "Sabrina Fair" on Monday night at the National Theatre for the benefit of the West Side Day Nursery.

NEWARK, Nov. 13 -- Officials of the Hospital Service Plan of New Jersey (Blue Cross) and representatives of four Roman Catholic dioceses in the state will meet here Monday to discuss differences over the organization's newly proposed agreement with hospitals.
FARMINGDALE, N. J., Nov. 13 -- A modest Buddhist temple set up in the scrub pine lands of this rural section by a band of refugee Kalmuk Russians observed today its first anniversary.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazil's man of the hour in efforts to clear up her chaotic economic situation, declared today Brazil wanted neither loans nor investments from abroad.

A small, wiry window cleaner was thwarted yesterday in his attempt to escape with a $2,900 payroll. Before he was subdued, he had smashed a police radio car, sent two policemen to the hospital and slashed a passer-by who assisted in his capture.

Rolande Young, pianist, made her debut in recital at Town Hall last evening. A native of Washington, Miss Young began her piano studies with her mother, later attending the Manhattan School of Music and the Juilliard Institute of Musical Art.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 13 -- The story of "Robin Hood" was under attack today by a member of Indiana's Textbook Commission, who demanded that the tale be removed from school books because it promoted Communist doctrine.

SANTA FE, N. M., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, told New Mexico ranch and farm representatives today his drought program was aimed at saving the foundation herds of established producers, but not necessarily those "of the speculators.''
Joseph P. Ryan, president of the old International Longshoremen's Association, was accused yesterday of stealing $45,000 in union funds over a seven-year period.
Commodity prices moved irregularly lower yesterday on the New York Exchanges.

The substitution of large numbers of atomic and hydrogen weapons for armed men on the ground and fighting ships at sea would represent at present an increased risk that could not be accurately calculated.
DAKAR, French West Africa, Nov. 6 -- The divergent colonial policies of Britain and France in West Africa are expected to make international cooperation increasingly difficult south of the Sahara.
PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Premier Joseph Laniel was asked tonight to promise that the French Government would accept no commitments at the coming international conferences at The Hague and Bermuda.

I was shocked to read the speech and subsequent statements of Attorney General Brownell. While it has been obvious that we have irresponsible elements in our legislative branch, it has been my sincere hope that the Administration would abate rather than inflame the hysteria these men have caused.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The stock markets ended the week on a satisfactory note today. Profit-taking was well absorbed and the undertone of all markets was described as firm, though price movements were irregular and mostly small.
Science can have a large role in providing a foundation for the future prosperity of the textile industry, it was brought out at the Textile Research Institute yesterday.

J. Russel Sprague, whose resignation as Republican National Committeeman from Nassau County was announced yesterday, was regarded as one of the ablest and most efficient political leaders in New York State.

The purpose of issuing a Congressional subpoena to Mr. Truman comes down to this: The record seems to indicate that there was gross carelessness in the consecutive appointments of Mr. White; these appointments were made by Mr. Truman, and according to the data of the F. B. I. and to Mr. Byrnes' public statement, Mr. Truman had been duly informed beforehand of Mr. White's espionage activities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Kid Gavilan breezed right through Johnny Bratton of this city in their fifteen- round contest for the former's welterweight championship of the world. Although he failed to floor the challenger, the tireless Cuban did just about everything else to gain the unanimous decision in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee predicted yesterday the Communists would "come to terms" on Korea if the Allies stood firm, but he left in doubt whether he expected a settlement peacefully or by force.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 13 -- The Western Big Three were reported to have made today a counter-proposal to a Yugoslav suggestion that a meeting be held to determine whether conferences on the Trieste issue were possible.

The Stockholders' Committee for Puget Sound Power and Light Company will not abandon its efforts to bring about a merger with Washington Water Power. Directors of the Puget Sound system on Thursday decided not to extend the termination date of the merger agreement beyond Nov. 19.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 13 -- The United States military mission has been told by local authorities that Denmark wishes to get a fair share of the vast construction work that is to be done at airbases and weather stations in Greenland. The bulk of it so far has been awarded United States contractors.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of wrecking the Korean peace talks and urged the United Nations General Assembly to intervene.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT died suddenly on Thursday, April 12, [1945] at Warm Springs, Georgia. He was sixty-three. In the afternoon, while he was having his portrait painted, he suddenly collapsed, and died a few hours later without regaining consciousness.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 13 - Mrs. Homer Lichtenwalter of Baltusrol was re-elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the annual meeting today at the Montclair Golf Club.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The sale of Lady Esther, Ltd., Chicago cosmetic producer, to Chesapeake Industries, Inc., New York holding company, for $3,275,000 was approved today by Judge William S. Ellis in Probate Court here.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 13 -- In an effort to avoid a serious intra-party dispute, leaders of the Young Democrats decided today to sidestep a decision on two rival delegates from Texas.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Brown University's team, held scoreless only by Yale, rules a slight favorite over Harvard's injury-weakened forces at Harvard Stadium tomorrow. The Crimson holds a 41-9 edge in the series, with one game ending in a tie.

The Pure Oil Company reported yesterday for the nine months to Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $18,518,000, or $4.14 a common share after preferred dividend requirements. This compares with $20,195,000, or $4.56 a common share, in the similar period of 1952.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics increased to 87.2 on Thursday from 86.9 on Tuesday. The figure for Nov. 20, 1952, was 191.1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -Transamerica Corporation today asked the Supreme Court to refuse a hearing -- to the Federal Reserve Board, which lost in a lower court its efforts to break up the banking chain as tending to become a monopoly.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The board of trustees of Syracuse University today approved the recommendation of a faculty committee to retain an associate professor who had invoked the Fifth Amendment when asked by a Congressional committee if he ever had been a member of the Communist party.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold asked the United Nations General Assembly today to approve a staff reorganization plan that he said would lead to increased efficiency.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 13 -Prospects are bright for the continuance of a high level of housing production in this country next year, Miles L. Colean, housing economist and consultant, told the Mortgage Bankers Association of America today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- House investigators said today that a Columbus, Ohio, concern plied Navy inspectors with gifts and drinking parties and then cheated them on lucrative contracts for Navy wiping rags.
A former Treasury Department official reported in a magazine article published in March, 1947, that President Eisenhower and Harry Dexter White had met in England in 1944.

Civic leaders and former associates of the late Clifford Milburn Holland, chief engineer of the Holland Tunnel, joined yesterday in paying tribute to his memory. The tube was opened twenty-six years ago yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Evaristo Sourdiz, Foreign Minister of Colombia, arrived today to put the issue of political asylum and the case of Victor Raul Haya de la Torre before the Inter-American Peace Committee of the Organization of American States.

Three of America's most expert teen-age doll makers will arrive here today for a four-day holiday. They are the winners of the national finals of Seventeen Magazine's Save the Children Federation Christmas Doll Contest.

TORONTO, Nov. 13 (Canadian Press) -- The United States won tonight's international jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair with clean performances by Paleface and Reno Kirk, ridden by Arthur McCashin and Mrs. Carol Durand.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 -- A joint conference of representatives of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., Presbyterian Church in the U. S. and the United Presbyterian Church of North America approved a plan of union here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- A University of Pennsylvania team that has been getting stronger as the season grows older takes on an up-and-down Army eleven before a crowd of 45,000 at Franklin Field tomorrow.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 13 -- An Army spokesman said that an Israeli guard reported abducted by Jordanians yesterday had been found dead today with seven bullet wounds in the back.

Every American who places above partisan politics the interest of his country and the inevitable success of the democratic forces of the world in behalf of orderly social and economic progress will share with you the displeasure reflected in your editorial "The Case of H. D. White," which appeared in your great paper on Oct. 10.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has been under twenty-four-hour police protection for the last few days, it was learned today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia entered the quarter-finals of the New South Wales tennis championships today by whipping Don Candy of Australia, 10 -- 8, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Eleven 2-year-old fillies will take a crack here tomorrow at $44,910, the most money ever available to the winner of the Selima Stakes in twenty-eight runnings.

What WATV (Channel 13) calls its first official telecast from atop the Empire State Building will occur tonight. From 9 P. M. until 1 P. M. tomorrow it will present a continuous all-star program in an effort to raise funds for the Lighthouse for the Blind.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Frederick M. Raubinger, New Jersey Commissioner of Education, said here tonight the No. 1 problem facing the state's public schools "is that the demand for qualified teachers far exceeds the supply."

BONN, West Germany, Nov. 13 -- Prof. Ludwig Erhard, West Germany's economics minister, who is soon going to the United States, suggested today that "bridges should be built" between the European Payments Union and the dollar market.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Papers of the late Harry Dexter White on file here show that he kept pressing inside the Roosevelt Administration for Soviet-American agreement as critical for peace.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Resort Airlines, Miami, announced today its withdrawal from the northern and midwestern travel field in order to concentrate on its Caribbean air cruises.

An additional class for cerebral-palsied children -- the fifth in the city -- and forty beds allocated for the severely afflicted in a city hospital still to be opened were among new services reported at the United Cerebral Palsy convention yesterday.

The Administration intends to reappraise and "tailor" functions of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of the Department, said yesterday. She said no vital services would be eliminated.
VIENNA, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Karl Gruber has resigned as Austria's Foreign Minister.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Jimmy Carruthers, the undefeated world bantamweight champion from Australia, easily outpointed Henry (Pappy) Gault of Spartanburg, S. C., in a fifteen- round title bout before about 35,000 fans tonight at the Sydney Sports Ground.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The United States offered a pledge of up to $14,750,000 today for the 1954 technical assistance program of the United Nations and its related agencies.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden accused the Egyptian Government today of spending large sums to influence the elections in the Sudan.

Steel and amusement issues led a stock market that pushed forward vigorously toward the close yesterday after floundering for much of the session. Volume, which went to 1,540,000 shares -- the best of the week -- was heaviest when prices were strongest.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Ernest Cuneo, New York lawyer who is president of the North American Newspaper Alliance, today urged New Jersey newspaper executives to "fight like tigers" against the suppression of news.
Columbia's football team, which has exceeded expectations in winning three of seven games, draws a formidable foe today. Lou Little's Lions will oppose Navy's powerful eleven at Baker Field.
YONKERS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Signal P. Direct, driven by Nick Laraia, won the $4,500 Washington Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:06 2/5.

A group of New York shipping men presented a medal yesterday to Vice Admiral Turner C. Joy for the way he bore himself as the ranking American officer and head of the United Nations Delegation at the Panmunjom truce talks.
This is last-chance day for New York horse, players who are trying to get even on the season. And, by the way, does anyone know any horse-park winner-hunter who isn't trying to get even?

Events tonight: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Mischa Elman, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Virtuosi di Roma, Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30; Yiddish Culture Chorus, Malin Studios, 225 West Forty-sixth Street, 8:30; Violin Teachers Guild, Norfleet School, 8:30; "Il Trovatore," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -Latin America's favorable trade balance with the United States set a new record in the first half of this year, the Department of Commerce said today.
During the fifteen months since mid-1952 transactions between the United States and the rest of the world on current account have been roughly in balance.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 13 -- The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church warned today that the American people stand in grave danger of losing a faith and confidence that in earlier days had been the hallmark of their devotion to human rights and liberties.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 -- Harrison B. Williams Jr., newly elected Democratic Representative from New Jersey, charged tonight that a Republican-controlled Congress was threatening "many of the social gains of the last half century."

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- One of the greatest problems in the rearing of handicapped children is "the achievement of a delicate balance of understanding which parents need in determining how much responsibility is appropriate for the age and condition of the child."
PANMUNJOM, Saturday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission was still studying today ways of solving the deadlock in the operations given it under the terms of the armistice.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Trade in soybeans settled down to more normal proportions after the skyrocketing of prices yesterday, and this tended to affect the grain list. Week-end profit-taking in wheat and corn was accelerated by a sharp downturn in rye, presumably because of heavy imports from Canada.

A people living between the earth's widest oceans and two practically invisible land frontiers, and with plenty of room to turn around in, cannot easily understand all the current fuss about boundaries. It's bad enough to have the world cut in two by super-charged barriers that keep the so-called East from meeting the so-called West.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged today that the Soviet Union was bent on sabotaging the work of the International Labor Organization.
HARTFORD, Nov. 13 -- Mrs. Alice K. Leopold, Connecticut's Secretary of State, has been offered the post of Director of the Women's Bureau of the United States Labor Department.
American ship designers can play a major part in keeping the American merchant marine in competition with foreign shipping, two shipbuilding experts told their colleagues yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, agreed today to submit evidence and answer questions Tuesday afternoon before a Senate committee investigating his charges that the Truman Administration in 1946 knowingly promoted a Soviet spy.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, declared tonight that the reduction of international tension was the prime subject for any big power conference and that therefore Communist China must take part if one was held.

A Brooklyn school teacher who was suspended for refusing to answer questions concerning alleged Communist affiliations testified yesterday that he had purged himself subsequently before Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

Three members of the Brothers of the Christian School will be honored at Manhattan College this morning by Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador to the United States; Count Jean de Legarde, French Consul General, and the Most Rev. Joseph P. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, declared today that an Army investigation of the Signal Corps laboratories at Fort Monmouth, N. J., had uncovered no evidence of espionage at this time.

The Quebec Hydro-Electric Commission announced yesterday plans to borrow $50,000,000 in the American market through an issue of debentures maturing in twenty-five years. The issue is to be guaranteed by the Provincial Government.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh rode roughshod over 103 "scofflaws" yesterday. He imposed a record $69,838 in Traffic Court fines, meted out a 300-day workhouse sentence and labeled the errant motorists neurotic "deadbeats" on the "lunatic fringe" in need of psychiatric diagnosis.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 -- The Federal Government will give indispensable financing assistance to the nation's communities in eliminating slums and rehabilitating so-called blighted areas, but will guard against Federal domination and interference, Albert M. Cole, Administrator of the Federal Housing and Home Finance agency, said today.

It is one of the cynical assumptions on which Communists operate that democracy destroys itself by its own excesses. They will be further encouraged in that view by the spectacle in West Berlin, the "island of democracy in a Red sea," where the democratic parties which heretofore have presented a united front against the Communist forces sniping at their half of the city have now split apart in order to fight one another.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives and Representative Clarence E. Kilburn, Republican of upstate New York, today cleared up an error made in the testimony of the late Harry Dexter White before the committee on Aug. 13, 1948.
The New York Rangers, unbeaten in their last three starts, will oppose the Detroit Red Wings, five-time pennant winners in the National Hockey League, at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Following are the texts of J. Russel Sprague's letter to Dean P. Taylor, chairman of the New York State Republican Committee, and of the statement of Lawrence W. McKeown, Nassau County Democratic leader:
In behalf of the Alumni Association of St. Paul's School in Concord, N. H., members of the ladies luncheon committee have arranged their first luncheon for Tuesday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
MIAMI, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The new Florida Racing Commission today deprived Hialeah Park of the right to run two extra days during the middle of the season for the benefit of college scholarship funds.

The human penchant for practical jokes is the subject of a new book by H. Allen Smith. Double-day will publish it next Thursday under the title "The Compleat Practical Joker." Mr. Smith tells of the idiosyncrasy in such personages as Mark Twain, Calvin Coolidge, Lord Chesterfield and the Living Buddha.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:
Tennessee Gas Transmission Company for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 cleared net income of $18,535,546, or $1.62 a common share, it was announced yesterday by Gardiner Symonds, president.

Eight decorators, in as many newly designed rooms to be opened for public inspection next Wednesday, will advance persuasive arguments for the vitality and flexibility that can be achieved in the use of antiques.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -- The motion-picture industry rolled out the red carpet today to welcome King Paul and Queen Frederika and was delighted to discover that the Greek rulers are enthusiastic movie fans. The royal couple made a quick tour of the Paramount studio, where they looked in on the filming of scenes for "White Christmas" and "Sabrina Fair" and chatted with the performers and other studio employes.

BAYONNE, N. J., Nov. 13 -- The rusting hulk of a Navy patrol craft in lower New York Bay is serving as a training spot for one of the Navy's most exacting group of specialists, the underwater demolition experts. The hulk lies midway between tiny Hoffman Island and even smaller Swinburne Island, off South Beach, S. I.
The police sent out an alarm last night for the arrest of Anthony James Palazzola, 26 years old, in the kidnapping of a 13-year-old girl from her East Side home.

Dr. Samuel M. Brownell has become the thirteenth United States Commissioner of Education. Appointed recently by President Eisenhower, Dr. Brownell succeeds the late Dr. Lee M. Thurston. The new Commissioner has had wide experience not only as a school administrator but as a teacher of teachers.

Lafayette High, bidding for its third straight unbeaten season, shares the local school football spotlight today with the Manual vs. Boys High contest, the forty- fifth of a series that began in 1901.

TRENTON, Nov. 13 -- Two hundred representatives of the milk industry and the consumer public in New Jersey met here today to dis cuss the price of milk and the manner in which the profits of the industry were distributed.

President Eisenhower and several Cabinet members will be honor guests at a Washington luncheon to be given Wednesday by the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. The organization's general board will convene Tuesday for a two-day bimonthly session.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 -- An Arab Legion spokesman said tonight that yesterday's shooting incident had begun when a group of thirteen Jews, including eight women, crossed the armistice line near Sharafat to pick olives on Jordanian soil.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 13 -- The Soviet Union is apparently making a drive for closer relations with India through trade and technical assistance. But the Kremlin's prospects do not look bright, in the light of recent history and attitudes here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- With Leopold Stokowski on the podium the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra opened its "season of decision" last night. The typical Stokowski program was repeated this afternoon and is scheduled for a third playing tomorrow night.

ROME, Nov. 13 -- The central directorate of the Christian Democratic party approved today an international conference as a means for reaching a "definite and total solution" of the Trieste problem. It did not insist that the United States and Britain carry out their decision to turn over Zone A of Trieste to Italy as a prerequisite to a conference.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The rare but unbeautiful kiwi that came recently from New Zealand to become the London Zoo's most valuable bird is faring well now. Its custodians fear that the flightless winged creature was "rather unhappy'' on its plane trip here.
