Six Columbia football men played sixty minutes and the Lions achieved their best performance of the season, but their best was not quite good enough to upset Navy yesterday at Baker Field. Three fumbles hurt the home side immeasurably as the midshipmen profited by these miscues and won the exciting contest, 14 -- 6.

NOW that maintenance and planting tasks are reduced to a minimum, various lectures and forums are scheduled throughout the week. At these gatherings, professionals and hobbyists will meet to exchange ideas and discuss new developments in the field of horticulture.

THE power of this taut portrayal of European automobile racing lies in the ability of the Welsh writer, Jon Manchip White, to project tense action in a multitude of small wisps that carry terrific punches. Racing cars, pictured as "small brightly colored toys," go rocketing down "the broad white ribbon of the track," and one of them, "traveling at over a hundred and sixty," slithers "sideways off the road like a boomerang."

ARGOSTOLI, Greece, Nov. 4 - Like ghosts haunting familiar precincts, gaunt folk bereaved and dispirited, still prowl about ruins here. These piles, everywhere to be seen, of fallen masonry and twisted iron were their homes before the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands nearly three months ago.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 14 -- Millions of Long Island potatoes have been stored this fall in huge underground houses to await what the Suffolk County growers hope will be a sharp upswing from the current price, $1.10 a hundred pounds. With yields averaging 320 bushels to the acre and production costs running to $450, every farmer who has the space is putting his potatoes in storage rather than sell now at a loss.
The United States Treasury "found" gold last week -- $1,000,000,000 worth.

After seven weeks of rising prices, the stock market failed to make much progress last week. Undoubtedly the suspension of trading for Armistice Day had some influence for, after easing under mild selling pressure, prices turned firmer near the weekend.
KHARTUM, The Sudan, Nov. 12 -- Political campaigning for control of the Sudan's first Parliament is dominated by a personal struggle between the leaders of two major Moslem sects here.
The traditional family-type farm is disappearing rapidly and is being replaced by large-scale and highly mechanized projects.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 14 -- Texans have been talking like natives of Missouri since the charge by Attorney General Brownell' that former President Truman had knowledge of Harry Dexter White's spying activities for Russia.

Ship arrivals at the port of Baltimore in the first nine months of this year registered an increase of 254 over the same period last year. However, coal and grain export shipments declined, according to comparative figures made public by the Baltimore Association of Commerce.
New York's football Giants return to the Polo Grounds today after a three-week absence to play the Pittsburgh Steelers. The game will start at 2:05 P. M.

Changing conditions affecting American commercial activities throughout the world will be central points of interest for the fortieth National Foreign Trade Convention opening tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

At just about the same time that Andrei Vishinsky was in his harangue at the United Nations to the effect that the United States was blocking any progress toward a Korean political conference there came the first break in the Communist stone wall of obduracy in the preliminary negotiation.

THE territory covered in "The White Ox" is rich in historical importance -- the great water highway from New York to Canada called "the warpath of the nations." Roaming the waters and shores of Lake Champlain in 1777 is a band of Green Mountain boys with young Ezra Button among them. While harassing British fortifications and waylaying men and supplies of the Crown, the patriot-farmers are searching for the scheming Tory Kyle Tucker.
A Brooklyn warehouse manager was held up yesterday morning for the second time in thirteen hours by the same gang of knife-wielding youths.

James Mahoney of Iona was the individual victor and Montclair State Teachers took the team title in the first cross-country championships of the Collegiate Track Conference at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Ten colleges from metropolitan New York and Connecticut competed in the meet.

IN establishing the Division of Philately in the Postoffice Department, Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield has done more for the stamp collecting fraternity than any one else since a philatelic section of the department was started in December, 1921.

DRAWINGS and water-colors comprising the little exhibition at the Delius Gallery entitled "Toulouse-Lautrec and His Circle" represent, with one exception, big men at their lightest and slightest. But though they are faint they are reflections of real, light things.

L. Arnold Weissberger's letter in your section on Nov. 1 mistakenly categorized as "foreign" the works of such major playwrights as Shakespeare, Shaw, Eliot, etc. To do this, is to misunderstand both the nature and the meaning of all that is best in the literature of the theatre.

When an American reads the official reports of the Chinese Republic on Formosa, as well as the unbiased reports by competent observers such as Senator Knowland, he cannot escape a sense of humiliation and shame.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today he planned public hearings "almost immediately" to clear up confusion stemming from two separate investigations of Communist infiltration at the Fort Monmouth, N. J. radar laboratory.

" The Man Who Wouldn't Talk" has finally talked. He is George DuPre, a Canadian World War II intelligence agent whose cloak-and-dagger experiences in France are recounted in a book by that name published Nov. 1 by Random House.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Alger Hiss will get another chance next Saturday at a parole from his five-year prison term.
THERE was a time when listeners to the better radio musical programs could enjoy an hour or more of uninterrupted classics. Not so any longer.

NOW that all the colorful leaves have fallen and many of the bright berries have disappeared, the native hawthorns are an unexpected and welcome sight on the landscape. Some of their berries fall to the ground, making a splash of color at the base of the tree.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 14 -- Michigan State, fighting for a trip to the Rose Bowl, smashed into first place and won at least a share of the Big Ten Conference championship today by grinding out a 14-6 victory over Michigan.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday that the city's traffic court system would be reorganized on Jan. 1. A special unified court will be set up to handle parking summonses on a citywide basis.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Kansas City Star said tonight it could be "revealed on the highest authority" that Mr. Hoover had not approved a plan to keep Mr. White in the Government in hope of trapping a Russian spy ring.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Having overcome objections of the Vatican, three French Cardinals announced today continuation of the mission of the worker-priests.
Concern for long-range personnel needs has led Cleveland retailers to join forces in a city-wide program designed to command the interest of young people still in high school and college.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 14 -- The Norwalk Community Theatre borrowed former President Harry S. Truman's "snollygoster" for its production last night and tonight of Lillian Kellman's play, "Another Part of the Forest."

WITH the house plant season in full swing, foresighted gardeners will take inventory of that all-important horticultural first-aid kit. The house plant supplies in the first-aid cabinet should include a laundry sprinkler, dimite, malathon, an aerosol bomb (make sure it's for plants), nicotine sulfate, DDT (25%), rubbing alcohol, a bar of white soap, absorbent cotton, toothpicks and a spray gun.

IN the Mississippi River delta below New Orleans many Cajuns live by hunting, fishing and trapping as did their French forebears who, driven from Canada, settled there. The Lajoi family are Cajuns. Young Gabee wants to be a good trapper and fisherman, like his father, and to have a cabin cruiser.
Retailers are preparing a new second line of defense in the excise tax fight.

ALL you need to write a Nero Wolfe mystery story is eleven days, if it is to be a novelette, or thirty-eight days, if it is to be a full-length novel. You put down six pages a day, preferably in the afternoon, for that is the more congenial time to work than is the morning.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -- Mrs. Gertrude G. Broderick, radio-television specialist in the United States Office of Education, said here today that the wise use of television would enable the man who spends his daytime hours at a work-bench or a desk to "sit in the quiet and comfort of his living room and get an education."

OTTAWA, Nov. 14 -- President Eisenhower started back to Washington tonight, leaving behind an impression of a man of goodwill who, if Congress permits him, will liberalize trade, share in the building of the St. Lawrence Seaway and cooperate fully with Canada in guarding this hemisphere from surprise atomic attack.

A dispute over "McCarthyism" has led James Burnham, author and critic, to resign as a member of the advisory board of Partisan Review, a bi-monthly literary magazine with a strong anti-Communist slant. The resignation was disclosed in an exchange of letters between Mr. Burnham and the editors in the magazine's current issue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Mr. Mitchell, in his announcement today, disclosed a recommendation by the Advisory Council that employers with "experience" records receive reduced tax rates after one year instead of the present three years.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech to a joint session of the Canadian Commons and Senate at Ottawa yesterday, as transcribed by The New York Times:

Who was Harry Dexter White? The moving spotlight catches a President and a former President of the United States. It lights on Cabinet members past and present, on legislators and business men. But the central figure of today's great political drama is a ghost off in the wings -- the ghost of the man named White, dead five years.

THE melancholy state of window boxes here in the Northeast merely accentuates the flowerless state of the landscape around us. For gone are the petunias, marigolds, geraniums et al. "Still, the outlook for the coming months need not be dreary," says M. E. Lane, Long Island gardener, "if a few evergreen plants are substituted for the flowering kinds."
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- There is no great enthusiasm in France for the Bermuda meeting. The enthusiasm that existed last July, when such a meeting was first proposed has disappeared.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 14 (UP) -- California and Oregon slithered through the mud to a scoreless tie today as two fine lines waged a series of brilliant and successful goal-line stands.

GOING to the hospital for an operation can be a difficult experience for a child. The building is big and confusing; it is filled with many strangers. Everything is different from home, and among all this newness the child must stay alone.

IN this new story about Penny and Pam, the twins have finished high school. Pam, who has always been the assertive one, discovers that Penny has developed a quiet decisiveness which marks a newly adult attitude; it is Penny who carries the day when it comes to a choice of a college for them both.

Less than two decades ago the victims of chronic disease had little hope for improvement, let alone a cure. World War II spurred new types of treatment which are the heart of hospital programs to care for chronic illness.
For several years the better women golfers of New Jersey have been clamoring for tournaments with keener competition. Last week a group of low handicap golfers formed an association for this purpose.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Reports that former President Truman retained Harry Dexter White in Government office as a decoy for surveillance of Soviet spy suspects have set off another round of charges and counter-charges here.

CALL it fate that made Dave Beck president of the nation's biggest and most powerful union at the very moment that a business man's government was taking over in Washington after twenty years of New Deal rule. For the leader of 1,300,000 truck drivers, who is now spearheading the American Federation of Labor drive to bring honest unionism to the crime-shrouded waterfront, is a business man with a union button.

IN recent weeks young boys and girls of the Downtown Community School have been going outside the classroom to pursue their study of American history. Curious about the New York of fifty years ago, the era of the melting pot, they have been calling on old people who lived here then or had just arrived from "the other side."

ALBANY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Representative Dean P. Taylor, Republican state chairman, predicted today that Senator Arthur H. Wicks would be defeated overwhelmingly in the showdown fight over his leadership at the special session of the Legislature Tuesday.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Pa. -- The congestion that for years has made the scenic drive through or near the Delaware Water Gap more of an ordeal than a pleasure is soon to be relieved with the completion of two new toll bridges and a four-mile stretch of four-lane freeway.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Under the personal direction of Governor Dewey, the state Republican party has undertaken a major campaign to recover the prestige it lost in recent months because of the visits made by Acting Lieut. Gov. Arthur H. Wicks to a convicted extortionist in Sing Sing prison and the harness racing scandals.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 14 -- The Long Island State Parkway police are preparing their fourth annual attempt to get pay increases from Albany.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 -- The Monsanto Chemical Company disclosed yesterday that it quit the National Association of Manufacturers because of what it called a trend in the N. A. M. toward reduction of tariffs.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 14 -- Lehigh University scored its seventh straight victory over Carnegie Tech, 26 -- 13, before 7,500 Parents' Day fans today.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 14 (AP) -- The twelfth and most successful meeting of Garden State Park was concluded today, and with it the end of thoroughbred racing in New Jersey for 1953.

WITH the announcement by the Metropolitan Opera of its engagement of Alicia Markova as guest ballerina for several performances during the coming season, a number of interesting items about the ballet and its rumblings and surgings at the opera house have come to light.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Ohio State's Buckeyes, with Quarterback John Borton returning to almost-perfect form, came from behind in the second period today to beat Purdue, 21 -- 6, in a Big Ten game before 77,465 fans.

THE summer before Steve Purcbas* first year at college was indeed an eventful one. He had expected to earn some extra money helping to build a new marine biological labora: tory. He had no idea he would find himself 'becoming a serious student of nartne biology.

The American Women's Unit for War Relief, Inc., will hold its annual bridge party on Wednesday in the Duchesne Residence, 1 East Ninety-first Street. Proceeds will be used by the organization in its work of sending packages of food and clothing to destitute persons in war-torn countries.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 14 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon spent his last full day in Korea in a swift tour of Army and Air Force installations.

NO one need worry about television luring the younger generation from books permanently when there are new stories as good as this one. There isn't a page that doesn't zip along with short brisk sentences and fast doings that keep eyes moving eagerly from chapter to chapter.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Roger Rotroff, Tennessee end who stands only 5 feet 10 inches, playing a position usually marked for big men only, stole the ball from Florida in the opening minutes to set up a touchdown and caught a 54-yard pass in the closing minutes to set up a field goal that gave the favored Volunteers a 9-7 victory today.

ALPHONSE is a French poodle with Gallic dash and wit, Archibald a huge English mastiff, not so deft, but patient and immovably brave. If these characterizations suggest national fundamentals, that obviously is the author's intent.

THE European actress, often more worldly, more subtle, more individual than her American counterpart, has intrigued moviegoers in this country since -- well, possibly 1916 when the moody, melancholy Nazimova began a blazing screen career in "War Brides."
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 14 -- An architectural sphere that may be the forerunner of lighter and cheaper housing is nearing completion here.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- Leaders of major New York affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations threw their weight today into a fight to make Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. the Democratic nominee for Governor in next year's election.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 14 -- Initial reports of Attorney General Brownell's charges concerning ex-President Truman's handling of the Harry Dexter White case found Utahans reacting along straight political lines. At Ogden a railroader who has been a Democrat "since the depression" said, "They lose in New Jersey so they jump on Harry S."

CHILDREN love bear stories, and Inez Hogan tells an interesting one. When the eagle told the American grizzly there were all kinds of bears in the world, the grizzly decided to go and see for himself. Thus starts an Odyssey through different countries and climates, on which the grizzly meets dozens of cousins of all sizes and colors; even some that do not look like bears.

IT takes all kinds to make up the theatre and there is nothing more foolish than to argue the relative importance of the playwright at his typewriter and the actress on her stage. One of the all kinds is little sung, however, although, like the others, he is in there battling also.

THE author of "Those Perplexing Argentines" was United States Ambassador to Argentina for two years, beginning in August, 1947. James Bruce arrived with "no prejudices," he says, and "under instructions" from President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall to be "as friendly as possible with the Argentines."

THE hopeful author of a book for children has to leap so many hurdles he is winded before be composes chapter two. He must placate the child psychologists, who have codified youthful behavior into charts and graphs: he must also win over the juvenile editors who employ child psychologists as consultants.

The Rangers put their modest winning streak of two victories and a tie on the line against the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game last night and lost, 3 -- 2, before the largest hockey crowd of the season in Madison Square Garden.
BOSTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Alert Boston University scored in every period today to gain a 31-19 victory over favored Villanova College before 10,944 fans in Braves Field.

REPUBLICAN National Chairman Leonard W. Hall, looking at the recent election returns, said, "There is no question about it -- as of today we are in trouble politically." The danger flags are flying for the Republican party and they are frankly recognized as such by many Republicans.

SAARBRUECKEN. After all the vicissitudes of the war, the pre-war depression and the Hitler era, the people of the Saar Basin, lying in the battered borderland between France and Germany, are at last approaching normality. There is full employment today in the Saar's rich coal mines and smoking steel mills.

BUFFALO, Nov. 14 -- The right of all accused persons, including those charged with being Communists, to be represented by able counsel was stressed by Judge Irving R. Kaufman at a dinner meeting of the Buffalo Lawyers Club tonight.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 15 -- The Communists' agreement yesterday to discuss the place, composition and time of the Korean peace conference concurrently was regarded here as a minor but clear victory for Arthur H. Dean, special United Nations representative, and his staff.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 14 -- Britain has been placed in an invidious position by the quarrel between her and Northern Rhodesia's 50,000 white settlers over franchise rights of the 2,000,000 Africans in that British-protected territory.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 14 -- After twenty years in the political wilderness the Liberal party of Honduras is heading back to power.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A Japanese Red Cross delegation here negotiating the release of prisoners still held by the Russians was informed officially today that 810 would be prepared for repatriation as soon as the delegation approves and signs a joint communique of its negotiations of the last several weeks with the Soviet Red Cross.
State and Federal legislators called for increased governmental assistance in the fight against cerebral palsy yesterday.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 14 -- Wisconsin spotted Illinois a first-period touchdown, then turned loose a sharp ground attack to down the nation's third ranking football team, 34 -- 7, today. The upset threw the Big Ten Conference race into a three-way scramble.

JUST because we all have the gift of gab does not mean we are endowed with the art of speech. And speech is an art, especially speech for the theatre. Those of us who devote ourselves to this art must continually question and re-evaluate our aims and methods.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 14 -- The Yugoslav Government is thinking of proposing a plebiscite for the city of Trieste, in which the voters would choose between Italian sovereignty and internationalization of the city.

RIP VAN WINKLE in the Korean Mountains? German fairy tales in "The Land of the Morning Calm"? Yes, and the reader will find other stories as familiar -- as well as many that will be freshly new -- in this collection of Korean folk tales.

JAN KAREL, oldest son of a displaced Czechoslovakian family and a violinist, is eager to be an American. Not only is he anxious for his father to take out naturalization papers but he himself wants to take some part in community activities.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The British approach the Bermuda conference in a mood compounded of caution, perplexity and pessimism. Very few people understand why the conference was called and what it is expected to accomplish.

" ONE thing is certain -- this country's in for a recession. And I can tell you, I'm pulling in my oars. Here's one banker who's going to play it on the really safe side; this thing won't catch me overextended.'' * * *

ON May 14, 1804, two young Virginians with a party of forty-three men embarked in a keelboat and two pirogues and started up the Missouri River from St. Louis on a journey which was to last more than two years and take them to the shores of the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today asked dismissal of a law suit attacking its new policy of withholding benefits from unions with officers under indictment on charges of filing false non-Communist oaths.
GAUHATI, India, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- Helicopters are going to be used to search for oil in the flat alluvial plains of the Brahmaputra Valley in India's Assam State.

MANY general-officer memoirs are turning up these days with the accent on world affairs. Brig. Gen. Frank Dorn has chosen to give us something more unusual -- a sort of fork and musket memoir. For the general's military exploits have been balanced by adventures in good cooking.

THE San Francisco Opera Company has named Kurt Herbert Adler artistic director to replace the late Gaetano Merola. With Howard K. Skinner to manage the business end, joint operation of the company is assured.

DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 7 -- A pink-cheeked nun stepped from behind the wheel of a truck today and walked onto the eight-acre site of her newest challenge. Construction workers were rushing the completion of a wing of Sister Mary Benedict's 350 - bed Holy Family Hospital here.

FARGO, N. D., Nov. 14 -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, former president and chancellor of the University of Chicago and since 1949 associate director of the Ford Foundation, declared this week that in his opinion the American people did not believe in education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell announced today a study to determine whether workers got enough from the present scale of unemployment compensation benefits to tide them over jobless periods.

At last week's Cambridge meeting of the National Academy of Sciences, Nobel prize winner Dr. Wendell Stanley, director of the Virus Laboratory of the University of California, reported that Drs. Howard L. Bachrach and Carleton E. Schwerdt of his staff had isolated and identified the virus of human poliomyelitis.

LAST YEAR'S winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature is the author of well over a hundred volumes, among which are six excellent novels. This indifferently translated novel, published in France as "Les Anges Noirs" in 1936, is not one of them.

IT is a considerably more mellow and persuasive Clarence Randall who speaks to us in "Freedom's Faith." His earlier book, "A Creed for Free Enterprise," published to the echo of the name-calling provoked by the great steel strike of 1952, cast him (no doubt to his own surprise ) in the role of a special pleader for a special interest.

SHIRLEY BOOTH wandered back into camera range the other day to start work in the title role of "About Mrs. Leslie" for Hal Wallis, and the boys at Paramount, where his films are made, are still rubbing their eyes with disbelief.
ALBANY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Governor Dewey approved today a budget of $414,800 for the Moreland Act Commission that he appointed on Oct. 8 to investigate harness racing in New York State.

SEND up a flare for "The Undaunted," one of the finest novels of British seamanship and airmanship to come out of the isles in World War II. A story of how all hands went to sea to rescue some airmen afloat in a dinghy under the enemy's guns.

TRENTON, Nov. 14 -- Gov.-elect Robert B. Meyner pledged in his recent campaign to crack down on crime and corruption in New Jersey. There is every reason to believe that he will have ample opportunity to fulfill his promise.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Ullstein Verlag, one of the best known publishing houses on the Continent until it was seized by the Nazis, has re-emerged with renewed vigor. It is operating what is said to be the largest and most modern printing plant in Western Europe.

ALLEN RIVKIN, for twenty years a writer of motion pictures, was thankful for his early training as a reporter when Dore Schary, head of Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer, assigned him to investigate the possibilities for a factual movie dramatization about the "brain washing" techniques used by the Communists on Americans captured in Korea.

ANOTHER contribution to the vast library of Lincolfi books is this distinguished adventure-portrait of the rawboned youth flatboating down to New Orlearm. Based largely on historical facts, it shows Abe at 22 already in possession of the strength, courage of decision and humility he was later to use in directing the fortune of this nat/on.

SPICED with the tang of salt spray and the aromatic smoke of tobacco, Mr. Middleton's history is a work of sound and thorough scholarship that will delight the reader interested in any one of a half dozen aspects of colonial American life.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Plans for a liaison with his constituents, an office where residents may take up directly with him or members of his staff any matters in which they are interested, were announced this week by Representative-elect Harrison A. Williams Jr.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Experts of the Food and Agriculture Organization working in Mexico announced today a plan to rescue from their humiliation Andalusian bulls rejected for appearances before the "aficionados" in the country's better arenas.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- The Pittsburgh Steamship Company has put five of its smallest freighters on the market in the interest of operating economy.
AN alluring and forceful demonstration of what can be done to make the evolution of mathematical thought exciting, Morris Kline's book is the first to deal with mathematics as a cultural subject.

PANSY plants are still brightening my garden on Long Island with two-inch, velvety purple flowers and mats of luxuriant foliage. Tireless after more than six months of almost continuous bloom, and undaunted by the season's first snowstorm these sturdy members of the viola clan are carrying on the die-hard tradition laid down by their wild ancestor, the diminutive johnny-jump-up.

Last week the House of Commons discussed a White Paper on the "Future Organization of the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Project." "Because of our strained resources and the rising cost of power from the sources that have been used hitherto," says the paper, "it is particularly important that we should not be left behind in a race on which our industrial future may depend."

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 14 (UP) -- Texas came from behind with two fourth-period touchdowns to down stubborn Texas Christian 13 -- 3 today before 42,000 fans. The victory enabled Texas to gain sole hold on the Southwest Conference lead.

EVER see a little girl make a doll's dress ? Usually the creation is only a piece of cloth with a hole in the middle and a snip of ribbon for the sash. A basic style, certainly, and lots of fun, but doll dressmaking needn't stop there, now that Emily Dow has come up with a full-fledged guide.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Owing to the increasing number of refugees from satellite countries of the Soviet Union, the Union for Defense of Oppressed Peoples, with headquarters in Paris, has begun a drive to obtain the recognition of exiled governments of these satellite countries as the only legiti mate authority representing these peoples.

THE pageantry of the ancient Olympic Games is the background of this sensitively developed story. Scheduled to compete in the Olympic pentathlon. Nicias of Athens determines also to enter the pancratium -an event combining boxing and wrestling -- where his opponent will be Ajax of Corinth.

THE trouble with the Amazon valley is that to this day at least in Latin America - it has served more as a pretext for adjective-studded anthology pieces than as a subject for serious scientific study. When writing on this rather puzzling region, authors generally lose all sense of proportion.
MANY a youngster of 16 feels that the grass must be greener on the other side of the fence. Like Chicken Little in the childhood fable he yearns to go out and see the world on his own.

ON the Alabama cotton farm where Missie lived, everybody was too busy to answer questions. Even the teacher in the one-room schoolhouse had no time to name the birds or explain half the things Missie wanted to know.

ONE sign that a recessive business tendency exists is an increase in commercial and business failures and the difficulty that creditors are having in collecting their bills. The credit fraternity, however, emphasizes that there is no cause for alarm and available data would seem to bear them out.

THEY say that a courtroom scene never fails on the stage. It isn't true, of course. A bad dramatist can fail with any kind of scene. But it is true that to fail with a trial scene is pretty difficult because a law case is about the only human activity which in real life automatically arranges itself in dramatic form.

As President Eisenhower said yesterday in his address to the Canadian Parliament at Ottawa -- and as this newspaper had said editorially in different words -- the subject of the long unfortified frontier between Canada and the United States "has become shop worn and well-nigh exhausted as a feature of after-dinner oratory."

IN 1952 Harvard unexpectedly and happily chose the distinguished lyrist, painter and unphilosopher E. E. Cummings to give the annual Charles Eliot Norton Lectures in Poetry. Not only is this chair a plum; it is locally regarded as implying the Ineffable Accolade -- and rightly so: whence a great deal of beardsearching and soulpulling when the news transpired.

IN a renewed drive to win passengers from highway and air carriers the Boston and Maine is placing in service tomorrow four more "highliners." These self-propelled Budd Rail-Diesel cars will bring to thirty-eight the number of such cars now in operation on the road.

TRENTON, Nov. 14 -- The chronic traffic law violator in New Jersey is involved in five times as many accidents as the average automobile driver. And his continued disrespect for state, county and municipal highway laws is due to his attitude rather than to his ignorance of regulations.

The breaking of the White case just after Republican losses in the Wisconsin and New Jersey Congressional elections led many Democrats to charge that the Republicans were trying to cover up their defeats. Last week, however, the White case had the effect of overshadowing a Republican victory.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- When a man and his wife start out on a six-month cruise around the world, leaving their two young children with a grandmother, the departure is likely to be a pretty complicated affair.

Professor Hook says: "The relevant provision of the Fifth Amendment is unknown to the legal systems of the Continent." He is mistaken. The statues of almost all, if not all, countries of Europe contain elaborate provisions with respect to this privilege which go far beyond the Fifth Amendment.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 7 -- A bitter controversy has been provoked by Government moves to reduce the British and increase the Afrikaner quality of South Africa's volunteer army.

NO one who has lived in biracial. bi-lingual New Mexico can fail to be impressed with the easy tolerance that exists between the English and Spanish elements in that "land of enchantment." Its political warfare -- and no state has been the scene of more bitter political feuds -- has always been confined quite strictly to party lines, never to racial.

WASHINGTON'S Mount Vernon, as it stands today, the resort of a million and more pilgrims a year, is not only a monument to the Father of His Country and the mirror of his chosen way of life. It is also a memorial to "the patriotism, energy and intelligence of the American woman."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Arab League has publicly offered the United States the choice of either greater friendship and cooperation with the Arab world or the loss of United States strategic bases and economic interests in the Middle East.
DETROIT, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The automobile industry next year will have to depend on salesmanship to keep its production at a high level.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, said today that he was confident the Government would reject any application by a United States company to sell automobiles in Communist China.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- The fifteenth constitutional convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, opening here Monday, will ratify a no-raiding agreement with the American Federation of Labor.

TURNING from his early solidly designed canvases, Vaclav Vytlacil has been developing in the last three or four years a more spirited and spontaneous statement in oil on paper and in gouache. His current show at the Feigl Gallery is devoted to interpretations of the Rocky Mountains and to land and impressions of Martha's Vineyard.
Works by critics of the Eisenhower Administration are among the 200 books that have just been given to the President by the American Booksellers Association for the White House library.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 -- The Republican victory in Tuesday's special election here disrupted a circumstantial jigsaw puzzle that California Democrats had been carefully piecing together to encourage the 1954 political campaign.

ONE thing is proved beyond question about the nature of CinemaScope with its second and milder demonstration in "How to Marry a Millionaire." The giant panel screen is without equal as a surface on which to display the casually recumbent figure of the temptatious Marilyn Monroe.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 14 -- Most people in this area were strong this week in defense of former President Truman and equally vociferous in condemnation of Republicans concerning disclosures in the Harry Dexter White case.

Aided by a grant from the Ford Foundation, seven Southern California colleges have founded an intercollegiate graduate studies program to get under way this fall. This project has been hailed by Pacific Coast educators as the beginning of a new approach in training college teachers and as a pattern for cooperation among groups of private colleges.

THE novel of the American abroad deserves its own category. We are the great travelers of our century, after all -- and the compulsions which have made us so, like most compulsions, reck little of results achieved, either for ourselves or the country we represent.

THE policy of restricted football telecasts may have helped "the gate" at college stadiums but it certainly has made for pretty dull viewing at home on Saturday afternoons. Another season of the drab fare seen this fall and the colleges are going to have to cut their price for the rights to televise games.

WHEN red-haired Michael McGillicuddy had three teeth loosened during a rough game with his four older brothers, his mother decided he must lead a quieter life. He longed for a playmate, but there wasn't even room for a dog in their little Chicago apartment.

Cold weather over much of the nation spurred sales of coats, suits, furs and quilted dusters last week, according to reports from resident buying offices. Woolens with surface effects continued to be favored.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Frederick Mullen, director of information for the Department of Justice, said here today that the new White House order governing the availability of Government information to newspapers corrected the "major criticisms" of the previous Administration's order.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 14 -Emotion and reason waged war in the minds of most Iranians this week as Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, the aged invalid who outraged reason but deeply stirred the nation's emotions during twenty-eight months as Premier, went on trial for rebellion.

THIS lightly romantic story will lift the heart of the quiet girl whose natural reserve seems an added hurdle in growing up. It will comfort those who inwardly despair as other girls with ready tongues make flip rejoinders to the easy banter of the boys they know.

THE work of Taro Yashimo leaves this reviewer with a strong feeling that here is an artist-writer who knows children, respects and loves them deeply. With both words and pastel-and-ink strokes he has captured their simplicity, gaiety and sense of wonder.

REPRODUCTIONS of full color photographs by Edward Weston appear in the December issue of Modern Photography. His picture of a desert-tanned boot against the background of reddish, aged wood best expresses his attitude toward color.

The Chemical Market Research Association and the division of chemical marketing and economics, American Chemical Society, will sponsor a meeting in Washington, D. C., next Wednesday and Thursday to hear Federal officials explain Government policies, services and programs affecting the chemical industry.

An appeal to American shippers to patronize American-flag shipping "in their own long-term interest" was made last week by Francis T. Greene, executive vice president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- A goal by Jimmy Mullen gave the Wolverhampton Wanderers a 1-0 victory over West Bromwich Albion in English League soccer today.

Then Mollie, the farm horse, gave Peter a brand new cocoa-colored colt; but Peter's father explained that Cocoa, the colt, had to "learn to be a horse before he could be cow pony" -- and that might take two years.

OTTAWA, Nov. 14 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who accompanied the President on his state visit to the Canadian capital, had her fifty-seventh birthday here today, but only a few persons were aware of it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A coal cook stove in the kitchen, an old coal furnace in the cellar and a pearly telephone in the master bedroom catch the eye of househunters going through the Victorian home of the late Senator Robert A. Taft.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Robert U. Brown, editor of Editor Publisher magazine, today was elected president of Sigma Delta Chi, journalism fraternity. He succeeds Lee Hills, executive editor of The Detroit Free Press and The Miami Herald.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 14 (AP) -- C. V. Whitney's Small Favor came from out of the pack to win the $25,000-added Selima Stakes at Laurel Park today from Hasty House Farm's Queen Hopeful, the favorite.
An all-Dickens sale Tuesday night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, is one of three auctions scheduled for this week by the art auction concern.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 14 -- More thorough training in oral and written English, broader cultural background and a more effective system of guidance for students were recommended in a report of a study made at Lafayette College through a grant from the Fund for the Advancement of Education.

The damp, chilly gloom that hung over New York and the suburbs all day yesterday was not a threat of another early snowstorm, but merely smog.
The Samaritan Home for the Aged will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Trip to Bountiful" on the night of Dec. 3 at the Henry Miller Theatre.
A lull hung over the baseball fronts yesterday. The forecast is this may continue for another twenty-four hours. But it won't last much longer.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 14 -- Cornell remained unbeaten in the race for Ivy League football honors with a thrilling 28-26 triumph today over a fighting Dartmouth team. While a nearcapacity gathering of 15,000 cheered them on, the Indians responded with a spirited rally after trailing by 21 points in the third period.

THE big news for travelers that came out of the recent convention in Rome of the American Society of Travel Agents was the announcement of a 25 per cent reduction in hotels, meals and transportation fares within Italy to coincide with the winter reduced-fare period of the trans-Atlantic airlines.

MARTHA Washington was a widow when the general married her; Dolly Madison saved a portrait of Washington from the burning White House; Mary Todd Lincoln spent too much money on clothes. There, excluding First Ladies of current memory, is about all most of us know -- or think we know -- of Presidential wives.

The post of deputy commander and chief of staff of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service changed hands last week when Rear Admiral Ralph E. Wilson was relieved by Rear Admiral Neil K. Dietrich.

MARGUERITE VANCE has written teen-age biographies of Lady Jane Grey, Martha Washington and several other historical figures. This time she tells of Andrew Jackson and his Rachel. It is a story of life and danger on the American frontier with Indians, war and politics; but it is also a story of love and domestic happiness and faithfulness.

YONKERS, Nov. 14 -- A record closing-night crowd of 25,576 turned out for the end of the standard-bred sport in the Metropolitan area tonight. Paul Vineyard brought the 17-20 favorite, Volto Man, home a one-and-one-half length winner in the $5,000 Albany pacing feature.

A large subscription has' been reported' for the pre-opening performance of "Escapade" on Tuesday night at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre for the benefit of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service. The benefit had been announced for the night of Nov. 10 but was postponed because of a change in the opening date of the Iproduction.
OTTAWA, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian wheat supplies for the 1952-53 crop year are estimated at 957,000,000 bushels, the Bureau of Statistics said today.

IN his personal formula for successful science fiction C. M. Kornbluth stages a supercharged melodrama against the background of a crazily wonderful future. The world projected in this novel is, by current standards, a completely amoral affair wherein "legitimate" government has long since fled the United States for a pirates' base in British Isles gone Celtic primitive.

WACO, Tex., Nov. 14 (UP) -- The University of Houston beat Baylor, the nation's eighth ranked football team, 37 to 7, today by a formula as old as football itself. Houston's line simply muscled the Baylor line out of the way and the Houston backs darted through the holes.

Dr. John A. Hannah, president of Michigan State College, who is on leave to serve as Assistant Secretary of Defense, has announced a general shakeup in the program of "information and education" for troops. He proposes that the instruction be simplified and that greater stress be laid on the basic tenets of Americanism.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 9 -There is a growing belief that Japan is playing a careful cat-and-mouse game with Southeast Asia by holding out the bait of flourishing trade in return for the restoration of normal diplomatic relations. Japan has yet to make peace with Burma, Indonesia or the Philippines.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 14 -- Midsummer next year will signal the biggest tourist boom St. Petersburg and Florida's west coast have ever known, William Davenport, manager of the St. Petersburg Chamber of Commerce, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- When the story of the Harry Dexter White case is reduced to its factual essentials, and the bludgeonings of partisan politics have produced the final casualty, the lesson of the episode may be a very ancient one. This is, that the careless use of words in the course of any human action inflicts more wounds than the facts that evoked their use.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell's initial statement on the Harry Dexter White case hit the West Coast with much more than a nominal impact. There were mixed wonder, shock, approbation and disbelief.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The bar association of United States judges and lawyers in Germany called today for an investigation of reports that the State Department was secretly recording the jurists' telephone conversations.

ONE of the pleasanter ironies of a century of wars and revolutions is our new esteem for the esthete. KANSAS CITY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Southeast High School students will line up next week for their rewards for good behavior -- slices of football goal posts.

Harrison of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology called attention to a solar-operated stove placed on the market by the Government of India at a cost of $14.

JOCOTEPEC, Mexico -- Mexico's great city of Guadalajara will be the tourist's dream-come-true next month. The first State Fair of Jalisco will be held there on a grand scale, and for once the tourist will find the splendors of a whole region gathered together for him in one place.

MADISON, Wis. -- Nov. 14 -- John W. Tramburg, the Wisconsin State Welfare Director, who has been appointed Federal Commissioner of Social Security, believes that a "social insurance program is the first line of defense against want and that the public assistance program is the second line."
The trail that led to last week's explosions over Harry Dexter White has been twisting through various Government departments for fourteen years.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Few Europeans ever manage to understand United States politics. The few who try are perplexed by the case of Harry Dexter White as it has been revealed in the last few days.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- A seven-year plan, aimed at achieving a "high degree" of self-sufficiency for Israel by 1960 was announced here tonight. It is expected to cost $1,710,000,000, a major part of which is to be raised in the United States.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 14 (UP) -- Oklahoma won its sixth straight outright Big Seven Conference championship and an Orange Bowl berth today by routing hapless Iowa State, 47 -- 0.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Marquette, a pre-game favorite, came up to form today to beat Holy Cross, 13 to 7, in a stubbornly fought game.

The Rudder Club of Brooklyn has elected Charles E. O'Meara commodore, succeeding Capt. Harry J. Parker, chief surveyor, National Cargo Bureau, Inc. Mr. O'Meara, who is superintendent of terminals for the Universal Terminal and Stevedoring Company, will take office Jan. 1 for a one-year term. He served this year as vice commodore.

THE Ballet Theatre, which was not to appear in Manhattan at all this season, has changed its mind and will give a very special benefit performance at the Metropolitan Opera House on Dec. 27. By means of it it will set in motion a drive for $200,000 to finance its fifteenth anniversary season a year from now, with new productions and the restoration of important old ones which have been dropped from the repertoire.

Many tickets have been sold for the performance of "Escapade" on Friday night at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Rudolf Steiner School.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 14 -- Distribution of the expropriated United Fruit Company land is set for tomorrow. Approximately 23,000 peasants will receive an estimated 210,000 acres of the 233,000 seized last February under the Agrarian Reform Law passed last year.

Then Grandmother herself got busy with the grater, and that evening there was boiled beef with horseradish sauce.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 14 -- Delegations representing the liberal wing of the Young Democrats won two victories here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -The National Aeronautics Association tonight named Representative Carl Hinshaw, California Republican, and Dr. Leslie A. Bryan, aviation institute director at the University of Illinois, to receive two of its highest awards.
Trucks equipped with "will o' he wisp" lights that glow and fade are held responsible for spreading death on the New Jersey Turnpike.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Komsomol Pravda, newspaper of the Communist Youth party, declared today the Harry Dexter White case was an attempt by the Eisenhower Administration to "raise a new wave of hysteria in the United States."

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Accused by his two so0ns, Gaston Dominici, 78 year-old farmer of Lurs in Southwestern France, continuned today to deny that he had murdered the Drummond family during the night of Aug. 4, 1952.

IN this well-intentioned novel of virtue triumphant in the tropics, Mary Gray, a most proper young lady from New Zealand, takes a position as governess for six little half-caste French girls on an island in the New Hebrides.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 14 (UP) -- Auburn stole Zeke Bratkowski's passing thunder and turned loose a fleet of speedy backs in the "wide-open spaces" of Georgia's secondary today as the victory- flushed Tigers routed the Bulldogs, 39 to 18, before 26,000 fans.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- Pacific Coast non-agricultural employment reached a new high of 5,263,000 in mid-September, a gain of 44,000 over August. Government employment increased as schools and colleges reopened, seasonal food processing in Oregon and Washington hit peaks, and additional hirings in aircraft production in California and Washington contributed substantially to the higher employment level.

THIS latest of the many recent collections of new writings contains several selections that are so outstanding, and is prefaced by an editorial statement so sound, that one is puzzled to account for the perfunctory quality of many of the poems.
BOLZANO, Italy, Nov. 14 -- The German-speaking people in what they still call the South Tyrol think the ill winds out of Trieste may blow some good up this way.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 14 -- Quarterback Johnny Gramling scored two touchdowns and passed to a third today as South Carolina defeated West Virginia, 20 -- 14, and broke the Mountaineers' winning streak at thirteen games.

STORRS, Conn., Nov. 14 -- Rhode Island counteracted Connecticut's "secret weapon" with one of its own today as the Rams defeated the Huskies, 19 -- 13, with a last- minute pass before a crowd of 12,500.

RECIFE, Brazil, Nov. 14 (AP) - A huge new hydroelectric plant near here, scheduled to begin work next year, is expected to start an industrial boom in Brazil's sleepy northeast region.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Inter-Parliamentary Union has recommended that, as a major step toward world peace, international aid be intensified to raise the living standards of underprivileged countries.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 14 -- Fullback Neil Worden was the main blockbuster of Notre Dame's savage wrecking crew today as the nation's number one college football team crushed North Carolina, 34 -- 14, for its seventh straight victory of the season.

IF you want an easy two-lesson course in precisely how much and in what respects the British thriller -- not the deductive detective story but the mystery-suspense melodrama -- has changed in the past quarter-century, you can have an absorbingly instructive time comparing Edgar Wallace's 1929 THE CRIMSON CIRCLE (Doubleday, $2.50) and Michael Gilbert's 1953 FEAR TO TREAD (Harper, $2.75).

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The refusal of the Russian Government to negotiate with the Western powers on Germany, paramount international issue in Europe, and its extreme reluctance to deviate from sterile propaganda in dealing with the problems of Asia reflect a drastically altered concept of the main problems of the Soviet Union in comparison with the concept that ruled the Soviet Government when it was under the thumb of Joseph Stalin.

THE great forest fire left only bitter ashes and smoldering trees throughout the valley of the muskrat colony and only the one Old Muskrat to make the long journey from the burned-out land. SKILLFUL and moving, this story of girls growing up is, I think, Mary Stolz' most successful one to date. Written for the eager 14 to 16-year-olds, it handles the painful problem of the too-fat heroine with subtlety and some humor.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 14 (UP) -- Gov. George Craig of Indiana said today "it's been a long time since anybody read Robin Hood to me." Mr. Craig, former national commander of the American Legion, declined comment on a charge by one of his appointees that the legendary character's activities in "robbing the rich and giving it to the poor" reflected Communist thinking.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Post Office technicians have developed new equipment that they hope will ease the aching backs of thousands of mail handlers.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Paul Cameron and Pete Dailey ran the Washington Huskies into the mud of Memorial Coliseum today as U. C. L. A. rolled to a 22-6 victory and a tie with Stanford in the close Pacific Coast Conference Rose Bowl race.

Performances of "The Solid Gold Cadillac," with Josephine Hull in the leading role, have been taken over on the nights of Nov. 24 and Dec. 10 at the Belasco Theatre to raise funds for the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House. Mrs. Henry N. Sachs and Mrs. Robert G. Janover are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 14 (UP) -Colorado stopped Nebraska on the one-foot line with a minute to play today to triumph 14 -- 10, in a homecoming game before 36,000 fans.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Harvard, with a whirling dervish, an artful dodger and a couple of Houdinis, defeated Brown today by 27 to 20 and one foot.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- At the week's end the Midwest was viewing the furor that followed Attorney General Brownell's charges as the "great muddle," Die-hard Republicans moved, with the week's developments, from the heights of jubilation over the charges against the last Democratic Administration to disappointment.

The expedition is the spearhead of Louis XIV's campaign to build up the French spice-trade.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Sophomore second-stringers, chiefly Halfback Joe Grier, turned in the key plays to power the University of Pittsburgh to a 40-6 victory over North Carolina State today, handing the Wolfpack its worst trimming of the season and the seventh in eight games.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 14 -- The naval amphibious base at Little Creek, Va., near here, is rapidly being converted from a temporary to a permanent installation. THE adventures of Peter Pan, Pinocchio, Robinson Crusoe, swash-buckling pirates, hooting cowboys and Indians -- all these and more are held out as tempting bait to the reluctant reader by Munro Leaf in his latest book, "Reading Can Be Fun."

Lafayette High finished its third straight unbeaten season by conquering Erasmus Hall, 20 -- 7, at Brooklyn College Field yesterday. It was the twenty-third successive game the Frenchies had played without meeting defeat. Their season record is six victories and a tie by New Dorp.
QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Federal police crushed today three demonstrations protesting Government closure of the independent newspaper El Comercio.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- After killing millions of rabbits in Australia, France and Scandinavia, the artificially propagated rabbit disease has returned by accident to Britain, where the original disease virus was cultured.

THE rapid expansion of housing during the past several years has seen whole communities created on sites that formerly were wooded areas. Houses have been built in areas which had good stands of trees and on sites that were formerly old private estates.

WHAT a gay new dress has been fashioned for the age-old tale of Johnny Cake in Ruth Sawyer's "Journey Cake Ho!" There is nothing of the hackneyed or trite in this quaint, dialectal version of that cake which merrily rolled away from all those greedy people and animals wanting to eat it.

THE story of the exploration and development of California begun because of Father Junipero Serra's dream of converting and civilizing the native Indians, is one of courage, faith in God and stubborn resistance to trial.

NOW that winter is fast approaching, visits from our fine-feathered friends are more noticeable than ever. The cardinal, for example, is the most popular of these boarders at our backyard feeding station. BONN, Germany, Nov. 14 -The United States, Britain and France notified the Soviet Union formally today that as of tomorrow East Germans can enter Western Germany without interzonal passes and residence permits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Herbert A. Bergson, who was Assistant Attorney General and prominent for his anti-trust activities in the Truman Administration, is being investigated by a Federal grand jury under the "conflict of interest" law.

Two grants from the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Republic for the advancement of Columbia University's bicentennial theme, "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof," have been announced by the university. The grants amount to $44,500, and are among the first to be made by the fund.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- The Eisenhower Administration this week reversed a stand taken by the Truman Administration in a four-year hydroelectric power battle.

MARGUERITE HENRY'S stories of horses and ponies are greatly liked by children. Her central character this time is a burro. The story, set in the West, combines adventure, mystery and sentiment, and is, partly at least, based on fact.
Six million truckers -- employers and workers -- will celebrate their industry's fiftieth birthday this week.

A fighting New Orleans storekeeper has pledged his last dollar to what he calls "the battle to guarantee the American housewife a fifth freedom -- freedom to shop."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The Army has quietly removed about 20,000 men -- the equivalent of an infantry division -- from Europe, informed Pentagon sources said today.

THIS " beginning to read" book with its clear, attractive type and bright pictures will be a welcome addition to the few good birthday stories for little children. Moreover, its special appeal lies in its emphasis on a child's growing appreciation of the happiness of others.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 14 -- Denmark's dollar exports have reached a new high. At the same time the outlook for trade with Britain and the Soviet Union is brightening in a most unexpected manner.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Thomas Graham Jr., a Princeton University junior from Louisville, Ky., has received some help from an "old grad" -- Adlai Stevenson -- on a matter of mutual concern.

A young grocery clerk who said he had been spurned in love was rescued last night as he tried to leap off the George Washington Bridge. Before he was brought to safety at 6:35 P. M., the 23-year- old clerk had fought off policemen for an hour along a narrow cable suspended 200 feet above the bridge roadway.

THE twins' bustling farm life takes a troubled turn in this third book of Elisabeth Lansing's about Ted, Sue and their pony, Twinkle. The pony cavorts like an untrained colt and won't be hitched or saddled. Baby Robby toddles gravely off into troubles small and large.

EXCEPTIONALLY fine illustrations, in sepia and soft green, make a memorable background for this story of Arun Krishna, a small boy in a small village in Hindustan. Unlike American children, Arun wears a turban, and has an elephant, Moti, for a friend; like children everywhere, Arun loves to play.

Petrillo, president of the federation, sent a letter to each company mentioning the approaching deadline and making the offer "to meet and confer with you at mutually convenient times and places for the purpose of negotiating a new contract."

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 14 -- Jordan said today she would refuse to consider the Jordan Valley Authority plan advanced here by Eric Johnston. The plan provides for cooperative use of the waters of the Jordan Valley system by Jordan, Syria and Israel.
YONKERS, Nov. 14 -- A group of State Senator William F. Condon's constituents has called for an explanation of his visits to Joseph S. Fay, convicted labor extortionist, in Sing Sing prison.

Sir Winston Churchill, 79 two weeks from tomorrow, has long made plain his desire to cap his majestic career by taking a lead in bringing peace to the world. He has also repeatedly made known his belief that peace could best be achieved in snug conference with the other men at the "summit" of affairs.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The bowler hat and a pair of tight pants have long symbolized the man of affairs in Britain. He wouldn't any more think of wearing a flashy American suit than he would of substituting opium for his morning tea.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Bobby Collins -- taking over for Jackie Parker, injured Southeastern Conference top scorer -- passed and ran Mississippi State to a 26-13 football victory over Louisiana State today.

THE Embassy Newsreel Theatre, Broadway and Seventy-second Street, which has been operating as a newsreel outlet for more than fifteen years, will switch to a first-run feature film policy on Thursday, Nov. 26 (Thanksgiving Day), it was learned last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- After the initial shock residents of this area settled back to await the outcome of the charges and countercharges in the White epicure before passing judgment.

FOR children too much keyed to rocket ship and fire engine, Phyllis Rowand brings breath of quiet in her two little books of home and of country. For those very little ones, "It Is Night" is a lulling bit of casual rhyme and calm pictures for bedtime.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Eisenhower returned to Washington tonight, gratified with the results of his goodwill trip to Ottawa and with Canadian hospitality.
Today starts off the busiest art week so far of the season. It includes among some fifty exhibitions a large number of events of unusual interest in museums and galleries.

Everything but ulcer cures -- ad men do not admit to the alleged occupational disease -- will be in evidence when the second annual Advertising Essentials Show opens today. WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Indian trouble has developed again in the West and this time it was not the Indians but the Great White Father who started it.
James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday he believed it was necessary to have a "continuing investigation" of the milk industry.
PARIS, Nov. 14--France has begun preparing for construction of a new trans-Atlantic liner for service between Havre and New York.

In the somewhat cluttered procession of special days and weeks cited for celebration or observance we always welcome Book Week about this time in November. Not generally heralded by executive proclamations, the festival of books is designed primarily to remind all functionally literate persons that books and the reading of them can be delightful.

The New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday it had filed a brief with the Court of Appeals regarding the trial of Minot F. Jelke, who was convicted of compulsory prostitution. It supported the contention of several newspapers and a press association that General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente had erred in holding the trial behind closed doors.

The late Harold L. Ickes, "the free-wheeling Republican Progressive" who served in the New Deal and Fair Deal Cabinets, kept a secret diary covering the years from 1933 to his death in 1952. He left a 6,000,000-word manuscript, On Dec. 1, Simon Schuster will publish the first volume of a series in "The Secret Diary of Harold L. Ickes."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining indicated today that the nation's top military chiefs hoped to lay before the White House soon their final defense spending proposals for next year.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Three New York sculptors had a tough time here today picking prize winners in an amateur sculpture competition. The contest was part of the twenty-third exhibition of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild, which makes annual awards in four classes.

The James Dawson Memorial Chapel in the new building of the Roman Catholic Sacred Heart Convent at 452 West Fifty - first Street, was opened for public inspection yesterday. The chapel honors James P. Dawson, sports writer of The New York Times, who died suddenly last March while covering the Yankees' spring training in Florida.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored three first-period goals tonight and coasted to a 4-to-1 victory over the New York Rangers to extend their unbeaten string to six straight games.
Jack Butler, a defensive halfback -- and a good one -- for the Pittsburgh Steelers, caught a 33-yard touchdown pass exactly forty-one seconds before the gun yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

He proposed a joint declaration by us both to Stalin. The document in which this was set forth must of course have been far advanced in preparation by the State Department at the moment when the new President succeeded.
STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Three dozen embattled property owners in the highly zoned Oronoque residential district surrendered today to the arguments of their fellow townsmen.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 15 -- For the first six months of this year the Netherlands had a surplus dollar balance on current account of 186,000,000 guilders against a deficit of 171,000,000 for all of 1952 and 653,000,000 in 1951.

I have read with interest your editorial of Nov. 3 "Tariffs and Subsidies," wherein you endorse the proposal to extend "governmental aid to those few communities and workers that might actually be injured" by cheap competitive imports. Also, you say that such domestic industries are now propped up by "high tariffs" and are "clearly uneconomic."

The newly formed Concert Society of New York presented Irmgard Seefried, soprano, late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall in her only New York recital of the season. That was one contributing factor toward the sold-out house. Miss Seefried, of course, already had built up a sizable reputation through previous appearances and her recordings.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Three second-half pass interceptions by Detroit's Yale Lary and a pair of touchdown tosses by Bobby Layne enabled the Lions to gain a 14-7 victory over Green Bay and undisputed possession of the lead in the National Football League's Western Conference.

DIGNE, France, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A bearded, 76-year-old French farm patriarch, accused by two of his own sons, was formally charged today with the slaying fifteen months ago of Sir Jack Drummond, Lady Drummond and their 11-year-old daughter.
In the ship-charter market the experts are like persons awaiting marriage. A change is coming, they concur, but they are not sure whether it will be for better or for worse.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 15 -- Reports of a prospective military pact between the United States and Pakistan are being watched in India with "intense concern," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today.

MANILA, Monday, Nov, 16 (AP) -- President Elpidio Quirino, defeated for re-election, appealed to the nation last night to cooperate with the new Nationalist- Democratic Administration under Ramon Magsaysay.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- The Monarchist party today announced today its support of a "technical conference" on Trieste, or, in other words, of a conference limited to diplomatic technicians, whose chief task would be to elaborate the agenda of a full conference for the solution of the Trieste problem.

The personal intervention of Nikita S. Krushchev, first secretary of the Communist party in the Soviet Union, won a Soviet visa for Marshall MacDuffie, a New York lawyer now in Moscow, friends of Mr. MacDuffie said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Stunned by Buddy Young's 104-yard touchdown return of the opening kick-off, the Philadelphia Eagles soared back with three brilliant pass plays today to whip the Baltimore Colts, 45 -- 14, in a National Football League game before 27,813 fans.

An audience of more than 1,300 persons attended the Cooper Union Forum last night to hear and discuss a program of contemporary music. The concert was sponsored by Broadcast Music, Inc., and was conducted by David Broekman, as the second event in his series, entitled "Music in the Making."

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 15 -- Nassau County Executive A. Holly Patterson emphatically denied today a published report that he had been asked by prominent local Republicans to take over J. Russel Sprague's post as county leader.

Renewed emphasis on spiritual values in higher education has resulted in a general brightening of the "academic weather," the Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, said yesterday.
Attacks on the Republican plan for reapportionment of the state's Senate districts came yesterday from two organizations in the city.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India, president of the eighth General Assembly, declared today that the way to make the United Nations Charter "live" was to translate its aims into the lives of millions of underprivileged peoples and those still fighting for independence.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Clarke Scholes of the United States, the 1952 Olympic 100-meter free-style champion, scored over Horischi Suzuki of Japan in his specialty tonight in the international swimming meet at Vasco de Gama pool.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, said today that his party intended to make communism in Government "one of the main issues" in the 1954 Congressional election campaign.

A junior high school is to be built and a public elementary school is to be enlarged in the Bedford - Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. The prospective school facilities provide for an additional 2,000 children.

The Virtuosi di Roma gave the second of the subscription concerts of the season in Hunter College Auditorium Saturday night. This chamber music organization, consisting of twelve strings, masters all, an oboist of equal eminence and Renato Fasano, a conductor of sensitiveness and authority, has no rival in its field, at least in any ensemble known in America.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- A study of possible prejudice in Protestant Church literature in the United States has been welcomed by editors and writers for Protestant school publications, the head of the project reported tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Wheat and corn futures worked upward last week, but oats and rye were still hampered by Canadian shipments to United States markets and buying support was hard to enlist.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- France's trade deficit for September was the lowest since February, 1951. Exports covered 94 per cent of the imports, They stood at 77.9 billion francs compared with imports totaling 83.2 billions.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Boston College's running game hit its season's peak today but the Eagle defenses were ragged in a 33-20 triumph over Detroit's Titans before 7,628 fans at Fenway Park.

A study on roasting turkey in aluminum foil, conducted at Iowa State College, shows the most desirable oven temperature to be 450 degrees F. The research also indicates foil-wrapped birds are best cooked unstuffed, with the stuffing baked separately.

Largely because of conditions not of his own making Secretary of Agriculture Benson has found himself the storm center of almost chronic controversy. A few days ago, however, he enjoyed for a change the pleasant experience of addressing a thoroughly congenial audience.

An amateur golfer's fondness for expensive golf clubs led to the apprehension in El Paso, Tex., last night of George Alexander Boss, charged with embezzling $19,700 from the Manufacturers Trust Company here.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15 -- Yugoslavia was believed tonight to have responded affirmatively to a proposal by the Western powers for a conference on the Trieste dispute.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 15 -- If Nicaragua is a dictatorship, says President Anastasio Somoza, the world would be a far better place with more like it.

In every quarter of the globe there are thousands of orphaned, diseased, hungry and homeless persons with whom Christians can share their Thanksgiving, the Rev. John F. McCarthy declared at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said tonight he planned to draft legislation that would remove tax exemptions from foundation funds going to any university or college that had "Fifth Amendment" people on its faculty.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Two ranking members of the Senate's Foreign Relations Committee voiced sharp differences of opinion here today on the question of American policy in the Middle East, particularly on the subject of Israel-Arab relations.

Mrs. V. S., who lives in Queens, was shocked when she was told that she needed an immediate operation for cancer. To make matters worse, she knew she could not afford the full cost of the operation and the hospital care that would be necessary.

The New York premiere of Rolf Liebermann's "Furioso" was the closing number of the Saturday evening concert by the Philharmonic-Symphony under Dimitri Mitropoulos in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Liebermann is a contemporary Swiss composer who flirts with the twelve-tone technique.
The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken suggested yesterday that personal handicaps be treated more as stimuli than as impediments.
A major campaign against discriminatory practices in privately owned housing will be undertaken in the coming year by the Mayor's Committee on Unity of New York City.

Pierre Monteux made his second guest appearance of the season with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. He again substituted for the indisposed Arturo Toscanini, who is scheduled to return to the podium next Sunday.
The holiday spirit is breaking out in sparkling glitter. A simple gift can be glamorized with a gay sprinkling of brilliant beads and metallic threads.

One of the commonest criticisms of Army organization is that, too often, men of high capabilities spend most of their time doing jobs little more important than sharpening pencils and emptying ashtrays.

From a distinguished federal judge comes a warning that our detestation of certain offenses must not lead us to deny justice to those accused. "The more vexing a crime," he told the Buffalo Lawyers Club Saturday night, "the more intense are our obligations to see to it that we do not chip away at the integrity of a man's right to counsel when accused of such a crime."
MONTREAL, Nov. 15 (UP) -- The way was cleared tonight for the entry of Havana into the International Baseball League, provided another city is found to round out an eight-team circuit.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Some Europeans, on reading that section of Sir Winston Churchill's memoirs dealing with his Soviet journey in 1944, were relieved that Britain's Prime Minister was going to Bermuda rather than to Moscow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15--The United Nations has almost $70,000,000 invested in the United States, a small part of it in the common stock of corporations that directly or indirectly are part of this country's defense machine.

With respect to the Fifty-ninth Street Coliseum, attempts are being made to create the impression that this matter is being handled with undue haste, which is not the case. From the viewpoint of New York City, as a whole, there is an urgency in the matter.
MANILA, Nov. 15 (UP) -- An 18-year-old high school student knocked in the winning run as an Oriental all-star baseball team defeated the barnstorming New York Giants, 2 -- 1, in ten innings today.
President Eisenhower was in New York, or just outside of it, for an hour and forty-five minutes yesterday but virtually no one here knew it.
A practical method for determining how closely one is following God's law was cited yesterday by the Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
Those Yale fellows may not have the best football team but they do come up with some whimsical surprises.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- With the fourth quarter half over, the year for the steel industry is drawing to a close on a surprisingly strong note. The good showing has been a surprise primarily to those outside of the industry unaware of the influence of seasonal factors.
The scope of American investment now developing the gold and chromite deposits in the Philippine Islands may soon be broadened to other valuable minerals -- molybdenum, for instance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Using a series of spread formations, the Chicago Cardinals marched 73 yards to score in the final minute of play and held the Los Angeles Rams to a 24-24 tie today in a National Football League game.
Bennett A. Cerf, president of Random House, said yesterday the publishing house probably would offer refunds to purchasers of the book "The Man Who Wouldn't Talk."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asserted today that "bungling or outright defiance by underlings" threatened President Eisenhower's program to end segregation in schools on military posts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Trade in soybeans was the most active on the Board of Trade last week, but wheat was a close second. Soybean purchases however showed a drop from the previous week, while wheat operations were expanded. Wheat purchases for the week were nearly twice as large as a year ago.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 15 -- An Iranian court-martial decided today that it was competent to try former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh on charges of rebellion.
