NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru opposed today the position of the United Nations Command that nonrepatriated prisoners in Korea would automatically revert to civilian status 120 days after the "explanation," period began.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon announced today he would visit Iran at President Eisenhower's request in early December

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Christy Scaperrotta, whose 9-by-12-foot pizzeria sign on the Saw Mill River Parkway has been found esthetically displeasing by the Westchester County Park Commission, moved backward today in his dispute. But not very far back.
Twenty-one college football teams, including Notre Dame and Maryland among the major elevens, still held perfect records yesterday.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army in Korea, Monday, Nov. 16 -- Exactly what would be done should South Korean troops breach the armistice agreement and, as South Koreans have threatened, resume the war, is unknown here.

Plans to enter the Broadway producing field on a novel scale were outlined yesterday by Edward Specter, a founder of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra and its former manager for twenty-five years. Mr. Specter says he is organizing a corporation, to be capitalized at $500,000, with the assistance of his attorney, John F. Wharton, who is a member of the Playwrights Company.

An issue of great public importance comes before the State Senate in the special legislative session which convenes in Albany tomorrow. It is not only the conduct of Senator Wicks, majority leader and President pro tem of the Senate, that is on trial for his repeated visits to Sing Sing prison to see Joseph S. Fay, convicted labor extortionist.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- American and Red diplomats agreed today to get down to work immediately on naming the site, time and nations invited to a Korean peace conference.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- While industrial securities have continued to rise in the last week, gilt-edge stocks have reasserted their leadership in no uncertain manner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Most cities in the United States appear to want Congressional investigative help in meeting their juvenile delinquency problems, Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, said today.

BUFFALO, Nov. 15 -- Social welfare workers heard themselves criticized tonight for failing to help the public understand the facts about increases in mental illness, broken homes and juvenile delinquency.
Several shifts of ranks or jobs among top Soviet military leaders are posing puzzles for analysts of Soviet affairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Senator William E. Jenner said today that the Senate Rules Committee, of which he is chairman, would re-examine the loyalty-security program for Senate employes when Congress reconvened.
A spry, 85-year-old woman, who had been active in stock market transactions as late as a week ago, was found stabbed to death yesterday in her shabby East Side apartment.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15(AP) -- Coffee available for export by producing nations will reach 32,135,000 bags -- a post-war record -- for the year 1953-'54 the Department of Agriculture predicted today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Both consumers and business are borrowing at a slower pace than they did a year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago reports in its monthly review of business conditions. The slower borrowing rate is a reflection of the modest decline in business in late summer and early fall, the bank said.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $79,551,488,059. They consist of Treasury bond certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
The 325th anniversary of the Collegiate Church of the City of New York was marked yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ernest R. Palen at the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church.
SOMETIMES one humble man or woman, by one simple act of kindness, can do more to tie two nations a little closer than any State Department or Foreign Office can.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Charles L. Clements, president of the United States Savings and Loan League, says there are many business men who believe in opposing inflation so long as their own enterprises are not affected.
Work kits containing information on the proposed Equal Rights Amendment have been sent to 2,900 business and professional women's clubs throughout the country.
A provisional charter for a World Parliament of Religions was drawn up yesterday at the close of a week-long organizing conference at the Presbyterian Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street.

Racing to the front in the first half-minute of play and maintaining the advantage throughout, the New York Knickerbockers gained a firmer hold on first place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association by whipping the Baltimore Bullets, 91 -- 79, in the feature game of a circuit twin-bill at Madison Square Garden last night.

Harold Cone, pianist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He was heard in a carefully contrived program, which in its four difficult offerings enabled him to make known his approach to classic, romantic and modern keyboard music.

Leonard Eisner gave his fourth recital in Town Hall last night. For two-thirds of the program he was a thoroughly competent pianist. Then he came to the Moussorgsky "Pictures at an Exhibition," which brought out the worst in him (as the work appears to do to so many young pianists).
Five new films, including an importation from Britain, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged today that the Republicans had turned the Federal Government into "a subordinate ally of big business."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The chemical manufacturing industry has told the Randall Commission on Foreign Economic Policy that some vital industries require "reasonable" tariff protection to preserve their skills and facilities for full use in defense programs.

Cotton prices in the futures market showed a firmer tendency last week. Advances on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from 12 to 45 points, or from 60 cents to $2.25 a bale. The more distant deliveries made the best showing.

More than 100 exhibitors offering a wide variety of goods and services to foreign markets will participate in the New York Export Show opening at noon tomorrow in the 165th Infantry Armory at Twenty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 16 -- North Korean prisoners of war, facing Communist "persuaders" once more in the demilitarized zone, continued vigorously today, for the most part, to reject the Reds' bid to "come home."

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 15 -- The preservation for scholars of a book of early Christian writings, some of which date from about 150 A.D., was announced here today by the Jung Institute for Analytical Psychology.

Plans for erecting an apartment house in the Bronx for completion next year have been announced in connection with the purchase by the Fieldboro Realty Corporation of four private dwellings at 2414 to 2422 Morris Avenue, south of Fordham Road.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- The American Friends Service Committee here issued a statement today on civil liberties and at the same time expressed concern over the Congressional investigation of communism in the Philadelphia public school system, which gets under way tomorrow.

After a period of uncertainty that caused justifiable uneasiness in France the Vietnamese Government has clarified its position. Vietnam, the Government now states in a message to Bao Dai, chief of state, is prepared to remain within the French Union on a basis of sovereign equality.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- Representative Dean P. Taylor met this afternoon with a group of key upstate Republican Senators to settle strategy in the attempt to oust Senator Arthur H. Wicks as Majority Leader and Temporary President of the state Senate.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh extended his war on traffic violators yesterday to include 1,168 New Jersey and Connecticut motorists who had been delinquent in paying their fines.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15 -- The austerity campaign in Brazil's national finances is arousing loud protests even before its strongest measures have been officially announced.

Although said to be in use in 30,000,000 homes, the conventional washer often is neglected in favor of the automatic one in discussions of laundry problems by experts. Noting that such a washer had its own virtues as well as its own problems, several speakers attempted to make up for the neglect at the recent Home Laundry Conference here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15--William Goetz' return to independent production will be marked by a film biography of Maurice Chevalier, with Danny Kaye impersonating the French entertainer who became an international movie idol in the early Nineteen Thirties.
The number of Government-owned ships operated by private companies dropped from 109 to seventy-five last month, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The New York State Optometric Association asserted today that the eyes of thousands of New Yorkers had been damaged permanently by defective, cut-rate glasses and "quickie" vision examinations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Two groups asserted today that the membership of the Hoover Commission's task force to study Federal power policies was weighted against public power.

THE Lighthouse, which does such wonderful work for the blind, realized approximately $135,000 in pledges from its telethon over Station WATV on Channel 13, which ended at 1:30 yesterday afternoon. If past experience with these marathon benefits is a gauge, perhaps $50,000 will be received in actual cash.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- The executive council of the old International Longshoremen's Association held a long secret session here today to determine the future of Joseph P. Ryan, union president, and of the union itself.
The city's credit is sound, but financial problems will plague the incoming regime of Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. for its entire four-year term, Controller Lazarus Joseph predicted yesterday.
NEWARK, Nov. 15 -- A 6-year-old red, fawn and white imported bulldog, Ch. Basford Vulconian Revenge, became best in show tonight in the thirty-fifth event of the Newark Kennel Club.
A grant of $50,000 to Columbia University has set in motion a study of the success of the nation's courts in deciding complex scientific questions.

Stanley M. Isaacs, leader of the Republican minority of two in the new City Council, said yesterday that he was "highly gratified" by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner's choice of Dr. Luther H. Gulick for the new position of City Administrator.
The founders' award of the Institute of Radio Engineers for 1954 will go to Dr. Alfred N. Goldsmith, editor for forty years of the institute's "Proceedings."

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- A large seashore pit on the Libyan coast of Africa has yielded evidence of almost continual habitation by various races of man and subman for at least 80,000 and perhaps more than 100,000 years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Halfback Eddie Macon was outstanding for the Chicago Bears today as they defeated the Washington Redskins, 27 -- 24, in a National Football League contest.
Leonard W. Hall, chairman of the Republican National Committee, praised Governor Dewey yesterday for his actions in the harness track and Joseph S. Fay scandals.

Increasing concern is being expressed over the progressive, and thus far irrepressible, strangulation of New York and other large cities by motor traffic. The solutions being suggested would seem at best to be partial and unsatisfactory in the end. Surprisingly, the inevitable requirement either has not been recognized or is being avoided.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Three field goals by Lou (The Toe) Groza, Otto Graham's sharp passing and a sturdy defense kept the Cleveland Browns ahead all the way today as they beat the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 23 -- 21, for their eighth straight victory in a rough game before 80,698 in Municipal Stadium.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 15 -- American and European buyers' complaints that Malaya is exporting substandard quality rubber will be investigated at an international conference to be held here soon, it was disclosed here today. The Rubber Trade Association of New York and the American Rubber Manufacturers Association are organizing the conference with the federation and Singapore rubber organizations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Two Democratic members of Congress declared today that Mr. Brownell had impugned the patriotism of former President Truman, while two Republicans insisted he had not.
A short circuit in an underground power line blew cast-iron manhole covers into the air on Central Park West last night, disrupting traffic for almost three hours.
The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and subsidiaries reported estimated net income of $24,156,882 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, equal to $2.78 a common share.

Moscow's Janus-faced propaganda line has rarely been more obvious than in this past week-end's developments. Last Friday Andrei Vishinsky delivered one of his bitterest tirades against the United States at the United Nations meeting here, a speech whose venom confirmed the impression of implacable hatred given by the latest Soviet note on Germany and by Marshal Voroshilov's speech a week earlier.

It will be good news to hard-pressed motorists to learn that City Construction Coordinator Moses has opened to traffic two widely separated but essential highway links -- a new bridge carrying Mosholu Parkway over Henry Hudson Parkway in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx and the final section of the Van Wyck Expressway between Queens Boulevard and Grand Central Parkway in Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Signs of a skilled manpower pinch were reported by printing industry employers today.
If you want to build an artificial ice hockey rink, just ask Headmaster-Coach Ned Hall of The Hill School of Pottstown, Pa. But be prepared to run as fast as you can.

DAKAR, French West Africa, Nov. 7 -- Islam is on the march in West Africa. The realization that this religion may ultimately engulf the whole area is causing grave concern here among Christian missionaries and colonial administrators alike.
TRENT, Italy, Nov. 14 -- Italian leaders in this semi-autonomous region are convinced that, despite the agitation of German political leaders in the South Tyrol, this will not become a new Trieste.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Activity on the tees, fairways and greens of this city's golf courses has been over par this year.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 15 -- When the Air Force recruiters start raving that the "chow" is good enough for gourmets, relax. It is.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 15 -- Former President Truman will defend his handling of the Harry Dexter White case before the nation tomorrow night, contending his Administration was trying to jail, not protect, an alleged Communist spy.

In this section of the Times a few days ago, a staff writer, Mr. Brendan M. Jones, reviewed, in general terms, the first week of hearings before the President's Commission on Foreign Economic Policy. That is the seventeen-member committee created last August under the legislation extending the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

Employes of drug stores over the city will give blood today and tomorrow to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. A bloodmobile will visit the Retail Drug Employes Union Local 1199 at 210 West Fiftieth Street for the mass donation.

The two-story building at 618-26 West 153d Street through to 623 West 152d Street, opposite Trinity Cemetery, has been sold by Frances W. Dean and George N. Willard to an investing client of David Friedland, attorney, for cash over mortgages amounting to $147,700.

The construction bustle is gone from the West 116th Street block between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, the city's present to Columbia University on its 200th birthday. Although some work still remains, the new campus walk will be nearly ready for the bicentennial celebration in 1954.

Louis Saritzsky and associates, in a purchase for investment, have acquired the twelve-story thirty-eight-family apartment house at 808 West End Avenue from the Lord Management Corporation. The property, on a plot 116 by 100 feet, is assessed at $425,000.

The Times is to be congratulated on its timely and effective editorial of Nov. 13 condemning as "immoral" the legislative reapportionment bill which the Republican administration intends to present to the special legislative session which convenes in Albany on Tuesday.

As we approach winter, with its more hazardous driving conditions, the Automobile Manufacturers Association comes up with a few facts and figures on travel conditions on the roads that should impress us increasingly with the greater need for care and caution on the part of motorists.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 16 -- As President Anastasio Somoza points out, the trappings of democracy are clearly to be seen in Nicaragua. The question is how much of the substance of democracy lies beneath them.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks rejected all suggestions today that he resign as Majority Leader and Temporary President of the State Senate and thus spare his Republican colleagues the necessity of voting him out at a special session of the Legislature tomorrow.

Salary increases, more promotions, a reduction in the work-load and expanded school facilities were recommended yesterday by faculty and staff representatives at a preliminary budget hearing of the Board of Higher Education. The meeting was held at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Robert Elkington Wood, chairman of the board of directors of Sears Roebuck Co., announced today his retirement from that post.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that United States exports -- not including military aid shipments -- declined and imports increased during the first nine months of this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Representative James P. Richards, Democrat of South Carolina, declared tonight that he was "definitely encouraged" over the prospect that the United States would pick up enough support to block the payment of indemnities to eleven discharged United Nations employes.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 16 -- More than 150 delegates from all the major Protestant churches and missionary societies in South Africa gathered in Pretoria today for a conference tomorrow on race relations.

The Brooklyn Museum's remodeled Egyptian Galleries will be opened to the public tomorrow. The galleries have just been completed in the first stage of a $3,500,000 rehabilitation and modernization program begun two years ago.

The nation's 104,000 letter carriers will begin this week to distribute on their routes envelopes for contributions for the battle against muscular dystrophy. The envelopes will be picked up Nov. 27 and it is hoped that the nationwide goal of $5,000,000 for research into and the care of victims of the disease will be reached.
Indifference to proper nutrition among families has been found widespread by a community survey reported in the current issue of The Journal of Home Economics.

Since you have lent your columns to protestants of the destruction the New York University project in Washington Square would cause, I should like to call to the attention of the readers of The New York Times the N. Y. U.- Bellevue housing project and what it means to every New Yorker to see that this project and ones similar to it are defeated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to determine whether the President had Constitutional power to make an executive agreement with Canada to regulate the importing of potatoes into the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Industrial users of sugar today called on Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson to abandon "a disastrous policy" of reducing sugar quotas below consumption estimates to provide a price stimulant for producers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The White House issued two statements today disassociating President Eisenhower further from the political free-for-all started by his Attorney General's charges against the late Harry Dexter White and the Truman Administration.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- France's now obscure European policy may be clearer after the four-day debate that will begin tomorrow in the National Assembly.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The majority of the Big Ten athletic directors indicated today that Michigan State's probation will not influence their vote for the conference's representative in the Rose Bowl.
BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- East German press reports indicate that several hundred persons may have been arrested in recent weeks on charges of spying, sabotage or anti-Communist agitation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The United States has decided to join Britain and France in introducing a resolution in the United Nations Security Council to condemn Israel for the raid on the Jordanian village of Kibya.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Only one American casualty turned up today as the New South Wales tennis championship tournament reached the semi-finals in the singles.
CLEVELAND Nov. 16 -- Following is the text of the letter sent to the Congress of Industrial Organizations convention today by President Eisenhower:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Eisenhower family acquired the Wherewithal today for a big Thanksgiving dinner.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Britain suddenly called back today her chief military negotiator from Cairo where he had been trying to work out a new Suez Canal defense pact with Egypt. There was no indication of a breakdown in the Cairo talks, however.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP) -- John M. Cabot, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today that misunder-standings and misconceptions were at the root of trade and political problems involving the United States and Latin American countries.

With hitherto available space outgrown by need and demand, the Industrial Home for the Blind at 520 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn 16, has acquired a new building to house many of its activities but needs the unstinted help of its friends to help pay for the project.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, advised India's Ambassador here today that the United States was considering some form of military agreement with Pakistan.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 16 -- In contrast to the moderate speech by Marshal Tito, Yugoslav President, on Trieste yesterday, the official Communist newspaper Borba published an uncompromising editorial on the subject today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Lawyers representing four groups of Negro parents told the Supreme Court today that it had constitutional power to end forthwith racial segregation in the public schools.

The Federal Government encourages contributions to the United Hospital Fund by grant ing income tax relief to those who support the fund. But your gift, in addition to having significant tax advan tages, serves you in an even more personal way.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- President Eisenhower said today that his recommendations for changes in the Taft-Hartley Act would be ready for submission to Congress when it met in January.
Harry Dexter White and his wife, the former Anne Terry, were regular buyers of United States Savings Bonds for six years beginning in December, 1939.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A group of all-cargo airlines asked today that the freight airlines and other "marginal" air operators be exempt from proposed charges for using the Federal airways.

The Metropolitan Opera Association opened its seventieth anniversary season last night with the return to the repertory of Gounod's "Faust," with new scenery and dramatic direction, a notable cast, and Pierre Monteux conducting the performance.
GENEVA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The International Labor Organization told the Soviet Union today it could not become a member under the organization's constitution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Federal, state and local expenditures for dependent children rose almost three-fold in the seven years between 1945 and 1952, a House Ways and Means subcommittee was told today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- A corporation chairman and a union president will begin a novel experiment tomorrow.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT died at a moment when political and military prizes of the highest consequence hung in the balance. Hitler's Western Front had collapsed; Eisenhower was across the Rhine and driving deep into Germany and Central Europe against an enemy who in places resisted fiercely but was quite unable to stem the onslaught of our triumphant armies; there seemed nothing to stop the Western Allies from taking Berlin.

From our point of view it seems that Indian Prime Minister Nehru has put much too sinister an interpretation upon talks between the United States and Pakistan. Pakistan's Governor General, Ghulam Mohammed, has been a guest for a short time in this country and a most welcome one.

Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was generally light. Coffee, rubber, cottonseed oil, copper and wool were mixed; sugar, hides, burlap, tin and zinc closed higher, and cocoa, potatoes, soybean oil and lead ended lower.

Elegant fashions at the opening of the Metropolitan Opera's season last night showed the international influence in fashion. From France, Italy, Spain, England, Greece, Austria and this country came the designs for stately full-length ball gowns that were slim, moderately full or bouffant.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 16 -- The Massachusetts Council of Church delivered a stinging indictment today of the methods used by certain committees investigating communism.
The main floor in the Brooklyn Supreme Court Building resembled yesterday a railroad terminal on a holiday eve.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 16 -- Danish allegations that United States geologists have worked in Greenland without Danish permission have drawn from the chief of the United States Northeast Command an assurance that there will be no repetition of such infringements.
Notre Dame and Maryland preserved their perfect records during a week-end of football upsets and retained the top spots in the United Press college football ratings yesterday.
Hard hit by the continued warm weather, the fur industry is casting about for ideas to step up retail sales.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight that he was broadening the agenda of the special legislative session that will meet tomorrow. This will enable it to act on legislation making 40,000 New York City employes eligible for Federal Social Security benefits.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, in striped trousers and cutaway coat, had a half-hour's private talk with Emperor Hirohito yesterday and conferred twice with Premier Shigeru Yoshida.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- All was not going strictly according to plan at the special clean-up convention of the old International Longshoremen's Association, which opened here today.

Commander Sverre Johannesen, recently released from active duty in the Navy, has been appointed assistant to the president of the Waltham Watch Company in charge of developing military and industrial contracts for the instrument division.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 16 -- Representatives of the newspaper Dawn and the sister publication, The Evening Star, were banned indefinitely today from Government offices, functions and press conferences.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Mrs. Thomas J. White said today that she never had advocated a ban on the story of Robin Hood but she stuck by her declaration that the tale's rob-the-rich-to-pay-the-poor theme was the "Communist's favorite policy."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, urged President Eisenhower and the State Department today to rebut immediately a proposal by India that, he said, might keep unrepatriated Korean war prisoners in custody indefinitely.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations charged today that the largest union in the American Federation of Labor was guilty of "raids" against C. I. O. unions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration liberalized its loan policy today to give all small companies equal opportunity with defense producers to obtain Government loans.
Trieste, the unhappy divided city, is in the midst of a cooling off period to permit the recent reign of emotion to be succeeded by the reign of logic.

BUFFALO, Nov. 16 -- Social welfare workers were advised here today not to seek the protection of the Fifth Amendment if they ever were questioned by any authorized group investigating Communist activities.

Mayor-elect Wagner has announced that he will retain Abraham D. Beame as the city's Budget Director. This is further good news, on top of the Moses and Gulick appointments. Mr. Beame is an able man on his own account, but he brings the added advantage of years of experience in this key post and as right-hand man to the late Thomas J. Patterson, his predecessor.

An industrial tract on Beach Seventy-ninth Street, between the Long Island Rail Road property and Barbadoes Basin, in Hammels, Queens, has been purchased by the Chain Bike Corporation for an expansion of its factory. The City of New York was the seller and W. F. Brunner, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 16 (UP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes' press secretary said tonight that "in view of the fact that Mr. Truman verified what Mr. Byrnes said, the Governor will have no comment tonight and probably not any at all," on former President Truman's speech.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 16 -- Sakari S. Tuomioja, Governor of the Bank of Finland, formed a non-party Cabinet today after having failed to get a coalition on a broad parliamentary basis. The new Cabinet, which will be appointed tomorrow, is composed mainly of rightists who will not be responsible to their parties.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- E. Roland Harriman announced at a news conference today the change of his title from that of president of the American Red Cross to chairman of the national organization.
Mrs. Margaret Rhodes will receive special recognition from the United States Lines today for being the 100,000th traveler to book passage on the United States, the world's fastest liner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Coast Guard today ordered two of its five floating weather and rescue stations in the North Pacific discontinued effective Dec. 6.
Hope that carpet prices might go down soon was raised by wool dealers yesterday but was quickly dashed by carpet wool buyers.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, ex pressed his confidence today that the obstacles to the formation of a European army with West Germany as a member would be overcome.

Walter F. O'Malley and Fresco Thompson, president and vice president, respectively, of the Dodgers, returned to New York by private plane yesterday after spending two weeks at the Brooklyn training camp in Vero Beach, Fla.

" CAN anyone tell me who writes the football scripts these days?" cheerfully asked Greasy Neale, the retired coach who now is a member of the idle rich. "They sure were dillies over the past week-end in both college and professional ball. I can't remember more dramatic or unusual scores."
BROAD BROOK, Conn., Nov. 16 -- The retreat of the textile industry from New England, a trend in effect for several years, soon will be felt in this town when its leading industry closes up shop.

In your editorial "What Does Tuesday Mean ?" printed on Nov. 5 you refer to newly elected Congressman Lester Johnson from Wisconsin's Ninth district as an "out-and-out isolationist." This is not justified.

The Greyhound Corporation and its subsidiaries, which operate buses over more than 96,000 miles of routes, rolled up a consolidated net income of $11,193,841 in the first nine months this year. It is the best for any such period on record.

Central America is still only a geographic expression, and when we read a series of articles from its various capitals such as this newspaper's correspondent Sydney Gruson has been writing it is easy to see why. The dream of a Central American federation has never died.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Rogers Hornsby said today he was quitting professional baseball to make television films. aimed at teaching the fundamentals of baseball to the youth of the nation.

A stay-away-from-classes demonstration was staged yesterday morning in front of Abraham Lincoln High School, Ocean Parkway and West Street, Coney Island. School authorities attributed the incident to the spring-like weather.

ATLANTA, Nov. 16 (UP) -- The Georgia Legislature was asked by the Talmadge administration today to prepare a constitutional amendment permitting abolition of the state's public schools in the United States Supreme Court outlawed segregation.

Steels, aircrafts, amusements and a number of specialties made fair gains in moderately active early trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. But almost all advances were erased before the close. Motors were especially weak.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The State Department made public today the following text of a note delivered to the Soviet Foreign Ministry:...
The New School for Social Research last evening presented a concert of works by Henry Cowell to commemorate his twenty-fifth anniversary as a member of the faculty.

Joey Klein, East Side welterweight, gained a split decision over Freddie (Babe) Herman in the feature bout of ten rounds last night at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn. It was a hard-fought encounter with the point scoring of Referee Barney Felix deciding the fight.
Although the chestnut blight many years ago destroyed this country's commercial crop of the meaty, delectable chestnut, Italy ships us enough to fill a demand that has increased recently.

By ingeniously transforming its main exhibition space into a luxurious office for a high-powered executive and by hanging paintings on the walls, the Downtown Gallery is hoping to encourage the use of original, contemporary art by business men in their offices.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- The Court of Appeals reserved decision tonight on an appeal by two wire services and five New York newspapers aimed at opening the sealed minutes of the compulsory prostitution trial of Minot F. Jelke.
The Cities Service Company and its subsidiaries lifted consolidated net income in the first nine months this year to $37,715,444, from $36,596,690. a year before.
Because a previous sale was stymied by an error in the amount of a check, the United States Government has received an additional $35,500 for the old Post Office site on Broad Street in Newark.
BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company reported today that its assets had increased $173,000,000 in 1952 to $1,757,750,387 on Dec. 31.

ARLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 16 -- This rugged section of Vermont has a large deer population, but the number of animals could not be compared with the legion of hunters that turned out for the opening week-end. A lot of the hunters saw deer, and some insisted they were only twenty or thirty yards distant, but the overwhelming majority of the deer lacked the antlers that would have made them legal game.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, said tonight that he had named a special three-man subcommittee to go to South Carolina to question Gov. James F. Byrnes of that state on the Harry Dexter White case.
Shades that recall the sunbathed colors of summer or the clear tones of gems are used for five new hand-printed fabrics available through decorators at Knoll Associates, 575 Madison Avenue.

Two leading British transportation experts expressed confidence here yesterday in the future of overseas travel. They were Frank H. Dawson, general manager of the Cunard Line, and Thomas D. Slattery, general traffic manager of British and Irish Railways.

The verbal barrage that annually precedes the Army-Navy football game started yesterday, The scene was Toots Shor's where the football writers held their weekly luncheon. In charge of the firing were Coach Eddie Erdelatz of Navy and Col. Jim Schwenk, Army's graduate manager of athletics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Herbert A. Bergson, a former Assistant Attorney General, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today for "switching sides" in anti-trust cases he had prosecuted as a Government lawyer.
Morris County, N. J., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Nov. 25 on an issue of $2,256,000 of general improvement bonds dated Dec. 1, 1953 and due Dec. 1, 1954 to 1977.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Americans bought an average of 3.15 pairs of shoes each last year, the Department of Commerce reported today. It indicated that the 0.15 is about what the men got. An agency official said women and teen-agers are the big shoe-buyers in this country.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Carl Greenblum, 37-year-old electrical engineer, identified himself today as the "mystery witness" before the Senate permanent subcommittee investigating alleged espionage at near-by Fort Monmouth.
OTTAWA, Nov. 16 -- The Liberal Government's policy barring competition against Government-owned companies was described as "socialism in a silk hat" in a debate today in the House of Commons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- "The Mountain," a French novel by Henri Troyat published here recently in English by Simon Schuster, has been purchased by Paramount. Mel Epstein, who will produce the film version, described the story as being a modern Cain and Abel drama played against the background of a search for survivors of a plane that crashes on a snow-covered peak in the Alps.

I read your editorial of Nov. 13 on the proposed reapportionment of the New York State legislative districts with some disturbance because I felt that it did not give your usual fair and complete picture of the situation under discussion.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Government demanded the death penalty today for the confessed kidnap-killers of 6-year-old Bobby Greenlease as their trial opened.

The men's clothing industry operated at 80 per cent of capacity during the first nine months of the year, the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. revealed over the week-end. During the comparable period last year, output was at 68 per cent of capacity.

The continued Communist stalling on both the Korean political conference and the interrogation of the anti-Communist prisoners raises an issue which has already led to conflicting interpretations of the armistice agreement and might lead to serious consequences unless settled in time.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 16 -- An agreement between Israel and Jordan for combined action to fight infiltration was extended for three months by the Mixed Armistice Commission meeting in Jerusalem today. The agreement was to have expired Dec. 8.

The Metropolitan Opera House became a septuagenarian last night. To celebrate its seventieth anniversary it opened its new season with Gounod's "Faust," which had occupied the gas-lit stage at the first first-night. And to prove that its ideas, if not its frame, were youthful, it provided a new, restudied "Faust" that was unconventional and daring in design.

The one-story factory on a plot 25 by 100 feet at 285 Grand Street in Brooklyn has been purchased by Frank and Joseph Muraco. Natale C. Tedone was attorney for the seller and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Following is the text of a nation-wide radio and television address by former President Truman last night from Kansas City, as transcribed by The New York Times:

The Near East College Association will be the beneficiary of a performance of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" on the night of Dec. 8 at the Martin Beck Theatre. Mrs. Frank R. Smith heads the committee in charge of ticket sales. Among her aides is Mrs. Walter H. Page.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 -- The Oil Workers International Union, C. I. O., has challenged the right of a company to instigate an employe stock purchasing plan without, in effect, obtaining the union's assent.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Otto Graham, quarterback of the Cleveland Browns, was "at home" to his weekly television audience tonight despite fifteen facial stitches and a swollen mouth that made talking difficult.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Herb McKenley, amateur runner from Jamaica who took two second places in the 1952 Olympics, has turned professional and will compete in races billed as the world professional sprint championships in Melbourne early next year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A $100,000,000 suit by a Swiss holding company for control of General Aniline and Film Corporation was thrown out of court today.

RICHMOND, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Southern Conference today found its anti-bowl rule a bit elastic and voted to let its executive committee pass on the post-season game question should one of its members receive an invitation for a New Year's Day appearance.
TORONTO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Shirley Thomas won the international individual jumping competition for Canada at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- Rocco B. Bunino of Blairstown, N. J., president of the National Licensed Beverage Association, called today for a readjustment of "strangulating taxation" on alcoholic beverages.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Eight rubber companies and the Rubber Association of Canada pleaded guilty today to conspiring to prevent or lessen competition in the sale of rubber tires and tubes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- There was an interesting omission in former President Truman's volcanic outburst against Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Wheat and corn futures showed a strong early upturn but as usual the demand diminished and there was a sharp recession from the tops. Later commission absorption was fairly active.

As far as the Weather Bureau is concerned, normal isn't normal any more. The agency has revised its gauge of normal temperature on evidence that Northern winters have averaged 2 degrees warmer in recent years.

Doris Betts of the University of North Carolina has been chosen to receive the $2,000 Putnam Prize for her "The Gentle Insurrection," a collection of short stories. The group, which will be published by Putnam in April, includes "Mr. Shawn and Father Scott," the story that won a $500 prize in Mademoiselle magazine's college fiction contest.
The eighteenth annual testimonial dinner in honor of Archbishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Diocese of Brooklyn war held in the grand ballroom of the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn last night.
Hearn Department Stores, Inc., will try to fill the merchandising and sales vacuum that will be created on Fourteenth Street when Ohrbach's moves uptown.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Following are excepts from the statement made before the Security Council today by Dr. Yusuf Haikal, representative of Jordan, on the Kibya case and other border incidents:

A year-end dividend of $1.25 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 14, was authorized yesterday by directors of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. Dividend declarations this year total $3.80, as interim dividends of 85 cents a share were distributed in three previous quarters.

OTTAWA, Nov. 16 -- In ceremonial garb of buckskin and eagle feathers, a group of Mohawks appeared in the Exchequer Court of Canada today to demand that the Government honor their ancient right to import personal goods from the United States duty-free.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 16 -- The World Veterans Federation, an organization representing 16,000,000 members in twenty nations, voted today to admit German veterans to membership.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Sir Winston Churchill proposed today that the forthcoming Bermuda conference adopt a program combining reassurance to the Soviet Union of the West's peaceful intentions with an attempt to make contact with the leaders of the Communist bloc to ease world tension.

MANILA, Nov. 16 -- In an obvious allusion to the role of the Roman Catholic Church in last week's elections, President Elpidio Quirino warned today against the participation of the church in politics and affairs of state. The Chief Executive said the people would "lose their respect for the church," if it persisted in taking part in politics.

Mrs. August Chronik, 85 years old, who was found slain Sunday afternoon in her flat at 225 East Sixty-sixth Street, had been stabbed eleven times in the chest and left arm, an autopsy showed yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Pakistan has indicated that if the United States arms her, she will grant Washington the use of bases and possibly will permit the construction of new ones.

The power and glory that once were Yale's and Harvard's on the gridiron may be one with the dodo, but the scrap coming up in the Bowl at New Haven Saturday is the nearest thing in years to a throwback to their earth-shaking epics of yore.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16 -- Argentina's attempts to stimulate further economic development with sound foreign capital investments promise that there will be "closer bonds" with the United States, Senator Homer Capehart declared today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The United States, Britain and France rejected today the Soviet Union's "price" for attending a conference on the unification of Germany. They accused the Soviet Government of seeking to link West European problems to those in Korea and other areas of the Far East. This would lead to a solution of none of them, the Western powers said.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 16 -- Former President Truman charged tonight that Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, had "lied" about the Harry Dexter White case.

Johnny Kelley, a "sleeper" from Boston University, broke away from the rest of the field on the back-breaking climb up Cemetery Hill and roared on to a decisive triumph in the forty-fifth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. varsity cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Herbert C. Gerlach, Westchester County Executive, submitted today to the Board of Supervisors the largest budget in the county's history.
A man who assumed a pose of great wealth among his Westchester County neighbors was able to net $250,000 in four months through fraud, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein charged yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The event of the season for collectors of Americana, the Eastern States Antiques Fair, opened today at the Westchester County Center for its semi-annual stand of six days. Hours are 1 to 11 P. M. except Saturday, when the fair closes at 6.
A former city official and his blind wife were manhandled and robbed in their Brooklyn home by a pair of husky young thugs Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today it is working on plans to clear up the $65,000,000 debt owed it by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. The debt is in the form of a bond issue, not due to be paid off in full until Jan. 1, 1965.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 17 -- The Communists proposed this morning that the Korean peace conference be held at Panmunjom.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Department of the Treasury today offered holders of $10,000,000,000 worth of fourteen-month Treasury notes maturing on Dec. 1 a chance to exchange them for a new shorter note at lower interest or for five-year bonds at slightly higher interest.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 16 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, former Premier of Iran, today abandoned tragedy in favor of sarcasm and lethargy as defense weapons at his trial by a court-martial on a charge of rebellion.
A regional meeting of the National Wholesale Frozen Food Distributor Association at the Statler Hotel heard yesterday that the supply of frozen orange concentrate from Florida may again be short.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 16 (AP) -- A bit of history went to the bottom of the sea today when the mackerel seiner Jean and Patricia burst into flames and foundered in Massachusetts Bay. Her crew of nine had been picked up by another Gloucesterman, the Serifina II.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy resumed closed sessions here yesterday on Communist espionage in General Electric plants and in the Army Signal Corps. He said forthcoming open hearings would produce "evidence of actual stealing of classified material from the Signal Corps after the war."

RIO DE JANIERO, Nov. 16 -- Oswaldo Aranha, Minister of Finance, whose statement Friday that Brazil did not need foreign investments has stirred up a hornet's nest, said today there had been a misunderstanding. He intended, he said, to refer only to private investments that are taxed by both the United States and Brazil on their income.

From the time a child is able to play with his first toys, his interest in the world of books should be encouraged, Mrs. Frances Lander Spain, superintendent of work with children for the New York Public Library, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Congressional reaction to former President Truman's talk to the nation tonight about his handling of the case of Harry Dexter White followed partisan political lines. It also indicated that it would remain an election issue for some time to come.

Those who call United Nations delegates frivolous because of the frequency of their cocktail parties, buffet suppers and informal dinners fail to credit these gatherings with their actual value in easing diplomatic tensions, Mrs. Frances P. Bolton said yesterday.

VIENNA, Nov. 16 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, who was dropped last week by the People's party as Austrian Foreign Minister because he had intimated in a recently published book that the party had been too susceptible to Communist intrigue, defended his position tonight before the Budget Committee of Parliament.

A hectic Board of Estimate session on the proposed 1954 capital budget of $531,745,343 was told yesterday that a $500,000,000 state bond issue would be necessary to enable New York City to build the schools it needs.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 16 (UP) -- Knotty Paul, who didn't compete as a juvenile last year, won his sixth race in nineteen tries today when he scored by three lengths in the Indian Summer Purse at Laurel.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, Nov. 17 -- Without warning, the Communists canceled today's interviews with prisoners of the Korean war. Their action was almost identical to that used in breaking off the talks on Nov. 5.
The American Federation of Labor's new pier union proposed yesterday that the first union representation election should embrace only the 15,000 longshoremen in the Port of New York.

Steel production declined slightly last week for the fourth successive time and is expected to ease further this week. In the seven days ended last Saturday the nation's mills operated at 92.3 per cent of capacity and turned out 2,081,000 net tons of raw metal.

A banking syndicate of eighty-eight investment houses headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will place on the market today about $26,000,000 of common stock of Pacific Lighting Corporation. The offering consists of 800,000 shares at $33 a share.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Dr. Susan Riley, president of the American Association of University Women, was decorated today with one of the highest awards of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Buyers from halfway around the world converged on the armory of the "Old Sixty-ninth" Regiment at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street yesterday for the opening of the New York Export Show.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Television viewers, who on Nov. 2 had admired the bearded and suave Leigh Kostelanetz as he demonstrated on a model his talents as "a Hollywood make-up expert," found out today why he had not made his advertised reappearance last Wednesday.
Trade-tariff policies based on "fair competition" between American and foreing industries were proposed yesterday by Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks.
Prices of cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 6 points off to 12 points up.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Profit-taking sales plus a hint of labor unrest in the heavy industries resulted in narrow and irregular changes on the stock market here today. Losses outnumbered gains but the undertone remained fairly firm.
Douglas Watson and Phyllis Love have landed featured roles in two forthcoming Broadway presentations, "The Confidential Clerk" and "The Family Man," respectively.

As a guess, say, the average apartment house in the city has six floors. Up from the basement, through each set of units, go the steam and radiator pipes. Say that in each unit there is an average of four people. That means, one on top of the other, served by the same set of pipes, lives an average of twenty-four individuals.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former Commander-in-Chief of United States Forces in Europe, declared here yesterday that there could be no greater contribution to our way of life than through the support of private centers of learning.

Stockholders of the Fire Association of Philadelphia, at a special meeting on Jan. 14, will vote on increasing the authorized capital stock from 360,000 shares of $10 par value to 800,000 shares of $10 par. There are 340,000 shares of stock outstanding.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- A potential split between Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner of New York and the Democratic State Committee over the issue of permanent personal registration came to light today at a hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee to study the election law.

Women have many peculiar ways around the house. When, as everyone knows, sausage and pancakes form the only decent Sunday morning breakfast, women boil up a mess of tasteless cereal. They insist that the bottoms of the shoes be rubbed clean on the mat outside the door before the shoes can carry their owners within.

A drive to obtain $146,600 for the work of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church in the coming year was started last night at a parish dinner in the Commodore Hotel. Expenses of the church will amount to $230,000, but income from endowments, offerings and other sources is expected to reach $83,400.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly deferred a vote again today on a resolution, sponsored by the United States and thirteen other nations, under which the United Nations Disarmament Commission would continue its work for another year.

Novel divertissements were features of the Fan Ball, which was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund. Mrs. Herbert T. Mundin headed the executive committee for the fete, which began with a dinner. The event had been underwritten by General Foods, Inc.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, Nov. 16 -- Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. of New York and Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey will have a chance tomorrow to chat about their recent victories over Republican opponents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The outlines of former President Truman's measured reply to the speech at Chicago on Nov. 6 by Attorney General Brownell were plain before Mr. Truman made it tonight. And from these advance outlines, and the established fact that the former President knows how to make the most of his artillery, it could only have been expected that Mr. Truman would, as he did:
A nation-wide program to vaccinate 500,000 to 1,000,000 children with the new anti-polio triple-vaccine will get under way in the week of Feb. 8, 1954.

Aviation was urged last night to end its dependence on Government orders by developing the domestic market for private planes and air freighters. The plea was made by Charles R. Sligh Jr., president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
TRENTON, Nov, 16 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson was praised and defended today for his public utterances on farm price support.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation continued its drive on floggings in a four-county area of North and South Carolina with the arrest today of fourteen alleged former members of the Ku Klux Klan.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The British Government announced today it had agreed to give the Government of Jordan 2,350,000 ($6,580,000) in financial assistance beginning April 1. The agreement is subject to approval by Parliament.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York, at its forty-third annual board meeting yesterday, elected Charles Merville Spofford, former United States deputy representative on the North Atlantic Council, to its board of trustees.

Not long ago the Governor of New York went out of his way to praise the voluntary hospital system. The citizens of New York can understand this enthusiasm, because they chose voluntarily to create the great system of non-profit hospitals that stands ready to serve them.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 17 -- The International Court of Justice ruled unanimously today that the minuscule reefs, rocks and islets in the English Channel known as the Minquiers and Ecrehou Islands belonged to Britain.

The race between Notre Dame and Maryland for the season's No. 1 rating in college football becomes closer at the other teams eliminate themselves from contention. The Irish and the Terrapins, the only major powers still undefeated and untied this season, rounded up 135 of the 151 first-place votes in the eighth weekly Associated Press ranking poll yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 -- Resentment over the declining role given to labor in the Government's foreign operations showed up today in resolutions laid before the Congress of Industrial Organizations' convention.
The Pennsylvania Railroad borrowed $4,230,000 in the public market yesterday on serial equipment trust certificates maturing over fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The White House tonight banned eyewitness stories of President and Mrs. Eisenhower's state dinner for the Supreme Court at which three of the principals in the Harry Dexter White controversy were guests.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 17 (UP) -- Mrs. E. H. Augustus' Helianthus, a 23-1 shot, defeated the favored By Jeepers and nine other 2-year-olds today in the $19,700 Spalding Lowe Jenkins Purse, closing-day feature at Laurel Park.

Carl Sandburg will receive the 1953 Book Award of the Tamiment Institute on Saturday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria. The $500 prize is presented annually to the author of a current book considered best in illustrating the American heritage of freedom. This year's award is for the first volume of Mr. Sandburg's autobiography, "Always The Young Strangers." Virgilia Petersen will make the presentation and Max Eastman and Peter Viereck will be speakers.

Nearly two-thirds of the 9,720 water-cooled gas refrigerators inspected by the Health Department since its survey began on Oct. 7 were defective. Of these, 2,609 were sealed as dangerously defective, while 3,703 had less serious faults.

Angered at former President Truman's Monday night attack on "McCarthyism," Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, demanded equal time and coverage on radio and television networks yesterday to answer the attack.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Former President Truman firmly refused tonight to say anything more about the Harry Dexter White case.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- The Republican plan for redrawing the state's Senate district lines was stalled in the special session of the Legislature today because nobody could find out who was leading the majority party.

Closely related to clothes and influenced by them are the fashion accessories that complete and spice up a woman's attire. This opinion was expressed yesterday by Nicholas Parker, vice president of Neiman-Marcus of Dallas, Tex., who spoke at the accessory show presented by the Fashion Group during lunch at the Astor Hotel.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Buck Hill, rising sharply above the famous Battenkill, had much in common with a similar terrain feature known as San Juan, at least so far as gunfire and the number of armed men were concerned. The harvest of deer, however, was almost negligible.

The United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America are engaged in a novel experiment. Benjamin F. Fairless and David J. McDonald, respective presidents of the two organizations, have begun a series of plant tours that will continue for some months, so it will be some time before the results may be evaluated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- J. Edgar Hoover declared today that the transfer of Harry Dexter White to the International Monetary Fund "hampered" rather than helped an investigation of Mr. White's alleged espionage activities.
The paste of sweetened ground almonds that goes by the name of marzipan is an essential Christmastide confection in many parts of Europe, particularly Germany, Austria and Scandinavia.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 18 -- The Times of London declared in an editorial today that some features of Mr. Truman's reply to the allegations against him in the White case were not convincing and left some questions unanswered.

Stock prices yesterday continued the downtrend that was in evidence on Monday. The market, as measured by The New York Times composite average of fifty stocks sagged to the lowest level since mid-October.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Joseph Stalin's face looked full and serene and his thick brownish hair and mustache were streaked with gray when his tomb was opened to the public today for the first time since his death.

The young lady in red who helped place a cornerstone plaque on the new ten-story building of the New York Infirmary yesterday was Camille Anne Giardino, 4 years old. A white apron and gloves were added to her attire for the occasion, at which she represented the 37,500 babies born at the hospital since its founding 100 years ago.

New issues of common stock of western public utility companies, of a New England brass manufacturer, and of a new midwestern petroleum pipe line enterprise will figure in the offerings of securities being made to investors today. The offerings, which have a total value of more than $15,700,000, are as follows:

The Sanitation Department's enforcement of alternate side parking has caused considerable hardship to New York's citizens. While it is desirable to clean the streets, the necessity of towing and impounding cars from unlittered residential neighborhoods is a cart-before-the-horse solution.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 17 -- The National Grange may be the first major farm organization to call for a Congressional investigation of the cost of food.

New York and other communities of the metropolitan area are on the threshold of a new expansion and change of governmental techniques that will stagger the imagination, Dr. Luther H. Gulick declared yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 17 -- Three women, landowners in the Oronoque residential district of Stratford, are determined not to yield in their fight against the building of a large helicopter plant in the area. They so informed Judge George C. Conway today in Superior Court here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, expressed his belief today that the United States had gained more than it had lost in twenty years of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 -- The delegates to the Congress of Industrial Organizations' convention applauded today a demand that Herbert Brownell Jr. resign as Attorney General because of his charges against former President Truman in the Harry Dexter White case.

William W. (Pudge) Heffelfinger, former All-America guard at Yale, yesterday was named the winner of the Touchdown Club of New York Award for 1953. The award is given annually for "a wholesome, constructive contribution to football over the years."
President Jefferson's alleged floutin of a subpoena in the Aaron Burr treason trial has been cited as support for President Truman's refusal to obey Congressional subpoena in the Whit matter.

After a five-year battle, the Department of Marine and Aviation has reached agreement with five reluctant railroads on leases covering the use of nineteen city piers and a float bridge at an annual aggregate rental of $1,643,932.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Following is the official transcript of testimony before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in the White case today:

Anyone wanting a buffalo or elk may have one as a gift of the National Park Service, f. o. b. But there are few takers and the only solution to surplus herds is to permit shooting in limited areas, Conrad Wirth, director of the service, told the National Audubon Society yesterday. The annual convention was held at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 -- The longest step toward unity since organized labor's original split in 1935 was taken here today. The Congress of Industrial Organizations, by unanimous convention action, followed the American Federation of Labor in ratifying an agreement aimed at prohibiting interunion raiding after Jan. 1.
If the Brooklyn baseball club is making any positive move toward finding a new manager it is being done after office hours -- and perhaps that's the way the matter is being handled.

On March 1 you published a letter by the undersigned group of Canadian lawyers which expressed doubts and misgivings about the Committee of Jurists' report to the then Secretary General of the United Nations concerning the loyalty standards of U. N. employes of United States nationality.

Volume increased on most commodities yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in potatoes was the heaviest since May 1. Prices moved irregularly, with coffee, sugar, burlap and lead mixed; cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, copper and rubber higher, and potatoes, hides, zinc, tin and wool lower.

IT was surprising, of course, to read in yesterday's papers that Herb McKenley, the holder of the world's 440-yard record of 46 seconds flat, had turned professional. The element of surprise was furnished not so much by the fact that Hustlin' Herbert had turned pro, but that there was a place for him to turn. Most folks had forgotten, it seems, that such a thing as professional racing for humans still existed.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 18 -- Communist delegates at the Panmunjom preliminary talks today seemed to have dropped demands for a round-table Korean peace conference because of United Nations opposition, but clung to demands that neutral nations act as a third party in the negotiations.

Bankers dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States increased seasonally during October by $1,781,000 to $516,722,000, the highest since December, 1934. The October aggregate was $67,293,000 more than a year ago.

Freedoms Foundation Civil Defense Awards for 1953 were received yesterday by Keith S. McHugh of the New York City Civil Defense Advisory Council and Arthur W. Wallander, former director of the New York City Office of Civil Defense.

Eighty-five business leaders were warned last night that unless industry contributed more generously to the country's medical schools "the schools will have no choice but to accept Government subsidies in increasing amounts until they are Government controlled."
LONDON, Nov., 17 -- Opposition was reported to be developing today within the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions to a proposal for a twenty- four-hour token strike.
OTTAWA, Nov. 17 -- Sufficient time has passed now and enough discussion has taken place to make it possible to appraise President Eisenhower's visit with hindsight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Warner Brothers is going to pour on the steam, Cinema Scope-wise, by using the wide-screen photographic system on sixteen of its major productions.
ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- A compromise solution of the Wicks case appeared to have been worked out today in a three-hour conference of Republican Senators behind closed doors in the State Capitol.
The cotton futures market here closed steady yesterday 2 to 10 points higher than on Monday. The volume of trading was moderate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The General Motors Corporation filed formal application with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the sale of $300,000,000 of debentures. The application said the debentures, to mature in 1979, would be offered publicly through an underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co.
The gargantuan job of reconstruction that has closed off a major part of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for three years is drawing to a close.

Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, president of the United Nations General Assembly and sister of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, told the Western allies last night that they had themselves to blame for the rise of Asian communism.

At recent tea meetings at the Waldorf-Astoria, plans have been advanced by members of the junior committee for the International Children's Bazaar, which will be held Monday in the Sert Room of the hotel for the benefit of the Save the Children Federation.
TORONTO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Capt. Colm O'Shea won the international two and two for Ireland tonight in the second phase of the international jumps at the Royal Winter Fair.
NAPLES, Italy, Nov. 17 -- The last of the 3,000 Hungarian Jews ransomed at $1,000 a head by United States Jewish organizations arrived here this morning and proceeded tonight to Israel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Department of Defense announced today it planned to back a program of scholarships for medical students to assure the military services of a steady supply of doctors.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 -- A sound approach to public relations could be the decisive ingredient in the solution of many of the world's problems, William G. Werner, retiring president of the Public Relations Society of America, said here today.

Mrs. Paul Pryibil of 960 Fifth Avenue and Bogheid, Glen Cove, L. I., will give a reception, cocktail party and dance on Dec. 22 in the Georgian Suite, 1A East Seventy-seventh Street, for Miss Nini Tilney of London, who is visiting her.
Having reached this stage of the campaign with four victories and three one-touchdown defeats, Fordham senses a chance to compile its best football record since 1950, when it won eight of nine games.
WASHINGTON Nov. 17 -- J. Edgar Hoover emerged from the White case hearings today as the decisive witness and probably the most powerful figure on Capital Hill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company (Cotton Belt) be authorized to merge its Missouri and Texas corporations and to shift its headquarters from St. Louis to Tyler, Tex.
The designs for a new jet airliner were displayed at the Wings Club in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday by Walter Tydon, chief engineer of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation of Hagerstown, Md.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 17 -- The Indiana chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union today was denied use of the Indiana War Memorial Building for a scheduled meeting Friday night.

BUFFALO, Nov. 17 -- Public Welfare agencies could save taxpayers money if they concentrated more attention on rehabilitation programs instead of simply providing subsistence aid, Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy of the New York City Department of Welfare said here today.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 17 -- West Berlin's special position and special importance as an outpost beyond the front lines of the "cold war" have been underlined by the appointment of a United States Assistant High Commissioner who will have his headquarters there.

The New York Football Giants' fortunes received a boost yesterday. Eddie Price, hampered by adhesions on his right foot, apparently has recovered fully and is expected to see extensive duty as a running back Sunday when the Washington Redskins are opposed at the Polo Grounds.

Fresh prints, pastels and navy that had a forward look to spring were among the attractive suggestions for holiday wear shown yesterday at Saks Thirty - fourth Street store. In junior and misses sizes, the presentation also included separates as well as a small collection of formal evening gowns.

HELSINKI, Finland, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Union, in a bid for Finnish friendship, has offered to negotiate for the possible return of vital territory lost by Finland to the Russians during the 1939 war.

Horse racing at the nation's thoroughbred running tracks broke all records again in 1953, an unofficial Associated Press survey of the attendance, betting and revenue of the twenty-five racing states disclosed yesterday. Wagering went over the two billion dollar mark for the first time.
MANILA, Nov. 17 -- President Elpidio Quirino announced today he would restore the writ of habeas corpus this week in the provinces of the Philippines where it was suspended three years ago.

The Foster Wheeler Corporation has begun limited operation at its new $5,000,000 steel fabricating plant at Mountaintop, Pa., nine miles south of Wilkes-Barre, the company announced yesterday. Full operation is not expected until after Jan. 1 because of the need for training plant personnel.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -- A Federal court jury today found lobbyist Arthur H. Samish guilty of income tax evasion late today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- James J. Nance, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, said today that the business road generally was rougher than anything experience since 1940. He also told the annual convention of the American Finance Conference, composed of independent automobile sales credit companies, that the recession widely forecast for 1954 was being grossly exaggerated.

GLEAMING successes marked the end of our campaign in the Mediterranean. In December [1944] Alexander had succeeded Wilson as Supreme Commander, while Mark Clark took command of the Fifteenth Army Group. After their strenuous efforts of the autumn our armies in Italy needed a pause to reorganise and restore their offensive power.

Smarting from two defeats by the Detroit Red Wings last weekend, the Rangers seek to return to winning form tonight when they engage the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

The free nations as a whole are in the process of closing the best economic year in their history, Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration, told the fortieth National Foreign Trade Convention yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 17 (UP) -- Mrs. Robert Greenlease, sitting twenty-five feet from the man and woman who kidnaped and murdered her son, Bobby, told today how she had tried to get from them positive evidence that he was alive.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Uganda Development Corporation announced today it had reached agreement with Colonial Development Corporation and Frobisher, Ltd., to provide funds to bring the Kilembe Copper Mine in western Uganda into production.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Elected representatives of the United Nations staff took a cool attitude today toward Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's request for wider powers of dismissal.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 18 -- Hope was fading fast this morning for the dying prisoner explanations at Indian Village. Even the efficient Indians who have nursed their ailing charges through one crisis after another could do little more than pray.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- After testing 600 men and women undergraduates at British universities, two women psychologists have reached the "interim conclusion" that men are more intelligent than women.
A redistribution of exeutive positions at Cecil Presbrey, Inc., will be made on Jan. 1. The changes, among others, involve the three top officials.
A thirty-three-ton propeller, the largest cargo ship screw ever manufactured in this country, safely cleared yesterday the first hurdle of a sea and road voyage from Staten Island to Quincy, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A former Government tax lawyer testified today that he believed the tough United States Enemy Alien Property Seizure Law was drafted by Harry Dexter White in "a nefarious scheme" to deliver Germany and Japan to communism.
Alfred and Herbert Teltschik, brothers from Floresville, Tex., who form a duo-piano team, played a recital in Town Hall last evening.

ON Sept. 9 in the year 1878, 284 sick and half starved Indians stole through a ring of armed United States soldiers on the plains of Oklahoma and set out on one of the most desperate, pathetic and heroic journeys in all history. They were Northern Cheyennes and they were determined to return to their ancestral hunting grounds on the banks of the Yellow stone River 1,500 miles away in Montana.
Following are brief sketches of some of the persons prominently mentioned in yesterday's testimony in Washington:
Park Commissioner Robert Moses' multi-million-dollar recreation centers were attacked by social workers yesterday as "shamefully wasteful."

Directors of the American Book Company declared an extra dividend of 50 cents a share, payable on Jan. 4. The company paid a similar extra in December, 1952, and the usual quarterly dividend of 62 1/2 cents on Nov. 2.
A collection of custom and ready-to-wear shoes, designed by Andre Perugia of Paris for Saks Fifth Avenue, was shown Monday at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

Is it because our modes and mores are unattractive to our artists that they discard them as anachronisms and favor historical accuracy or dateless, unidentifiable garments when they depict Biblical scenes? Or are they afraid of "dating" their pictures?
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox today issued a winter roster of thirty-nine players, including two national defense list men.

Columbia replaced the usual contact scrimmage in yesterday's practice with a light offensive and defensive drill as the tired Lions worked out for their final game of the season against Rutgers Saturday.
A transportation company executive testified yesterday that Michael Clemente, dock union leader, had been paid $40 to $60 a boatload for newsprint unloaded at an East River pier in 1950 and 1951.

Priority was given to missionary work in India and Pakistan by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church yesterday. A budget of $6,208,098 was adopted for 1954 at the close of the board's annual two-day meeting here.

Ten billion dollars in fourteen-month Treasury notes bearing 2 1/8 per cent are scheduled to mature Dec. 1. The Treasury has just announced that it will offer holders a choice of two types of securities for the obligations coming due. They may exchange them for a twelve-and-one-half-month note bearing 1 7/8 per cent or for a 2 1/2 per cent bond maturing Dec. 15, 1958, or a little over five years.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Ray Eliot, Illinois football coach, today declined to accept roses emblematic of a Rose Bowl bid for his team and said "send 'em to Michigan State."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Charles E. Slusser, Public Housing Commissioner, announced today that the next sale of new Housing Authority bonds will be on Dec. 15.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 17 -- The Danish Government, backed by representatives of Danish industry, has decided to decline a United States offer to sell surplus farm products in Denmark for local currency.
