PARIS, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- Right-wing dissidents launched tonight a movement in the National Assembly to crush the proposed six-nation community of Western Europe.
The special calendar call in Brooklyn Supreme Court of personal injury and death actions settled down yesterday to a normal routine.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The United States position is that all unreturned prisoners of war in Korea should be "given their freedom" by next Jan. 22.

The new American Federation of Labor pier union asserted yesterday that the old International Longshoremen's Association was so "controlled" by employers that it should be barred from a ballot by which longshoremen here would choose their bargaining agent.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 17 (UP) -- Trainer R. H. McDaniel tied the record for saddling winners in a single year when he sent Mr. and Mrs. N. G. Phillips' Cornerstone to the post for his victory in the featured Lankershim Hotel Purse at Bay Meadows today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The opening of the sixteen-day Bowie racing season tomorrow signals the year's final major meeting in the East. The overnight entries for the first program had many top Maryland, New York and New Jersey stables represented.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Industrial consumption of aluminum is expected to reach a new high of 3,400,000,000 pounds 25 per cent over 1952, the De- this year, an increase of about partment of Commerce said today.
MIAMI, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Eastern Air Lines will begin passenger service between New York and Miami "every hour on the hour" next month, Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, board chairman, announced today.
MADRID, Nov. 17 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford said today that the United States was "very close" to the end of its defense build-up.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's 1953 wheat harvest was even bigger than anticipated, reaching 613,965,000 bushels. This is a jump of almost 20,000,000 over the last estimate in September and comprises the second biggest wheat crop in history, about 74,000,000 bushels below the high of 687,922,000 bushels produced last year, the Bureau of Statistics reported in a final crop estimate today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Eric A. Johnston told President Eisenhower today the four countries to which he presented the proposed Jordan Valley authority plan had promised they would give the project the "most careful study."
EDMONTON, Nov. 17 (Canadian Press) -- The Alberta Government's decision on export of its natural gas may be announced by the week-end but more probably by the middle of next week.

Supreme Court Justice Walter R. Hart submitted yesterday to the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., his recommendations for settling their dispute over new transit operating schedules that are designed to save $1,250,000 a year.

TRENTON, Nov. 17 -- The New Jersey Farm Bureau went on record here today as favoring a flexible farm price support program. At the same time, it expressed "vigorous opposition" to present high, rigid price supports.

The New York Automobile Club and the American Automobile Association have done much to promote highway safety, and have earned public gratitude thereby. But their opposition to the new "Drunkometer" method of testing a suspected drunken driver's sobriety by measuring the alcohol content of his breath is hard to understand. Their argument is that it "violates the constitutional bar against self-incrimination."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The close ties between the Red Cross Societies of this country and Cuba were accented by the arrival here today of Senora Martha F. de Batista, First Lady of Cuba.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Repeal of duties on wool and substitution of direct Government support payments to the American growers based on sales of wool and lambs was proposed today.

Arlene Dahl canceled her guest appearance on the Bob Hope television show last night because of a tired voice. A spokesman for City Center, where the actress currently is co-starring with Jose Ferrer in "Cyrano de Bergerac," said that Miss Dahl had found it impossible to fulfill both commitments. She made her regular stage appearance last night in the role of Roxane.

Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country on former President Truman's speech on the Harry Dexter White controversy, as gathered by The Associated Press and The United Press:

Louis S. Rothschild, maritime administrator, announced yesterday that he would begin on Monday a series of talks with the governors of the four states now training merchant marine officers in maritime academies.

TOKYO, Nov. 17 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida, facing critical tests of his conservative Government in the weeks ahead, moved dramatically today to give his Liberal party, the majority it needs in Parliament.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's statement that if there is no Korean peace conference, the fate of the prisoners must be turned back to the two belligerent commands for settlement, won't delay the disposition of the prisoners, in the opinion of High Indian officials on the scene here.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 17 -- Former Premier Sukiman Wirjosandjojo, a leader in the dominant Opposition Moslem party, called last night for immediate general elections in Indonesia as a "must" if the country was to achieve stability.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., Nov. 17 -- A plunging Air Force Flying Boxcar cut a swath of death through a mass drop of paratroopers jumping from planes ahead of it today and then crashed in flames. At least fifteen men were killed.
The Government has begun advertising for bids for the sale of its twenty-seven synthetic rubber plants.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- A Bronx and Westchester department store chain sued in Supreme Court here today to balk construction in Yonkers of the proposed Central Park Avenue segment of the New York-to-Buffalo Thruway.
NEWTON - STEWART, Scotland, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Sir Adrian Dunbar, 60-year-old American farmer who inherited a Scottish baronetcy, arrived at his ancestral mansion today and found himself locked out.

Nearing the close of his eight years in office as Controller, Lazarus Joseph gives some sound advice on New York City's financial problems. The occasion is his required final report to the Board of Estimate and the City Council on the proposed 1954 capital budget. He points out anew that it is easy to borrow, but the reckoning always must be met in the expense budget, and by the taxpayer.

Employes and common stockholders of the Eastman Kodak Company shared in favorable dividend actions taken yesterday by the directors in Rochester. The moves reflected the greater sales and earnings reported for the quarter and the nine months as compared with the results for the corresponding periods last year.

Seventy years ago today the present system of standard time was officially adopted by the United States and Canada. Before that, time was of the essence of confusion, with each community and even each railroad keeping its own time.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- United Nations delegations were still searching for unanimity today on a disarmament resolution that in effect de-emphasizes the majority plan for atomic control.
The Coca-Cola Company had higher earnings in the third quarter and nine months this year than in 1952 and will pay the $1 year-end extra to common stockholders, as it did last year.

Big Board commission rates on stock transactions were raised 18 per cent more than a week ago. Evidently, however, those people interested in owning a seat on the New York Stock Exchange still are not too sure that transacting other folks' orders for securities will prove a profitable business even with a bigger commission.
Assistant Secretary of State John M. Cabot is performing a useful service in clarifying consistent misconceptions concerning our trade relations with Latin America.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The price recession in grains which started late yesterday was extended in the early trade this morning, but selling pressure abated and there was good recovery from the initial low spots. Commission absorption in wheat, corn and soybeans was active, while the liquidating sales, which were largely for the account of too-enthusiastic bulge buyers yesterday, proved of limited volume.
A faculty meeting at Columbia College has gone on record as being firmly opposed to present Congressional investigations of educational institutions as "unnecessary and harmful."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The Western Big Three reached agreement tonight on a resolution censuring the Israeli attack on the Jordanian village of Kibya.
" Escapade," a London hit, starts its New York career at 8 o'clock this evening at the Forty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, reaffirmed today his confidence that the European Defense Community Treaty would be ratified by France.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- The special convention of the International Longshoremen's Association absolved its retiring president, Joseph P. Ryan, today of all charges of stealing union funds.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Five Chrysler Specials -- pepped-up versions of the United States stock car -- were lined up against the pick of European sports entries as nearly 200 cars prepared today for the Pan-American road race.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Highland Scots are poor, proud and unused to asking for help, but the derelict state of their homeland has prompted launching of the Highland Fund to finance individual economic activity in an area largely untouched by the industrial revolution.

Raymond M. Miles, assistant controller of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., since 1942, has been elected controller and assistant treasurer. He succeeds Eugene F. Walsh, who has been elected vice president and treasurer of the company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Poland informed the United Nations Secretariat today that it was contributing $150,000 to the organization's Technical Assistance Pogram. But officials of the program are still not sure that the money will be there when they reach for it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Eisenhower's Commission on Foreign Economic Policy will conclude its hearings here on Thursday.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- Boston formally moved out of the horse and wagon era of marketing today with the dedication of a $12,000,000 terminal geared to the tempo of motor traffic.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The proposal to call a token twenty-four hour strike in the engineering industry was the main factor in the stock market's dullness today. With only a slight increase in selling volume, prices slipped back in all markets except those for mining and rubber shares.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The name St. Louis Browns passed into history officially to-day when stock-holders of the organization changed the formal name to Baltimore Baseball Club Inc., informally the Orioles. It was the last step in the franchise transfer.

The warmest Nov. 17 in fifty-seven years brought out shirtsleeve strollers yesterday, set roses and other flowers to blooming in sheltered gardens, and in general turned late fall into a sort of spring fantasy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee moved late today to expand at once its investigation of the case of Harry Dexter White.
The Inter-American Press Association's Executive Committee will meet here next Monday to consider measures for defending new threats to freedom of the press in Ecuador and Bolivia.
Handsome new examples of the American ceramist's work are on view in several shops here.

A couple in their early thirties began their roles of foster mother and father yesterday at a house-warming in a remodeled residence in Brooklyn. The three-story frame house in a quiet residential section of the Midwood area is the first "demonstration" foster home of the Jewish Child Care Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The trucking industry said today the Government could save about $100,000,000 a year by using more trucks instead of trains to carry the mail between cities up to 300 miles apart.
ISLIP, L. I., Nov. 17 -- This Suffolk township has set up roadblocks to check the condition of vehicles on its streets but has found the drivers need checking instead.
The "Drunkometer," a chemical gadget put into operation by the Police Department on Sunday to test the sobriety of drivers, had its first test on an arrested driver yesterday.
The search for the real owners of pari-mutuel harness racing tracks has been extended to all of the state's tracks.
A lawyer declared yesterday that manufacturers who fix store prices have lost their case before a group more powerful than any court -- the American public.

Confronted with Soviet rejection of three invitations to a Big Four conference issued within the last four months, the United States, Britain and France have at last come to the conclusion that the Soviet Government does not want any negotiations at this time except on its own impossible terms, and are acting accordingly.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 17 -- The court-martial trying former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh for rebellion heard today the first "witness." It was the recorded voice of Hossein Fatemi, former Foreign Minister, delivering a harangue against the monarchy during the disturbances of last August.

Johnny Vaught, Mississippi's coach, said Bernie Faloney's first-period pass interception halting a Rebel drive on Saturday was the turning point in Maryland's 38-0 rout of the team considered its toughest opponent.

Confronted with Soviet rejection of three invitations to a Big Four conference issued within the last four months, the United States, Britain and France have at last come to the conclusion that the Soviet Government does not want any negotiations at this time except on its own impossible terms, and are acting accordingly.

IF Martha Raye had a regular weekly television show this season, the chances are good that she would be pressing Lucille Ball for top honors among TV's comediennes. In her periodic appearances over N. B. C. she has been an extremely funny gal, and currently much the most amusing of the video ladies.
ROME, Nov. 17 -- The Chamber of Deputies rang with fierce denunciations of Britain this afternoon during the first day's debate on the Trieste situation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 -- Greek, Turkish and Yugoslav military representatives concluded today the talks they have been holding since Nov. 10 to work out specific plans for joint defense in the Balkans.
MANCHESTER, England, Nov. (UP) -- Colin Clark, an economist with a nation-wide reputation, said today a United States depression with 6,000,000 to 7,000,000 unemployed was all but inevitable.
Margaret Harshaw was suddenly compelled yesterday afternoon, by an attack of laryngitis, to cancel her scheduled appearance as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 17 (AP) -- America's Tony Trabert whipped Australia's Mervyn Rose in a strenuous five-set match played in 100-plus heat today to set up a preview of Davis Cup strength in the semi-finals of the New South Wales tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Eisenhower received at the White House today thirty trustees of the Eisenhower Exchange Fellowship, Inc., an organization through which foreign men and women will be brought to this country and Americans will be sent abroad for a year's specialized training.
Golfers need not expect any drastic change in the rules next year, the United States Golf Association said yesterday.
The first international fair devoted entirely to ships, shipping and other things nautical will open next May in Naples, an Italian Government official announced here yesterday.

Thirty-eight resolutions were fed yesterday into the City Council hopper. Four were said to have a slim chance of action before the present Council dies officially on Dec. 31 and all pending legislation is voided automatically.

Because the mental illness of children causes family problems far different from those resulting from other childhood ailments or disturbances, there is even greater need for parents to participate in group discussions of their individual problems with experienced leaders. Dr. Saul Gurevitz declared last night.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- A plague belt of small black flies, called coelopids, now extends for more than 100 miles along the south coast beaches of Britain, from Kent to Hampshire. Isolated swarms have reached the London area.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Advocates of high support prices are seeking short-term political gains more avidely than the long-term welfare of Agriculture, it was declared here today.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "The Man Between," a British-made melodrama directed and produced by Sir Carol Reed and starring James Mason, Claire Bloom and Hildegarde Neff, is at the Victoria. Harry Kurnitz wrote the screen play from an original story by Walter Ebert. Geoffrey Toone, Aribert Waescher, Ernst Schroeder and Dieter Krause are among the supporting players of the London Films offering, which Lopert Films is releasing.

Mal Whitfield of the Grand Street Boys, Olympic 800-meter champion, has been selected the outstanding athlete registered and competing in this district by the Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union meritorious award committee. Whitfield, who received 294 points, was named by the board of managers following a mail vote.

S. KELLOGG STRYKER, professional stamp man here, thinks he may have fallen into a tidy profit through a rush of wind. He was water-testing $5 postage stamps last spring in his home in Oradell, N. J., when his son and daughter tore through the study, the backwash lifting into the water pan some $1 stamps with Woodrow Wilson's image on them.

When Albert M. Cole was named Federal Housing Administrator last winter his appointment was widely criticized on the ground that his voting record as a member of Congress had shown him to be a consistent opponent of federally subsidized public housing. It had been hard enough to get even the present inadequate program through Congress in recent years without the additional handicap of an administrator who didn't like the whole idea in the first place.

Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, agreed yesterday with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, that espionage in the Signal Corps laboratories at Fort Monmouth, N. J., had extended through the post-war years and possibly as late as 1951.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Directors of Security-First National Bank today approved proposals to split the bank's stock two-for-one and to increase capital $7,500,000 by a 25 per cent stock dividend, according to George M. Wallace, chairman of the board.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- The United States answered today East Germany's spectacular series of spy trial announcements by charging the Communists there with a campaign of "brutal terror" to wipe out the opposition.

Leonard W. Hall, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Field he also hoped that Communists in the Federal Government would not be an issue in next year's Congressional elections.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold urged United Nations delegates today to grant at this session of the General Assembly his requests for increasing his powers of dismissal.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Favored Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles and Australia's Frank Sedgman advanced to the final of the international indoor professional tennis championships with straight-set victories today. They will meet for the title Friday night.

After twelve days of inter-party debate and Congressional investigation at least one fact emerges clearly. There was ample reason in 1945 and 1946 to question the loyalty of Harry Dexter White to the Government of which he was supposed to be the servant. This has been demonstrated not only by the impressive evidence introduced by Attorney General Brownell and F. B. I. Director Hoover.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- The Legislature approved unanimously today a bill that would permit New York City to make 40,000 of its employes eligible for benefits under the Federal Social Security program. The measure was sent to Governor Dewey.

Miss Jacqueline Byrne, 29 years old, an artist, of 423 East Fiftieth Street, became early today the second person to fail the Police Department's new "Drunkometer" test. In so doing she more than doubled the mark set for safe driving, the police said, and far exceeded the score made by the first man tested officially.

Earnings of $1,433,037 were reported yesterday by the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation. The statement, covering the thirty-nine weeks ended on last Sept. 26, includes the profits of subsidiaries.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 18 (UP) -- Federal Judge Albert L. Reeves said tonight that he would hand the fate of Carl Austin Hall and Mrs. Bonnie Brown Heady, the kidnappers and murderers of 6-year-old Bobby Greenlease, to a jury twenty-five minutes after he opened court tomorrow.

An increase last week of 1,222,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 144,954,000 barrels, compared with 143,732,000 a week earlier and 123,313,000 a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Eisenhower sought today to quiet India's fears about a possible military alliance between the United States and Pakistan.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

A syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and the Dominion Securities Corporation will place on the market here today a new issue of $18,600,000 of serial debentures of the city of Toronto, Ont.

The New York Produce Exchange has taken a twenty-five-year lease on nearly 21,000 square feet of space in the thirty-story building which will replace the present Exchange structure at 2 Broadway. About 12,000 square feet on the ground floor of the new structure will be used for a trading area, and about 9,000 square feet on the second floor will be occupied by executive offices.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Thirty to forty British business men were planning today to go to Moscow at the end of this month to promote trade with the Russians.

Eight engineers from other city departments inspected yesterday the $599,684 sewer section that Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens condemned Oct. 20 as "in danger of immediate collapse." Mr. Lundy wants the city to replace it.
Ilona Kabos, Hungarian born pianist, made her second recital appearance at Town Hall last evening. The artist made her debut there in December, 1951.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Israel urged the United Nations Security Council today to expedite its decision on Israeli preparations to divert the upper Jordan River for an electric power development.

Roger MacDougall's "Escapade," which has been fervently admired in London, has come to the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, where it opened last evening. Anglo-American relations will start deteriorating again. In the course of three shrill acts, Mr. MacDougall has some admirable things to say: That children are clearer-minded than adults, that peace must be won the hard way and that the signing of peace manifestoes by self-righteous egotists is not good enough.

The speech of Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell before the Congress of Industrial Organizations convention yesterday merits the approval of all fair-minded people, whether employers or employes. In his first public address since he was appointed the new Cabinet officer was frank, realistic in his promises and liberal in the expression of his beliefs and policies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Eisenhower indignantly bounced back to the press today the question whether his Administration had embraced "McCarthyism," as former President Truman charged in a speech Monday night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: While I was in Korea I was a member of the War Crimes Investigation Team on Koje Island at the United Nations Prisoner of War Camp. I would like to comment on the current report being submitted to the United Nations concerning the war atrocities committed by the North Korean People's Army.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 11, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -- James P. Mitchell, in his first major speech as Secretary of Labor, told the Congress of Industrial Organizations today that some provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act were "really dangerous to labor, really loaded and really unfair."

This is still the land of the free. And so the American Legion and a band of Indianapolis ladies known as the Minute Women have every right to protest, as they did, the use of the Indiana War Memorial Building for a meeting of the American Civil Liberties Union.
The New Jersey Highway Authority arranged yesterday to finance completion of the state's 156-mile-long Garden State Parkway linking Paterson and Cape May City at an interest cost of 2.7652 per cent.
The Yankees, the first of the local major league baseball clubs to do so, sent their 1954 reserve list of players to Commissioner Ford Frick's office yesterday.

Today's new film is Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's comedy. "Take The High Ground," at the Mayfair. Starred in the cast are Richard Widmark, Karl Malden and Elaine Stewart. Russ Tamblyn, Carleton Carpenter and Steve Forrest have featured roles.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, declared today the Soviet rulers were afraid to meet the West on European problems.

Senator Wicks has at last yielded to indignant public opinion and resigned his leadership posts. It was unthinkable that he should continue as majority leader of the Senate, President pro tem and Acting Lieutenant Governor -- posts that put him next in line to the Governor's seat in the event of emergency -- after disclosure of his several visits to Sing Sing Prison to see Joseph S. Fay, convicted labor extortionist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Justice Department denied tonight any change in the policy established during the Truman Administration against opening Federal loyalty files to Congressional inquiry committees.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- The United States, Britain and France made public today a resolution in which they will ask the United Nations Security Council to express "the strongest censure" of the Israeli raid last month on the Jordanian village of Kibya.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- This community will announce tomorrow the rezoning of 1,000 acres of choice property from a one to a two-acre category in a move to discourage undesirable development and preserve the character of the town.

Christmas is upon you, despite the recent balmy weather, if you want to send packages to brighten the day for soldiers, sailors and civilian personnel with our armed forces overseas. The Post Office had asked that all parcels headed for military and naval stations out of the country be mailed between Oct. 15 and Nov. 15.
Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced plans yesterday to distribute an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on Jan. 15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Sonja Steinman Gold of Pittsburgh, whose name was among those mentioned in yesterday's testimony by Mr. Brownell, testified before the House Committee on Un-American Activities in August, 1948, that she was not a member of the Communist party and never had been.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- All over the world, United States soldiers may as well face up to this fact: on Thanksgiving Day, whether they like it or not, the main dish for their main meal will be turkey.
LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -British and continental newspapers shook their heads sorrowfully today over the Harry Dexter White affair and prayed that it would soon be over.
New York's touch of Indian summer continued yesterday, with the mercury reaching a high of 68.8 degrees at 3:25 P.M. That made it the warmest Nov. 18 since 1928, when the temperature hit 71.
Thirteen convicted secondary Communist leaders charged yesterday in appeal briefs that they had not received a fair trial and that the trial judge had made reversible errors.

Walter A. Lynch, chairman of the boards of arbitration in the wage disputes between the Transport Workers Union and nine private bus lines, made the following statement yesterday in which he announced the arbitration awards:

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 18 -- Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. of New York and Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey, vacationing here, joined today in castigation of United States Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and the Republican National Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Representatives Steven B. Derounian and Frank J. Becker, Republicans of New York, declared today that closing of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, N. Y., would amount to "scuttling of our national maritime training policy."
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 19 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today the United States "made a mistake in 1946" when it advised Japan to do without an army and navy.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Favored Dan Bucceroni, a ranking heavyweight contender from Philadelphia, battered aging Freddie Beshore of Los Angeles for seven rounds tonight and then stopped him on a technical knockout in the eighth.

LINCOLN, R. I., Nov. 18 (UP) -- Parnassus, a 3-three-old son of War Admiral, won the richest race ever staged at Lincoln Downs as he led home a fifteen-horse field today in the $20,000 Autumn Handicap.

Gifts received by Teachers College, Columbia University, in the 1952-53 academic year reached a record total of $1,322,444, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William F. Russell, president of the college.
James A. Roe has no intention of resigning as Queens Democratic leader, a post he has held since 1938.

In the highly competitive cakemix market, manufacturers woo the home cook by a constant change of formulas and package designs. Apparently she responds by buying their products, for the number of cakes made with mixes now has a slight edge on the number home-baked from scratch.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Eisenhower received a new desk telephone today, the fifty millionth phone put into service in the United States. It is black, trimmed with gold and has the Presidential seal in the center of the dial. Forty-eight gold bars surround its base.

The American News Company has purchased a vacant plot at the southeast corner of Garfield Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street in Winfield, Queens, from Will Gottfried in a transaction negotiated by Queens Industrials as broker. The site, containing about 16,000 square feet of space, will be improved with a one-story building to be used as a garage and warehouse for the storage and distribution of magazines.

Cocktail and evening designs by Filcol Originals composed Arnold Constable's showing of glamorous evening attire yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The cocktail fashions were both slim and full-skirted, of satin and taffeta, the majority with flashing jeweled trim.
BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Primate of Poland, who recently was interned by the Polish Communist Government, has been charged with "initating a spy organization."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The City Council to take office on Jan. 1 will include two Republican Councilmen out of a total of twenty- five. Through an accident of fate Stanley S. Isaacs is joined by a member of his own party to constitute the total opposition to the Democratic majority for the next four years.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- The power and the glory of the Achaemenian Dynasty, founded by Cyrus the Great and reduced to charred rubble twenty-three centuries ago, will be recalled tomorrow in a book.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption averaged 35,237 bales each working day in October. This compared with an average of 36,022 for September and 36,992 for the corresponding period a year ago.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 18 -- The World Veterans Federation, meeting here in its fourth annual assembly, today named the "Unknown Soldier of Korea" as winner of its peace award for 1953.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Following is the text of the resolution on disarmament adopted by the United Nations General Assembly Political and Security Committee today:

Manual Training High retained the Brooklyn title and John Adams High kept the Queens team crown in the Public School Athletic League borough championship cross-Country races yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
SPARTANBURG, S. C., Nov. 18 -- The Spartanburg County Foundation, a community trust with a managed plan of philanthropy, will celebrate its tenth anniversary tomorrow.
ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- The Legislature abandoned today a controversial plan for redrawing the Brooklyn Senate district lines to favor election of Republican candidates there.
The new Institutional Investors Mutual Fund, owned by New York's mutual savings banks, favors "defensive" equities under present conditions, J. Wilbur Lewis, the fund's president, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Eisenhower said today that he did not believe the Federal budget could be balanced in the 1955 fiscal year, which starts next July 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- You could have knocked them over with an ice pick.
Price reductions ranging from $57 to $160 were offered on the 1954 line announced yesterday by Nash Motors division of the Nash Kelvinator Corporation.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 18 -- The military prosecutor diverted his fire today from former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh to hi co-defendant and former Chief of Staff, Brig. Gen. Taghi Riahi, at their court martial trial on charges of rebellion.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 18 -- The first phase of a national insurance program was adopted by the Knesset (Parliament) in Jerusalem today. It provides for compulsory insurance to cover the aged, survivors, maternity cases and victims of industrial accidents.

As far as jinxes are concerned, the New York Rangers are certain that they have disposed of the hoodoo that the Chicago Black Hawks use to have over them. Engaging the Windy City Skaters in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
BUFFALO, Nov. 18 -- Social workers were told here today to get more "aggressive" if they wanted to solve the problem of juvenile delinquency.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 -- Erwin D. Canham, editor of The Christian Science Monitor, told the Public Relations Society of America conference here today that the nation is going through a crucial testing time within the American political and economic communities.
Though still in its early stages, the much-publicized Kremlin program to increase food and consumer goods production already is running into obstacles.

Officers of the Algam Corporation, which owns Yonkers Raceway, have been subpoenaed by the Moreland Act Commission to explain how and why a convicted robber acquired 5,000 shares of the stock of the corporation.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The return of the one-platoon system was blamed by a University of Virginia doctor today for an "alarming" 30 per cent increase in injuries to players on Virginia's football squad.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 18 -India's "intense concern" over the possibility of a military alliance between the United States and Pakistan has given impetus to this young country's determination to begin formal talks at an early date.

An agreement under which American Red Cross units across the country will be able to call on the membership of the National Defense Transportation Association for assistance in disaster relief emergencies was signed yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- While the Communists booed and jeered, Premier Giuseppe Pella told the Chamber of Deputies today that The believed a solution of the Trieste problem could be found within the framework of the North Atlantic Treaty.

Tempers were ablaze in the Fire Department last night after the Civil Service Commission issued a promotion list for deputy chief showing that only thirty-four of 176 candidates had passed the eligibility examination.

The French chateau-style mansion of the late Augustus Van Horne Stuyvesant Jr., last of the direct descendants of Peter Stuyvesant, New Amsterdam's last Governor, became an auction room yesterday with the public buying its furnishings.
Dennison Manufacturing Company has entered into no negotiations to sell either of its New York City stores, H. E. Gorton, director of merchandising, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Douglas Skyrocket has flown 1,272 miles an hour, within split seconds of doubling the speed of sound.

Alfred Lunt, who has had a long and brilliant career in the theatre as an actor and director, will stage "Ondine," Maurice Valency's adaptation of the play by the late French dramatist, Jean Giraudoux.

A shipping agent here for a Canadian newsprint concern testified yesterday in General Sessions that after conversations with Michael Clemente, dock union leader, the agent placed checks or cash in sealed envelopes to be delivered to a "union hall."

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 17 -- Jordan will adopt a liberalized import program enabling her to purchase $30,800,000 in goods and services abroad during the coming fiscal year, the Government announced today.

An arbitration panel awarded the forty-hour week and a 26 1/2-cent hourly pay increase yesterday to 8,000 employes of nine privately operated bus lines in thecity. The arbitration proceeding was the outgrowth of a twenty-eight-day strike last January.
SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Both America's Davis Cup hopes -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas -- were beaten today in the semi - finals of the New South Wales tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- The Post Office Department dismissed Michael D. Fanning, Postmaster of Los Angeles, today, on charges of "favoritism, incompetence, inefficiency, waste and falsification of records."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 19 -- The nation's newspapers are the most effective media for attracting travel and resort customers, it was declared here today. This declaration was made at the National Association of Travel Organizations at the Greenbriar Hotel by George Zuckerman, director of publicity and promotion for Asbury Park, N. J. "

Shipbuilding in this country, is so far as the private shipyards are concerned, fell to a new low last month with only fifty-two seagoing vessels of 1,000 gross tons or more under construction or on order.

Activity continued to improve yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Volume in potatoes surpassed that of Tuesday and was at the highest point since May 1. Zinc registered the best trading since Sept. 21 and coffee since Oct. 15.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Donald Niven Wheeler, named yesterday by J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as once a spy suspect, said that the allegation was "entirely false and malicious."

The servantless home of today affords the American woman "far less leisure than her grandmother or her great-grandmother had," despite the advent of modernized household appliances and synthetic fibers, according to Mrs. Dorothy Swenson.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Eisenhower laid down today a broad pattern for conferences with Republican and Democratic leaders to help him draw up his legislative program for next year.

The fundamental attitude of the United States Government toward Soviet imperialism has been outlined anew by Secretary Dulles in his Cleveland speech, in which he proclaims in effect a Dulles Doctrine that may take its place beside the Monroe Doctrine, the Stimson Doctrine and the Truman Doctrine as a basis of our international relations.
Wayne County, Mich., announced yesterday that there would be offered for sale on Dec. 16 an issue of $3,565,000 of bonds of the Middle River Parkway Interceptor Drainage District.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- Dr. Harold C. Case, president of Boston University, said today that Prof. Maurice Halperin, chairman of the Department of Latin-American Studies had been suspended pending a re-study of his activities in the Office of Strategic Services during World War II.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A Chicago banker said today "Government regulation of installment credit is absolutely unnecessary."

The Bakelite Company has started quantity production and marketing of microscopic plastic balloons that it believes may eventually save the United States oil industry as much as $60, 000,000 a year. The balloons, varying from .0002 to .0036 of an inch in diameter, are designed to be floated on the surface of crude oil in storage tanks to reduce evaporation.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The stock markets had a patchy appearance today. Industrial shares continued to sag chiefly because of the possibility of labor trouble in the engineering industry.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said today he thought he had "set the record straight" in his speech on the Harry Dexter White controversy.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, told members of its new International Longshoremen's Association last night that they had broken the grip of the old longshoremen's gang on the Port of New York.

Janet Blair, in 414 E 52d St; Derek O'Donoghue, through Brown, Harris, Stevens Inc, in 1133 Park Ave; Robert B. Meyer, in 1172 Park Ave; Dr. Kemp Clark, in 19 E 66th St; Mrs. Judy Goodbody, in 924 Madison Ave; Mrs. Paul W. Bates, in 36 1/2 E 75th St; Albert L. Worthen,
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr., calling the current legislative reapportionment proposals "shameful" and "immoral," last night demanded that Governor Dewey veto the bill passed by the Legislature.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A new medical machine developed here can record a heart beat at the same time it checks the amount of oxygen in your lungs and body cells.

Women active in furthering the work of the Big Brother Movement have taken over a block of seats in the mezzanine for the performance of the Christmas show at the Radio City Music Hall on the night of Dec. 17 to raise funds for the organization. Mrs. Henry B. Guthrie is chairman and Mrs. Nichola Danforth, honorary chairman. Among their aides are Mrs. G. Edgar Hackney and Mrs. Lewis C. Murdock.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- The refusal of nine employes of the General Electric Company at Lynn, Mass., to say whether they were Communists yesterday convinced Senator Joseph A. McCarthy that a party cell was in operation there, the Senator said.

Standing Still in Time Though 'clocks tick and strike the hours, though leaves are taken from calendars, and though seasons change in their appointed days, man subconsciously tends to think of time, in relation to himself, as standing still.

Stockholders of the National Cash Register Company at a special meeting in Baltimore yesterday voted to amend the company's charter to clear the way for a 10 per cent stock dividend previously proposed.

MANILA, Nov. 19 -- President Elpidio Quirino resumed his campaign theme of American intervention in Philippine politics today. He accused Maj. Gen. Robert M. Cannon, chief of the United States Military Advisory Group, of "politicking."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- United Nations delegations voted today for the idea of a private conference among the major powers on the long-disputed question of disarmament and atomic control.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 19 -- The United Nations special envoy, Arthur H. Dean, told the Communists at Panmunjom today he thought their support for the participation of neutrals in the Korean peace conference concealed "some hidden purpose."
CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -- Following is the text of the address delivered at the Congress of Industrial Organizations convention today by James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor:

Herman Basch has purchased for investment the ten-story and penthouse apartment building on plot 50 by 120 feet at 952 Fifth Avenue, near Seventy-sixth Street, from a client of the Walter Scott Management Company who bought it recently.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 18 -- Apprehension over Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson's reorganization of the Soil Conservation Service was expressed today at the annual meeting of the National Grange.

The American Pipe Manufacturers Association said yesterday that President Eisenhower's rejection of the Federal Tariff Commission's recommendation to increase import duties on low-priced briarwood pipes "constitutes a death blow to the domestic briarwood pipe industry."

While many companies are experiencing cut-backs in defense orders, one of the top can manufacturers is enjoying big business from this source. Thomas C. Fogarty, executive vice president of the metal division of the Continental Can Company, reported yesterday the highest aircraft and defense work sales in the company's history for the first nine months this year.

NEWARK, N. J. Nov. 18 -Dr. Abraham Wolfson, who was described by the Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr., as a Communist friend of Harry Dexter White, had been a prominent dentist here for years until his death on July 18, 1952.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 --"It seams to me," said Attorney General Brownell to the Senate subcommittee yesterday in comment on former President Truman's explanation of his handling of the Harry Dexter White case, "that this raises more questions than it answers." That comment could be made with equal truth about the entire record in the case. For examples:
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- The twenty-six-year reign of Joseph P. Ryan as president of the International Longshoremen's Association came to an end with his resignation here today.

The building with eighty-three apartments and four stores at 3235 Grand Concourse in the Bronx was bought by the Pleasantville Realty Corporation from Sam Schwartz and resold to the Lenlad Realty Corporation for cash above mortgages of $455,000. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers in both transactions.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Iowa's Bill Fenton, whose rugged end play in Iowa's unexpected 27-0 victory over Minnesota earned him honors as The Associated Press lineman of the week, is hoping for another Hawkeye surprise against Notre Dame Saturday.

Advertisers who cut their advertising budgets as well as those who increase them will find it necessary to spend more money and thought on merchandising their advertising to the consumer next year. This is the conclusion stated in the latest issue of the Bach letter, published monthly by Henry Bach Associates, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, a session attended by 179 reporters. Because conference rules forbid direct quotation of the President, his remarks are given in the form of indirect discourse.

Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., opened a $1,500,000 six-story addition yesterday adjoining its main store at Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. The opening attracted a crowd estimated at 7,000 to 8,000.

A warning that New York and most areas of large populations in the United States were faced with a "continuous problem" of finding fresh water sources was given yesterday by Col. B. B. Halley of the Army Engineers Corps.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -Representatives of New Jersey seashore resorts, aroused by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's statement that the state would not seek federal aid to repair damage caused by the Nov. 6 gale voted today to ask him to reconsider.

Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education for fifteen years until last May, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters at Brooklyn College's tenth annual honors day convocation yesterday.

Paintings, pastels and graphic work by a late nineteenth-century artist, whose early work looks back to Corot and the impressionists, and whose later work forecasts German expressionism of the Nineteen Twenties, make up a very interesting show at the gallery of Hirschl Adler, 270 Park Avenue.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Nov. 19 -- A direct clash between the Indians and the Communists is the latest reason the prisoner-of-war explanation sessions have been brought to a halt.

Three individuals, a welding supply company and a plumbing supply concern were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of forging and submitting false bids for $1,500,000 in supplies for the Air Force building program in North Africa.

Many parties were given at the annual tea dance and fashion show for the benefit of the Judson Health Center, which was held yesterday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Paul H. Raymer headed the committee in charge of the plans for the fete. Miss Olivia E. Hutchins was chairman of the debutante committee.

Almost lost amid the proposals, counter-proposals, attacks and charges that flew about during the two days of Board of Estimate hearings on the proposed capital budget for 1954 was a suggestion that deserves attention by city officials. That is the offer of Harold Riegelman to have the Citizens Budget Commission, for which he is counsel, make for the city a detailed review of the capital budget-making procedure.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Mr. Nixon said in his speech today that if the Korean war had not been fought "Japan today would be under the domination of Communist imperialism."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -President Eisenhower reiterated today that he looked upon the forthcoming Bermuda conference as a round-table discussion without formal agenda, an occasion for seeking solutions of the problems common to the United States, France and Britain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The position currently taken by the new A. F. of L. International Longshoremen's Union puts the weight of all organized labor in opposition to the compulsory registration of workers. It also removes the only sound argument that Joseph P. Ryan and his clique had for continuing in the leadership of the I. L. A.

Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country on the testimony Herber Brownell Jr., Attorney General, and J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, gave to the Senate Internal Security sub-committee Tuesday in the Harry Dexter White case, as gathered by The Associated Press and The United Press:
NEWARK, Nov. 18 -- William J. Egan, chairman of the Essex County Democratic Committee for the last three years, said today that he planned to retire.

Lee R. Pennington, veteran inspector at the Federal Bureau of Investigation headquarters in Washington, has been appointed director of the American Legion's National Americanism Commission. Mr. Pennington will assume his new duties on Monday at Legion headquarters in Indianapolis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -Hollywood's army of unemployed writers found a few faint rays of sunshine in the annual report submitted to the Screen Writers Guild membership last night by Richard Breen, the retiring president.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A former member of James A. Leary's law firm testified today that as a nominee for Mr. Leary he held property and sold it to the Saratoga Harness Racing Association, but did not receive the $15,000 sale money.

Word has been passed to liquor wholesalers here that the paper work involved in selling liquor free of New York State tax to United Nations personnel and other diplomats here has been eased by the Beverage Tax Bureau of the State Department of Taxation and Finance.

Picketing of Grace Line piers by members of Local 22, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., was barred permanently yesterday by Justice Edgar N. Nathan Jr. in New York Supreme Court. The union had been under temporary restraint since Oct. 1.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- This high corner of the Catskill deer zone provides something more than a "big woods" illusion. Its hardwood ridges not only harbor an adequate number of deer, but also provide the hunter with an opportunity to stretch his legs.

" How to Lie With Statistics" is coming out in the statistical first month of the new year and will divulge some deep secrets on handling figures, according to Norton, the publisher. Written by Darrell Huff and illustrated by Irving Geis, it will tell how to be a success with a souped-up graph, a well-chosen average, an insignificant difference and "the everimpressive" decimal.
A member of the House Ways and Means Committee gave business men assurance yesterday that Congress would consider concrete and specific plans to ease "double taxation."

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The Government defended in the House of Commons today a bill it is sponsoring for modification of the functions of the Raw Cotton Commission. Provision also is made for its eventual dissolution.
ARLINGTON, Wash., Nov. 18 -- The United States Navy in a history-making episode flashed a message today to its globe-scattered craft and units -- on land, and on and under the sea.
Youth is no deterrent to a group of designers now rising to prominence in this city's great garment industry.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Cabinet submitted its resignation in a dispute over foreign policy, but the Generalissimo refused to accept it, high official sources said today.
TRENTON, Nov. 18 -- The nucleus of a state-wide citizens committee whose ultimate goal is the establishment in New Jersey of a state medical-dental school and health center was formed here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -- Thomas J. Donovan of New York City, vice president, Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., charged here today that tax-inflated prices are forcing the average American citizen out of the legal liquor market.

JAMES JOSEPH DYKES is a reformed man. When the Mack brothers, Roy and Earle, gave the bounce to Jimmie as the manager of the Athletics, they offered as one reason the fact that the Little Round Man played too much golf.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Eisenhower said today he hoped the Communists-in-Government question would not be an issue in the 1954 Congressional campaign.
Start of construction of the long-delayed New York Coliseum was finally in sight yesterday.

VANCOUVER, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Payloads on Canadian Pacific Airlines operating to Tokyo may have to be reduced because of removal of a United States weather ship stationed in the North Pacific.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- A college professor who once worked on a secret atomic project at the University of California today refused to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee if he ever belonged to the Communist party.

The draw for the second annual Holidays Basketball Festival, an eight-team, three-day event which opens at Madison Square Garden Dec. 26, was made yesterday. Asa S. Bushnell announced the results at Leone's Restaurant on behalf of the Metropolitan Basketball Committee, sponsor of the tournament.

The pilot of the airliner involved in the first fatal accident at New York International Airport said yesterday at a public hearing that there was a decrease in visibility as he attempted to take off and that the plane never rose above the fog.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- One of those unusual occurrences in modern Parliaments, a revolt in the House of Lords, appeared to be shaping up today over the question of commercial television.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The United States tonight clinched the international low-score jumping competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair by winning the team event, the final phase of the three-day tests.
Stockholders of the Kings County Trust Company will receive a 300 per cent stock dividend after a two-and-one-half for one stock split, according to plans announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Two New Yorkers, alleged to have been long active in the Communist party today lost appeals from deportation orders.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Eight of the thirty-three Army Signal Corps civilian employes who were dismissed from their laboratory jobs a month ago reported back for duty today but were not assigned to their old jobs, according to one of their counsel.

PARIS Nov. 18 (UP) -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther has ordered an immediate 20 per cent reduction in officer personnel at Supreme Allied Headquarters in Europe, which has almost doubled since the command was created thirty-one months ago.

BATHURST, Gambia, Nov. 10 -- The expression "broke but happy" often is used these days to describe Gambia, Britain's smallest West African colony. To the inquisitive visitor, this would appear to be a reasonably accurate statement.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- In spite of assurances from many major United States spokesmen, the Germans are still hearing reports that the United States military forces in Europe will be reduced. These reports are causing some worry.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Yale and Harvard meet in the Bowl here Saturday, with the Big Three football championship at stake for the first time since 1946. A crowd of 60,000 is expected.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 18 -Hugh S. Cumming Jr., United States Ambassador, has denied speculative Indonesian press reports that Washington had threatened Indonesia if this country concluded a Pacific rubber pact with Communist China.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A crowd of 9,583 watched Mrs. Jules Schwartz' Fair Brother win the Prince George Purse by a nose today in the kind of inviting weather that the absentee Larry MacPhail gladly would have paid for last fall.
PARIS. Nov. 18 -- The feeling here that the French are under United States and British pressure as they seek to formulate their European policy was illustrated by reports of today's cabinet meeting.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government gave publicity today to a newly published booklet describing in detail the horrors of Hitler's first major anti-Jewish pogrom.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Eisenhower urged today that religious cooperation be accented and differences minimized in the interests of advancing democracy in this country.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Irregular price trends marked trading in grains today. Wheat was strong for a time early, but again failed to enlist outside buying support on the rallies.
The synthetic oil plant of Carthage Hydrocol, Inc., at Brownsville, Tex., may be acquired by the Stanolind Oil and Gas Company, Guy Gabrielson, president of Carthage Hydrocol, announced yesterday.
In a day that saw twenty new lows for the year and only six new highs, the stock market yesterday responded to excellent earnings reports and dividend announcements and closed with a small net gain.

An all-star fun/[ raising p;ogram, which will not receivetlephoned pledges from viewers while the show is in progress, will be presented over the A. B. C. television network on Wednesday from 11 P. IVf. to 1 . M.

A strong stand against discriminatory employment practices in Brooklyn was taken yesterday by thirty-seven leading women's organizations of the borough. They called on all employers to hire workers on the basis of "ability alone."

This country should move with greater consistency toward reduction of import barriers, Eugene Holman, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, said last night. He stressed the need to eliminate uncertainties in this phase of United States foreign policy.

" Anti-tension teams" from Fisk University, working with local volunteer groups, have helped improve inter-group relations in a score of American communities, the United Negro College Fund forum was told yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -Thirty-seven communities, with about 33 per cent of the state population, have considered changes in their form of government in the last thirty months, the New Jersey State League of Municipalities was told today.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 18 -- Former Premier Urho Kekkonen's remarks that he had been seeking closer ties with the Soviet Union caused surprise in this capital today.
The Glen Cove mansion occupied by the Soviet Union on Long Island's exclusive North Shore was put on notice for public sale last night because of $2,396 in unpaid taxes owed to Nassau County.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Following is the text of a draft resolution presented to the Security Council today by the United States, Britain and France on recent Israeli-Jordanian border incidents:

ANDRE MALRAUX' "The Voices of Silence"* is the most challenging book on art and art's place in the life of man that has appeared in a generation. It is a portly volume (about the size of a box of cigars for Sir Winston Churchill) glowing with a brilliant galaxy of pictures and the sparks of innumerable ideas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Senate investigators produced today documentary evidence to show that John W. Snyder, former Secretary of the Treasury, promoted an alleged spy and praised him two years later even after he had been denounced publicly.
A twenty-year-old bottleneck under the George Washington Bridge will be eliminated tomorrow when a new ramp leading from the span to the southbound lanes of Henry Hudson Parkway will go into service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -President Eisenhower plans to spend Thanksgiving as most grandfathers would like to do -romping with his grandchildren.

The increase in the aggregate short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange between Oct. 15 and Nov. 13 was the greatest since January, 1951. The total was the largest since February of this year.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 17 -- Because of a New York aural surgeon, life may be made easier for about 40,000 Israelis, handicapped professionally or socially by hearing defects.

Television station WABD canceled a program last night featuring George Blake Charney, labor secretary of the New York Communist party, on the ground that "our facilities should not be used for Communist propaganda."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Neil Johnston scored 41 points for the Warriors tonight but his fine performance went for naught as the New York Knickerbockers gained an 88-83 triumph over Philadelphia in a National Basketball Association game.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were somewhat irregular again yesterday. The closing prices were 1 point off to 8 up, the distant months showing the most strength.
ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks resigned today, effective tomorrow, as Majority Leader and Temporary President of the State Senate.

Consumers need more information about lighting as well as better, non-expensive devices to do the job, it was agreed Tuesday evening at a meeting of the Residential Lighting Forum at the Consolidated Edison Company, 4 Irving Place.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- The need for cutting farm operating costs through mechanization points to good business for the agricultural implement industry for many years to come, members of the American Bankers Association were told today.
A program to expedite traffic on the New Jersey side of the George Washington Bridge will be completed about Jan. 1 by the Port of New York Authority.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Cook County American Legion's anti - subversive committee called on members of civic, veteran and school groups today to boycott Lillian Hellman's play "The Children's Hour."

Alfred Fromm announced yesterday the formation of Carmel Wine Company, Inc., with offices at 400 Madison Avenue, to market a new wine from Israel. Mr. Fromm, it was emphasized, maintains his position as vice president and treasurer of Fromm Sichel, Inc., proprietor of the Paul Masson vineyards and wineries in California and distributor of the Christian Brothers wines and brandies.

In a city as well provided as is New York for the souvenir hunter, especially in a year when many of our local mementos are specially emblazoned with commemorative legends relative to the city's tercentenary, we are happy to recommend without qualification a modest but attractive little item which goes on sale for the first time today down on Thirty-fourth Street at the corner of Park Avenue.
The Jewel Tea Company, Inc., has arranged to borrow $5,000,000 privately from two insurance companies on 3% per cent notes issuable by November, 1955, and due on Nov. 1, 1978.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Tony Manero of Greenwich, Conn., teamed with Victor Cohen and Fred Wilk, both of the host club, for best-ball cards of 29, 31 -- 60 in heading fifty-five rival teams in a Westchester post-season pro-amateur golf tournament at the Vernon Hills Country Club today.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -- The Argentine Government has posed a ticklish problem for the United States Government by buying a steel mill owned by Czechoslovakia. According to sources here the United States Government embargoed the shipment of a modern mill to Czechoslovakia in 1949 and the crated plant is scattered in warehouses throughout the United States.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation increased its earnings in the nine months to Sept. 30 to two and a half times the 1952 figure. The total also surpassed every full year's profits in its history, according to figures reported yesterday by Robert E. Gross, president.

Half a million more children were employed in 1950 than in 1940, and their total was 1,300,000 at the last count, according to the National Child Labor Committee. Most were part-time workers. The group's annual report was presented yesterday at a directors' meeting at the Gramercy Park Hotel.
Both the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations gave the cold shoulder yesterday to the orphaned International Longshoremen's Association.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- West Berlin's political parties, which recently have been at odds with one another on almost everything else, achieved unanimity today in attacking Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner, for having licensed another newspaper in Berlin.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- Governor Dewey was disclosed today to have been ready to file impeachment charges against Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston if Mr. Wicks had not resigned as temporary President of the State Senate.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- Governor Dewey signed into law today the Republican program for redrawing the state's Senate district lines and defended it as being "in precise accord" with the constitutional requirements for legislative reapportionment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The United States today renewed its request to Canada that Senate espionage investigators, be permitted to question a former code clerk of the Soviet Embassy in Canada. The State Department transmitted to Ottawa, for the Second time and with renewed official endorsement, a request by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee that subcommittee investigators be permitted to question Igor Gouzenko.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The first nation-wide token strike in Britain's history was voted today by the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions.
The American Government and people have been served a cynical ultimatum by Abdel Khalik Hassouna, Secretary General of the Arab League, as reported in your issue of Nov. 15.

The influence of American design in home furnishings is evident everywhere in Europe, Stanley Salzman said yesterday, reporting on a recent trip abroad. Mr. Salzman, architect and industrial designer, spoke at the New York School of Interior Design, 29 East Seventy-second Street.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Mississippi's proposed program to give Negro and white children the same educational opportunities cleared a major hurdle in the State Senate today.
An equipment interchange agreement involving three of the country's major airlines has been recommended by a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Members of the New Jersey Bankers' Association were told here today that "caution" is the dominant note in the present consumer credit picture.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Former Premier Rene Mayer told the National Assembly tonight that the overthrow of France's foreign policy by a "negative coalition" that agreed on no alternative policy would be "not only grave but Criminal."

Upon ending a visit to Italy on Aug. 28, 1944, Prime Minister Churchill composed a message to the Italian people setting forth some tests of freedom. "This does not seem to require any alteration to-day," he writes in the current volume. The teats as he set them forth follow:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Hugh O'Brian and Buddy Hackett will take over the lead spots in "Fireman Save My Child," which the comedy team of Bud Abbott and Lou Costello had been scheduled to make for Universal-International.
More eviscerated turkeys will be in retail stores for this Thanksgiving than in any previous year, the Consumers Service Bureau of the city Department of Markets reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- During the week ended Nov. 18 member bank reserves increased $414,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 19 -- On the eve of the official opening of the citrus export season, planters and the Government were still deadlocked today over the exchange rate growers will get for foreign currency earnings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- The Government today revoked an order designed to prevent synthetic rubber consumption from falling below 510,000 tons a year.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Randolph Churchill, son of the prime Minister, accused The Times of London and The Daily Mail tonight of suppressing his speeches to "protect the pornographic papers from criticism."

NEWARK, Nov. 19 -- The products of twenty-five New Jersey specialists in handicraft will be on display and for sale beginning tomorrow in the Newark Museum's fourth annual Christmas Craftsmen Exhibition.
The United States Golf Association has called on its member clubs to halt the distribution of the smaller golf ball, which is illegal for use in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals agreed today to hear oral argument Dec. 23 on a motion to rescind or have reviewed an order of the Federal Power Commission granting New York State authority to join Canada in the building of the St. Lawrence River Power Project.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 19 -- Military representatives of Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia have signed an agreement defining their mutual obligation in a joint defense against aggression in the Balkans.
BUFFALO, Nov. 19 -- Proposals to encourage private industries to invest in the development of atomic energy received further impetus here today.
The cotton fuures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed somewhat irregular yesterday, 4 points up to 2 points off.
Nobody but Santa Claus himself will arrive at Gimbels tomorrow. And what will he bring with him? Nothing but eight live -- but slightly phony -- "reindeer."

The remarkable thing about "Don Juan Tenorio," which the Spanish Theatre brought here last night for the first time since 1932, is the durability of the play itself. For not only were the rolling cadences of Jose Zorrilla resounding in the Broadhurst Theatre.

Volunteer donors gave 1,180 pints of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Wednesday, making the day's receipts the greatest so far this month. Camp Kilmer, New Brunswick, N. J., led with a contribution of 306 pints. At Lever Brothers, 390 Park Avenue, employes gave 292 pints. Masons gave 226 pints at the Grand Lodge, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, delivered today a slashing attack on the economic and social policies of the Administration to a cheering convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today.

In the face of a violent press campaign the United States Ambassador to Indonesia has been obliged to declare that the United States has not informed Indonesia that it will cut off all assistance if Indonesia goes ahead with the projected plan to negotiate sales of rubber to Red China. This episode has some salutary lessons.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Sir Roger Makins, British Ambassador to the United States, said today that neither public clamor nor the "outraged cries" of well-meaning idealists must be permitted to upset the balance of armament and diplomatic policies of the Western democratic alliance.

Directors of the National Cash Register Company voted a 10 per cent stock dividend yesterday on the common, payable on Dec. 15. A quarterly dividend of 75 cents a common share, payable on Jan. 15, was also authorized.
Burke M. McConnell has been appointed vice president in charge of merchandising spun blend fabrics of Textron, Inc.

MONTREAL, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- New regulations have been approved to allow international airlines to carry such special cargoes as radioactive isotopes on an "interline" bases, the International Air Transport Association Traffic Conference announced today.

The showpiece of the City Park Department's recreational program, the $2,000,000 St. Mary's Recreation Center in the Bronx, is being used by youth of the congested community, from 40 to 81 per cent of capacity, an inspection showed yesterday.

The garden type apartment group comprising ten buildings and ten garages at 209-24 to 209-46 Thirty-fourth Road and 209-43 Thirtyfifth Avenue in Bayside, Queens, has been sold by Mrs. Gertrude H. Calfee to an investing customer of Horace S. Ely Co., brokers in the transaction.
The American Arbitration Association honored the memory of one of its pioneers, the late Miss Frances Kellor, by dedicating one of its hearing rooms at 7 Rockefeller Plaza to her yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19 -- Radcliffe College undertook today a $2,000,000 campaign for the building and endowing of a graduate quadrangle to achieve the "one element of strength" lacking in its educational plant.

The banking and finance industry stands ready to do "whatever is feasible to help management in these competitive days." This assurance was given yesterday by Herbert R. Silverman, vice president of James Talcott, Inc., a large old-line commercial factor.
A liberal foreign trade policy, free of constant changes and giving the fullest play to private enterprise, was urged on the United States Government yesterday by a prominent business organization.

A collection of unusual tablecloths has been designed by Erwin and Estelle Laverne. Four of the cloths described here may be found at Bloomingdale's in a week; four others are available through decorators at the Laverne Originals showroom, 160 East Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) - The Department of Agriculture announced today a new subsidy program designed to increase wheat exports.

The Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., settled their dispute over new economy schedules for city-owned transit lines yesterday. They thereby cleared the way for an annual operating saving of $1,434,400.

MONTREAL, Nov. 19 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens maintained their two-point lead in the National Hockey League tonight as Bernie Geoffrion's second-period goal and Gerry McNeil's flawless goaltending produced a 1-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs before 14,421 fans at the Forum.

The indivisibility of liberty and the vital part that freedom of the press plays in it are being well demonstrated in Ecuador and Bolivia today. Both countries are violating the canons of a free press in a shocking way and both are thereby exacerbating internal problems and making a deplorable impression abroad.
Reuben Kaplan has been appointed director of new home sales of Kraham Realty of Kew Gardens, Queens. He was formerly sales director of Warfield Tarlofsky, builders of homes on Long Island.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Princeton University's football team next fall will play a nine-game schedule, including all seven other members of the informal Ivy League.

Artificially produced variants of chemical elements that give off positive electrons are being used successfully to detect, as well as to locate, hidden brain tumors that otherwise would mean certain death.

Shipments of steel products from the nation's mills in September, at 6,400,757 tons were down about 141,000 tons from the total in the same month of last year. This was the first time the shipments had fallen below the year-earlier level since the strike period in the summer of 1952.

The Federal Communications Commission has granted permission for the National Broadcasting Company to televise the "Comedy Hour" in color on Sunday from 8 to 9 P. M. on an experimental basis. Donald O'Connor will be the star.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky denounced today an Army publication that had been attacked by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as "Communist propaganda."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Russians have produced probably the most venomous anti-American movie in the history of their film industry.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The General Electric Company tried 2,468 times today to prevent a Manhattan mother's being harassed by misdirected telephone calls from its electronic tube customers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation disclosed today that it had accepted bids for only thirty-nine of the 171 lots of bonds that the agency put up for sale on Tuesday. The bonds were issues of public agencies and had a par value of $1,600,700.

In the resolution of censure to be introduced today in the Security Council of the United Nations by the United States, Great Britain and France the tragic Kibya raid is described as a "retaliatory action." There is no question in anybody's mind that the attack was provoked by a long series of Arab incursions on Israeli villages in the inflamed borderland between Israel and Jordan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Appointment of Alice K. Leopold, Secretary of State of Connecticut, to succeed Frieda S. Miller as Director of the Women's Bureau, Department of Labor, was announced by the White House late today.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the annual Bagby concert for the benefit of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., which will take place on Monday afternoon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Five members of the Board of Education today forecast swift action in the cases of public school teachers who refused to testify on alleged Communist affiliation before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Mixed movements were the rule in the grain futures market today. Wheat was under pressure, with considerable long liquidation developing in December. Corn turned strong after a slight early dip in sympathy with other grains.

The New York Zoological Park in the Bronx has negotiated a "swap in snakes" with the Colombo Zoological Gardens in Ceylon. The purpose is to help build up what Dr. James A. Oliver, curator of reptiles in the local zoo, describes as a "spectacular collection."
