PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers defeated the Baltimore Bullets tonight, 96 -- 85, for their third straight victory in the National Basketball Association. Carl Braun tallied 28 points for the winners.

Preparations are being made by Norman Rose and Peter Capell to produce "The Gimmick" on Broadway in late February or early March. The author of the comedy is Joseph Julian, an actor. Basically, his play, which is said to have several surprise twists, deals with a playwright's struggle for security.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Two old men, a Labor politician who went to work in the coal mines at the age of 12, and the Prime Minister, who was a cavalry officer in the army of Queen Elizabeth's great-great-grandmother, today bade the Queen Godspeed On her voyage round the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- President Eisenhower, garbed in academic gown, declared today there was no peace in military strength alone, but pleaded for universal knowledge and understanding as the fundamental basis of a tranquil world.
A recital of considerable distinction was played by Maurice Wilk, the violinist, at Town Hall last evening.
EAST NORWICH, L. I., Nov. 19 -- The Russians have gone into the red on taxes for another mansion in Nassau County.
A 42-year-old Queens housewife was committed yesterday to Kings County Hospital for mental observation after the slaying of her husband with a stone-cutter's hammer and a night table.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The Israeli delegation to the United Nations charged today that a move by the United States, Britain and France to censure the Israeli raid on the Jordan village of Kibya "crystallizes and conserves all the causes of tension in our area." Fifty-three persons were killed in the raid.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $30,460,000 in the public market yesterday to continue the temporary financing of five state-aided projects. Borrowing cost ranged from 1.25 per cent to 1.30 per cent less dollar premiums ranging from $48 to $80.

Members of the alumnae of Barnard College are active in plans for the reception to be held this afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club for Professor Emerita Minor Latham, who taught drama at Barnard for thirty-four years until her retirement in 1948.

" Transocean: The Story of an Unusual Airline," by Richard Thruelsen, combines biography with industrial history. It will be published by Holt on Nov. 30. The book presents a story of the life of Orvis Nelson, whose flying career began in the days when the Army flew the mails.

HERSHEY, Pa., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Harold Johnson of Philadelphia, No. 1 contender for the world light heavyweight title, tonight scored a unanimous 10-round decision Byer Chubby Wright, steelworker from Reading, Pa. Johnson, at 177, conceded 9 pounds to Wright, but made up for it in speed and punching power.
EASTON, Md., Nov. 19 -- Twenty-six dogs remained in the running for the national retriever championship after one land and two water series today.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, U. S. A., Retired, the new president of the Greater New York Fund, and John A. Coleman, the new chairman of the fund's board of directors, who were elected to office Wednesday evening, paid tribute to each other yesterday at fund headquarters, 11 West Forty-second Street.
Durable Dick Carr, Columbia quarterback, will have a chance to set another record in the final game of the season when the Lions meet Rutgers at Baker Field tomorrow.
ROME, Nov. 19 -- Diplomatic representatives of thirty - eight countries expressed sympathy to Pope Pius XII today about religious persecution in Poland.
WASHINGTON, Nov 19 -- It was "Ladies' Day" at the White House today.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Three Communist soldiers raced across the demilitarized zone last night, pursued by Communist security troops, and surrendered to American military police.

Arturo Toscanini, in fine spirits and seeming fully recovered from the respiratory ailment that forced him to cancel two appearances with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, rehearsed the orchestra for the first time this season at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

Chico Vejar, Stamford (Conn.) welterweight, now a soldier stationed at Fort Benning, Ga., will attempt to repeat his upset victory of eight months ago when he faces Vince Martinez, 24-year-old performer from Paterson, N. J., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A composition by Boris Blacher, a man who has emerged out of post-war Europe with a reputation of some substance, was introduced to this country by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night.

The old basketball rivalry between City College and New York University is in danger of being terminated. City College's General Faculty Committee on Intercollegiate Athletics made it clear yesterday that there would be no contest between the teams this season at any place except the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's remarks after receiving an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at the special convocation marking the fifteenth year of the establishment of the National Catholic Educational Association of the Catholic University of America:
Some New Yorkers may see mail being transported by a horseman this morning.
Can the city stop a person who owns a water-cooled gas refrigerator from using it if he is willing to run the risk of poisoning himself with carbon monoxide?

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The United States made official today its stand against payment by the General Assembly of compensation to eleven United States employes of the United Nations dismissed for having refused to testify in Congressional loyalty investigations.

SPARTANBURG, S. C., Nov. 19 -- President Eisenhower's proposal to expand the Government's role in some fields of welfare should not be construed as a departure from a basic policy of shifting greater emphasis to the activities of private and voluntary agencies, it was asserted here tonight.

The Amor Musicae Ensemble, a new group for the presentation of early music, gave its first concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The report is that the beginning was shaky, but the performing improved and if the group, in maintaining its good taste, can develop a little more expertness it should prove a welcome newcomer to the ranks of those helping to bring some charming music off the shelf.
Mystery comparable to the discovery of a new atomic weapon surrounded the introduction of coffee pots and radios into detention pens in the city's magistrate courts.

The city's maritime interests are still knee-deep in the destructive effects of the storm that swept the metropolitan area on Nov. 6 and 7. Losses may run into millions of dollars, but insurance men will not even estimate the cost, the aggregate of which will not be known for months.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Admiral Robert B. Carney, Chief of Naval Operations, said today the United States would turn over two destroyers to the Nationalist Chinese on Formosa.

In a noisy demonstration that included egg throwing, 100 students of James Madison High School, Brooklyn, protested yesterday against a no-smoking rule in the building and an order prohibiting them from eating lunch off the premises.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 9 -- The Biblical story of how Joseph stored grain during the seven good years to feed the people during the seven years of famine is being re-enacted here. The United States Point Four mission for technical assistance and the Jordanian Government are the sponsors.

Trading continued active yesterday on most commodities on the New York exchanges. Zinc registered the largest volume of the year and potatoes had the most sales since April 9. Prices closed generally lower with potatoes, cocoa, coffee, sugar, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, tin, rubber and wool declining. Zinc, lead, copper and burlap showed gains.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities asserted today that the group's Truman subpoena still stood, and that he hoped the former President "will see the necessity" and appear voluntarily.

In roasting turkey -- a timely topic with Thanksgiving less than a week away -- there are two schools of thought. On one side is the fine professional chef; on the other, the culinary experts of the Poultry and Egg National Board, a trade group.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, Nov. 20 -- The Communists stalled another meeting today on the Korean peace conference arrangements. But they seemed late yesterday to have taken a more conciliatory stand.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- A report charging serious construction defects and demanding reconstruction of many sections of a $2,500,000 combined four-story office building and six-story cooperative apartment house that collapsed here on July 10, killing three workmen and injuring ten, was filed with the Village Board today by consulting engineers hired by the village.
THE liveliest group in town are the men and women of the Yorkville Neighborhood Club, made up of men and women from 60 to 90 years old.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 19 -- The Chinese worker, like the hapless prototype in George Orwell's novel "1984," is seldom far from earshot of his Communist Government.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- The United States moved today a resolution seeking to persuade at least one Communist to refer politely to the Nationalist Chinese. The United States withdrew it resolution, but said that it might try with another later.
The American Commission on Foreign Trade, now meeting in Paris, was urged yesterday to resist "diplomatic double talk" seeking a reduction of Government aid to American-flag shipping.
Stock prices recaptured almost all of the week's losses in heavier trading yesterday.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 19 (AP) -- River Jordan, a former hurdle horse, won the $5,000 added Patuxent Handicap today, giving Jockey Ira Hanford his second score of the afternoon.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday the election of two vice presidents and assignment of new responsibilities to another officer, effective Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Debt collection policies of the Government have driven some small business to the verge of bankruptcy, the Small Business Administration said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- David Poleri, tenor of the New York City Center Opera Company, singing the role of Don Jose in "Carmen," startled an audience here tonight by striding abruptly off the stage during the last act after saying to the conductor: "You finish it yourself."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Public Housing Administration plans to transfer to private financing all public housing projects on which the Government now owns more than 70 per cent of the bonds.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A driver and four spectators were killed today as the Pan American road race got off to the most tragic start in its four-year history.

The five-story house on lot 22 by 100 feet at 35 West Seventy-fifth Street has been sold by the Estate of Caroline W. Astor to a client of Irving Lent, attorney. It is assessed at $35,500 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $25,000 in a deal negotiated by the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company in conjunction with the Cruikshank Company, brokers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A budget cut of $6,000,000,000 will be sought by the Administration in shaping up estimates of the Government's expenditures for the coming fiscal year.
New issues of public utility preferred and common stocks valued at more than $9,400,000 will be offered to investors today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today the Government had a record $4,053,142,000 tied up in farm price support programs on Sept. 23. The previous high was $4,036,175,000 on March 30, 1950.
It wasn't just the heat that caused distress here yesterday; it was the inflexibility.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 20 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon resumed his tour of Asia today, leaving the Japanese pleased that he had acknowledged a United States "mistake" in stripping this nation of its armed might after World War II.

The Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs recommended yesterday that it be Continued as a combination of officials and private citizens. The seventy-six-member group reported to Mayor Impellitteri on its four years' work for the city's newest population segment -- some 400,000 Puerto Ricans.

Fordham's twenty-two seniors led the spirited Ram football team through a light workout yesterday at Fordham Field in the Bronx as the Maroon completed preparations for tomorrow's clash with Holy Cross at Fitton Field, Worcester Mass.

NEWPORT, R. I., Nov. 19 (AP) -- F. Frazier Jelke, oleomargarine heir and international banker who died here Aug. 30, left a personal estate of $6,985,795, according to an inventory accepted in Probate Court today.

At the end of October, the average price of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange stood at the highest mark since Jan. 31. The figure was $97.59, the Exchange reported yesterday, against $96.74 on Sept. 30 and $97.66 on Jan. 31.
PANAMA, Nov. 19 -- The headquarters of the United States Caribbean command disclaimed today all responsibility in what has become known here as case of the cleaned-out PX.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (UP) -- A decision by the Maryland Racing Commission on racing dates for next year was postponed today when a squabble behind the scenes between the three major tracks came to a head.

Miss Frieda Miller, retiring chief of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor appealed to women yesterday to promote support for the United Nations among the one-third of the population of the United States that apparently opposes the world organization.

The Franklin National Bank of Franklin Square plans to absorb the First National Bank of Bellmore. Proposed consolidation of the two Long Island banks was disclosed in a letter to First National's stockholders and signed by its president, Henry J. Schuler.
Customs agents here arrested five men yesterday on charges of having smuggled into this city from Canada $60,000 worth of linens manufactured in Communist China.

The belated arbitration award dealing with issues that caused the month-long strike against privately owned bus lines last January will pose a problem for the low-fare advocates in the Board of Estimate. The award grants the 40-hour work week and adjusts hourly wage rates so that take-home pay will not be reduced.

With the Bermuda conference only two weeks away the United States, Britain and France have made new representations to both Italy and Yugoslavia urging them to stop trading insults over Trieste and to join in a Five-Power conference in an effort to remove one of the obstacles blocking an adequate Western defense against the common Soviet menace.

TRIESTE, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Several hundred job hunters, protesting rising unemployment in Trieste, broke some windows, smashed furniture and damaged card index files at an Allied Military Government labor office here today.
A sentence of death by demolition seemed set last night for the notorious "Tweed Courthouse," the faded gray structure that stands just north of City Hall's back door.
TORONTO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Ronnie Mutch of the United States tonight won the international individual fault-and-out stakes at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Gordie Howe's disputed third-period goal carried the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-to-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight before 10,255 fans at Olympia.

Adequate provision for air-pollution control over New York City is painfully overdue. No service of local government is more fundamental than that which safeguards the air which its people must breathe.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 19 -- The National Grange today recommended continuation of current Federal farm price supports until markets can be developed to solve the farmers' problems.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 727,058 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- A mild-mannered upholstery supply dealer voluntarily testified today that he was a Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover agent who had been counterspying on Communist cells in General Electric Company plants since 1941.

In the last three years thousands of small fry have inserted nickels in a device resembling a penny peanut machine and have received from one to eight small plastic or metal objects known as "charms."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Public Housing Administration plans to transfer to private financing all public housing projects on which the government now owns more than 70 per cent of the bonds.
Contracts totaling $12,621,638 for four new schools and three additions were awarded yesterday by the Board of Education.
A ten-count indictment was returned yesterday against Anthony James Palazzola, 26-year-old tattooed ex-convict, charged with kidnapping and raping a 13-year-old girl last Friday.

IN television, the quiz shows have been subjected to more distortion, abuse and nonsense than probably any other form of program. Either the ridiculous questions, the rewards for stupidity or the maudlin heart- throb confessions of participants have reduced most of the question -and-answer presentations to banal and tedious sessions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- President Eisenhower held another in a series of stag dinners tonight for prominent American business, labor, finance, publishing and education leaders.
Mixed influences held the net expansion in New York bank loans to business at $6,000,000 last week.

FOR most of the nation's teams the Great Autumnal Madness will end tomorrow. What makes that practically official is that it will be the day of The Game. Or maybe it should be more properly described as THE GAME. As even the most backward student knows, this naturally means the Yale-Harvard game. Once upon a time the two traditional foes fought for the national championship.

MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 19 -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, today relegated communism-in-Government to the position of "an underlying issue" in the 1954 Congressional election campaign.

It is hard to understand your editorial statement that "a more profoundly anti-Communist document could hardly be imagined" than the recent Presbyterian "manifesto," as you call it. It would indeed be surprising if your statement were correct, for the signer of this extraordinary "manifesto" is Dr. John A. Mackay, who recently signalized his selection as head of the Presbyterian Church by stating in all seriousness that anti-communism is more dangerous than communism.

SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The young Australians, Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad, came from behind today to beat Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert, of the United States, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, in the doubles final of the New South Wales tennis tournament.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Nov. 19 -- A Mayor's Advisory Council headed by Nathan Straus, with Averell Harriman as honorary chairman, will supply expert advice and guidance to the new city administration. Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. announced the new plan here today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 19 -- After the excitement of the Yale game last week, Princeton is looking for another lively afternoon of football against Dartmouth. The teams close their seasons in Palmer Stadium on Saturday, with play starting at 1:30 P. M.

The editorial entitled "A 'Task Force' on Power" in the Times of Nov. 13 is not as objective as it might appear to be at first reading. Comments on the new Hoover Commission have been made in such a manner as to subtly imply that certain federal power activities should not be "reorganized." The impression given is that the Tennessee Valley Authority should be immune from task-force probing.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- A movement exists in this country to transfer the management of business to politicians and labor organizers, Donald R. Richberg said here tonight.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Organized campaigns against two performers will result in the abrupt closing, on Sunday night of the stage season at the Astor Theatre here, it was said today by James Russo, a partner in the venture with Michael Ellis.
The National Committee for Import Development announced yesterday that it has organized on a formal basis, after operating informally since its organization a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Official quarters expressed considerable skepticism and surprise tonight over reports that Argentina had bought from Czechoslovakia a Czechoslovak-owned steel mill held in this country.

State investigators of harness racing are trying to find out how much influence James J. Hines, who served a prison term as political protector of the Dutch Schultz gang, had in the affairs of Yonkers Raceway.

Edwin M. Otterbourg, president of the New York County Lawyers Association said last night that on the basis of pre-election pledges the incoming administration might be expected to support the association's program dealing with juvenile delinquency.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The revised conventions between France and the Saar were ratified today by the French Council of the Republic, the advisory second house.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Only two days after Attorney General Brownell informed a Senate subcommittee that he will ask Congress to admit information obtained by wire-tapping as evidence in espionage trials by the federal courts, signs are appearing of a deep difference of opinion on the proposal in this country.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 19 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, former Premier of Iran standing trial for rebellion, blurted out to the court-martial today that he feared he would be killed in prison.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. The Federal Reserve Board's weekly report listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:
The price of world sugar will be held between 3.25 and 4.35 cents a pound after Jan. 1, Dr. Arturo Manas, a member of the Cuban Sugar Stabilization Institute, said yesterday.

Several months ago President Eisenhower publicly deprecated, and quite justifiably, the idea of what he called "taxes on taxes." He had in mind not only the overlapping of state, municipal and federal taxes but more particularly double taxation, such as occurs when corporate profits are taxed first as corporate income and later, in the form of dividends, as individual income.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 19 (AP) -- A vote of confidence in State Senator Samuel L. Bodine of Hunterdon, chairman of the Republican State Committee, was given tonight by seventeen county chairmen.

Roy Campanella, who won the distinction in 1951, yesterday was named the National League's most valuable player for 1953. Seventeen of the twenty-four first-place votes went to the Brooklyn catcher, who collected 297 points.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Yesterday's improvement on Wall Street and announcements of good dividends by several important companies helped the stock markets here to recover today. Buyers remained cautious pending the outcome of the Engineering Union's recommendation for a one-day token strike. But selling of industrials diminished and prices became steadier.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Former President Truman said tonight the Democratic party "must bring its efforts to bear on the problems which we will face, not on the one which we faced in the past."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The Soviet Union condemned today the conference that the leaders of the Western Big Three will hold in Bermuda next month.
A new attack on one of the city's most pressing ills -- its traffic congestion -- was opened yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- American-owned The Pie King was rated England's top 2-year-old thoroughbred for 1953 today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations spurned today a plea by James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, to be "realistic" and stop talking about repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Membership in the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, now covers 1,036 papers and newspaper ad representatives -- a new high -- it was announced yesterday by Harold S. Barnes, director.

A CHECK on the hunting activities in the three most popular deer counties in the Catskill zone, Sullivan, Greene and Delaware, reveals that both deer and hunters are, if anything, more plentiful than ever, but that the success ratio is rather low, from the hunter's, not the deer's, viewpoint.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Federal, state and local authorities told Senate investigators today that juvenile delinquency was too big a problem to be met by the local community alone.

Sharp condemnation of the proposed resolution in the United Nations Security Council to censure Israel for border violations was expressed yesterday by the American Zionist Council. the public relations branch of Zionist groups in this country.

MANILA, Nov. 19 -- The United States Embassy and President Elpidio Quirino's office made public today copies of a memorandum from a United States Army officer to his men that contained no instruction to them to meddle in the recent elections. Mr. Quirino had charged that they had been told to do so.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 19 -- Bobby Greenlease's kidnap killers were sentenced today to be executed on Dec. 18.

Combined Canadian and United States production of newsprint in October was the highest for any month on record, according to a report yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau. Canadian output for the month was 510,772 tons, while that in the United States was 97,112, making a total of 607,884 tons.

An aged person never should be denied his dignity as an individual, Miss Ollie A. Randall, consultant on the aged for the Community Service Society, declared yesterday at a meeting of the society's women's council at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The United States, Britain and Canada will begin soon an exchange of information on the effects of atomic and hydrogen weapons "on human beings and their environment." The purpose is to aid in defensive measures for troops and for the civiilan population.

The Southern Presbyterian Journal, unofficial weekly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, charged in its issue last Wednesday that the recent letter sent out by the General Council of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. was "one of the most insidiously dangerous documents we have yet seen."
Three Thanksgiving menus at varying cost have been planned by the Consumers Service and Research Bureau of the Department of Markets, of which Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon is director.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The ten couturiers, members of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers, gave a joint fashion parade yesterday for Queen Elizabeth II, the Queen Mother and Princess Margaret at the home of their president, Lady Clark.

In the last few days New York City and neighboring communities in New Jersey have been getting a stiff dose of smog -- or "smaze," if you prefer the new name given to it by air-pollution experts. Some of it was man-made, from smoke stacks and, to a lesser degree, automobile exhaust; some of it was weatherman-made.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- "Precise assurances" regarding the prolonged maintenance of United States and British troops on the Continent to guarantee the proposed European army treaty will be asked by the French Government, Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister, told the National Assembly today.

The Brooklyn College basketball team opened its season last night with a 78-45 victory over an Alumni quintet on the school's court. Stan Katzman led the Kingsmen with 16 points, while Joe Post starred for the Alumni with 15.

ABSECON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- The ageless glaciers and the modern mechanical dishwasher are among the many factors that threaten New Jersey's water supply, Dr. Thurlow C. Nelson said here today. The chairman of the New Jersey Water Policy and Supply Council spoke at the thirty-sixth annual meeting of the New Jersey Utilities Association.
BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Marketing, rather than reduction of output, was recommended today by Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, as the best solution to present farm problems.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 20 -- Impressed by the "great spirit and determination" shown by the University of Houston football team in its upset victory last Saturday over Baylor, Hugh Roy Cullen gave the university $2,250,000 today.

Most of the important stock market groups were mixed yesterday, losses canceling out gains. The result was a virtual stand-off in The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks, which closed at 176.42 for a loss of 0.02. Rails fell 0.12 to 63.33 and industrials rose 0.08 to 289.52.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed two more bills of the proposed Negro-white school equalization program today and Gov. Hugh White predicted the entire program would be enacted within two weeks with the possible exception of finance measures.

In its first change of ownership since 1895, the eight-story and basement building at 110 to 114 West Thirty-second Street running through to 113 to 117 West Thirtyfirst Street has been sold by the Estate of Lucy A. Dully.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn backed Park Commissioner Robert Moses all the way yesterday in the skirmish with social workers over the city's multimillion-dollar recreation centers program.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- The United States Savings and Loan League today predicted continued American prosperity in 1954 and cited five "good reasons" for the group's optimistic outlook. They are comparatively "easy money," lower taxes, large volume of savings, continued heavy spending by Government and vigorous action by business to boost consumer demand and increase sales.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 -- A national football championship is not at stake, but you could not tell this from the atmosphere in New Haven today as Yale prepared to make its bid for the Big Three championship against Harvard in the Bowl tomorrow.

The 389 parishes in the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese will take part in the Thanksgiving clothing collection for Korea and refugees in Europe, the Near and Far East from tomorrow to Nov. 29. Catholic churches will be collection centers for the clothing and money. The program is under the sponsorship of the bishops of the church in the United States.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Snooks T., owned by P. A. Kilpstein, today won the feature at Bay Meadows with a stretch drive that furnished a length and a half margin over the runner-up, Sun Deck.

Although the Federal program for slum clearance and redevelopment of American cities has been slow in getting going, wide public sentiment in favor of broad plans for improvement of deteriorated areas will help bring results, members of the New York chapter of Lambda Alpha, land economics fraternity, were told yesterday.

A new national bank, described as New York State's first in twenty-three years, is slated to be established in Great Neck, L. I., early next year. The Controller of the Currency has approved the application of a group of residents of the area who have subscribed $1,000,000 to found the institution.

Ray Lev conformed to usual practice in her annual piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall. She selected for her program one big number (Beethoven's "Waldstein" Sonata), a less-familiar romantic work (Schumann's "Humoresque"), and several new short works by contemporary composers.
BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- The wave of arrests of alleged spies and saboteurs in East Germany appeared to be continuing today. The Communist press told of seizures in a number of cities and towns.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, said tonight the Eisenhower Administration was making progress on its program of expanded national security with reduced expenditures and reduced personnel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Representative Samuel K. McConnell Jr., Republican of Pennsylvania, chairman of the House Labor Committee, predicted today that a bill revising the Taft-Hartley Act probably would be acted upon early in the next session of Congress.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 20 -- Skippers, crews and friends of the International Class of racing yachts discussed the synthetic material dacron as a replacement for duck in mainsails and jibs at the fall dinner meeting of the class at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club tonight. About 100 attended.
The bankrupt Long Island Rail Road moved yesterday to abandon its Montauk branch between Patchogue and Montauk, a distance of sixty-two miles.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, Republican majority leader, called today upon President-Elect Magsaysay of the Philippines to take the leadership in organizing seven Far Eastern nations to challenge the Communist scheme for the conquest of the Orient.

Government and city officials, civic and religious leaders and professional philatelists joined yesterday in ceremonies that ushered into use the Post Office Department's newest commemorative stamp -- a 3-cent purple for the tercentennial of New York.
NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- The manager of the Great Western Food Market turned detective today and traced $700 of his company's money that a woman customer had carried off unwittingly a few minutes before.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Citing unsatisfactory export figures and an inadequate balance of payments surplus, R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, cautioned today against any complacency about Britain's economic situation.

A century ago youth was told to "Go West," for fame and fortune. Now a company which has made one fortune out West thinks it may make a second by spreading itself a bit more in the East. Lingan A. Warren, president of Safeway Stores, Inc., told the Los Angeles Society of Security Analysts yesterday his company thinks its biggest opportunity and profit region in the future is in the area around New York City.

The International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., filed unfair labor practice charges yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board against both the New York Shipping Association and the old I. L. A.

VIENNA, Nov. 20 -- The Austrian Government was reported to have told the Joint Executive Board for Jewish Claims on Austria that it was not prepared to negotiate now regarding heirless Jewish property.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 -- Walter P. Reuther was unanimously elected today for a second year as president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Greentree Stable's Tom Fool, who is at Greentree Farm, Lexington, Ky., where he will enter the stud, has been picked as the champion race horse of 1953 by the members of the New York Turf Writers' Association. Results of the balloting were announced yesterday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 2 -- The Netherlands Government announced t day it would propose a special world conference to solve the United States farm surplus problem. The proposal will be made formally at the biennial conference of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations that opens in Rome Monday.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 -- The retail price of milk will advance one cent a quart throughout northern New Jersey on Dec. 6. The rise was authorized today by the State Office of Milk Industry, which also granted a half-cent increase in the consumer price in seven South Jersey counties.

Commissioner Ford C. Frick will have to make a decision within the next few days not unlike that by one of his world series umpires who must determine who arrived at the bag first, the ball or the runner.
The scheduled Broadway opening on Dec. 7 of R. C. Sherriff's comic-melodrama, "Home at Seven," starring Paul Muni, has been canceled because of third-act trouble.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Murray Snyder, assistant White House press secretary, said today it was true that President and Mrs. Eisenhower would be week-ending in their remodeled Pennsylvania farm house by next spring.

Mickey Spillane would have loved it. The corpses of reputations were strewn all over the Astor Hotel. When the annual Financial Follies of the New York Financial Writers Association hit the business world last night, virtually nobody escaped unscathed.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The story of an eight-day struggle to save a ship stranded on the Labrador coast was told here today by the United States Northeast Air Command.

Most commodities yesterday avoided the usual pattern of dull trading prior to the week-end. On the New York exchanges, lead registered most sales since Aug. 4. Zinc continued active and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides and cocoa had sizable volume.

Nothing that happened at the special convention of Joseph P. Ryan's long-shore union should modify the determination of the American Federation of Labor to press its drive for a clean waterfront. Neither Mr. Ryan in his farewell speech as president nor his successor, William V. Bradley, gave any indication of recognizing the racketeering conditions and other evils that prevail in this port.

The Alfor !achinery Company,' manufacturer of machine parts, has purchased the one-story factory which it has occupied under lease at 307 Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. Henrietta IV[ohr was the seller. The sale was negotiated by Eugene J. Keely as broker.

Your editorial "The Truman Subpoena" in the mind of this citizen is slanted to defend the Truman Administration in its laxity and to cast aspersions on Congressional committees for their efforts to uncover Communist infiltration.
HANOI, Saturday, Nov. 21 (AP)-- The French High Command said today that the French and Vietnamese paratroops dropped at Dienbienphu had fully occupied that rebel center.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that cost-of-living bonuses paid to a New York City school teacher could not be included in her salary for the purpose of computing her pension benefits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved increases in mail rates on catalogues, similar printed advertising matter, and controlled circulation publications. The effective date has not been set by the Post Office Department.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20 -Harvard University announced today the receipt of gifts totaling $2,293,113.32 in the July-September period. Of the amount, $2,033,175.32 was for immediate use and the rest for endowment.

THIS morning's books are voyages of discovery into three great realms: In "Unseen Life of New York,"* William Beebe presents the town and its fathomless suburbia as a naturalist sees it. In "My San Francisco," Joseph Henry Jackson lets his critical guard down and writes a fine Valentine to one of the most beautiful places anywhere. And in "Emett's Domain" the best of all Punch cartoonists, Rowland Emett, spoofs trains, trams, Englishmen and their England.

Events today: Little Orchestra Society Young People's Concert. Hunter College. 11 A. M.: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert. Town Hall, 3 P. M.; "La Forza del Destino." Metropolitan Opera, 2; National Association of American Composers and Conductors, Town Hall, 5:30; Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 3.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Eisenhower today sidestepped an opportunity to cast the deciding vote in a crucial matter of tariff policy.

The Floyd Taylor Memorial Room, honoring the first director of the American Press Institute, was dedicated yesterday at Columbia University. The room is on the second floor of the Journalism Building.

A prayer read at the opening meeting of the New Amsterdam Common Council in 1653 has been provided for use this week-end by Jews, Roman Catholics and Protestants in the observance of Religious Freedom Week.

Brooklyn College does not make a habit of giving honorary degrees. But, with the approval of the Board of Higher Education and the State Board of Regents, it has conferred the title of Doctor of Humane Letters on Ordway Teed, for fifteen years (until last May) chairman of the Board of Higher Education.

Hoyt O. Perry Jr. of the Pequot Yacht Club was elected chairman of the Atlantic Class Association last night at that organization's annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club. He succeeded Charles E. Ames of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Army will count as dead in January almost two-thirds of the servicemen still listed as "missing" in Korea.

The automobile ostensibly is a willing servant of mankind and yet there is an ineffable quality about it that often changes the entire personality of a person when he sits behind the steering wheel. From the foreheads of the most mild-mannered persons unseen horns sprout upward and their faces take on satanic leers.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 20 (UP) -- J. J. Forbes, director of the United States Bureau of Mines, pledged his cooperation today "in every possible way" to help the coal industry grow and "regain its proper place in the over-all fuel economy of the nation."

A new organization has been formed to transmit gifts of alcoholic beverages in states where such shipments are permitted. It is Beverage-By-Wire, Inc., with temporary offices at 595 Fifth Avenue. Package liquor stores in cities from coast to coast are signing up as participating members of the organization.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 13 points higher to 5 points lower yesterday after a moderate volume of business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Complaints of slow mail service from New York City to the Worcester, Mass., area have been sent to the Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, by Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A Congressional hearing today resulted in a charge that a press release had reported testimony of a witness even before he had been questioned.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Australia's Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad dealt another blow to American Davis Cup hopes today when they rallied to defeat the top United States doubles team of Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert for the New South Wales championship, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5.

APPREHENSION for the future and many perplexities had filled my mind as I moved about among the cheering crowds of Londoners in their hour of well-won rejoicing after all they had gone through. The Hitler peril, with its ordeals and privations, seemed to most of them to have vanished in a blaze of glory.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 517 pints of blood on Thursday. Included were 129 pints donated at the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, 67 Broad Street, and 129 given in the first of a two-day community collection at East Hills School, Roslyn, L. I.

An eye-smarting, throat-irritating twilight gray hung over New York, New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester all day yesterday. There was little hope for relief today unless showers, predicted for tomorrow, happen to arrive earlier.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 20 -- With national elections to be held Sunday, Yugoslavia appeared today to be more concerned with the Trieste dispute than with the outcome of the voting.
THE reports on northern deer hunting show that conditions as well as results have improved greatly during the past week, with excellent hunting now available in northern Maine and New Brunswick.

Mr. Truman, then President, condoned the presence of Harry Dexter White in a critical govrenmental office after he had received definite warning that White was unquestionably a subversive. Mr. Truman concedes that the final decision rested with him.
TOKYO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Japan's growing optical industry announced today it would begin the first large-scale production of the world's fastest camera lens.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Despite United States resistance to putting up money for such programs, a United Nations committee agreed today to keep alive its special fund for economic development.
Another perjury indictment was returned yesterday against a waterfront figure by the special Federal grand jury investigating crime along the sprawling New York Harbor.
HANOI, Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 21 (UP) -- More than 1,000 French Union paratroopers dropped in a mass jump at dawn yesterday to attack a Communist stronghold 125 miles west of here.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Dartmouth's pass-minded team will face Princeton in Palmer Stadium tomorrow in the final football game of the season for both squads.

Two flights up in a Sixth Avenue rookery. Current Stages is exhibiting its own production of Moss Hart's "The Climate of Eden," one of the casualties of last season on Broadway. In view of the difficulties involved in mounting a big play in a small loft, it is remarkable that Current Stages can achieve anything intelligible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Joseph N. Rosenbaum, a Washington attorney, was acquitted by a Federal jury late today of charges of lying to Senators investigating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) -For the ninety-first time a birthday cake was admired and then eaten in honor of Connie Mack, the fabulous figure, of baseball. But Connie, who sampled a piece of the cake, made the biggest fuss over a birthday congratulatory note from another rather famous sportsman, President Eisenhower.
Bob Mercier, Lion left halfback, returns to a starting role today as Columbia and Rutgers conclude their football seasons at Baker Field. The game will start at 1:30 P. M.
TORONTO, Nov. 20 -- One has only to fly a short distance over south Ontario to understand why Canadians of this part of the country refer to Ontario with pride as "the workshop of the nation."
There is a wide variety of styles and mediums in the current exhibitions of art.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Air pollution specialists here believe that the traditional pea-soup fogs of London were less dangerous than the modern variety that are less dense, more frequent and probably contain more lethal sulphur dioxide.

The Home Lines announced yesterday that it had completed negotiations for the purchase of the Pacific cruise liner Mariposa from the Matson Navitation Company of San Francisco. The price was not disclosed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- A United Nations official urged the organization today to use conciliation, persuasion and friendly cooperation with the South African Government to solve its racial problems.
Juvenile offenders who like their coffee and music hot are going to be disappointed in Brooklyn Adolescent Court.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Farm representatives of the cotton states today fixed an allotment of 21,315,000 acres for proposed cotton planting next year.

NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- Gas distribution and maintenance workers employed by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company went on strike today at 7 A. M. over a wage dispute. The 1,800 men install equipment and service home and industrial gas systems.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -Twenty-six public school teachers, including sixteen who rebuffed the House Un-American Activities Committee, were suspended this afternoon.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 -- Israel must concentrate on agricultural expansion rather than on industry if she is to solve her pressing economic problems, it was declared here today.

The Esso Standard Oil Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), reduced the price of heating oils yesterday by three-tenths to one-half cent a gallon in the New York and Boston areas.

Air France began weekly non-stop de luxe service from New York to Paris last night. Thirty-two newspaper men and radio personalities left on the opening flight from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

New York University started its forty-eighth basketball season last night with a 94-53 triumph over an alumni team at the University Heights gymnasium, the Bronx. Hal Weitz and Ted Elsberg led the varsity with 21 points each while Ray Lumpp and Dick Bunt topped the alumni with 6 apiece.

A Trans World Airlines Constellation en route to London and Frankfort with fifty-six persons aboard was forced to turn back to Gander, Newfoundland, last night as "a precautionary measure." The four-engine craft, which left New York at 1 P. M. yesterday, landed safely at Gander at 1 A. M. today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A call to a spiritual battle against communism and against the "bitterest, bloodiest persecution in all history" was issued today by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States.
How do children themselves feel about organized play programs after school?

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, Paul L. Troast and Republican State Chairman Samuel L. Bodine walked out of a meeting of top Republican party leaders here today after the group had demanded drastic reforms in party policy and leadership.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- J. Howard McGrath, former Attorney General, said today he had authorized a letter in an anti-trust case that gave Herbert Bergson an additional $50,000 fee.
ALBANY, Nov. 20 (UP) -- The State Thruway Authority is asking private operators to bid for leases on fourteen gasoline stations along the 427-mile New York-to-Buffalo express route.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 20 -- A new phase of the cultural war between the United States and the Soviet Union has been waged here since the United States Information Services announced a virtual subsidy for Hebrew translations of American books published in this country.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 21 -During a three-hour subcommittee meeting at Panmunjom today to determine the place and composition of the Korean peace conference, Arthur H. Dean, United Nations representative, lashed back at the Communist delegates.
TRIESTE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Jobless Triestini besieged their City Hall and raided a civil mess hall today in the second day of demonstrations reportedly sparked by Communists.

A bid of $700,000 has been accepted for The Boston Post buildings at 245-75 Washington Street and 4 to 10 Williams Court, in Boston, Mass., it was announced here yesterday by Joseph P. Day, Inc., auctioneers, who conducted a sale of the property in Boston on Thursday.

The placement of orders for two 38,000-deadweight-ton tankers by the Shell Oil Company is being viewed in industry circles as indicative of recognition by foreign oil companies of the trend toward giant petroleum carriers. The two new tankers are to be constructed in United Kingdom shipyards.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- David Poleri, who stalked off the stage of the Civic Opera House last night in the final scene of "Carmen," presented by the New York City Opera Company, voiced today an apologetic aria.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (UP) -- A Christmas tree ornament sold with the claim that it would act as a fire extinguisher might set off phosgene, a deadly war gas, the Chicago Board of Health warned today.
DENVER, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The DC-7 flying to Los Angeles failed today in an attempt at the first "legal" nonstop flight by a commercial airliner from the East Coast to the West.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Expenditures by the country's railroads for improvements to plant and equipment will aggregate more than $1,200,000,000 in 1953. This will be the sixth consecutive year in which those outlays topped $1,000,000,000, William F. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -President Eisenhower and J. Edgar Hoover said happy birthday to Clark Griffith today, but their felicitations were no match for the message that came in from the Lone Ranger.
Hiram Walker - Gooderham Worts, Ltd., on the second highest sales in its history in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, increased earnings 22 per cent over those of the preceding period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith was told today that progress made in last forty years in fostering intergroup harmony and protection of civil rights was threatened "by the current forces of hate and fear."

President Eisenhower is not suffering from heart disease, as some newspaper columnists and radio commentators have reported, Maj. Gen. Howard McC. Snyder, the President's personal physician, declared here yesterday.

CAIRO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- An unusual snow and rainstorm sweeping the eastern Mediterranean was reported to have caused at least thirteen deaths and to have wrought destruction through the ancient lands along its shores.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- This is the story of a tramp freighter without a cargo and of its captain -- a skipper without crew -- lacking food for days and uncertain about a seagoing future.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 20 -- Chile will again seek a United States market as the only logical outlet for its copper production under present world conditions, informed sources here said today.

Ed O'Connor, 6-foot 6-inch junior, went on a scoring spree as Manhattan College crushed an alumni quintet, 70 -- 53, in the season's opener last night at Manhattan. He tossed in 28 points, the result of ten field goals and eight fouls, to garner high-scoring laurels.

Perched on top of the Eastern division, the Knickerbockers face one of their sternest tests of the season tonight when they meet the second-place Syracuse Nationals in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20 (AP) -- In a final tune-up for the Barbara Frietchie Handicap here next week, Howell E. Jackson's Ballerina won the $6,000 Meadows Purse today by a length from T. F. White's Miss Weesie.
Increases in the size and complexity of our social problems brought about by the nation's growth were the speakers' theme last night at the annual dinner of the National Institute of Social Sciences.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -President Eisenhower had an unheralded breakfast conference today with Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, and a group of Administration officials.
After a long investigation, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan issued an order yesterday that is designed to curb the practice of policemen tipping off towing garages of accidents.

Prime Minister Churchill's "Tests of Freedom," laid down in a message to the Italian people in 1944, reaffirmed in his current chapters of his history of the Second World War, reprinted in this newspaper yesterday, still stand.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20 (UP) -The Mexican Army reported today that two more drivers had been killed on treacherous roads in the second day of the world's toughest auto race.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren today named six members of the commission that will study the question whether Congressional and judiciary pay should be increased.

The Algam Corporation, holding company for the Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways, returned yesterday its filled-out and sworn-to questionnaire to the Moreland Act Commission that is investigating state agencies in relation to pari-mutuel harness racing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Mrs. Alice K. Leopold, newly appointed Director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, has been assigned additional duties not previously associated with that post.

Canada's individual income and corporate taxpayers still are important contributors to economic expansion there despite rates said to be much less severe than those in this country. This fact was pointed up yesterday by Douglas Abbott, Canadian Minister of Finance, in an address before the concluding financial conference of the American Management Association in the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A football tee for kicking extra points and field goals is protected by Patent 2,659,604, granted to Neil E. McGowen, who at the time he filed the application in 1950 was assistant coach at Alabama Polytechnical Institute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today suspended for five months a $5,306,000 annual wholesale natural gas rate increase which New York State Natural Gas Corporation of Pittsburgh proposed to put into effect tomorrow.

The installation of Dr. Arthur A. Thibodeau as president of the Alumni Association of the Hospital for Special Surgery took place last night at a dinner at the Yale Club. It followed the association's annual meeting yesterday at the hospital, during which Dr. Thibodeau read his presidential address on "Present Status of Treatment of Osteomyelitis."

Vince Martinez of Paterson defeated Chico Vejar of Stamford in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Although the contest was savagely waged, the verdict went to Martinez by unanimous vote.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Soviet Army, now exerting greater influence on top-level policy-making in the Soviet Union, is believed to be urging the Government to concentrate on overtaking the West's technical and industrial lead.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Common Pleas Judge Joseph L. Harter tonight fined Local 927, United Auto Workers, C. I. O., $50,000 for contempt of court as a result of last Tuesday's violence at the struck North American Aviation, Inc., plant here.

The most discouraging aspect of the Israel-Jordan case, now the subject of bitter debate in the U. N. Security Council, is the revelation that the border situation is steadily deteriorating. No one can view this worsening vista without deep disquiet. For on the Palestinian question time, instead of healing the breach, seems to aggravate it.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The stock markets relapsed into dullness today, with prices slipping back in nearly all markets because of slight selling pressure. The brewery and gold mine shares were exceptions, making further good gains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Canada has registered its concern with the United States against the release of a once-secret letter crediting a highly placed Canadian official with information about the late Harry Dexter White.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions notified the Ministry of Labor today of its plan to stage a twenty-four-hour strike on Dec. 2. The confederation did not ask the Ministry to intervene to try a settlement.
TORONTO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Charles Baker tonight won the international individual jumping stake for Canada with a faultless performance aboard Starclift in a jump-off.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren said today that the "withering hand of politics" should be taken from the shoulders of honest police officers in the interest of better law enforcement.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Nov. 21 (UP) -- North Korean and Chinese prisoners refused to parade for identification before a Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission team today and forced cancellation of a scheduled "murder investigation."
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Mr. Rosenstock, who conducted the opera last night, issued this statement today:
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill rose today to propose the health of "a distinguished statesman," Clement R. Attlee, his most powerful political opponent.

DALLAS, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Air Force Chief of Staff, indicated today that long-range bombers of the United States Air Force were capable of delivering hydrogen bombs.

A Brooklyn High School music teacher who was suspended for refusing to answer questions concerning Communist party affiliations testified yesterday that he was not now a Communist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on last Tuesday to 109.8 (1947-49=100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products and processed foods more than offset an increase in the average of all commodities other than farm and foods.

Far Rockaway's unbeaten, though once-tied, eleven, host to Stuyvesant, commands top billing on the New York City school football program today. Other attractions will be found at Baldwin, L. I.; Orange, N. J., and Rye, N. Y.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- A metal tree, on which were suspended kitchen utensils and other gift suggestions, was a feature today at the opening of the fourth annual Design-for-Christmas exhibition of the Institute of Contemporary Art.

A new type resuscitator, designed especially to breathe new life into victims of a nerve gas attack whose breathing apparatus would be crippled, was described here yesterday. The details were given at the conference on electronic instrumentation and nucleonics in medicine at the New Yorker Hotel.

Yale and Harvard in the Bowl at New Haven and Notre Dame and Maryland defending their spotless records against Iowa and Alabama command much of the interest in college football's final full-length program today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- The General Assembly's Legal Committee adopted a resolution this evening directing the chairman of that committee to address all delegates as "delegates."
ALBANY, Nov. 20 (UP) -- More than 4,000,000 Christmas trees, nearly double last year's supply, are expected to reach retail markets through New York State next month.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 20 -- Unbeaten Notre Dame, labeled the nation's strongest college football team, anticipates a keen challenge omorrow from an improving young Iowa squad that has compiled its best record in many years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Wheat futures developed considerable weakness today. The price depression reflected further heavy long liquidation in the December as well as more favorable weather conditions for winter wheat, while there also apparently was selling of the bread grain against purchases of corn.

This is, of course, the old Courthouse just north of City Hall, built in 1869 and 1870 under the administration of the so-called Tweed Ring.
The Waterfront Commission disclosed yesterday that it was issuing only temporary licenses to pier hiring bosses, superintendents and stevedores.

LYNN, Mass., Nov. 20 -- Officials of the union at the General Electric Company plant here took steps tonight to hear charges against two workers who refused to answer questions of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations in Boston yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The customs district of New York handled about $637,400,000 in exports and imports of foreign and domestic goods in June on dry cargo and tanker vessels.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman of Australia, who turned professional less than a year ago, overwhelmed Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, in the final of the international pro indoor tournament at Wembley Stadium tonight.

More than 700 students with special abilities in science will be selected for a year of graduate scientific study during the academic year 1954-55 in the National Science Foundation's third annual graduate fellowship program. The fellowships are awarded to American citizens who will begin or continue their studies at the graduate level in the mathematical, physical, biological, medical and engineering sciences during the coming year.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 -- Although many vessel operators are spurning storage grain cargoes, brokers have succeeded in lining up considerable tonnage in the last three weeks. The fleet of grain-laden freighters in Buffalo Harbor is climbing steadily.

Dr. Calvin F. Konzak, Brookhaven biologist, announced last week at the meeting of the American Society of Agronomy in Dallas, Tex., that nuclear projectiles from the atomic pile at Brookhaven National Laboratory induced resistance to rust in a single susceptible variety of oats.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 21 -- The Netherlands Government expressed concern today over what would happen if the United States ceased to supply it with military equipment after 1955. It said it had put the problem up to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Paris.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 21 -- The house where Edgar Allan Poe courted Sarah Helen Whitman -- the Helen of one of his more famous poems -- is being divided into apartments.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -- Allied consent has been given for one of the steel-trading combines in West Germany to continue operating as a unit rather than to be split in two under the decartelization program.

BALDWIN, L. I., Nov. 21 -- Two touchdowns in the final period enabled the Baldwin High eleven, coached by George Craig, to clinch the Triple A championship in the Nassau Scholastic Football Conference with a 21-7 victory over Freeport before 6,500 fans on Gardiner Field today.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 -- Predictions that department store sales during the Christmas season will range 4 to 5 per cent above those in a comparable period last year are being made here. ENGINEERS and music lovers who thought they had spawned a hobby in high fidelity now realize it is making more noise on cash registers than a loudspeaker in a closed telephone booth. From anthills of wires and dials in cellars and living rooms, high fidelity has grown in ten years into an industrial mountain worth nearly $100,000,000 and the peak is not yet in sight.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, said today that American education was under attack from "people who are trying to discredit the educational enterprise."

DURANGO, Mexico, Nov. 21 -- Italian Lancias and Ferraris traded the lead today in the big sports car division of the Pan American road race. The speed duel cost the life of Italy's Felice Bonetto -- one of the world's renowned racing drivers.

TOKYO, Nov. 21 -- Would there now be a stalemate in the Communist prisoner - of - war explanations in Korea, if, say, 25 per cent of those interviewed so far had decided to go home? Most emphatically not, is the answer given by observers at Indian Village in the demilitarized zone.

Three student panelists at the New York Times Youth Forum yesterday expressed fear that the continuing dispute between Israel and the Arab nations might eventually lead to another World War. The three other panelists, although not expressing themselves on this point, emphasized in their comments the importance of resolving conflicts between the disputants.

Research will be carried forward in five business areas, with the objective of promoting better teaching through research work.

Kaplan Assistant Professor of Pediatrics. Both received their medical degrees at Witwatersand University, Johannesburg, South Africa.

IN 1931 Carl Ebert was appointed general director and chief producer of the Staedtische Oper in Berlin. Two years later Hermann Goering offered him the position of chief of all the opera houses in Germany. But Mr. Ebert liked the Nazis so little that instead of accepting he gave up his Berlin post and left Germany as a voluntary exile.
The earnings of more than 45 per cent of this port's longshoremen in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 were substantially above the average pay of the nation's 14,000,000 factory production workers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 21 -- The Yugoslavs vote tomorrow in national elections in which paper ballots will be inscribed in secret. For the first time in postwar Yugoslavia, there will be a number of individual contests in the national elections, although most of the competition is limited to the provincial level.

The nations second largest insurance company, pledged to protect the investments of its millions of policyholders, declared yesterday that business in 1954 would maintain a level of activity almost identical to that of 1953.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Trustees of the University of Illinois were told last night that the university had netted $912,570.11 from the estate of George A. Miller, former Professor of Mathematics, who died Feb. 10, 1951. Mr. Miller had never earned more than $6,000 a year in his university post.

THE Civil Aeronautics Administration, like many other agencies of the Federal Government, has slashed millions of dollars from its budget, is discharging hundreds of its personnel and curtailing services considered unnecessary for commercial and private aviation.

BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- The key to Soviet policy in East Germany appears to be the successful carrying out of the "New Course" policy there. It is widely believed in West Berlin that the achievement of this goal is very far in the future and that until it is reached the Russians will not negotiate with the Western Allies on the question of Germany's future.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States said today that a process that degraded human dignity was "viciously at work in our own country."

SMALL rock garden shrubs have proved their value in places other than the rock garden. They may be planted, for example, to cover a dry bank, around the rim of a pool, or as an edging or group along a flower border to face down taller shrubs.

New Jersey State Teachers College at Jersey City has been designated as a testing center for the 1954 nationwide administration of the National Teacher Examinations next February. College seniors preparing to teach and teachers applying for positions in school systems that encourage or require applicants to submit their scores on the National Teacher Examinations along with their other credentials are eligible to take the tests.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Business activity in the Chicago area set new monthly high marks for September in several categories of industry, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" the night of Dec. 2 at the Martin Beck Theatre for the benefit of the Mobile Clinic of the Speyer Hospital for Animals. Mrs. S. Sloan Colt is chairman of the patroness committee for the benefit.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Bishop William D. O'Brien, auxiliary to Samuel Cardinal Stritch of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago, is now Archbishop O'Brien. Announcement of the papal elevation was made Wednesday by Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani of Washington, apostolic delegate to the United States.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 21 (AP) Lewis Hoad, one of Australia's young tennis stars, captured his second straight title today by defeating his countryman, Ken Rosewall, 8 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 9 -- 7, 10 -- 8, for the New South Wales singles championship.

HIGH-FIDELITY music systems rarely give trouble once they are properly installed. The unusually high quality of the individual components which go into the make-up of an amplifier, preamplifier, etc., combined with the careful pre-production and final testing of each item, insures a finished product which under normal operating conditions provides extremely long, trouble-free life.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Charles A. Halleck, Republican Leader of the House of Representatives, charged today the Eisenhower Administration was being "sabotaged" by Democrats who still hold key Government jobs.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII said today that public authorities should not hinder normal private enterprise in the housing field.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- To Europeans Uncle Sam has generally appeared as a heroic or a generous or an inspiring figure. Verdi's "La Forza del Destino," which was restored to the Metropolitan Opera repertory in a new production last year, was presented at the opera house yesterday. The report is that the production is still musically first class, though they are still tinkering with the arrangement of the musical numbers to make a satisfactory dramatic piece out of a somewhat rickety libretto.

NOT long ago I was driving through Bootle, a grimy industrial jungle on the edge of Liverpool. A decade ago a bomb had blown a gap in a row of shabby houses, baring the wall of one of them. The day was raw and rainy. Perched precariously on the foundation of the destroyed house a group of five women, high-colored, bare-legged, were retouching with black paint some lettering on the wall.

Dr. Willard F. Libby of the Institute of Nuclear Studies at the University of Chicago is using tritium (triple-weight hydrogen, which is radioactive) to find out how old is some of the water on earth.

THE automatic diaphragm flash computer on the Bolsey Set-O-Matic miniature camera has been made available for other Bolsey cameras as well, the Bolsey Corporation of America announces. CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A team of surgeons described this week how a "frozen sleep" treatment enabled them to drain and slice open the hearts of human patients so they could see and repair defects inside.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- The possible purchase by the state of California of the Central Valley Project, a huge power and irrigation work constructed by the Federal Government, was under study this week by a subcommitte of the Assembly Interim Committee of Conservation, Planning and Public Works.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 21 -- Members of forty-six Protestant denominations in the United States gave $1,401,114,217 to their churches in 1952, a new high record, according to a report filed here on Monday at a conference of church fundraisers.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 10 -Moslem fishermen are hauling record catches off the shores of this capital, which promises to become the commercial fishing center of Asia.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 21 -- A visit to the United States has swept away former prejudices of a 20-year-old Bavarian exchange student, Roswitha Leuthold, who is spending her junior year at Smith College. One of thirty-eight foreign students from twenty-three countries at Smith this year, her former impressions of the United States had been largely based on American soldiers "chewing gum and yelling, 'hi, babe.'"

By the tragic death of Dylan Thomas Wales and the English-speaking world have lost one of the greatest of contemporary poets. It was perhaps fitting that Dylan should end his days in America, where he was so loved and appreciated. Wales, in particular, admires the warmth with which Americans have acclaimed the poet's work -- culminating in the magnificent gesture of opening a fund for his dependents.

LIKE the Metropolitan, the Brooklyn Museum is undergoing an extensive program of modernization. A few weeks ago the Metropolitan opened Its reinstalled Egyptian galleries and now the Brooklyn Museum has done likewise.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- After some backing and filling the Malenkov Government of Russia has settled down to a policy best described as Stalinism without Stalin. The Asian despotism of the great dictator and its brutal application have been assuaged. But the political philosophy that dominates Soviet procedure, both internal and external, remains essentially unchanged.

BIRDS are on the move again. Flights of northern species are replacing many of the insect eaters which have flown southward. Even the resident birds are leaving their summer haunts. Freed now from the heavy responsibilities of nesting, birds travel farther afield.

The ten-day suspension of economic aid to Israel, ended on Oct. 28, was characterized yesterday by Averell Harriman as one of the most shameful developments in the foreign policy of the United States under the Republicans.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 21 -- Gov. C. Elmer Anderson is under increasing pressure from Republican party leaders to run next year against Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- Industrial, commercial and agricultural loans by reporting member banks in the Twelfth Federal Reserve District decreased by $10,000,000 in the week ended Nov. 11 to $3,287,000,000, up $45,000,000 over a year ago.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 -- Mayor Norris Poulson has a new policy to reduce the traditional mayoral chore of public appearances.

The latest thing in naval craft will be commissioned in Brooklyn on Wednesday -- a wooden ship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- An economy measure aimed at reducing personnel in the Army, Navy and Marine Corps by at least 10 per cent is under discussion at the Pentagon, the Army-Navy-Air Force Journal said today.

LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Fourteen whaling expeditions are heading out of European ports for the Antarctic in the annual big hunt.

Tuesday afternoon Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. hit back hard.

To him without question, belongs the title of the Duveen of the Impressionist -Post-Impressionist-Picasso-Braque period.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Norman Jacobs, a junior at near - by Highland Park High School, was elected this week as president of the New Jersey Association of High School Student in Councils.

THE major part of a $250,000 restoration project has started at Monticello,Thomas Jefferson's home at Charlottesville. Va., and will close the main part of the building to the public until March. The restoration project includes reinforcing with steel beams the first and second floors; installing a modern heating and air-conditioning system: restoring several basement rooms and replastering moisture-mottled walls.

Edward M. M. Warburg, general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, announced yesterday that Levi Eshkol, Finance Minister of Israel, would visit this country early in December to confer with appeal leaders. Mr. Eshkol will address the organization's annual national conference, which will be held Dec. 11 to 13 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NOW that Dylan Thomas is gone, how many natural poets have we among us? Poets whose habit fits them so well that when they use prose it sounds as though they were writing in a foreign language? The field of modern poetry is littered with canceled letters of credit.

ROME, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations said today that falling prices and mounting stocks of unsold food, particularly in North America, threatened to widen the gap between the world's few well-fed and the many hungry.

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, meeting in Rome tomorrow, will face among other problems that of chronic hunger in vast areas of the world and that of an agricultural surplus in the United States. It has been estimated that the United States Government's purchase of such surpluses will amount to six billion dollars by the end of the present year.

ATLANTA, Nov. 21 -- Retail trade in the Southeast for the year is an estimated 3 per cent above the corresponding period of 1952 and most merchants predict that buying from now through Christmas will be maintained at satisfactory levels.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 21 -- Rhode Island state agencies are asking for $47,000,000 for a six year capital improvement program, with most of the money to be spent for new jublic buildings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Not since the "war between the states" has the American mind been divided by "such bitterness as divides it now," the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith was told here tonight.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 21 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, who has announced his decision to retire from office, said tonight he was leaving with the "satisfaction of knowing that the country is much stronger than it was on the day I had the honor to proclaim its independence."

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- William H. Teto of Ashby, a self-described undercover man who said he had reported on Communist activities to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has been summoned to testify before the State Legislative Commission against communism.
