ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- Almost unnoticed during the two-day special session of the Legislature this week were the opening salvos of the Democratic campaign to elect Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as Governor in 1954.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 21 -- With the aid of desperate clock-stopping measures, Notre Dame scored two under-the-gun passing touchdowns to salvage a 14-14 tie with Iowa today. The deadlock qualified as one of the season's most startling upsets. The Irish, decisively victorious in seven previous starts, had been favored by two touchdowns.
A smiling, energetic woman resigned yesterday as executive director of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 21 (UP) -- Oklahoma, with the Big Seven Conference title and an Orange Bowl berth assured, methodically overpowered Nebraska, 30 -- 7, today in a Conference game before 31,000 chilled fans.
MADRID, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -- The opening of the Fenix, another luxury hotel in Madrid, has drawn attention to the importance with which Spain now regards the tourist trade.

HIGHWAYS designed for speeds in excess of posted legal limits actually safeguard the lives of motorists, according to Charles M. Noble chief engineer, New Jersey Turnpike Authority. Thus, the accident hazards created by a troublesome minority who zoom along the roads regardless of life or property damage are materially reduced.

BENGT DANIELSSON is the red-bearded Swedish anthropologist who with five Norwegian companions sailed half-way across the Pacific. from Peru to the Marquesas, on the balsa raft Kon-Tiki. The first inhabited island they very literally struck was Raroia.

Rinse out spraying equipment not once but several times with water, wipe dry and oil before storing.

A GARDEN doesn't have to have a flower border in order to be pleasing. It may consist of only evergreens and other trees and shrubs. In other words, it can be a green garden. In fact, many home owners with limited time to spend on chores would do well to consider this type of landscaping.

A NEW "Faust," new in outlook and design and as romantic in spirit as the dashing gallantries and ardent sentiments of the nineteenth century, filled the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House as it opened its season last Monday night. To many in the audience it was just another opening-night opera, and anything else might have served as well.

EVERYONE who likes to have flowers around the home should have a fairly good assortment of containers. For often either a low bowl or a tall vase or just a dainty little container is needed if the flowers are to look their best, rather than putting them in any old thing that happens to be around the house.

Loyal believers in the authenticity of Daisy Ashford's claim to authorship of "The Young Visiters" sprang to her defense last week, chiding The New York Times for including her book in a story about literary hoaxes.

CLEMSON, S. C., Nov. 21 (UP) -- Auburn's bowl-hungry Plainsmen stole passes for their first two touchdowns and completed their own for two more today in rolling up a 45-to-19 victory over Clemson in an all-offensive game before 20,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- More than 380 employes either were dismissed or allowed to quit during the three-year Congressional campaign against wrong-doing in the Federal Internal Revenue Bureau, Senator John J. Williams disclosed today.

The State of Florida is about to add to the many new brands of state school bonds that are developing from the nation-wide boom in public school building. The new Florida bond is scheduled to make its market appearance on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON; D. C. -- Two new segments of the Baltimore - Washington Expressway, which upon completion next year will replace one of the most dangerous and unsightly highways in the United States, have been opened to traffic recently.

AS a newspaper man, Eugene Lyons was in Moscow from 1928 to 1934. He went there as a vague admirer of the "great experiment." He returned a determined opponent of the system. His book "Assignment in Utopia" was one of the first confessions of bitter disillusionment.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The International Light Tackle Sailfish Tournament, which was held the past two years at Acapulco, Mexico, comes back to the Palm Beaches this year to open the winter season Dec. 8 to 11, inclusive.

ON the old story framework of slum-boy-makes-good-in-pro-baseball. Jack Weeks has built an arresting sports novel. Mario Canto, whose home circumstances are lightless and brutal, makes a hard and thrilling fight against outer and inner obstacles on his way to the big leagues.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Tony Rados, playing his final college football game, pulled a Penn State football team together today to direct a 17-0 triumph over Pitt.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Measures to control onchocerciasis, a disease often resulting in blindness, will be discussed by a committee of the World Health Organization for the first time at a week-long conference beginning Monday in Mexico City.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Republican State Chairman, Representative Dean P. Taylor, said tonight that the resignation of former Acting Lieutenant Governor Arthur H. Wicks "in all respects" met the demands of the G. O. P. executive committee.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 10 -- Queensland expects to increase her sheep by one to two million in the next few years. This hope is based on fencing out the dingo, the Australian wild dog. A fence, estimated to cost 433,000 [about $973,000]), will enclose the sheep lands of Southern and Southwestern Queensland and the Central West and Northwest areas west of the Great Dividing Range.

ROME, Nov. 21 -- Italy has agreed in principle to attend a five-power conference to seek a solution of the Trieste problem. The other conferees would be the United States, Britain, France and Yugoslavia.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 21 -- Although Marshal Tito, Yugoslav President, is more certain of tomorrow's election outcome than even former President Truman was of his own prospects in 1948, they have had one thing in common. Just as the crowds urged Mr. Truman to "give 'em hell, Harry," so have crowds that gathered around Marshal Tito anticipated fireworks.

Persons interested in furthering the work of Help and Reconstruction, Inc., have taken over the performance of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" on the night of Dec. 3 at the Martin Beck Theatre to raise funds for the organization. Mrs. Max M. Warburg, chairman of the organization's women's committee, heads the group in charge of the plans for the benefit.
LITTLE ROCK, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Louisiana State University made a first quarter touchdown, kicked a field goal and then protected its lead to nudge the University of Arkansas, 9 to 8, today.

JAPAN, with a new fleet of modern cargo carriers, is making a bid for her share of freighter-passenger travel across the Pacific. Half a dozen Japanese lines, established or reconstituted since the end of the occupation, now operate passenger-carrying freight ships from Kobe and Yokohama to the Pacific Coast, Gulf ports and through the Panama Canal to New York.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 21 -- The rolling wooded hillsides, river banks and shoreline of Fairfield County have become the scene of fighting without parallel since the Indian Wars. Battle cries and the crash of musketry have been replaced by legal briefs filed here in the courts of the county seat, but the struggle remains essentially the same, one for possession of the soil.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles, mixing the National Football League's most potent offense with a numbing defensive line, powered to their sixth straight victory tonight, 38 -- 0, over the victory-less Chicago Cardinals.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 21 (UP) -- Kentucky, after eighteen futile years of trying to beat Tennessee, downed the Vols, 27 -- 21, by taking advantage of a blocked punt in the final period today. The victory made the Wildcats a leading bowl candidate.

It was most gratifying to read Peggy Durdin's article entitled, "A New Act in Cambodia's Drama" (Nov. 8 ). Not only was the article a well written and factual presentation of the situation in Cambodia, but also a sound analysis of recent events in Cambodia which clearly show that the author comprehends fully the political factors involved and possesses a firm understanding of the problems which confront His Majesty Norodom Sihanouk and the Cambodian Government.

GREAT radar antennae, slowly and ceaselessly rotating on isolated hilltops, comb the skies of North America these days and nights on a twenty-four-hour-a-day vigil. A chain of such outposts, as long as both United States coastlines and reaching northward into Canada and the Arctic, is constantly being extended. For some type of warning system is essential to continental defense against devastating surprise in the Atomic Age.

HOUSTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Texas Tech scored twice before Houston's "million dollar" Cougars could gain a yard today, then methodically rapped out a 41-to-21 victory to keep in the running for a major bowl bid.

EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 21 (UP) -- A 30-yard touchdown run of an intercepted pass by Tommy Little, fullback, enabled Oregon State to upset Oregon, 7 -- 0, on windy, rain-swept Hayward Field today to maintain Coach Kip Taylor's record of never having lost to the Beavers' most bitter rival.

MANY indoor gardeners will be interested to learn that the exotic bird-of-paradise, long known to arrangers as a cut flower, can be grown as a house plant. It makes a handsome foliage plant throughout the year and its annual flowering is an exciting event.

Life for sidewalk superintendents grows easier day by day. Besides peepholes for observation, there are now posted descriptions of the work as it progresses.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Fordham's football squad was upset by Holy Cross today. The Crusaders dominated play virtually all the way as they swept to a 20-to-7 victory.

IF there were no such organization as the United Nations, men of good-as the United Nations, men of good-be demanding its immediate creation. The third week of opera at the Metropolitan, which starts next Monday, will be marked by a performance Wednesday evening of Verdi's "I1 Trovatore." This opera has been missing for a season. Zinka Milanov and Kurt Baum, both of whom have appeared previously in the work, will sing the leading roles.

The Bermuda conference is the sign of the general agreement among the Western Governments that Soviet policy has not changed. An apparent shift of tactics after Stalin's death led many Westerners to imagine that there might be four-Power discussions for a settlement of the German question.

MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 22 -- Society women of this section and the Great Neck peninsula are actively engaged in plans for the fourth annual Thanksgiving Ball, a benefit for the North Shore Hospital, to be given Saturday in O'Hara Hall of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point. Mrs. John Hay Whitney and her sister, Mrs. William S. Paley, are co-chairmen of a large committee.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Scott Crossfield, the first man to fly twice the speed of sound, said today that flying 1,327 miles an hour gave him a feeling "sort of like a stomach ache and a touch of the flu."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 22 -- Today was election day in Communist Yugoslavia, but the occasion was only a formality.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Americans who condone the "bizarre methods" of current Congressional investigations were charged here today with being victims of the same "poisonous abnormality" that was responsible for the Inquisition and the Ku Klux Klan.
It was good to meet Mrs. Helen Evans Brown, author of one of the bibles on our culinary shelf, "The West Coast Cook Book" (Little, Brown, 1952).
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, Nov. 23 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission rejected today, 3 to 2, a Communist plan to get the stalled prisoner-of-war explanations going again.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22--Everything is in order now for the marriage of the motion picture business and television -- on a limited scale at least.

ZURICH, Nov. 22 -- Not since the end of World War II has the stock exchange in Zurich been so disturbed as last week, when Interhandel common stock, which the week before stood as high as 1,675 francs, slumped heavily. The price sank day after day, at one time touching 1,250, closing on Saturday at 1,350.

Life insurance policyholders throughout the United States will reap a record harvest this year. Dividends paid by insurance concerns during 1953 are expected to reach a new high level of $850,000,000, an increase of 11 per cent over last year's $765,921,000.
Many investors are taking the steps necessary to make their 1953 tax liabilities as painless as possible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Federal Civil Defense Administration said today that the havoc of a major atomic attack on this country could be so terrible that 10,000 squads should be organized immediately to rescue the injured.

LEONIA, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church received unfair treatment last July before the House Un-American Activities Committee, it was charged here tonight by the man who was his legal counsel at the hearing.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 22 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations that held its annual convention here last week was a much better insurance risk than the faction-torn group that battled over the selection of a successor to the late Philip Murray a year ago.

R. Turner Arrington has been promoted from assistant vice president of Life Insurance Company of Virginia to treasurer, effective on Dec. 1. On tha tdate Herbert B. Lee, treasurer, and H. V. Schenck, vice president in charge of the investment department, will retire.

Queen Elizabeth will break precedents in the round-the-world journey she will begin tonight. She will go farther than any of her predecessors; she will visit places such as the Tonga or Friendly Islands (pop. 46,000 in 1951), where they never dreamed of going; she will use airplanes, as they couldn't or wouldn't; she will be away longer.

The battle for control of the Port of New York will be broadened today to take in Jersey City. Extending operations across the Hudson River, the new American Federation of Labor pier union will open an office -- its sixth -- in the New Jersey port. The union plans to intensify its efforts to win away from the old and orphaned International Longshoremen's Association thousands of members.
On Nov. 11 you published a letter from J. Enrique Hertzog Garaizabal, former President of Bolivia, in which he charges that the Government of Bolivia is Communist dominated.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Berliners greeted with elation today the news that, beginning next Wednesday, they will be allowed to visit West Germany without any special travel papers, for the first time since World War II.

The Rev. Dr. Ronald Bridges, executive director of the department of broadcasting and films for the National Council of Churches, declared yesterday that a "sense of responsibility" had developed out of our times. Preaching at Union Theological Seminary, he said:

Because of the many racial elements in New York City's huge population of 8,000,000, New York City long has been a "melting pot." Sometimes there are tensions or friction, and it is to the credit of sound-thinking men and women of all racial groups here that these generally are smoothed out.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The first sapling of Penn-Israel Amity Woodland was planted today by Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania on a Judean hillside near the Eashtaol settlement, midway between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv.

TRENTON, Nov. 22 -- State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes, a leader of the younger element in the Republican party in New Jersey, today assailed the caucus system practiced in the Republican-dominated state Legislature.
New York State has rejected a proposed new schedule of automobile liability insurance rates that would have discriminated against most city motorists.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, who collapsed while speaking in the National Assembly on Friday, was reported recovered today. He was expected to resume work on Tuesday.

EASTON, Md., Nov. 22 -- F. T. Ch. King Buck, owned by John Olin of Brighton, Ill., and handled by T. W. (Cotton) Pershall, captured the national retriever field trial championship today. The winner in 1952, King Buck was the first to score two years in a row since the performance of Paul Bakewell's Shed of Arden in 1942-43.

Around about are a good many manifestations that the long, bleak winter may already have settled in. There was, of course, that surprise snowstorm, which caught the elder world without chains and the younger with sleds still in the attic.

SUMMIT, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Because a local post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars objected, the phrase "a future citizen of the world" has been dropped from a pledge recited by students of Summit Junior High School.

Fifty - four patriotic societies marked Religious Freedom Week and the 300th anniversary of the incorporation of New York City yesterday afternoon at their annual service in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
The Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner declared in his sermon yesterday that the Broadway Tabernacle Church, Congregational, at Fifty-sixth Street, would remain at its present site in mid-Manhattan.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 -- Steel sales officials predict that their customers' inventory trimming will have to run its course within another two months. This appears to be one explanation of the steel order booking situation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Prices of dairy products to the consumer would be controlled by the law of supply and demand under a plan proposed by the National Milk Producers Federation, Russell S. Waltz, president, said today.
With the approach of Christmas, parents may welcome some Toy Guidance Council advice, released yesterday, on the "right toys for the right age."

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 22 (UP) -- The San Francisco 49ers remained in the race for the National Football League's Western Division Championship today as they routed the Green Bay Packers, 37 to 7, in a game played with a wet snow falling.

DR. DALLAS W. SMYTHE, research professor at the University of Illinois, is easily the country's most durable television viewer. Each year, with the help of a staff, he monitors for a full week every single minute of programming put out by the seven stations in the New York area.
Rain washed the fog, smoke, haze, smog or smaze right out of New York early today.
A season that opened to the crash of football's mighty ended for most teams last Saturday with favorites kicking the dope bucket across the country.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Breckonhill Banner, a 2 1/2-year-old black-and-white dog owned and handled by Conway H. Olmsted of Lake Forest, Ill., won the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels that brought the two-day meeting of the New Jersey Spaniel Field Trial Club to an end today.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Nov. 23 -- United States circles expressed gratification today following an announcement by President Syngman Rhee that he would agree to country-wide elections for President if Korea was unified.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee was represented tonight as having evidence in its hands sufficient to convict some Russian spies.
ROME, Nov. 22 -- An international group of farmers decided today to urge upon the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization the need for establishing a world food reserve.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Benoit Frachon, Communist Secretary General of the French General Confederation of Labor, was arrested tonight.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22 (UP) -- The Hamilton Tiger-Cats ended four years of frustration today with a 22-11 victory over the Montreal Alouettes that gave them the Big Four Football League championship and the right to oppose the Winnipeg Blue Bombers in the Grey Cup national championship game next Saturday.

The first concert of the Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble was played on Saturday evening at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. H. A. As in previous seasons the program was enterprising, containing a mixture of new and old music for combinations not too frequently encountered.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Cornelius (Corny) Shields, 1952 North American sailing champion and former national dinghy titleholder, gave his rival skippers a sailing lesson in the light airs which hovered over Larchmont Yacht Club today to win the third championship regatta of the dinghy season.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Sid Smith tallied two third-period goals within 29 seconds tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 1, before 6,308 fans.

Inventors are taking out fewer patents than they did a generation or so ago -- a phenomenon on which we have commented more than once. Why there should be this decline has not been satisfactorily explained. That ingenuity is as active as ever is proved by the flourishing state of industry and the advance of technology as a whole.

Representatives of nearly two score colleges, seminaries and hospitals took part yesterday in the dedication of three stained glass memorial windows at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

SHIRLEY BARKER, whose command of the resources of the English language is exceptional, is one of the most disappointing of modern American novelists. Each of her novels is worse than its predecessor. What the reason is for this distressing situation is not clear. Miss Barker is a former librarian, a poet and an authority on Colonial America. Her books are plainly the result of loving care.

A Federal Maritime Administration hearing of the disputed arrangement by which American Export Lines, a subsidized steamship company, is acting as agent in this country for the Italian Line, is to start today. C. W. Robinson, hearing examiner, will be in charge of the proceedings, which will get under way at 10 A. M. at 45 Broadway.
Five new films, including importations from England and Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Three of this week's larger exhibitions are devoted to French art of the past and present. French seventeenth-century paintings are being shown at Jacques Seligmann's, eighteenth-century paintings at Duveen's and, opening tomorrow at Curt Valentin's, is a first showing of paintings, sculpture and ceramics done by Picasso in the last three years.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 22 -A group of 180 left Bangkok today in the first phase of a plan to repatriate as many as possible of the Vietnamese refugees in Thailand. The refugees' first stop is Saigon from where they will be sent to their villages.

The fifth program of the Concert Society of New York late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall was oddly assorted, but behind the diverse works presented there was one common factor. All three were played by top-ranking experts in a manner that was free of all self-seeking.

The latest setback of the Giants, a 24-21 defeat by the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds yesterday, is easy to explain. Two little fellows, the 5-foot, 9-inch Eddie LeBaron, and the 5-foot, 10-inch Bill Dudley, took charge in the second half and turned an 0-14 deficit into a 3-point victory that moved the 'Skins into third place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League.

James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, Archbishop of Los Angeles, presided in the sanctuary of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday at a solemn mass marking Religious Freedom Week. The week is part of this city's tercentenary celebration.
The list of collegiate football's unbeaten and untied teams was reduced to nineteen over the week-end, with Maryland the lone major eleven still having a perfect record.
Americans have 40 pep cent of the world's income, according to a survey by the Twentieth Century Fund.
To cut costs, the Board of Estimate is considering a policy of renting, instead of building, some types of structures.

Two vice presidents of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc., have been elected to the company's board of directors, it has been announced by Edmond J. Moran, president. They are John S. Bull, vice president in charge of sales, and John J. Metzner, who directs operations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 22 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion said tonight that the proposed United Nations censure of Israel for the attack on the Jordanian village of Kibya would not weaken his Government's resolve to protect the lives of its citizens.
For the teen-age girl the party dress is of utmost importance, particularly at this time of year, with the holiday parties looming. Her requirements are varied she needs dresses for dates and dances.

A 23-year-old pianist from the Netherlands, Daniel Wayenberg, made his United States debut yesterday afternoon as soloist with the Philhamonic-Symphony in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Wayenberg chose to exhibit his wares in that most trusty of warhorses, the Rachmaninoff C minor Concerto.

" Temple tramplers" demonstrate the "danger of going to church," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday at Riverside Church. He included among them devotees of popular preachers, tranquillity seekers, sectarian-minded persons and the church-going spectator.
BOSTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Calum Mackay's third-period goal gave the Montreal Canadiens a 2-2 tie with the Boston Bruins tonight. The Canadiens lead the National Hockey League by 3 points.

Price increases of $15 to $118 on the 1954 line were announced yesterday by the Studebaker Corporation. The cars will go on display today at Studebaker outlets in the city. All twenty models in the Champion and Commander series that comprise the line are affected by the upswing.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The president of Texas A. $ M. College, David H. Morgan, said today an investigation had been completed into the case of a pre-law student who had been told to leave school by a group of students who did not like what the youth had written in a letter to the college newspaper.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The government, a major rubber buyer, will soon ask industry representatives how it can help prop up the sagging market for natural rubber.
Trading in the foreign exchange market during the past week was limited. Price movements in the British pound sterling and Canadian dollar was confined to a narrow range.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 22 -- Dutch foreign trade continues to develop favorably.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Dullness enveloped almost the whole stock market today. Losses in industrials. though widespread, were usually less than one shilling (fourteen cents).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A two-day conference to discuss ways of cutting red tape in proceedings before administrative Government agencies opened here today. The first day's session ended in a sharp debate over the principal proposal for dealing with the problem.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- Twentieth Century-Fox, preparing to launch its 1954 program of CinemaScope productions, is reaching out to corner big-name male stars.
THE current fog, smog, smaze and precipitation have been rough on all hunters but the waterfowl enthusiasts were hardest hit by the freakish weather.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- As far as Italy is concerned invitations to a five- power conference on Trieste could be issued immediately, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. Although no decision has yet been reached on a conference agenda and procedures, if necessary such questions could be taken up after the conference had been convoked, the spokesman added.

Directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation declared yesterday a higher quarterly dividend of 150 cents, an extra of 25 cents and a stock dividend of 5 per cent, all on common shares of record of Dec. 4.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, implied tonight that the national debt limit would have to be raised.

In your editorial discussing the recently announced objectives of the new head of the United States Information Agency, Theodore C. Streibert, you state that the "emphasis will be on information as such rather than propaganda." But this was also the announced intention of Mr. Streibert's predecessors.
East Coast longshoremen will vote next month on whether to accept the last offer made to them before they struck on Oct. 1. The voting date will be between Dec. 5 and 19.
PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 23 -- Soothing news tonight for millions of slumber seekers: Rhythmic murmurs are to replace raucus roars often emitted by trucks on city streets and rural roads.

Many members of society and well-known persons in music and diplomacy attended yesterday afternoon the annual concert for the benefit of the Bagby Music Lovers Pension Fund in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. George L. Bagby is president of the beneficiary, which provides pensions for needy artists.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Sir Walter Monckton, Minister of Labor, said today that the United States and Britain should not be deflected from the main task of leading the free world to peace by misunderstanding each others' intentions and domestic affairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23--Short- term borrowing costs of the Treasury equaled an interest rate of 1.488 per cent for the latest weekly issue of $1,500,000.000 of three- month Treasury bills sold yesterday. They bill be dated Nov. 27 and will mature Feb. 25.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezrat Benson today announced acreage allotments assigned the various producing states for planting cotton under a rigid production control program proposed for 1954.

Stocks moved erratically yesterday. There were wide swings in early trading but by the close both losses and gains had been reduced, a semblance of steadiness had been restored and the net loss on the day turned out to be far smaller than had once seemed likely. The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks slipped 0.88 point to 175.54.

TOWARD the end of the sixteenth century, when the Portuguese had succeeded in establishing a trading base at Macao, Jesuit missionaries supported financially by the rich merchants of Macao began to spread their faith in the ancient empire of China. At that time Marco Polo's narrative of his travels was the chief source of information about China and little enough of that fascinating book was believed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower declared tonight that one of the basic democratic principles of this nation's greatness was the right of every man "to meet his accuser face to face."

During the past two years I have kept track of the useless mail delivered at my house. About 75 per cent of all mail delivered goes to the waste basket. It has reached a point where I do not bother to open or examine any mail not first class, excepting papers and periodicals to which I subscribe.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 23 -- Milwaukee County sheriff's deputies are being organized in an American Federation of Labor union.

Edward A. Ruppell, former Republican leader of Richmond County, died late Sunday night of a cerebral hemorrhage. He had been scheduled to go on trial next month on charges of stealing party funds and of testifying falsely before the State Crime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Former President Hoover, chairman of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, today announced the appointment of a twelve-man task force to study activities of Government lending agencies.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- In Westchester County many aged patients who are chronically ill are dependent upon inadequate accommodations, a committee reported here today.

Advertising agency operations, always considered rather complex, are becoming more complicated because of two far-reaching factors -- "the second retail revolution" and the growth of media, new and old.
Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Mayor-elect, returned to his Municipal Building office yesterday and went to work.
A Queens hair-net manufacturer went on a rampage through his home early yesterday, sending his wife, his 7-year-old daughter and himself to the hospital with serious wounds.

Eating habits ir America have changed radically since 1941, Miss Dorothy Klitzke, assistant professor of home economics at Cornell University, said yesterday. She addressed the annual extension conference for the New York Metropolitan Area Food Marketing Program.
Public utility companies borrowed $30,000,000 in the public market yesterday on the security of issues of first mortgage bonds sold at public bidding.

The police received a report early today that a sit-down strike would be staged at 8:30 this morning by members of the old International Longshoremen's Union on Piers 58 to 62, North River, in the Chelsea area. The reason given was dissatisfaction with the activities of two foremen on behalf of the new A. F. L. union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A 7.7 per cent population growth for the Mountain and Pacific states between April 1, 1950, when the last census was taken, and July 1, 1952, was reported today by the Bureau of the Census.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Eric A. Johnston, who has just completed a tour of Middle East capitals at the request of President Eisenhower, said here today he was confering with United Nations officials about the kind of legal arrangements that would be required to implement the United States plan for a "T. V. A. on the Jordan."

Senator Frank Carlson, chairman of the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee, will attempt to convince the next Congress that in handling the mail the hand is not quicker than the electronic eye.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 23 -- Not everything went smoothly in yesterday's national elections but the Communist Government, which was without formal opposition, recorded a resounding official triumph.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Georgia Tech has accepted an invitation to be the host team in the Sugar Bowl football game on Jan. 1, 1954.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 23 -- Victors in a court suit that ended with a full $100,000 award for 150 horses and burros slaughtered by Federal rangeland officials, thirty-three Navajo tribesmen left for home today -- riding atop trucks loaded with gifts of warm clothing, blankets and canned goods.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 23 -- Bermudians finished putting up flags, crowns, royal banners and bleachers today and prayed that the warm sunny weather and clear skies would continue tomorrow for the visit of Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh.

Tonawanda, N. Y., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Nov. 30 on bond issues totaling $4,494,000 to finance water, drainage, sanitary sewer and paving projects. The bonds will be dated Aug. 1, 1953 and will come due serially on Aug. 1 from 1954 to 1981.

The problems the average middle income New York family encounters in finding suitable housing were discussed yesterday on the "Mrs. New Yorker Wants to Know" radio series arranged by the Women's City Club of New York and station WQXR.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Corn and soybeans paced the grain markets, which gained considerable bullish momentum today. In early trading wheat, rye and oats were inclined to lag, but all finally joined the climb, led by corn and soybean futures.
WESTFIELD, N. J., Nov. 23 -- Japan and her role among the free nations of the world were discussed here today by students representing six secondary schools.
The Russian Government acquired the six-story building at 49 East Sixty-eighth Street yesterday as a residence for Andrei Y. Vishinsky, the Soviet Union's permanent delegate to the United Nations.
The newest addition to New York's sports plants will be opened today.
The end for "South Pacific" may come on Saturday evening, Jan. 16. Within a day or so, its Broadway closing date will be settled unless, of course, an unusual upsurge in business decrees otherwise.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A Senate hearing was told today that there was "very definite proof" that heroin smuggled in from Communist China was responsible for the rise in narcotics addiction among juveniles on the West Coast.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., the Speaker of the House, returned from Europe today and said that the prospects for peace were "much better" than two years ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The expected showdown between the Communists and the West over the question of calling Chinese delegates Chinese delegates in the United Nations was put off today.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden sent a personal message to Maj. Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi, the Iranian Premier, a week ago, the Foreign Office disclosed tonight. Contents of the message, which was sent via the Swiss Embassy, have not been revealed.
JUAREZ, Mexico Nov. 23 (AP) -- An Italian Lancia and an American Lincoln scored record victories as the biggest, fastest and deadliest of four Pan-American road races ended today.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that it had turned over to District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County a report charging irregularities in roofing contracts at three schools.
For thousands of dairy farmers in New York State, heavy debts have become as real as their sixteen-hour day and seven-day week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Israel sought today to force Jordan into "direct and immediate negotiation" by invoking an article of their armistice agreement that would require the United Nations Secretary General to convoke a conference at the request of either party.

A Federal Maritime Board hearing to determine whether American Export Lines, Inc., should continue to act as agent in this country for the Italian Line, a foreign competitor, began here yesterday morning.

At the end of June, when harvesting was just getting under way, the Dow Jones futures index of commodity prices stood at 156.50. Many persons will no doubt be surprised to know that last week, despite big crops and heavy surpluses, the index had actually risen from that earlier figure to 159.39.
From the manger scene to the portrait of a child in front of the Yule tree, the meaning and joys of Christmas are depicted in almost endless variety in this season's card collections.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Delegates and associates here expressed their regard today for the services rendered to the United Nations by Sir Gladwyn Jebb, head of the British delegation, who is to become British Ambassador to France.

Commodity prices moved irregularly higher yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Volume eased but coffee and cocoa continued active and the domestic sugar contract had the most sales since Oct. 21. Cocoa, wool, soybean oil, hides, rubber, zinc, copper and tin closed higher; cottonseed oil, sugar, burlap and potatoes were lower and coffee and lead ended mixed.

Sir Gladwyn Jebb's three years in this country have been spent as Britain's delegate to the United Nations, not as an envoy to the United States. He has, however, made his personality felt here strongly and favorably. When critical moments for the Western Powers have come up at the east end of Forty-second Street Sir Gladwyn has been an effective spokesman for Western ideals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Defense Department, carrying out President Eisenhower's executive order on the safeguarding of official information, prepared today to declare the "restricted" stamp obsolete.
DALLAS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A Cotton Bowl official said tonight that a visiting team for the New Year's Day football game may not be picked before late Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture today recommended a 7 per cent cut in spring vegetable production next year and a 24 per cent slash in the early commercial potato crop.

VIOLA, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- A youth described as a "teen-age maniac" went on a rampage late today in an unincorporated area in the Town of Ramapo. The youth, who was still at large tonight, beat and injured seriously a woman who was ill in bed with pneumonia, wrecked the interior of a private home and apparently started a small fire in a summer hotel.

Jack Benny is still determined to make a hit out of "The Horn Blows at Midnight," one of his unsuccessful movies, produced in 1945. The comedian has taken the original basic idea from the movie and prepared a special fifty-minute play to be presented on "Omnibus" over the C. B. S. felevision network on Sunday at 5 P. IV[. Ralph Levy wilI direct the play, which will originate in Hollywood.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Among the exhibits laid before the Randall Commission for strengthening the economy of, and hence the support of free enterprise in, the non-Communist world, reports by fifteen foreign groups are especially arresting. These groups are composed of business men abroad who are affiliated with the International Chamber of Commerce, and their views were solicited by the United States Council of that organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Dr. Marek Stanislaw Korowicz, who had broken with Poland's delegation to the United Nations, attested today to the enslavement of his countrymen -- perhaps 300,000 of them -- in forced labor camps in Poland.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- An Army Ordnance officer testified today that a million tons of titanium could be used annually in Army Ordnance equipment if plenty of the material were available and price was no concern.
The Young Presidents Organization heard yesterday of the advantages of buying or selling companies, at a regional meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The Soviet bloc caused a last-minute hitch today in United Nations plans for a fund to help under-developed countries.

Reflecting a sharp rise in sales, the consolidated net income of the Corning Glass Works and its subsidiaries rose to $10,198,314 in the first three quarters this year from $7,092,972 in the corresponding period of 1952.

An exhibit of export goods from Austria, reflecting substantial economic and trade gains made by that country in the last two years, was opened here yesterday. It will be permanently housed at the Austrian Consulate General, 31 East Sixty-ninth Street, and changed three times yearly.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- On the theory that young people cannot be expected to defend and promote democracy unless they know something about it, the New York State Teachers Association urged today that schools undertake a day-to-day program for education in democracy.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Federal Judge Stephen W. Brennan signed a consent judgment today against seventeen members of the National Association of Leather Glove Manufacturers, halting alleged restraints of trade in the leather glove manufacturing industry.

It is difficult to believe that the editorial "Israel vs. Jordan" in The New York Times for Nov. 20 was written either in serious vein or with any real knowledge of the background of current Israeli-Arab tensions.
HONOLULU, Nov. 23 -- Completion of a global air tourist network by the addition of a trans-Pacific tourist class and a tourist class over the mid-Atlantic was announced here today.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 23 -- Adlai E. Stevenson came to golf-loving Georgia today to tell of Democratic plans to to shoot 108: "Out in 52, back in 56." The Democratic Presidential nominee of 1952 got a warm welcome to Georgia, which is President Eisenhower's favorite golfing retreat.

The Aluminum Association has issued a statement "welcoming" the clarification by the Department of Defense of its policy on the buying of foreign semi-fabricated aluminum products for defense purposes.

Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary for External Affairs, urged here last night that freedom-loving nations accept each other's assurances of "sincerity and good faith" in dealing with the questions of security and subversion.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address last night to the B'nai B'rith Anti-Defamation League in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:...
BONN, Germany, Nov. 23 -- In a formal statement United States authorities in Germany denied again today that they were planning to revive coal and steel cartels in West Germany.
Today's new film is "Cease Fire," a stereoscopic, realistic drama of the Korean war which will have its premiere tonight at the Criterion. The Paramount production was directed by Owen Crump.
ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Louis (Bobo) Newsom, right-handed pitcher known as the most widely traveled man in baseball, announced his retirement today after twenty-six years in the game.

The story of climbing Mount Everest by the leader of the British expedition, Sir John Hunt, has been scheduled for Jan. 25 publication by Dutton. "The Conquest of Everest" describes the meticulous preparations for the undertaking, progress to the mountain, the selection of the two final assault parties and the strike for the peak by Hillary and Tenzing.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- The East German Government urged its West German counterpart today to demand economic concessions from the Western powers similar to Moscow's decision to end reparation payments by the Soviet-occupied zone.

The State Housing Commission announced yesterday it would turn off heat, gas and electricity next Monday night in the last two projects of those established in the commission's emergency program for more than 17,000 families of World War II veterans.

Interest-bearing deposits of the Canadian Bank of Commerce crossed the $1,000,000,000 mark for the first time in the institution's history during the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31. They were up more than $48,000,000 to $1,004, 482,525.

The millions of people who live in the New York metropolitan area have had a grave but wholesome warning in the past week of the necessity for a more aggressive and relentless attack on the smoke problem. The smog, smaze or smurk that settled down last Tuesday and wouldn't lift because of weather conditions was a frightening thing.

One hundred thousand Junior Red Cross members throughout the city are preparing to make the coming holiday season more cheerful for the ill and the less fortunate here as well as in other parts of the world.

One of the greatest guessing games since the passing of Cock Robin will end shortly after 11:30 A. M. today. President Walter F. O'Malley of the Dodgers will reveal to all the world -- or that part of it interested in baseball -- the new manager of the Brooks.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Tuesday, Nov. 24 -- The political committee of the Mapai party voted in Jerusalem early today to nominate Moshe Sharett as Prime Minister to succeed David Ben-Gurion. Mr. Ben-Gurion has announced his decision to retire.

This is a rebuilding year for Columbia's basketball coach, Lou Rossini. Although seven of eleven men were lost through graduation, the current Lion squad has speed, adequate balance on defense and depth.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The global tour of Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh began at 8:01 o'clock tonight when one small light detached itself from those lining the far runway at London Airport and floated slowly into the darkness above.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- United States corporations offered $6,400,000,000 of new securities for sale in the first nine months of 1953 -- 10 per cent less than in the corresponding months of last year -- Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, struck a new note today by recalling Moscow's wartime cooperation with the United States and declaring the two countries still should act together "in the cause of peace and progress."

IT was inevitable, of course, that the football folks would pounce on Notre Dame's strategem of feigning injuries as a clock-stopping maneuver in order to gain the tie with Iowa last Saturday. This was the first topic of conversation as they gathered yesterday at Toots Shors for their weekly exchange of truths, Half-truths, lies and exaggerations.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Wes Santee of Kansas shot ahead of the pack at the three- mile mark to win the fifteenth annual N. C. A. A. cross-country run going away today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 23 -- Production of tin in concentrates increased during September in all important producing countries, the International Tin Study Group reported here today World mine production was 14,800 long tons, compared with 13,700 in August.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Justice Department said today that a White House official requested and obtained a report from the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Harold Glasser, accused of spying for Russia, a month before he received a 1946 Treasury Department promotion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Technological progress has been a major factor in the expansion of equipment purchases by private business in recent years, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce said today.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 23 -- In the case of Dr. Cheddi Jagan, leftist former Prime Minister of British Guiana, India seems to have reached some sort of compromise between traditional hatred of colonialism and a newly found suspicion of communism.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The appointment of Sir Gladwyn Jebb, permanent British representative in the United Nations, as Ambassador to France was announced today by the Foreign Office.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- Creation of a world food reserve was urged today at the seventh conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization by Prof. Josue de Castro of Brazil, chairman of its council.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 24 -- Communist China's official radio announced today that the Chinese and North Korean Communist Governments signed a ten-year economic assistance agreement in Peiping yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People protested today against Maj. Gen. William S. Biddle's participation in a ceremony dedicating a segregated school at Fort Hood, Tex.
A recital of more than usual excellence was played last evening by the pianist Nikita Magaloff in Town Hall.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 23 -- Fairleigh Dickinson College of this city and Bergen Junior College of Teaneck, N. J., will be merged under the name of Fairleigh Dickinson College it was announced here today by Edward T. T. Williams, chairman of the board of trustees of Fairleigh Dickinson.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Georgi N. Zarubin, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, told the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee today that his delegation believed the Charter and staff regulations gave Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold adequate provision for the removal of unsatisfactory staff members.

If the American people held a popularity contest among all the activities of the Federal Government it is a safe bet that the work of the National Park Service would stand high in the front ranks. As custodian of twenty-eight parks and nearly 150 other areas this agency played host last year to the incredible total of 42,000,000 people -- in statistical terms, one out of every four persons in the entire United States.

PRESIDENT TRUMAN arrived in Berlin the same day as I did [July 15, 1945 I was eager to meet a potentate with whom my cordial relations, in spite of differences, had been established by the correspondence included in this volume. I called on him the morning after our arrival, and was impressed with his gay, precise, sparkling manner and obvious power of decision.
New Yorkers were called upon yesterday by Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, to save water.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 24 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission was reported to be preparing to publicize its differences over the handling of the problem of "explanations" to prisoners of the Korean war who do not want to return home.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 23 -- As the major phase of the balloting for Sudan's first Parliament approaches its end it is becoming increasingly clear that the Sudanese voters intend both to turn the British out and to hold the door shut against any major Egyptian influence.
Perhaps it was football when Notre Dame players feigned injuries, saved precious seconds and gained a tie with Iowa last Saturday. But was it cricket ?

American Fidelity and Casualty Company, major insurer of trucks and busses, is offering to its common stockholders rights to subscribe to 150,000 new shares of $1.25 dividend convertible preferred stock until Dec. 9 at $22.25 a share.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 23 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh reasserted his role as the star of his own court-martial today with two tirades and two more attempts to walk out.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, said today that he was sorry to disappoint the Soviet delegation to the United Nations and "some of the prophets of gloom on both sides of the Atlantic."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- An examiner's report urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to retain existing railroad rates on grain off the Great Lakes for export through New York City, Boston, Portland, Me., Philadelphia and Baltimore.

COPIAGUE, L. I., Nov. 23 -- The Suffolk County, District Attorney's office and Babylon Town police are investigating two blazes in eight days at the partly built home of a Brooklyn Negro business man planning to move into a predominantly white area in this industrial town.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 7 points higher to 19 points lower than Friday, with the far months showing the most weakness.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent indicated in the House of Commons today that Canada's re ply to a second United States request for permission to question Mr. Gouzenko had been sent to Washington.

The steel industry's operating rate this week is scheduled to be the lowest thus far this year -- 87.6 per cent of capacity, down 3.1 points from last week's actual rate. A railroad strike at one big mill is believed to be the principal cause of the decline, but repair work and slackened demand at some other mills are also said to be contributing causes.
TRENTON, Nov. 23 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that municipalities had no legal right to impose fees for the privilege of publishing a newspaper.

Directors of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation yesterday approved two plans for substantially increasing deliveries of natural gas to the metropolitan New York-New Jersey-Philadelphia areas.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 23 -- Republican members of the 1954 State Senate met briefly in Trenton this afternoon, elected officers and then adjourned to meet here tonight with Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 23 (UP) -- A Government attempt to silence one of its chief newspaper critics failed today through the action of a local judge.

The 1953 football season is now history for the vast majority of college teams, but much unfinished business remains to be taken care of Thursday and Saturday before the books are closed for the year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Consideration of the Trieste question was postponed again today by the United Nations Security Council. The new time for debate is the week beginning Dec. 8.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Federal Parole Board refused today, for the second time, to release Alger Hiss on parole from prison.

Nat Winston, 37-year-old operator of the Suburban Club and Restaurant in Brooklyn, observed yesterday that "it never rains but it pours." He had reasons. Within thirty-six hours the club and two of its patrons had been robbed of nearly $25,000 in cash and jewelry.

TOKYO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of the agreement for economic ad cultural cooperation signed in Peiping yesterday between the People's Republic of China and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, as broadcast by the Communist China radio:

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 15 -- In the lovely Rio Yeguare valley stands the Pan American School of Agriculture, dedicated to the progress of Latin America through development of one of its most basic needs, the trained tropical agriculturist.
TORONTO, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Twelve rubber companies and the Rubber Association of Canada were fined $170,000 today for fixing prices and restricting competition in the rubber industry.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23 -- (UP) -- Billy the Kid, the missing Navy goat, was returned to wildly cheering midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy tonight by an Army lieutenant colonel.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 23 (AP) -- A dual conspiracy to fix prices in Alaska's big salmon industry was charged today by the Federal Trade Commission.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Following is the text of a letter from Abba Eban, Israeli representative, to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, involving Article XII of the Israel-Jordan Armistice Agreement, followed by the text of the article:

Harold Riegelman was "welcomed home" yesterday to the Citizens Budget Commission at a luncheon given by that organization in the Yale Club. He had been on leave from his post as general counsel, spending three months as Acting Postmaster of New York and three more in an unsuccessful bid for the Mayoralty on the Republican ticket.
Some progress is being made in setting up in Latin America circulation standards similar to those used by the Audit Bureau of Circulations in this country.
There is urgent need for Spanish-speaking volunteers who will give part-time service as interpreters for the Puerto Rican patients at the Welfare Island Dispensary, 535 East Eightieth Street.

The arrest of the French Communist labor leader Benoit Frachon on Sunday is an inducement to take another look at the problem of communism in France M. Frachon is accused of fomenting sabotage and conducting subversive propaganda in the army. The charge could not be made to stick against other Communist leaders last spring and it may not be upheld against M. Frachon now.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Studies of Federally aided child health and welfare programs to ascertain what they actually do and what the ydo not do would receive top priority in a proposed research program for the Federal Children's Bureau.
The Brooklyn College football situation erupted anew yesterday when Ted Rosequist, head coach since 1948, was relieved of his post and returned to a full-time teaching schedule.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The fate of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, N. Y., was left dangling today. Its future, however, was viewed here as not too bright.

Gray skies -- usually no cause for by -- brought cheer yesterday to many New Yorkers who had seen almost no sky during six days of maze, smog and fog. Yesterday's rain clouds were a portent of blue skies, which the Weather Bureau aid would break through the gray t intervals today.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 (AP) -U. C. L. A. was named today by unanimous vote as Pacific Coast Conference representative in the Rose Bowl against Michigan State's Spartans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -The Republic of Korea today awarded decorations for meritorious service to four Americans.

On the marshy edge of La Guardia Airport, along the lonely Rikers Island Channel shore, an engineer spied a mass of twisted gray metal and fabric in a ditch at 8:45 A. M. yesterday. That was how it became known that five persons had died in a private plane crash in fog there perhaps thirteen hours before.
The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced yesterday a grant of $3,750,000 to the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association.

The timing of the exhibition and public sale of original prints by young American artists, which opens today at the Museum of Modern Art, is excellent. For, with prices averaging from $35 to $40, with techniques ranging from elaborate color woodcuts to richly black lithographs and subjects from whimsical walruses to non-objective designs, there is an abundant and excellent supply of "art for Christmas gifts."
BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- The Massachusetts Legislative Commission on Communism confirmed today that four college presidents and a dean had testified before the commission in private sessions.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- William Goetz will tackle a big-scale Western, "Dawn In the Sky," with James Stewart heading the cast, as his second independent production.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Purchases of December wheat against sales of May and other deferred deliveries marked grain trading here today. There was also persistent buying of corn, which lifted that cereal to new highs for the movement. The spread between December and May wheat narrowed considerably under free selling of deferred wheat positions because of favorable weather reports and a dearth of export buying orders.

A song recital of high competence was offered last evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by Roberta Peters, coloratura soprano. The event was second in the Major Concert Series presented by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

A new work by Kurt Singer, author of "3,000 Years of Espionage'' and "Spies and Traitors of World War II," is published today by the Beacon Press. "The Men in the Trojan Horse" is an account of the work of some of the most expert espionage operators of our age, such as Lavrenti Beria.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The chief of the Italian Administration in Somaliland offered an emphatic rebuttal here today of nationalist criticism of his regime.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -- If Navy's football team can attain the emotional peak that the brigade of midshipmen is working up to, Army's slightly favored squad won't have a chance in the fifty-fourth clash between the service academies at Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium on Saturday.

While the dinner itself is a whole day and some extra-long hours away, there are indications that everything is properly in order. The butcher has been seen and the size of the turkey discussed, and toward the middle of this afternoon a monstrous package wrapped in clean white paper will be delivered to the cook.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Abolishment of the Federal public housing program was demanded today by delegates to the annual convention of the United States Savings and Loan League. In a resolution adopted at its final session, the convention denounced the program as "extremely costly" and cited "increasing disadvantages" which it said experience with the program is uncovering.

When the listener has the impression that what he is hearing is not instruments sounding notes printed on paper but musical strains stirring in the imagination of a composer -- that is great' playing. And the New Music Quartet provided playing of that caliber last night in its program at Town Hall.

TORONTO, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- One of Canada's biggest paper companies today announced it would "assist in the development of a sister commonwealth nation" by supplying advice, technical help and men for an $80,000,000 newsprint development in New Zealand.

Brooklyn is running true to form. The unpredictable has happened again. Walter Alston, recently manager of the Montreal Royals, has been selected to succeed Charlie Dressen as manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers.

VICTORY over Japan was neither the most difficult nor perhaps the most far- reaching of the problems which confronted us at the Potsdam Conference. Germany had collapsed; Europe must be rebuilt. The soldier must go home and the refugee return, if he could, to his country. Above all, the nations must make a peace in which they could live together if not in comfort, at any rate in freedom and safety.
The new Mayor's advisory council is to be small and compact enough to "avoid being a debating society," Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner made known yesterday.

Two powerful-looking vehicles, each of a kind never seen before on the streets of New York, drew up yesterday morning before the American Museum of Natural History for an inspection by museum officials before taking off for the desert and mountains of Africa.

It is high time to take a firm stand against the oft-repeated view that reform of our tax structure must again be delayed for reasons of expediency -i. e., the need of the Federal Government for revenue, regardless of how it is obtained. Our Congress has for years shirked the job of eliminating inequities from both income taxes and excise taxes alike.

A return to two deliveries of mail a day in residential areas and the elimination of Saturday deliveries would save $20,000,000 a year nationally, the Senate postal inspection team was told yesterday.

IT was unexpected enough to be rated as the most logical of all moves -- by Dodger standards, anyway. The fast-talking, controversial and extremely well-known Charlie Dressen has been succeeded as Brooklyn manager by the quiet, mild and almost unknown Walter Alston. Howdy, stranger. Jes' tie up your hoss to the hitchin' post and mosey up to the bar for a get-acquainted drink. It sure beats all getout, don't it?
The old December cotton futures contract on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 6 points yesterday but other months lost 3 to 15 points.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The stock markets opened weak today, steadied around midday and made a small recovery in the afternoon. A rally in British Government securities eliminated early losses and replaced a few of them with small gains.

Thirty Children of Paul's and eighteen Vicars Choral -- to give the members of St. Paul's Cathedral Choir their formal titles -- ended a two-month American tour with a concert at Carnegie Hall last night.

Today's new film is "Flight to Tangier," a Paramount melodrama in Technicolor with Joan Fontaine, Jack Palance and Corinne Calvet, at the Palace. Nat Holt produced and Charles Marquis Warren wrote the screen play and directed. Robert Douglas, Marcel Dalio, Jeff Morrow and Richard Shannon are among the supporting cast.

Tomorrow. Thanksgiving Day, is one holiday observed in all financial centers of the country. All the United States stock and commodity markets will be closed. Canadian and European markets, however, will be open for business as usual.

The states of North Carolina and Florida raised $35,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance the building of public schools. For Florida, the transaction represented the first borrowing under a $100,000,000 program authorized last year by an amendment to the state Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The State Department gave full backing today to Vice President Richard M. Nixon's statement that the United States had "erred" in disarming Japan at the end of World War II.
Following is the text of a radio and television address last night by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times:

As he has done so often in the past, President Eisenhower has again made with sincerity and simplicity a statement to the nation of the kind of thing in which he believes. This time his declaration, addressed to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, dealt with the President's concept of America and the character of our society.

REGENSBURG, Germany, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Two anti-Communist Czechoslovaks who skittered over the Iron Curtain to freedom in a tiny sports plane said today they had fled their homeland because they "no longer could distinguish truth from lies."
WEST POINT, Nov. 24 -- King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece closed their official visit to the United States with a tour of the military academy today.

IF Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse have their wits about them, they will read the riot act to the Columbia Broadcasting System for its merciless and inexcusable distortion of "Life With Father" on television. One of the most beloved works of the contemporary theatre has been turned into a tawdry and pedestrian Hollywood farce in the worst video tradition. Out with it!
Supporters of Robert F. Wagner Jr. and his running mates spent $781,561 in the recent city election campaign, financial reports filed with the Board of Elections show.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Administration was in the midst of another controversy today over the implementation of President Eisenhower's principle that an accused man should always have the right to confront his accuser.
The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company approved an extra dividend of $2 a share and a quarterly dividend of $1.25 on the common stock, it was announced yesterday.

The proposed extension of a Government waiver permitting American Export Lines to continue to act as agents here for the Italian Line was supported yesterday by two Export officials and an Italian diplomat at a Federal Maritime Board hearing.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 24 -- The United States, Britain and France still are searching for a formula to solve the crisis over Trieste. Thus far they have not made any formal proposals to either Italy or Yugoslavia for a conference.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The United States advised the Soviet Union today that one way to change public opinion toward Moscow was to have the Communist party stop seeking the violent overthrow of the United States Government.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler said today that the average standard of living in Britain had improved during the two years the Conservatives have been in power.

LYNN, Mass., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Two employes of the General Electric Company said tonight that they had denied charges of alleged communistic activities at "a fair and democratic" hearing before the executive board of Local 201 of the International Electrical Workers Union, C. I. O.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 24 -- Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania told an audience here tonight that former President Truman was "exceedingly negligent and used poor judgment" in the Harry Dexter White case.

The story of a great or even good wine concerns the flowering of the grape blossoms, the forming of the fruit, picking and crushing the grapes, storing the juice (sometimes for more than two years) and bottling and aging it. When a connoisseur says sound wine is a delicate production of nature and man, he is not exaggerating.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 -- A Republican committee of twelve men and women, headed by the state chairman, Samuel L. Bodine, will seek to take control of the party in New Jersey as soon as Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll leaves office on Jan. 19.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A sharp controversy over merits of a proposed new Securities and Exchange Commission rule permitting certain types of public utilities to market their securities by negotiation rather than competitive bidding was in the making here today.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 24 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield set up here today the first of fifteen projected regions of the Post Office Department in a reorganization to achieve economy and efficiency through decentralization.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 24 -- In a forthright statement of policy on Communist infiltration of the school system, representatives of 53,000 members of the New York State Teachers Association declared today their readiness to testify fully before legislative bodies.
The Flatbush mystery has finally been solved. Walter Emmons (Smokey) Alston, a tall, scholarly sort of fellow who will be 42 next Tuesday, is the new manager of the Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Long Island Transit Authority opposed the Pennsylvania Railroad's new plan for reorganizing the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road today on the ground that it would result in fare increases that riders could not pay.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 24 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower arrived here today for a Thanksgiving holiday family reunion.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 24 -- The West German Government, which steadily has been taking more and more money from the nine states in the Republic called on them today for yet another increase in their contributions to the Federal treasury.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged last night in a television address that former President Truman had given help and encouragement to others besides Harry Dexter White who were suspected Communists or fellow travelers.
Upon reading Philip M. Brown's letter in your Nov. 14 issue appealing against the recognition of Red China I feel a more realistic approach to the problem is necessary.
Mighty Maryland, which kept its record spotless while Notre Dame held to a tie, took over the top spot in The United Press college football ratings yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov 24 -- Outstanding commercial debts due to American exporters will be fully liquidated by the end of this year, Finance Minister Oswaldo Aranha said today.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Nov. 24 -- Jamaica, all dressed up and bursting with excitement, prepared today to welcome the first reigning monarch to set foot upon its shores.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Army's coaching staff, which says Navy has superior manpower, will field a starting team that matches the middies man for man in their game Saturday at Philadelphia.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 24 -- The famed 11,000-ton aircraft carrier Belleau Wood, which went through almost every major Pacific battle in the war with Japan, arrived at the Norfolk naval shipyard. Portsmouth, Va., today from the West Coast. This is the first time the carrier has been on the East Coast since her commissioning in 1943.
Despite a bad slump in soft surface floor coverings and spotty sales in the hard surface field, the outlook is bright for sales of linoleum, plastic tile and other floor and wall coverings.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Canada will allow United States investigators to cross the border to examine Igor Gouzenko, the former Soviet Embassy code clerk who helped uncover a Communist spy ring.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The British Government has made oral representations in Cairo about an increase in incidents against British personnel and installations in the Suez Canal zone.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- A sharp and unexpected storm blew up in the House of Commons today against Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill. Parliamentary veterans were searching their memories in vain for a time when a bolt came so completely from the blue.

When Roland Petit's Ballets de Paris plays its New York season at the Broadway Theatre beginning Jan. 19 under the joint auspices of S. Hurok and the Messrs. Shubert, the repertoire will consist of four ballets by Mr. Petit, all new to this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said tonight the fight against communism "will not be won by following the type of leadership exemplified tonight which seeks to undermine" former President Truman and President Eisenhower.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Nov. 18 -- A large terracotta scarab, found on the biblical battlefield of the Vale of Rephaim, outside Jerusalem, where King David defeated the Philistines, has been identified as the seal of the defeated Philistine commander.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Holders of the fourteen-month Treasury notes maturing on Dec. 1 will exchange about 99 per cent of the outstanding issue, or $9,920,000,000, for other Treasury securities.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. H. L. Nathenson's Guy broke a 25- year-old track record in winning the $6,000-added Pocomoke Handicap at Bowie race course today, despite a muddy, holding track.

In one of the most remote sections of the United States, the southeastern corner of Utah, white ranchers have for some twenty years been disputing grazing rights with the Navajos. The argument came to a head with the slaughter, by agents of the Federal Bureau of Land Management, of 150 Indian-owned horses and burros found in areas said to be reserved by law for the whites.
ROME, Nov. 21 -- The Cardinal's Flying Squad is the latest sensation of the anti-Communist fight in Emilia, the principal Red strong-hold in Italy.
British manufacturers are leading a movement to eliminate concealed and artificial government subsidies for exporters in Great Britain and western European countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A trained welfare worker testified today that more than 7,500 youths in New York were narcotics addicts.

With an increase in the number of hospitals referring chronically ill youngsters to the Handicapped Children's Home Service, the group urgently needs more volunteer workers, Mrs. Margery D. McMullin, executive director, said yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A Congressional investigation was told today that two top A. F. L. Teamsters Union men set up an agency that paid their wives $65,000 in dividends in less than three years.
ATLANTA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of the speech by Adlai E. Stevenson to the Georgia Legislature today:

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- The "democratic bloc," embracing all of East Germany's political parties and mass organization, urged today that the Government take extraordinary measures to collect potatoes from the peasants. It said many of the peasants were hiding their crop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The right to teach and learn Marxism at the Jefferson School of Social Science in New York was defended today in a petition signed by 134 persons, including educators and ministers.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 24 -- The Indianapolis Archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church today frowned on the use of premises of the church by the American Civil Liberties Union.

ROME, Nov. 24 -- The United States is "anxious to find ways of using its available stocks, to improve the living standards of hungry people" provided this can be done "without interfering with normal markets and normal channels of trade."

New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $15,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings include mortgage bonds, preferred stock and common stock. The money raised by the financing will be used largely to retire bank loans and to pay for new construction work.
Reflecting an increase in gross revenues, the consolidated net profit of the Hilton Hotels Corporation in the first nine months this year rose to $4,281,238 from $3,104,704 in the 1952 period.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 25 -- The United Nations Command has disclosed that it is making final preparations for its effort to convince its former personnel now in neutral custody to break with communism and return home.

PARIS, Wednesday, Nov. 25 -- Unable to reach an accord on the endorsement of the European Army Treaty, the French National Assembly, in the early hours of today, suspended its foreign affairs debate until 3 o'clock this afternoon.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- A resolution expressing "the strongest censure" of the Israeli raid on the Jordanian village of Kibya, in which fifty-three persons were killed, was adopted tonight by the United Nations Security Council.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Penn Center, a $100,000,000 development along the lines of New York's Rockefeller Center, was born today with ground-breaking ceremonies for a twenty-story office building.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. Cocoa, burlap, coffee, cottonseed oil, potatoes, hides and zinc closed lower, wool, rubber, copper and tin were higher, and soybean oil, sugar and lead ended mixed. Trading was light but soybean oil had its fifth largest volume of the year and the most sales since Oct. 23.
