LEVAN, Utah, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The mightiest underwater explosion ever recorded in the United States hurled a column of water about 3,000 feet into the air today and rattled windows fifteen miles away.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations has won its first foothold in the New York Telephone Company. This became known yesterday with a disclosure that members of the Empire State Telephone Union, an independent organization representing 4,804 upstate plant employes, had voted to affiliate with the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 24 -- Bermuda today greeted Queen Elizabeth II, the first reigning British sovereign to visit the islands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, ruled today that a Reserve officer should not be dismissed from the service although his father and sister were charged with Communist associations.

Yesterday's stock market was a dull affair until about the last hour of trading. Then, strong demand developed for half a dozen blue chips, with the result that the list, on the average, more than erased all the ground lost on Monday.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 25 -- The United States special envoy, Arthur H. Dean, told the Chinese and North Korean Communists today that the Soviet Union had sided with them in the Korean war and had therefore ruled itself out as a "neutral."

The Republic Steel Corporation has acquired, through a Canadian subsidiary, a deposit of high quality limestone adequate to supply its open hearth steel-making furnaces for several generations at the present operating rate.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said tonight the United States never would win the peace until it had done away with the "witchhunt and the merchants of hate."

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 24- Lawrence McKeown, Democratic leader of Nassau County, charged today that the deputy commander of the county's Civil Air Patrol had been linked with Communist activities. Accusing the Republicans of "downright carelessness, or worse", Mr. McKeown demanded an investigation into Nassau's civilian defenses.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 24 (AP) -- It will be Maryland, the nation's No. 1 football power, against fourth-ranking Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl at Miami on New Year's Day.
The special state commission investigating harness racing is preparing to check on the operators of all concessions at the track.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Major sectors of the economy showed relatively small changes this fall, according to the November report of the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce. Production in a number of industries was being trimmed while others showed a firmer tone compared with the earlier part of the year, the report showed.
A Solemn Mass yesterday marked the observance of Religious Freedom Week at Old St. Peter's Church, Barclay and Church Streets, the city's oldest Roman Catholic parish.

The theft of jewelry worth $59,000 from Lee Shubert's apartment in the Ritz Towers was discovered yesterday. The loss was noted by the theatre owner's wife as she and her husband were preparing to depart for Florida.

Traditional Thanksgiving services will be conducted today and tomorrow in churches here. Gifts of fruits, vegetables and money will be taken to the needy at home and in hospitals. Dinners will be provided for unfortunates by many missions, churches and church-affiliated welfare agencies.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the New York Junior League Ball to be held tonight in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the organization's welfare fund. Mrs. Frank Richards Ford is chairman of the executive committee for the fete.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The United States got 279 new citizens today in a mass naturalization ceremony described by immigration officials as probably the largest ever held at a military post.

THERE were only four men in the Hudson bomber plane when it smacked down onto the choppy waters of the North Sea. It was the late autumn of 1944, and Flying Officer Harding had been assigned to ferry a V. I. P. back to England after he had completed some hush-hush investigations of the captured German rocket sites.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The procedural wrangle in the General Assembly's Legal Committee over how Nationalist Chinese should be addressed, has been settled, it is hoped, in a high-level compromise deal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, said today that the Democrats were ''prisoners of their own tragic errors in coddling" Communists in the Government.

It seems to me that both former President Truman and Attorney General Brownell, in their presentations of the circumstances surrounding the retention of Harry Dexter White in Government service, have failed to mention the most important and obvious circumstance of all: the climate of the times in which the events in question occurred.
Operations of Montgomery Ward Co. in the quarter and nine months ended Oct. 31 resulted in lower earnings than a year ago, reflecting partly more competitive conditions.
Your newspaper on Nov. 20 carried a news item to the effect that the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs recommended that it be continued as a combination of officials and private citizens.

When you consider that there are only three starters available from last season's quintet you can agree that Howard Cann has every reason for being pessimistic concerning the 1953-54 basketball outlook at New York University.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The New York Knickerbockers, leaders of the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, rallied in the third period tonight to defeat the Boston Celtics, 103 -- 92.

Mrs. Henrietta S. Klotz, secretary to the former Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau Jr., since 1922, confirmed last night that she had testifed on Monday in a closed session of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in Washington.

Directors of the South Porto Rico Sugar Company approved a project yesterday for erection of a plant at La Romana in the Dominican Republic for production of furfural from bagasse. Capital investment required for the project will be less than $7,000,000 and it is planned to have the new plant in operation by mid-1955.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 24 -- Indignation here over reports from London that the growing Communist influence in Indonesia would be a major item at the Bermuda conference reached a climax today when Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo declared that Indonesia was an independent and sovereign state that would view with concern any international interference with its personal affairs.

Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that, effective April 1, it would establish round-trip air-tourist service between New York and Madrid at a fare almost 25 per cent less than its first-class summer season rate to the Spanish capital.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 24 -- A major spy trial began here today under a smoke screen of words and procedure imposed on Finland by her political dependence on her next-door neighbor, the Soviet Union. Eight persons, six of whom are believed to have been working for the Soviet and the remaining two for Sweden, are on trial.

The City Department of Correction announced yesterday that it had ordered its 1,062 correction officers to turn in their badges and 250 of them to surrender their revolvers. In an un usual step, it began the distribution of identification cards as substitutes for badges.

The football Giants are angry. Not at themselves, as some of their fans might immediately conclude, but at the Philadelphia Eagles. That's what Coach Steve Owen said yesterday at the weekly Polo Grounds luncheon.

Stockholders of Merrit-Chapman Scott Corporation cleared the way yesterday for a further expansion of that contracting concern's facilities. The annual meeting approved an increase in the authorized common stock to 3,000,000 shares from 1,000,000.
Rehabilitation funds for Korea will be applied mainly to purchases of capital goods so that the Koreans can produce what they need, the Export Managers Club was informed yesterday.

Dr. John Edward Lowry, a 55-year-old Flushing physician, was elected last night to the presidency of the Medical Society of the County of Queens. He is the first Negro doctor to be chosen head of the 147-year-old medical organization.

The biggest toy buying splurge in history will be under way in the next five weeks. More than $500,000,000 worth of playthings, about 10 per cent more than in 1952, will be sold by the nation's retailers from Thanksgiving to Christmas, according to Melvin Freud, president of the Toy Guidance Council.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A conference to discuss ways of reducing administrative red tape got snarled up in it today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The State Department said today that a note would be delivered to the Soviet Union tomorrow from the West proposing that the four major powers resume their negotiations on the long-overdue state treaty for Austria.

Keyed to the Thanksgiving dinner are a number of items in a new shop at Hammacher Schlemmer. Attractively shown in a small, white - walled setting flooded with light, the shop's wares are made up of accessories for the home, all in contemporary style.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Pacific Greyhound lines asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve a distribution of 97,300 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value as a dividend on its common stock.

Co-Capt. Jack Hyatt turned in his most impressive running effort of the season yesterday in Fordham's scrimmage with the freshmen. The effort won for Hyatt the starting left halfback job Saturday in the Rams' season finale against Villanova in the Polo Grounds.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy started his showdown public hearings yesterday on whether Soviet spying might still be going on in the Army Signal Corps.

" How many failures have marked my political career!" admitted General de Gaulle in a recent press conference in Paris. Undiscouraged by this patent fact, the General and his followers in the present Cabinet are making a desperate effort to defeat the advocates of the European Army project.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- John Foster Dulles said today that it was "entirely appropriate" for a Congressional committee to ask Canada for permission to question a former Soviet Embassy clerk now under Canadian protection.

The New York Rangers will have an opportunity to gain ground in the National Hockey League when they meet the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight, then play the same team again in Boston tomorrow night.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles, although they have been in existence as a new major-league club for only a little over a month, have already sold more than $300,000 worth of tickets for their coming campaign this summer.
Once upon at time most babies were born at home.
The United Press yesterday revealed its 1953 All-America football team, selected by 265 sports writers and broadcasters in a nation-wide ballot.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Coach Forest Evashevski of the University of Iowa says there was a "gentlemen's agreement" among Big Ten football coaches that players don't "go down" unless they are hurt. Notre Dame generally is considered to abide by Big Ten rules.
The Federal Maritime Board took the first step yesterday toward providing the Bloomfield Steamship Company with a subsidy for service between western Gulf of Mexico and North European ports.
A new shutdown of the city's milk supply was averted yesterday by Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L.
" The Shrike," last year's Pulitzer Prize winner, will be revived at 8 o'clock tihs evening at the City Center.
MERYLE RENIE EVANS at the New York Historical Society has come up with some interesting research notes on Thanksgiving Day in this city.

William Walter Remington's perjury conviction was upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals in a two-to-one decision. The 37-year-old former Government economist is serving a three-year term in the Federal prison at Lewisburg, Pa.

A 5-year-old boy was revived for brief period in Bellevue Hospital yesterday after he had been admitted as "dead" from a truck accident. His heart, massaged back into rhythm, kept beating for two hours forty minutes before it stopped forever.

WITH hunting conditions improved, and a long holiday week-end in prospect, the Catskills should give up a number of bucks during the next few days, but the heavy pressure probably will be exerted on Monday, when the deer season closes.

A suit to invalidate the law rearranging legislative seats that was enacted only last week at a special session of the Legislature was started yesterday in Queens. The petitioner in the case is David A. Fay of 209-33 Thirty-ninth Avenue, Bayside, a retired police lieutenant now practicing law in Jamaica.

Chief Police Inspector Conrad H. Rothengast applied yesterday for retirement, effective Dec. 24. The first chief of the uniformed force ever drawn from the detective ranks, Mr. Rothengast had served in every grade since he started as a rookie policeman nearly thirty-three years ago.
East Coast longshoremen will vote Dec. 16 and 17 on whether to accept the last contract offer made to them by employers before they went on strike Oct. 1.

Newly designed engines with increased horsepower are offered in the 1954 truck line announced yesterday by the Chevrolet Motor Division of General Motors Corporation. The vehicles will go on display Saturday in Chevrolet dealer outlets throughout the city.

VIOLA, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- After an intensive overnight search through this rural area, a youth who had been described as a "teenage maniac" by a woman he was alleged to have beaten was captured today by the Ramapo police. He turned out to be a local lad who had consumed too much wine, the police reported.

Again we have all been urged by the city Water Commissioner to avoid water waste. The request is a reasonable one, for the city's Catskill and Croton supplies are down now to about 45 per cent of capacity. Unfortunately, such rainfall as we have had this fall has not been sufficient to keep our water supplies from dwindling steadily.
Some opinions on noise in the home were aired yesterday at a symposium here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A plan to bring more small machine plants within the scope of the rapid tax amortization provisions of the Defense Production Act has been worked out by the Small Business Administration with the Office of Defense Mobilization.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 -- The first trans-Pacific flight of a Japanese commercial airliner since World War II was completed at 11:07 A. M. today, when the City of Tokyo, flagship of Japan Air Lines, taxied up to the apron at San Francisco International Airport.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 24 -- A building contractor, surprise witness at today's hearing in the Superior Court-ordered inquiry into this city's financial transactions, testified that two city officials had urged him a month ago to give false testimony regarding work he had done two years ago on the home of one of the officials.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Mississippi's proposed program to give Negro children schools equal to those of white children leaped a major hurdle late yesterday when the State Senate adopted the costly program's first revenue measure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of the Air Force Harold E. Talbot today was summoned before a Senate subcommittee to give his views on testimony that drastic shortages of titanium may reduce the United States Air Force to a "second best" status.
ATLANTA, Nov. 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared today that the Eisenhower Administration could not long govern the nation and guide the world by "promises, postponement, paralysis and slander."

Replying to the persistent Soviet "peace offensive" which seeks to cover up aggressive designs with pacific words Ambassador Lodge has again outlined before the United Nations the fundamental consideration which governs American policies and actions. This consideration, which takes account of the ultimate objective admitted by the Soviets themselves, is that the Kremlin "seeks the violent overthrow of the United States" and "is plotting our destruction."
The chemical industry's investment in new plant and equipment for this year will total $1,600,000,000, William C. Foster, president of the Manufacturing Chemists Association, predicted yesterday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 24 -- Plans for an overhaul of the Cabinet to close a breach threatening the position of Prime Minister Mohammed Ali were put off today to early December. An announcement said Mr. Mohammed Ali had "extended his stay at a health resort by five days."

Although the discussion on forced labor before the United Nations Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee has not concluded it has progressed far enough to indicate the main outlines of the argument. The nations that uphold the report of the special U. N.-International Labor Organization Committee have given voice to the conviction that the committee's conclusions, especially those referring to the system of forced labor in the Soviet Union and its satellites, are correct.
BUFFALO, Nov. 24 -- A Supreme Court jury late last night awarded a New York City woman $50,344.47 for the death of her husband and personal injuries, the result of a two-car crash here Aug. 12, 1950.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Despite opposition in local areas and a pending law suit, the State Thruway Authority is pushing into the pick-and-shovel stage its plan to route the cross-state expressway close to the Yonkers Raceway.
OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- Efforts of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee to extend its questioning over the border onto Canadian soil aroused bitter resentment and indignation here today.

The Governors of New York and New Jersey expressed certainty last night that everything was in readiness for driving out waterfront crime when the bi-state pier compact becomes fully effective on Tuesday.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be represented by Lord Ismay its Secretary General at the forthcoming Western Big Three talks in Bermuda, it was announced today

MANILA, Nov. 24 -- Halfway on his trip around the world, Vice President Richard M. Nixon has come to some solid conclusions about the matter in which he is most interested -- the reasons behind the appeal of communism to the great masses of the people of Asia.
The slump that has plagued the electric household appliance industry so far this year appears to have bypassed the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
Most city employes will get something extra this week-end to be thankful for -- an extra day off.
Juan T. Trippe, chairman of the fortieth annual National Foreign Trade Convention, observed in his opening remarks to that meeting:

The Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries, producers of parts for the automotive industry, attained a new high sales record in the fiscal year ended last August and increased earnings over the previous year.

FRUSTRATION was the fate of this final Conference of "the Three." I have not attempted to describe all the questions which were raised though not settled at our various meetings. I content myself with telling the tale, so far as I was then aware of it, of the atomic bomb and outlining the terrible issue of the German-Polish frontiers. These events dwell with us to-day.

Their long good-will barnstorming tour to Japan finally at an end, the baseball Giants are now about to concentrate their energies on gaining a little goodwill for themselves at the Polo Grounds for 1954.
FORT BRAGG, N. C., Nov. 25 -- Dispersion and speed, deception and surprise are the paratroopers' answer to the increasing threat of atomic weapons to airborne operations.

YONKERS, Nov. 25 -- State Senator William F. Condon, Yonkers Republican, has explained further his visits in Sing Sing Prison to Joseph S. (Joey) Fay. On Oct. 2 Senator Condon said his visits to the convicted union extortionist were accommodations to George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, and other union officials.

In a preholiday lull volume slipped yesterday on most items traded on the New York commodity exchanges. Rubber, however, showed a flurry of activity. Prices moved irregularly with sugar, zinc, lead, copper and tin mixed; cocoa, burlap, coffee, cottonseed oil and soybean oil higher, and rubber, hides, potatoes and wool lower.

Having deposited "Cyrano" in the storehouse, Jose Ferrer and his playmates have installed "The Shrike" at the City Center, where it opened last evening. This also is a fascinating theatre work, and it is done with skill by some of our best theatre workmen.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Navys coach, Eddie Erdelatz, revised his practice schedule today and ordered more rough work to "sharpen" the midshipmen for their game with Army.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- At the Commerce Department here, officials expressed amazement at reports that the agency's study of investment possibilities in the South African market should be resented there.

The clapping of 100 pairs of hands at St. Vincent's Home for Boys at 66 Boerum Place, Brooklyn, last night welcomed back two former inhabitants of the shelter whose cause for thanksgiving was that they had survived a death march and three years in a Korean prisoner of war camp.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Top White House staff members were hopping mad today about Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's TV-radio, speech last night.

The home owners of Riverdale in the Bronx have the City Planning Commission on their side in trying to preserve the present character of their community against encroachment -- or development, depending on the point of view -- of large-scale apartment houses.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Although the British Government is willing to do all it can to speed the establishment of the European Defense Community, it refuses to guarantee by a long-term treaty the maintenance of British forces on the Continent at their present strength.

MILFORD, N. H., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Milford's police chief, Oliver G. Williamson, admitted today that prior to becoming a law officer he was a "dues-paying Communist" working at a war plant, but the town's Selectmen voted tonight to keep him anyway.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 25 (AP) -- A national fraternity today asked a Federal Court for an injunction restraining the State University of New York from banning national fraternities and sororities from units of the State University.

Under existing farm legislation when total supplies of a basic commodity such as wheat, corn or cotton exceed a pre-established "normal" steps must be taken to bring about a reduction in the surplus. The Secretary of Agriculture decides how much the reduction should be, and then translates that into acres that may be planted.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Cornell, newly crowned champion of the Ivy League, will meet Pennsylvania for the sixtieth time in their traditional Thanksgiving Day game before 40,000 at Franklin Field tomorrow.

There is a glimmer of truth in the talk about town that Betty Hutton may appear in the forth-coming musical version of "Seventh Heaven." Reached at his office yesterday, John Golden conceded that he had discussed the project with Hollywood's famous bundle of energy, and that the actress was willing to undertake the part of Diane.

The United Nations Security Council has voted censure of Israel for the Kibya raid. The U. N. is the international authority that sanctioned the creation of the State of Israel. It brought about the armistice after the Palestinian war and has maintained ever since on the ground a supervisory committee to see that the truce is kept.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Finished with heavy work, an Army football team that is "as ready as it can be" began putting on the final polishing touches today for Saturday's big contest with Navy at Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25 -- Georgia's House of Representatives today approved two of Gov. Herman Talmadge's legislative proposals that he maintains are necessary to meet a possible adverse decision by the United States Supreme Court in the school segregation case.

INCHON, Korea, Thursday, Nov. 26 (UP) -- A Czech officer who left Communist territory only six days ago to join a neutral inspection team here "apparently" shot and wounded himself in his quarters today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Roman Catholic Bishops made public today a statement praising the self-regulatory machinery adopted by the motion picture industry to guard the moral qualities of films.
The Delaware Power and Light Company is giving its common stockholders rights to subscribe for 232,520 new shares of common at $24 a share until Dec. 15.
Plans to form an American Action Committee, designed to combat the trend toward internationalism in the United States, were disclosed yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, Nov. 25 -- American Legion Post No. 8 here has asked the New Rochelle Community Chest to withhold funds for the Guidance Center of New Rochelle, Inc., until the status of its consultant, Dr. Goodwin E. Watson, has been clarified. It cited similar action taken last week by the Larchmont Chest.

" Blue chips" participated diffidently in a buoyant pre-holiday stock market yesterday. The list as a whole seemed to be enjoying considerably more strength than the fifty stocks in The New York Times combined average, which rose 0.48 points and closed at 177.32, for the best final level since Nov. 9.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The United States Consumer Price Index has risen slightly for the eighth straight month.

Despite Soviet rebuffs to all their efforts to start genuine negotiations on the concrete problems facing the world, the United States, Britain and France have embarked on another attempt to induce Soviet Russia to restore freedom and independence to at least one country -- Austria.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon told the United Nations Security Council today the resolution adopted yesterday regarding the Israeli raid on the Jordanian village of Kibya "is the first gleam of hope in years that the Arabs are not going to be wronged again."

STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 25 -- J. Harry Spear, town building superintendent, handed Nelson Downs, plant superintendent of the Sikorsky division of United Aircraft Corporation, a permit at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon Thus there ended quietly a controversy that has churned the community for months, provoked reaction in Washington and echoed across the country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Considerable reductions can be made in military as well as economic aid to Western Europe in the fiscal year starting next July 1, Harold E. Stassen has advised Congress.
The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics Consumer Price Index for this city for October, which was released yesterday, showed virtually no change over the September level.

The New York Rangers got back on the winning road last night. Opposing the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden, the Broadway Blues carved out a 5-3 triumph to the satisfaction of a crowd of 8,725.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 25 -- Preliminary discussions between the United States and Pakistan on a military alliance may be tabled indefinitely.

In a deal closing out its realty holdings in Greenwich Village, the Estate of Marie Hillenbrand has sold the five-story building contraining two stores and five apartments on lot 22.6 by 39 feet at 281 West Twelfth Street.
Payment of a 10 per cent stock dividend to shareholders of record of Feb. 11 was recommended yesterday by the board of trustees of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The United States won three clear-cut victories in the United Nations today on the issue of programs for world economic development. They were:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The District of Columbia Board of Commissioners -- the city's ruling body -- today ordered all its agencies to hire and discharge employes without regard to race, creed or color.

Julius Mintz, real estate operator, has contracted to purchase the remodeled four-story nine-family apartment house at 362 Henry Street, Brooklyn, from the Matove Realty Corporations. The property, on a plot 22 by 102 feet, is in the same block with the Long Island College Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following changes for the week ended Nov. 18, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
KARACHI, Nov. 25 -- With the retail price soaring here the Government announced today that it would purchase from Japan and other countries during the next three months more than $1,300,000 of cloth.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- In an intensive effort to influence French public opinion at a critical time, Walter Ulbricht, acting Premier of East Germany, said today that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's chief target was France, rather than the Communist world.

The U. S. S. Aggressive, a wooden, highly maneuverable mine-sweeper, was placed in commission yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn. Rear Admiral Roy T. Cowdrey, commander of the yard, turned her over to her skipper, Lieut. Lawrence W. Kelley of West Roxbury, Mass.

During the past week we have observed with heartfelt emotion the commemoration of Religious Freedom Week in the City of New York. It is good to know that the Acting Mayor of this great city has invited New Yorkers to pray for those in other lands who do not enjoy the blessing of religious freedom, a sentiment which you so nobly echoed in your editorial columns this week.
Members of the new Hi Neighbor Club, all past 60 years, were entertained yesterday with a variety show staged by residents of Mary Manning Walsh Home, whose average age is 78.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 25 -- Eric Louw, Minister of Economic Affairs, accused the United States today of an "unfriendly" action against South Africa.

WISCASSET, Me., Nov. 25 (UP) -- The investigation into the mysterious death of Mrs. Sally Maynard Moran, 49 years old, of New York, on Monhegan Island last summer was officially marked "closed" tonight.

Construction of a shopping center at Hempstead, L. I., has been stopped temporarily. Disputes have arisen among shareholders of Hempstead Shop Park Corporation, which is building the center, and financial problems have been encountered.
The Board of Estimate will not consider until next Tuesday an appeal by nine private bus companies for a higher fare and reduction of tax payments to the city.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 25 -- The preliminary Korean peace conference has reached a crucial stage. Within the next two or three sessions the United Nations representative, Arthur H. Dean, should have accumulated enough data to report back to the nations he represents.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- An ex-convict, his wife and their college student son were arrested today in connection with an $681,700 armored truck robbery in Danvers, Mass., March 25, 1952.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative, said today that it would be "unwise" for the United Nations General Assembly to renew debate on the proposed Korean peace conference as long as discussions on arrangements were continuing at Panmunjom.

Each of us, sitting down to his own table today, can reckon best his own reasons for giving thanks. Thanksgiving is, as one of our Presidents said, "altogether a good custom," having the "sanction of antiquity and the approbation of our religious convictions." It is a day given over first of all, perhaps, to celebration of abundance.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 25 -- Gov. Gordon Persons told applauding Alabamans today that Adlai E. Stevenson was "an all-American" around whom Democrats should build their team for certain victory in 1956.
A "chance caller" at the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn sixteen years ago who apparently just dropped in to look around has left $2,500,000 to the hospital for a new building.
Civic and business spokesmen and a priest importuned the City Planning Commission yesterday to remove the dross, but not the gloss, from Times Square.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 25 -- Business and political circles have been analyzing throughout today the puzzling interpretation of a decision made late yesterday by a special committee set up in the Senate. This committee approved a policy of selling Chile's copper production, second largest in the world after the United States, to all countries without distinction.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Income taxes from increased earnings of the 63,000 disabled men and women who received vocational rehabilitation in 1952 will repay in two-and-a-half years the Federal expenditure of $22,100,000 on the program that year.

A plea for further removal of international trade and exchange restrictions was made by L. S. Mackersy, president of the Imperial Bank of Canada, in addressing shareholders at the seventy-ninth annual meeting in Toronto yesterday.
The Federal Maritime Board hearing on an extension of a waiver permitting American Export Lines to act as agent in this country for the Italian Line, a foreign competitor, was adjourned yesterday.
An effort to oust George Morton Levy as a director of the United States Trotting Association is expected to be made at its annual meeting next month.

White chrysanthemums, snapdragon and white oleander trees combined with boxwood and smilax provided the traditional white and green decor for the annual New York Junior League Debutante Ball, held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Forty-two debutantes of this season, provisional members of the New York Junior League, were guests of honor.

The letter of David Stock urging a complete ban on private passenger cars in the congested business areas of New York has emboldened me to submit a less drastic suggestion, which I have mentioned orally to many friends. Truth to tell, I have received very little encouragement.
The city will mark today its first Thanksgiving Day since the end of hostilities in Korea.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The three Western Allies opened every possible door today to the resumption of negotiations on an Austrian state treaty with a reluctant Soviet Union.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Emlyn Williams was welcomed back to the West End stage tonight as an actor-playwright, putting aside the lectern and beard of the Charles Dickens readings for a chilling role in a murder thriller.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 25 -- Moshe Sharett's nomination as successor to David Ben-Gurion as Prime Minister of Israel was unanimously confirmed tonight by the Mapai party's Central Committee. The nomination will be recommended to President Izhak Ben-Zvi who has constitutional authority to call upon a member of the Knesset (Parliament) to form a new Cabinet.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 25 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower, comfortably settled in their new white cottage overlooking the fairways of the Augusta National Golf Club, are planning a quiet family Thanksgiving.

When Sri Aurobindo died in 1950 at the age of 78, he was considered one of the great Hindu seers of the century as well as poet, critic, scholar, thinker, nationalist and humanist. One of his major works, "The Mind of Light," will be published tomorrow by Dutton.

Although there are nine letter men back from the 1952-53 squad that carved a 20-6 won-and-lost record, height and experience seem to be the chief problems confronting Coach Ken Norton at Manhattan College this season.
A reprieve seemed possible last night for the "Tweed Courthouse" at City Hall's back door.

Simplicity and perfection of line generally characterize Pauline Trigere's designs. Her resort collection, shown by Bonwit Teller yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, re-emphasized this with handsome linens and piques that, completely without trim, relied upon their flawless cut for beauty and distinction.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 25 -- Reports of a proposed military alliance between the United States and Pakistan have brought forth a renewal of anti-American propaganda by pro-Indian officials in Kashmir.
A former convict was arrested yesterday afternoon after attempting to hold up two banks on Eighth Avenue in ten minutes.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The suburbs are excellent for rearing children, but they can add to life's problems for grown-ups, in the opinion of Leonard Mayo, executive director of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children in New York.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Virginia sportsman, Christopher T. Chenery, saw his 8-year-old color-bearer Fly-Lo make a sloppy track look almost fast today by running six furlongs in 1:11 1-5 to win the Lothian Handicap.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned rather sluggish yesterday and prices fell 8 to 14 points. The opening was 1 to 6 points below Tuesday's close.
ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- New York was accused today of "rapidly becoming a 'Tobacco Road' state" because of "flagrant violations" of the migrant farm laws.

King Paul of Greece received yesterday copies of the New Testament in modern and ancient Greek in a ceremony at the Bible House of the American Bible Society, 450 Park Avenue. Queen Frederika was unable to attend.

UNITED NATIONS, N Y., Nov. 25 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Legal Committee serenely resumed business today, just as if the recent squabble over calling the Chinese delegate the Chinese delegate had never happened.
A career of forty-three years with the Panama Canal Company and its forerunner, the Panama Railroad Company, will end on New Year's Eve for W. R. Pfizer, one of the port's veteran shipping experts.
LONDON, Nov. 25 (Reuters) -- Hungary's Olympic champion soccer team today defeated England in Wembley Stadium, 6 to 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 (UP) Little Eddie Chavez of San Jose consolidated his claim for a shot at the lightweight championship tonight as he pounded out a close ten-round decision over fourth-ranked Art King of Toronto.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 25 -- Colgate's Red Raiders are slight favorites over Brown tomorrow morning. Colgate has won its last three games, but Brown coaches are depending on the light schedule since the Bruins' good game against Harvard to work to their advantage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The armed services are exploring the possibility of shrinking over-all manpower requirements by 230,000 during the fiscal year to begin July 1.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Prices improved slightly in the stock markets here today but there was no corresponding rise in business volume. South African gold minings issues and the commodity share markets were firmest. On the other hand, one or two groups of industrials such as textiles seemed to be slipping again in the late dealings.
A former detective, who survived an explosion that killed his colleague, helped the police trap three burglary suspects because he remembered a face.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The chairman of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee protested tonight against the terms set by Canada offering to make Igor Gouzenko available for questioning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 -- A battle of proxies for control of the Blair Holdings Corporation will be fought at the annual meeting in New York in April, according to Eugene H. O'Donnell, attorney for two local stockholders who are suing to oust the directors.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Nationalist China charged in the United Nations today that the Communist Peiping Government had turned the Chinese mainland into a "vast slave labor camp" in which at least 6,000,000 men, women and children serve.

MONTREAL, Nov. 25 -- The Montreal Gazette says in a frontpage story appearing in tomorrow's editions that Fred Rose, one-time member of the House of Commons for Montreal-Cartier and convicted member of a Russian spy ring exposed by Igor Gouzenko has gone behind the Iron Curtain He now is said to be in Czechoslovakia.
The American Federation of Labor has rejected a suggestion that it join with the Congress of Industrial Organizations in closing its foreign offices.

CAIRO, Nov. 18 -- Thousands of the Middle East's countless blind, traditionally doomed to idle darkness or beggary, will benefit from a modern rehabilitation center established near here by the Egyptian Government and the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Prospects of increasing to $500,000 the size of securities issues exempt from registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission were described as bright today by Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut.
Had the sacrifice fly rule been changed a year earlier, would Mickey Vernon and Carl Furillo still have won the 1953 batting championships?

Although winter doesn't begin officially for some weeks, we know what to expect -- wind, ice, snow and freezing temperatures. Fortunately, the majority of us in America are able to make provisions against the storms that are sure to rage. We will be comfortable in our houses or apartments with well-stocked fuel bins and ample supplies of woolen clothing.

LOUISBOURG, N. S., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Six crew members of the sinking Newfoundland coastal vessel Danzig were picked up at sea late tonight about twenty - one miles northeast of Scatari Island off the eastern tip of Cape Breton Island.
VIENNA, Nov. 25 -- Former Chancellor Leopold Figl was chosen today to succeed Dr. Karl Gruber as Austria's Minister for Foreign Affairs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Articles of incorporation were filed today with the Illinois Secretary of State to organize Northern Illinois Gas Company as a subsidiary of Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago. The action implements Edison's previously announced plan to segregate its gas operations.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The Government reeled but fought back stubbornly in the House of Lords today as a group of influential peers, among them Britain's highest-ranking churchman, denounced the plan for commercial television.

Representative Charles A. Buckley, Bronx Democratic leader, has asked Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. to retain Edward T. McCaffrey as Commissioner of Licenses and Anthony Masciarelli as Commissioner of Markets. Both are residents of the Bronx.

NO angler or hunter can let this day pass without being thankful for many things, and if he is thoughtful he will resolve to do all in his power to see that the same reasons for thanksgiving are present on future observances of the holiday.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 25 -- Queen Elizabeth II and her party left Bermuda before dawn today.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs denied today that the warning the Federal Bureau of Investigation sent to the White House on Harry Dexter White had come from a "high-placed" Canadian Government source.

A twenty-one-hour telethon will be presented over Channel 7 next month in behalf of the annual fund raising drive for United Cerebral Palsy Associations, Inc., which seeks to raise $1,000,000. Personalities of stage, screen, television and radio will appear on the program, which will start at 8 P. M. on Dec. 12. Robert M. Weitman, vice president of the American Broadcasting Company, has been named honorary producer of the telethon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Ludmilla Tcherina, the ballerina, is expected to arrive here next Tuesday from Paris without her dancing shoes to make her American film debut in "Sign of the Pagan" for Universal-International.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 25 -- President Eisenhower has named Walter W. Stewart of Gladstone, N. J., as the third member of his three-man Council of Economic Advisers.
HAVANA, Nov. 24 -- Something of an industrial revolution took place in Cuba today when management entered into a deal requiring it to go to work for organized labor.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- The declarations made yesterday by Col. Gen. Koca Popovic, Yugoslav Foreign Secretary to the Tanjug news agency have been interpreted in Rome as a Yugoslav refusal to participate in a five-power conference on Trieste.
A new approach to preparing copy has been tried and proven successfully by Klores Carter, Inc. Harry Carter, president of the agency, calls it the "Pitchman Method."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 25 -- Other Europeans waited impatiently tonight for the French National Assembly to decide when or whether this Continent would move further toward union through a European army and a European political community.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 25 (UP) -- America's Davis Cup hopes, dampened when Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert lost to Australian stars last week, faced another possible blow today when Seixas announced he might not play in the Victorian championships because of the recurrence of a knee injury he suffered last summer.
Judge William Clark seems to have a talent for getting embroiled in controversies.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The South Korean Government accused India of working for the Communists today. It threatened to "take action that appears appropriate" against the key member of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission if the truce were not "faithfully" observed.
The judge was ready, the jury was waiting, the prosecutor stood by, and all seemed properly set yesterday in Queens County Courthouse to try the case of the stolen refrigerator.
Favorable action taken by directors of two banks spotlighted yesterday's dividend declarations by a long list of companies.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Ten companies were named today as participating in an illegal price-fixing combine spread over almost the entire $124,000,000 Canadian electrical wire and cable industry.

The faculty of Columbia College, Columbia University, recently made a statement on certain questions of academic freedom which have been raised by the Congressional investigations. This statement was reported by The New York Times in its issue of Nov. 18.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 25 -- Nassau County's record $89,860,447 budget calling for an 11 1/2-cent tax rise came under fire from Democrats and the Nassau Taxpayers League here today.

Within walking distance of the Broadway theatre district, the Actors and Writers Theatre, formed to present plays of well-known writers in fields outside playwriting, is offering as its first production "The Quick Years." Written by Vance Bourjaily, the play is being shown through tomorrow evening at St. Clement's Church, 423 West Forty-sixth Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (UP) -- West Virginia's Mountaineers, featuring a smooth split T operator in their sophomore quarterback, Fred Wyant, were picked today as twice-beaten Georgia Tech's opponent in the Sugar Bowl football game here New Year's Day.

Despite the buyers' market in the men's wear field, there is less resistance to higher-priced clothing than to the low-end lines. While the consumer has more merchandise to choose from and has become more selective, he is apparently willing to spend a little more and get quality, both manufacturers and retailers report.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Representative Charles J. Kersten Republican of Wisconsin, today named 118 defense plants that he said were "penetrated by the Communist-dominated United Electrical Workers Union" and had Government contracts of $500,000 or more each.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Nov. 26 -- Experts here on the economic conditions of the Chinese mainland are skeptical about the Communists' ability to fulfil the extensive aid program for North Korea announced from Peiping Tuesday.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 25 -- Queen Elizabeth II and her husband flew into Jamaica today and immediately won the islanders' hearts by driving 120 miles across the country heedless of the blazing tropical sun.
The increasing importance of women in the country's labor force will be the next subject investigated by the National Manpower Council of Columbia University's Graduate School of Business.

A seven-game schedule, topped by the Fordham-Prep-Xavier test at Randalls Island and the St. John's Prep-Brooklyn Prep affair at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, closes the school football season in New York City today.

An increase last week of 239,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 145,193,000 barrels, compared with 144,954,000 a week earlier and 123,885,000 a year ago.

Minnie, a striped gray cat employed by a bar and restaurant, was given up for dead in a fire yesterday afternoon near Times Square but was revived by artificial respiration. Her mother perished in the fire.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- William Clark, Chief Justice of the United States courts in Germany, said today he had been dismissed by the State Department.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Corn futures were again in the spotlight today, registering new highs for the season for all except the December delivery. Cash corn more than kept pace with the No. 2 yellow selling at 1 1/2 to 2 cents over the December, the basis being 1/2 to 1 cent higher.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

THE voting for the Most Valuable Player award has produced so much rancor on so many occasions that the balloting members of the Baseball Writers Association have been accused by indignant fans of everything from blindness and stupidity to downright dishonesty. None of these charges ever had the slightest basis in fact, of course, and the typewriter pounders have bitterly resented them, weird though their findings may have seemed at times.

Harold O. Washburn has been elected chairman and John E. Carroll president of the American Hoist and Derrick Company, St. Paul, effective on Dec. 1. Mr. Washburn formerly was president of the company and Mr. Carroll was vice president of sales.

In undertaking what must be the pleasantest shopping chore of the year, acquiring toys for Santa's pack, parents will find many this season with which, in adult-sized versions, they are already familiar. Model Jaguars, prefabricated housing, "do-it-yourself" kits, model homes and contemporary furniture are some of the realistic toys available.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP) -- An A. F. L. local officer from Chicago refused today to confirm or deny a Congressional investigator's estimate that an insurance agency controlled by his wife and son received more than $1,000,000 in commissions from A. F. L. teamsters' business in the last four years.
OTTAWA, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Following are the texts of notes exchanged between the United States and Canada concerning Igor Gouzenko, former Russian cipher clerk here:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Americans for Democratic Action today praised Air Force Secretary Harold E. Talbott for overruling "guilt by association" security charges against a Reserve officer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- It was not reasonable to expect that Senator McCarthy of Wisconsin in his speech last night would echo the President's hope that "this whole thing" -- the purge by his Administration of Communist infiltration in the Roosevelt-Truman regime -- would be a matter of history by the time of the Congressional elections in 1954.

During the past six months there have been many predictions about the trend of business in the months and years ahead. Forecasts have ranged from a recession of varying depth and duration to a maintenance of the present high level of activity. But to my knowledge none of the estimates has mentioned the tremendous growth of the nation's economy which transcontinental thruways will bring.

We join with Governor Dewey and Governor Driscoll in commending the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor on the progress it has made in paving the way for control of the waterfront on Dec. 1. Thirteen employment information centers are ready, their staffs are familiarizing themselves with their duties and explaining to stevedores and shipping companies the procedures about to be inaugurated.

Having spent three-quarters of a recital last night making an impression as an unusually talented and well-equipped pianist, Leonard Hungerford proceeded to spend the final quarter trying to tear everything down.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy presented yesterday a hostile witness who he said had been described by others in executive sessions as a present Communist spy. The Wisconsin Republican also threatened contempt citations against a Columbia University assistant professor and a Fort Monmouth, N. J., Signal Corps employe.

BOSTON, Nov. 25. (AP) -- Ed Macauley scored 28 points and Bob Cousy got 20 while pacing the Boston Celtics to a 96-84 victory tonight over the New York Knicker-bockers in the second game of a National Basketball Association Double-header at Boston Garden.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Churchill Government rejected today a Laborite demand that the sale of British shipping to Panamanian companies be stopped until their vessels obeyed the regulations of the International Labor Organization.

ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 25 -- Fire drove forty students and teachers of the Beard School for Girls from two dormitories just after 1 A. M. today. The fire ruined two adjacent administration and classroom buildings.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Premier Joseph Laniel asked today that a vote of confidence be taken Friday on a motion giving only indefinite French National Assembly support to the European army treaty.

Robert Morris, counsel to the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, said yesterday he believed the national Administration would offer immunity from prosecution to induce disaffected Communists to testify about Soviet spying in this country.
Vacancies in new office buildings in Manhattan today stand at less than 1 per cent, with prospects bright for a continued demand for executive business quarters in the city.

A new contract providing for wage increases of $1 to $2.50 a week for 18,000 plant employes of the New York Telephone Company was announced last night by the company and the United Telephone Organizations, independent.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 25 -- The Finnish Government's till is just about empty but the Riksdag (Parliament) goes on making new appropriations.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Ed (Moose) Krause, Notre Dame athletic director, said today that the time out granted the Irish before their tying touchdown in the first half against Iowa Saturday, was "according to the rules."

An official source on the committee of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy qualified yesterday the Senator's charge in a nation-wide speech last night that former President Truman's definition of McCarthyism" was exactly the same as that of The Daily Worker, Communist newspaper.

The major emigration movement to Canada from Europe since the end of the war has lured a large number of passenger ships to ports of the Maritime Provinces and brought about a flourishing general travel industry.

The pumpkin comes into its own particular glory with the folklore of Halloween, with the decorative motifs of harvest celebrations and late autumn landscapes, and reaches its peak of eminence in Thanksgiving Day pumpkin pies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board heard today that the Jefferson School of Social Science in New York was created, financed and administered by the Communist party.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Sir Winston Churchill and his Cabinet held a special meeting today and decided to hold firm against yesterday's pension rebellion in the House of Commons.

Capt. William V. Bradley, newly elected president of the old International Longshoremen's Association, announced a reform program yesterday. It was aimed particularly at the New York District Council and its seventy-two affiliated locals.
The American spirit of unity was extolled last night by King Paul of Greece, who called it "your answer to the barren promises of the totalitarian nations."
I was surprised to read Louis Lipsky's statement in Letters to The Times, Nov. 20, regarding the recent address of Abdel Khalik Hassouna, Secretary General of the Arab League.

A special service of thanksgiving, commemorating Religious Freedom Week and New York City's 300th anniversary, was held yesterday afternoon at the Congregation Shearith Israel of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 (UP) -- Sunshine Nell, given a fine ride by Hedley Woodhouse on a muddy track, outran La Corredora in the final eighth of a mile today to win the $22,200 Barbara Frietchie Handicap by a neck at Bowie.

The Appellate Division was praised yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York for a decision that will "probably" save the city's shoppers from paying higher prices for many articles.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (UP) -- William Hal Bishop's Steak Bone, with Robert Lee Baird aboard, whirled to victory in the Thanksgiving Day Handicap today before a record crowd of 20,000 spectators in the Fair Grounds opening racing program.
Sho1em Asch, novelist, will sail on the Queen Elizabeth today to rejoin his wife, who is in poor health in Nice, France.
DUN LAOGHAIRE, Ireland, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The end of one of the world's longest strikes was announced today.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., one of the nation's largest retailing groups, which operates Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus here, yesterday reported increased sales but lower earnings. The report covers thirteen and fifty-two weeks ended on Oct. 31.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 26 -- By majority of ninety-nine votes, the Belgian Chamber of Deputies approved today the six-nation European defense community treaty.

Lulu Perez, the 20 - year - old featherweight from Brooklyn, will oppose Dave Gallardo of Los Angeles in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The clash is a return affair, Perez having gained a knockout triumph in their first meeting.

John Coulis, 20 years old, and John Tricarico, 19, turned two miles of Queens into a speedway Wednesday night. While racing each other in their fathers' cars, they went the wrong way on a one-way street, failed to signal at eight turns, ignored three "Full Stop" signs and two signal lights, failed to keep to the right and went well in excess of fifty-five miles an hour.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 26 -Progress in building the Exposition and International Fair to mark the four-hundredth anniversary of the city of Sao Paulo next year is belying rumors of possible curtailment of the plans.
The United States Field Hockey Association tourney got under way yesterday at the Hunter College field in the Bronx. This marked the first time the event had been staged in this city.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky implied today that the Soviet Union had pushed ahead of the West in the field of atomic weapons.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Officials of the National Assembly today set Dec. 17 as the date for election of the President of the French Republic. The date was the earliest possible under existing regulations.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The attempts of some individuals and organizations to stifle freedom of thought in this country were denounced here today at a convention of educators.

IN addition to getting lost, suffering from exposure, being cut by axes or knives, being burned by falling in campfires or being subjected to assorted mental or physical strain as a result of the misadventures which plague the novice woods runners, deer hunters this season have reported a number of incidents that are more humorous than serious.

Restoration work on one of the city's historic landmarks -- Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Tenth Street -- has reached the halfway mark. Its Gothic pinnacles and parapets are no longer in danger of crumbling and crashing down.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- With no great expectations, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor and Foreign Minister, left Bonn today to attend the week-end conference of the six "little Europe" foreign ministers at The Hague.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Man's capacity to learn has not increased since the Ice Age, yet knowledge has multiplied 10,000 times, a University of Illinois professor told a group of educators today at the convention of the American Vocational Association.

While most of the free countries of Europe, thanks to American aid, have been able to stage a substantial economic recovery, there is one country outside of that aid program which is running into serious economic difficulties. That country is Finland, the little but stout neighbor of mighty Soviet Russia.

Classicism and modernism -- if two works so old that they date from the first quarter of our singularly advanced century can properly be called "modern," made the program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Dmitri Mitropoulos conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

The retirement of Conrad Rothengast as chief inspector will be a serious loss to the city and to the New York Police Department, which he has served with distinction for thirty-three years. He was the first man ever drawn from the detective ranks to lead the largest police force in the country.
AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 22 -- Foreign observers here are increasingly fearful that Moscow has marked Jordan as the focus of a Campaign of subversion and propaganda in the Middle East.
Americans at home and abroad took yesterday off to celebrate the three hundred and thirty-second Thanksgiving Day since the Pilgrims at Plymouth gathered in their first harvest.
Negotiations to avert a threatened strike against six New York daily newspapers, beginning with tomorrow's day shift, will be resumed at 11:30 this morning.

SEATTLE, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Coast Guardsmen with fixed bayonets stood guard at Pier 56 for seven hours yesterday to avert possible disorders in a jurisdictional dispute between two unions over stewards assigned to the passenger ship Aleutian.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Wake Forest scored twice in the third period to break a half-time tie and hung on grimly today to upset South Carolina, the nation's fifteenth ranking football team, 19 -- 13.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 2 -- The half-way mark in delivery of the United States gift of 700,000 tons of wheat to Pakistan was reached today as the Strathbay, from Galveston, docked with 9,800 tons of the grain.

There is something special about the $20,000,000 cooperative housing project sponsored by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union on the lower East Side. On this site, where Grand Street meets the East River, the last slum in this section of Manhattan has been razed.

MADRID, Nov. 26 -- A campaign is under way to induce the Spanish Government to improve the legal position of the Spanish married woman, who under present law is denied the right to her home and her children when she separates from her husband.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The State Department announced late tonight that the Soviet Union had proposed that the foreign ministers of the Big Four powers meet in Berlin. No date was specified.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 26 -- The way was cleared today for release of the $26,250,000 United States grant in aid to Israel for the six months ending Dec. 31. An exchange of letters between the United States Embassy and the Israeli Foreign Ministry governing use of grant-in-aid funds, a necessary preliminary to actual releases, was completed today.
Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station telephone supervisors explained yesterday why long waits were sometimes necessary before calls for train information were answered.

ON the tenth of January, 1480, a girl was born in the city of Brussels whose various relatives and in-laws comprise one of the most impressive catalogues of royal names in history. Her grandfather was Charles the Bold, the rash and bellicose Duke of Burgundy whose power was greater than that of most kings. Her father was Maximilian I, among whose innumerable titles was Holy Roman Emperor.

Correction Department officers have been assaulted and their lives endangered in "overcrowded" city prisons as a result of Commissioner Albert Williams' recent order that they turn in their shields, a spokesman for the Correction Officers Benevolent Association charged yesterday.

Now that its physical presence has been washed, blown and earnestly wished away, one can look with clearer eye on the semantic aspects of this recent sm-omething. While it was with us the question arose, Should the gray, dismal blanket that 'was smothering the East for almost a week be properly called a smog or a smaze, or really something like smoze or smag, which would nicely combine all three ingredients, smoke, fog and haze?

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 26 (AP) -- America's traditional Thanksgiving Day took precedence over work on plans for a Korean peace conference and the stalled Communist campaign to woo home prisoners of war who have refused repatriation.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 26 -- Queen Elizabeth expressed hope today that the British West Indies would build for the future on the principles of parliamentary government, which, she said, had been "tested and tried over the centuries and found to be sure and true."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Cornell's claim to the Ivy football championship, its first since 1949, was established beyond question today.
A baritone named Oliver J. Dragon made his debut last night at Town Hall, and somehow managed to attract a full house. This a rare phenomenon for any debut artist.

Outside the ancient city of Athens twenty-three girls live and study in a converted stable. They are from all over Greece, having come from remote islands and mountain villages to study at the Young Women's Christian Association School of Social Work and live in its cooperative dormitory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -The Government spent $11,000,000,000 during July and August and had $149,800,000,000 in unspent money on hand Sept. 1. Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Top defense and foreign aid offi cials are reported considering a cut of about $1,000,000,000 in military aid funds for Western Europe next year.

Professional people conducting business from their homes in residential districts in New York suffer greatly from the fact that there is only one mail delivery a day. By comparison this service is worse than in any other industrially developed country of the world.

MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 25 -- Election of Dr. John P. Tilton as vice president of Tufts College was announced tonight by Arthur J. Anderson, chairman of the board of trustees. He succeeds Dr. Nils Y. Wessell, former vice president and newly elected Tufts president.

THE first Navy team coached by Eddie Erdelatz administered a stunning 14-2 upset to Army four years ago. The long-silent bell at Annapolis pealed out the happy news as the shouting, beaming midshipmen and the local yokels lined the streets for the victory parade. Along came Erdelatz atop a fire truck, sirens screaming.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Sir Winston Churchill's two chief aides poured the cool water of persuasion on a smoldering rebellion among the Conservative rank and file tonight. At the end of a meeting addressed by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, the rebellious members of the House of Commons appeared to have lost much of their enthusiasm for a fight over the cost of living of retired service officers.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Class Paterson gave a ball last night in their home at 116 East Eightieth Street to introduce to society their niece, Miss Olivia Endicott Hutchins, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hurd Hutchins of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Masses of pink camellias and garlands of foliage formed a pink and green decor for the fete.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Directors of Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company decided to issue a combined stock-cash dividend valued at 8 cents in place of the usual $1 a year cash dividend paid on common stock since 1943.

In contrast to the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, the great majority of local chambers of commerce in the Tennessee Valley support T. V. A. Obviously it makes a difference if you live with a resource development, take part in it and know what its benefits are.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- British diplomatic sources said tonight that the Soviet note expressing willingness to take part in a Big Four conference appeared to be aimed at making the maximum trouble for Premier Joseph Laniel's Government in France.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Cloyce Box, robbed of his blinding speed by a leg injury, came up with his best catch of the season today for a dazzling 97-yard touchdown pass play that sparked the Detroit Lions to a 34-15 victory over the Green Bay Packers in Briggs Stadium.

ANCIENT dwellings with authentic ghosts are hard to find in mid-Twentieth Century New York City, but one still stanchly hangs on at 29 East Fourth Street, between the Bowery and Lafayette Street. It is The Old Merchant's House, which is open to the public from 11 A. M. to 5 P. M. on weekdays and from 1 o'clock to 5 on Sundays and holidays.
Copies of a booklet entitled "Permit Communist - Conspirators to Be Teachers?" are to be distributed soon at public expense to the 35,000 teachers in the city's schools.

Thousands of residents in two New Jersey towns were endangered early yesterday morning and late Wednesday night when unidentified persons tampered with high pressure valves of the strike-bound Public Service Electric and Gas Company.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- White Plains High School completed its fourth straight unbeaten-untied season today by walloping the Henry Snyder eleven from Jersey City, 32 to 13.

Spectacular foot work marked a test match yesterday at Sterling Oval, where a picked team of Eastern Seaboard stars defeated an American Soccer League eleven, 5 -- 4. The outcome will have a bearing on the selection of the United States team that will visit Mexico in January.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Night-flying Soviet-made MIG's are prowling near a United Nations airbase island 125 miles northwest of Seoul, causing frequent alerts, a reliable source said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Air Force is considering establishment of a $100,000 trust fund for the North Korean pilot, who flew his Russian-built MIG-15 fighter to a United Nations airstrip last September.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- India's refusal to endorse a United Nations report on forced labor although the agency that made the report was headed by an Indian was explained officially here today as "without political implications."

Since helicopters were placed in regular service in the New York- Connecticut-New Jersey area more than a year ago, there has been an increase in the use of air mail as high as 300 per cent in some communities.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 27 -- Arthur H. Dean, for the United Nations, urged again today, at a subcommittee session at Panmunjom held to settle points of the place and composition of a Korean peace conference that the Soviet Union participate as a Communist belligerant.

St. John's Prep captured the hythical city Catholic high school football championship by overwhelming Brooklyn Prep, 48 -- 6, in the thirty-fifth meeting of the teams before 6,700 spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday morning.

BABYLON, L. I., Nov. 26 -- Guy Lombardo has signed a contract with the Long Island State Park Commission to produce a musical spectacle for the Jones Beach Marine Amphitheatre next summer. The announcement was made today by Robert Moses, president of the commission, and by Commissioners Clifford L. Jackson and Herbert Bayard Swope.

The Thanksgiving turkey is a thing of beauty, but it isn't a joy forever. Yesterday -- Thanksgiving Day -- it was indeed a beautiful sight. It came to table piping hot and buttery brown, bursting with savory stuffing and accompanied by giblet gravy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Democrats accused a House subcommittee today of trying to "smash" the Social Security System and denounced as a "crime" the group's issuing a subpoena for Arthur J. Altmeyer, former Social Security Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner, William F. Cusick, recommended yesterday that Capital Airlines be authorized to operate non-stop service between Cleveland and New York.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A. E. Barit, president of Hudson Motor Car Company, said today merger talks involving his company have been strictly of an exploratory nature and are still far from any definite decision.
BOSTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Jerry Toppazzini scored his first three goals of the season tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the New York Rangers, 5--2, before 8,939 fans at Boston Garden.

Paul M. Hahn, president of the American Tobacco Company, spoke out yesterday in defense of cigarettes against the charge that they were injurious to health. He was the first major cigarette company executive to do so in recent months.

Uncertain business conditions, combined with an acute shortage of traveling attractions, has caused a sharp falling off of Theatre Guild-American Theatre Society subscribers in twenty cities. New York, which is handled independently by the Guild, is also included in the survey.

Three views of housing were presented at a panel meeting at the Architectural League this week by Lewis Mumford, a critic of architecture; Henry Churchill, an architect, and Ira Robbins, president of the National Housing Conference.

The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission ruled today that the United Nations may use only five officers in its "come-home" interviews with 351 Allied prisoners now in the Indian custodial forces' care. These prisoners include twenty-two Americans, 328 South Koreans and a Briton.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 26 -- Guiseppe Pella, the Italian Premier, said today that Italy's ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty would be greatly facilitated by solution of the Trieste problem.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, today predicted "tremendous developments in engines, air frames and guided missiles" for the nation's future air power.

The annual Gotham Debutante Ball for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Forty-five young women were presented at the fete and were guests of honor at a dinner earlier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -The National Temperance League today hailed as a "hopeful sign" a hint from John A. Hannah, Assistant Defense Secretary, that a move was under way to ban bottle liquor sales at all military bases.
CORFU, Greece, Nov. 26 -- Life in red Albania, smallest of Soviet satellites in Europe, was described here today by two fugitives from that country in bleak terms.

RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 26 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon took the wind out of the Burmese Communist sails today by marching smilingly into the middle of an anti-American demonstration and shaking hands all around.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Small Business Administration invited more than 16,000 banks across the country today to join in meeting the credit needs of enterprises that have been refused private financing.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 26 -- Despite the absence of Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, and of a French foreign policy, five European foreign ministers, meeting here today, seemed disposed to continue their efforts toward a European political community.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 26 (UP) -- Texas clinched at least a tie for the Southwest Conference championship today by beating Texas A. and M., 21 -- 12.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the country's gross national product would total about $368,000,000,000 in the calendar year 1953. This would be 5 per cent greater than the 1952 record of $350,000,000,000.
Don Menasco officially was made eligible yesterday to play for the football Giants against the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds Sunday.

ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 26 -- A controversy bearing on the current state-wide political issue concerning racial separation policies in the public schools has unfolded on the University of Georgia campus here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- "Foreign government pressures," not all to the disadvantage of United States motion-picture producers, are largely responsible for the upswing in film-making abroad by Hollywood interests, according to the current "intelligence report" mailed yesterday to members of the Screen Actors Guild.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The names of sixteen thoroughbreds were dropped into the entry box today for the $10,000 added Inaugural Handicap at Tropical Park tomorrow, feature event on the program opening the Florida horse racing season.
David M. Margolis, formerly chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Company of Dayton, Ohio, has been elected a vice president of Bond Stores, Inc.
OTTAWA, Nov. 26 -- The Canadian Government has gone as far as it intends to go toward meeting the United States request for permission to send investigators here to question Igor Gouzenko.
Whitefish, yellow pike and carp, three of the most popular fresh water fish in this area, are approaching their seasonal peak.
GENEVA, Nov. 26 -- A United States delegate said today the Eisenhower Administration regarded the International Labor Organization as the "greatest single agency of international action that exists."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A far-traveled Senatorial investigator proposed today the immediate termination of the independent status of the Government's foreign aid and information agencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers received about $24,800,000,000 from marketings in the first ten months of this year, 5 per cent less than in the same period last year.

Crafts of various countries and other items are discussed in five books published recently which include information on pottery, glassmaking, hand-hooked rugs, unusually small collectors' items and the folk arts of Norway.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union revealed himself today as a student of American music, or at least that part of it known as "You, You, You.'
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars announced plans today for a "thorough-going anti-Communist assault" both on its own and in concert with other organizations.

A refreshing note of realism marks the statement on foreign economic policy filed by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) with the commission appointed by the President to study this subject. Eschewing extremes, this statement points out that national security and the national interest, not the desires of particular special interest groups, must dominate United States policy.

Plans for construction of two 15,000-gross-ton Japanese passenger liners for trans-Pacific service have been shelved temporarily because of lack of funds, according to Yuji Sawa, shipping attache at the Japanese Embassy in Washington.
The Board of Estimate has been advised by the city's Transit Advisory Commission to delay for at least a month any decision on the appeal for a 15-cent fare by nine privately operated bus lines.
