PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, Nov. 27 -- Conferences among top American and South Korean officials set off speculation today that a turning point in the deadlocked preliminary talks here on a Korean peace conference was imminent.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky gave a British and a French delegate a piece of his mind today for leaving for home before the last word had been said in the disarmament debate.
Summer lingers in the fruit stalls, where Spanish melons are on display during the late fall and early winter.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 26 -- This morning thousands of shame- faced residents are returning to their homes in the near-by port of Callao after a mass evacuation last night caused by a false rumor that a great tidal wave would engulf the city.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The issue of sovereignty in underdeveloped countries receiving foreign capital investments was debated today in the Economic and Financial Committee of the General Assembly.

NEWARK, Nov. 26 -- East Orange took advantage of breaks to score in the first two periods and defeat Barringer, 12 to 0, before 11,000 at the Newark School Stadium today. As a result, East Orange stayed in the running for the Group 4 title in North Jersey with an 8-1 record.

DENVER, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers (Ind.) today projected a four-point program to combat an "economic crisis in the nonferrous metals industry" and "signs of a threatening general economic collapse."

The four largest veterans' organizations in the New York area have gone into the campaign against admission of Red China to the United Nations at this time. They will start a "mobilization'' here next week to obtain signatures to the petitions of the "Committee for One Million."

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 -- Canada and the United States are pressing ahead with the design and construction of additional defenses in the far north to guard against a surprise attack, Defense Minister Brooke Claxton told the House of Commons today.

MELBOURNE, Friday, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Peter Molloy, a 30-year-old Melbourne week-end player, eliminated Bob Perry, a member of the United States Davis Cup squad from Los Angeles, in the first round of the Victorian tennis championships today, 6 -- 3, 2 -- 6, 6 - 3, 6 -- 4

George Axelsson's article of Nov. 3 on the Icelandic economy was something of a surprise. He refers to the opinion of some "responsible circles" that in the opinion of this writer seem to have been slightly irresponsible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -The Internal Revenue Service announced today that Garland H. Williams, head of its Tax Frauds Investigations Division, had recently resigned after "discrepancies" were found in his own income tax returns.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Three touchdown sprints by Johnny Mapp brought Virginia Military Institute the Virginia "Big Six" football championship today as the Keydets whipped Virginia Tech, 28 -- 13.

BUFFALO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Bevo Francis broke the Memorial Auditorium basketball scoring record with 64 points tonight as Rio Grande set a new team mark for the hall in conquering Erie County Technical Institute, 120 to 59.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York, realty operators, have purchased the four-story apartment building for nineteen families at 50-05 Forty-fifth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, in a deal negotiated by George Brezel, vice president of Sydney M. Siegel Co., Kew Gardens brokers.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- A Briton told the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization today that the world's surplus food stocks could best be reduced by increasing consumption and the only sure way to increase consumption was to lower prices.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 -- Several thousand political prisoners will be released during celebrations by the Yugoslav regime of the tenth anniversary of its founding.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 26 -- Frustration -- that was the theme of Colgate's exhibition this morning as it struggled to a 7-all tie with Brown in the thirty-fifth football meeting between the schools. The Red Raiders outpassed and outrushed their rivals all the way, but were lucky to gain an even break.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- When Mr. Truman, in a letter to the House Committee on Un-American Activities, based his refusal to respond to its subpoena on the doctrine of the separation of Government powers, several constitutional lawyers whose opinion was sought by this correspondent approved the argument and thought Mr. Truman had set a proper precedent and made good history.

One of the main reasons for thanks yesterday by throngs of children here was the prospect of Christmas as it was previewed in Macy's twenty-seventh annual Thanksgiving Day parade. Two million children and parents swarmed to watch the sun-brightened spectacle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Alger Hiss is one of nine former Federal employes now under "special scrutiny" because they were continued in their jobs despite security reports linking them to Soviet spying, Senator William E. Jenner declared today.
ORANGE, Tex., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The secretary who disappeared twenty-two years ago with her boss said, "We're happy -- don't ask us any more questions now, please."
WICHITA, Kan., Nov, 26 (UP) -- Detroit earned a share of the Missouri Valley Conference football championship with Oklahoma A. and M. today by defeating Wichita, 26 -- 6, before 9,500 fans.

More than half of Brooklyn's state legislators and City Councilmen have been made politically displaced persons by the reapportionment bill that the Legislature enacted at a special session last week. At least five and possibly six of Brooklyn's nine State Senators are confronted with the choice of moving their homes or retiring from the Legislature.
DETROIT, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk achieved his third shutout of the season tonight as the Detroit Red Wings blanked the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 0, before 13,497 fans at Olympia.

BERLIN, Friday, Nov. 27 -- East Germany made public last night the alleged confession of a Western spy that indicated that at the end of 1951 France sought to establish secret contact with the East German Government.
Parents and teachers who would really "know" an exceptional child sufficiently to understand his feelings must be prepared to try to face and understand their own feelings.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Ed Furgol of St. Louis, and Dick Knight of Omaha, Neb., tied for the first-round lead today in the $10,000 Columbia open golf tournament with 65's, seven strokes under par for the 7,000-yard Armed Forces course.
Mr. and Mrs. Jose Martinez had ninety guests for Thanksgiving dinner last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Without a Presidential guest of honor for their fifty-fourth meeting, Army will oppose Navy here Saturday in what promises to be a better-than-average service clash.
The "rights" of American families will be drawn up in a "character" by a new committee of the Family Service Association of America.
Prayers for continuing peace and prosperity were offered yesterday in church and synagogue as New Yorkers gathered to give thanks for the blessings inherent in a free and democratic nation.

New Yorkers consumed well over 6,000,000 tons of food last year. Their gas and electric appliances and heating needs utilized additional millions of tons of coal and oil. One resident in ten earned his living, directly or indirectly, on the business generated by the arrival here of 69,560,000 tons of foreign and coastal cargoes and the outbound shipment of 17,784,000 tons.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 26 -With a combination of threats and cajolery, the Government of Thailand is trying to get trade in imported goods rolling again in this country. The market came to a standstill last week following the imposition of tight licensing controls on imports of almost all kinds of goods.

The tie-up of the New London Freight Lines, which operates a ferry service between Orient Point, L. I., and Saybrook, Conn., across Long Island Sound, entered its third week today. Service on the line had been disrupted by a strike by members of Local 333, United Marine Division, International Longshoremen's Association, independent.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 26 -- President Eisenhower publicly gave thanks tonight for the return of the sons of Americans -- including his own -- from the Korean war.
David Lakritz, a 44-year-old state insurance examiner, who had told his friends he would win the forty-third annual City Hall-to-Coney Island walk, did so yesterday.

THREE of the television networks, the American Broadcasting Company, Columbia Broadcasting System and National Broadcasting Company, have hardly covered themselves with journalistic glory in their handling of the speech Tuesday night by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Cases of influenza in Britain last winter were reduced by 40 per cent among those who were inoculated with a new mixed anti-influenza vaccine prepared by the British Medical Research Council.

In giving thanks, those who live and work here may recall that they are protected by the finest hospital system in the world. The eighty-one voluntary, non - profit hospitals that make up this system were organized by civic - minded persons, many of whom acted in deep religious feeling toward their fellow men.
Roy W. Vorhees has been appointed supervisor of product planning and estimating for the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The stock markets were quietly firm today despite a further decline in business. Prices of all the main sections crept up and although they hesitated in the afternoon, notably in the industrial and South African gold mine markets, they closed with another fairly long list of small rises.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 26 -- The Iranian military prosecutor ended today a nine-day-long accusation of former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and his former top military aide. He made a renewed demand that the court-martial impose death sentences on both for rebellion.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The executive committee of one of the unions committed to a twenty-four-hour token strike Wednesday declared today that it would not ask its members to take part.
While we await the results of the vote of confidence in the French National Assembly today on the Laniel Government it is important to keep the issues in mind and to recognize their gravity.

The first alternate-side-of-the-street parking area in Queens will be established Monday in the Steinway section. It will cover seventy-three square blocks extending from Twenty-eighth Street to Northern Boulevard and from Thirty-second Street to Forty-fourth Street.
Proposed legislation that would restrict taxicabs here to small stock models will be the subject of a public hearing next Tuesday. The bill would outlaw the prevailing big cabs after 1954.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 26 -- Distributors of American motion pictures have been assured that all limitations and bars to the importation and licensing of United States films have been lifted. Raul Apold, chief of Argentinas Sub-secretariat of Information, made the announcement today to Stuart B. Dunlap, representative of the Motion Picture Export Association.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The House of Lords upheld today, by a vote of 157 to 87, the Government's plan to permit commercial television.
Professional wrestling returned last night to Madison Square Garden with a crowd of 7,522 paying $26,701 to watch the six exhibitions.

Doctors, lawyers, architects, dentists, engineers and other professional men should be permitted to do a great deal more advertising. This is the contention of Jules Alberti, president of Endorsements, Inc.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, Michigan leader of the Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., will get his chance tomorrow to answer charges leveled against him at a House Labor subcommittee hearing here. His scheduled appearance on the stand is expected to mark the fourth day of the hearing.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 27 -- Officials attending the European foreign ministers conference here expected tonight that Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, would discuss the Saar question with Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, after attending the final meeting of the conference. M. Bidault is due here tomorrow morning.
The posthumous award of a Silver Star Medal for gallantry was made yesterday to 2d Lieut. Russell A. Sieder of Westfield, N. J., who was killed in action in Korea on April 16.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Greater government support for scientific and industrial research was announced here today by Sir Ian Heilbron, chairman of the advisory council for the scientific and industrial department concerned.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Nov. 28 -- The United Nations representative, Arthur H. Dean, is prepared to make today a counter-proposal on the composition of the Korean peace conference. He hopes his suggestions will lead to a successful conclusion of the preliminary talks here.
TOKYO, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- A new enthusiasm for photography in Japan has created a domestic sales boom for the camera industry, whose growth is the top success story of post-war Japan.
The revival of Debussy's "Peleas et Melisande" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, is, by all odds, in its sum total the best that we have seen this season in this theatre.

Al Rosen has been voted the most valuable player in the American League for 1953 and, as a refreshing change from the frequent bitter controversies of recent years, this is one verdict that brooks no further discussion.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Member states voted 36 to 5 today to have the findings of a United Nations inquiry into forced labor taken up in 1954 as a "matter of urgency."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Eight countries joined today in asking the United States to work for the evacuation of all proNationalist Chinese troops on Burmese soil.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The Wilmington (Del.) Trust Company, filing the first defense brief following the hearing of testimony in the du Pont anti-trust suit, asserted today that the Government had failed to make out a case against the bank and trust company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Army has balked at shrinking its manpower requirements by 10 per cent after next July 1, a target raised by the Defense Department for economy.
A report of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association indicated yesterday that manufacturers of refrigerators, farm and home freezers, ranges and water heaters may end this year successfully.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -A House subcommittee announced today that it would open hearings on Monday into alleged "shenanigans" in the sale of tungsten to this country by Thailand mining concerns that cost taxpayers $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission tightened its rules on multiple ownership of broadcasting stations today. In line with this policy it immediately ordered the Columbia Broadcasting System to show cause why it should not dispose of some of its holdings.
The Transit Authority granted a request by Michael J. Quill yesterday to meet with him and other officers of the Transport Workers Union C. I. O., next Thursday.
The banquet manager of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria received a one-week delay yesterday for entering his plea to a charge that he permitted the overcrowding of the hotel's Starlight Roof.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The House subcommittee studying the Social Security system quarreled in public today before a witness whom the chairman was accused of having "brought in at the end of a chain."

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 27 -- President Eisenhower played golf today with his son John and probably won the match, that is, unless Major Eisenhower was able to drive a good bargain in the pregame handicapping.

A home colony for 105 families has been opened by Robert Kasin and William Synek, builders, at Sunrise Highway and Connetquot Avenue in Central Islip, L. I. John W. Wade, architect, has designed the houses for the development, which is known as Evergreen Park.
The St. Paul's Cathedral choir, forty-eight strong, sailed for home yesterday with fond memories of forty-one American cities and Eisenhower hospitality.
ATLANTA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Georgia Democratic leaders today assailed Mr. Brownell.
An iron-man quarterback who played every minute of every one of his team's games and a standout tackle who received unreserved praise from rival coaches head the 1953 All-Ivy football team.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 27 -- A light new Belgian rifle now being tested by the Army will be manufactured at the United States Armory here if it is adopted as a standard weapon, it was reported today by Col. John F. Harlan, acting commanding officer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A former engineer of the Federal Power Commission said today that a study of all available Government reports had convinced him that the Idaho Power Company had the best development plan for the Hell's Canyon section of the Snake River.

The bowl of nuts in shell that formed an attractive centerpiece for the Thanksgiving dinner table perhaps was left untouched by many families and guests after the last crumb of pumpkin pie was swallowed.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) Fifteen railroad employes' unions today asked the dismissal of a suit filed by the nation's Class I roads seeking to prevent the unions from asking certain benefits.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Dick Knight of Omaha, Neb., and Ed Furgol of St. Louis, were still deadlocked with 135's today after the second round in the first annual $10,000 Columbia open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -Admiral Robert B. Carney, Chief of Naval Operations, said tonight that defense spending could be cut sharply only by making "substantial" reductions in personnel, arms purchases and military activities.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The shipbuilding and engineering industries advised their members today to remain open Wednesday when the nation-wide one-day strike of their employes is planned, and to put to work all those who report.

Our own street -- to call it so -- it's marked Forty-third on the city plan -- is just now the scene of varied activity -- including operations on the street itself, politely excused by the sign "Dig we must, we'll move on and clean up" -- and what's doing on both sides in two deep holes in the ground where new buildings are being planted with the usual accompaniment of mechanical noises.

Today's new film is "Trent's Last Case," a British-made melodrama with Michael Wilding, Margaret Lockwood, Orson Welles and John McCallum, at the Little Carnegie. Herbert Wilcox directed and produced from a screen play by Pamela Bower, based upon a story by E. C. Bentley, Miles Malleson, Hugh McDermott, Jack McNaughton and Sam Kydd are featured in the Republic Production.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- The possibility of a Big Four Foreign Ministers conference to discuss German unification -- especially if it is held in Berlin -- is bound to bring a surge of hope in East Germany as well as in West Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Delaware Valley area is undergoing a "kind of renaissance" by reversing the nation-wide trend towards less spending in 1954 on new plant and equipment, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia disclosed today.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 27 -- The vice president of an aeronautical engineering school was arrested by the Nassau County police tonight and booked on charges of grand larceny.

NEWARK, Nov. 27 -- The three-week-old strike of 1,100 production workers in three plants of the Ronson Art Metal Company here ended today when 1,100 strikers ratified a tentative settlement agreed upon yesterday. The union involved was the Amalgamated Local 589 of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O.

Michael Dalessio, one of three brothers who purportedly control gambling activities on Staten Island, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to fifteen months in the penitentiary on his plea of guilty to income tax evasion.
Loans to business by New York banks dropped $84,000,000 contraseasonally last week, the largest reduction since Sept. 23.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -Secretary of the Air Force Harold E. Talbott urged today that the Government take immediate steps to increase domestic production of titanium, a vital metal in the production of jet-age aircraft.

At first glance the most important fact about the new agreement concluded between Red China and North Korea seems to be that impoverished China has agreed to contribute $317,000,000 -- even more than the $250,000,000 Russia has promised -- to help rehabilitate the Communist portion of Korea.
A conference on "Rural Missions and Human Needs" abroad will be held Wednesday through Friday in Philadelphia.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 27 -- Was he or was he not at the Queen's table at the state dinner given for her in Government House?
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 -- The nation's English teachers outlined a program today for dealing with persons who tried to tamper with public education in the name of anti-communism.

Wall Street isn't the place most folk go to do their Christmas shopping, but one investment concern hopes it may become so. B. G. Phillips Co., investment dealers, beginning next week and extending to Dec. 24, plans to offer Christmas gifts of mutual fund shares, priced at $25 to $100.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 28 (AP) -The Army said today that Sgt. Maurice L. Schick, 29 years old, of Canonsburg, Pa., had confessed he strangled 9-year-old Susan Rothschild, a colonel's daughter, a week ago. But the military withheld disclosure of the motive.

The retirement of Johnny Mize, announced by the renowned slugger the day after the world series, became official yesterday a far as the Yankees were concerned. General Manager George M. Weiss revealed that the Bombers had made Big Jawn a free agent.
MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 27 -A new-born baby, found this morning in a suitcase that a woman had left with a stranger at a railroad station, died tonight at North Shore Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP)--There were about 267,000 private manufacturing establishments in the United States last year, the Bureau of the Census reported today. Nine out of ten of them had fewer than 100 employes, it said. Manufacturing payrolls covered 15,944,379 workers.

HARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Two service men en route to military bases after the Thanksgiving holiday were killed here this morning in an automobile accident on the Hutchinson River Parkway, Westchester County's most deadly highway.
Philadelphia's four teams continued to dominate the national field hockey tournament on the fields of Hunter College in the Bronx yesterday. All won, as they had on the opening day, Thursday.

The new East Side Airlines Terminal on First Avenue between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets will be dedicated at 6 P. M. Monday. Robert Tuttle, treasurer and general manager of the East Side Airlines Terminal Corporation, announced this yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Plans were being made today to postpone full debate on Korea until the United Nations found out whether both sides could agree on arrangements for the peace conference called for in the July 27 armistice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -Representative H. Carl Andersen, Republican of Minnesota, chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Agriculture, said today that he would fight any further attempt to cut payments to farmers for soil conservatian.

MELBOURN, Australia, Nov. 27 -- Richard G. Casey, Minister of External Affairs, told the House of Representatives today that the political conditions essential to a wide security alliance in the Pacific did not exist. Speaking on the recent defense conference in Washington of Anzus (the United States, Australia and New Zealand), he declared it was not possible to say how such an alliance could be brought about.

The Coast Guard demonstrated yesterday two of the three new ninety-five-foot patrol boats that have been assigned to security watch off the entrance of Ambrose Channel and near City Island in Long Island Sound.

ORANGE, Tex., Nov. 27 (UP) -Thomas C. Buntin and Miss Betty McCuddy, who abandoned family and two fortunes twenty-two years ago, intend to go on living in Orange as Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Palmer as they did before their secret was discovered.

In a tactical maneuver designed to relieve it of the onus of preventing any negotiations on anything, the Soviet Government now drops its impossible conditions for attending a conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, long urged by the Western Powers, and agrees to such a meeting in Berlin at a date still to be fixed.

For the fifth time in its history the Central Reference Library finds it necessary to make a public appeal for funds to help maintain the activities of the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The question that first comes to mind is, "Why must a public operation supported by taxes need to make appeals for funds?"

The one-story taxpayer at 205-01 to 205-35 Linden Boulevard in Cambria Heights, Queens, has been sold by the estate of Morris Walzer to a client of Leo Kotler, attorney. The sale was negotiated to Pearce, Mayer Greer as brokers. William Walzer was attorney for the seller.
BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- Eugene O'Neill, noted American playwright whose prolific talents had brought to him both Nobel and Pulitzer Prizes, died today of bronchial pneumonia. His age was 65.

Events today: Young People's Concert, Philharmonic - Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Grace Castagnetta, pianist, Town Hall, 2:30; Denyse Santini-DuBois, mezzo-soprano, Carl Fischer Hall, 5:30; "Faust," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Composers Forum, McMillin Theatre, 8:30; Quartetto Italiano, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; Oldtimers Symphony Orchestra, Walton High School Auditorium, 8:30.

The regional Red Cross blood program collected 488 pints of blood on Wednesday. At 195 Broadway a three-day collection from American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Western Electric Corporation employes ended with a grand total of 472 pints, and 100 pints were given at Cooper Union Fourth Avenue and Seventh Street.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and prices of active months advanced 3 to 7 points.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Department of Justice advised the Supreme Court today that it had ample constitutional power to outlaw racial segregation in the public schools and should do so.
An unidentified man about 30 years old was shot dead at 10:35 last night in the back room at the Glass Bar on the northeast corner of Fifty-second Street and Ninth Avenue.

Tung Kwong-kwong, a young pianist from China, impressed as a talented instrumentalist in her debut last night at Town Hall. Her instincts were all in the right direction, and she played in a lively, spirited manner.
The Matson Lines and the Isthmian Steamship Company announced yesterday they shortly would open a jointly staffed Hawaiian Department in New York.
An audacious attempt to rob a small bank branch on Governors Island and escape by ferryboat to Manhattan failed yesterday for two young civilians from Miami Beach, Fla.
DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production in the United States this week will amount to 68,732 units, compared with 104,231 last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 (UP) -Gulf Oil Corporation announced today it will cut imports of foreign crude oil in the fiirst quarter of 1954 by an average of 10,000 barrels a day. This will be the third consecutive quarter that Gulf has cut back its imports of foreign crude into the United States.

The Circle Steel Partition Company, in an expansion move, has leased the new one-story building at 330-332 Metropolitan Avenue in Brooklyn and will use it for the manufacturing, finishing and distributing of steel partitions. The Kalmon Dolgin Company, broker, represented its own interests in the transaction. The building contains 7,000 square feet of space.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -"Hurricane Road," slated for production next year by Allan Dowling Productions, Inc., will be a full-length record of a tropical big wind from its origin in the South Caribbean to the time it strikes along the Eastern coast of the United States.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A Lansing, Mich., inventor accused Sears, Roebuck Co. today of infringing on his patent for a vacuum cleaner attachment.

There is considerably more significance in what has happened in Pegu, Burma, than the fact that a demonstration of self-possession and good humor was given by a man who happens to be the Vice President of the United States. Mr. Nixon effectively disarmed an anti-American demonstration by the simple process of shaking hands and talking with the placard bearers and slogan shouters.

Useful and comparatively inexpensive hand-made objects made by the Craft Students League of the Young Women's Christian Association are now on sale at 7 East Fifty-fourth Street. The shop is open every weekday from 10:30 A. M. to 5:30 P. M. and on Thursdays until 8:30.
Twenty-two characters in search of atmosphere in which to rehearse Sidney Kingsley's stark drama of city streets, "Dead End," found that the city's face had changed considerably since 1935.
Price reductions of half a cent a quart on milk they supply to dealers and through home deliveries were announced yesterday by Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., and The Borden Company.

A dispatch to this newspaper has given a brisk and encouraging account of the great gains that are being made in, and the ambitious plans that are laid for, the fishing industry in Pakistan. It can be a far larger food source in a country that is now protein deficient.
WASHINGTON, Nov. -- An increase of 25 per cent in the commutation fares of the Long Island Rail Road was recommended today by an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner, Charles B. Gray.

October witnessed a gain of $1.58 in the average value of the shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange. That body reported yesterday that the figure rose from $38.20 on Sept. 30 to $39.78 on Oct. 30. On July 31 the average was $40.21.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 27 - -The nation's educators were urged today to clear up confusion about politics by giving their pupils a thorough understanding of the workings of democratic government.
Efforts by the state to force the eviction of 165 World War II veterans and their families from the Manhattan Beach and Marine Park temporary housing colonies were complicated further yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- The United States, Britain, France, Australia and Turkey will introduce a resolution next week calling on the General Assembly to condemn atrocious acts against captured military personnel and civilian population.
After a successful salvage operation, the empty passenger liner Nuevo Dominicano rolled over and "died" in Southern waters on Thursday night, it was reported here yesterday. No one was injured.
PUSAN, Korea, Saturday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A wind-whipped fire, roaring unchecked f r many hours, cut a mile-and-a-half-long path today through this crowded port.

The New York Knickerbockers, unbeaten in four home games, will oppose the Rochester Royals at Madison Square Garden tonight in the second game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader. The opening contest, which will start at 7:30 P. M., will pair the Boston Celtics and the Syracuse Nationals.
Carmine Campisi, the big left tackle who missed the Holly Cross game because of injuries, will play for Fordham against Villanova today in the Polo Grounds game starting at 1:30 P. M.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- The United Nations elected Feodor Ivanovich Kozhevnikov, a 50-year-old Soviet professor of law, to the International Court of Justice today.
Dave Gallardo, a rough little mauler from Los Angeles, had little trouble defeating Lulu Perez, Brooklyn featherweight, in the feature event of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- During the week ended Nov. 25, member bank reserves decreased $269,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

If it were possible -- Providence forbid -- to erase from the average American magazine all the information that was gleaned from the New York Public Library, there would be enough blank space to mystify millions of minds.
The National Committee for Labor Israel will seek to raise $5,000,000 to carry out a four-point program for the rehabilitation of new immigrants in Israel.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 27 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived here today for a three-day visit. At the airport, Mr. Nixon said there were two reasons for his visit -- to bring official greetings from the United States and President Eisenhower and to convey greetings from the Americans to the Ceylonese.
Howard Armbruster's letter printed Oct. 10, critical of American policy on Germany, should be scrutinized by every American and every European. I have read it many times.

Anna Russell, the gifted and irreverent singing comedienne, appeared at Carnegie Hall last evening in a program guaranteed to deflate the ego of any vocalists or would-be vocalists who happened to be on hand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- An egg with an artificial shell made of sheet metal or plastic was patented this week by David Adams of Concord, Mass. Mr. Adams prefers the cubic form, but his patent covers also oval, spherical and tubular shapes.

WESTBROOK, Conn., Nov. 27 -- A threat of wind will never keep the ducks moving. The local wild fowlers are growing tired of threats that never become actualities. They turn out on the river marshes and breakwaters in hope that the weather man was considering their locality when he made the forecast.

Together your editorial and Arthur Krock's column in The Times of Nov. 19 furnish not only a thoughtful analysis of recent developments in the Harry Dexter White case but a valuable check list of points all Americans should be thinking about as further disclosures and discussions in this case appear.

The cultural and intellectual prestige of the United States as well as the economic interests of American authors would benefit from our ratification of the Universal Copyright Convention, which was signed by forty countries, including our own, at Geneva last year.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Nov. 28 -- The Communist-hating Presidents of Nationalist China and South Korea conferred anew today after a dinner last night at which their champagne toasts strengthened signs of an anti-Red alliance.

Commodity prices moved generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light following the holiday. However, cocoa had the fourth best volume of the year and the largest number of sales since Nov. 12.
As a youth, Walter K. Marks, the "iron man" of New York's millinery industry, rarely saw a hat. Most of the women in his native town of Prshkau in Poland wore a babushka, or shawl, for work or dress.
There is a considerable variety of styles in six of this week's exhibitions of paintings.

Garlands of yellow chrysanthemums and streamers of smilax provided a holiday decor for the first Junior Assembly of the season last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The same flowers combined with smilax festooned the boxes and entwined the columns of the ballroom.

The Sanitation Department impounded 137 cars in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn on Wednesday and yesterday, the first two days of enforcing the alternate-side parking ban in that area. The rules were suspended for Thanksgiving Day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -Mr. Brownell, in the brief, noted that some Southern leaders had predicted an upsurge of "popular antagonism" if the court should strike down the segregation barriers -- and he suggested a one-year transition period with allowance for a further "reasonable" extension.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Representatives of Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos subscribed today to a definition of the French Union that declared these Indo-Chinese states independent, sovereign, free and equal with France regarding their rights and duties.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The first new shipyard to be built in Britain in more than 26 years was opened today at Newport in South Wales by Sir David Maxwell Fyfe, Home Secretary and Minister for Welsh Affairs.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 27 -Foreign Minister Vicente Rao told a visiting United States Senate group today that his Government believed the United States and Brazil were fated "irresistibly" to collaboration that could be worked out only by putting their common good above private interests.

All segments of the raw cotton industry are girding for a fight against increasing competition from synthetic fibers, burlap, paper and "other substitutes." Participants on cotton's side will be producers, ginners, seed crushers, warehousemen, merchants and spinners.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Robert Abial (Red) Rolfe returns from the baseball wars to his native New Hampshire hills next year as athletic director of Dartmouth, his alma mater.
Photo-engravers on six major New York City newspapers decided yesterday to go on strike today for higher pay and other contract improvements.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 27 -- Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University, urged Congress tonight to retain present educational legislation for Korean war veterans. He warned that a proposed amendment favored by some educators was "not likely to reflect much credit on education."
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday that he was not considering establishment of a Municipal Loyalty Board in the Department of Investigation to root out subversives among city employes.

City College's soccer team rallied for two goals within four minutes to defeat Queens, 2 to 1, in a play-off for the Metropolitan Collegiate Soccer Conference crown at Brooklyn College Field in Brooklyn yesterday. The Knights had held the Lavender scoreless for the first three periods.
Donald L. Redfield has been appointed manager of the business shows department of International Business Machines Corporation.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 27 -- The Appeal Court has ruled that the Government cannot curtail the movements of persons accused of being Communists without first giving them an opportunity to defend themselves.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -Canadian Government was doing all possible to avoid being drawn into "the rough waters of United States internal policies."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The State Department responded coolly but inconclusively today to the Soviet Union's counter-proposal for a four-power foreign ministers' conference on world tensions.

ATHENS, Nov. 27 -- The military talks recently concluded in Belgrade among representatives of Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia resulted in a common plan for the defense of the three nations bound by the Ankara pact, Premier Alexander Papagos told the Chamber of Deputies tonight.
A proposal to reduce the length of taxicab wheelbases to lessen traffic congestion was criticized yesterday by James A. McCarthy, executive secretary of the Hotel Association of New York City.

We can be thankful for the small mercy that the Laniel, Government avoided defeat in the French National Assembly yesterday. It could have been much worse. At least Premier Laniel and Foreign Minister Bidault can now go to Bermuda with a mandate to represent France and to keep the idea of the European Defense Community and of Europeanization as a whole in being.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- George Washington University took a two-point lead over Harvard, the national champion today as the Mark Timme Angsten Memorial intercollegiate regatta for Class D frostbite dinghies began.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (UP) -- "Mr. X," widely sought for six days to warn him he had been bitten by a rabid dog, was found feverish and in pain today and doctors fought to save his life.

Stocks boiled into activity in the final thirty minutes of trading yesterday. Although the upswing was too abrupt for general participation, The New York Times average made its biggest jump -- 2.14 points -- since Oct. 15, almost passed through the high of 179.79 registered on Nov. 6 and came to rest at the highest closing level since Aug. 17, when the figure was 179.61.

In Nassau County, where the population has more than doubled in the last twelve years, there are now close to 600 preschool youngsters busily participating in cooperative nursery school programs, thanks to their parents' enthusiastic initiative.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A busload of Negro soldiers, driven to police station after one of them sat by a white girl, were fined $1,573 on disorderly conduct charges today.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 27 -Queen Elizabeth II sailed away from Jamaica on the liner Gothic late this afternoon to resume her global tour of the British Commonwealth countries after three days on this Caribbean island.
MELBOURNE, Nov. 27 (AP) -America's Davis Cup tennis forces hoped today their luck would change for the better before the challenge round against Australia here Dec. 28-30.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman declined today to interfere in any way with hearings of the House of Representatives Un-American Activities Committee scheduled to open here next week.
The following are new products that may be of interest to homemakers:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -Army and Navy meet here tomorrow in football's prize spectacle, with the West Point cadets favored to win in a close contest. Brisk, partly cloudy weather was forecast for the game, following a brief flurry of snow this afternoon that changed to rain.

Four thousand more teachers -in the parochial schools of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn -- will receive the anti-Communist pamphlet that the Board of Education and the New York Archdiocese have approved and that the Board of Higher Education is expected to approve on Dec. 14.

At least there is no mystery about the motives of the Soviet Government in finally accepting the invitation to a Four-Power conference. An editorial in Pravda two days before the note was received, declaring in effect that there was no reason why the United States and the Soviet Union could not cooperate, gave the first hint of a shift in Kremlin tactics.

A slim, glib 135-pound confidence man strolled unmolested past City Prison guards to freedom at 3 A. M. yesterday. James Briggs, 39-year-old fugitive from New Jersey and Michigan, accomplished the maneuver merely by responding to the name of his cellmate, Herbert Brown.

Even before the commuting public had had a chance to react to it, news of an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner's recommendation of a 25 per cent increase in commutation fares on the Long Island Rail Road met a militant reception yesterday.

The Waterfront Commission of the New York Harbor announced yesterday that the right to work on the waterfront after Monday had been denied for the time being to 187 longshoremen, twenty-four hiring bosses, four pier superintendents and forty port watchmen.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The stock markets were affected today by international developments. At first, prices held steady despite selling, under the influence of the Russian agreement to attend a four-power meeting. Toward the end they tended to sag, chiefly, it was suggested, on reports that the French Government might fall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 725,732 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,326 cars or .002 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 85,341 cars or 10.5 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 14,285 cars or 2 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
With the traditional Christmas opening date of the winter cruise season less than a month away, the steamship industry is looking confidently forward to the biggest one since the war.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- The General Assembly ordered today the compiling of information that will be needed if a special conference is held in 1956 to revise the United Nations Charter.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 27 -Doubts about the motives of the Soviet Union in accepting the Western invitation to a four-power foreign ministers' conference and about the probable outcome of such a meeting were evident today in Bonn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -President Eisenhower has expressed hope that a Senate investigation of juvenile delinquency will "alert our community leaders and all of our parents to the responsibility that is theirs."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, began today his realignment of posts in the Soil Conservation Service.

" Gently Does It," the British murder melodrama by Janet Green, has decided to join the parade of six other outgoing attractions tonight. It will quit the Playhouse after a total of thirty-seven showings. The next tenant at the theatre will be "In the Summer House," starring Judith Anderson, opening Dec. 29.

Following are the texts of statement issued yesterday by William Mapel, president of the Publishers Association of New York City, and by Denis M. Burke, president of Local 1 of the International Photo-Engravers Union:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Coach Gene Ronzani resigned under fire today because of Green Bay's disastrous season and his three assistants were put in charge of the Packers for the rest of the campaign.

The only book published today is a work by Ernest Godlove Eberhardt entitled "Eberhardt's Bible Thesaurus," which Exposition Press is selling at $5. The book is subtitled "Choice Scriptural Texts Alphabetically Arranged Under More Than 100 Essential Topics to Show What the Bible Teaches, as an Aid for Study and Devotional Reading."

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Gerald Parchute, a University of Indiana freshman, today upset first-seeded Mike Green of Miami Beach, Fla., in a quarter-final match in the junior singles of the national indoor tennis tournament.

A new method of pricing steel mill products will be started on Dec. 15 by the Republic Steel Corporation, the country's third largest steel concern. It will apply initially to hot rolled carbon bars, but will be extended to Republic's other steel mill products.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson, 1952 Democratic Presidential candidate, is speending the week-end at the home of a former Democratic Senator, Millard E. Tydings.

The A. O. Smith Corporation, manufacturer of chassis frames and parts for automobiles, trucks and trailers and of welded equipment for several other industries, showed substantially improved earnings in the latest quarter.
A letter from Albert Forman published in The New York Times on Nov. 18 criticizes the Sanitation Department's enforcement of alternateside parking.

A truck driver failed yesterday, the police said, to profit in a business venture because he passed a red light. They ignored the traffic violation, but held James Thomas, 47 years old, of 143 West Sixty-fourth Street, on a charge of grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -Following is an unofficial English translation of the Soviet note of yesterday on a conference of the Foreign Ministers of the Soviet Union, the Untied States, Britain and France, released today by the State Department and the text of a statement by the Department:
Dividend declarations of the Laclede Steel Company will be increased this year to $7.30 a share on the common stock, from the $4.50 received by stockholders in 1952.
Dividend declarations of the Laclede Steel Company will be increased this year to $7.30 a share on the common stock, from the $4.50 received by stockholders in 1952.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Coming after collarless necklines for winter, a surprise element among the few midseason models shown by Jacques Fath were coats and jackets with collars. The points of the turn-over collar on a dark gray tweed suit were fixed to the lapels by single buttons.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Michigan Teamsters Union, A. F. L., told Congressional investigators today that his union frequently had given him blank checks to help the financing of political campaigns or "to help any locals in trouble."

ALBANY, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed State Senator Paul D. Graves of Gouverneur as a State Supreme Court Justice in the Fourth Judicial District, to replace the late O. Byron Brewster.

The average child in New York spends about fourteen hours a week viewing television, according to a survey just completed by the United Parents Associations. Although the 500 parents responding were still loud in criticism of many programs, a substantial percentage reported that other programs had increased their children's interest in reading, art, music, dancing and dramatics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP)--Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson proclaimed 1954 tobacco marketing quotas today which permit about the same production of flue-cured leaf but cut acreage on burley, fire-cured and dark air-cured tobacco.

NEWARK, Nov. 27 -- A second conference before the State Board of Mediation failed today to settle the seven-day-old strike of 1,800 gas distribution workers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. The next meeting was set for Wednesday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 (AP) -An Orphans Court Judge ruled today that a faded portrait had sufficiently established the identity of a St. Louis widow as the long missing heir to a $3,500,000 fortune and ordered a $479,730 share to be paid to her.
WEST, POINT, N. Y., Nov. 27 -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was denounced here today as a "dangerous adventurer" making an "unscrupulous grab for publicity."

A law antedating the Saxon invasion of England in the fifth century was the basis of a $22,000 Supreme Court award made yesterday by Justice Martin M. Frank. It went to a private detective for injuries suffered while helping a policeman to restore the peace.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- The United States told the United Nations today that President Eisenhower would support full independence for Puerto Rico if the Puerto Rican Government asked for it.

An ex-convict boss trucker, who allegedly had his wife and son "front" for him in the operation of an extensive racing stable, became the central figure yesterday in a flat racing investigation that crossed the line of the state's inquiry into harness racing.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The British Government delegation will go to the Bermuda conference with the United States and France intent on arranging the foreign ministers' meeting with the Soviet Union suggested in the Soviet Government's latest note.

In the last half-century the death rate in this city has been reduced by more than half. The record is better than for the nation as a whole. The non-profit, voluntary hospitals of the city have played an important part in this achievement.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Wheat prices failed to hold early advances today and the liquidation of December contracts became more active in the latter part of the session. Germany postponed her buying of wheat until Dec. 3 and then is expected to take 200,000 tons, supposedly red and hard wheat.

Lord Taylor, as evinced by their showing yesterday at the store of Young New Yorker fashions, are ready with a host of gay and youthfully sophisticated designs for holiday wear North and South. In the younger set's favorite saucy, full-skirted silhouette and sleek, slim sheaths, the fashions, in sizes five to fifteen, highlighted Judy and Jill and Anne Fogarty designs.
ATLANTA, Nov. 27 (UP) -Tyrus R. (Ty) Cobb established an educational fund today to help Georgians obtain the higher education he "passed up" to become one of baseball's immortals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -The Amateur Athletic Union today began a vigorous campaign to challenge Russia in wrestling and gymnastics, two sports in which the Soviet scored heavily in the 1952 Olympics. The action was taken at the sixty-fifth meeting of the A. A. U.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 (UP) -Unbeaten but tied Notre Dame, seeking to regain top ranking nationally, clashes tomorrow with the University of Southern California in the silver anniversary game of their intersectional football rivalry.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 -- The city's three largest department stores -- the May Company, Kaufmann division; Gimbels and the Joseph Horne Company -- were struck today by Local 249, General Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, A. F. L., over a contract dispute involving changes in the working conditions of 500 members.

IN a way, the music festivals that Pablo Casals has been directing have been as much a mecca for the recording engineers as the music lover. Columbia apparently had microphones set up for every event, and throughout the year has been issuing the fruits of the occasions in what appears to be an endless succession of LP's. Latest to arrive are two albums of chamber music.

KARL VON CLAUSEWITZ, a German general who served in the Russian Army from 1811 to 1815, once wrote that "a conqueror is always a peace lover * * * he would like to make his entry into our state unopposed." Lenin, a constant reader of Clausewitz, underscored this line and gleefully commented: "Ha, Ha! Pretty clever!"
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 28 (AP) -- A general was kept waiting more than an hour yesterday by a former Air Force enlisted man who overslept his appointment to receive a commendation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- An order permitting preliminary work on 14,563 new public housing dwellings in Chicago and seven other Midwestern cities was issued this week by William E. Bergeron, Chicago field office director of the Public Housing Administration.

THESE two big books, carrying a full load of nostalgic, amusing and informative illustrations, spin leisurely through the half century which has set America awheel. Floyd Clymer's book, "Those Wonderful Old Automobiles," has the intimate touch of the veteran who has lived through much of the development of the motor-car age and taken an active part in it.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 28 -- A report that the New York Stock Exchange had refused to alter its listing requirements so that certain Dutch corporations could have their shares traded on the Exchange caused considerable interest here this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Representative Clair Engle said yesterday California officials apparently had proposed buying the Central Valley reclamation project to "get out from under" provisions of the reclamation law, including the 160-acre limit.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- A German archeologist, Dr. Friedrich Karl Doerner, is risking the wrath of an unknown "great goddess" to open the mountain tomb of Mithridates I, King and god of the Greek Kingdom of Commagene, which flourished in Asia Minor in the first century, B. C.
The storage shelves of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and those of its distributors and dealers are almost as bare as Mother Hubbard's cupboard.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 28 -- After years of political controversy over highway, road and street financing from state funds, Minnesota has called in two groups of outside experts to get an objective report on the problems involved.

HAVING observed during the past season that, as drama critic of The Times, I have written pleasantly about some plays and unpleasantly about others, the editors of the Magazine have asked for precise information. They would like to know what constitutes the magic in the theatre that produces hits.

APPREHENSIVE of commodity price movements in a contracting economy, industry is carefully watching all factors that might influence fluctuations. Not the least among these factors is the forthcoming reduction in excess profits taxes which, if taxes are an item of cost, might conceivably affect commodity prices.

THE Supreme Court has before it the jackpot question: Should radio and television quiz shows be banned as lotteries? The Federal Communications Commission said yes, and tried to rule them off the air; a New York tribunal said no, and on the air they stayed.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 28 -- Behind the facade of apartheid, the system of race segregation with which Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan says he is safeguarding white supremacy in the multiracial Union of South Africa, more and more non-whites are entering industry and slowly but surely pushing the color bar upward.

A FIRST novel is searched hopefully for many specific things: for the fresh viewpoint, the ability to mirror human behavior truthfully and for an integrity that does not follow the slick or obvious plot twists. Margaret Bridgman meets all these requisites in "Love Is a Place" and while she has not written a great novel, she has certainly written a good one.

A recent pilgrimage of eighteen Soviet Moslems to Mecca was the beginning of a major Soviet effort to make friends in the Middle East and Pakistan, but its success was less than Moscow had hoped, according to diplomatic circles.

THE last Arbor Day of the year -- or perhaps it's the first of another season -- is observed by the State of Georgia on the first Friday in December. This annual celebration is marked by tree-planting ceremonies and appropriate programs conducted by the public schools and garden clubs.

NEITHER of this week's two exhibitions celebrating great classical periods in French painting contains any very important pictures but both -- that of the seventeenth century at Seligmann's and of the eighteenth at Duveen's -- provide opportunities for deep enjoyment.

THIRTY years ago this fall, the fabled Four Horsemen of Notre Dame were riding roughshod over the opposition. They galloped through Purdue 34 to 7, Georgia Tech 25 to 7, Princeton 25 to 2, Carnegie Tech 26 to 0 and Army 13 to 0. Sports writers hailed them as the greatest backfield combination of all time.

" THE very best place for a boy to be born," says Manuel Komroff in the very first line in this book, "is on an enchanted isle." For him that means Manhattan Island when its other name was Little Old New York -- yet already it was a microcosm of the world and a sampler of all the races of the earth.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Nov. 28 -- The fall term of the Morris County grand jury has been extended into 1954 by Superior Court Judge Donald Waesche. He asked for a further inquiry into the problem of juvenile drinking and the sale of obscene literature.

WHAT the dance business needs in New York is a co-ordinator of some kind. Since the closing of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on Oct. 11, we have been without performances of any kind in the so-called Broadway district, but when January comes around we shall have all sorts of conflicting seasons.

BARACOA, Cuba -- On the north coast of the far eastern tip of Cuba sits the town of Baracoa. It has been sitting here since 1512, when it was founded by Diego Velazquez as the first settlement in Cuba. Later its creole aristocrats worked vast plantations with slaves from Guinea, and built their mansions with profits from the coconuts and coffee they sent in sailing vessels to Boston and New York.

BUSHNELL, Fla. -- There is a quiet peacefulness about Dade Memorial Park. It lacks the blatant advertising so characteristic of many tourist attractions. Spanish moss hangs from tall live-oak trees, and palmetto bushes behind which Seminole Indians once fought grow in natural clusters.

In the course of his testimony on the Harry Dexter White case before a Senate subcommittee, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced that he would request the next session of Congress to legalize the use of evidence secured through the tapping of telephone wires in certain classes of Federal prosecutions.

IF, as the pseudosopher poet Edgar Guest came near saying but didn't, "it takes a heap of lovin' to make a house a home," then Mammy Pleasant was in the same line of work as the present-day madam-of-letters, Miss Polly Adler. Yet Mammy and Polly were as far apart as Sir Pandarus of Troy and Mickey Jelke.
The abbreviation A. K. U., already renowned internationally in the textile trade, is about to enter the public register of the American investment world.

A PROJECT in sharing their knowledge of photography and in helping teen-age boys and girls in the local community centers, is the initial venture of the University Camera Club of 158 West Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, a group of eight photographers.

A NEW airliner has brought Los Angeles within a working day's flight of New York. American Airlines today begins the first non-stop service from coast to coast with the Douglas DC-7, the world's fastest piston-engine airliner.

ONE finishes a preliminary reading of Ralph Kirkpatrick's "Domenico Scarlatti," just issued by the Princeton University Press, and lays down the book with recollection of the story told of a Parisian lady of the Eighteen Thirties who had the reputation of a musical connoisseur and was asked to compare the rival virtuosos, as they then were, Liszt and Thalberg. Which was the greatest pianist? Undoubtedly Thalberg.

JOHN TRUMBULL, who flourished shortly after the American Revolution as a brilliant American painter, and then lived out a long life as a mediocre one, exerted a tremendous and equivocal influence on artistic thought in the United States.

GENEVA, Nov. 27 -- A bit of obscure diplomatic history, a tale of intrigue and stolen documents and a distinguished looking gentleman who was once a close collaborator of Lenin and Stalin, all came to light in Geneva today and made up a story that is passing strange.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 27 -- In an editorial headed "A Timely Shock," the Johannesburg Star said today:

THE first step in winter protection of plants (both hardy and near-hardy) is, paradoxically, freezing. This changes the cell contents from a watery solution to a more stable state of starches, sugars and other protective compounds. Thus winter covering is not so much protection from cold as from fluctuating temperatures which keep the plants off balance and so do infinitely more harm than sub-zero temperatures.

A NOVELIST, Louis de Wohl has a simple method. He selects a subject whose life "reads like a novel," chooses the more dramatic scenes, fits them out with believable dialogue. He makes little attempt to illuminate a shadowed face in the mural of history or to redefine a familiar character.

Economists are beginning to believe that the pooled liquid savings of the people may be one of the main forces in the 1954 economy. These savings now stand near $369,000,000,000 and about two-fifths of them are estimated to be available for spending if their owners desire.

A FAVORITE topic of conversation among Billy Yanks in Virginia early in 1864 was the new general-in-chief who had established his headquarters among them. They recognized him as the "hero of Vicksburg," but Vicksburg they regarded as not much of a fight and Grant's opponents in the West they rated as pushovers in comparison to Jackson and Lee.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 28 -- The Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission appears certain to close the Delaware free bridge eighteen miles north of here Tuesday despite mounting protests from near-by sections of Pennsylvania and New Jersey.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- The Armour Laboratories Division of Armour Co., the meat packers, formally opened its new $12,000,000 pharmaceuticals manufacturing plant last week.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 21 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan has told the Cape Province convention of his Nationalist party that he will order an investigation of South Africa's "land barons." They are rich and flourishing white farmers who buy up more land than they can put to use.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Harvey V. Higley, the new administrator of the Veterans Administration, has set out on a man-size job to "humanize" the sprawling agency, which employs 175,000 and controls $5,000,000,000.

TOM MALONEY'S annual report on the state of contemporary photography, "U. S. Camera, 1954" (New York: Duell, Sloan Pearce; Boston: Little, Brown. $7.95), to be published tomorrow, has a distinctly international air.

As was noted in this column last Sunday, one of the most important constructive advances made in World War II was a wider acceptance and better understanding of our emotions, the effect of environmental stresses on personality and the universality of nervous reactions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Department stores in the Chicago area were out to increase a small trade lead over last year as they entered the Christmas buying season. Sales from Jan. 1 to Nov. 14 were 1 per cent above a year ago. Colder weather brought out a large volume of promotions.

MANY a wistful sigh will rise as mothers, long used to the vagaries of adolescent sitters, shut Mary Furlong Moore's little pink book and place it in some carefully obvious spot in the living room. On the other hand, the sitter serieuse who absorbs even just the nub of the advice -- to be gay, kind, patient and respectful with children -- will be the diamond in her client's crown.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov., 28 -- United Nations delegates received today from the United States a 152-page record of horror in Korea.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 27 -- The agreement granting Government insurance subsidies and pension rights to Roman Catholic priests on the same basis as workers will go into force in Croatia Tuesday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- With the approach of winter, Chicago faces the probability of major catastrophies involving fires in slum areas.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output in the United States has tapered off substantially in recent weeks but the year's total is going to be even greater than many estimates.

PROFESSIONAL philatelists with long experience in organizing and handling exhibitions agree that the fifth annual National Postage Stamp Show, which closed last Sunday after being viewed by an estimated 68,500 people in three days, was the most spectacular affair of its kind since the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition (CIPEX) held here in 1947.

A FACTIONAL dispute in the Sudanese Federation of Labor at Khartum appears meaningless to the average newspaper reader. To Lewis L. Lorwin, an authority on international labor, it means the cold war has reached colonial Africa just as it has already been carried to Asia and other areas.

WEST ISLIP, L. I., Nov. 28 -- Thousands of amateur parakeet breeders throughout the nation will soon be asked to apply their hobby to such community projects as combating juvenile delinquency and giving mental therapy to veterans in hospitals.
CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 28 -- New Hampshire's Congressional candidates already are preparing the blueprints of the campaign vehicles they plan to ride in 1954.

ON the whole, I agree with the tenor of Marian Rich's article in your section on Nov. 15 on the necessity for placing greater emphasis on the integrated training of the technical phase along with the sensitive phase of an actor's preparation.

BEING in bed with a cold, I feel alarmingly articulate, and I would like to express some of my thoughts on television shows I have seen lately, especially more or less serious dramatic programs dealing with what they fondly think is religion.

PRE-SOVIET Siberia is seen through the eyes of 12-year-old Kolya during his first year in a country village. Kolya (the young Kalishnikoff) tells of adventures with his step-father's animals, a trip to a fair, a horse race, a mounted attack on a snow fort and other rural excitements. Above all it is the record of Kolya's affection for the Tartar horseman and storyteller Yakub.

WITH the 1953-54 theatre season only a little more than twenty-four hours from its exact midway point, a student of baleful facts wishes to intrude with the thought that the trend toward a paucity in musical production continues.

FOUR weeks ago many people breathed more easily. The Sunday papers carried the news that the Metropolitan Opera and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians had settled their differences and the opera season was assured.

THE sixth and last volume of Sir Winston Churchill's World War II Memoirs covers the decisive period from June 6, 1944 (the supreme "D-Day"), to July 26, 1945, when "just before dawn I woke suddenly with a sharp stab of almost physical pain" (the stab was induced by a premonition that the Labor party had won the general election).

THE encounter had taken place on the banks of the Tiber, where the Colonna had challenged the Orsini. At first unfriendly words had passed, then coarse insults, and finally blows. Swords had been drawn, reinforcements had been called for on both sides, and the dispute had degenerated into a brawl in which neither force asked any quarter.

This correspondent, an old liberal Republican, read twice Jacob K. Javits' article "A Liberal Republican Takes Stock" (Nov. 15). After each reading, the gloom deepened as to the survival of the Republican party.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, demanded yesterday that Governor Dewey be brought before a grand jury to offer any evidence the Governor may have that would warrant "impeachment" of State Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston. He made this demand in a telegram to State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

IT is indeed an achievement to take an overwritten subject and give it freshness. Emmett Dedmon's book is aglitter with anecdotes set in a solid historical fundament, so that old lady Chicago blooms out like a stockyard's heiress in her European crown jewels.

ZIGUINCHOR, French West Africa, Nov. 14 -- The French peanut project near Sedhiou on the Casamance River was a hazardous venture when it started four years ago, but it has now been blessed with its first bumper crop. The event is not likely to pass unnoticed in Africa.

FOR Jeff Miles and his family moving to Garrison, Col. was a dream come true. Mr. Miles' work as a mining engineer had taken them all over the map. To Mrs. Miles, Jeff and Virginia, his decision to buy an abandoned mine and settle in the town closest to it meant a home, real friends and a feeling of belonging.

PEARL LANG and her company will divide a program with Lucas Hoving and Lavina Nielsen in the Students' Dance Recitals series at the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, on Saturday evening.

Once there was a bright young man who worked for a utility company. He wrote a book about gas heating when such heating was usually confined to the portable burner in the bathroom and the simulated log in the fireplace. A manufacturer of heating equipment who spotted the book thought of buying it, then decided instead that he had better hire the author.

A strike of Local 1, International Photo-Engravers Union, A. F. L., prevented publication yesterday of two of New York's three major afternoon papers. The three morning papers affected were able, before the strike began at 7 A. M. yesterday, to publish Sunday editions for sale today.
A comprehensive farm program is being prepared by the Eisenhower Administration for submission to the coming session of Congress.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 -- Although retail trade in this area this month has made a better comparison with a year ago than it did in October. it is still a bit on the disappointing side. When the final figures for department store sales in Boston for November are in. they will probably show a drop from a year ago, but less than the October decline.

BECAUSE of the publicity given to the sale of dramatic properties to the movies at handsome prices, it may seem to many persons that Broadway plays as often as not have canisters of gold waiting for them at the California end of the rainbow.

THERE is a spirit of kinship between pioneer Israel and pioneer America. The lines engraved on the Statue of Liberty: "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free * * *" might well be the keynote of "My Promised Land."

THERE is a pleasant, pre-atomic flavor all through this love story of the "dancing daughter of that play-boy Frith Cunningham" and her Michael Faulkner, which makes it more a vanished enchantment than a dark one. The setting is Provence, in a France which we might like to think existed, a pre-war fairy-tale country of peasants, childlike innkeepers, gypsy witches, naive lovers; a France seen through traveling English eyes.

THIS is an oddly constructed biography of the man who wrote "The Story of San Michele." It consists of sketches from various phases of his life by his cousin, Dr. Gustaf Munthe, and his friend, Baroness Gudrun Uexkull.

WHEN the lights come on and the doors open for the first time at the Phoenix Theatre on Tuesday evening, I shall take a moment off to remember a little Soho restaurant in London on an evening in July, 1952; for it was there, while raking around in the theatrical ashes with my dinner companion, that fine actress Pamela Brown, that the Phoenix idea was discovered in embryo.

TROY, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- The New York Operations Office of the Atomic Energy Commission has engaged Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute researchers to analyze radioactivity in rain water, ground water and soil of this area, Dr. Wendell F. Hess, director of research at the institute, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Air Force expects to send its first squadrons of pilotless bombers -- ground-to-ground guided missiles -- overseas early next year.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28-- Unemployment in Ohio. which appeared to be leveling off, took another jump this week and is now at the highest level since the start of hostilities in Korea in mid-1950. Total state unemployment compensation claims hit the 55,000 mark two weeks ago and there appears to be no signs of a let-up.

WHEN Horace Traubel died in 1919 he left in manuscript three unpublished volumes of his "With Walt Whitman in Camden." His third volume, bringing his famous conversations with the aged poet down to Jan. 20, 1889, was published in 1914.

SOMETIME within the next few weeks the bushes of hybrid tea roses should be given winter protection. The amount of protection required is determined by the exposure in which they are planted, the locality and weather conditions.
West Germany's surge of postwar recovery recently has turned strongly toward rebuilding foreign trade.

A symposium on proposals for tax amendments in the interest of small business will be held Tuesday afternoon at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel under the auspices of the National Association of Independent Business.

THIS is the year of Queen Elizabeth. The understandable, if misguided attempt to equate the attractive young British Queen with her red-headed Tudor predecessor has led to considerable writing and talk.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 28 -- Dr. Charles Frederick Menninger, chairman of the board of the Menninger Foundation, died here today. He was 91.

GOTEBORG, Sweden -- "The liner, she's a lady," wrote Kipling. The M. S. Kungsholm, the Swedish-American Line's brand new contribution to the Atlantic passenger trade, is just that, and an extremely beautiful lady to boot.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 28 -- Representatives of all levels of government in Bergen County are studying a broad program for "keeping Bergen County clean" as laid down by State Senator-elect Walter H. Jones.

THAT nineteenth-century stand-by -- the Conflict Between Science and Religion -- isn't very real today, at least not in the terms of the nineteenth-century controversy. But the conflict between what is called Science and what is called Humanism is real enough to be approaching a crisis.

TOKYO, Nov. 28 -- Arthur H. Dean, special United Nations representative, made a counter-proposal to the Communist plan for a Korean peace conference at Panmunjom today. He agreed to accept neutrals as "nonvoting" observers at the peace talks.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 19 -- By Government edict many more thousands of native Africans are to be uprooted in and around the Johannesburg area and removed to new districts designated by the Government.

Out of all the productions recently on Broadway (excluding repertory), only five could honestly have been classed as serious; moreover, of the latter, two have been withdrawn: "Take a Giant Step" and "Ladies of the Corridor." It is the closing of the latter production which prompts this letter.

ENTHUSIASTS for color television are going to have to readjust their sights. Seeing last Sunday's color telecast of Donald O'Connor's appearance on the "Comedy Hour" left no doubt that the novelty of color can wear off quickly and that the acid test of the tinted medium will be the same as in black and white -- how good is the show? Color by itself will not save any show.
DAKAR, French Africa, Nov. 21 -- The natural elegance of the Wolof women of Dakar and their extraordinary flair in matters of dress have made this city the undisputed fashion capital of West Africa.

IN the fall of 1897, in the pages of The Book Buyer, Rufus Rockwell Wilson first wrote on "Lincoln in Caricature." Throughout a long life Mr. Wilson, a pioneer in the field, continued his interest in the subject, and this posthumously published work is the culmination of his studies.

General of the Army George C. Marshall said yesterday that he regarded the award of the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize to him not as individual honor but as a recognition of the work of the entire American people for world peace.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- A sophomore halfback led Army to its first football victory over Navy since 1949 today with a performance almost unparalleled in this 63-year-old rivalry.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- The Army knows a good idea even if it was the Navy's.
HONG KONG, Nov. 27 -- A serious food shortage is expected in Communist China by next spring. Informed sources here foresee the possibility of famine conditions in some regions.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The Americon correspondents in London, generally considered by their British colleagues a hard-bitten lot, will go out of character in January and give a luncheon to a retired public relations officer.

PADRAIC COLUM is a folk-poet, or but one step removed from the folk. His verse (it is but rarely charged with the special verbal magic we have come to define rather exclusively as "poetry") is well-made, but it is made to be sung, perhaps to the accompaniment of some rustic musical instrument in a tavern or under a maid's window, rather than read.

IN his review of Arthur O. Bestor's "Educational Wastelands." Gordon Chalmers gives good space to Mr. Bestor's thesis that "every department" of a college "is a department of education in the legitimate sense of the word."

IF it chooses to look gingerly back down the years, middle age can remember as a part of boyhood's spring, the Memorial Day in any small American town. There was the band, which was willing but was not Sousa, there was the distinguished orator, there was the group of ladies -- each one in her own right a renowned cook -- who served the noonday meal at the village hall.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Officials of the 225,000-member Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of America, A. F. L., have changed their opinion of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin. The change of opinion was made apparent in an editorial in the November issue of The Butcher Workman, the union's monthly magazine.
