THE International Music Council, an organization created under the asupices of UNESCO in 1949, is pursuing its aims with the most modest of means. Nevertheless, it is making progress. The general public, particularly in this country, knows little of the Council's work, but as it discovers more about the program, it should be eager and generous with its support.

IN the summer of 1950 Mr. Schildt and his wife Mona sailed their ketch Daphne from Rapallo down the Italian Riviera through the Straits of Messina, across the Mediterranean to the Ionian Islands. They went to Cephalonia and Ithaca and into the Gulf of Corinth to Patras.

THE National Broadcasting Company's two new mobile color TV units will make their debut under actual broadcast conditions when they are used to televise, in color, the Tournament of Roses parade in California on New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- This country is not adequately prepared to meet an atomic attack, and it will not be until Americans face the facts and overcome six "attitudes" they have, Val Peterson, Administrator of Federal Civil Defense, asserted in an interview this week.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- Victoria State, of which Melbourne is the capital, has embarked on a significant program of soil and water conservation and reclamation.

IT was a week signalized by exhibitions of recent work by elder artists. The extraordinary versatility of Picasso has never been better demonstrated than in the exhibition at Curt Valentin's, with landscapes, figures, portraits, sculpture, ceramics and graphic work in full range.

FOR many years now, Octavus Roy Cohen has prospected in the literary diggings -- short stories, books, plays, motion pictures. His present story of the fabulous gold and silver mines and of wicked Virginia City, Nev., is a rich mixture of pure quill romance and pure quill history.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Benjamin C. Willis, Superintendent of Schools, has presented to the Board of Education for consideration a single salary schedule for Chicago's more than 14,000 public school teachers.

PREPARATIONS for a new production push are being stepped up at Twentieth Century-Fox and that means several hundred employes who were dismissed or handed lay-off notices during the last six months will soon be hearing the welcome "back to work" call.

The only industry ever spawned by a Constitutional amendment is doing quite well. Tubie Resnick, executive vice president of Calvert Distillers Corporation, must be credited with that description of the alcoholic beverage industry.

The forty-second annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will begin next Sunday. Among the contributions that will be included in the campaign are legacies from nine New Yorkers, who indicated through their bequests the spirit of neighborly help upon which the appeal is based.

IN collaboration with Helen Ferris, in "Partners: United Nations and Youth," Eleanor Roosevelt provided valuable information regarding the work of the international organizations affiliated with the United Nations. As the title indicated, this was addressed primarily to younger readers.

IN a comedy encore as broad as its protagonist, Robert Tallant presents Mrs. Candy of Cairo Street, New Orleans, and her roomers. Since the first Mrs. Candy report, "Mrs. Candy and Saturday Night," published some six years ago, this talented young Louisiana writer has concerned himself with such widely diverse personalities as the traveling salesman (deep-South division), Lafitte the pirate, and "The Romantic New Orleanians."
BONN, Germany, Nov. 28 -- West Germany has a surplus of doctors, East Germany a shortage, according to figures published today in the weekly bulletin of the West German Government.

THE practice or "copying down" has become so rampant in the home-furnishings industry that at least one manufacturer admits he has been forced to copy one of his own expensive designs for a lower-priced line. The manufacturer makes printed draperies.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 25 -- Watches, synthetic diamonds, necklaces and earrings -- smuggled to Israel in food parcels -- are giving a headache to customs officers here.

Representatives of the nation's rubber industry are going to Washington on Wednesday to talk over the Government's stockpiling policy and decide whether something can and should be done to strengthen the price of natural rubber.

ATHENS, Nov. 28 (Nana) -- A Greek fisherman has found a bottle floating in the sea and in it a treasure-trove message written by four German officers at the time of the German retreat from Greece. The message, sealed with wax in a dirty one-ounce bottle, describes in cryptic language how the four officers buried 2,500,000 gold soveregins (worth about $25,000,000) near the headquarters of the Greek Nature-Lovers Soviety.

IN this new theatrical season three plays have been immediate successes. They are Paul Claudel's "Christopher Columbus," Jean Anouilh's "L'Alouette" and Jean Giraudoux's "Pour Lucrece." These stand out from a background which is not wholly devoid of interest, although somewhat overshadowed by these triumphs.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Nov. 28 -- A record-breaking attendance was in prospect today for the forty-second annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America, which will get under way tomorrow at the Hollywood Beach Hotel here.

WALT DISNEY'S persevering operatives, who are just as likely to surprise an Alaskan Eskimo as an unsuspecting rattlesnake basking in the torrid desert, are ranging farther afield. Last week, it was learned that Disney camera crews now are gathering film footage for future features in such widely scattered areas as the Falkland Islands, Siam, Switzerland and Morocco.

THE review by Adolf A. Berle Jr. of Herbert Feis' "The China Tangle" contains a provocative sentence. Mr. Berle tells us that he is convinced that sometime in 1944 the Kremlin decided to "act unilaterally" at the end of the war, adding "It was the real beginning of the cold war."

Paul G. Hoffman in "How to Avoid a Psycho-Recession" (Nov. 15) points reassuringly at our national economy, and informs us that all we have to fear is fear itself. It cannot be disputed that fear for the future is not justified in view of our high income and productive prowess.

NEXT Thursday a "push-potatoes" merchandising campaign begins throughout the nation. Retailers plan to sell potatoes at more favorable prices than will be effective later. Much emphasis will be placed on the nutritive value of the potato which, despite the fact that a medium-sized one has only 100 calories, is popularly considered to be a weight-producing food.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 28 -- The Government today ordered a major amnesty covering 7,194 prisoners, most of whom were opposed to President Tito's revolution or the practices of his regime.
Signs of weakness in the commodity prices during November were more prominent than indications of strength.

THE vastly unpleasant realities of the deadly practice of war, which are crowding the thoughts and apprehensions of many people these days, come in for some heavy demonstration, in one or another way, in the three most considerable and important of the recently arrived new films.

THERE'S many a gift could be put under the Christmas tree for gardeners this year. It might be a gadget like the new rotary duster, or a tool such as an aluminum trowel or a small pocket-pruner that could be stuffed into a stocking.

THE center of Asia is a land of unending steppes surrounded by mountains, deserts and inland seas. Geography and politics concur to make it inaccessible: yet it has provided the history of mankind with some of its most cataclysmic events. for it was the cradle and springboard of the Turkish race.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 28 -- Florida sold a $15,000,000 "test issue" of school construction bonds this week at interest rates that were called "exceedingly gratifying."

THERE is probably no kinder man in London today than T. S. Eliot. He finds time to sit on a large number of committees for a variety of causes which benefit by his name, his experience and his shrewd judgment, and once he takes on such a job he does it thoroughly, putting to shame many fellow committee members with more time but a less exacting sense of responsibility.
HOLLYWOOD. THE primary question asked of me lately by interviewers is, "Aren't you a little worried about doing so many remakes?"

ROME, Nov. 27 -- The United States, Britain and France will try again next week to induce Yugoslavia to accept the proposal for a five-power conference on Trieste, according to advices Rome. Italy accepted the proposals last week.

ACCORDING to Rocky Graziano, former middleweight boxing champion, no ring opponent ever rocked his senses as much as the television life into which he recently entered as Martha Raye's boy friend on her N. B. C. program.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 28 -- Nearly three-fourths of Indiana's 1952 rural traffic deaths in accidents were classified as "survivable," Indiana state police reported today.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 28 -- President Eisenhower passed up the Army-Navy football game in Philadelphia today for another round of golf in crisp weather as he neared the end of his Thanksgiving vacation here.

PERSONS with prolonged illness says the author, receive inadequate medical, social and psychological care -- not only to their detriment, but to the detriment of their families and communities and to our national economy.

THIS book was inevitable. Sooner or later someone with stature in Zionist letters had to put aside the blinkers, take a long and fearless look at modern Israel, and cry, "Woe is me!" It is a satisfaction that the mission has fallen to Maurice Samuel -- a distinguished writer, whose authority to speak with sympathetic forthrightness about Israel is buttressed by his credentials as intimate co-worker with some of the giants of Zionism.

LAST week in this space we commented on the return of the "bully" as a topic of discussion in parents' groups. Today we'd like to consider another type of youngster who seems to have been newly rediscovered in some quarters -- the shy child, too often in the recent past labeled "withdrawn" or "insecure."

George Morton Levy Jr., son of the general counsel of Roosevelt. Raceway, asserted yesterday that his gross receipts were $116,000 for taking motion pictures of races at Yonkers and Roosevelt raceways, and not a reported $160,000.

WITHIN its framework of science-fiction, this is essentially a human - interest story. The action covers several years round about 2000 A. D. Man has already established colonies -- unprofitable ones -- on the Moon, Mars and Venus; now it rests with Congress whether to finance a commercially unpromising expedition to Jupiter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin ended his TV broadcast last Tuesday with a quotation from a Lincoln speech that goes to the heart of the present controversy on how to deal with Communists and other subversive elements in America.

TONY BEAVER, cousin of Paul Bunyan, seems to be one of our folk heroes who concentrated on Free Enterprise. Nineteen and a half feet tall, a mighty logger, he made West Virginia a state, invented matches, clothespins, peanut butter and a barter system to beat the depression of 1873.

About 10,000 persons are expected to attend the Popular Price Shoe Show of America, which opens here today at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels. The semi-annual five-day market is held by the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores and the New England Shoe and Leather Association.

IN January, 1951, Columbia transferred to an LP disk earlier recordings by the Budapest String Quartet of the first two of Mozart's Six Quartets Dedicated to Haydn. In the meantime, the vogue for recordings of complete cycles having grown, the same ensemble has made new recordings of all six works in the set and Columbia has issued them in a three-disk, box-type album.

CAIRO, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- Thousands of young men, including civil servants, business men, students and workers are joining Egypt's new National Guard, and many of the recruits have been undergoing commando-type training.

IT is beginning to dawn on the American people, and, I hope, to trouble their conscience, that all is not well with their schools. Headline after headline extends the nation-wide report of overcrowded schoolrooms and teacher shortages. What the headlines do not tell us is how vitally these conditions are affecting our chances of survival, not just in the "cold war," but in the historical perspective of Western civilization.

THE fireside season is at hand for yachtsmen. The cruising types are working up the logs of their summer's voyaging; the boats are getting their winter covers fitted; the bar committee is putting away the hot-weather mixers and getting out the toddy glasses.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- French schools and colleges have opened this year to find thousands of classrooms overcrowded, owing to the combination of the housing shortage and the increased birth rate during the years just after World War II.

The first issue of Tape Film Recording, a bi-monthly magazine published in Severna Park, Md., has just been released nationally. Designed to do for this new hobby field what the photographic magazines are doing for photography, the publication is thirty-five cents a copy, $2 a year. The editor is Mark Mooney, Jr., former editor of Camera Magazine. The publishers are Mooney-Rowan Publications.
A quiet but major revolution in the chemical field is fast taking shape.

WITH highway safety programs being intensified throughout the state in an effort to curb the increasing accident toll, the Motor Vehicle Bureau warns motorists, "You may keep your driver's license as long as you drive safely, provided you renew it within the time allowed."

THE names of Guy Bolton and P. G. Wodehouse no longer appear with their erstwhile frequency in the drama news columns. They are nevertheless, fondly remembered, in fact, deeply cherished by a generation of theatregoers who once were wont to throng the musicals on which the two collaborated as book writer and lyricist.
Once merely a thorn in the side of the established retailer, the "discount house" has grown into a major irritation.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 28 -- Southern Arizona will open Dec. 30 a six-month celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Gadsden Purchase.

CHRISTMAS is being heralded early this year with Santa Claus workshops and festivals of light starting the season with popular Yuletide features. On Wednesday Atlantic City throws the switch on its Christmas Festival of Lights.
LIEUT. GEN. GEORGE P. HAYS speaks highly of Maj Gen. Edward C. Rose And General Rose speaks highly of General Hays.

ONCE again, Moscow's line appears to be shifting, this time from the "soft" approach to the "hard" approach in its relations with the Atlantic powers. What do the Russians really want ? The persistent question which grows ever more urgent will be in the background, if not on the agenda itself, of the Bermuda conference, set for this week between President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Laniel.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 28 -- The State of Florida has embarked on a two-year, $37,000,000 building program for the mentally ill and physically handicapped, and for higher education and penal institutions.

There is a curious mixture of carrots and sticks in the latest flurry of diplomatic moves initiated by Moscow. On the one hand, Andrei Vishinsky practiced a bit of "atom bomb diplomacy" himself at the United Nations by hinting broadly that the Soviet Union is abreast of or ahead of the West in the field of the atomic hydrogen bombs.

Fordham's inability to contain Villanova's Gene Filipski caused the Maroon football team to finish the season in the red yesterday at the Polo Grounds and the Wildcats rolled to a 20-13 triumph over Eddie Danowski's Rams.

GIDE'S self-assigned function was to disturb. He did it through the fervor which he imparted to his lyrical effusions and to his most pathetic stories of love defeated by intellectual analysis or by puritanical restraint. But that sentimentalist was also a comic writer, that belated symbolist was also a satirist.

IN order to keep a symposium from becoming what a participating member recently called an "imposium," it is necessary not only to provide comfortable chairs, agreeable lighting and a well-organized program, but also to have a subject of sufficient significance and magnitude to justify the time thought and attention of both audience and speakers.
MANILA, Nov. 28 -- President-elect Ramon Magsaysay in casting around for the nucleus of a new Government is setting the pattern for a post-election revolution in the purely political sense.

ERICH AUERBACH begins his study of mimesis or the imitation of life in Western literature by examining famous episodes in Homer and the Bible. He concludes by analyzing passages in Virginia Woolf and Proust.

OMAHA, Nov. 28 -- Ernest (Ole) Lindquist, fighting to avoid deportation to his native Sweden, received a hearing this week before P. S. Willmore, inquiry officer of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, who said he would rule at an early date.

Heavy demand for holiday merchandise, particularly in dressy garment styles, is noted by resident buying offices. However, with many manufacturers turning to cruise line production, the supply of such goods is dwindling.
New Department of Traffic regulations, designed to relieve congestion on major mid-Manhattan crosstown streets during rush hours, will go into effect this week.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 28 -- Gov. Louis Munoz Marin said today that he, "as well as a majority of the Puerto Rican people," favored Puerto Rico's continued association with the United States.

But that sentimentalist was also a comic writer, that belated symbolist was also a satirist.

OMAHA, Nov. 28 -- Ernest (Ole) Lindquist, fighting to avoid deportation to his native Sweden, received a hearing this week before P. S. Willmore, inquiry officer of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, who said he would rule at an early date.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 28 -- Gov. Louis Munoz Marin said today that he, "as well as a majority of the Puerto Rican people," favored Puerto Rico's continued association with the United States.

A HISTORICAL novel staged in fourteenth-century Rome, "Bettina Colonna" tells of the time when the Popes abandoned the Eternal City for the more secure Avignon and Rome gained, for awhile, a sort of self-government. The situation, however, was far from satisfactory.

THE best possible invitation to learning is a child's natural curiosity. Parents and teachers who keep alive this desire for intellectual exploration lay a strong foundation for the structure of a soundly built education. This enthusiastic approach to learning can be fostered by welcoming questions and providing satisfying material to answer them.

PARIS -- Twelve hours and thirteen minutes from the head of the runway at Idlewild to the head of the runway at Orly Field, the time it took for Air France's inaugural flight of the extra de luxe Golden Parisian sleeper plane, is not a record for a non-stop run.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- The Disabled American Veterans began distributing this week its 1954 automobile license identification key ring tags to 39,000,000 motorists throughout the nation.

A research institute devoted to gathering material on the history of the Jewish community in this country, and on American Judaism in general, will be opened here next Tuesday. To be known as the American Jewish History Center, it will be at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street.
IN view of the close proximity of Christmas and Channukah, International Records has released a disk, Holiday time, on which Christmas and Channukah music are combined.

CONTAINING two separate memoirs, of two separate journeys made by Colette back into the flowering garden of her childhood world, this little volume is invested with the distillation of experience: gravity, tenderness, delight, a trace of longing, a trace of melancholy and devoted tranquil love.

IT seems to me that the review of Galileo's "Dialogue" by I. Bernard Cohen did not take sufficiently into account the difficulties Galileo faced in writing the book and the mental climate he had to cope with.
CONGRATULATIONS to Messrs. Bleiler and Dikty on this, their paper anniversary! After five years of poring over the excellent and the awful, their taste remains unerring.

THE American Contract Bridge League's last big tournament of the year is under way in Dallas with eight national championships to be decided in the eight days' play which will end next Sunday. It is the first time a national tournament has been held in the Southwest, and Texas patriotism has made the entry list a large one.
I CANNOT help expressing a feeling of injury over so prejudiced and unjust a review as David Donald's of my "Stanton."

HERE it is close to the first of December, and high time to take up again the topic of British plays on Broadway. They are not making any welkins ring. With the exception of last year's "Dial M for Murder," which transforms a grisly crime into after-dinner entertainment, they do not make much impression on Gotham audiences.
Despite all precautions, lawsuits exact a heavy annual toll from advertisers and their agencies. Complainants may be ordinary citizens or representatives of Government bureaus.

ALL that most people remember about wartime labor-management relations is that John L. Lewis called a coal strike and the Army carried Sewell Avery out of his office at Montgomery Ward. In this useful and skillfully compiled book, Joel Seidman fills out the record that contributed to the monumental outpouring of weapons that crushed the Axis.

HARTFORD, Nov. 28 -- Connecticut Democratic leaders are starting to discuss three possibilities for their party's nomination for Governor next year, although none of the three has yet declared his candidacy for the nomination. Nevertheless, all three are known to have privately shown an interest in the nomination.

IF nothing has been done to the grapevines in the garden since the fruit was harvested, they should be pruned and trained, but only after freezing sets in. For when a vine is properly pruned, trained and trellised, it will bear larger crops for upwards of fifty years.

NEW YORK CITY has joined more than four hundred other American communities in employing a chemical breath-testing device against drunken drivers. In the past the police and the courts have found it next to impossible to convict these miscreants on human evidence alone.

Weather, continuing the dominating factor in determining retail sales in New York City, was responsible for a drop last week compared with the like week of 1952. The decline was estimated as high as 8 per cent. It was considerably warmer than normal early in the week -- about 12 degrees -- and rain on Monday and Wednesday hurt selling.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 28 -- Illinois toll roads plans were moving closer to the blueprint stage this week.

IT really isn't difficult to keep a Christmas tree alive for many years after it has fulfilled its traditional purpose indoors. I have done this with our trees for six years and it has added greatly to the family's anticipation of the season. To children it affords an insight into the now legendary old-fashioned Christmas, when yule logs were tugged in through deep snow and father came back from the woods with "The Tree."

WHEN the author of "The Carrot Seed" and "A Hole Is to Dig" writes a new book, people take notice, for Miss Krauss stories are sure successes with young children. In "A Very Special House" she once again interprets for children their own feelings.

CLAUDE BERNARD, an outstanding medical philosopher of the last century, wrote of man's "internal environment" in an oft-quoted passage. He meant that man and other higher organisms are self-contained systems somewhat like electrical kitchen refrigerators, unaffected by most external changes.

AS important a gift as the writer of popular entertainment can have is one that you won't find explained in texts on writing or defined in works of literary criticism. It is the gift of storytelling, a combination of vigor.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 28 -- Construction on a $1,000,000 chemistry building at Mount Holyoke College will begin immediately according to the college's President, Roswell Gray Ham. The new building will replace 61-year-old Shattauck Hall, which has long been inadequate for present needs of the college.

The usual year-end developments were reflected in the stock market last week. Influenced by dividend news and tax selling, price changes although mixed turned stronger. Activity was restricted by the Thanksgiving Day holiday, which reduced trading to four days. Business conditions, although somewhat spotty, were better than had been predicted.

It should not really have been necessary for President Eisenhower to give the assurance, as the climax of the discussion of Puerto Rico's status, that he would recommend to Congress the enactment of an independence law if that was what the Puerto Ricans freely desired.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States has decided to sell by auction or sealed bid the $17,000,000 steel mill owned by Czechoslovakia and stored in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The President and his aides have now received a clear warning from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin that has angered all of them, alarmed most of them and forced them nearer to their inevitable battle with him for the mind and spirit of the Republican party.
Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, got another strike threat off his chest yesterday.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, Nov. 30 -- The Communists today proposed that the Korean peace conference be held at New Delhi starting Dec. 28 with the Soviet Union and four Asian nations sitting in as non-voting participants.

The seventy-ninth year in the life of Sir Winston Churchill has been a memorable one. Posterity will not so much recall the personal things -- the knighthood of the Order of the Garter and the illness that almost struck him down.

Philadelphia's Eagles, billed as the "hottest club in the National Football League," were cooled off by the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. After six straight triumphs, the visitors were upset, 37--28, before a crowd of 20,294.

Efforts to settle the photo-engravers' strike, which had closed six New York newspapers, including The New York Times, appeared to have made progress early today. Publishers and union representatives succeeded in "narrowing the points at issue" in peace talks and strikers were expected to vote today on whether to return to work.

MOUNT SHASTA, Calif., Nov. 29 -- A member of a mountaineering team led by Jon Lindbergh, son of the famed aviator, died today as rescuers climbed to reach him. He had lain critically injured through the night on the icy slopes of the 14,162-foot peak.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- A group of atomic researchers asserted today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigation at the Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar laboratory threatened "the research which supports our national defense."

ZURICH, Switzerland, Monday, Nov. 30 -- Sir Benegal Narsing Rau of India, a judge of the International Court of Justice at The Hague, died of intestinal cancer in a hospital here early today. He was 66 years old.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 29 -- The Stockholm newspaper Expressen published a cable today over the name of Ho Chi Minh offering to discuss a possible armistice for ending the seven-year war in Indo-China.

These are days when it is useful to see the world steadily and see it whole. The results, as in a 1,300-page tome written by W. S. Woytinsky and E. S. Woytinsky and published by the Twentieth Century Fund, are sometimes extraordinary.

The new Department of Air Pollution Control has now been at work for a year, and Commissioner Leonard Greenburg feels that enforcement figures show "tremendous improvement" over like data compiled by the old Bureau of Smoke Control.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States will reassure France at this week's Big Three meeting in Bermuda that it has every intention of keeping its troops in Europe to cooperate with the projected European Army.
JAJCE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 29 -- President Marshal Tito said today he was ready for a mutual withdrawal of Yugoslavia's and Italy's armies from their common frontier north of Trieste.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Felicitations and boos greeted former President Truman here during a busy week-end.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Much of the extraordinarily good feeling toward President Eisenhower among the Democrats that typified the first session of the Eighty-third Congress has disappeared.

In the face of typically cynical opposition from the Soviet representative, the General Assembly has endorsed the work of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees by extending the office for five years and by reelecting the incumbent, Dr. G. J. Van Heuven Goedhart of the Netherlands.
CAIRO, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- The Egyptian Government radio reported tonight that pro-Egyptian candidates had won a clear majority of seats in the Sudan's first House of Representatives.

Walter W. Stewart has been selected by President Eisenhower to be the third member of the reorganized Council of Economic Advisers. Arthur F. Burns of the National Bureau of Economic Research was chosen early last spring.
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. announced yesterday that he would appoint Henry Epstein as Deputy Mayor. Mr. Epstein, former State Solicitor General, has been slated for the post for two weeks.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 5 -- Saudi Arabia's King Saud Ibn Abdul Aziz called today for accelerated economic development at home and more effective military collaboration with the Arab states abroad. The appeal came in his first comprehensive policy statement since taking the throne Nov. 9.

The hearings held before the New York Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission, with a twin commission from New Jersey sitting in, renewed interest in the desirability of seeing the region's mass transportation needs whole, rather than as bits and pieces.

An agreement to lay the first telephone cable across the Atlantic Ocean has been signed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and British and Canadian concerns. Construction will begin as soon as engineering computations are completed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Tax investigators of the House of Representatives proposed today enactment of a law limiting Treasury control of the Internal Revenue Bureau to policy-mak ing. Seeking to end "political meddling," a House Ways and Means subcommittee that has been running down tax scandals for more than two years said it was not enough to have this transfer effected by delegation of authority as the present Administration is doing.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Dec. 3 -- South Korean soldiers who embraced communism while in North Korean prison camps rejected "come home" appeals again today as Allied speculation increased that most of the non-repatriates, including twenty-two Americans, would refuse to come home.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 6 -- It is an unusual conference, not simply because it is the first time since Potsdam of both heads of government and foreign ministers, but because these important personages, more powerful than the Kremlin when they are in concert, are really getting down to cases in this meeting -- the cases being the great issues that divide the world.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- A move by Ho Chi Minh, Vietminh leader, to negotiate an armistice in the war in Indo-China aroused intense interest here today, so general is the desire in France to end the costly fighting.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Nov. 30 (UP) -- Former Gov. Kim Sigler of Michigan and three other persons were killed today when the plane he was piloting hit a television transmitter tower and crashed into a hilly field.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Senate investigators today made public hitherto secret data of the Federal Bureau of Investigation charging that a "Soviet agent" in the office of Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King in 1945 might have given Russia information on this country's proximity fuse.

Negotiations between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., over the union's demand for a $50,000,000 "package" of pay rises and improved working conditions for the authority's 44,000 employes will begin at 10 A. M. today at authority headquarters, 370 Jay Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Rear Admiral William S. Parsons, who assembled in flight the trigger of the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima, died today of a heart attack at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 52 years old.

As the situation stands, the largest obstacle to any sort of agreement on the plans for a political conference on Korea is the question of the role to be assigned to the Soviet Union. The Chinese Communists and the North Koreans have insisted that the Soviet Union be present at the projected conference as a "neutral," presumably without a vote.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 4 -- Allied diplomats outlined today a new United States-British plan aimed to get Italy and Yugoslavia around a five-power conference table for a final settlement of the Trieste dispute.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Henry A. Byroade, Assistant Secretary of State, will leave for Bermuda tomorrow to consult with the British on the possible role of United States oil companies in a solution of the Iranian oil problem.
PRAGUE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 1 -- Yugoslavia probably is not capable of "going it alone" nor does she have this desire, one of Yugoslavia's highest-ranking leaders has declared in an interview.

ATLANTA, Nov. 30 -- Thirteen minor league players, involving an outlay of $132,500, were drafted by major league clubs today as baseball's annual bargain-basement grab bag officially opened the minor convention.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative, told the United Nations General Assembly today that "close to 38,000" prisoners had been massacred or tortured by Chinese Communist and North Korean forces.

Things have begun auspiciously for the new Phoenix Theatre, which opened for business Tuesday evening at Twelfth Street and Second Avenue. Its first play is "Madam, Will You Walk," the last work of Sidney Howard, who died in 1939. After his tragic death it was acted on the road but withdrawn before its scheduled New York opening.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6 -- Iranian opponents of the Government's policy of reconciliation with Britain produced minor incidents today in Teheran's two traditional trouble spots, the

The visit of Vice President Nixon to New Delhi provided an opportunity for a friendly airing of Indian-American differences. Mr. Nixon saw Prime Minister Nehru for a private talk and also addressed both houses of Parliament and radio broadcast. Mr. Nehru gave an on-the-record interview to the American newspapermen accompanying the Vice President.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda Dec. 3 -- Joseph Laniel, Premier on France, and Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, arrived here by plane today after an overnight flight from Paris for the coming Western Big Three talks starting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy summoned his followers today to a pressure campaign intended to force President Eisenhower to reverse himself on the issue of trade with Communist China by this country's allies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the United States would attend a foreign ministers' meeting with the Soviet Union if it promised a discussion of some of the specific, "soluble" problems now confronting the world powers.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill, Britain's link with the golden past and the embodiment of a confident present, began his eightieth year today.
Management and union representatives met again last night in a second attempt to settle the photo-engravers' strike, which has closed six New York newspapers since Saturday morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Department of Justice today denied charges by Democrats that it had refused to assist in a jury-tampering investigation that smashed a crime ring in Denver, Col.

Federal mediators made a new effort yesterday to settle the nine-day photo-engravers' strike by conferring with representatives of other unions whose members have refused to cross the strikers' picket lines. The mediators also continued their daily negotiations with the strikers' committee and a committee representing publishers of the seven closed newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the C. I. O., accused the Eisenhower Administration today of talking instead of taking vigorous action to head off mounting unemployment and a "depression."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Senate investigators developed for the record today that three Treasury officials were kept in their posts, received important assignments and were even promoted despite warnings by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of Communist activity on their part.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Nothing in the Taft-Hartley Labor Law bars the discharge of workers for "disloyalty" to their employers, the Supreme Court ruled today.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The American Medical Association has liberalized its policy on medical ethics to provide more and quicker news to newspapers, magazines, radio and television.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 6 (AP) -- Records made public by the Internal Revenue Service on the sale of gamblers' occupation, tax stamps today would seem to indicate that three areas in the nation were devoid of professional gambling.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition Government introduced today a military conscription bill.

India has lost one of her most distinguished sons in the death of Sir Benegal Rau. More than that, the world has lost one of its really fine judicial minds, a wise counselor, a calm adjudicator, a man who often served as a balance wheel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, denied today that the effect of his "write-to-Ike" campaign was to place the foreign policy leadership of the Eisenhower Administration "on the public auction block."

ATLANTA, Dec. 2 -- A bombshell in major league player-owner relations exploded today with a detonation that just about reduced to a whisper everything else that happened on this third day of the annual minor league convention.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative, told the General Assembly today that the riots inside United Nations prison camps in Korea a year ago were dircted by General Nam Il of North Korea. General Nam Il was simultaneously representing North Korea and Communist China in the armistice talks at Panmunjom.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Tuesday, Dec. 8 -- The governments of the United States, Britain and France asserted in a communique today that the mounting strength of the free world had made the danger of aggression less imminent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower gave his general support today to Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, in the brewing Pentagon controversy over an Army manpower cut.

The Soviet proposal of Berlin as a suitable locale for a Four Power conference appears to be approved in the Western capitals. Mr. Molotov suggested Berlin without any reference to the fact that he was invited to Lugano, and the switch from the sun-washed shores of a Swiss lake to the tense gray city on the Spree encounters no audible objection from the other Foreign Ministers.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 5 -- The Western Big Three powers began drafting a note today in reply to the Soviet Union's suggestion that a four-power foreign ministers' meeting be held in Berlin.
The Long Island Rail Road took the first step yesterday to raise its commutation and other fares from 11.6 to 14.5 per cent, effective Jan 3.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 5 -- Tornadoes smashed tangled paths of death, injury and damage across Mississippi, Louisiana and Arkansas tonight. The toll, still mounting, stood at four dead and many scores injured.
PHILADELPIA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Pope Yeatman, internationally known mining engineer, died today at his home in suburban Chestnut Hill. He was 92.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 7 (AP) -- John J. Meegan, secretary and director of the Buffalo Courier-Express, Inc., collapsed and died the newspaper's executive offices late today. He was 62 years old and had been in ill health for some time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Washington officials attached serious significance as "a new departure," today, to a peace gesture made by Ho Chi Minh, head of the Communist rebel Vietminh government in Indo-China.
HONG KONG, Dec. 5 -- The Peiping Government is determined to find major petroleum deposits in Communist China.

Michael J. Quill is once more talking about a strike on New York City's public-owned transit system. He says he will call a subway strike if "forced to protect the 44,000 employes of the Transit Authority." He adds that "I have that right as an American citizen."

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The Court of Appeals cleared the way today for the proposed merger of the Congregational Christian Churches of the United States and the Evangelical and Reformed Church. The move affects 1,850,000 members of the two churches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- South Carolina, Kansas and Virginia asserted today that racial segregation in the public schools was a states' rights question and the Supreme Court did not have power to declare it unconstitutional under the Fourteenth Amendment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The final battle to outlaw racial segregation in public schools everywhere in the United States began in the Supreme Court today.
MADRID, Nov. 30 -- The Spanish Parliament approved by acclamation today the United States-Spanish military and economic agreements signed Sept. 26.

A new arbitration proposal to settle the four-day photo-engravers' strike was agreed on last night by union and publisher representatives. It will be submitted to a union membership meeting for ratification at 11 o'clock this morning in Roosevelt Auditorium, Fourth Avenue and Seventeenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower saw today "more froth and fury than good sense" in arguments over conservation and control of natural resources.

Representatives of the publishers of six major New York City daily newspapers and of the striking photo-engravers resumed recessed mediation sessions at 9 P. M. yesterday in another effort to end the ten-day-old newspaper strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from an unofficial transcript of that part of today's White House conference that dealt with the issue of "Freedom Versus Communism," including quotations from the President's prepared statement:
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (UP) -- A feud between rival American Federation of Labor and independent maritime unions flared into fist fights on the waterfront here today.

TOKYO, Tuesday Dec., 8 -- Chinese Communist Premier Chouen Lai told the United Nations yesterday the United States Government was "deliberately" delaying negotiations for a political settlement in Korea. He intimated the General Assembly should intervene to break the deadlock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- The shouted epithets "paid perjurers," "stool pigeons," "rigged committee" and "smear" echoed through City Hall today at the closing sessions of the Bay area hearing of the House Un-American Activities Committee.

The hills stand clean and open now, their shapes and outlines obvious, and the winds course the ridges with a minimum of interruption. The leaves lie low, bedding the roots against the cold. The snow will follow the contours of the land, smoothing them, easing their harshness, as the leaves smoothed them only a few months ago.

VIENNA, Dec. 3 -- A Czechoslovak grandfather told today how he and four of his family had shuttled back and forth three times across the Iron Curtain, hidden under a pile of lumber on a freight car, before they finally reached freedom.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The State Civil Service Employes Association asked the state today for pay increases that would cost an estimated $22,000,000 a year.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 6 -- The United States has decided to urge Britain to conclude a seven-year pact with Egypt governing the administration of the Suez Canal base and its gradual turnover to Cairo.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- G. I. victims of Communist atrocities in Korea filed to a Senate witness stand today and swore to experiences that shocked a large audience.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Pope Pius XII said today that any future supranational political community should be distinguished by religious tolerance. He explained that a citizen of any member state should be free to exercise his religious practices and beliefs throughout the community.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- An early meeting of the Big Four foreign ministers now appears a certainty.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The British frigate Flamingo put a midnight boarding party on the sailing vessel Naram Passa in the Arabian Sea Thursday and captured a pirate gang that had seized the ship from her Indian crew.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 4 -- According to the best information available, there is no major policy difference over Iran at the top levels in London and Washington. Both are agreed on the necessity for helping Iran toward stability to check Communist infiltration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Constitution forbids Congress to make any law "abridging the freedom of the press," the heart of which freedom is the right to publish what the management of the press elects to publish, subject only to the penal statutes.

TRENTON, Dec. 7 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today forbade the distribution of the King James version of the New Testament and two books of the Old Testament in the public schools of this state. In a unanimous decision the court ruled that the works in question were sectarian and that their dissemination in public schools would be a violation of both the United States and the New Jersey Constitutions.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 2 -- The Soviet Union's new envoy to Israel made a formal call on Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett in Jerusalem today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The United Nations General Assembly today adopted a resolution expressing "grave concern" over the reported atrocities committed by North Korean and Chinese Communist forces. The resolution contained also a general condemnation of war atrocities by any government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A group seeking to replace the striking United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., as bargaining unit at the Columbus plant of North American Aviation, Inc., says it will file incorporation papers for a new union with the Secretary of State.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 6 -- President Eisenhower will fly to New York Tuesday and address the United Nations General Assembly on the "perils that confront the world in this atomic age."

Violence in the Newark area of the port of New York was the highlight of yesterday's developments in the growing struggle for power between the discredited and the reform elements in the dock labor force.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -- Representative Harold H. Velde charged today that many of our scientific secrets, including the atomic bomb, had been lost to the Soviet Union through the failure of former President Truman and his Cabinet members to prosecute spies.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 2 -- India and the Soviet Union signed a five-year bilateral trade agreement today. The pact came into force immediately.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Tougher administration of the income tax laws to prevent fraud and favoritism was urged today by investigators for the House of Representatives.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The following Big Three conferences communique was issued early today at the end of the meeting of United States, British and French Government leaders:

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- The Working Committee of the ruling Congress party adopted a resolution today strongly condemning the Western powers for what it called their new attempt to consolidate their hold "politically and economically" on many countries in Asia and Africa.

Committees of the city's publishers and photo-engravers met again last night in another futile attempt to settle the five-day strike which has closed all seven major newspapers and thrown 20,000 employes out of work. The meeting was adjourned until this afternoon.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, Dec. 6 -- The United Nations delegation to the preliminary Korean peace conference is prepared to push to its limit this week in an effort to reach agreement but it is now the belief of the delegation that the Communists wish to stall any settlement until the issue can be thrown in the the special session of the United Nations General Assembly in February.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 6 -- The death toll in the tornado-stricken city of Vicksburg climbed to twenty-six today as searchers combined the ruins left by a $25,000,000 twister.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon will inform doubters in the United States that any impression that India is leaning toward Communist ideology is completely erroneous," he assured a gathering of Indian legislators tonight. His statement was cheered.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Eisenhower Administration today proclaimed a fundamental split with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin on the conduct of the nation's foreign policy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- "If we open up a quarrel between the past and the present," Winston Churchill said in 1940, "we shall find that we have lost the future."

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 5 -- Arthur H. Dean, special United States envoy, will meet with Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, in Seoul this morning presumably to iron out differences concerning the Korean political conference.
The photo - engravers' strike against six major New York newspapers entered its second week yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee today subpoenaed WilUam L. Ullman, former Governiment employe nsmed as a onetime member of a Soviet espionage ring, to testiy Wednesday in its investigation of alleged ommu.nist infiitratioi in Governmet
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Treasury officials disclosed today that, for the first time since 1949, Americans were buying more United States Savings Bonds than they were cashing in.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- The Soviet Union's omnibus "peace plan," consisting of proposals that have been rejected decisively by the United Nations General Assembly in recent years, again was rejected today.
Sullen longshoremen immobilized 75 per cent of the port's waterfront yesterday in what appeared to be a double gesture of defiance.
Negotiations were still deadlocked last night in the six-day photo-engravers' strike. The city's seven major newspapers remained closed. Twenty thousand employes were still out of work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to pass on the constitutionality of a section of New York's banking law that prohibits national banks from soliciting or receiving savings deposits.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 7 -- Two Teheran University students were shot and killed and another wounded today by Iranian soldiers who fired into an anti-British demonstration on the university campus.
Former President Harry S. Truman declared last night that the United States had the responsibility of promoting peace between the Arab states and Israel.

As President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Laniel prepare for their Big Three meeting in Bermuda it becomes clear that, barring new Soviet maneuvers, this meeting will be followed in the near future by a Big Four Foreign Ministers' conference with Soviet Russia.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A can shortage faced the citrus industry today as the result of a strike against the nation's two largest can manufacturers. No settlement is in sight.

It might possibly be raised also in the Armistice Commission in Korea whose presumptive function is to see that the terms of the agreement are carried out.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Britain suggested today that the International Court of Justice at the Hague be asked to rule on the legalities of indemnities awarded to eleven United States citizens dismissed by the United Nations for refusing to answer questions about alleged subversive activities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee agreed late today to interview Igor Gouzenko on the terms of secrecy and censorship imposed by Canada.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- When the Supreme Court last spring submitted a series of questions to the lawyers in the school segregation cases its purpose was to be furnished with every conceivable legal and factual argument on both sides of an issue so profound as to merit the most exhaustive research. But another effect was to put the attorneys on their mettle.

Having signed Alexander Borodin as composer, the manufacturers of "Kismet," which opened at the Ziegfeld Thursday evening, have quite a deep reservoir of music to draw on. Derived from nine-teenth-century Russia, it is good music for turbulent dances and wild choruses; and some of it presumably has been freely adapted into songs suitable for a conventional operetta.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Dec. 3 (UP) -- University of Iowa scientists said today that the first child ever conceived by insemination with deep frozen male sperm cells should be delivered in less than three months.

The Big Three of the West -- President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Laniel -- meet in Bermuda today for a five-day conference at which they will review the international situation and seek to concert the policies of their countries in meeting the threat of Communist aggression.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower today took personal charge of his Administration's counter-attack on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 7 -- An American sculptor, Alexander Calder, inventor of "mobiles," and Pablo Picasso are the two artists who have rooms of honor at the second biennial International Exhibition of Modern Art of Sao Paulo Museum, which will have a preview for artists, architects and critics tomorrow night.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Notre Dame closed its first unbeaten season in four years today by battering Southern Methodist, 40-14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged today that Brig. Gen. Telford Taylor, who criticized him recently in a speech at the United States Military Academy, had left the Government last year with an "unresolved question of loyalty" showing on his Civil Service record.

Now that Igor Gouzenko, the Soviet code clerk who broke the Canadian espionage case, has indicated his refusal to testify before the United States Senate subcommittee, the case ought certainly to be considered closed. It has done enough damage to Canadian-American relations and it never offered any real hope of new revelations.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Undisturbed by reports that United States hesitancy about a meeting with the Soviet Union seemed to be growing, Prime Minister Churchill departed for the Bermuda conference by plane tonight intent on arranging a conference with the Soviet Union and uniting Allied policies in Asia and Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, said today he thought there was a chance that the Senate would vote revisions of the Taft-Hartley Law based on President Eisenhower's recommendations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- The United States challenged the Soviet world today to accept an on-the-spot investigation to confirm or disprove charges of Communist atrocities in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A labor dispute defying solution "by the most expert mediators" is heading toward a Christmas Eve dock strike for ports along the Atlantic seaboard from Hampton Roads to Maine. A Presidential Board of Inquiry sent this warning to the White House today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower remained cool today toward a Big Four foreign ministers' meeting, but in official quarters the United States, Britain and France were expected to lay the basis in Bermuda for a discussion of the world's troubles with the Soviet Union. The President will leave for Bermuda at 8 A. M. Friday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, today discounted the Army's objections to a 10 per cent manpower cut.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Val R. Lorwin, former State Department economist, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today for falsely denying membership in the Communist party. He is now a member of the faculty of the University of Chicago.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 4 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Eden were accompanied by Premier Laniel and Foreign Minister Bidault of France when they greeted President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles at the airport on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board was asked by one of its members today to decide whether the Labor Youth League might file a brief against "McCarthyism."

The Board of Estimate has reduced the City Planning Commission's proposed 1954 capital budget by $25,400,217 and adopted a schedule of $510,966,795 for construction and equipment-purchase improvements for next year. This is a budget higher by $78,686,802 than the present year's.
TORONTO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Igor Gouzenko in an article copyrighted by The Toronto Telegram said today he had decided not to be interviewed by the United States Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Undersecretary of the Interior, Ralph A. Tudor, today defended new policies regulating the sale of public power in the Missouri River Basin. He added that they would not necessarily set a nationwide pattern.
PANMUNJOM, Korea Wednesday, Dec. 2 -- The Allies were rebuffed today in talks to woo back home prisoners who have embraced communism.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 5 -- Thomas E. Murray, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said tonight that the Soviet Union's development of a hydrogen bomb made it necessary for this nation's officials to be acquainted with "the atomic facts of life."

ATLANTA, Dec. 1 -- As the minor league convention moved into the second session of player-drafting, the Dodgers decided that today was as good a time as any in which formally to introduce their recently signed new manager, Walter Alston, to all and sundry.

Confronted with an open attack on his Administration and his foreign policy by Senator McCarthy, President Eisenhower has thrown the weight of his office and his prestige into the scales to preserve the unity of the anti-Communist front within the free world and the cohesion of the Republican party, on which depends the success of his policies.

The New York Telephone Company asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for permission to increase rates 75 cents a month for most home phones. It asked also for a $2-a-month rise for most business phones.

Mayor-Elect Wagner continues to make good appointments, and Henry Epstein to be Deputy Mayor is one of the best, a first-class man for a key post in the new administration. Educated in the public schools here, a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School, Mr. Epstein served for a decade as Solicitor General under Governor Lehman and was the Democratic candidate for Attorney General in 1942.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The State Department has asked Canada to make arrangements for the questioning of Igor Gouzenko by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The United States' insistence that Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, be consulted at every step in the proposed Western foreign ministers' meeting with Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, has excited strong opposition in both official and unofficial quarters here.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 30 -- The opinion that the Communists are deliberately stalling at the conference going on here to arrange a Korean peace parley gained strength today with the introduction of a new "over-all" proposal by the Reds.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 4 -- John V. Kenny said today he would resign on Jan. 1 from the post of Mayor which he wrested from the Frank Hague Democratic organization in 1949 and retained in a test last May.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 4 -- The Western Big Three began their long-awaited conference here this afternoon with a general review of the world situation and agreed on an agenda for talks through the week-end.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., will take "prompt and appropriate action" against seven private bus lines if they fail today to meet retroactive wage payments, Michael J. Quill, T. W. U. president, told the companies late yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The difference over foreign policy between the President and Secretary of State Dulles on the one hand and Senator McCarthy on the other has now been neatly packaged. The Senator believes the United States should use coercion on nations associated with it against world Bolshevism that do not see eye to eye with us on certain major courses, and he believes this coercion would inevitably bring them into line.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Navy is bolstering its defenses against the threat of Russia's growing submarine strength by converting ten big World War II carriers to deal with the undersea craft.

The shape-up, long held to be a major source of waterfront corruption, gives way today to employment information centers. This is the day the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission takes full charge over the registering, licensing and hiring of pier workers in the New York port area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Telegrams for and against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in his attack on Administration foreign policy continued to roll into the White House today, and the latest tabulation indicated a lead of better than 2 to 1 in his favor.
Former President Truman curtailed his usual early morning walk yesterday to get his news first hand in the headquarters of The Associated Press at 50 Rockefeller Plaza.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 7 -- This tornado-blasted city today began to bury its dead as it continued to search for others believed covered by the ruins of the smashed business district.

Milt Gross, cartoonist and author, famous for his "Nize Baby" and Dunt Esk" stories and drawings and for his accounts of such characters as "Looey dot dope" and "Mrs. Feitlebaum," died Saturday aboard the trans-Pacific liner Lurline on his way home from a vacation in Hawaii.

The Communist counter-proposals in the peace conference negotiation at Panmunjom appear to accept, at least in principle, the United Nations position that "neutrals" at such a conference should appear in an observer capacity only.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower came up today with a political change of pace.
HONG KONG, Dec. 4 -- Peiping has fixed stringent new terms for foreign capitalist concerns wishing to trade with Red China.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 4 -- Allied and Communist negotiators trying to plan a Korean political conference met again at Panmunjom this morning, with each side charging the other with stalling the preliminary talks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The White House announced today it had received 19,517 telegrams in response to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's request for public support to halt United States aid to Allies that trade with Communist China.

It is gratifying to be able to note a new modern low in the traffic death rate for the nation as reported by the National Safety Council for the year 1952. The rate for each 100,000,000 miles of motor vehicle travel was 7.3 deaths. This is the fifth time in seven years that highway fatality rates have reached a new low-water mark.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy accused the White House tonight of making after his appeal to his supporters tion of telegrams it had received a "grievous mistake" in its tabulato let President Eisenhower known how they feel about "blood trade" with Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Through a second day of horror testimony of Communist atrocities in Korea, more former United States prisoners of war swore to a Senate inquiry today to details of shootings in the back, murders of wounded and other stark brutalities by Communists.
The Presidential board of inquiry into the complex waterfront labor dispute will resume hearings today in an atmosphere of mounting confusion.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 5 (AP) -- After a seven-hour deluge of telephone calls, The Toledo Blade cut off its switchboard at midnight last night and sent home forty exhausted men and women who had been trying to keep up with the overwhelming response to a "phone your letter" suggestion made on the front page of yesterday's paper.
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. announced yesterday that Peter Campbell Brown former chairman of the Congressional Subversive Activities Control Board, would be his Commissioner of Investigation.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 5 -- Iran and Britain announced today a decision to resume diplomatic relations as the first step toward ending the long dispute that began in April, 1951, with nationalization of British-owned oil properties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield gave Santa Claus an official home in the United States today -- a "North Pole" postal station will be established in New York State on Dec. 16, nine days before Christmas.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6 -- The New Jersey Congress of Industrial Organizations urged Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner today "to sweep out the maladministrators, the misfits and the political malingerers from offices under his jurisdiction," following his inauguration on Jan. 19.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- Robert T. Lansdale has resigned as State Commissioner of Social Welfare, effective Dec. 6, for reasons of ill health. He has headed the State's welfare activities since June, 1943. He has been ill since the spring of 1952.
The photo-engravers' strike shut down another newspaper yesterday, the seventh day of the strike and the eighth paper to suspend publication.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A plan to make careers in the armed services more attractive by higher pay, increased emphasis on rank, discipline and officer authority was made public today by the Defense Department.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 1 -- The first formal demonstration of motion picture projection on television sets by means of magnetic tape was made here today. The demonstration was attended by top executives and technicians of the television and motion-picture industries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Soon after noon tomorrow, the Supreme Court will take on what is considered the most far-reaching and explosive issue of the present term. It is the question of whether the United States Constitution permits state and local public school authorities to segregate white and Negro pupils.

The city's basic real estate tax for the second half of this fiscal year, the period from Jan. 1 through June 30, 1954, will be $3.60 for each $100 of assessed valuation. The new rate, highest by far in the city's history, was set yesterday when the City Council added 27 cents to the $3.33 rate it fixed last June 23 for 1953-54.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 7 -- Chinese Communist Premier Chou En-lai has condemned "in the strongest possible terms" the resolution adopted last week by the United Nations General Assembly expressing grave concern at reported Communist atrocities during the Korean war.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Wesley A. Gilman, president of the advertising concern of Lewis Gilman, Inc., was found dead of a heart attack yesterday during a hunting trip at the Darlington Valley Gun Club, near Malvern, Chester County.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 28 -- Defying Chinese Communist occupation authorities, the Dalai Lama of Tibet has refused to fly the Red flag of Mao Tse-tung over the sacred Potala Palace in Lhasa.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- A twenty-four hour token strike called by the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions in support of its claim for a 15 per cent wage increase shut down or seriously impeded the work of thousands of British factories and shipyards today.

Two Navy fliers were rescued at 8:02 A. M. yesterday after bobbing twelve hours in a rubber life raft on Long Island Sound in fog and near freezing temperatures. Navy spokesmen credited a new type exposure suit with saving their lives.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Eisenhower Administration apparently is ready to make a change in its electric power policy for the Missouri River Basin as a result of increasing protests from farm groups.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The French Government issued a statement tonight leaving the door open to peace negotiations with Ho Chi Minh, Communist leader of the rebels in Indo-China, who indicated in an interview last week that he was willing to talk peace.
ROME, Dec. 5 -- Yugoslavia and Italy agreed today to withdraw troops from the borders of disputed Trieste. Official Italian sources said tonight that the withdrawal had begun.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- United Nations delegates voted today to call for efforts to evacuate all Nationalist Chinese troops of Chiang Kai-shek remaining on Burmese soil.

Eugene O'Neill, dying at the age of 65, still seemed to many of us a young man, although a distressing illness made it impossible for him to write during his later years. The final plays he did do that reached the stage -- notably, "The Iceman Cometh" -- had tremendous vigor and a depth of perception that had developed with the years.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 4 -- India's five-year trade pact with the Soviet Union, signed while Vice President Richard M. Nixon was in New Delhi on a goodwill mission for the United States, is being described in official circles as a reaffirmation of this country's middle position between opposed power blocs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- United States diplomats were heartened today by developments in two of the world's most critical trouble spots.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns, relaxed after clinching the Eastern Division championship a week ago, breezed to their eleventh straight National Football League victory today by smothering their arch-enemies, the New York Giants, 62 -- 14.

In Washington some 1,400 conservationists, businessmen, public officials and others have been meeting to discuss the future of our country's natural resources. The conference, supported by a grant from the Ford Foundation, considered one of the most fundamental of American domestic problems. On its ultimate solution our prospects as a rising or declining society might well depend.
LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga., Dec. 6 -- Four Air National Guard Thunderjet F-84 plans, making a weekend instrument flight, crashed near this community last night. The four pilots were killed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Over Soviet bloc opposition, the United Nations General Assembly voted 40 to 5 today to recommend a full airing in 1954 of a report that finds forced labor is practiced in Iron Curtain countries for political coercion and economic ends.
HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 30 -- The Vietnamese greeted with hostility the report of Ho Chi Minh's offer to negotiate.
The Board of Estimate unanimously adopted yesterday a 1954 capital budget of $510,966,795.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Undisturbed by reports that United States hesitancy about a meeting with the Soviet Union seemed to be growing, Prime Minister Churchill departed for the Bermuda conference by plane tonight intent on arranging a conference with the Soviet Union and uniting Allied policies in Asia and Europe.

An agreement to lay the first telephone cable across the Atlantic Ocean has been signed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and British and Canadian concerns. Construction will begin as soon as engineering computations are completed.
PANMUNJOM, Korea Wednesday, Dec. 2 -- The Allies were rebuffed today in talks to woo back home prisoners who have embraced communism.

A new arbitration proposal to settle the four-day photo-engravers' strike was agreed on last night by union and publisher representatives. It will be submitted to a union membership meeting for ratification at 11 o'clock this morning in Roosevelt Auditorium, Fourth Avenue and Seventeenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Senate investigators today made public hitherto secret data of the Federal Bureau of Investigation charging that a "Soviet agent" in the office of Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King in 1945 might have given Russia information on this country's proximity fuse.

As President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Laniel prepare for their Big Three meeting in Bermuda it becomes clear that, barring new Soviet maneuvers, this meeting will be followed in the near future by a Big Four Foreign Ministers' conference with Soviet Russia.
Sullen longshoremen immobilized 75 per cent of the port's waterfront yesterday in what appeared to be a double gesture of defiance.

The Soviet proposal of Berlin as a suitable locale for a Four Power conference appears to be approved in the Western capitals. Mr. Molotov suggested Berlin without any reference to the fact that he was invited to Lugano, and the switch from the sun-washed shores of a Swiss lake to the tense gray city on the Spree encounters no audible objection from the other Foreign Ministers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Washington officials attached serious significance as "a new departure," today, to a peace gesture made by Ho Chi Minh, head of the Communist rebel Vietminh government in Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Eisenhower Administration today proclaimed a fundamental split with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin on the conduct of the nation's foreign policy.

ATLANTA, Dec. 1 -- As the minor league convention moved into the second session of player-drafting, the Dodgers decided that today was as good a time as any in which formally to introduce their recently signed new manager, Walter Alston, to all and sundry.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 28 -- Defying Chinese Communist occupation authorities, the Dalai Lama of Tibet has refused to fly the Red flag of Mao Tse-tung over the sacred Potala Palace in Lhasa.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- The United States challenged the Soviet world today to accept an on-the-spot investigation to confirm or disprove charges of Communist atrocities in the Korean war.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 1 -- The first formal demonstration of motion picture projection on television sets by means of magnetic tape was made here today. The demonstration was attended by top executives and technicians of the television and motion-picture industries.

Now that Igor Gouzenko, the Soviet code clerk who broke the Canadian espionage case, has indicated his refusal to testify before the United States Senate subcommittee, the case ought certainly to be considered closed. It has done enough damage to Canadian-American relations and it never offered any real hope of new revelations.

The city's basic real estate tax for the second half of this fiscal year, the period from Jan. 1 through June 30, 1954, will be $3.60 for each $100 of assessed valuation. The new rate, highest by far in the city's history, was set yesterday when the City Council added 27 cents to the $3.33 rate it fixed last June 23 for 1953-54.

Things have begun auspiciously for the new Phoenix Theatre, which opened for business Tuesday evening at Twelfth Street and Second Avenue. Its first play is "Madam, Will You Walk," the last work of Sidney Howard, who died in 1939.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, today discounted the Army's objections to a 10 per cent manpower cut.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the United States would attend a foreign ministers meeting with the Soviet Union if it promised a discussion of some of the specific, "soluble" problems now confronting the world powers.
PRAGUE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 1 -- Yugoslavia probably is not capable of "going it alone" nor does she have this desire, one of Yugoslavia's highest-ranking leaders has declared in an interview.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield gave Santa Claus an official home in the United States today -- a "North Pole" postal station will be established in New York State on Dec. 16, nine days before Christmas.
Former President Truman curtailed his usual early morning walk yesterday to get his news first hand in the headquarters of The Associated Press at 50 Rockefeller Plaza.
The Presidential board of inquiry into the complex waterfront labor dispute will resume hearings today in an atmosphere of mounting confusion.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower gave his general support today to Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, in the brewing Pentagon controversy over an Army manpower cut.

ATLANTA, Dec. 2 -- A bombshell in major league player-owner relations exploded today with a detonation that just about reduced to a whisper everything else that happened on this third day of the annual minor league convention.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The French Government issued a statement tonight leaving the door open to peace negotiations with Ho Chi Minh, Communist leader of the rebels in Indo-China, who indicated in an interview last week that he was willing to talk peace.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 2 -- The Soviet Union's new envoy to Israel made a formal call on Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett in Jerusalem today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower came up today with a political change of pace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower remained cool today toward a Big Four foreign ministers' meeting, but in official quarters the United States, Britain and France were expected to lay the basis in Bermuda for a discussion of the world's troubles with the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- A twenty-four hour token strike called by the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions in support of its claim for a 15 per cent wage increase shut down or seriously impeded the work of thousands of British factories and shipyards today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative, told the General Assembly today that the riots inside United Nations prison camps in Korea a year ago were dircted by General Nam Il of North Korea. General Nam Il was simultaneously representing North Korea and Communist China in the armistice talks at Panmunjom.
