The Senator believes the United States should use coercion on nations associated with it against world Bolshevism that do not see eye to eye with us on certain major courses, and he believes this coercion would inevitably bring them into line.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee agreed late today to interview Igor Gouzenko on the terms of secrecy and censorship imposed by Canada.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower saw today "more froth and fury than good sense" in arguments over conservation and control of natural resources.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower today took personal charge of his Administration's counter-attack on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin.

Mayor-Elect Wagner continues to make good appointments, and Henry Epstein to be Deputy Mayor is one of the best, a first-class man for a key post in the new administration. Educated in the public schools here, a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School, Mr. Epstein served for a decade as Solicitor General under Governor Lehman and was the Democratic candidate for Attorney General in 1942.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Department of Justice today denied charges by Democrats that it had refused to assist in a jury-tampering investigation that smashed a crime ring in Denver, Col.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- G. I. victims of Communist atrocities in Korea filed to a Senate witness stand today and swore to experiences that shocked a large audience.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Dec. 3 -- South Korean soldiers who embraced communism while in North Korean prison camps rejected "come home" appeals again today as Allied speculation increased that most of the non-repatriates, including twenty-two Americans, would refuse to come home.

Committees of the city's publishers and photo-engravers met again last night in another futile attempt to settle the five-day strike which has closed all seven major newspapers and thrown 20,000 employes out of work. The meeting was adjourned until this afternoon.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 2 -- India and the Soviet Union signed a five-year bilateral trade agreement today. The pact came into force immediately.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Senate investigators developed for the record today that three Treasury officials were kept in their posts, received important assignments and were even promoted despite warnings by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of Communist activity on their part.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Dec. 3 (UP) -- University of Iowa scientists said today that the first child ever conceived by insemination with deep frozen male sperm cells should be delivered in less than three months.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A can shortage faced the citrus industry today as the result of a strike against the nation's two largest can manufacturers. No settlement is in sight.

Having signed Alexander Borodin as composer, the manufacturers of "Kismet," which opened at the Ziegfeld Thursday evening, have quite a deep reservoir of music to draw on. Derived from nineteenth-century Russia, it is good music for turbulent dances and wild choruses; and some of it presumably has been freely adapted into songs suitable for a conventional operetta.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy summoned his followers today to a pressure campaign intended to force President Eisenhower to reverse himself on the issue of trade with Communist China by this country's allies.

VIENNA, Dec. 3 -- A Czechoslovak grandfather told today how he and four of his family had shuttled back and forth three times across the Iron Curtain, hidden under a pile of lumber on a freight car, before they finally reached freedom.

Violence in the Newark area of the port of New York was the highlight of yesterday's developments in the growing struggle for power between the discredited and the reform elements in the dock labor force.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Constitution forbids Congress to make any law "abridging the freedom of the press," the heart of which freedom is the right to publish what the management of the press elects to publish, subject only to the penal statutes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The United Nations General Assembly today adopted a resolution expressing "grave concern" over the reported atrocities committed by North Korean and Chi-lution contained also a general nese Communist forces.
Former President Harry S. Truman declared last night that the United States had the responsibility of promoting peace between the Arab states and Israel.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon will inform doubters in the United States that any impression that India is leaning toward Communist ideology is completely erroneous," he assured a gathering of Indian legislators tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Henry A. Byroade, Assistant Secretary of State, will leave for Bermuda tomorrow to consult with the British on the possible role of United States oil companies in a solution of the Iranian oil problem.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The Court of Appeals cleared the way today for the proposed merger of the Congregational Christian Churches of the United States and the Evangelical and Reformed Church. The move affects 1,850,000 members of the two churches.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda Dec. 3 -- Joseph Laniel, Premier of France, and Georges Bidault French Foreign Minister, arrived here by plane today after an overnight flight from Paris for the coming Western Big Three talks starting tomorrow.

The Long Island Rail Road took the first step yesterday to raise its commutation and other fares from 11.6 to 14.5 per cent, effective Jan. 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- The shouted epithets "paid perjurers," "stool pigeons," "rigged committee" and "smear" echoed through City Hall today at the closing sessions of the Bay area hearing of the House Un-American Activities Committee.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Notre Dame closed its first unbeaten season in four years today by battering Southern Methodist, 40-14.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 5 -- Thomas E. Murray, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said tonight that the Soviet Union's development of a hydrogen bomb made it necessary for this nation's officials to be acquainted with "the atomic facts of life."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Britain suggested today that the International Court of Justice at the Hague be asked to rule on the legalities of indemnities awarded to eleven United States citizens dismissed by the United Nations for refusing to answer questions about alleged subversive activities.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 5 (AP) -- After a seven-hour deluge of telephone calls, The Toledo Blade cut off its switchboard at midnight last night and sent home forty exhausted men and women who had been trying to keep up with the overwhelming response to a "phone your letter" suggestion made on the front page of yesterday's paper.
The photo - engravers' strike against six major New York newspapers entered its second week yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Telegrams for and against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in his attack on Administration foreign policy continued to roll into the White House today, and the latest tabulation indicated a lead of better than 2 to 1 in his favor.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, Dec. 6 -- The United Nations delegation to the preliminary Korean peace conference is prepared to push to its limit this week in an effort to reach agreement but it is now the belief of the delegation that the Communists wish to stall any settlement until the issue can be thrown in the the special session of the United Nations General Assembly in February.

In Washington some 1,400 conservationists, businessmen, public officials and others have been meeting to discuss the future of our country's natural resources. The conference, supported by a grant from the Ford Foundation, considered one of the most fundamental of American domestic problems.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 5 -- The Western Big Three powers began drafting a note today in reply to the Soviet Union's suggestion that a four-power foreign ministers' meeting be held in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A labor dispute defying solution "by the most expert mediators" is heading toward a Christmas Eve dock strike for ports along the Atlantic seaboard from Hampton Roads to Maine. A Presidential Board of Inquiry sent this warning to the White House today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged today that Brig. Gen. Telford Taylor, who criticized him recently in a speech at the United States Military Academy, had left the Government last year with an "unresolved question of loyalty" showing on his Civil Service record.
ROME, Dec. 5 -- Yugoslavia and Italy agreed today to withdraw troops from the borders of disputed Trieste. Official Italian sources said tonight that the withdrawal had begun.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 5 -- Saudi Arabia's King Saud Ibn Abdul Aziz called today for accellerated economic development at home and more effective military collaboration with the Arab states abroad. The appeal came in his first comprehensive policy statement since taking the throne Nov. 9.

It is gratifying to be able to note a new modern low in the traffic death rate for the nation as reported by the National Safety Council for the year 1952. The rate for each 100,000,000 miles of motor vehicle travel was 7.3 deaths. This is the fifth time in seven years that highway fatality rates have reached a new low-water mark.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 5 -- Tornadoes smashed tangled paths of death, injury and damage across Mississippi, Louisiana and Arkansas tonight. The toll, still mounting, stood at tour dead and many scores injured.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 5 -- Iran and Britain announced today a decision to resume diplomatic relations as the first step toward ending the long dispute that began in April, 1951, with nationalization of British-owned oil properties.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Wesley A. Gilman, president of the advertising concern of Lewis Gilman, Inc., was found dead of a heart attack yesterday during a hunting trip at the Darlington Valley Gun Club, near Malvern, Chester County.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 6 -- The death toll in the tornado-stricken city of Vicksburg climbed to twenty-six today as searchers combined the ruins left by a $25,000,000 twister.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the C. I. O., accused the Eisenhower Administration today of talking instead of taking vigorous action to head off mounting unemployment and a "depression."

WASHINGTON, Dec., 6 (AP) -- Records made public by the Internal Revenue Service on the sale of gamblers' occupation. tax stamps today would seem to indicate that three areas in the nation were devoid of professional gambling.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 7 -- Chinese Communist Premier Chou En-lai has condemned "in the strongest possible terms" the resolution adopted last week by the United Nations General Assembly expressing grave concern at reported Communist atrocities during the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, said today he thought there was a chance that the Senate would vote revisions of the Taft-Hartley Law based on President Eisenhower's recommendations. The President's proposals are due soon after the first of the year.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6 -- Iranian opponents of the Government's policy of reconciliation with Britain produced minor incidents today in Teheran's two traditional trouble spots, the university and the bazaar.

Federal mediators made a new effort yesterday to settle the nine-day photo-engravers' strike by conferring with representatives of other unions whose members have refused to cross the strikers' picket lines. The mediators also continued their daily negotiations with the strikers' committee and a committee representing publishers of the seven closed newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, denied today that the effect of his "write-to-Ike" campaign was to place the foreign policy leadership of the Eisenhower Administration "on the public auction block."

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 6 -- The United States has decided to urge Britain to conclude a seven-year pact with Egypt governing the administration of the Suez Canal base and its gradual turnover to Cairo.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The British frigate Flamingo put a midnight boarding party on the sailing vessel Naram Passa in the Arabian Sea Thursday and captured a pirate gang that had seized the ship from her Indian crew.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Soon after noon tomorrow, the Supreme Court will take on what is considered the most far-reaching and explosive issue of the present term. It is the question of whether the United States Constitution permits state and local public school authorities to segregate white and Negro pupils.

Negotiations between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., over the union's demand for a $50,000,000 "package" of pay rises and improved working conditions for the authority's 44,000 employes will begin at 10 A. M. today at authority headquarters, 370 Jay Street, Brooklyn.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6 -- The New Jersey Congress of Industrial Organizations urged Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner today "to sweep out the maladministrators, the misfits and the political malingerers from offices under his jurisdiction," following his inauguration on Jan. 19.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Tougher administration of the income tax laws to prevent fraud and favoritism was urged today by investigators for the House of Representatives.

The hearings held before the New York Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission, with a twin commission from New Jersey sitting in, renewed interest in the desirability of seeing the region's mass transportation needs whole, rather than as bits and pieces.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 6 -- President Eisenhower will fly to New York Tuesday and address the United Nations General Assembly on the "perils that confront the world in this atomic age."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Eisenhower Administration apparently is ready to make a change in its electric power policy for the Missouri River Basin as a result of increasing protests from farm groups.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- The Working Committee of the ruling Congress party adopted a resolution today strongly condemning the Western powers for what it called their new attempt to consolidate their hold "politically and economically" on many countries in Asia and Africa.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Pope Yeatman, internationally known mining engineer, died today at his home in suburban Chestnut Hill. He was 92.
LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga., Dec. 6 -- Four Air National Guard Thunderjet F-84 plans, making a weekend instrument flight, crashed near this community last night. The four pilots were killed.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 6 -- It is an unusual conference, not simply because it is the first time since Potsdam of both heads of government and foreign ministers, but because these important personages, more powerful than the Kremlin when they are in concert, are really getting down to cases in this meeting -- the cases being the great issues that divide the world.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns, relaxed after clinching the Eastern Division championship a week ago, breezed to their eleventh straight National Football League victory today by smothering their arch-enemies, the New York Giants, 62 -- 14.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Over Soviet bloc opposition, the United Nations General Assembly voted 40 to 5 today to recommend a full airing in 1954 of a report that finds forced labor is practiced in Iron Curtain countries for political coercion and economic ends. Twelve states abstained on the vote.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Navy is bolstering its defenses against the threat of Russia's growing submarine strength by converting ten big World War II carriers to deal with the undersea craft.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Pope Pius XII said today that any future supranational political community should be distinguished by religious tolerance. He explained that a citizen of any member state should be free to exercise his religious practices and beliefs throughout the community.

TOKYO, Tuesday Dec., 8 -- Chinese Communist Premier Chouen Lai told the United Nations yesterday the United States Government was "deliberately" delaying negotiations for a political settlement in Korea. He intimated the General Assembly should intervene to break the deadlock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Nothing in the Taft-Hartley Labor Law bars the discharge of workers for "disloyalty" to their employers, the Supreme Court ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Undersecretary of the Interior, Ralph A. Tudor, today defended new policies regulating the sale of public power in the Missouri River Basin. He added that they would not necessarily set a nationwide pattern.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Tuesday, Dec. 8 -- The governments of the United States, Britain and France asserted in a communique today that the mounting strength of the free world had made the danger of aggression less imminent.

In spite of the fact that the Korean armistice terms are plain on the point, it is possible that the issue of the ultimate disposition of reluctant prisoners might be reopened in the United Nations. It might possibly be raised also in the Armistice Commission in Korea whose presumptive function is to see that the terms of the agreement are carried out.

TRENTON, Dec. 7 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today forbade the distribution of the King James version of the New Testament and two books of the Old Testament in the public schools of this state. In a unanimous decision the court ruled that the works in question were sectarian and that their dissemination in public schools would be a violation of both the United States and the New Jersey Constitutions.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 7 -- This tornado-blasted city today began to bury its dead as it continued to search for others believed covered by the ruins of the smashed business district.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The final battle to outlaw racial segregation in public schools everywhere in the United States began in the Supreme Court today.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The following Big Three conference communique was issued early today at the end of the meeting of United States, British and French Government leaders:

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 7 (AP) -- John J. Meegan, secretary and director of the Buffalo Courier-Express, Inc., collapsed and died in the newspaper's executive offices late today. He was 62 years old and had been in ill health for some time.

The visit of Vice President Nixon to New Delhi provided an opportunity for a friendly airing of Indian-American differences. Mr. Nixon saw Prime Minister Nehru for a private talk and also addressed both houses of Parliament and made a radio broadcast.

Representatives of the publishers of six major New York City daily newspapers and of the striking photo-engravers resumed recessed mediation sessions at 9 P. M. yesterday in another effort to end the ten-day-old newspaper strike.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 7 -- An American sculptor, Alexander Calder, inventor of "mobiles," and Pablo Picasso are the two artists who have rooms of honor at the second biennial International Exhibition of Modern Art of Sao Paulo Museum, which will have a preview for artists, architects and critics tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to pass on the constitutionality of a section of New York's banking law that prohibits national banks from soliciting or receiving savings deposits.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The United States' insistence that Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, be consulted at every step in the proposed Western foreign ministers' meeting with Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, has excited strong opposition in both official and unofficial quarters here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The White House announced today it had received 19,517 telegrams in response to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's request for public support to halt United States aid to Allies that trade with Communist China.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 7 -- Two Teheran University students were shot and killed and another wounded today by Iranian soldiers who fired into an anti-British demonstration on the university campus.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 8 -- Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner suggested here tonight creation of a Rural Advisory Commission to help him fix long-range objectives. Mr. Meyner, who will take office on Jan. 19, addressed a joint meeting of the New Jersey State Grange and the New Jersey Horticultural Society.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill said here tonight that the Big Three conference just ended had been "of great value."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- An echo of the not too distant days of price controls was in the background of a report issued today by the National Canners Association.

Almost six months have passed since the last major wave of purges in the Soviet Union -- the wave of which Lavrenti P. Beria was the most prominent victim. Now the purge has found a new and important victim, V. M. Andrianov, who has just been removed after long service as Communist party boss of Leningrad Province.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 8 -- With the question of military aid to Pakistan, Washington faces a crossroads in its policy toward the Middle East and South Asia, particularly India.

Not even the linen closet is safe from the "do-it-yourself" enthusiasts, it appears from the entries in the second sewing contest just held by Lever Brothers Company and the Pfaff Sewing Machine Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The White House announced late today that it had received 25,033 telegrams and "about as many letters" in response to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's write-and-wire appeal to his followers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy set his sights today on a perjury indictment as he opened public hearings in his investigation of happenings at Fort Monmouth, N. J.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 8 -- The Western Big Three and their retinues start quitting Bermuda today and handclutching honeymooners began to resume their rightful place on this idyllic isle.

HONG KONG, Dec. 8 -- The Government of Communist China announced yesterday the second national bond issue since the regime was formed in 1949. No amount for the new National Construction Bonds to be put on sale next year was revealed.

IF ever there were doubts over the complementary rather than competitive nature of the major news media, they were put at rest during the suspension of newspaper publication. Television and radio filled a real public need with their news schedules, but necessarily they fell far short of meeting the public's hunger for information.

GENEVA, Dec. 7 -- Max Weber, member of the Swiss Government in charge of the Department of Finances, in effect the Minister of Finance, resigned today. It was generally believed that his action was decided upon because of the resounding defeat in yesterday's nation-wide referendum of the Government's proposals for broadening the tax base of the Federal Government.
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. told the Women's City Club yesterday that his appointees as heads of various city departments would be better qualified than their predecessors in most instances.

The 22,000-ton motorliner Kungsholm of the Swedish American Line, which made her debut in the North Atlantic luxury trade with her arrival last Thursday, will sail for Goeteborg at 11:30 A. M. today on the return leg of her maiden voyage.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A 1953 cotton crop of 16,437,000 bales, the fourth largest output on record, was estimated today by the Department of Agriculture.
TOKYO, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- Takeo Yoshikawa today revealed his key role in the sinking of the United States warships at Pearl Harbor twelve years ago yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A new scientific attack on the housefly, aimed to hit him in the intestines, was reported today to the Entomological Society of America.

Stone masons were busy the other morning on the old, gray stone tower of St. Peter's Church, Chelsea, in West Twentieth Street, renewing and repairing that weathered landmark now in its second century.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -- Members of the Mouse Un-American Activities Committee held here a week of sometimes turbulent hearings in which, they declared, they had observed "communism in action."
The New York Racing Associations announced yesterday they had hired William L. Pfeiffer, former Republican state chairman, as their "legislative consultant." His salary was not made public.
Sales of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., for the quarter and for the fifty-two weeks ended on Oct. 31 were slightly less than those for the corresponding periods a year earlier, but earnings improved.
Bergdorf Goodman's collection of Yuletide gift suggestions now on view is as chic and saucy as the many prominently displayed felt Christmas stockings in the shape of high buttoned shoes.

Four masked and armed robbers forced their way last night into the apartment of Arthur Murray, nationally known dance instructor, at 820 Park Avenue. One thief held Mr. Murray and his wife at pistol point while three of the intruders collected $25,000 worth of jewelry and $500 in cash from Mrs. Murray.

The Bermuda conference was never intended for anything but a personal get-together and tour of the horizon by the Big Three statesmen. From that point of view the communique contains all that one could hope or expect. Such statements are perforce vague and general.

The chief mediator involved in settlement of the photo-engravers' strike expressed hope last night that the accord would bring long-term stability to the newspaper industry through establishment of a uniform expiration date for contracts covering all the industry's seven mechanical unions.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 8 (AP) -- A former bank president and another man have been cleared of charges in connection with a $780,000 swindle of the Central National Bank of Mineola.

The arrival of President Eisenhower at La Guardia Airport yesterday and the course of his motorcade to and from the United Nations headquarters were marked by almost casual turnouts in contrast to the rousing send-off the President got on his departure from Bermuda.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Vincent Hallinan, wealthy lawyer, and Independent Progressive party candidate for President in 1952, was sentenced today to eighteen months in prison and fined $50,000 for Federal income tax evasion. He was convicted Nov. 14 of five counts of a seven-count indictment, and found guilty of evading $36,739 in taxes for 1947 through 1950.

In a speech before the Security Council of the United Nations, reported in The New York Times on Nov. 17, Dr. Yuseff Haikal of Jordan quoted extensively from a leaflet published by our organization several months ago. The general tenor of Dr. Haikal's speech was to the effect that the State of Israel lacks respect for international covenants and does not hesitate to violate them.

In a recent article in The Times in which you comment on the statements of President Batista, you allude to the various announcements made for elections in Cuba in a form which could be wrongly interpreted.

In the final hour of trading yesterday the stock market retraced much of the ground it had lost early in the session. Prices as measured by The New York Times composite average of fifty representative issues stood at 181.10 at the close, off only 0.46 on the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Cutbacks in demand for military products containing copper and copper base alloys this year have been more than matched by civilian orders for goods containing such metals, the Department of Commerce announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower today canceled all engagements for the rest of the week because of a bronchial condition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The three Western Allies proposed today that the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union meet in Berlin Jan. 4.

The producers of natural gas who have been fighting so long and so hard to escape federal rate-regulation have now definitively lost their battle in the courts. By refusing to review the Phillips Petroleum case the Supreme Court has nailed down an appellate decision that the Federal Power Commission does have rate-making authority over the "independent" natural gas producers who sell gas for transmission through pipelines in interstate commerce.

In 1929 a group of school teachers associated with Baylor University in Dallas, Tex., set up a system of medical care in accordance with which each paid three dollars for twenty-one days of hospital care in semi-private accommodations per semester. Out of this modest local beginning grew the Blue Cross and the Blue Shield plans, the one limited to defraying the cost of hospitalization, the other designed to pay physicians' fees.

The concert of British music given last night at the Juilliard School of Music was the fourth in the festival of compositions from Great Britain being held at that institution. The series began Dec. 2 with the concert of orchestral works conducted so brilliantly by Jean Morel.
TOKYO, Dec. 7 -- Recent important developments in Korean demilitarized zone have been:

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 8 -- Maurice Dejean, French Commissioner General in Indo-China, declared here today that France would not negotiate peace with the Communist-led Vietminh that would mean despotism for the Indo-Chinese people.

The liner Kungsholm, as clean, light and gracious as a modern Swedish home, welcomed 350 New Yorkers aboard for luncheon Monday. After a tour of the new motor vessel, which is the pride of the Swedish American Line and of Sweden, the guests found that her cuisine proved as excellent as the famed fare in that Scandinavian country.
The baseball set, which had listened to a lot of trade conversation but had seen little action either at Atlanta or here, yesterday had a major player exchange to discuss.

Four model rooms crammed with objects typical of the second half of the nineteenth century will be open to the public at the Brooklyn Museum today. The rooms cover a thirty-year period and show changing attitudes toward interior decorating.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States note to the Soviet Union:
Clear mild weather brought out customers in number yesterday, and retail merchants now expect sales volume will be close to the 1952 record level.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A critical shortage of operating funds for the nation's seventy-nine medical schools is threatening the future of American medicine. Dean Stanley E. Dorst of the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine said today.
Word of the end of the photo-engravers' strike sent workers flowing back to their jobs in all New York newspaper offices yesterday just after 4 P. M.
OTTAWA, Dec. 8 -- At midnight, a new tariff measure to protect Canadian manufacturers against unfair competition in the form of "dumping," will go into effect.

The resumption of diplomatic relations between Iran and Britain is a cause for satisfaction politically, not economically. Iranian oil is not needed in present circumstances. Oil shipments ceased on June 22, 1951. Abadan, the world's largest refinery, was closed down two weeks later.

NAGS HEAD, a pleasant stretch of beach on North Carolina's Outer Banks that, according to local legend, was a "hotbed of barratry" when the coastal schooners plied these dangerous waters, is a verdant mecca for surf-casters and wildfowlers, and right now the latter are in the majority.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Hearing on the proposed reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road went into its final phase today before an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Atlantic state Democrats are assembling some of their biggest vote getters for a party rally in Philadelphia Saturday. They hope to raise $100,000 in campaign funds at the gathering and to spur victory efforts in the 1954 Congressional and state election campaigns.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- French observers seemed to agree today that the results of the Bermuda conference were singularly negative in view of the importance and numbers of those who had participated.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A three-man division of the Interstate Commerce Commission today approved sale of the Government barge line to private interests of St. Louis, Mo., for $9,000,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Defense contentions that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., did not control composition of the board of General Motors Corporation "just don't hang together," E. Houston Harsha, head Government attorney, asserted today in the second day of oral arguments in the du Pont anti-trust trial.

" Richard III" will be ushered in at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center as the third in a series of four fortnightly revivals. Staged by Margaret Webster, the production will have a cast including Jose Ferrer, who fills the title role; Vincent Price, Florence Reed, Jessie Royce Landis, Maureen Stapleton, Staats Cotsworth, Margaret Wycherly, Philip Huston and William Post Jr.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Eisenhower Administration told the Supreme Court today that segregation of races in separate public schools could not be maintained under the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution.
A detective shot and killed a man suspected of being a narcotics seller in an apartment house at 889 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 155th Street, yesterday, the police reported.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 9 -- Special United States Envoy Arthur H. Dean told the Chinese and North Korean Communists at Panmunjom today that the Soviet Union was a "warlike, powerful and aggressive" nation that would never be accepted as a neutral participant in the proposed international conference to settle Korean problems.

Something new has been added as changes in wages and working conditions on this city's transit system are discussed. For the first time there is no cushion of tax subsidy to fall back on, so operating costs cannot outrun fare revenues. Michael J. Quill and his Transport Workers Union are making demands, to the tune of $50,000,000 added cost per year, that ignore this stern fact.

A copy of a book that brought order to the law of New York in 1752 was presented yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, to Dean William Warren of the Columbia Law School. The presentation took place at a meeting of leaders of the law school's sustaining fund in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.
The Detroit Lions, sure of at least a tie for the divisional lead, will face the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sunday in the final day's play of the professional football season.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- A smiling, waving President Eisenhower was given one of the United Nations' warmest receptions today.
NEWARK, Dec. 8 -- Two instances of suspected sabotage were reported today in the strike of 1,800 gas maintenance employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 8 -- Prince Faisal, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, said today his Government would welcome a United States offer of good offices in its dispute with Britain over the border oasis of Buraimi.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Subversive Activities Control Board denied a motion by the Labor Youth League today for dismissal of a Justice Department petition to declare the league a Communist-front organization.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 -- A Lithuanian emigrant who helped organize and direct an underground movement there against both the Russians and the Germans during World War II told the House Baltic Committee here today that his old organization still was operating in Soviet Lithuania and in greater strength than during the war.

Amid a maze of contradictory and confusing statements, club owners of the National and American leagues completed their separate meetings at the Commodore yesterday. They did not reveal how they stood on the player pension fund issue, which has kept the baseball world in a turmoil for the past week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The dispute between the Eisenhower Administration and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy over the conduct of United States foreign policy is not over.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Albert F. Fitzgerald, president of the United Electrical Workers, Ind., testified today that he had "no personal knowledge" of communism or of whether any officers or members of his union were Communists. But he admitted The U. E. W. News had "recommended" to U. E. W. members the book "We Can Be Friends," by Carl Marzani.
The New York Times, in its existence of more than a century, has exerted unusual efforts on a few occasions to maintain its record for continuity of publication dates.
TOWNSFOLK suddenly bereft of their daily journals in the recent strike found themselves in the position of the man in the whaler's crow's-nest, in Herman Melville's "Moby Dick."

Cornell became a member of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League and the schedules for the various circuits connected with the Eastern College Athletic Conference were approved yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. The annual sessions of the E. C. A. C. will continue through Friday.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 8 -- Two proposals for amending the Federal Constitution to authorize the creation of a military establishment in West Germany were made public here today. Both were presented to Parliament last week but the texts were not then available.
The A. B. C. television network will present a series of one-hour melodramas on Sunday evenings bginning Jan. 3 'at 8 P. M. Robert Stevens and Halsted Welles have been signed as co-producers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Powerful Congressional Republicans are determined to make alleged communism in Government a great issue not only in next year's Congressional elections but also in the 1956 Presidential election as well.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 2 -- Under Paul Eugene Magloire, her strong-man president, Haiti has achieved, for the time being at least, the political stability indispensable to economic and social development. The pace forward may be excruciatingly slow but it is in the right direction.
When newspaper presses in New York ground to a stop on Saturday morning. Nov. 28, resultant ripples spread far.

THERE may not be a more intriguing trade in a long time than the one which sent Mickey McDermott and Tom Umphlett from the Red Sox to the Senators in exchange for Jackie Jensen. It virtually demands speculation and it probably defies any accurate evaluation. It's one of those deals that -- if you'll forgive so overworked a phrase -- "should help both teams."

Representatives of the Transit Authority and of three unions of workers on the city-owned subway, elevated and surface lines continued their negotiations yesterday for a new agreement on wages and working conditions for the authority's 44,000 employes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Price action on the grain market was mixed today and at the finish most contracts were lower. December wheat showed relative firmness on renewed buying by elevator interests. Red winter wheat was firm in contrast to hard wheat which closed lower.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Della May McKeon celebrated her sixty-eighth birthday anniversary today by getting a $479,730 inheritance check she never would have received except for a faded photograph.
This is in reference to a news story entitled "Rural Electricity Rises As an Issue," carried in The New York Times on Nov. 8 under Washington dateline Nov. 7.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 8 --- The United States, Britain and France have agreed on two essential preconditions to their consideration of a Soviet proposal for a Big Five conference, including Communist China.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Stanley Kramer is returning to independent film production in association with United Artists, which will arrange complete financing for pictures he will make under a three-year contract.
Efforts to forestall a disastrous port-wide waterfront strike after the current Federal injunction ends on Christmas Eve were being pressed yesterday here and in Washington.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- The Pope inaugurated today the Marian Year. He traveled from Vatican City by motorcar to the Basilica of St. Mary Major where he recited a prayer that he himself had composed in the Virgin Mary's honor and imparted his benediction, Urbi et Orbi -- to the City and World.

WHEN the award of the Nobel Prize for literature to Sir Winston Churchill was announced several weeks ago the general satisfaction was immense. This nappy state of affairs does not always prevail. Minor writers of small consequence have been so honored and also major writers whose merits are highly controversial.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- By a vote of 55 to 0, the United Nations General Assembly decided today that it would reconvene to discuss developments in Korea whenever a majority desired a debate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower called on the Soviet Union today to join the United States in contributing part of its atomic stockpile to an international pool of nuclear fuel that would be immediately available for peaceful uses.
Eugene Ormandy led the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last evening in an all-Beethoven concert that ended with the Ninth Symphony, the Temple University Chorus assisting.
A housing development is planned for the fifty-six-acre estate in Manhasset, L. I., owned by the late Frederik Lunning, founder of the Fifth Avenue silverware concern of Georg Jensen, Inc.
A court held yesterday that a juror had a right to criticize publicly a court in which he had served -- but that a judge had a right to subpoena him to testify regarding his criticism.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 8 -- The Bermuda conference has passed into history. Its real results will be seen in the policy decisions made by the participating Governments in the months to come, for it is clear from the communique and the "clarifications" extracted from official sources during the four days when the leaders of the West were engaged in strictly private conversations that few decisions were made here.

OTTAWA, Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower's address on the perils of atomic war had an intently interested audience here today because of the partnership that exists among Canada, Britain and the United States in nuclear fission research.

In the subtlety, skill and variety of color of his playing last night at Town Hall, Larry Adler showed that he is approaching the same status as a player of the harmonica that Andres Segovia has achieved as a player of the guitar. And it is not just the unusualness of their instruments that suggests the parallel, for Mr. Adler is coming to play with the same intensity of expression as the Spanish guitarist.

Two witnesses yesterday asked the Federal Court here to enjoin Senator McCarthy from forcing them to produce documents and records relating to their suspension and reinstatement as technicians at Fort Monmouth, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Deartment of Justice faced a new handicap today in its war on a major source of income for organized crime -- the illegal coin-fed gambling machine.

Debt securities of the nation's foremost manufacturing company -- the General Motors Corporation -- will go on the public market for the first time today. Three hundred million dollars of twenty-five-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures, priced to yield 3.22 per cent, will be offered to investors.

In his dramatic speech before the General Assembly of the United Nations yesterday President Eisenhower gave the world a terrifying picture of the danger of total annihilation hanging over it as a result of the vast growth of atomic weapons. He appealed to all nations to cooperate in finding ways and means to control this awesome force that science has released.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower's speech today was applauded by many delegations as the first important new contribution to the atomic energy debate since 1946 when the United States first put forward the Baruch proposal for atomic energy control.

TRENTON, Dec. 8-- Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner reiterated here tonight that appointments to his Cabinet would not be announced until after Christmas. He spoke after a three-hour conference with Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and the fourteen members of the latter's Cabinet.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower today brought a spark of life -- and an entirely new approach -- to the problem of atomic energy control.
BALLSTON SPA. N. Y., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Paul W. Williams, special prosecutor, denied today that Governor Dewey had ordered the Saratoga gambling investigation in order to "get" James A. Leary.
Following is the text of the address delivered by President Eisenhower before the General Assembly of the United Nations yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
Johnny Lattner of Notre Dame received the 1953 Heisman Memorial Trophy last night as the Downtown Athletic Club's selection as "the outstanding college football player in the country."
Two men were stabbed and several others were severely beaten late last night as violence spread in the wake of the day-old strike of 1,500 employes of 500 private garbage removal companies.

SANTA PAULA, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Arrangement for the entry of 500 farm laborers, recruited from the British West Indies, as citrus workers in Ventura County was announced today by the Ventura County Citrus Association.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 8 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon plodded through a drainless refugee village of 20,000 persons this morning and talked sympathetically with the occupants of rag tents and straw huts for more than an hour.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower has told Sir Winston Churchill that the United States does not even wish to discuss at this time the possibility of admitting West Germany into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should the project for a European army fail to be ratified.
Four medical reports were presented here yesterday linking cigarette smoking and disease, particularly lung cancer, without qualifications.
In his address yesterday before the General Assembly of the United Nations President Eisenhower made two momentous disclosures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Organized labor was stirred today by a Supreme Court ruling that an attack on the quality of an employer's product, even in the excitement of a strike, was a valid cause for dismissal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Republicans and Democrats in Congress joined today in praising President Eisenhower's proposal for an international atomic energy agency but several warned of the need for "adequate safeguards."

The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday a plan to turn its Chance Vought aircraft division into a separate and, within the coming year, an independent corporation. The plan was announced yesterday in a letter to stockholders by Frederick B. Rentschler, chairman, and H. M. Horner, president.

Seton Hall, one of the top college basketball teams in the nation the past two seasons, bowed to Temple of Philadelphia, 73 -- 59, and Louisville turned back Manhattan, 87 -- 76, in a double-header before 7,562 fans at Madison Square Garden last night.

Government witnesses testified yesterday in Federal Court that Robert G. Thompson, convicted Communist leader, knew of a court order directing him to surrender on July 1, 1951, to begin his three-year prison term for conspiracy.

The newspaper strike ended at 3:53 P. M. yesterday in its eleventh day. It had forced six major New York papers to suspend publication for nine or ten successive daily editions, another for five days, and a smaller one for five days.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The United Nations General Assembly elected a United States lawyer today to the Administrative Tribunal, a body that has come under sharp attack from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Retail stores sold about $14 billion worth of goods in November, the Department of Commerce said today.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Colonial Secretary Oliver Lyttelton, who has been under heavy fire from the Labor party, announced in Parliament today that 2,822 natives had been killed in the clean-up campaign against the Mau Mau terrorists in Kenya in the first eleven months of this year.

The State Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions showed keen interest yesterday in proposals to liberalize benefit payments under the workmen's compensation, unemployment insurance and disability compensation laws.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- Carl W. Fulghum of Colorado was sworn in here today as acting chief justice of the United States Court of Appeals in Germany. He is replacing Chief Justice William Clark, who twice has defied removal.

BERLIN, Dec. 9 (UP) -- A United States soldier, charged with affiliating with the Communist East German secret police, asked a United States Army court-martial today to call the Soviet colonel commanding the Soviet army headquarters in East Berlin as a defense witness.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The British Boxing Board of Control dismissed a complaint against Randy Turpin, former world middleweight champion, that he had employed "unorthodox training methods" before his title fight against Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu in New York.
Gyorgy Sandor gave last night at Carnegie Hall his first New York recital in three years. In the interim, his playing has changed very little.

Government officials, shipping executives and rank-and-file longshoremen agreed yesterday that the new Waterfront Commission was making encouraging headway in its enforcement of the bi-state compact intended to smash crime on the New York and New Jersey docks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -Near-record milk production this winter may force the Government to step up its dairy price support outlays by as much as $100,000,000.

A remarkable study has just been issued by the International Press Institute, with headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on "The Flow of the News." The time, energy and money spent in this analysis of news to and from the United States, Western Europe and India make the report unique in journalistic history.
New Jersey's Republican Senators at a secret meeting here last night decided to abolish their party caucus system.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Air Force confirmed today that it was eliminating one of the five bases it originally planned to build in North Africa.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today abandonment of 156 miles of narrow gauge railroad operated in western Colorado by the Denver Rio Grande Western.
POTSDAM, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Robert C. McEwen of Ogdensburg has been chosen by the St. Lawrence and Franklin County Republican Committees to run next month in a special State Senatorial election.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP)-- Hi Billee, with Apprentice Johnny Rotz up, scored a nose victory in the $7,500 Hurricane Handicap at Tropical Park today.
Negotiations to solve the International League franchise situation struck another snag yesterday and Frank Shaughnessy, the league president, said it might be another week before it could be settled.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The State Department was in a quandary today over the case of Justice William Clark.

Although aircraft and utility shares gained, the stock market as a whole moved in an unusually narrow range yesterday. Except for the tobacco shares, which plummeted 3 to 4 points as a result of the publication of four new medical reports correlating cigarette smoking and cancer, changes in either direction were small.

The United States has a weapon more powerful than the atomic bomb in combating the spread of communism. It is the reduction of our tariff walls, Communism breeds in poverty. To fight it a minimum standard of world living must be maintained -- not by charity, but by the ability of anyone to sell the fruit of his labors regardless of his race, creed, color or nationality.

The United Jewish Appeal will open its sixteenth annual conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow to run through Sunday. Twelve hundred delegates, representing every section of the country, are expected to attend the three-day meeting, which will set the stage for the appeal's 1954 campaign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Eisenhower named seven Republicans and five Democrats today as members of the new Federal Farm Credit Board. The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, will appoint the thirteenth member.

It is no secret that the Giants, in their efforts to emerge from the second division, are in the market for a top-flight pitcher. Nor is it violating a confidence to report that the Braves would like to deal for a right-handed hitting outfielder and that the Redlegs are in the market for a right-handed hurler. The Yankees would not frown upon a new starting pitcher and the Tigers are looking for outfield help.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 -- Yugoslavia has rebuffed the latest Western proposal for a fivepower conference on the Trieste dispute.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Apparent discrepancies in construction cost estimates for two of the Idaho Power Company's three proposed dams in the Hell's Canyon area of the Snake River were explained today at a Federal Power Commission hearing.

BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Art Larsen, former United States singles champion, won two matches today to lead five other Americans into the fourth round in men's singles at Barranquilla's international tennis tournament.
It was virtually unanimous. New York was glad yesterday to have its newspapers under its arms again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- In his historic half-hour yesterday on the rostrum of the General Assembly of the United Nations the President restored to its proper perspective much that malicious propaganda has distorted.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 9 -- United States efforts to solve the British-Egyptian impasse over the future of the strategically important Suez Canal base failed to make any headway in Bermuda.

THE surface of North Carolina's Roanoke Sound resembled a giant reflecting pool. An occasional gull wheeled lazily overhead, an echelon of geese came honking past, saw the decoys and came in for a visit. It was one of those unbelievable days.

" Indiscretion of an American Wife," co-starring Jennifer Jones and Montgomery Clift and directed and produced in Italy by Vittorio De Sica, has been acquired for distribution by Columbia Pictures, according to a joint announcement by the film company and the David O. Selznick enterprises.

France's perennial political crisis and her inability to reach a decision on a European Defense Community are once again loudly deplored. It seems, indeed, as if many of us felt it comforting to have such a convenient whipping-boy as France at hand and we nag the French patronizingly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Ignatz Mezei, Hungarian-born, who has tried for three years to get a hearing on an order that he be excluded from the United States, obtained one today from the Justice Department.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 10 -The United Nations and Communist negotiators talked through another session at Panmunjom today. But apparently they came no closer than before to setting the terms for an international political conference on Korean affairs.
Burton D. Chait, 24-year-old operator of the Putnam Stables, admitted to the State Racing Commission yesterday that he was largely financed by his father, an ex-convict.

The New York Knickerbockers will try to widen their Eastern Division lead tonight when they tangle with the Boston Celtics in the feature game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. In the first game at 7:30 the Philadelphia Warriors will meet the Baltimore Bullets.

SANTO DOMINGO, Chile, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Bruno de Otero Hermanny of Brazil, a 20-year-old law student, returned in the outstanding individual performance so far in the world modern pentathlon championship today when he won the 300-meter swim in 3 minutes 57.9 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The United States Tax Court has ruled that the restaurant chain of the Waldorf System. Inc., is entitled to a refund of excess profits taxes under the so-called variant profits cycle theory.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The British Treasury was charged in the House of Lords today with making it impossible for shipowners to set aside adequate reserves to meet the cost of replacing their vessels.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- American motion pictures, as familiar to people abroad as in this country, have contributed importantly in preparing the world to accept the leadership of the United States in international affairs, Mahmud Shafqat, first secretary of the Pakistan Embassy in Washington, said here today.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 9 -- President Itzhak Ben-Zvi today asked Moshe Sharett. Foreign Minister and acting Prime Minister, to form a new Government. The outgoing four-party coaolition retired last Sunday with the resignation of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion.
The Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Associations will present a benefit dance concert tonight in the Kaufmann Auditorium, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -Arthur H. Samish, a California liquor lobbyist, was sentenced today to serve three years in Federal prison and pay a fine of $40,000 for evading the payment of income taxes.

Just when it seemed as if the Rangers couldn't miss beating the Detroit Red Wings in their National Hockey League game last night, the speedy visitors drove home a goal that gave them a tie. While the greater part of the crowd of 7,852 in Madison Square Garden looked on dejected, Jonn Wilson of the Red Wings nudged a shot past Johnny Bower to bring about a 3-to-3 deadlock.

The American President Lines has withdrawn its court action against the Federal Maritime Board seeking to upset its decision granting operating differential subsidies to Pacific Transport Lines, Inc., and to Pacific Far East Lines, a spokesman for the board's New York headquarters said yesterday.

Russeks' collection of Southern resort fashions, shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was as pretty and lively as one could wish. Highlighting such colors as fashion - important khaki, clear bright tones of yellow, orange and geranium red, as well as a soft pastel pink, the presentation gave glimpses of new swim suits, shorts fashions, sundresses and enchanting evening dreses for Southern nights.
Part of the "do-it-yourself" movement that has sprung up with rising costs are community services operated by women volunteers.

Any strike involving a public utility is fraught with dangers to the public. The strike of 1,800 gas maintenance employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which serves New Jersey, has brought unusual dangers because of reckless acts committed. The company estimates that some twenty-five separate acts of vandalism or sabotage have been committed since the strike, over wages, began on Nov. 20.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 9 (AP) -Navy's basketball team led most of the way to top American University today, 63 -- 53.
Tobacco stocks dropped nearly four points yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the wake of unqualified medical reports linking cigarette smoking with lung cancer.

ROME, Dec. 9 -- All former Fascists and Communist partisans still in prison for political crimes committed during the war, or in the turbulent first post-war year, will be freed if the Senate endorses a vote taken in the Chamber today.

The possibility of another substantial increase in fares on the Long Island Rail Road is disheartening to the many commuters on the line. In the past five years fares practically have doubled and still the revenue derived by the road is considered inadequate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -Mrs. Perle Mesta was back in Washington shopping for a house today but she disavowed any immediate plan to try to regain her title as the capital's number one party giver.
The City Planning Commission decided yesterday that houses, not horses, should play a vital role in the future development of the Baychester area of the Bronx.

TORONTO, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 3 to 0, tonight in a National Hockey League game marked by a third-period fight involving almost every player on both teams.

The $300.000,000 General Motors Corporation debt financing passed into history, early yesterday as a notable market success, and underwriting capital is directing its attention again to the pricing of smaller issues of prime securities of more run-of-the-mill kind.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -The Agriculture Department said today there might be "considerably fewer" Christmas turkeys available this year because of the nation's huge Thanksgiving appetite.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec9 -- Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India, president of the United Nations General Assembly, expressed the hope today that Sir Winston Churchill, Prime Minister of Britain, Georgi M. Malenkov, Soviet Premier, and the President of France would follow the example of President Eisenhower and address the Assembly on world problems.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (UP) -La Salle College, led by Tom Gola with 29 points, romped to its third straight basketball victory tonight by defeating Albright College, 76 -46, at the La Salle Field House.

Jose Ferrer's acting in "Richard III" does not equal his acting in "Cyrano de Bergerac" and "The Shrike." Since those productions came out of his repertory, they had only to be renewed for the City Center series. Excepting a Canadian performance in 1946, his version of Richard the Crookback is a fresh creation in Margaret Webster's staging of Shakespeare's violent drama.

A fear that the present trickle of offices to the suburbs may be changed into a torrent is the keynote of a report by our Chapter Committee on Public Affairs occasioned by the recent announcement in The New York Times of plans for a new nineteen-story office building to replace the Center Theatre at Radio City.

" Too much of a tax burden can cancel out the natural competitive advantages of the city and kill the goose that lays the golden eggs. Too little attention to the city's needs, particularly in the area of planning and maintenance of existing facilities, adversely affects property values, and can be equally or more damaging in the long run.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- British diplomatic sources insist that the Western powers must meet the Soviet Union in the proposed foreign ministers' conference armed with a coordinated policy, elastic to permit negotiation, but united to deflect increased Soviet attempts to divide the Allies.
NEW HAVEN, Conn. Dec. 9 -Paced by its high-scoring center, Ed Conlin. Fordham University methodically drubbed Yale, 80 -- 51, in the Payne Whitney gym tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Eisenhower today set up a board to disprove the adage that everybody talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it. The President appointed five civilians to complete a Weather Evaluation Board authorized by Congress last year.

Output of polyethylene which with nickel and some steel items, is one of the few critical industrial materials still in short supply, is gaining rapidly, the Bakelite Company reported yesterday. Full-scale operation has been achieved by the company at its new plant in Texas City, Tex., which means an increase of 45 per cent in the industry's production.

Labor and industry representatives selected yesterday a third person, representing the public, as chairman of the fact-finding board to settle remaining issues in the newspaper strike that ended Tuesday. The name of the chairman was withheld until his acceptance could be obtained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -The Atomic Energy Commission, which supervises the making of industry's deadliest products, today won the National Safety Council award of honor for a low score on death and injury among employes.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization will concentrate on building up airpower in 1954 if the Council of Ministers approves the goals agreed on by their military, economic and political representatives.

Pleasant hours and profitable results may come from making some of the ten Christmas projects described in a new "do-it-yourself" leaflet prepared by the Douglas Fir Plywood Association. The leaflet includes directions for making gifts for children, decorations for the outside of the house and a single suggestion for an adult present -- a small snack table.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, world-wide communications and manufacturing company, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $14,926,304 for the first nine months of this year. This was equal to $2.08 a capital share, and compares with a net of $15,324,144, or $2.14 a share, in the first nine months of 1952.

NEWARK, Dec. 9 -- Officials of the State Board of Mediation, encouraged by settlement of the photo-engravers strike in New York, made a new move today to end the strike of 1,800 gas maintenance employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Arguments ended in the Supreme Court today on whether racial segregation in the public schools is constitutional, and the nine justices took the question under advisement. A decision is not expected for several months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Treasury said today it sold 23 per cent more "E" and "H" savings bonds during the first eleven months of 1953 than in the same months of 1952.

THE grumblers and the finger-pointers are bound to view with cynical suspicion the ruling Ford Frick made the other day. The Commissioner decided that Ralph Terry, a 17year old fireballer, was the property of the Yankees rather than the Cardinals. The suspicions would be as utterly unfair as would be the probable accompanying remark, "What else would you expect? The Yanks have enough power and money to sway anyone."

Directors of the New York Central Railroad Company declared a 50-cent dividend yesterday for payment on Jan. 15. This brings the total for 1953 to $1 compared with 50 cents in 1952, paid at the yearend.
MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 9 -- Dr. Nils Y. Wessell, 30 years old, was installed today as the eighth president of Tufts College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Eisenhower's overture to the Russians to accept peaceful internationalization of atomic power has greatly strengthened his hand in world affairs against critics in his own party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 2:

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 9 (AP) -Gen. George C. Marshall arrived by plane here today to receive the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize. He said he was "greatly honored and profoundly grateful" for the award by the Norwegian Nobel Committee.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9 (UP) -- A panel of 112 turf experts has selected a pair of fast New Jersey colts and a reliable old Illinois gelding as the outstanding trotters of the 1953 season.
The leading trade association of the American electrical products industry presented yesterday an extensive analysis of a major business headache -- growing foreign competition.

Washington's Potomac was selected yesterday as the site for the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges sprint championships May 15, 1954. This was one of the major developments as the Eastern College Athletic Conference convention continued at the Hotel Biltmore. Approval of dates and sites for 1954 and 1955 events and election of officers were the principal actions taken at separate meetings.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Suffolk Superior Court Judge John E. Swift today awarded Carl von Trescoe, a New York financial advisor, a $31,856 judgment against the Pierce Consulting Engineering Company of Boston.

President Eisenhower's proposal for a new approach to the problem of atomic control seems to have collided head on with the continued Soviet insistence, now as for years past, that the first step toward removing the nuclear menace from the world must be the complete prohibition of all atomic and hydrogen bombs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Eight of nine resolutions dealing with trust territories under United Nations jurisdiction were adopted with large majorities today by the General Assembly before it recessed.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, prices 7 to 16 points net higher on active months.
Two armed men were captured yesterday morning by the head of an electrical supply corporation after a hold-up at the Union League Club, at 38 East Thirtyseventh Street.

The following is the text of the joint statement issued yesterday by the National and American Leagues after their adoption of a resolution to appoint a committee to consider the possible termination in 1955 of the players' pension plan:

An increase last week of 256,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies amounted to 150,098,000 barrels, compared with 149,842,000 a week earlier and 129,470,000 a year ago.

The Mackinac Bridge Authority, Mich., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 17 for the purchase of $99,800,000 of toll revenue bonds to finance construction of a five-mile-long suspension bridge across the Straits of Mackinac connecting Mackinaw City with St. Ignace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today denied charges by Senator Estes Kefauver. Democrat, Tennessee, that there had been a planned "slowdown" in the Rural Electrification Administration program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -Under Secretary of Agriculture True D. Morse said today the United States was anxious to increase exports of wheat but did not intend to adopt "dumping" measures to gain markets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Several industries of major national importance were beset or threatened today by strikes directly and indirectly affecting millions.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- Sir Winston Churchill cabled his wife "good luck and all my love" from Bermuda today, as she waited here to accept his Nobel literature prize tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Interior Department officials renewed today a promise to interpret liberally the provisions of a controversial new power sale policy, and denied the department was acting as a "stooge" for a private power monopoly.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, urged the Department of Defense today to make use of $25,000,000 worth of available surplus air base construction material in French Morocco for pro-...
The Best Foods, Inc., account has been resigned by Benton Bowles, Inc., effective Feb. 1. Most of it will go to Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., on that date.
A three-judge Federal Statutory Court upheld yesterday the constitutionality of a section of the new bistate waterfront reform compact that bans public loaders on piers.
Accessories representative of two art eras in Japan, the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, make up an exhibit in the Far Eastern Galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
A ten-year investigation of tooth decay suggests that it starts after teeth have softened because they have lost minerals. A report on the investigation was presented here yesterday by Dr.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- James A. Leary, Saratoga County Republican leader, tonight was found innocent of charges of perjury and conspiracy to obstruct justice.
ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Governor Dewey will return from a ten-day vacation in the South tomorrow to face the problem of drawing up his party's 1954 legislative program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, said today that Ralph Demmler, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will be summoned Friday to explain S.E.C. policy on venture capital for domestic minerals development.

Just about the most important vehicle on the roads these days can be seen lumbering along at certain hours of the morning and late afternoon with its cargo of hopes, fears, laughter, frowns, songs, jeers, whistles and all the other emotions and sounds common to youth.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Freedom of speech of an Army censor who refused to be censored, became an issue today in the United States Court of Military Appeals.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 -- Angel Borlenghi, Minister of the Interior, today denied the Government's major opposition party permission hold an open air rally Friday to express its views on the amnesty and electoral bills currently being debated in Congress.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -President Eisenhower's proposal for an international agency to develop atomic energy continued to win support today from a world preoccupied with the threat of atomic destruction.

The Supreme Court of the United States is the subject of a new book by Fred Rodell, Professor of Law at Yale University. It is an account of the court's history, the personalities who have been part of that history and the crises the tribunal has faced.
Sparked by gains by the new, non-cellulose fibers, the production capacity of the man-made fiber industry should increase 12 per cent in the next two years, the Textile Organon predicted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- An appeal for the Administration to exclude all imports of synthetically produced star sapphires and rubies was made to the Federal Tariff Commission today.

Club owners of baseball's two major leagues, concluding an extraordinary joint session at the Biltmore yesterday before Commissioner Ford C. Frick, voted to set up a committee to study the posibility of scrapping the players' pension fund.

Louis W. Dawson, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, was elected yesterday president of the Life Insurance Association of America at the association's annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He succeeds Morton Boyd, president of the Commonwealth Life Insurance Comuany of Louisville, Ky.

A tough anti-Communist policy was announced yesterday by the General Electric Company. The concern, which has 131 plants and 230,000 employes across the country, explained that in a crisis virtually all its factories would become "essential instruments of national defense."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The 4,871 national banks operating on Sept. 30 had total assets of more than $106,000,000,000, Ray M. Gidney, Controller of the Currency, reported today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 9 (UP) -- Francis M. McHale sued in Fedeial Court today to have'sgregation restored at naval bases; The lawyer argued that mingling'of Negroes and whites eventually could cause mankind to, revert to "Simian" traits.

The City Stores Company, which operates a group of department stores including Oppenheim, Collins and Franklin Simon, had lower sales and earnings in the thirteen weeks through Oct. 31 than in the similar 1952 period.
Election of Harry A. DeButts and C. R. Smith as directors of the Chase National Bank was announced yesterday by John J. McCloy, chairman.

Organized low-cost group and individual student travelers to Europe cannot expect too much help in the form of tourist class space on regular trans-Atlantic liners next summer, according to the Council on Student Travel.
HONG KONG, Dec. 9 -- Unloading of United States dollars increased on local markets here today and the exchange rate dropped to the lowest level in many years.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is planning to borrow $100,000,000 in the United States market next month on bonds maturing in fifteen years.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 9 -- Elections for the first Parliament of the Central African Federation are being contested on the same basis as in South Africa, where the principal issue is race.
After a two-day trial, Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan reserved decision yesterday in the contemptof-court charge against Robert G. Thompson, one of the eleven convicted Communist leaders.
MANTALOKING, N. J., Dec. 9 (AP) -- James J. Turner told the story tonight of how he had caused a stir in the ornithological world with a pair of wood - and - linoleum bird feet.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 9 (UP) -- DeLaney Kiphuth, son of the Eli and Olympic swimming coach, was appointed today as director of athletics at Yale.

With the premiere of "John Murray Anderson's Almanac" (designated as a musical harlequinade) at 8 o'clock tonight at the Imperial, Hermione Gingold, a popular London comedienne, finally reaches her goal under the banner of Michael Grace, Stanley Gilkey and Harry Rigby.

BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- Sources with contacts in the Soviet zone believe that the East German Cabinet will announce tomorrow a twenty-point program of concessions to the poplace that probably will include further price cuts and wage increases.
Two 18-year-old British students applauded yesterday President Eisenhower's statement to the United Nations requesting an international pool of atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith and Donold B. Lourie, the two Under Secretaries of State, have given notice of their intention to resign within a few months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The expected return of Vice President Richard M. Nixon next Monday will signal a speed-up here in plans for United States military assistance to Pakistan.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's Chancellor, will go to Paris tomorrow or Friday in search of inside information about the prospects for European integration after the Bermuda conference and the outlook for the four-power meeting in Berlin.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- A four-year plan to help French television grow out of its present stagnant state of obscure infancy was withdrawn tonight by Government officials angered at the National Assembly's refusal to vote the means of financing this development.

A split City Planning Commission yesterday upheld Robert Moses, chairman of the Mayor's Slum Clearance Committee, in his controversial plans for a $28,960,000 housing project for Washington Square Southeast.

Money, as every adult knows and as all children soon learn, takes on many associative values over and above its primary practical meaning. People see money differently. One in terms of cans of coffee, another in months of rent, another as base capital from which a certain interest accrues, another just physically -- in terms of how a quantity of bills bulge in the wallet or how change hangs in the pocket.
Negotiations between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union on $50,000,000 in union demands were described by Michael J. Quill yesterday as "deadlocked."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The White House and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin today called off further publicity on telegrams and letters concerning the Senator's demand that all aid be withheld from Allied nations that trade with Red China.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -Business is spending a record $27,827,000,000 improving its plant equipment this year, the Government estimated today.
