Rabbi Norman Salit, president of the Synagogue Council of America, declared last night that the Bonn Government should "implement a broad and intensive campaign to exorcise the devil of antiSemitism from the soul of Germany."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The peoples of the Arab nations are more determined than ever to remain aloof from the struggle between the Western and the Soviet blocs, the Secretary General of the Arab League reported today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Representatives of virtually the entire labor force of United States railroads were in direct or indirect negotiation with railroad management in Chicago's Union Station and other offices in the city today.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- President Eisenhower's speech yesterday proposing an international agency for nuclear materials was emphasized above all other news in the French press today and brought enthusiastic comments.

They come by runaway train; they come by kidnapped plane; they crawl through the barbed wire; they creep past the signal towers; they come a stowaways or as "freight." They leave everything behind: always their possessions; usually their friends, often their families, sometimes an arm or a leg caught in a minefield.

PARIS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Paris police said today that they had been told that the Swiss authorities planned to ask the extradition of Harold E. (Whitey) Dahl, 44year-old United States pilot arrested here last week and since charged with the theft of 12,000,000 francs ($34,285) in gold.

GENEVA, Dec. 9 -- An international agreement designed to stabilize the price of tin was approved today by the United Nations Tin Conference in its final session here. It is still only a draft agreement, however. Many governments, including the United States, the world's greatest tin user, have not decided yet whether they want any tin control agreement at all.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- (UP) The Department of Agriculture announced today the 1954 wool crop would be supported at not less than 52.1 cents a pound. The present support price is 53.1 cents, which was 90 per cent of parity at the beginning of the marketing season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -The Veterans Administration announced today it would pay a regular dividend of $190,000,000 next year to veterans holding about 5,000,000 National Service Life Insurance policies.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
President Eisenhower's eloquent address to the United Nations was a moving argument for peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -The Government issued a complaint today against the Studebaker Corporation and Local 5 of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., at South Bend, Ind., for allegedly requiring union members to own Studebakers.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 (AP) -Rocky Castellani stood off the savage buzz-saw fighting of Gil Turner with toe-to-toe slugging tonight to win a unanimous tenround decision in a wild bout in Cleveland arena. The victory strengthened Castellani's bid for a title shot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Railroad told an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today that as much as $250,000 a year might be saved in power costs by "coasting" trains. Altogether he listed savings aggregating $3,500,000 a year.

The Heyden Chemical Corporation has sold its antibiotics division to the American Cyanamid Company for $12,000,000 cash, which is about $6,000,000 in excess of the book value of the assets sold, John P. Remensnyder, chairman, and Simon Askin, president, informed stockholders.

BONHAN, Tex., Dec. 9 (UP) -Sam Rayburn, Minority Leader of the House of Representatives and dean of Congress, said today that the Republicans were wasting time preparing a legislative program to submit to Congress in January.

" Don Giovanni" will have its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan tonight at 8 P. M. Max Rudolf will conduct and the cast will include Cesare Valletti, making his debut as Don Ottavio; Nicola Rossi-Lemeni, Margaret Harshaw, Eleanor Steber and Roberta Peters.
Boris Leontiev is the leading foreign affairs commentator of the Soviet radio, according to The Assocated Press.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad sold $6,600,000 of its 3 3/4 per cent equipment trust certificates yesterday to a group headed by Salomon Bros. Hutzler. The certificates, maturing annually, Jan. 1, 1955 to 1969, are being reoffered by the underwriters at prices to yield 2.50 per cent to 4 per cent.

Commodity prices moved generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light, but cottonseed oil and soybean oil continued active and coffee registered the highest volume of the year for the second consecutive day. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa, sugar, hides, rubber, lead and zinc were lower: coffee, burlap, copper and tin closed higher, and wool and potatoes ended mixed.

Al (Dusty) DeStefano, St. John's University's quiet-spoken basketball coach, is not one to go overboard when it comes to predicting his team's chances. Dusty's current Redman five is "basically a good one and a team which should click if we can overcome the height problem," the St. John's pilot declared yesterday.
NORWICH, Conn., Dec. 9 -The Most Rev. Bernard J. Flanagan was installed today as the first Bishop of the new Norwich diocese of the Roman Catholic Church in Connecticut.

In translation, here are some of the words from the chorale that closed last night's concert of the Bach Aria Group at Town Hall. "God has beautifully arranged the earth. . . . We thank Him greatly and pray that He may give us the sense of the spirit that we understand such things aright."

Because nurses have voluntarily given up the right to strike, hospital administrators are morally obligated to bargain collectively with them on salaries and working conditions, Julius Manson, supervising mediator of the State Board of Mediation, said yesterday.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 9 (UP) -Cornell's basketball team set a school scoring record by defeating Clarkson, 92 to 37, tonight. The Big Red had tallied 89 points against Hobart in its opening game of the season.

Hunter College students will help add to the frame of a colorful landmark in Greenwich Village, the Brevoort Hotel, by using it as the setting for their follies production, "High Spirits." This is to be presented tomorrow night and Saturday night at 8:30 P. M. in the Hunter College Playhouse, 695 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- A drastic decline in soybean prices weakned grain markets today as long liquidation became general. Selling of soybeans was a result of further weakness in the market for soybean oil, and also because of evidence of an unwieldy long interest in that market.
The Department of Sanitation will take over in part today the task of collecting from commercial establishments the waste usually picked up by private companies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- An increase of 4.8 per cent in college and university enrollment over the last academic year was reported today by the Federal Office of Education.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Dealings between E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and General Motors Corporation on tetraethyl lead, antiknock compound, were far from "arm's length," it was charged here today. E. Houston Harsha, chief Government attorney made the assertion during oral arguments in the du Pont anti-trust trial.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 9 -- The South African Government, annoyed with the United Nations because of the constant attacks on its racial policy, is reported to have decided to leave three United Nations organizations.

Army's football team, beaten only once in 1953, yesterday was named the winner of the August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy, symbolic of Eastern supremacy. Of the 40 first-place votes cast by sportswriters and broadcasters, 36 went to Earl Blaik's squad and 2 each went to Penn and Penn State. Cornell, Syracuse, Yale, Navy and Harvard also received votes, but none for the top spot.

An owl in Union Square, angels on Fifth Avenue and forty-foot trees that seem to have sprouted overnight are among the improbable happenings contributing to the never-never land of New York at Christmas time.
MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Moscow has purged the leadership of the Armenian Communist party for failure to dismiss adherents of the ousted Lavrenti P. Beria, former Deputy Premier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- With the backing of President Eisenhower, the Defense Department has ordered the Army, Navy and Marine Corps to trim their manpower by about 10 per cent in budgeting for the riscal year to begin next July 1.
EASTON, Pa., Dec. 9 -- A trio of sophomores turned on the fast break to spark Lafayette from a 30-30 half-time tie to a 69-61 victory over Princeton tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Louis Budenz, ex-Communist today started identifying some 200 organizers, administrators and teachers of the Jefferson School of Social Science in New York City as Communists.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -Whether a company's employe stock purchasing plan is subject to collective bargaining is the issue in dispute between the Richfield Oil Corporation of California and the Oil Workers International Union, C. I. O.

A choice of more than 160 apartments in permanent public housing projects remained available yesterday for the ninety-six families who have refused to move from the two emergency housing projects in Brooklyn that the State Division of Housing seeks to close.
MADRID, Dec. 9 -- Nearly 2,000 workers in a Bilbao plant have been dismissed because they struck when management announced a reduction in overtime pay, wellinformed sources said today.

A fabulous dining-at-home treat for those to whom the words "Dinner at Maxim's" spell magic in elegant eating is now available to New Yorkers. Six dishes superbly prepared, packaged and frozen by the famous restaurant's chefs in their Paris kitchen are on sale this week at Altman's.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Eisenhower is gradually but nevertheless definitely adopting a bolder role in the conduct of the Presidency.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 934 pints of blood Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations informed a Fort Monmouth radar expert today that it would seek his indictment for espionage as well as for perjury. Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, sub-committee chairman, conceded that the subcommittee's case against Aaron H. Coleman probably would require bolstering at points.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., Dec. 9 (UP) -- County detectives reported today a group of teen-age boys had collected $1,500 for a single mowing of the lawn of an absent-minded widow.
ALBANY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed Frederic R. Blair of Huntington to replace Spencer E. Bates of Hewlett as a member of the State Tax Commission.

OTTAWA, Dec. 9 -- Canadian comment continued to be cautious and restrained today on President Eisenhower's proposal to establish an international stockpile of fissionable material under United Nations auspices for research and development of atomic energy for peaceful uses.

The new $6,800,000 East Side Airlines Terminal on First Avenue between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets is a fine improvement. It is a convenience to air travelers and a major contribution to relief of traffic congestion in the Grand Central area and thus a general public service.

Royal W. Ryan, executive vice president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, was honored yesterday by his associates at a luncheon in conjunction with the annual meeting of the International Association of Convention Bureaus in the New Yorker Hotel.

Standards applicable to claims for permanent loss of hearing as the result of employment in noisy surroundings were announced yesterday by Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board.
Christmas gifts of films and candy were presented yesterday to the children at Bellevue Hospital, while money was donated to the New York Foundling Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Public Housing Administration announced today that Salomon Bros. Hutzler had bought more than half of the $113,114,000 short-term loan notes sold yesterday by 100 local housing authorities.

ROME, Dec. 9 -- Philip Vincent Cardon, 64 - year - old United States agricultural scientist, was unanimously elected today to head the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization for the next two-year term.
Two workmen climbed out last night on one of the main support spires of the George Washington Bridge, almost 500 feet above the Hudson River, and rescued a 28-year-old father bent on suicide.
An exhibition covering 200,000,000 years of flight by insect, bird and man will be opened today in New York's Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
Three infants were among the seventeen persons rescued yesterday from a two-alarm fire in a rooming house at 47 East Twenty-first Street, near Gramercy Park.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 9 (AP) -- "The Naked and the Dead," one of three novels around which a censorship dispute swirled recently, received a clean bill of health from the Milwaukee County, Literary Commission last night.
A deported henchman of Charles (Lucky) Luciano, deported racketeer, was shot and killed by three men in a tavern at 634 East 183d Street, the Bronx, early yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Directors of the American Farm Bureau Federation approved a proposal today to increase 1954 cotton acreage and distribute the additional acreage among the states.
Peace and prosperity are the objectives of American labor, George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared last night.

THESE children grew up in southern Illinois, not far from Mark Twain's country. They enjoyed life in the second and third decades of the century and shared it with friends of various national origins. They had such household pets as Prophet, a somewhat unreliable horse; Cherry, a dependable Holstein cow, and Blizzard and Prince, who were their father's prize bird dogs.

There is no longer any doubt that both in the cold war and in the diplomatic efforts to achieve peace the West has now seized the initiative. Soviet Russia has been put on the defensive, politically and morally. This is demonstrated by the results of the Bermuda conference, which emphasized the essential and unbreakable unity of the Western Powers.
Young Johnny, with the curiosity of his age, picked up some matches and began striking them just as he had seen his mother do. He suffered a critical burn.

The author of the Baruch plan for international control of atomic energy expressed cautious optimism yesterday concerning President Eisenhower's proposal for an international atomic stockpile for peaceful development.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 9 -Congressional investigating committees frequently usurp the functions and prerogatives of law courts in a clear threat to democratic justice, it was held here today.
Lance H. Cooper, chairman of the Mond Nickel Company, Ltd., has been elected a vice president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -Lord Beaverbrook's Evening Standard said today that the late Harry Dexter White, former Assistant Secretary of the United States Treasury, helped place a "throttlehold" on the British Empire.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (UP) -Insect poisons derived from nerve gases developed during World War II and new toxins designed to kill DDT-resistant flies and household pests were reported by scientists today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 9 -- Vice-President Richard M. Nixon, arriving in Iran as the Teheran Government moved to end the period of suspicion and hostility toward the West, today assured this nation the United States wanted only to help it be "strong, independent and free."
The Phelps Dodge Corporation is going to sell its refined copper at a single delivered price throughout the United States, beginning with sales for shipment in January.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The Moscow radio tonight harshly rejected President Eisenhower's plan for an international atomic energy pool for peaceful purposes.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Dan Shannon and Patti Matz, junior ends from Chicago, were named co-captains of the 1954 Notre Dame football team tonight at the annual civic dinner honoring this season's undefeated team.

The daylight coach fares of at least two of the country's airlines were increased yesterday with almost no general public notice, "because of the recent newspaper strike." One of the companies reported that the rise had caused its passengers some difficulties and had aroused protests.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 9 (UP) -The 13,334-ton Norwegian liner Stavangerfjord with 644 passengers, many of them Americans, lost her rudder during a full gale off the coast of Newfoundland, the Norwegian-American line reported tonight.

An array of pretty packages filled with unusual and fascinating items for gift-giving are displayed in Elizabeth Arden's boutique, on the second floor of her salon, and in her new "Paradise-for-Men Shop" newly opened at 1 East Fifty-fourth Street.

Commenting yesterday on President Eisenhower's speech Tuesday before the United Nations General Assembly, Walker L. Cisler, president of the Atomic Industrial Forum, said that the President had made "a genuinely significant proposal."

ISLIP, L. I., Dec. 9 -- Long Island's Great South Bay is zoned like the towns next to it the Islip Town Board ruled today as it turned down a plan for a floating diner. The ground for refusal was that the water-borne business might accidentally anchor near a residential area.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 9 -- Diplomatic circles here are watching United States negotiations with Pakistan for a military aid pact "very closely," according to highly placed informants from several countries. They believe Washington's ultimate action will indicate future United States policy for the Middle East as well as south Asia.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 9 -- Workers at the Big Enka plant in Lowland Community near Morristown, Tenn., who made national headlines for months in 1950, prefer to remain without a union, the results of a National Labor Relations Board election showed this afternoon.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., said today the president of a rival union "did not tell the truth" when he said all the United Electrical workers assigned to classified "secret" projects in General Electric plants had been investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The stock market here was progressively weaker today. Turnover continued to dwindle and prices slipped in the afternoon session under slightly increased selling pressure, attributed to fears of labor disputes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Government gave notice today that it was not through with Harry Bridges. It made a move indicating that it intended to prosecute the Australia-born, West Coast longshore leader once more as a prelude to a renewed attempt to deport him.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- A United States commissioner today refused a plea that he dismiss charges against three suspects in the $681,000 Danvers armored car theft.
Asked last night if he was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, Representative Franklin D. Roosesvelt Jr. replied:

Imaginative fabrics in bold colors, as well as delicate pastel shades, were outstanding in the collection of cruise clothes at Ohrbach's previewed for the press yesterday. From bright awning-striped cotton to delicate appliqued tapestry prints, fabrics stood out as important resort news.

Now that Thanksgiving Day is over, this is, of course, the inevitable time for the Christmas lists. They can be found, by way of a little searching, everywhere about the house. This search is necessary, for they are lists kept in secret, although they are referred to so often that the hiding places of necessity grow less obscure as time goes on.

Despite the steep drop in movie attendance since 1948, the reading of newspaper amusement pages has continued high. Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, made this assertion yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- An attorney today questioned whether public agencies in Oregon might seize one of Idaho Power Company's three proposed dams in the Hell's Canyon section of the Snake River between Idaho and Oregon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -The Democratic National Committee said today that Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. omitted from his testimony on the Harry Dexter White case a "crucial statement" contained in a Federal Bureau of Investigation report.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, quit as an adviser of the Foreign Operations Administration today. He said the F. O. A. was ignoring the role of free labor in fighting communism abroad.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Dec. 10 (UP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. predicted today that Republicans would gain "at least 20" House seats next year and added:
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 5 -- Saudi Arabia is preparing to embark on an ambitious program for channeling her large oil revenues into productive economic and social reform.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., took over today the union's Local 445, Westchester County, N. Y. He said he had acted because of reports of misconduct by the union officers.
Today's new film is "Violated." a melodrama produced in New Yorkk by Wim Holland, who also heads the cast, at the World Theatre. Panther Productions, Inc., is distributing.
Future appointments, reinstatements, transfers and promotions in eighteen city departments classified as "security agencies" will be subject to a new form of loyalty test.

CHICAGO, Dec, 10 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox today obtained Outfielder Willard Marshall from the Cincinnati Redlegs in exchange for three players, Pitcher Saul Rogovin and Infielders Connie Ryan and Rocky Krsnich. No cash was involved in the deal.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 10 -- Eli Lilly Co., Indianapolis pharmaceutical manufacturer, will begin the manufacture of agricultural antibiotics shortly after Jan. 1. Lilly will use its facilities and buildings at its plant in Greenfield, Ind., to produce the antibiotics to be sold in bulk form to feed manufacturers, who in turn will incorporate it in feed for chickens, turkeys and livestock.

MIAMI, Dec. 10 (AP) --Art Wall Jr., a comparative newcomer to the professional golf trail, putted brilliantly today to capture the first-round lead in the $10,000 Miami open tournament with a five-under-par 65.

Fresh pork in family meals is not only traditional at this season, but market reports indicate that it is cheapest from November to February. Hearty and satisfying, pork has added appeal when accompanied by autumn's abundant sweet potatoes, fresh apple sauce or cranberries.

It is expected that one of the results of Vice President Nixon's visit to Pakistan will be increased American support of some sort of program designed to make Pakistan stronger militarily. Such a program seems to us to be realistic, rational and feasible. If Pakistan needs and can use our help to this end, the help should be given.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The French Government intends to seek through the North Atlantic Treaty the new United States and British guarantees for the proposed European army that it has failed to get from Washington or London, a high authority said here today.

No major league club owner wants to scrap the ball players' pension fund. All are agreed that it should be kept in operation and they intend to continue their part in it unless the players insist on running it themselves or the players' demands make it economically impossible for the owners to operate it for them.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Big Ten athletic directors restricted basketball scouting and discussed curbing football scouting today, while other proposals before the conference winter meeting were deferred.

For many years my checkbook has furnished documentary evidence of an interest in opera, concerts, and phonograph records wholly out of proportion to my available time and income. For many years, too, I have read the reviews and commentaries of your distinguished music critic, Olin Downes, and have never failed to profit by his erudition and penetration.
TRENTON, Dec. 10 -- The New Jersey Legislature was the scene of bitter debate here today as separate but identical bills designed to bar any new race tracks in the state were adopted in both houses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Executive planning of the Administration's legislative program for the next session of Congress is in its final stages, the White House disclosed late today.
BLUE POINT, L. I., Dec. 10 -- A television set here had its face turned to the wall yesterday for gross misbehavior in frightening little children.

Tobacco stocks are as hard to give up as the weed itself, judging from what has happened to cigarette shares in the last two days. Enough of the investors who swore off such issues on Wednesday to the extent of losses ranging to four points resumed their holdings yesterday to bring about some moderate recoveries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -Jacob Friedus, president of the Starrett Television Corporation of New York, was convicted in Federal Court today of filing false statements with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in 1950.

On Nov. 25 you published an interesting letter on tax structure by Milton Gottdiener. It states that income from oil ventures should be taxed as straight income without a depletion allowance. This suggestion has no merit, because when one "buys into an oil field venture one is actually paying for anticipated oil under ground.
ROME, Dec. 10 -- The Italian railroad network was brought to a standstill tonight when employes of the state railroads began a twenty-four-hour strike.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 10 -- The Communist Vietminh radio renewed today offers to negotiate a peace in Indo-China. A peace feeler was put out recently by Ho Chi Minh, Vietminh leader, in an interview with a Swedish newspaper.

Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the board of International Business Machines Corporation, received a citation of merit yesterday from the Salvation Army Association of New York. The presentation was made at the annual luncheon of that organization in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The annual showing of spring and Easter lines by the National Association of Display Industries, which opened Sunday on a pessimistic note, closed yesterday on an optimistic one.

Steve Owen will trade his coaching post for a front-office job with the New York Football Giants following the team's final 1953 game with the Detroit Lions at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. His decision to retire yesterday marks the end of one of football's longest coaching tenures.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- There was no reaction here today to the Vietminh broadcast reviewing an offer to negotiate a peace in Indo-China. However, the Cabinet declared shortly after a Stockholm newspaper interview with Ho Chi Minh that it would examine any Vietminh offers if they were made "in an official manner."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A possibility arose today of an early end to a long Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on a proposal to reorganize the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road.
If City College doesn't come up with a standout season, it won't be the fault of Coach Dave Polansky. The Beavers possess experience and enough height and speed for the making of a winning team.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Weather can be utilized as a military weapon and some day it may be entirely feasible for the United States to induce torrential rains or prolonged droughts in Russia.
Governor Dewey proposed last night the creation of an overseer for the courts of New Yor state.

Dresser Industries, Inc., manufacturers of oil, gas and chemical equipment, had net earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 of $5,110,776 on sales of $128,978,716, H. N. Mallon, president, reported yesterday.
Piel Bros. announced yesterday the purchase of the Staten Island plant of the Rubsam and Horrmann Brewing Company in an expansion program.

Some of your readers may be interested in a correction to the article on Eugene O'Neill which appeared in The Times of Nov. 28. The article says, "He * * * went to Princeton. After ten months at the university he was expelled for heaving a brick through a window of the local stationmaster's house.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 10 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, came here today and censured various economic and political segments of the region for business practices and philosophies he said tended to "defeat the integrity of our entire national economy."

Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, reported yesterday that New York had entered upon a period of economic readjustment. This involves a reduction of takehome pay because of diminished overtime work, a leveling of employment and a drop in the production of both durable and nondurable goods, he explained.

LYNN, Mass., Dec. 10 -- The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., retained its bargaining rights at General Electric Company plans here and in neighboring Everett today in a National Labor Relations Board election.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 11 -- The United States special envoy, Arthur H. Dean, told the Communists in Korea today that the Soviet Union had "inspired and directed" the war there. Hence the Soviet Union could not be accepted as a neutral in the projected international conference on Korean affairs.

CHILDS RESTAURANT in Columbus Circle, pre-dawn meeting place for actors, writers, prizefighters and men about town, served its last rounds of wheat cakes around midnight, Nov. 30. The establishment, like many of its neighbors, is to be wrecked because it stands on the new Coliseum site.

A Christmas tree forty-four feet high was lighted in Union Square yesterday and dedicated by neighboring business men and residents. The tree was the gift of the Fourteenth Street Association, whose officers said it was the first to be put up in Union Square.

WALNUT CREEK, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Representative Robert L. Condon, Democratic of California, today formally asked the opportunity to deny publicly before the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee reports linking him to communism.

EDMONTON, Dec. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Gilbert A. Labine, president of Gunnar Gold Mines, Ltd., said today the company is preparing to spend more than $14,000,000 on expansion and development of its uranium mine on Lake Athabaska, twenty miles from Uranium City in northwestern Saskatchewan.

Volume continued light yesterday on most commodities on the New York exchanges. Prices moved generally higher with cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil. Chides, wool, potatoes, zinc and copper increasing, rubber closing lower and coffee, sugar and burlap ending mixed.

THE winds blew, the waters tossed, the waves were crested and the sun made only brief irregular appearances throughout the morning. In brief, the conditions were such as to make any wildfowler's heart vibrate with delight, hope and anticipation.

Bliss Laughlin, Inc., steel producer, increased the quarterly dividend to 50 cents on the common stock and also voted an extra of 60 cents, both payable on Dec. 31. Including the previous quarterly disbursements of 30 cents, this year's figure will equal the $2 distributed in 1952, when the year-end extra was 80 cents.

The Seaboard Finance Company ended its fiscal year on Sept. 30 as the most active and profitable in its twenty-six years of operation. Volume of business, receivables outstanding and net income reached new high levels, according to the annual report issued to stockholders today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Leonard S. Hobbs of East Hartford, Conn., the man most responsible for development of the Pratt Whitney J-57 jet engine, was announced today as the winner of the Collier Trophy for "the outstanding achievement in aviation during 1952."

It is striking, apropos of the newly staged "Don Giovanni" given last night at the Metropolitan, to reflect that the principal merits of the occasion were those of the musical performance and the conspicuous shortcomings those of the spectacle and action.
Stephen Berrien of Upper Montclair, N. J., whose interest in the game began during his caddie days, became the president of the Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Inchin, a son of Brookfield, was a driving winner of the seventh and best race of the card at Tropical Park today, a mile and a sixteenth event for 2-year-olds.
A special committee set up by the American Federation of Labor to recommend machinery to keep its unions from fighting one another is in general agreement on how to ban raids within the federation.
ROME, Dec. 10 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella called upon Yugoslavia today to give proof of her desire to cooperate on a solution of the Trieste problem by laying her cards on a conference table.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Veterans' Administration said today it would pay a regular dividend of $21,000,000 next year on 375,000 Government life insurance policies held by World War I veterans. The dividend will go to those with permanent plan policies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent below the level of the corresponding week of last year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York, came out today for higher Social Security benefits and broader coverage

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Three unions of operating and office employes on Britain's nationalized railroads rejected today a wage increase of four shillings (fifty-six cents) a week, awarded by the railway staff national tribunal last week.
Leaders in education from eighteen states are among those who have answered a challenge to break the virtual monopoly on appointments to the Board of Education now held by New Yorkers.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- William L. Pfeiffer, the former Republican State Chairman who retired because of pressure of "business interests," has registered as a lobby-it for a group of engineering concerns. He will represent them in the Legislature during the 1954 session.

The holiday ham may be more costly this year if current upward retail price trends continue. In the last two weeks, regular smoked hams and the ready-to-eat variety have advanced 4 and 6 cents a pound, respectively, to 69 and 75 cents. Last year at this time they were priced at 65 and 69 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The State Department has authorized Arthur H. Dean, United States envoy and United Nations representative at Panmunjom, to return for consultations on the deadlocked Korean peace talks.
Investment bankers priced a new issue of the highest grade public utility bonds yesterday to yield to the investor an interest return of 3.15 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The State Department announced today that a fifteen-member delegation would represent the United States at the three North Atlantic Council meeting in Paris.

Gen. George C. Marshall, soldier and statesman, was rightly honored yesterday at Oslo, where he received the Nobel Prize for peace. Specifically it was for the Plan that bears his name that he received the medal and the prize. It ought not to be forgotten that this Plan was not intended to be partisan and that it was originally open to all countries willing to cooperate, including those behind the Iron Curtain.
A New York Supreme Court Justice will have to decide whether Bedloes Island, home of the Statue of Liberty, is in New York or New Jersey.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 10 -- The rival claimants to the title of presiding officer of the United States Court of Appeals in Germany entered into a tactical contest for control of the court in Frankfurt today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. L., Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower's plan for an international atomic-materials bank was praised today by Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, who four years ago urged the United Nations to concentrate on the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower today directed the United States Tariff Commission to make an immediate investigation of the effects of rye imports on the Federal price support program for the grain.
Ralph T. Seward, Washington lawyer and professional arbitrator, was named yesterday chairman of the three-man fact-finding board to-settle remaining issues from the recent newspaper strike.

Sudden, intense winds hit the New York area yesterday and injured four persons in Rockefeller Center when bits of ripped decorative metal fell from the coping of the United States Rubber Company Building.

New York Stock Exchange governors will consider on Dec. 23 transfer of the membership of the late Oliver S. Campbell to Robert L. Cahill, that of the late E. Coyne Maloney to William C. Hartmann, that of the late Frederick H. Prince to George W. Young, and that of the late Harry R. Engeman to Joel A. Batchker.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower tonight gave the eleventh in a series of White House stag dinners. Invited to tonight affair were:
OTTAWA, Dec. 10 -- Igor Gouzenko, who in 1945 exposed the operation of Soviet spy rings in Canada, has agreed to talk with representatives of the United States Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it had engaged James B. Edmunds, a retired Army colonel and specialist in motor transport maintenance, to take charge of its surface vehicle garages and repair shops at a salary of $15,000 a year.

Edgar Bergen has been signed by the Kraft Foods Company to do a weekly one-hour radio show, beginning sometime next year. Charlie McCarthy, the pal of the ventriloquist, is expected to be featured as a disk jockey, playing recorded music and interviewing persons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The National Education Association estimated today that 632,000 children this school year would be "deprived of full-time schooling" for lack of class rooms.

The concluding volumes, VII and VIII, of "The Letters of Theodore Roosevelt" have been scheduled for Feb. 28 publication by Harvard University Press. Subtitled "The Days of Armageddon," the books begin in 1909 and end with Roosevelt's death in 1919.

Bessie L. Eisenberg has sold the four-story building containing six stores and thirty-seven apartments at the southeast corner of Marine and Fourth Avenues in Brooklyn to Mr. and Mrs. Louis Waldman. The property occupies a plot about 100 by 112 feet.
Yesterday's stock market was a virtual stand-off, with the large number of stocks selling ex-dividend giving it the appearance of softness.
A collection of custom clothes designed and shown publicly for the first time by John Circe Rich was presented yesterday during luncheon in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel.

It is encouraging to note that a three-judge Federal Statutory Court has upheld a section of the bi-state waterfront reform compact banning so-called "public loaders" from the piers. We are pleased but not surprised. The bi-state compact of New York and New Jersey, adopted by the two State Legislatures, held that the "public loaders" were responsible for violence, extortion and criminal activities.
Business in the curtain and drapery manufacturing trades turned upward this week just when manufacturers and fabric converters had become resigned to slow-paced buying.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The United Electrical Workers, representing 20,000 production employes at the main General Electric Company plant here, threatened today to "take appropriate steps to protect the job security of all G. E. workers" in the face of the company's new anti-Communist policy.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Following is the message by Sir Winston Churchill accepting the 1953 Nobel Prize for Literature tonight:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday were 662,035 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 65,805 cars, or 11 per cent more than for the preceding holiday week, 57,289 or 8 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year and 111,495 or 14.4 per cent fewer than two years ago.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker, who said last night that he would not try to reach 500 victories this year, booted home three more winners at Bay Meadows today to raise his world record of season triumphs to 473.
BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Optimism in the United States' Davis Cup camp hit its highest peak of the Australian tennis campaign today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Pacific Coast Conference went on record today in favor of the new limited substitution rule in football. In an official statement the group said it would oppose any effort to return to the two-platoon system at the National Collegiate Athletic Association meeting in Cincinnati next month.
Striking drivers of private sanitation trucks voted unanimously last night to reject an employer offer of $5 a week in wage, welfare and pension benefits.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- In anticipation of a four-power foreign ministers' conference here next month. the United States Army is awakening Berlin's "sleeping castle."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- United States concern over developments in the Middle East mounted today as both Britain and Egypt began to express a "stand pat" policy toward the settlement of the bitter Suez Canal dispute.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The Government has been requested by the Church of England's Moral Welfare Council to set up an inquiry into homosexuality in this country.
Home owners and builders throughout the country soon may pay more for linoleum and other hard-surface floor and wall coverings.

The Long Island Transit Authority appealed to Governor Dewey yesterday for full state support of Federal legislation to end overlapping state and Federal jurisdiction over reorganization of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road.

When Senator McCarthy says "I will not have any further comment at all," it's a good bet that he has been defeated. That is certainly the case in the present instance. What Mr. McCarthy now promises not to comment on is the popularity contest he attempted to conjure up last week between his own foreign policy and that of the Administration.
Public hearings to expose charity rackets and wasteful use of contributions will begin here next Monday before a joint legislative committee.
An application involving United States landing rights for a British-flag all-freight airline across the North Atlantic has been taken under consideration by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The United States, Britain and France have agreed on what they want the United Nations Security Council to do about the dispute between Israel and Syria over utilization of water from the Jordan River.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady early, but eased later and closed 2 to 13 points net lower.

The New York Shipping Association recommended to its membership of 170 steamship companies and stevedores yesterday that they employ properly registered longshoremen to load and unload tracks at piers and waterfront terminals.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 10 -- The overseas territory of the United States was increased tonight by approximately 1500 square feet. The accession -- a 15-foot wide, 100-foot long strip -- came about through the visit here of Vice-President Richard M. Nixon.

ROME, Dec. 10 -- Efforts to increase agricultural production in some areas of the world will fail, the Pope said today to delegates who attended the seventh conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, unless they take social conditions into account.
Controller - elect Lawrence E. Gerosa has offered to settle his $490,000 damage suit against the city for $75,000, it was learned last night.
Diplomatic sources in this country believe that Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party boss, is settling some old scores and putting his own men in key posts during a current Soviet purge.

A grand jury will begin on Monday an investigation into the alleged failure of Brooklyn hospital officials to comply with regulations covering the admission of patients on whom criminal abortions have been performed.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -- The Motion Picture Industry Council listed today several principal reasons American movie producers are doing more filming abroad.

MONTREAL, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard scored three goals tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a penalty-studded game that took more than two and one-half hours to complete.
The American Legion added its voice yesterday to those protesting the closing of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- A survey indicates that factory employment in Nassau and Suffolk Counties may attain a peacetime high of more than 100,000 in 1954, with prospects favoring further rises in 1955. The survey was made by the Long Island Association and the New York State Department of Commerce, assisted by several local chambers of commerce.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 10 -- Chief Makomba Lugedhlama rose today before his 5,000 tribesmen in the Tenbosch area of the Transvaal, defied the Government and, in his last command to his people, told them to scatter to the four winds and forget their tribe.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- A Government attorney in the du Pont anti-trust trial today assailed a contention in the brief of the United States Rubber Company that if testimony of Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson is believed the Government's case must fall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Reduction of the number of independent agencies of the Federal Government from seventy to thirty or fewer is proposed to President Eisenhower in a report made public at the White House today.
Warm tribute to the late George McAneny was offered yesterday in the high-vaulted Federal Hall Memorial, the old Sub-Treasury at Wall and Nassau Streets.

Ten years ago this evening the City Center of Music and Drama raised its curtain to the public. The Center has yet to prove Mayor La Guardia's exuberant prophecy that it "will live for centuries to come," but the signs are hopeful for the immediate future and it certainly deserves hearty congratulations for a decade's accomplishments.
Business loans supplied by New York City banks dropped $24,000,000 last week in the third successive weekly decline.

In late fall, as regularly as a fresh nip of cold comes in the air and as shops blossom with Christmas decorations, the familiar little stamps which fight tuberculosis put in their appearance. Everyone expects them. They have come out regularly for forty-seven years. But this year their sale has not come up to the mark.

New York City has borrowed $40,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due April 27 at an interest rate of 1 3/4 per cent, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes were sold by allotment to twenty-one banks and trust companies as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The White House expressed today the hope that the Soviet Union would accept President Eisenhower's latest proposal to internationalize and harness atomic energy for peaceful purposes.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 10 -- India was understood to have completed the selection today of members of a committee to serve with Pakistanis to arrange a plebiscite in Kashmir. The committee is to serve after the appointment of a neutral administrator by April 30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Defense Secretary, may be forced to back down somewhat on his order for a 10 per cent cut in Army, Navy and Marine Corps manpower, high Defense Department officials said today.
After 211 years in business the Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company of Cincinnati has decided to discontinue operations.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Two tiny Korean war orphans got their first embrace today from a Michigan couple that adopted the children they had never seen from a Seoul orphanage.

Color -- in fabrics, clothes and accessories for the home -- strikes a cheerful note in a new shop, Eshkanian-McIntyre, as well as in some additions to the wares at Hanlan Associates. The former shop is at 111 Seventh Avenue South (at Sheridan Square), the latter at 129 MacDougal Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The recent attempt of a single Senator to invoke an imposing national poll in favor of his stand against a major foreign policy endorsed by the President was notably unsuccessful. But this result does not obscure an underlying fact that the President and the Secretary of State will be wise to keep constantly in mind.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The Labor party threw down today the gantlet of a motion of censure against the Government on African colonial affairs.
Orlando Zulueta, Cuban lightweight, will oppose Wallace (Bud) Smith of Cincinnati in the feature event of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Ailing with an injured knee and elbow, Bob Cousy, the Boston Celtics' slippery, high scoring operative,' had been scheduled to be used sparingly last night. The plan had to be shelved, however, as the Celtics won a two-overtime period game from the Knickerbockers, 113-108.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Justice Henry Clay Greenberg of the New York Supreme Court today asked the Subversive Activities Control Board for a ninety-day postponement of hearings on the International Workers Order, a fraternal insurance group.

Liselotte Koestec Stahl, of the ballet team of Koester and Stahl, was denied entry into the country on medical grounds by the United States Public Health Service after her arrival yesterday with her husband on the French liner Liberte.
A mechanical device that can spend part of the time in the dentist's chair while the patient stays home was described here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The far-flung work of American Red Cross volunteers was hailed tonight by General Charles L. Bolte, Vice Chief of Staff of the Army.

W. W. (Pudge) Heffelfinger, one of football's immortal players, last night was honored by the Touchdown Club of New York at that organization's twentieth annual dinner at the Hotel Astor. More than 350 persons, most of them prominently identified with football in the past or present, attended the affair.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 10 -- King Haakon VII saved an embarrassing situation today when a noisy Communist demonstration marred the presentation of the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize to General of the Army George C. Marshall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower summarily removed two Democrats today from $14,000-a-year places on the War Claims Commission and appointed Republicans to succeed them.

HANOVER, Germany, Dec. 10 (UP) -- A British airborne private told a press conference today of being questioned sixteen hours a day, kicked, beaten and punched while held in Soviet prisons for eight years on espionage charges.

SANTO DOMINGO, Chile, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Gaabor Benedek, a 26-year-old Hungarian white-collar worker, today finished first in the 4,000-meter cross-country run to win the world modern pentathlon tournament. Sweden captured the team title.

Carolyn Schnurer's seventh trip to far-away countries resulted in one of the most appealing of her foreign-inspired collections of sportswear. This time it was the mosques, minarettes and bazaars of Turkey that gave her designing talent fresh inspiration.

NEWARK, Dec. 10 -- The State Board of Mediation today presented to the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and 1,800 striking gas distribution and maintenance employes a formula for settlement of the three-week-old strike.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 10 -- Assets of the nation's savings and loan associations have jumped from $10 billions to more than $25 billions since World War II, Walter W. McAllister, chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board, said here today at the semi-annual meeting of the New Jersey Savings and Loan League.

Plans for establishing new headquarters on the East Side were announced yesterday by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization in America, Inc., which has purchased for the purpose the five brownstone houses at 63 to 71 East Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A Shouting almost hysterical witness who sought a chance to deny under oath that he ever spied against this country was ejected from a hearing of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigations sub-committee.

As a Briton who (as your columns will confirm) has consistently opposed formal recognition of Communist China and its admission to the United Nations I ask your hospitality for some observations on the proposal to bludgeon America's allies (specifically the United Kingdom) into cutting off all trade with Red China.

Two means of reducing competitive bidding for athletic talent among colleges and universities were proposed to the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday by Dr. E. Kenneth Smiley, vice president of Lehigh University.

Look about you. How many of our friends and acquaintances we paid a visit to a hospital, and returned in better health ? There is a good reason why the hospitals of today are knitting more bodies and saving more lives than in bygone years. Advances in techniques and in medicine -- many of them developed in the hospitals' own laboratories -- are put to everyday use. Years are being added to life.
BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Walter Ulbricht, acting Premier of East Germany, said today that he "welcomed" Western acceptance of the Soviet proposal to hold the coming foreign ministers' conference in Berlin.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 10 -- A conference of representatives of all territories in Southern Africa to deal with race questions has been proposed.
All three ocean-going salvage vessels of Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation are engaged in refloating operations on three ships stranded in the Caribbean and South Atlantic.

Since John Murray Anderson is the king of revues, it is practically inevitable that his "Almanac" should turn out to be a bright and brilliant show. With an excellent cast that includes Hermione Gingold, it opened at the Imperial last evening to an audience that could enjoy the scenery but also laugh at the jokes.

THE "whodunits" and police yarns on television are cut from such sterotyped cloth that it is becoming increasingly hard to tell one show from another. The hero is usually a smugly knowledgeable gent who shaves once a day, smokes the sponsor's brand of cigarettes, takes himself very seriously and ignores the blandishments of the luscious dish who is the villain's moll.
Heart disease in all its forms, the nation's No. 1 killer, will cost life insurance companies $1,000,000,000 in death claims this year.

QUINCY, Mass., Dec. 10 -- The Marine Dow-Chem, first ocean-going tanker ever built in this country expressly for the transport of bulk liquid chemicals, was launched here today from the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard.
AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 10 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States Representative to the United Nations, paid tribute to Wendell L. Willkie tonight as a "man of foresight and integrity."

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Patrolman Elmer Dolan has been suspended from the Police Department and formal charges will be filed against him and former Police Lieut. Louis Shoulders as a result of their handling of the Greenlease kidnapping case.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 10 (UP) -- Jack Sheehan, president of the Springfield Cubs, resigned today and observers believed the action might be a forerunner of the abandonment of an International League team here by the parent Chicago Cubs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Hi-Lo's Forbes, Keystoner and Adois Boy won honors in their age groups today as a panel of 112 turf writers selected them as the top 1953 pacers in the poll for the United States Trotting Association's Harness Horse of the Year.

New approaches to handling United States trade and tariff policies were proposed yesterday by two major business groups, the American Iron and Steel Institute and the National Council of American Importers.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- The Sudan's pro-Egyptian National Union party, which recently won a large majority for the Sudanese lower house, today led the poll for the Senate, election results showed.
Ralph R. Stubbe has been appointed chief engineer of the General Instrument Corporation, manufacturer of television, radio and electronic components.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 10 -- With one voice, all the political parties in the West German Parliament reaffirmed today their hopes for the reunification of this country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- During the week ended Dec. 9, member bank reserves increased $246,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The wholesale price of gasoline will be reduced today by .2 cent a gallon throughout eighteen Eastern states and the District of Columbia. This cut is the second in the last six weeks, the first having been .3 cent a gallon.

The closing of "South Pacific," one of the great musicals of the American stage, is now official for Jan. 16 at the Broadway Theatre. When the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d-Joshua Logan show, inspired by James A. Michener's Pulitzer Prize novel, "Tales of the South Pacific," rings down its final curtain, it will have been performed for the 1,925th time under the combined auspices of Messrs. Rodgers, Hammerstein, Logan and Leland Hayward.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Ed Sanford scored three goals tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Detroit Red Wings by 6 to 3 before 6,947 fans at the Boston Garden.

Mid - Manhattan Magistrate's Court at 153 East Fifty-seventh Street will be eliminated and its quarters assigned to social courts dealing with vice, narcotics and probation cases. Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh made the announcement yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Foreign Minister Walter Guevara Arze of Bolivia said today that a loan of $9,000,000 recently obtained from the United States would provide farm credits for the host of new land-holders established through his country's agrarian reform of last August.
Mieczyslaw Morszowski, pianist, played a recital program of unusual interest at Town Hall last evening.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Sir Winston Churchill, in a Nobel Prize acceptance speech read by his wife, counseled mankind tonight to be tolerant and calm in this "age of storm and tragedy" where "the power of man has grown in every sphere except over himself."

Customs collections at the Port New York last month totaled $29,268,447, an increase of $1,871,069 over a year ago, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs here, reported yesterday. However, the November revenue was only $7,265 above October.
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. condemned the McCarren-Walter Immigration Law last night, terming it "an ugly monument to the theories of racism and isolationism.
George Szell arranged an attractive program, the Philharmonic-Symphony was in good form, and Carnegie Hall turned out an agreeable place to be last night.

Lady Dhanvanthi Rama Rau of India was honored by Barnard College yesterday for her contribution to the advancement of women's rights and the general welfare of India. Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard, gave her a citation from Barnard and a souvenir bicentennial medallion from Columbia University.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Strong bidding for leading South African goldmining shares was a main feature of the stock markets today. Prices jumped on reports of a rich strike in Orange Free State by the Geduld Mine and optimistic remarks by the chairman of the Consolidated Gold Fields.

A person discharged from a job for refusal to answer a Congressional committee's questions about Communist activity is guilty of misconduct and cannot receive unemployment benefits for seven weeks after his discharge, a state unemployment insurance referee held yesterday.

Events tonight: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 o'clock; Radcliffe Choral Society and New York University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; British Festival Concert, Juilliard School, 8:30; People's Chorus of New York, Christmas concert, Waldorf-Astoria, 8:30.

HANOI, Vietnam, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- The French High Command said today it had rushed 136 planeloads of reinforcements, arms and supplies to Dienbienphu as 12,000 Communist-led Vietminh rebels closed in on the mountain fortress.

IN an Alice in Wonderland setting where things are not always what they seem, the major league owners have set in motion the dissolution of the players' pension plan. But the magnates insist, almost with sobs in their voice, that they have no intention of ever dissolving it. The pension plan is wonderful. They're all for it. They want it to continue. But . . .

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Grain and soybean trading was affected by a sharp upturn in rye futures and closed mainly higher today. Active buying of rye futures was prompted by news that President Eisenhower had directed the Tariff Commission to investigate the effects of rye imports on the domestic support program for that grain.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 10 -- The Netherlands Government has reversed its decision against purchasing American farm surpluses and is negotiating for them.

LONDOON, Dec. 11 -- Prices continued to fall on the stock markets here today, mainly under the influence of uneasiness about the labor situation in major industries. Nevertheless, the atmosphere was not as dull as yesterday and some gains offset losses.

A group of stars will shine under the floodlights of Bear Mountain Park tonight when the Eastern ski jumping season gets under way. Art Tokle, national champion, and Mezzy Barber and Art Devlin, past titleholders, will be among those competing. The field will be enlarged for the ninth annual Torger Tokle Memorial jump tomorrow afternoon.
DENVER, Colo., Dec. 11 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee will begin an investigation here tomorrow of charges made in a controversy over the dismissal of a United States Attorney.
The twenty-five-year opposition of the Police Department to smaller taxis has been reversed by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.
Joseph A. Meek has been appointed director of industrial relations of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- The Government has approved a bill designed to remove obstacles to foreign investment in Turkey, an official announcement said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The United States has asked the Soviet Union to give full and serious study to President Eisenhower's proposal for an international pool of atomic-energy materials as a most significant step toward world peace and stability.

Husbands with complaints that their wives spend money too freely might have done well had they sent their spouses to Gimbels yesterday. There they could have watched 760 of the smartest little Christmas shoppers in town.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A Government housing program was drawing criticism here today before details even had been formally released. It probably will not be submitted to President Eisenhower for some days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Fish and Wildlife Service today extended the 1953-54 hunting season for migratory waterfowl in West Virginia and New York. Shooting in those states was curtailed during the prescribed seasons because of the unusual fire hazard caused by drought.

NEWARK, Dec. 11 -- Deputy Police Chief Hugh O'Gorman said today that Mrs. Henry Leibel, 49-year-old mother of four children, had signed a statement admitting she bludgeoned her widowed sister-in-law to death with an axe yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Average weekly earnings of production workers in Hollywood studios since last January fluctuated between $107 in May to $118.19 in June.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 11 -- Two American musicians were among eleven prize winners tonight in an international competition for contemporary orchestra compositions.

City College of New York yesterday cited the war record of its students and alumni in answer to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's remark on Thursday about holding a "class reunion" of the City College graduates he had questioned.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Scarce American tractors bought at exorbitant prices with United States lend-lease money for export to South America may have ended up in Communist hands, an Alabama farm equipment dealer told a state examining board.

Lumber production in the week ended Dec. 5 was 6.1 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 3.3 per cent and orders were up 1.3 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower appealed today for generous support of the various volunteer organizations providing relief for victims of the recent fire in Pusan, Korea. He issued this statement:

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 10 -- A great debate is under way in Puerto Rico on the question of the island's relationship with the United States. It will probably result in a formal request to Washington for more autonomy for the Island government.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:
Resales by operators featured Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

Determined to give Steve Owen, their well-liked coach, a winning send-off to his front-office job, the New York Football Giants bore down in practice yesterday. They will play their final 1953 game against the Detroit Lions at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 11 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan said today that Negroes, Indians and others proscribed by racism would be excluded by Government action from South Africa's two leading universities, Capetown and Witwatersrand.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Governor Dewey of New York told President Eisenhower and his staff today about two fights he would like to win in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Georgia R. Lusk, former Democratic Representative, said today she had decided to accept as final President Eisenhower's removal of her as a war claims commissioner.

FONTHILL, Ont., Dec. 11 (UP) -- Marlene Stewart, who brought home the nation's first victory in the British open golf tournament, was named today by British United Press client editors Canada's sports figure of the year.

After more than two months of tension, which at one time assumed explosive proportions, the situation in and around Trieste is getting back to "normal." The rival Italian and Yugoslav troops which had marched against each other toward their joint frontier are marching back again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Representative J. Harry McGregor, Republican of Ohio, predicted today that Congress would continue the 2-cent Federal gasoline tax instead of letting it drop automatically to 1 1/2 cents on April 1 as scheduled.
Screams of children frightened by the discovery of two snakes at a Manhattan playground last night attracted more than 200 persons to the scene and gave the police a ticklish hour's work.

As has become its habit more and more in recent weeks, the stock market reversed its direction in the closing hours of yesterday's trading. This time, however, the downward trend had been so gentle that a tiny advance was able to leave The New York Times combined average with a plus sign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy reported today he had information indicating that some 125 German Communists had infiltrated the office of the United States High Commissioner in Germany.
A four-story dwelling at 30- 32 Thirty-second Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Gabor Marklari from A. Koetzl. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The physical change in the name of West Fifty-fifth Street, between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, to City Center Street, lasted only a week. The spiritual change, however, was never more apparent than last night.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 12 -- The United Nations Command will make its first effort Monday to convince the American soldier-prisoners who have thus far chosen to remain with the Communists in Korea to return to their homes and families.

We believe that the Supreme Court majority was correct when, by six to three, it ruled that an attack on the quality and facilities of a television broadcasting station program by strikers was a valid cause for dismissal on "disloyalty" grounds. The case involves the Charlotte, N. C., television station WBTV and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. L. affiliate.

Kid Gavilan yesterday was named the fighter of the year by the New York Boxing Writers Association. The balloting, which took place at the organization's meeting at Al and Dick's Restaurant, earned for the Cuban boxer the Edward J. Neil plaque, which will be presented to him at the annual dinner of the association at the Hotel Astor on Jan. 14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Admiral Emory S. Land, wartime head of the Maritime Commission and War Shipping Administration, resigned today as president of the Air Transport Association, effective Dec. 31.
HAVANA, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The American Embassy replied today to strong Cuban criticism of the United States Government for the recent arrest in Miami of Carlos Prio Socarras, former Cuban President.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The Government has been forced into wholesale abandonment of most of the charges it made in its complaint in June, 1949, in the du Pont anti-trust case, it was charged here today. John M. Harlan, defense counsel made the assertion in opening oral arguments in Federal District Court for the defense.
Scathing attacks on what they called unjustified accusations of Communist sympathies were made last night at Columbia University by two educators.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The 1954 Maryland racing season will open March 22 at Laurel and close Dec. 4 at Bowie under dates assigned the state's three major tracks today by the Maryland Racing Commission.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 11 -- Dr. Albert C. Jacobs, president of Trinity College, declared tonight that "unless freedom of expression is fully protected, consistent with the national security," this country was in danger of falling into a "pattern of thinking that will preclude new ideas and will stifle future advances."
Mothers should never economize on baby-sitters, is the advice given by The Two to Five World Newsletter, a monthly journal for parents of pre-schoolers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Dr. Charles A. Malik of Lebanon charged today that Israel's preparations to divert water from the Jordan River were intended to bring about the "Israelization" of the demilitarized zone between Israel and Syria.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Western Conference (Big Ten) today took the position tthat the National Collegiate Athletic Association must break up football television into regionally limited offerings or face an entire collapse of its controlled program.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Gilbert Gay's Brother Friar, under a light impost, won his first race of 1953 as he toyed with eight other 3-year-olds in the $2,400 Ventura purse at Tropical Park today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The Pacific Coast League directors voted today to leave the San Francisco Seals baseball franchise in conditional custody of Damon Miller's "little corporation," thus assuring fans of a home-owned club here next season.
GARFIELD, N. J., Dec. 11 -- Most of the teachers in this Bergen County industrial city of 28,000 went on strike today for higher salaries. As a result, all nine public schools here were closed.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Some European officials are counting on the discussions next week of the 1954 North Atlantic Treaty defense program to clarify the intentions of the United States and Britain regarding commitments on the European Continent.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 11 -- Efforts of Jackie Robinson, the Brooklyn Dodgers' baseball star, to find a home for his family in the residential district of North Stamford has touched off a widening controversy.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A definite decline in willingness and ability of buyers to pay their bills was noted today by the American Collectors Association, largest organization of bill collecting agencies.
ROME. Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations aimed tonight its 1954 sights on feeding more people -- instead of just growing more food.
L. D. Freeman's new play of life among the Louisiana Cajuns, "Black Candle," is closer to a Broadway production with the engagement of Richard Barr as director.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Admiral Robert B. Carney said tonight that the Soviet Union was determined to challenge United States sea supremacy by buying merchant ships from our "friends and allies" so Soviet yards could concentrate on warships.

Events today: "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Rudolf Firkusny, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Robert Casadesus, pianist, Hunter College, 8:30.

Between Oct. 31 and Nov. 30 the average price per share of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose 47 cents, the Exchange reported yesterday. The average went up from $39.78 to $40.25, the highest month-end figure since May 31.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- A Queens attorney with the hobby of testing reapportionment legislation went into court today to combat the recently adopted Republican plan for redrawing the state's Senate lines.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- A diplomatic artifice today permitted the signature of five European conventions that have been blocked for months in the Council of Europe by the French-German controversy over the Saar.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Jim Welch, 18-year-old newspaper copy boy who donated a segment of the bone from his left leg to an ailing girl, is amazed to find himself nationally spotlighted. As gifts and laudatory messages pile up in his hospital room, Jim said today he could not understand why there should be so much fuss over a "routine matter."
New York's famed receptions to heroes and dignitaries for the last thirty-five years will be revived vicariously through photographs in an exhibit that will be open to the public beginning Dec. 21.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Discussions on railroad wages went on all day today and are to continue tomorrow, strengthening hope that a rail strike or disorganization may be averted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today the withdrawal of the Government's 1952 civil anti-trust suit against the Sunbeam Corporation of Chicago. The suit had challenged the company's distribution contracts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Judge Richmond B. Keech of the United States District Court ruled today that when the Washington Redskins paid off Guard John De Laurentis in 1952, the money was compensation for injuries, not a settlement of a breach of contract claim.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has affirmed the permit it gave the Isbrandtsen Lines in mid-September to establish a new intercoastal steamship service from the West Coast to the East Coast.

The Festival of British Music that the Juilliard School of Music has been sponsoring in its concert hall for the last two weeks came to a close last night with a performance of "Britannia Triumphans." Considering that this was most likely the first performance since its premiere in 1637, one can safely claim for the event a certain amount of novelty.

The operators of Roosevelt Raceway made the first court challenge yesterday of the powers and scope of the Moreland Act Commission named by Governor Dewey to investigate the state's harness racing tracks.
Following is a round-up describing home furnishing shows of various types that opened during the newspaper strike.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- While sanctioning the rearmament of Western Europe and the maintenance of United States troops there, Hans Morgenthau, University of Chicago political science professor, cited today "two basic mistakes" in this country's European defense policies.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Carl Austin Hall, the kidnap-killer of 6-year-old Bobby Greenlease, planned to slay his partner. Mrs. Bonnie Brown Heady, former police Lieut. Louis Shoulders said tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Dec 11 (AP) -- James P. Finnegan, a friend of former President Truman, surrendered today to begin serving a two-year prison term for official misconduct as an internal revenue collector here.
HONG KONG, Dec. 11 -- Information reaching here indicates that the Chinese Communist regime is making the most intense effort since it was established to collect food grains from farmers.

MINEOLA, Dec. 11 -- The Nassau police became interested in Eugene J. Carroll, 27-year-old salesman, on Tuesday after his wife, Joan, said he threatened her with a pistol. Today they seized him on charges of felonious assault and suspicion of burglary.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Gustavus T. Kirby of the Columbia class of '95 received the annual Lion Award of the Columbia Alumni Club of Central Westchester at its annual smoker in the Larchmont Yacht Club tonight. The citation was "for distinguished service to his university, his community and to amateur sports."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 11 -- Five anti-Communist parties submitted a motion in Parliament today that opposes a recent reorganization of the Army's General Staff. The action might force a reshuffle of the Cabinet in the next fortnight.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- It is the responsibility of every parent to discard or repair broken toys and dangerous playthings that can be potentially as threatening to children as forbidden adult weapons, according to the Institute for Safer Living of the American Mutual Liability Insurance Company. This advice was offered by the institute in a statement this week.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman declared last night that the Soviet cause had gained more from the "paralyzing influence of McCarthyism" than it could have from a knowledge of all of the country's vital defense secrets.

The fact that the American representative in Korea, Arthur H. Dean, has been authorized to return to the United States to report does not mean that the negotiation with the Communists on a projected peace conference has completely broken down. It does mean, however, that we are once more faced with the stubborn problem of trying to reach an agreement with those who are not disposed to agree on anything except their own terms.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov said today that "attempts to revive German militarism are causing justified concern to all peaceloving peoples in Europe."

BLUE POINT, L. I., Dec. 11 -- The longest television marathon on record came to an end at 1:15 P. M. today, when a woman's face, which for fifty-one hours seemed to be tattoed on a TV screen here, was lost to view as abruptly and mysteriously as it had first appeared about 10 A. M. Wednesday.
