A fact-finding board will hold its first hearing today on the wage and hour issues of the recent newspaper strike.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 11 -- Communist China officially joined the Soviet Union and India today in objecting to Pakistani negotiations for defensive military aid from the United States. The Government said the Chinese protest had been given to the Pakistan Ambassador, Maj. Gen. Nawabzada Agha Mohammed Raza, in Peiping.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 11 -- One thousand Pakistani crane operators whose two week's pay is less than a day's wage of a United States seaman agreed on the second day of their strike to return to the docks for fifteen days pending further arbitration.

The New York Central Railroad soon will start proceedings in the New York Supreme Court to determine its rights in the sale of real estate in the Grand Central Terminal area. William White, president, announced yesterday. He said the road had an offer from Webb Knapp, Inc., to purchase the 270 Park Avenue property and also the Yale Club and Vanderbilt Concourse properties.
The American Merchant Marine Library Association has released its nineteenth annual Christmas sea letter, an appeal for funds to help it keep going as the "public library of the high seas."
MIAMI, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Doug Ford, closing out his most profitable year on the golf trail, was hot after another big prize today as he took the second-round lead in the $10,000 Miami open tournament.

The rise in the price of fluid milk has prompted the local office of the New York State Extension Service in Marketing to turn its attention to the economics of family milk buying. It asks and answers this question:

Several books published this year, both fiction and nonfiction, have presented life in South Africa with emphasis on the racial problem. On Jan. 20, Crowell will publish "Red Dust of Kenya," by Alyse Simpson, which bypasses that question. The author describes her life as a young bride who chose to follow her husband from her own tranquil Swiss village into the desolate wastes of Kenya.

The financing volume of the specialized finance industry, which supplies dollar sinews for manufacturers, processors and distributors, will total about $33,000,000,000 this year, it was reported yesterday by Theodore H. Silbert, president of Standard Factors Corporation.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned from Bermuda today intent on countering the Russian campaign to divide the Western Allies before the proposed foreign ministers conference in Berlin.

Friends of Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, have urged him to become a candidate for Democratic National Committee-man to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader. They have informed him that enough votes in the Democratic State Committee are in sight, both in the city and upstate, to insure his election.
Motion pictures taken with X-rays at the moment of birth of laboratory animals suggest that usual obstretical practices may contribute to high human infant death rates in the first day of life.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Judge Clark gained support from a former colleague today in his fight against his ouster by the State Department.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- A Foreign Office spokesman sharply denied today reports that John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State and President Eisenhower during the recent Bermuda conference had sought to change Britain's stand in the Suez negotiations with Egypt.
Mediation efforts in the strike of private refuse truck drivers were postponed yesterday until Monday.
BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- Soviet acceptance of the Western invitation to open the proposed foreign minister's talks in West Berlin Jan. 4 appeared highly probable today.

One of the strangest and most important legal cases in Latin-American history has once again come to the fore in recent days. It is the case of the Peruvian political leader, Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, who sought asylum in the Colombian Embassy in Lima on Jan. 3, 1949, and who is still there.

Five adjoining apartment buildings housing 100 families at 1763 to 79 Fulton Avenue in the Bronx have been purchased by Home Properties, Inc., operators. They are assessed at $180,000 and were sold subject to mortgages of $128,000.
Dividend action taken by company directors yesterday was not all on the favorable side. Two companies omitted dividends, another deferred action, and several others declared smaller payments.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -A substantial amount of profit taking in both grain and soybean futures proved hard to digest in the grain market today, and there were sharp declines all along the line while. The declines were for a liter reduced or eliminated.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- British scientists now declare that at least one of the so-called flint tools found with the skull of the Piltdown Man is as bogus as the bottom jaw.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that its store sales of television receivers last month had been three times those in October. The report was made by R. L. Sandefur, sales manager of the company's radio and television division.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- The Foreign Oil Policy Committee, called upon President Eisenhower today to begin an investigation of the importation of residual oil.
Out in Oklahoma City they know what Gayla Peevey's going to get for Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Harold Worden Mosher, 27 years old, a television repairman, testified today that he joined the Communist party in New Haven, Conn., in 1947 as an undercover man for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday yielded to pressure from New Orleans and elsewhere in the South. Prices dropped to new lows for the season. and to net losses of 18 to 25 points.

The United Jewish Appeal's constituent agencies reported yesterday that $119,921,150 would be required next year to aid needy Jewish men, women and children here and throughout the world. Special emphasis was placed on Israel because of that country's economic problems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 --A small, soft-spoken divorcee from Ithaca, N. Y., defied Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today as he sought to get her to admit or deny that she or her former husband had engaged in espionage.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Former State Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of the State Crime Commission, will head the joint legislative committee for the bicentennial of Columbia University. Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of Mr. Proskauer to lead the state's official delegation to next year's celebration.

Elimination of a $100,000 allocation for preparing plans for two new ferryboats for the Manhattan-Staten Island service from the city's new capital budget was viewed yesterday as a temporary measure by Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

Times Square with its theatres, lights and crowds is one of New York City's greatest attractions. The city government is represented there with a Police Information Booth, at Forty-third Street, which was built five years ago and which looks now as though it had never been painted since.
The Public Service Commission rejected yesterday an application by the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road for an increase of 12.9 per cent in commutation fares and 5 per cent in single trip rates.

The Mergenthaler Linotype Company, manufacturer of type-setting machines and composing-room appliances, reported yesterday its net income for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 at $1,651,409, against $1,605,936 the year before.

DALLAS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The faculty committee, the law-making body of the Southwest Conference, opened its winter meeting today with an intimation that Texas Tech again would be submitted for membership.
The National Labor Relations Board called off yesterday a "last offer" vote among East Coast longshoremen. The balloting, required under the Taft-Hartley Act, had been scheduled tentatively...

VIENNA, Dec. 11 -- Austria is dissatisfied with the manner in which Italy has been implementing her agreement to grant autonomy in part to the South Tyrol. She will bring, the matter officially to Italy's attention.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Novadel-Agene Corporation, and Wallace Tiernan Company today filed a merger certificate after a Delaware chancery court vacated a preliminary injunction issued Nov. 25 to bar the merger.

DES MOINES, Ia., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Forest Evashevski, who has made it clear he would like to round out his football coaching career at the State University of Iowa, received his wish today, a new ten-year contract.

Every morning during the Bermuda conference Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles had a rendezvous for an early swim from the secluded beach of the Mid-Ocean Club. Only the tame waves breaking softly on the sunny shore could hear what was said in these well-guarded tete-a-tetes, but they probably accomplished more in the way of mutual understanding than the more formal discussions at the conference table.

Bishop William C. Martin of the Methodist Area of Dallas, Tex., who is president of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., personally will convey Christmas greetings to United States troops in Korea and Japan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Army will draft 18,000 men in February, the smallest monthly intake since June of 1952. The figure was disclosed today by Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today that the Democrats should be represented when Senate Republican investigators interviewed Igor Gouzenko, the man whose testimony exposed a world-wide Communist atomic spy ring.

Both television and radio will cover an address tonight by Adlai E. Stevenson at the Atlantic States Regional Conference and dinner of the Democratic National Committee in Philadelphia. The address will be presented over Channel 2 and WABC radio at 11 o'clock and by WCBS radio at 11:30.

The one-story taxpayer containing nine stores at 5501-17 Thirteenth Avenue in Brooklyn has been purchased by the Lilro Management Corporation in a transaction negotiated by Lennard Sons, Inc., as brokers. Leon Weinstock was attorney for the sellers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have no reason to believe that Edgar Snow, Wilma Fairbank, John K. Fairbank or Benjamin Schwartz ever had any connection with the Communist party, nor did I intend to imply any such thing. Indeed, one of the purposes of filing this particular dispatch was to demonstrate the dangers of just such charges in the Davies case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A patent on an elaborate automatic store, invented by the late Clarence Saunders, was issued to his assignee, Automatic Systems Corporation, Memphis, Tenn. Mr. Saunders was the inventor of the Piggly Wiggly, Keedoozle and other merchandising systems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, left today for the Paris meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization with a reminder to the free world that it must "maintain the power to defend against and strike back against any aggressor."

" I remember the little wooden house in which I lived," a fourth-grader wrote recently about his past in Puerto Rico. "It had a porch. I would run from the street to my mother's arms. She would hold me in her lap and sing a soft song."

NEWARK, Dec. 11 -- Representatives of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and 1,800 striking gas distribution and maintenance workers were unable to agree today on details of an arbitration formula that would end the twenty-two-day work stoppage.

Stockholders of New York Air Brake Company, at a special meeting here yesterday, approved a plan to merge its subsidiary, Kinney Manufacturing Company, into the parent concern. The plan provides that 4 1/4 shares of Air Brake common be exchanged for each Kinney preferred share outstanding and three shares of Air Brake common for each share of Kinney common.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Four Milwaukee players scored in double figures tonight to lead the Hawks to an 82 -- 70 triumph over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ralph H. Demmler, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today he will recommend an increase from $300,000 to $500,000 in the amount of new security offerings which can be exempted from strict S. E. C. filing regulations.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 11 -- Premier Nguyen Van Tam charged Vietnam's Chief of State, Bao Dai, today with conservatism and inactivity, and it therefore appeared unlikely that Bao Dai could keep the Premier in office.

Neither the Post Office Department nor the Civil Aeronautics Board has prepared a preliminary report on the current experimental transportation of first class mail by the scheduled airlines, but there are indications that the project may be extended beyond its trial period.

LYNN, Mass., Dec. 11 -- Albert F. Fitzgerald, president of the United Electrical Workers Union, independent, indicated today that he might petition for another National Labor Relations Board election next year if the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., declined to participate in "joint contract negotiations" in General Electric plants, here and in Everett.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The United States is seeking to encourage the free nations of Asia to initiate an alliance among themselves to strengthen their defenses against any new Communist aggression.

Most commodities on the New York exchanges registered greater activity yesterday than is normal before a week-end. Coffee continued active and burlap had the second highest volume of the year, trailing the sales for Sept. 14 by one contract.

William B. Kuntz of Bonnie Briar Country Club was re-elected president of the Westchester County Golf Association at the annual meeting of the organization yesterday. Along with Kuntz, the entire board of officers was renamed during the session at the Hotel Roosevelt.
OSLO, Norway, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Nobel lecture delivered by Gen. George C. Marshall today at the Oslo University Festival Hall:

In the past eleven months, Treasury figures reveal, sales of "E" and "H" savings bonds -- the two securities issued particularly with the small investor in mind --have exceeded the total for the corresponding period in 1952 by 23 per cent. Cash sales of the two issues have exceeded redemptions, since Jan. 1, by a margin of $181.6 millions.

Madison Square Garden double-header and Columbia's debut against Army in the Columbia gymnasium tonight are the local highlights of college basketball's most active Saturday to date. A leading item of interest farther afield will be the opening of the Eastern Intercollegiate League's fiftieth championship season.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 11 -- The wool selling season is now half over and up to Oct. 31 brokers had sold 111,217,000 worth, or about 16,000,000 more than in the comparable period of last season. If values remain steady the 1953-54 crop should bring about 440,000,000, or 35,000,000 more than that of 1952-53.

NEW DELHI, India. Dec. 11 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru warned the people today that India would have to be "prepared to face all contingencies in the future" as a result of talks going on between the United States and Pakistan for conclusion of a military alliance.
OTTAWA, Dec. 11 -Canada's newsprint- makers were as pleased as New York straphangers that the ten-day-old newspaper strike on New York nawspapers is over.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 762 pints of blood on Thursday. In the total were 154 from employes of security and bond houses completing a four-day collection at the New York Stock Exchange. Also on Thursday Masons gave 201 pints at the Grand Lodge, 71 West Twenty-third Street.
ROME, Dec. 11 -- The most successful strike of Government employes and workers in Italy since World War II partly paralyzed the country today.

DESPITE the bluebird weather and the possible recourse to rock (striped bass) fishing on Pamlico Sound, we decided to try for ducks and geese on one of the shallow ponds near Oregon Inlet, for our first day at Nags Head, N. C. It was extremely productive even if the weather man did not cooperate.

Women headed by Mrs. Louis E. McFadden have arranged the annual holiday benefit in behalf of the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women for the night of Dec. 22 at the Christmas show at Radio City Music Hall.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A Washington dispatch signed by James Reston, dated Dec. 8, referred to "a mixed crew of Communists and liberals" identified as "Anna Louise Strong, Agnes Smedley, Benjamin Schwartz, Edgar Snow, John K. Fairbank and his wife, Wilma Fairbank." The reporter speculates whether John Davies, a Foreign Service officer, proposed to enlist "these persons" "in behalf of the Communist conspiracy, and because he was soft on communism."

One of the great art and literary collections of modern times, brought together by a former worker in the oil fields of Oklahoma, changed hands recently in what is considered the most remarkable transaction of its kind in decades.
TAUNTON, Mass., Dec. 11 -- A 273-day blackout of Taunton police news ended today, although the editor of The Daily Gazette still had his fingers crossed.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Peter Thorneycroft, President of the Board of Trade, announced today that British exports in November amounted to 239,900,000 ($671,720,000), the highest of any month since March, 1952.
Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan warned yesterday that he would take drastic disciplinary action against any policeman who shakesdown business men for Christmas gifts.

In financial circles the Mississippi River Fuel Corporation generally is considered to be a utility. William G. Marbury, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts at a meeting held in Schwartz's Restaurant the other day that the concern actually derives about 60 per cent of its revenues from non-utility drilling operations, such as selling gas to industrial users and oil and gas operations.
Two women sculptors working in near-realist styles are among the large number of artists exhibiting their work this week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Times on Nov. 24 printed an interesting story from its London correspondent, Drew Middleton, describing the departure by air of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth and her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, for an extended tour of the British Empire, which is to last six months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. They remained at 110.1 per cent of the 1947-49 base level.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 11 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Iranian Premier Fazlollah Zahedi discussed today current problems of this nation and the United States' role in the past and the future in helping solve them.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ted Williams, Boston Red Sox star, won individual honors today in the international sailfish tournament. He boated two more sailfish to give his team the international championship.
Significant progress on all major fronts of science is described in the annual yearbook of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, released yesterday by its president, Dr. Vannevar Bush.
A water-cooled gas refrigerator that has been condemned by the city as unsafe must be replaced by an adequate unit if a landlord wishes to forestall a rent reduction.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Parts of a mural painting of the fist half of the fourteenth century have been discovered at the Tower of London during repairs to the Byward Tower.

Following the recommendation of its committee on advertiser relations, the American Association of Advertising Agencies has reissued its booklet "Standards of Practice" and suggests that members give it wide circulation.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Acting Gov. C. E. Johns suspended the five-man State Road Board and the Hotel Commissioner today in a strong bid for control of the administration he inherited in September when Gov. Dan McCarty died.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Peter Thorneycroft, President of the Board of Trade, announced today that British exports in November amounted to 239,900,000 ($671,720,000), the highest of any month since March, 1952.

RICHMOND, Va. Dec. 11 (UP) -- Pleas to bolster football squads by making freshmen eligible failed by two votes to win the approval of the Southern Conference today, although half the league's ten members joined in the request.

For the first time in the history of the sport at the school, Iona College's basketball team is facing a schedule of major proportions. A seasoned outfit with ten letter men as its nucleus, the Gaels have the necessary height, speed and know-how to carve another fine record under Coach Jim McDermott.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 11 (AP) -- What started as a pleasant dinner meeting of the Milwaukee County Medical Society wound up in a sharp debate when the guest speaker attacked the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A proposal to have states take over several welfare programs now run by the Federal Government, and to finance the operations from tax sources now monopolized by Washington, was made by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- North Atlantic Treaty Organization experts have decided on the basis of military calculations that there should be no relaxation of the Allies' defense efforts.

In several short weeks the year 1953 will end. Many of us will have gone through the year in good health. But close to 1,000,000 men, women and children will have sought help in the voluntary hospitals of New York.

Today's new film is "Anna-purna," a Technicolor documentary of the Himalayan conquest made by the French expedition of Maurice Herzog, at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux Theatre. The English commentary was adapted by Janet Adam Smith and Nea Morin, translators of M. Herzog's book.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The Labor Department reported today that 1,102,000 jobless persons claimed unemployment benefits in November. This is an increase of 30 per cent from October's 839,984 and the highest since January.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The well-earned reputation of The New York Times for fairness, which we Indonesians appreciate especially, leads me to believe that you will wish your readers to know that there is another side to the question of "Indonesia and Rubber" discussed in your editorial of Nov. 20.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- In an effort to retain as much as possible of nearly 2 1/4 billion dollars, the Treasury today offered to let holders of series "F" and "G" savings bonds, maturing in 1954, exchange them for other bonds.
Winchester, Mass., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Dec. 22 on $1,790,000 of school bonds dated Jan. 15, 1954 and maturing from Jan. 15, 1955 to 1974.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 11 -- West Germany's nine states have begun putting up a fight against the Federal Government's demand for more of their tax revenue.
Steel production in November dipped below the levels of both the previous month and November of last year. But the nation's output for the first eleven months of 1953 still set a new high record.

Sales and production of wool apparel fabrics for civilian use in the first nine months of 1953 exceeded that of the same period last year, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers reported yesterday. However, a sharp drop in military buying caused the nine months' totals to dip below 1952.

The transfer of the sponsorship of next year's college holidays basketball festival in Madison Square Garden from three New York colleges to the Eastern College Athletic Conference was effected yesterday at the E. C. A. C.'s annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. has developed a financial program for his first year in office that will require almost $150,000,000 in additional revenue. Of this amount, $60,000,000 would be used to adjust the wages of the city's 180,000 employes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -Representative W. Sterling Cole said today the Soviet Union could strike the United States a "nearly mortal" atomic blow.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 29 -- Communists and other Leftists have made formidable alliances for an immediate challenge to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party in two southern states.

SO far in my life I have not had much interest in gardening but now that I am going on nine I think I should take it in my mind more. There is plenty of space in our yard to have a little garden of my own. Also I plan to help on the family garden.

Fellowships enabling high school teachers to extend their education and improve their teaching ability by spending a full year away from the classroom have been established by the Fund for the Advancement of Education.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams ended their 1953 National Football League season today by downing the last-place Green Bay Packers, 33 to 17, in Memorial Coliseum. The victors closed with an 8-won, 3-lost, 1-tied record in the Western Division of the circuit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- This week has brought one of the few dips in what has been on the whole the steadily ascending curve of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's career as a powerful figure in the Republican party.

COLLEGE historians have chronicled most American colleges old enough to have any history and some that are not. It is time for a history of the American college. The task of synthesis has been undertaken by Ernest Earnest of Temple University in a volume that is sprightly and informative.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -The Eisenhower Administration was reported today to be drafting a far-reaching new social security proposal, keyed to higher benefits and a bigger tax base.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 12 -- Democrats in City Council again will name a Republican to serve as Mayor of the city.

The 1953 National League official batting records, released yesterday, stamp last season as one of the greatest seasons for slugging in the history of the senior circuit. They also underline the offensive excellence of the champion Brooklyn Dodgers.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 12 -- Uncle Sam's storage bins are bulging today with grains and related commodities held under Federal price support, and there is prospect that the storage will reach a record.

How they do it year after year always remains a mystery, but the National Motor Boat Show this winter will have on display a record number of 305 recreational boats of all types. This is the latest word from Joseph E. Choate, who is show manager and secretary of the sponsoring National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers.

RECORDS of the Civil Aeronautics Administration show that License No. 93258, issued on Nov. 30, 1939, authorized one Lieut. Col. Dwight D. Eisenhower to fly a two-seated, single-engined land plane. The license

THE specifications for a Christmas book, as for other Christmas gifts, are extremely simple: it should be something that the recipient cannot afford, does not need, and will enjoy forever. I think, for instance, of the indecipherable writing which it pleased Saul Steinberg to spread over two pages of his book of cartoons, "The Art of Living."
An ancient manuscript of "The Rubaiyat" by Omar Khyyam, the Persian poet, will be auctioned Tuesday evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

DURING the period of the newspaper strike the television and radio fields made news on many fronts. There were developments in the technical field, one of which is expected to have profound repercussions on the whole entertainment field; an important change of top executive personnel at the National Broadcasting Company, and assorted doings in the realm of programming.

I WISH the American Bar Association would circulate Lord Dunsany's article on the vanishing adjective to its members. In legal writing above all -- should I have said below? -- the adjective theatens to become obsolete.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- Charges of unfair labor practices were filed this week with the National Labor Relations Board by rival unions as the aftermath of rioting last week on the San Francisco waterfront.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Four persons were killed and 1,000 injured today when more than 500,000 Mexican Roman Catholics surged to the Shrine of the Virgin of Guadalupe to honor the patron saint of the Americas.
The following maritime briefs include a number of reports of the last two weeks that The New York Times was unable to publish because of the photo-engravers' strike.

Last-minute calls for quick- delivery merchandise, particularly in better sportswear, higher-priced holiday dresses and accessories, formed the bulk of this week's activity in resident buying offices.

May I add my 2 cents on the issue raised by former President Truman in your letters column? People commonly speak, and I think properly, of a "new" President every time there is a change of Administration.

GRAND opera as a feature of the full life in the United States is as recognizable as, say, the rose window was of Gothic architecture. Not as eminent a feature, agreed, as the pointed arch: but not as minor as the gargoyle.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 7 -- Saudi Arabia is planning to expand and re-equip her ground forces and build a small air force. This is part of a proposed two-year extension of the military training program now conducted by the United States Military Assistance Advisory Group here.

There are thousands who now preserve on magnetic tape broadcast music, plays, jokes and speeches. The record can be played back over and over again. On Dec. 1 the Radio Corporation of America, at its David Sarnoff Research Center, Princeton, N. J., demonstrated an amazing invention that makes it possible to record television programs on magnetic tape in a similar way by what has been aptly called "electronic photography."

ONE of the most original men writing in the English language today is Cyril Connolly, who has just come along with GREAT ENGLISH SHORT NOVELS (Dial, $6). He hasn't written the novels. He has selected them, and written an over-all introduction as well as short prefaces to the chosen big-little eleven.

Those among us who have never visited Berlin may imagine that city today as New York might be if Manhattan were free and separately governed, but surrounded on all sides by unfree territory. The Bronx, Queens and New England would be in the hands of the oppressor, and so would much land to the west, at the edge of a broad commuting zone.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 12 -- The average child between 4 and 6 years of age can learn to speak several languages simultaneously without interfering with his ability to master his native tongue, Prof. Theodore Andersson, director of the Master of Arts in Teaching Program at Yale University, said this week.

Women of this city and communities in Westchester County and Connecticut are serving on the committee for the lecture and tea to be given this afternoon at Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in Purchase, N. Y., by Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy of Hyannisport, Mass., and Palm Beach, Fla.
DYLAN THOMAS was a man of genius who wrote poems when he could and who made his living by reading aloud, by lecturing and by hack writing. "The Doctor and the Devils" is a piece of hack writing.

AS one of the first acts of his administration Harvard's new president. Nathan M. Pusey, announced plans for strengthening and expanding the university's Divinity School. This gives special interest to Willard L. Sperry's SERMONS PREACHED AT HARVARD (Harper, $2.50).

VIENNA, Dec. 8 -- City fathers here are worried -- and no wonder. They have just been told that their music-loving city is doomed. By 2,000 A. D., experts claim, there will be only 1,000,000 Viennese left in the dying city, or about half the present population.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The capital's own annual "amateur night" held the national spotlight here tonight.

PARIS, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Organization for European Economic Cooperation (O. E. E. C.) said today that, "because it has the economic strength to exercise leadership, the United States bears a special responsibility" in efforts to solve Europe's dollar-shortage problem.

When I read Lord Dunsany's article, I was reminded of an incident which occurred in my school a few years ago. I went into a ninth grade English class and found the teacher amazed because a boy in the class had just called the word "through" an adjective.

LIKE her earlier novel, "Fruit in His Season," Helen Barney's new book is a story of the Quaker heritage in American history. Susan, heroine of "Green Rose of Furley," belongs to a family of Maryland Friends who aid and shelter fugitive slaves and give impartial care to the wounded of both armies in the Civil War.

OCALA, Fla. -- This central Florida city, made known to visitors because of its proximity to two of Florida's stellar tourist attractions, Silver Springs and Rainbow Springs, is now becoming a stopping-off place for lovers of thoroughbred horses.

Henry Epstein, recently named as Deputy Mayor in the incoming City Administration, said yesterday that, unless the post had the importance he was sure it would have from his talks with Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr., he would "go back to the practice of law."

Levi Eshkol, Israel's Finance Minister, declared last night that his nation had passed the half-way mark toward economic self-sufficiency and would not be deterred by "Arab efforts to destroy the new state's sovereignty."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 12 -- John Landy today ran the third fastest mile ever recorded, 4 minutes 2 seconds, but as soon as he recovered his breath the 23-year-old Australian student said he had driven himself to the limit of his speed.

KITTY HAWK, N. C. -- Eight Air Force Sabrejets are scheduled to dive through the sonic barrier here Thursday at five-second intervals as a loud salute to the progress of aviation during the last fifty years. The event is part of a four-day celebration opening at near-by Kill Devil Hill tomorrow to commemorate the golden anniversary of the Wright brothers and the world's first powered flight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Tax exemptions or concessions designed to revive the flow of private investment capital abroad are under examination by a Governmental tax committee.

More Vassar College students than ever before in the college's eighty- eight-year history -- better than one out of every two undergraduates -- worked at paid or voluntary jobs during the 1953 summer vacation, a survey by the college Vocational Bureau has disclosed.
ALTHOUGH it is unlikely that there will be any strolling bands of carolers in the vicinity of Shubert Alley on Christmas Eve, the approaching holiday season does mean something special to Broadway.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Leaders in education, insurance and the American Legion attended a funeral service today for Col. Franklin D'Olier, retired president of the Prudential Insurance Company and first national commander of the legion.
The Commonwealth Fund made grants totaling $4,548,576 in the 1952-53 fiscal year for medical education, experimental health services and medical research.

The public, whose shopping has been hampered by war shortages, post-war shortages, and finally by shortages developed from over-careful retail buying policies, may see in 1954 a condition which has not been general since 1941: stores carrying well-rounded stocks.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis is pushing plans to triple the amount of gamma globulin available to the public for fighting polio next year.

BROOKS ATKINSON, ruminating pleasantly in his corner of The New York Times dramatic section a few Sundays ago, had an answer for the response of the public to the "fictitious homicide" presented nightly in a certain Broadway play.

New York University's basketball team made a successful 1953-1954 debut in Madison Square Garden last night. Coach Howard Cann's Violets, capitalizing on foul awards in the closing minutes, turned back a hard-driving Syracuse quintet, 78 -- 73, in the second game of a double-header witnessed by 9,549 spectators.

INTERIOR decoration more accurately than anything else reflects the culture of a period, Dr. Irwin Edman, Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, pointed out in a lecture delivered here this fall. Four rooms which illustrate this opened at the Brooklyn Museum last Wednesday. They represent the styles of the latter half of the nineteenth century and present a fascinating picture of the interests and temper of those times.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 12 -- The Government announced tonight that it had seized a cache of documents giving "the most detailed and accurate information on the Tudeh (Communist) party yet discovered."
It has now been decided that members of the working press are passengers and not freight.

ON Nov. 29 your critic accurately described the difference between English and American drama, but he failed completely in seeking to suggest a reason for the difference. British plays do "look naive to us" for -- like "Escapade" -- each has "a lot of surface movement. * * * but little internal growth."

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The long-term results of the brief discussion of Far Eastern problems, particularly China, by President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill and French Foreign Minister Bidault may turn out to be among the most important of the Bermuda conference.

GARFIELD, N. J., Dec. 12 -- The outgoing Democratic Administration of this mill community began today a procedure to give the striking teachers of the city's nine public schools the $82,000 in pay rises demanded. It left the task of raising the money to the incoming Republicans.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra, which has enriched this city's cultural life for seventy-two years, called this week on the business community to help restore its depleted capital assets.

THERE is little about the Waldorf-Astoria that isn't at least touched upon -- and seen through rosy glasses -- in this book. Since the Waldorf was opened at the old stand at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-third Street in 1893 (to have the Astoria added to it on the next corner four years later) it has been not only a hotel but an institution around which legends have clustered.
NEWARK, Dec. 12 -- The retirement last week of Superior Court Judge William A. Smith deprived New Jersey of one of its most colorful and esteemed jurists.

THE death two weeks ago of Joseph Burstyn, a top importer of foreign-language films and an indomitable champion of the screen's freedom in the famous case of "The Miracle," was one of those many occurrences which did not receive due note or appropriate editorial attention because of the recent hiatus in the news.

NEW YORK CITY'S voluntary welfare agencies provide indispensable facilities and skills for the care of the sick and needy. Without them the city could not carry out its responsibilities to the destitute. The great majority of children and adults who have become public charges in need of institutional care receive that care not in public institutions, but in the institutions which are maintained by the voluntary agencies.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 12 -- Electronic"brains," such as recently served the armed forces in computing complex artillery and guided missile data may ultimately be used in a different kindof struggle. The United States ArmyCorps of Engineers announced lastweek that research had beeninitiated to develop specially designed "brains" for use incontrolling the Missouri River.

Of necessity in the administration of the income tax the application of its rates must be related to a taxable period. The unit of time for which personal income is generally reported is the calendar year.
SADIE THOMPSON, the passion flower of Pago-Pago, is back in bloom again. Rita Hayworth will portray her in a new movie, "Miss Sadie Thompson," following a long line of actresses in the role.

THIS city gardener wants quite a few things for Christmas but, unfortunately, almost none of them is in the traditional gift category. I mean, who would ever dream that I wanted two gallons of expensive, durable outdoor paint (gray) for the terrace boxes and tubs?

BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Tony DeMarco of Boston had Teddy (Red Top) Davis on the verge of a last-minute knockout tonight while out-pointing the Hartford (Conn.) boxer easily in a nationally televised ten-round bout at the Boston Garden. At 140 1/4 pounds, DeMarco had a nine-pound margin.
The world's largest television and radio network is out to beat in 1954 the $100,000,000 sales mark it will chalk up this year.

Oliver Clausen, who wrote "Moscow's New 'War' on Finland" (Nov. 15), evidently met the wrong people in Helsinki. * * * The impression he gave of sudden urgency and drama to Finland's unenviable position in the world today is erroneous.
LONDON, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- The London Daffy Telegraph urged the British people today to ignore hostile criticism of United States troops in this country.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is considering the establishment of a committee of experts to revise the basic structure of European defense in view of developments in atomic weapons.
PANAMA, Dec. 11 -- The Venezuelan Government gave further evidence today of its strengthening position by releasing 300 political prisoners, arrested during recent weeks.

American business prospered in the first nine months of this year. Industrial profits showed a 14 per cent increase over the corresponding period of 1952. And despite some slipping of statistics in the economy, 1953 will rank as one of the best years in corporate history.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 12 -- Fordham, considered one of the East's ranking quintets, encountered unexpected first-half opposition tonight before going on to defeat Princeton, 74 -- 61, in the Dillon Gymnasium. The victory was the fourth in a row for the unbeaten Rams, who led at the intermission by a 30-28 margin.

ON these pages today are told the stories of the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City. They are the stories of neighbors of yours -- good people overwhelmed by circumstances, even as you, except for the turn of fortune, might also have been overwhelmed. On their behalf at this Christmas season, The New York Times makes its forty-second annual appeal.

THE events of recent weeks -among them, the jabs of Senator McCarthy, and the pressures of domestic and foreign needs -- have brought Dwight D. Eisenhower to a crossroads in his White House career. Between now and the time the Congress meets in January, he must not only make up his mind on what sort of a President he wants to be.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- This is Gridiron week-end in Washington, when the little shots and the big shots get together to laugh at one another's folly.

The lack of Sunday newspaper advertising, the fact that Christmas comes a day later in the week than last year, and the continuing warm weather combined to lower retail business by more than 6 per cent last week from the same week a year ago.

The resounding notes of organ music filled the concourse of Grand Central Terminal yesterday as the annual program of Christmas carols got under way. Wreaths and other Christmas decorations adorned the station.

Wider reading of international news can be accomplished by greater balance in coverage, increased space and more explanation, the International Press Institute declares in a one-year survey completed recently.
MYCENAE, Greece, Dec. 1 -- This famed site connected with Homeric legend has once again produced treasures of prehistoric times and in great number and variety.
For the first time in several months there is a feeling along the waterfront these days that a new dock strike on Christmas Eve may not be inevitable.

The tension that marked President Eisenhower's first public encounter with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in Wisconsin during the '52 campaign -- when he endorsed the Senator without naming him -- has visibly increased during the past year. Senator McCarthy has repeatedly projected himself into the President's domain of foreign affairs.

NO matter how many years a person has gardened, there's always something that he or she would like for Christmas. Maybe it's a tool that seems a luxury from the standpoint of the weekly budget. (One year I went for months wanting a long-handled shovel with narrow blade.)

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 12 -- Pakistani and Western diplomatic and military observers here professed to be puzzled today by India's outcry against prospective United States arms aid to Pakistan. It was believed in these quarters that this move, which would have the effect of strengthening India's most vulnerable frontier without cost or commitment to New Delhi, should normally be welcomed by the neighboring country.
Business forecasters, peering into their perpetually murky crystal balls, are discovering wider and wider areas of disagreement.

THE National Broadcasting Company has selected "Home" as the title for a new Monday through Friday series of service programs designed especially for a women's audience and scheduled to begin on Jan. 18, from 12 to 1 P. M.

CHILDREN are frequently better entertainers on television than the professional adult performers, according to Art Linkletter, whose interviews with youngsters between 5 and 10 years of age are a standard feature of his "House Party" program on C. B. S. He never knows what they are going to say -- and some of their innocent comments, although wringing great laughter from the studio audiences, are unprintable.

DENVER. Colo., Dec. 12 -- Federal District Judge Willis W. Ritter, whose comments on a Denver jury tampering case stirred up a political controversy, said today he would not have spoken out if he had thought his remarks would be seized upon as they had.

WHEN Joe Laurie Jr. sets out to write theatrical histories, he is no niggard with the basic facts of life. Some time back, he and Abel Green turned out "Show Biz," which was something special in that it stressed grosses, salaries and bookings as well as the more conservative Shakespeare and O'Neill.

BY this time most of us have given the lawn its final manicure of the season and are ready to store the mower with a mixed feeling of relief and regret. Relief because it marks the completion of a long and arduous chore; regret because -- well, who likes to shovel snow?

THIS is the time of the year when experts (EXPERT, n. A man who gets paid for guessing) make up-their teams of All-America football players, and when other experts present their lists of Best Books of the Year.

EASTON, Pa., Dec. 12 -- Capt. John Alviggi of West Orange, N. J., set a Lafayette College scoring record in tallying 36 points tonight as the Leopards toppled City College of New York to its first defeat of the season. The score was 84 -- 57.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Nov. 12 -- The Capetown Chamber of Commerce has issued a warning to the public that this city's rival capital, Pretoria, is trying by "white ant tactics" to undermine its position as one of the two capitals of South Africa.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 12 -- The new Administration of Moshe Sharett is expected to continue the program of the outgoing Government of David Ben-Gurion. The change in leadership is not necessitated by a political crisis but by Mr. Ben-Gurion's professed desire for a respite of "a year, two years or perhaps more."

MOST of us have a distorted picture of oil-rich Oklahoma and Texas. We expect from flamboyant press accounts nothing but emeralds as big as eggs, multi-million dollar hotels and oil heiresses who check several furs at the country-club cloak-room so they can change off during the evening.
The American farmer is pacing the growth of the population by improved efficiency in his production.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 1 -- Along the narrow cobblestone streets and twisting covered ways of the Suk el Juma'a quarter 2,500 Arab refugees from Palestine have found a haven in the generations-old community of Damascene Jews.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 12 -- The decision by Premier Fazlollah Zahedi to resume diplomatic relations with Britain is a gamble that could easily bring either salvation or defeat to his Government.
All levels of the shoe industry have been compensating for mistakes made earlier this year and will end the year without heavy carry-overs.

THIS season of the year dictates a selfless frame of mind. THE BOOK REVIEW accordingly decided it would be handsome all around if authors of best-selling books would tell our readers what books they themselves enjoyed reading most in 1953.

The members of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association gathered last night at the Hotel Statler to honor its All-America team. Certificates were awarded to the ten men selected for the game's top honors for 1953. Some of the athletes were absent because of duty with the armed forces.

BONN, Germnay, Dec. 12 -- Political quarters in Bonn have received reports from East Germany that the Soviet Union will request a month's delay in starting the proposed Berlin conference. According to those reports, which come from confidential sources, Moscow will propose that the conference of the Western Big Three and the Soviet Union foreign ministers be set back from Jan. 4 to a date early in February.

IF I were allowed to choose only one of the year's art books as a Christmas present for myself (leaving aside the new Malraux volume which is in a special category), I would unhesitatingly ask for "Byzantine Painting."
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 5 -- Alabama's poll tax law, adopted in 1901 to discourage Negro voting, will undergo a drastic change Dec. 15 if the voters approve.

The Winged Foot polo team registered an unexpected triumph over the Squadron A trio at the latter's armory last night. Conceded a two-goal handicap, the Winged Foot riders showed that they needed no such help as they made their way to a 14-to-6 victory.

TWENTIETH Century-Fox's CinemaScope wide-screen process is widening its orbit. Last week it was learned that the process will be used for the first time in England by an independent group, Warwick Productions, on two pictures of ambitious proportions.

A Surrogate's Court jury returned a verdict early yesterday morning finding that Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee was mentally competent when she executed her last will in November, 1950, and that the testatrix had not been under undue influence.

FAVORITE STRAUSS WALTZES AND OVERTURES: Waldmeister, Fledermaus, Gypsy Baron, Blue Danube, Voices of Spring, Artists' Life; Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, Karl Boehm conducting; Symphony Orchestra of Radio Leipzig, Hermann Abendroth and Herbert Kegel conducting (Urania).
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Nine out of ten Air Force cadets receive their initial pilot training in schools operated by civilians, the Aeronautical Training Society said today.
TRENTON, Dec. 12 -- The New Jersey Legislature, which convened in special session on Dec. 4, resumed its deliberations on Thursday and will try to wind up its activities on Dec. 21.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Bill Dineen scored two goals and added a pair of assists tonight as the Detroit Red Wings scored their first victory in five starts, turning back the Boston Bruins, 7 to 1, before 11,511 fans at Olympia.

The Soviet Union's trade with the non-Communist world during the first nine months of this year was about one-third less than the value of this trade during the same period last year, data compiled by the Statistical Office of the United Nations show.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The Adoption Service Fund of Westchester, a recently formed citizens' group, announced appointments today to its first board of directors.

The ten-day strike against six major New York newspapers, which ended last Tuesday, posed many problems for the advertising business. Aside from the advertising departments of the newspapers themselves, those most affected were department stores' advertising staffs and agencies specializing in classified and mail order advertising.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- Averell Harriman, former Mutual Security Director, charged this afternoon that the Republican party was "afraid of overproduction" and did not "believe in full employment."
A fact-finding board held its first hearings yesterday on the wage and hour issues of the recent newspaper strike.

The Amateur Athletic Union, which has not been able to lure star Europeans away from training for the 1954 European track championships, revealed yesterday it had invited Russia and Czechoslovakia to send stars to compete in the 1954 indoor track and field meets.

The stalemate, if not complete rupture, in the preliminary peace negotiation in Korea again focuses attention upon the whole problem of Pacific defense structures. Washington is now said to favor some sort of regional alliance but to feel that the initiative and the leadership should come from Asians.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 30 -- The color of the West German Socialist party's policy appears to be changing from pre-war red to post-war pink.

AMERICA includes among its citizens today more older people than ever before. And for the first time in history oldsters are beginning to outnumber pre-school age children. While this matter has been getting ample attention from the specialists, only recently have we observed a growth in popular interest in what this change in vital statistics means in terms of human relations and, inevitably, family life.

TORONTO, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Harry Lumley carded his third consecutive shutout on home ice and his fifth of the National Hockey League season as the Toronto Maple Leafs posted a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

GERIATRICIANS, historians and ordinary Americans whose past includes the period from the outset of the New Deal to the outburst of the cold war will find equally fascinating the diaries of Harold L. Ickes. In a real sense for him life began at 59 after neary forty years of political reform in which he consistently found himself on the wrong side.

A simple reply without a gift was all that an 8-year-old child asked from Santa Claus in a letter that was found last week among the 4,000 notes sent to that Merry Gentleman by way of the General Post Office.

SALISBURY, England. THE man who knows as much about the common cold as anyone in this cold-ridden world is a lean British medical researcher called Dr. Christopher H. Andrewes. On the subject of cold cures he has a reputation for being a pessimist.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Harness racing's Grand Circuit admitted two new track members, re-elected officers and voted two important changes in its itinerary during its annual meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Four million Christmas food packages will be distributed to the needy in twenty foreign countries in an Operation Santa Claus by the Foreign Operations Administration.

' PHOTOGRAPHY is the only real international language," write editors Norman Hall and Helmut Gernsheim in a brief introduction to "Photography Year-Book. 1954" (London: The Press Centre Limited. $4.95). Then, without benefit of a single comment or caption other than photographers' credits, they attempt to prove their point with 164 excellently reproduced photographs.
Brooklyn College's basketball team broke its three-game losing streak last night by defeating a determined Yeshiva University quintet, 57 -- 55, at the winner's gymnasium.
A healthier society can reduce juvenile crime, in the opinion of Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper of the Court of Special Sessions.

The brilliantly lighted counters of the 191 supermarkets of Food Fair Stores, Inc., have little difficulty these days in disposing of that chain's grocery bargains. But Louis Stein, president since last August of Food Fair, could tell quite a different story about his patient efforts in 1936 to sell dollar bills to Wall Street for a nickel apiece.

When 3,500 physicians from all parts of the country gathered in St. Louis recently for the seventh annual clinical session of the American Medical Association, the program was directed largely to the general practitioner.
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday he was working on legislation to finance a $500,000,000 school construction program.

Chile abandoned this week the curious price-supporting role she has been playing in the world copper market since early summer. And many metals authorities believe the beginning of copper's long-expected price decline may not be far off.

Ten "do's and don'ts" concerning Christmas trees were urged yesterday by the Safety Services Department of the Queens Chapter of the American Red Cross. The list was issued with the warning that Christmas tree fires are most difficult to extinguish and precautions should be taken to avoid them.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 12--The Marine Division of the Nassau County Police Department has installed ship-to-shore communication equipment in each of its sixl patrol boats.

TO at least one of his admirers, the death of Eugene O'Neill on Nov. 27 was a profoundly sorrowful occasion. A giant writer has dropped off the earth. A great spirit and our greatest dramatist have left us, and our theatre world is now a smaller, more ordinary place.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- To celebrate its third birthday the Rochester Arena Theatre is producing a new comedy by Arnold Sundgaard, "The Kilgo Run." To judge by the laughter of one of the week-end audiences, Mr. Sundgaard's droll yarn suits the taste of the customers; and it also makes theatregoing reasonably pleasant for a down-state moocher temporarily out of bounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Storm clouds gathering on the economic horizon have been worrying small-business experts here. To prevent thousands of small manufacturing, wholesaling, service and retail establishments from going to the wall in the "minor readjustments" ahead, tax relief and facilities for long-term credits will be essential, the specialists agree.

MARK down "In the Twilight of Socialism" as a long but fascinating epitaph upon a lost cause. The cause is (or was) socialism in pre-war Austria -- for a generation and longer the model and paragon among Social-Democratic parties on the European Continent.

Recent Soviet statements and other information indicate that if the Soviet Government wishes to, it should be capable of contributing substantially to the materials and personnel needs of an international atomic energy agency such as that suggested last Tuesday by President Eisenhower.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- A United States armored division that had been promised to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in 1954 will not be sent as scheduled. This weakens the program of Continental defense and worries the United States' allies.

FOR any gardener who likes to read about his hobby when the garden is asleep in winter the perfect gift is no problem. It's a book, of course, and the field is limitless. What is more, among the many volumes new this year are those which definitely qualify as gift books because of their handsome format.

SOUND kitchen equipment eases holiday cooking. The right tool for the job cuts time and labor. That is why home cooks would do well at this season to acquire, as advance Christmas gifts to themselves, needed new culinary pieces.

MERCHANTS in this city and throughout the country are highly optimistic for a good holiday season -- in some areas a record one. Santa Claus is their biggest ally, for the reason that gifts which are given must first be bought. Consumer purchasing power is at a high level, and, while distant rumblings of recession, adjustment, retrenchment and other semantic dodgings are heard now and then, there is no downturn except on the horizon.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12 -- Andre, favorite in the field of a dozen distance horses, captured the $7,500 Ponce de Leon Handicap at Tropical Park today with a length victory, covering the mile and a sixteenth in the excellent time of 1:44 3/5.
Mayor de Lesseps Morrison of New Orleans received yesterday the third annual La Guardia Award for outstanding achievement in municipal affairs.

ANY musician spends countless weeks and months preparing himself for the ordeal of a New York appearance. If he is an artist with an established reputation, his career cannot be affected seriously by a failure to be noticed in the press.

AS founder of the Metropolitan Museum's Department of Prints and its head for thirty years, William M. Ivins Jr. is well qualified to write the history of print-making in all its aspects, from the middle of the fifteenth century to the present.

Prayers will be offered in all churches of the New York Protestant Episcopal diocese today for the success of the efforts begun by President Eisenhower to harness the power of atomic fission "for the benevolent up-building of human welfare and the cause of world peace."
There's no question about it, Brownie likes policemen. Brownie, a cinnamon colored mongrel, was never happier than when keeping watch outside the Seventy-fourth Precinct, in Brooklyn.

MONTREAL, Dec. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Amateur Ski Association announced today that thirteen skiers would participate next month in the final trials for the world championship events at Are, Sweden, in February.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 12 -- With Johnny Clune scoring 31 points and his running-mate, Don Lange, right behind with 30. Navy rolled its third straight basketball victory of the season today by handing Yale its fourth defeat in five starts, 90 -- 82.

Steve Owen's Giants held their final workout of the season yesterday at the Polo Grounds. For Stout Steve it was more than just a drill in preparation for today's finale against the Detroit Lions. Some thirty hours later Owen was to walk off the gridiron under Coogan's Bluff for the last time as coach of the Giants.

At the request of the Atomic Energy Commission, General Electric engineers have constructed a fifteen-ton remotely controlled arm to take the place of human brawn in radioactive areas where men could not survive. "O-Man" (short for "overhead manipulator") is the name of the invention.

EIGHTEEN months ago a retired Paris pediatrician, sick of seeing his efforts to reforest his thousand-acre estate near Dreux frustrated by nibbling depredators, caught two wild rabbits and injected them with a virus called myxoma.

ROME, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Striking Government workers went back to their jobs today after a twenty-four-hour workout, but the nation braced itself for a second round. Five million industrial workers have been ordered to lay down their tools Tuesday in a follow-up show of labor strength.

The echoes of President Eisenhower's speech to the United Nations Assembly on Tuesday will be heard at the three- day meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council, opening in Paris tomorrow. They will not have died down by Jan. 4 when the foreign ministers, one hopes, will meet in Berlin.

THE problem of agrarian people of Mexican descent in the southwestern and western parts of this country is a growing one, and lately has been the subject of several novels. Easily the most powerful one this reviewer has seen on this topic is William E. Barrett's.

ANGEL RECORDS can call itself with considerable accuracy "the new label with the old tradition." A fifty-year-old disk of Tamagno singing the "Death of Otello," for instance, bears the trademark of the Recording Angel.

WASHINGTON -- For those who like to travel during the Christmas holidays or who cannot get to their family homes during the Yuletide season, Washington is being suggested as a natural and colorful place to visit during the Christmas-New Year period.

I., Dec. 12 -- A young Methodist minister, who commutes 220 miles each day four days a week from his home and pastoral duties in East Hampton to classes at the Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan, may suffer a serious jolt if the Long Island Rail Road gets permission to abandon its Montauk Branch.

OTTAWA, Dec. 12 -- The first task of the Canadian-United States Economic Committee of Cabinet Members will be to seek solution for a variety of trade and tariff problems and allay the fears of prairie wheat farmers of a price war between the two countries. Together, the two countries hold a large surplus of wheat.

The President has appointed a board which is to study the possibility of controlling the weather. Among the four new members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters whose election was announced yesterday is John Hersey, 39-year-old novelist. He has the added distinction of becoming the youngest member of the body.

Sumptuous and rare textiles and other art objects of the Dikran Kelekian collection will be auctioned in its second and final part on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

From reflections on a recent pilgrimage to the tombs of five of our greatest Presidents one thought above all remains with me as of timely significance in our current political confusion: While these Presidents were vigilant leaders in the fulfillment and the defense of liberty, they put just as much emphasis on equality as a fundamental ideal in the American concept of democracy.
Stock traders took time out last week to do a little year-end reckoning. Prices opened lower on Monday and gave ground grudgingly in the next four sessions.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has turned down a petition by common carriers in coastwise and intercoastal shipping urging that contract carriers be required to file copies of their shipping agreements with the commission.
The "threat of the book burners" was singled out last night by Senator Herbert H. Lehman as the most pressing problem confronting the United States.

Yesterday afternoon's broadcast performance "Rigoletto" from the Metropolitan Opera House brought two speakers to the nation-wide audience with a plea for continued support of the Metropolitan Opera. They were Irving L. Olds, former chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, and Lewis L. Strauss chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

RECENT openings in the rush of pre-holiday exhibitions include a number of large group shows of unusual interest. The Whitney Museum has placed on view its acquisitions of the year through purchase, gift or exchange -- twenty-three paintings, four pieces of sculpture and one drawing, and has supplemented the showing with selected examples from the permanent collection.

So says Brillat-Savarin in his definition of gastronomy and so say we in our definition of modern cookbooks, which in their number and variety cover everything from a boiled egg to a banquet.

A special event of the season will be the first local appearance of Paul Draper in more than three years at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., on Wednesday evening. AS the year ends with a whimper, it somehow seems an opportune time to pass along a few of the reprint facts made available by the H. W. Wilson's "Catalog of Reprints in Series" (14th edition, $4). Once again the reprint champion is Grace Livingston Hill, with seventy available titles.

JUST 100 years ago on Dec. 30, James Gadsden, the U. S. Minister to Mexico, and the Foreign Minister of "His Most Serene Highness" of Mexico, Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna, signed a treaty in Mexico City.

Fighting off their rivals in the closing minutes, Columbia began its basketball season last night by turning back Army, 66 to 57, at the University Hall Gymnasium. It also was the 1953-54 curtain-raiser for the Cadets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The meeting President Eisenhower has scheduled with his legislative leaders for next week ranks as one of the most important of his White House career.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- An unusual array of canned and bottled goods is being assembled at the offices of the Food and Drug Administration here.
The New York Times today carries the largest Main News section and the heaviest volume of news and advertising it has ever printed.

AN editorial note says of Robert Hillyer (who wrote " -- And Live Again in Wonderland," the front page poem for the Children's Book Issue) that "He is presently Visiting Professor of English at the University of Delaware."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- Industrial activity in Pennsylvania caused by the Korean war boom has about subsided, according to the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University. The bureau based its finding on the movement of its index of industrial activity, which dropped to 226 in October from 233 a year ago.

" CHRISTMAS won't be Christmas without any presents," begins one of the hardiest perennials in juvenile literature. Wise Miss Alcott knew that the quickest way to a young reader's attention was an account of Christmas -- with or without presents -- and gave us two in "Little Women."

THREE judges, Berenice Abbott, Alfred Van Loen and George B. Wright, representing the points of view of the photographer, the artist and the editor, picked Morris H. Jaffe's picture of a boy at play as Print of the Year in the recent competition at the Village Camera Club.

College girls are becoming increasingly more realistic in their approach to post-graduate job-hunting, Dr. Marion J. Crosby, director of the Hunter College Graduate Placement Bureau, reports, Her bureau, which handles applications from seniors and graduate students aside from teacher placement, has seen a marked increase in the number of requests for secretarial and clerical positions.

Three new members -- to replace a like number who resigned -- have been elected to the board of directors of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City. Announcement of the selection was made yesterday by Carl M. Loeb Jr., president of the council.

IN this kind of light English novel, no matter what the family problems are or what trials and tribulations must be faced by parents or offspring, an atmosphere of good breeding and cheerful resolution is constant throughout.

THE recently opened 400-room Hotel Tamanaco in Caracas, Venezuela, is only twenty-five minutes by motor from the airport at La Guaira, which is served by four international airlines. The $8,000,000 hostelry is the tenth in a chain built and sponsored by the International Hotels Corporation of New York in this and foreign countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- Adlai E. Stevenson asserted tonight that "four fears" had replaced the "four freedoms" since the advent of the Eisenhower Administration. He listed current fears of depression, of communism, of ourselves and of freedom itself.

One of America's oldest steamship concerns, the Ward Line, will be sold next month as soon as stockholders of the line's parent holding company give their consent.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The United States envoy, Arthur H. Dean, said today he would wait no longer than a week for the Reds to make the first move toward resuming the broken-off talks to arrange a Korean peace conference.
New Yorkers were urged yesterday to give blood to the Red Cross Regional Blood Program here during the holiday season to help assure an adequate supply for those in need.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- A nationwide railway strike, the first in twenty-seven years, faces Britain at Christmas, when travel will be at its peak.

Fears that the rapidly growing pension funds might become a Gargantua, upsetting the capital market, are unfounded.

BEETHOVEN: 'Cello Sonatas in A, Op. 69, C and D, Op. 102, Nos. 1 and 2; Pierre Fournier and Artur Schnabel (Victor). Another Treasury of Immortal Performances release. Although the original pressings were shellac, the transfer sounds first-class.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, asked the Senate Armed Services Committee today for an investigation of the Army's decision to give to General Motors Corporation a virtual monopoly on production of military tanks.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 12 -- Maj. Imam Sukarto, an Indonesian Army spokesman, denied today that there were any rifts within the armed forces.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon has done a lot of traveling over the past ten weeks. The arrival of his plane at National Airport, Washington, D. C., tomorrow will mark the end of a 45,000-mile junket that took him to twenty-one countries in the Pacific, Asia and the Mid East -- the most extensive foreign tour ever made by a U. S. Vice President. Mr. Nixon rode in helicopters, jeeps, tractors and ox-carts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The White House was moderately encouraged today by a radio report from Moscow that the Soviet Union would give "serious attention" to President Eisenhower's atomic energy speech to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of Interior, said today the water supply in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area "is adequate to satisfy expected requirements for many years to come."

Of all the leafless trees in the winter landscape, the most eye-catching and spectacular is the white birch, particularly when seen against the grays and browns of a snowless hillside. It has a grace of line, a slimness of bole, a clean, sleek look that is sheer beauty.

Every day Dr. John Pettit, geophysicist on the Los Angeles campus of the University of California, feels the earth's pulse in a basement laboratory. The beats are caused by the gravitational pull of the sun and moon on the elastic earth. A steady rise and fall of the earth, which in some places amounts to two feet, follows the line of attraction of the two heavenly bodies as the earth rotates.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Seven non-league teams survived second-round play in the Football Association Cup competition today. Peterborough United and Hastings United headed this group, scoring over third division opponents. Peterborough beat Aldershot by 2 -- 1 and Hastings turned back Swindon Town, 4 -- 1.

A more adequate approach to education with emphasis on the arts and including a broad concept of religion was advocated by Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael in the forty-eighth annual report of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.

THE late Walter C. Kelly, a wild and merry vaudevillian of recent decades, was a man whose enjoyment of life was marred by few setbacks and no regrets. THE books for Christmas giving this year are in more even balance than they have been at any time since the war. There are volumes for every taste and inclination and delight. PLANS currently under way for the 1954 "Tops in Photography" show sponsored annually by the Metropolitan Camera Club Council call for a balanced program of both practical and inspirational material. Instead of being held in March as usual, the 1954 show will be in April or May so that the event may be used to help amateurs off to a good start of successful summer shooting.

Announcement of the engagement of Miss Margaret Manson Mayne of New York to James Alexander Kridel, son of Mrs. Alexander Hayes Kridel of 29 East Sixty-fourth Street, has been announced here by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Mayne of St. Louis.

REPORTS have been coming in this week of shrubs and trees abloom around New York City and the suburbs because of the unseasonable, warm weather. According to Clarence E. Lewis at the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute, however, "Such bloom is not unusual."

A dropped stick in the final event, the 880-yard relay, caused Bishop Loughlin to finish in a tie with Cardinal Hayes for the team trophy last night in the fourth annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association Relay Carnival at the 102d Engineers Armory, Manhattan. The two rivals scored 15 points each as the local interscholastic track season was launched.

Kyes, deputy secretary of defense, and Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, headed a group of Pentagon officials that met with the President and his aides from 9 A. Four or five generations ago the rightly called "civilized tribes," forced out of Georgia and Tennessee by the pressure of white settlers backed by Andrew Jackson, found themselves in what were then the desolate lands of the Indian Territory. These enforced pioneers suffered terribly on the journey and during their first years in the new land.

The 22,000-ton motor liner Kungsholm is at sea today, homeward bound on the return leg of her maiden voyage. While in New York, she received the traditional warm welcome accorded by the city to every new ocean queen.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Small modern branch savings banks with shiny glass-brick frnots are springing up in Turkish cities.
Add the Giants -- the baseball Giants, that is -- as the latest to yield to the general trend of increasing night game bookings.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Soviet radio listeners were told today that the Soviet Union had promised the United States it would give "serious attention" to President Eisenhower's new proposals for pooling the world's resources of atomic energy for peaceful uses.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Dec. 12 -- Heckscher Park, maintained for public use by the Heckscher Trust for the last forty years, is soon to be deeded to the Town of Huntington.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12 -- They call the Miami open "Sam Snead's Tournament" and the West Virginian gave the designation new authority by shooting out a four-under-par 66 in today's third round from fourth place into the lead.

Lord Dunsany protested that "through is not an adjective." However, Webster's New Collegiate Dictionary, sixth edition, has this to say: "through: -- adj. admitting free passage; as a through way." Is Webster too radical for the British? Or is Lord Dunsany doing what so many teachers of English do: beating a dead horse, and inveighing against usages that have become so common among educated people that they are no longer in disrepute? * * *

Is Webster too radical for the British? Or is Lord Dunsany doing what so many teachers of English do: beating a dead horse, and inveighing against usages that have become so common among educated people that they are no longer in disrepute? * * *
The historic 1953 bond market is nearly over, but it has by no means run out of thrilling surprises and suspense pieces.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Ministers of the fifteen-power Advisory Council of Europe urged France and Germany today to hasten bilateral negotiations on the Saar. They also approved a policy of firmness for Western defense in the proposed talks in Berlin of the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.

The annual series of Christmas carol programs by church choirs during dinner at the Savoy Plaza Hotel will begin Tuesday night and continue nightly through Wednesday, Dec. 23, except on Saturday and Sunday.

One of the most important problems in group life today is how to get persons of differing personalities and backgrounds to work together effectively when they find themselves members of the same organization.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser, 1944 titleholder, yesterday gained her fourth straight victory in the national women's championship tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation, at the Manhattan Chess Club. Mrs. Gresser leads N. May Karff and Mrs. Rosalie de Serrano who each have 2 1/2-1/2 scores.
