The rhythm of drum beats they couldn't hear sent seventy-five persons "do-si-do-ing" in Queens in what is believed to have been the largest demonstration of the ability of deaf mutes to square dance.

REDUCTION of death and injury resulting directly from the interior of automobiles is the objective of an intensive program of study and tests extending from door latches to steering wheels under supervision of Hugh de Haven, director of the Crash Injury Research, Cornell University Medical College, 1300 York Avenue.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- United States representatives are telling America's Atlantic allies not to worry too much about talk of cuts in United States military aid to Europe.

THE landscape of childhood is one I have never mourned. Indeed, having been for some time citizen of a better nation, my papers perfectly in order, I find its outline tends to blur upon my memory. I am continually astonished at the ease with which certain contemporaries of mine, especially the writing ones, recall every detail of that well-lost land.

THE landscape of childhood is one I have never mourned. Indeed, having been for some time citizen of a better nation, my papers perfectly in order, I find its outline tends to blur upon my memory. I am continually astonished at the ease with which certain contemporaries of mine, especially the writing ones, recall every detail of that well-lost land.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 12 -- Long years of neglect have laid a heavy hand on old family burial grounds in this community. Many graves of colonials and Revolutionary patriots lie forgotten beneath a dense growth of scrub trees, brambles or vines.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 12 -- With flags of thirty-nine participating countries and the United Nations flying over two glass-and-concrete pavilions, the international exhibition of modern art of the Sao Paulo Museum of Modern Art was opened today.

More than 60 per cent of the 460 Smith College students who graduated last June are now working or doing graduate study. Statistics, compiled on the basis of replies from 275 members of the class of 1953, indicate that the largest number, fifty-four, are doing graduate study in twenty-four colleges and universities in this country and in eight universities abroad.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 -- U.S. Special Envoy Arthur Dean's abrupt and angry walkout today from the negotiations at Panmunjom emphasized two significant facts about the discussions for setting up a Korean political conference. One is the increased resistance of the United Nations delegates to the delaying tactics which have characterized the Communists' course all through the Korean peace efforts.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 12 -- Plans have been completed for the Nassau County Juvenile Detention Center, a $550,000 project that will include a children's detention building and a Juvenile Court building separated by miles from adult courts and jails.

DREARILY Krishna enlightens his university students in India about the refinements of English grammar and spelling, and by reciting to them the mad exhortations of King Lear, he tries to scare up at least a glimmer of sensitivity.

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 12 -- New York and Philadelphia qualified today for the final round of the Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles. They will meet tomorrow in John Hay (Jock) Whitney's Greentree Court, starting at 11 A. M.

AMONG the record companies which have been interested in American music, Mercury has been one of the most active by virtue of its American Music Festival Series. Howard Hanson has been the prime mover here, and in the latest of the Mercury releases devoted to native composers he conducts the Eastman-Rochester Symphony Orchestra in a wide miscellany.
May I express some concern about a certain American - French misunderstanding which seems to endanger part of the negotiations between the two countries?

THIS is the way the newspaper strike affected the city's concert life. Box office telephones rang "like crazy," and artists, who thought they were not going to receive reviews, tore their hair, but attendance figures did not fall off very seriously.
A SUMMARY of the duck and goose shooting along the Outer Banks is certain to be colored by the same factor that influenced the deer hunting during the early season -- weather.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Two influential Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee joined today in opposing the Attorney General's proposal to allow wire tap evidence in espionage and other cases in Federal courts.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 12 -- "New pollution has been curbed, existing pollution is being decreased and the trend of half a century has been reversed," the Ohio River Valley Water Sanitation Commission announced last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- How to close 500 post offices and still do a bigger volume of business with a quicker turnover of inventory is what is sought by Arthur E. Summerfield, the automobile dealer from Flint, Mich., turned Postmaster General.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 12 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon left today for Tripoli, Libya, after letting the Government of Premier Fazlollah Zahedi know that the United States was convinced that the dispute with Britain over oil must be resolved before Iran could expect long-term financial aid from Washington.
SANTA CLAUS, Ind., Dec. 12 (UP) -- Business was booming for the sixty-seven residents of Santa Claus today with only fourteen mailing days to go until Christmas.

WHILE Britain and Egypt argue -- sometimes beyond the point of shouting to shooting -- over the Suez Canal, a fact often lost sight of these days is that business as usual goes on in the canal, one of the most lucrative private transportation enterprises in existence. The Suez Canal Company (or Compagnie Universelle du Canal Maritime de Suez) is ninety- five years old -- and, from the standpoint of investments, better than ever.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 13 -- The special United States envoy broke off negotiations for an international political conference on Korea yesterday after Communist delegates had accused the United States of "perfidy."

IF there is a stranger duty anywhere than that served by the men of the Air Force here, then they would like to hear about it. They have been set down at Thule, half way between the Arctic Circle and the North Pole, to man a tremendous air base, our northernmost military installation.

AMONG the choicer developments to come to light with the lifting of the recent news blackout was the fact that producer Gilbert Miller, in a flying fortnight's visit abroad, had nabbed the American rights to Agatha Christie's latest murder play, "Witness for the Prosecution," a sensational hit in the West End.

ONE usually thinks of Mr. Beebe as being somewhere deep down or far away. However he does have his headquarters in New York, and in this book he enlarges upon a fact which naturalists are fond of recalling: namely, that there are plenty of wonders near home.
Changes in ship commands were announced last week by two North Atlantic passenger steamship companies.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Richard H. Balch, New York Democratic State chairman, said today he did not think Governor Dewey would seek re-election because "he's afraid of getting licked."

The chairman of the board of the Armstrong Cork Company, H. W. Prentis Jr., declared last night that the American way of life "will not exist much longer unless we arouse ourselves from our present lethargy and meet the rising tide of collectivism with intelligence and decisive action."
Changes in ship commands were announced last week by two North Atlantic passenger steamship companies.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Richard H. Balch, New York Democratic State chairman, said today he did not think Governor Dewey would seek re-election because "he's afraid of getting licked."

THE last performance that this writer reviewed, prior to the cessation of the publication of The New York Times for the eleven days, was the Metropolitan Opera Association's revival of "Pelleas et Melisande," on Friday evening, Nov. 27.

IT is the last weeks of war in Germany. Hitler lies dead in a Berlin bunker. In a bastion of the Bavarian Alps a company of German soldiers, led by an ambitious S. S. commander, is about to stage a wild attack against the small garrison of American soldiers stationed in the town below.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Hints that a new personality, not hitherto disclosed as a Communist courier, may be revealed in investigations of Soviet espionage have been given by Whittaker Chambers, self-confessed former Communist agent.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The United Nations was told today that it should take its show on the road more often.

Seven Czechoslovak refugees, who escaped their Communist-dominated homeland last summer in a fake armored car, sampled New York hospitality yesterday for the first time. They found it as telling an ordeal as their dramatic flight to freedom.

Tony Trabert of Cincinnati has been recommended for the No. 1 spot in the 1953 men's singles rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association. The choice of the national singles champion for the top berth will not be official until the report of the ranking committee is reviewed at the U. S. L. T. A. annual meeting here on Jan. 16.

THE first virtue of "Norms for the Novel" is that it is conceived with acumen and written with grace. The second virtue is that it treats the novel -- that still historically quite new and presumably not yet exhausted form -- not as a mere exercise in escape or as a work of grim sociology but as a serious artistic attempt to render in words the mysterious drama of human experience.
Beginning Thursday, two deliveries of mail each day, including Saturdays will be made in all residential areas in Manhattan and the Bronx. This service will continue through Dec. 26.

To a great extent, unreliable standards by which to judge the attainment of success are responsible for the world's discontent, Rabbi Aaron B. Ilson said in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The business of self-defense is so costly that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is going to have a new look at itself next week to find out whether it should not change its ideas about how to spend in the future and what to spend on. That, in a nutshell, is the main task of the conference of NATO foreign, defense and finance ministers starting on Monday.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 12 -- A proposed toll bridge from Long Island to Fire Island was approved yesterday by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors. The board voted unanimously to have the county construct the bridge over Moriches Bay, an arm of the Great South Bay, from Smith's Point, Mastic, in the town of Brookhaven, to the ocean beach.
The American Federation of Labor warned yesterday that a quick longshore election would help the underworld maintain its rule over the Port of New York.

PRINCETON, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- A check that transferred $1,500 from a manufacturer of hydraulic equipment to Princeton University after a three-year legal battle found a place today in photographic form in Princeton's archives.

The National Kids Day Foundation, which sent out requests for donations over the names of Bing Crosby and Mrs. Bob Hope, raised $2,931,000 last year but spent only 10 per cent for charity. That charge was made yesterday by State Senator Bernard Tompkins, chairman of a joint legislative committee.
MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 13 -- Philadelphia retained the Payne Whitney Memorial Cup today in the intercity court tennis doubles tournament.

ROME, Dec. 13 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella will tell the North Atlantic Conference in Paris that Italy intends to continue, though in reduced measure, the extraordinary defense appropriations that together with United States and products have brought about a rebirth of the Italian armed forces.

BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., scored a decisive 6-4, 1-6, 6-2, 6-3 victory over Budge Patty of Los Angeles today to win the men's singles laurels of the Barranquilla international tennis tournament.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13 -- The Government announced tonight that it had moved Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, Iran's ousted Premier, from the gloomy Sultanatabad palace, where he was imprisoned since August, to more comfortable quarters in the Army Officers Club, seven miles north of Teheran.

The Brookhattan-Galicia eleven moved into a tie for third place with the Brooklyn Hispanos in the American Soccer League by beating the Philadelphia Americans, 3 -- 2, yesterday at Sterling Oval, the Bronx.

The leaders in the national championship tournament for women at the Manhattan Chess Club were successful in the fifth round yesterday. Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser gained her fifth consecutive victory, and triumphs were recorded by N. May Karff and Mrs. Rosalie de Serrano, each undefeated and tied for second place. Mrs. Micaela Babakin of Astoria was the fourth winner.

Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued to decline last week. Final prices at the close of the trading session on Friday ranged from 65 cents to $1.30 a bale lower. The major factor in the decline was hedging and liquidation prompted by the prolonged circulation of notice calls for the current December option.

MIAMI, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Doug Ford, the most consistent golfer of the 1953 professional campaign, whipped Sam Snead in a keen two-man battle over the final eighteen-hole stretch today to win the $10,000 Miami open tournament. The Yonkers pro carded a 67 for a seventy-two-hole total of 272, while Snead took second place with a 72 for 276.
Talk has become so cheap throughout the world that not even telephone bills can curb it.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 13 -- John D. Rockefeller Jr., has, pledged an additional $15,000,000 toward restoring this historic capital of eighteenth century Virginia.

Seventy-five years ago last Saturday the elder Joseph Pulitzer got out the first edition of a newspaper called at first The St. Louis Post and Dispatch and later, and ever since, The Post-Dispatch. Mr. Pulitzer announced that his newspaper would "serve no party but the people" and that it would "oppose all frauds and shams wherever and whatever they are."
Maureen Connolly, winner of the national crown the past three years, has retained her No. 1 rating among the country's women tennis players.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 13 -- With arguments completed last week before the United States Supreme Court on the issue of school racial segregation, this was the picture in the South today:

Clinton W. Blume, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., denounced yesterday the plan of the incoming Wagner administration to obtain new revenues of $150,000,000 as "a heavy blow to every walk of life in the city."
Adlai E. Stevenson, accepting an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Yeshiva University, warned last night that the free mind had "enemies in our midst."
BOSTON, Dec. 13 -- Dr. Kirtley F. Mather, Harvard University geologist, protested today against any tendency to make the term "Communist" synonymous with "spy" or "traitor."

An investor has purchased the Castle Apartments, a six-story elevator building on plot 93 by 160 by 100 feet at 2475 Palisade Avenue, overlooking the Hudson River in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx. The building was erected in 1933, its construction featuring a 200-foot foundation and circling terraces.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Swift Co. announced today record production and sales and sharply increased net income in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31. The net profit amounted to $33,903,294, equal to $5.72 a share of common stock, compared with $21,698,417, or $3.66, in the preceding fiscal year.
GARFIELD, N. J., Monday, Dec. 14 -- A strike by 170 teachers will keep the school bells silent in this industrial community today for the second day.
The trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was slightly larger in November than in the preceding month but smaller than in the corresponding month of last year.

Despite some notable improvement in recent months, freedom of inquiry and communication is in "grave danger," according to a comprehensive report made public today by the American Civil Liberties Union.
The Rev. Dr. Frederick R. Knubel said yesterday there had never been a time in history when Americans were more aware of their need for religion than they were today.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 13 -- Mrs. Leonard Smit of Ho-Ho-Kus, N. J., who has had many note-worthy terriers over the years, came up with a new imported winner tonight in the Worcester County Kennel Club show.

When our representative, Arthur H. Dean, walked out of the preliminary conference talks at Panmunjom on Saturday he was doing several things. First of all, he was rebuking the Communists for their imputation of perfidy and treachery to the United States in their charge that this country had "connived" at the release of anti-Communist war prisoners by the Republic of Korea.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- United States representatives will go into the twelfth conference of ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries tomorrow with a four-point program dealing with atomic weapons, the Soviet threat, the European defense army and United States aid.

" A Girl Can Tell" winds up its engagement Saturday night at the Royale. The F. Hugh Herbert comedy, directed by the author, will have registered a run of sixty performances with Janet Blair, Paul McGrath and Tod Andrews heading the cast.

" Heaven and Hell," the third in a series of four dialogue sermons by the Rev. Dr. Julian V. L. Casserley and the Rev. Dr. George W. Barrett, was preached yesterday at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

Christmas group shows and one-man showings of painting and sculpture make up a large part of this week's art activities. On Friday, the Metropolitan Museum will open an exhibition entitled "American Painting, 1754-1954," with oils and water-colors fro mthe museum's colections supplemented by prints and drawings.
Richard Wagner's "Tannhaeuser," which has not been seen in this city since March 12, 1948, will be restored to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera on the evening of Dec. 26.
A northeast storm was sweeping up the coast toward New York last night, bringing with it gale winds, high tides and heavy rain.

When Darwin brought back from his world-wide travels the theory of biological evolution, nineteenth-century scientists were given an entirely new set of hypotheses with which to investigate the nature of man, even the nature of nature itself. But Darwin's findings seemed so important, so at the center of things, that their influence spread beyond the domain of the physical scientists.
There can be no peace in the world "unless there is justice between nations and among men," the Rev. Fidelis Rice declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Light flashed along Park Avenue at 6:15 o'clock last night from the 12,000 yellow and white bulbs that adorn the thirty tall Christmas trees from Thirty-fourth Street to Ninety-sixth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12 -- An anti - Communist movement that promises to spread to such an extent that the Communist party maybe outlawed in this country has been launched by the Argentine Maritime Association.

Under auspices of the International Peasants Union, a forum on "The Crisis in Soviet-style Agriculture Behind the Iron Curtain" will be held tomorrow and Wednesday at the Carnegie Endowment International Center, First Avenue and United Nations Plaza.

This has been a big year for the business for forecasters. So many -- and varied -- have been the published predictions concerning business activity that one wonders what forecasters can possibly find to say that will be new, come January, which is a big month for putting ears to the ground and peering confidently into the future.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles, winging homeward on the passing of Bobby Thomason, stormed from behind twice today and then outclassed the champion Cleveland Browns, 42 -- 27, for the worst defeat ever suffered by the Browns in the National Football League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Eddie LeBaron played an unwilling Santa Claus role today when his behind-the-goal-line pass backfired into an interception that handed the Pittsburgh Steelers an upset 14-13 victory over the Washington Redskins.

George J. Novek and Associates have purchased the four-story apartment building for thirty-two families on plot 81 by 100 feet at 220 Seventy-second Street, in the Shore Road section of Brooklyn, from the M. W. M. Realty Company, which bought the property recently.
RYE, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- A new Girl Scout headquarters, converted by the efforts of the townspeople, was dedicated here today.

The first goal meant nothing for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. Despite the fact that Paul Ronty gave them this valuable edge in the initial period, the Broadway Blues were forced to bow to the Toronto Maple Leafs by the score of 2 to 1.

ONE of the more interesting by-products of the newspaper strike was the realization by some Broadway producers that television might be a useful means of stimulating added interest in the legitimate theatre. In fact, the sages of the Rialto are hinting that TV may be a means of circumventing the so-called "life-or-death" power of the drama critics over a new show.

The New York Times Youth Forum on Saturday will present the first television or radio program related to the Columbia University bicentennial celebration when the Du Mont Network carries the session on WABD from 5:30 to 6:30 P. M.
The ship charter market last week was out of the doldrums. It was being blown far off course by strong headwinds and was losing way.

Those of you who follow this column, especially the American Designer Series of Patterns of The Times, will recall that on Dec. 4, 1950, we showed two sophisticated dresses -- one formal, the other semi-formal -- by the well-known American designer, Philip Hulitar.
VIENNA, Dec, 13 -- Hungary and Rumania announced substantial concessions to their populations this week-end.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. has decided to ask Governor Dewey and the Republican-controlled Legislature to increase the state's contribution to school operating costs here by $55,000,000 a year. He also will ask the state to provide $25,000,000 annually for the next ten years to meet the city's school construction needs, making the total increase $80,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Government reported today that a recent count had shown its wild musk ox herd on Nunivak Island national wildlife refuge in Alaska had increased from seventy-five to ninety animals during the last year.

As expected, it will be the Detroit Lions against the Cleveland Browns for the professional football championship of the world on Sunday, Dec. 27, at Detroit's Briggs Stadium. While the Browns had been "in" for the past two weeks, it was not until yesterday that the Lions, needing only a tie to clinch the play-off berth, qualified by defeating the Giants, 27 -- 16, at the Polo Grounds.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The British Government was reported on excellent authority today to be determined to use every method at its disposal to prevent the nationwide railway strike called for midnight next Sunday.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Lyon Boston, New York attorney and a founder of the Bill of Rights Society, said today that no man should be permitted to invoke the Fifth Amendment to hide a conspiracy "against the whole Bill of Rights and the whole Constitution."

A deeply affecting and finely coordinated performance of Beethoven's Concerto No. 4 in G major was the special feature of the admirable concert given by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra under George Szell, with Rudolf Firkusny as piano soloist, Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 4 -- Saudi Arabia is constructing what is believed to be the world's largest quarantine station with United States assistance to handle the annual flood of Moslem pilgrims from all parts of the world to Mecca and other Islamic holy places in this country.

Igor Gouzenko, the former Russian code clerk who exposed Russian espionage in Canada in 1945, has been working four years on a novel that deals with the decline and murder of "a people's writer" similar to Maxim Gorky. Among the minor characters of the 300,000-word story are Stalin, Malenkov, Voroshilov and one named "Veria," who might be Beria.

ROYSE CITY, Tex., Dec. 13 -- A station wagon and the crack Texas special passenger train smashed together here tonight, killing the six persons in the car and sending the engine and all but four of the fourteen train cars crashing off the tracks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Gordon Dean, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, tonight hailed President Eisenhower's proposal for an atomic energy pool for peaceful purposes as "thoroughly workable." Mr. Dean said the President's plan also had the advantage of offering a practical means of bringing the United States and the Soviet Union together on a sensitive matter.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Last February, Merrill (Mezzy) Barber was told by physicians that his ski jumping career, after twenty-five years, had ended. The Brattleboro, Vt., rider broke four ribs and suffered a serious shoulder injury in a spill in the national championships at Steamboat Springs, Colo.

Col. Elliott W. Amick (U. S. A., retired) was elected president of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association as the seventy-first annual convention of the organization closed yesterday at the Hotel Statler.

THE book business in 1953 was just about the same as in 1952, which means it was pretty good -- and this in spite of the usual complaints caused by high manufacturing costs, a dearth of notable fiction and excursions and alarms caused by cheap paper-bound books. More paper-bound books were sold in 1953 than ever before.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 13 (AP) -- John Landy, who ran a 4:02 mile yesterday at Olympic Park, spent today pursuing his favorite hobby -- chasing butterflies in the country forty miles from Melbourne.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 13 -- Prime Minister John Kotelawala has decided not to allow a goodwill mission from Communist China to visit Ceylon.

The Home Lines passenger vessel Atlantic, delayed a day on its inbound voyage from German and Channel ports by two Atlantic storms, spent slightly less than nine hours in port yesterday. This was described by company officials as the fastest turn-around of any its ships in the Port of New York.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 13 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said tonight that he thought persons suspected of communistic tendencies "are all out of Government now."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Equipped with first-hand impressions of governments, peoples and issues from Tokyo to Teheran, Vice President Richard M. Nixon will return tomorrow from a 'round-the-world trip as President Eisenhower's personal representative.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Without being quite sure how to go about it, the United States would like to develop with its Allies a common Atlantic policy of food stockpiling. The stocks would be justified by defense considerations. But the idea is becoming popular at this time mainly for economic reasons.
Arturo Toscanini conducted the N. B. C. Symphony yesterday evening in Carnegie Hall in the final broadcast concert of his current series. Next week he will surrender the baton to Guido Cantelli.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers broke their five-game losing streak tonight, defeating the Fort Wayne Pistons, 69 -- 68, in a National Basketball Association game. Vince Boryla set the pace for the Knicks with 23 points.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 -- Diplomats and politicians in Bonn have gone into training, so to speak, for the big match, with the Russians in Berlin. But there is an air of unreality about all the shadow-boxing and bag-punching. Almost nobody seems to think the contest will decide anything.

WHIRLPOOL, Ont., Dec. 1 -- This is the postal address of one of the three temporary communities established for the 6,800 men hastening to complete an engineering project designed to produce from the Niagara River more than 1,800,000 horsepower.

Two and three decades ago our women's clubs wilted under the scorn of invading British lecturers. Our intellectual tastebuds, it seemed, had not learned to savor the esorterica of Bloomsbury and Chelsea. The American husband did not palpitate to prunes and prisms.

A recommended decision by C. W. Robinson, Federal Maritime Board hearing examiner, on the important question of whether American Export Lines will be permitted to continue as agent in this country for the Italian Line, a foreign competitor, is due within a week.

Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate were asked yesterday to take prompt action to have the City Planning Commission release its report on relocation of tenants displaced by slum clearance operations and other public improvements.

The strikes we have been seeing in the United States have their parallel in Europe, France, Britain, Italy and even Spain are figuring in the news these days with labor strikes. Italy is only the latest focus of trouble. Britain, ten days ago, had a strike of the engineering unions that was unique in her history, for it was one of those twenty-four-hour "flash" strikes so popular in the Continental labor movement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Purchase of the Eagle Lion Studio for $1,100,000 by a syndicate composed of investors and oil men, including Edwin W. Pauley, former Democratic National Committee chairman, was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Eisenhower and his party's leaders of Congress are entering a week of great exertions that may go far to determine the record of the Republican Congress in the 1954 election year.

A panel of the National Labor Relations Board meets in New York today to consider a critical decision affecting the waterfront dispute. The Board has before it petitions for a representation election to determine whether the longshoremen wish to be represented in collective bargaining by the old International Longshoremen's Association, which was expelled from the A. F. L. for failing to rid itself of racketeers, or by the new A. F. L. longshore union.
The inner workings of the pension and welfare fund of Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., will be disclosed at public hearings starting tomorrow.

OGDENSBURG, N. Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Marion U. Wells, Saint Lawrence County Republican leader, resigned yesterday as vice chairman of the county Republican committee. The resignation followed a meeting of Franklin and Saint Lawrence Republican committees last week in Potsdam.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- The Democratic donkey plans to reverse the usual role and try the "carrot and stick" treatment on people.

The Stone Webster Engineering Corporation was quoted yesterday as warning that if foreign-made electric equipment is extensively used in the utility systems of the United States it might lead to extended paralysis in the American economy in the event of disaster, such as the 1938 hurricane on the Eastern seaboard or the Kansas City floods of 1951.
Late in October Buenos Alres announced the first shipment of goods for the Soviet Union under the Russian-Argentine trade agreement signed in August.

RYE, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- William C. Kernan, who ended twenty-six years as a Protestant Episcopal minister last year to embrace Roman Catholicism, took issue today with his former superior, Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the New York Protestant Episcopal diocese.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- A home-building technique developed in South Africa has been adapted by United Nations experts to help spur South Korea's first national housing program since the end of the war.

There's some arithmetic involved in a new gimmick to promote the sale of bobby socks. Rudin Roth, one of the largest makers of the anklets for women and girls, is wrapping up "$50 an ounce" Folie de Minuit perfume with every three pairs in a box of acetate. "

In your recent summary of the Truman-Brownell controversy you indicated that one of its practical effects might be legislation authorizing Congress or its committees to grant immunity from federal prosecution to those witnesses who claimed the protection of the Fifth Amendment.
BRISBANE, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The interzone tennis matches with Belgium here this week-end will provide the acid test for America's Davis Cup doubles combination of Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert.

Business transacted in the foreign exchange market during the past week was fairly heavy at certain periods. Quotations for the British pound sterling moved erratic while the Canadian dollar displayed a very strong undertone.

A world-wide program of relief and rehabilitation among Jewish men, women and children, with special emphasis on Israel, was adopted yesterday by the United Jewish Appeal. A goal of $119,921,150 was set for 1954.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Y. A. Tittle tossed four touchdown passes as the San Francisco Forty-Niners defeated the Baltimore Colts, 45 -- 14, today, but the victory was in vain as Detroit clinched the western division title with a victory over New York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- The chair is the home furnishing item of most popular interest for store buyers and consumers, a poll at the Good Design exhibit at the Merchandise Mart here shows. Almost five hundred home furnishings objects make up the exhibit, arranged by the Museeum of Modern Art and the Merchandise Mart.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Italy was understood today to have informed the French that a new crisis in Italian-Yugoslav relations might be inequitable. This might be averted, it was said, if the United States, Britain and France made a determined effort to persuade Belgrade to accept a five-power conference for a final solution of the Trieste question.

In 1798, a young British philosopher-economist, Thomas Robert Malthus, published anonymously a treatise of 50,000 words under the title "An Essay on the Principles of Population as it Affects the Future Improvement of Society."

Mayor Impellitteri has been warned that New York's aged are increasing nine times as fast as the rest of the city's population and are confronted by serious social and economic problems that make them "easily fall prey to demogogic proposals."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 13 -- A radical revision of Israel's farm settlement pattern involving a shift from small to large holdings has been recommended to the Government by an official of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 14 -- Arthur H. Dean, special United States envoy, urged the Communists last night to drop their tactics of abuse, tirade and delay and give some indication that they were prepared to negotiate "in a reasonable way" for a Korean peace conference.

LOU LITTLE is currently taking a poll of various interested parties on the subject of footballs platoon systems. The Columbia maestro is the chairman of the coaches' rules committee and he'd like to arm himself with both facts and measured opinions before he faces the other members of the lodge. He's even canvassing those who are supposed to have their fingers on the public pulse -- the football writers.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- As Christmas and the year end draw near, a noticeable but normal slackening of interest in the stock markets is developing and a gentle downward swing in security prices is accompanying this public preoccupation with the holidays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Accelerated tax certificates, covering eighty-eight defense production projects with an estimated value of $85,642,531, were granted by the Office of Defense Mobilization in the period from Nov. 19 to Dec. 2, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy declared tonight that the Eisenhower Administration was "heading in the right direction" in eliminating subversives from Government, but added:

INDIAN VILLAGE, Korea, Monday, Dec. 14 -- The United Nations Command was informed officially last night that the United States soldiers who preferred to remain prisoners of the Communist command in Korea had refused to appear today before their fellow countrymen for explanations of why they should return home.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The gas strike is not over yet, but representatives of the striking union and the Public Service Electric and Gas Company today cooperated in raising a Christmas wreath at the First Baptist Church here.

The forty-second annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund began yesterday. Many of the 584 persons who gave $88,180.42 toward this year's campaign expressed a hope that the week's delay in the opening of the appeal, caused by the newspaper strike, would not affect the benefits to individuals and families in need.

PANAMA, Dec. 12 -- Pedro Estrada, Chief of Venezuela's security police, says he has evidence that Communists, on instructions from abroad, plan to try to disrupt the Conference of American States to be held in Caracas.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany, who had private talks today with the Western Big Three's foreign ministers, said tonight that he "had not dared to hope" to find the others and himself so well agreed.
Public schools of this city will need 15,500 to 18,900 new teachers in the 1953-61 period, it was reported yesterday.

The twelve young women and twelve men of the Vienna Academy Chorus wound up their first United States tour yesterday afternoon with a concert at Town Hall. It meant that this city was finally able to hear the sort of accomplished singing that other American cities have already enjoyed.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The American Farm Bureau Federation this week will hold what may be the most widely watched convention in its history.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 13 -- Vietnam's Chief of State, Bao Dai, discussed with Premier Nguyen Van Tam today the Premier's ultimatum for contacts with the Communist-led Vietminh rebels looking toward negotiations, general elections and a national union government.

The Choate School's new artificial hockey rink, dedicated a week ago last Saturday, has been named the Courtenay Hemenway Rink. The selection of the name comes as no surprise to the school's alumni. Hemenway has long been known as the father of Choate hockey because he introduced the sport at the Wallingford (Conn.) school forty-one years ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Public school enrollment continues to rise in the state, according to the State Education Department. A report today showed that there were 2,204,605 pupils in the schools on Sept. 30, an increase of 90,368, or about 4.3 per cent correspondingly over 1952.

WASHINGTON Dec. 13 (AP) -- Two Republicans and two Democrats joined tonight in saying that Communist investigations should be taken out of the hands of the committees headed by Senator McCarthy, Senator William E. Jenner and Representative Harold A. Velde.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Dec. 13 -- Mrs. Janet Jagan, Chicago-born secretary of the left-wing Progressive People's party was arrested with nine other party members and charged with a breach of the British Guiana emergency regulations here tonight.
In a recent news story under the heading "Child Delinquency Called Challenge" it is stated that "the problem has become too big for local handling alone."

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- That there should be no dollar shortage in 1954 but that the dollar problem remains unsolved is one of the conclusions of a report on the economy of the United States published here today. The report was drawn up by the Organization for European Economic cooperation.

The problem of resolving law and liberty is the outstanding "dilemma" of our time, the Rev. Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, former dean of Drew Theological Seminary, Madison, N. J., declared yesterday. He was guest preacher at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
DETROIT, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay and Bill Dineen each scored two goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings edged the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 3, before a crowd of 13,731 at Olympia.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 -- Control of steel inventories, and reduction of them in some instances, has been causing the steel rate to decline. In recent weeks it has sagged below 90 per cent. Last week's estimate was 86 per cent, down one point from the rate in the two preceding weeks.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The Marymount College Glee Club of ninety-five women's voices and the United States Military Academy Glee Club, ninety strong, will give the second of a home-and-home series of pre-Christmas concerts in the Army Theatre at West Point next Saturday evening.

Ask and it shall be provided might be an appropriate theme for department stores and specialty shops saluting the approaching holidays this year. The variety in food presentation is apparently endless.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Federal Office of Education has just issued a ninety-one-page pamphlet on three-dimensional teaching aids. But it has nothing whatever to do with 3-D movies and comic books.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Britons of all political hues are stirred up over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's attacks on British trade with Communist China.

Italy won applause the other day from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization when the Italian delegate gave up the seat on the Problems Committee to which he had been elected to the defeated candidate from Yugoslavia. This was a small gesture and received little publicity, much less than if the representatives of the two countries had fought for the post.
A brilliant spectacle was in order when the Guard Republican Band of Paris, as it is called in announcements, gave its New York concert of its present tour last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Projected outlays by industry and business for a new plant and equipment were viewed by Congressional economic experts today as a highly encouraging signal for the country's economic course.
A factory worker, his wife and their two daughters were found dead last night in their Brooklyn apartment, where they had been overcome by gas fumes from the kitchen stove.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Increasing pressure of profit-taking sales in grain and soybean futures took the edge off Board of Trade bull markets last week. There appeared to be increasing unwillingness to follow bulges at current levels, notwithstanding bullish developments in the wheat market and continued strength in cash corn and oats, country offerings of which were light.

A meeting of American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations seamen's unions will be held in Washington on Jan. 18 to discuss topics ranging from governmental policy on the merchant marine to inter-union problems.

Bonds called for payment in November before maturity dropped to the lowest level for any month since September, 1949. The total of $9,948,000, compared with $13,506,000 in the preceding month and $19,197,000 in November, 1952.

KHARTUM, Sudan, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Final election results in the Sudan gave the pro-Egyptian National Unionist party tonight a total of twenty-one of the thirty elected seats in the fifty-member upper house (Senate) of the first Sudanese Parliament.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 13 -- Strained Benelux relations have improved following last week's conference. Besides the agreement on a common trade and payments policy against a third country, the conference of ministers has in principle decided upon freeing inter-Benelux capital traffic.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Howard McMichael, the men's Long Island Sound sailing champion, won today's Frostbite regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Communists are so deeply entrenched in all phases of Guatemalan life it may no longer be possible to eliminate them peaceably, according to the National Planning Association.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- A $250,000 program to provide hearing aids for deaf children whose parents are unable to afford such devices will get under way in the state early next year. Governor Dewey announced today that the state would cooperate with county governments in financing this new aspect of the 35-year-old physically handicapped children's program.
EVERY skipper dreams of the day when he will swallow the anchor, buy a small farm and turn his back forever on the sea. Only one among hundreds ever gets to live out the dream.

The twin-engined turbojet transport that the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation of Hagerstown, Md., plans to build for the ailines and the Air Force may have to be enlarged and its payload and range increased. This appeared likely last week after airline spokesmen had inspected the specifications.
Members of Local 1, International Stereotypers Union, A. F. L., voted unanimously yesterday to accept the formula that ended the recent newspaper strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Mrs. Georgia Lusk, former chairman of the War Claims Commission, aid today the agency should have a surplus of about $20,000,000 after paying off private claims against former enemy nations.
The suburban schools in the metropolitan area are facing difficult problems. The population is growing so rapidly that classrooms cannot be built fast enough to provide space for the pupils.

SALISBURY, Md., Dec. 13 (AP) -- A couple and their two young daughters were killed today after their car was struck at a street intersection here by another automobile and sent spinning 30 feet into a filling station.

A fourth patient was added yesterday to the caseload of three Merrit-Chapman Scott Corporation ocean-going salvage vessels ministering to three small cargo ships stranded in Caribbean waters. She was the 3,805 grosston Colombian motor cargo ship Ciudad de Bogota.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 12 -- Relations between the United States and South Korea have reached an acute stage.

Jacob Avshalomoff and the Columbia University Chorus presented Handel's "The Triumph of Time and Truth" Saturday night at the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University. In doing so, they placed American choral societies and, it is to be hoped, many future concertgoers deeply in their debt.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Government circles are concerned over the situation of the French coal industry. Sales have dropped, creating increased stockpiles, causing unemployment and considerable financial loss.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 13 -- Thirty-two appointments to Rhodes Scholarships were announced here today by Dr. Courtney Smith, American secretary of the Rhodes Scholarship Trust, who is president of Swarthmore College.
Whether or not Western nations engage in "non-strategic" trade with the Communist world is an issue that could influence far more than American political contests of the immediate future.
The Edward John Noble Foundation, a philanthropic agency, announced yesterday that it had received a gift of $2,000,000 from Edward J. Noble of Greenwich, Conn.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Portia Howe, the mother who waited in vain to see her war prisoner son who has renounced his country, today read a letter from him jeering at the United States.
SAIGON, Dec. 13 -- The military situation is becoming increasingly grave all over Indo-China.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals exploited the breaks to score their first victory of the season in a National Football League finale against the Chicago Bears, 24 -- 17, before 38,059 today.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 -- West Germany's industrial magnates have served notice on the Government that they will oppose the introduction of the United States economic concept and practice of free competition as the basic pattern of the German economic system.
A decline in bond flotations and an increase in stock issues marked the public offerings of new securities here in November.
HAVANA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Rice growing has become a boom business in Cuba.

The portent of the atom is uppermost in men's minds today as the NATO nations' ministers meet in Paris to chart the future course of the free world's defenses. On our side of the Iron Curtain, millions of men and women are discussing with new hope and excitement the promising proposals put forward in President Eisenhower's brilliant address last week.

On April 14, 1919, Pierre Monteux conducted a performance of "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera. Shortly, thereafter he left the company, having been associated with it for two seasons. Thus, while the "Carmen" he conducted at the Metropolitan Saturday night could not properly be called a "first," only a handful of oldtimers could vouch for his previous work in the opera.

HUNTINGDON, Tenn., Dec. 13 (UP) -- A battered Republican "Old Guard" leader, cut and bruised after a county convention that wound up in a fist fight, conceded today that he had lost his eight-year chairmanship to a representative of the county G. O. P. "New Guard."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 13 -- Factionalism caused by the harness racing scandals led today toward a secession movement from the United States Trotting Association by a score of pari-mutuel betting tracks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Bill Mosienko scored with only 75 seconds left to play tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 2-2 tie with the Boston Bruins before 5,092 fans. The deadlock was the second between the teams in six National Hockey League games this year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- All grain futures as well as soybeans were under pressure in early trading today. But demand in all pits became more active on the setbacks, with considerable commission absorption on resting orders. Professional traders were inclined to press the market at times.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The warning by John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, of a change of United States policy if the European army was rejected came as a shock to the French today. Mr. Dulles made this statement at a news conference after having made it at a meeting of the North Atlantic Council.

The world's smallest regular radio -- small enough to fit in the palm of the hand -- was demonstrated yesterday afternoon in Times Square. The populace took the coming of the "Dick Tracy Age" with disconcerting calmness.
Nathan Milstein, in brilliantly fine form, gave one of the season's outstanding violin recitals at Carnegie Hall last evening.

The Radio Corporation of America estimates that its gross earnings for 1953 will approximate $830,000,000, compared with $690,641,130 last year, and that net income will amount to about $34,700,000, or $2.25 a share. In 1952 the company earned $32,325,299, or $2.10 a share.
OTTAWA, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Trade Minister C. D. Howe said today that Canada had accepted a limitation "for a relatively short period" of exports of oats to the United States.

George H. Coppers has been elected a trustee of the Greenwich Savings Bank of New York. He is president and a director of the National Biscuit Company, a trustee of the Consolidated Edison Company, and a director of the Home Life Insurance Company.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14 -The Yale Medical School tomorrow will receive $8,000 to further research on leukemia. The donors, firemen of New Britain, Conn., have promised that more will be available yearly.
Forty-two thousand city employes not covered by the New York City Employment System are now eligible for Federal Social Security benefits.
A proposed law to permit the city to regulate slum homes with rented rooms was discussed here yesterday by state legislators.

Michael J. Quill fired a warning blast yesterday in a new -- but not unexpected -- transit war of nerves. The excitable president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., who has often threatened to call a strike on New York's municipal subway, bus and elevated lines, but never actually has, reported he had been "compelled" to break off negotiations with the New York City Transit Authority.

Heffernan-McMahon, Inc., a newly organized general advertising agency, has leased office space in the Grand Central Terminal Building at 70 East Forty-fifth Street. Robert Phelps Kukuck, president of the agency, formerly was an executive of Flint Advertising Associates.

Mrs. Portia Howe, mother of an American prisoner of war in Korea, is still waiting to see her son, who has renounced his country. Meanwhile the son has written her a letter jeering at the United States. "Where did I fail?" asks Mrs. Howe.

Two Russian imports, "Daring Circus Youth" and Chuk and Gek," have been added to the week's schedule of openings. The Stanley will present the two films on Saturday, with "Daring Circus Youth," a documentary of the Moscow Youth Circus, making up the first half of the program.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Government's plan to introduce commercial television was caustically criticized today by Labor party spokesmen in the House of Commons.
The New York Knickerbockers, having broken a five-game losing streak at Fort Wayne Sunday night, will be at home in Madison Square Garden tonight against the champion Minneapolis Lakers.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy announced yesterday that he would demand the names of individuals who had cleared a man to handle classified Navy data during World War II -- after the man's name had appeared on numerous articles in the Daily Worker and New Masses, Communist publications.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 14 (AP) -- General Shoe Corporation announced tonight it had purchased I. Miller Sons, Inc., women's shoe manufacturing company with offices in New York and factories in New England.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that dealers selling automobiles under franchise agreements with the major motor car manufacturers were under the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board in their dealings with employes, even though their operations took place within one state.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -The short subject, practically made extinct by the double feature, is expected to regain some of its old importance as more theatres turn to a single picture exhibition policy with the showing of CinemaScope productions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -New York State contended today, in a brief filed with the United States Court of Appeals, that it had legal authority to accept a Federal Power Commission license to join with the province of Ontario, Canada, in the construction of the St. Lawrence River power project.
Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba, his former Interior Minister and two Americans pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to a charge of violation of this country's Neutrality Act.
Charity fakers have taken at least $120,000,000 out of this year's record donations by the American public of $4,000,000,000, a joint legislative committee was told yesterday.

One hundred American cooks combined imagination, hard work, good ingredients and recipes culled from tradition, experience and happy accidents to produce the fifth annual Grand National Recipe and Baking Contest Bake-off in the Waldorf-Astoria's grand ballroom yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation is preparing to reindorse its position favoring flexible farm price supports. It appears, however, to be softening to a degree its opposition to supports at high, rigid levels.
General Robert E. Wood, chairman of the board of Sears, Roebuck Co., has been named chairman of an advisory committee for the Merchandise Mart Hall of Fame in Chicago, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A continued decline of business activity sent industrial production in November below the year-ago level for the first time in 1953, the December report of the President's Council of Economic Advisers showed today.

A yawning set of shark jaws that must have been anything but inviting to ocean fish of twenty-five to fifty million years ago will greet visitors to the new Fossil Fish Alcove of the American Museum of Natural History when it is opened next year.
Directors of Johnson Johnson declared an extra dividend of 25 cents yesterday to be paid common stockholders on Jan. 11. This will bring 1953 declarations to $1.65 compared with $1 paid in 1952.

Four new groups of bedroom furniture, adapted from nineteenth century styles and having a small-scale appearance, are on view at the Harry Meyers Company, 18 East Fiftieth Street. The furniture is available through decorators.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 14 -- Chief United States District Court Judge Paul Leahy dismissed today the Department of Justice's anti-trust suit charging E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., with a monopoly in the manufacture and sale of cellophane.

TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- The deer hunting season opened in New Jersey today and will continue through Saturday. With far more of the fleet-footed animals roaming the sate than at any time in the last 100 years, upward of 5,000 sportsmen are expected to participate in the hunt.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- There is to be no chance in the United Kingdom's policy regarding the delimitation of territorial waters, Selwyn Lloyd told the House of Commons today.
The city's proposed $510,966,795 capital budget for 1954, largest in its history, was approved without change yesterday by the City Council Finance Committee.

IF Jack Webb, the Sergeant Friday of the Dragnet program, were a sports nut, he'd still say with deadpan seriousness, "I only want the facts, ma'am." But he could find every sports fact he ever wanted to pursue in the new "Encyclopedia of Sports," an extraordinary volume just published by A. S. Barnes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The speech of Adlai E. Stevenson at Philadelphia Saturday night is another demonstration of the high standards that guide him in political controversy. The temptation is strong to a defeated Presidential candidate to make the welkin ring, whatever that may do to the Liberty Bell; and many of his party leaders and most of those shorn of office and power expect it of him.
KITTY HAWK, N. C., Dec. 14 -A reconstruction of the crude loblolly pine hanger and summer house built here more than fifty years ago by Orville and Wilbur Wright was dedicated this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower called on 175 mayors and city managers today to help prepare the country's defenses while there was time for an "ordered haste" to spare the cities the disaster of "panic."

The sixth shipload of United Nations military personnel returned direct from the Far East to the Port of New York is scheduled to dock here tomorrow morning. Eleven hundred American soldiers, many veterans of the Korean war, will be lining the rails of the Navy transport Gen. LeRoy Eltinge.

NYACK, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Enraged residents from Pearl River, N. Y., and near-by Rivervale, N. J., protested tonight a plan by the American Cyanamid Company to store 60,000 pounds of explosives on a site less than two miles from their villages. The proposed site is on the west bank of the Hackensack River.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower will be told that there is important opposition in both parties in Congress to the Administration proposal to freeze Social Security taxes at the current level.
More new lows -- fifty-three -- were reported on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday than in any day since the first week in September. The market slumped generally after noon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Two Democrats notified President Eisenhower today that they would go to court to challenge his power to remove them as members of the War Claims Commission. They charged that the Republicans he had named to succeed them were "usurpers and intruders."
Only one member of the twentyfour-man voting committee dissented as Harvey Kuenn, the brilliant shortstop of the Tigers, was named rookie of the year in the American League for 1953.

The financial helping hand extended to industries in critical target areas in return for bombproofing their plants actually endangers the national security, an executive of a factory-locating organization contends.

A package offer of $3.75 a week plus fact-finding -- the formula that ended the recent newspaper strike -- was offered yesterday to members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. L., by the Publishers Association of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -The Democratic Mayors of Philadelphia and Houston, Tex., tonight sharply criticized the Eisenhower Administration for not telling the American people more about civil defense and atomic warfare.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 14--Lewis Carroll should have written the dialogue for the scene enacted today in a tiny courtroom in Frankfurt. Alice should have been the defendant.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The British Cabinet held an emergency meeting tonight to consider means of averting the nation-wide railway strike threatened for midnight Sunday.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 13 -- The new look of Argentine policy toward the United States makes a strong impression on a visitor to Argentina today. Hearty friendliness in official circles has replaced a hostility that at best was veiled and often open.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The nation's top military planner reported today on the "New Look" at the armed services. He forecast a defense establishment based on air supremacy, increased reliance on atomic weapons and fewer men under arms.

Cocoa prices were up the limit in all positions on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. The rise was due to reports that purchases of main crop Accra cocoa are running well behind last year's figures and that the Bahia crop is practically sold out.

Subversive infiltration in the Government is the subject of a book on which James Burnham is now working. Based on the testimony of the many Congressional investigations and court trials, the book will be entitled "The Web of Subversion: Underground Networks in the U. S. Government."

GARFIELD, N. J., Dec. 14--Striking teachers here will picket nine public schools tomorrow. The strike was called last Friday by Garfield Local, American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., in protest against the failure of the city to provide the pay increases that have been promised the teachers since September, 1952.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, warned the North Atlantic Treaty allies today that if a European army, including West German contingents, was not established soon the United States would be forced into an "agonizing reappraisal of its own basic policies."

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The threat of a railroad strike next week brought dullness to most domestic industrial stocks here today. However, some of the best industrials resisted the trend, while South African gold mining issues and foreign bonds improved modestly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Reorganization of the National Park Service to "more effectively meet current needs" was announced today by Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announced today sugar quotas for 1954 at 8,000,000 short tons, raw value, or 200,000 tons larger than the initial 1953 figure.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 14 -Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion reverted today to his role of four decades ago, before he piloted the Jewish people to national revival. With his wife Paula, he settled in Sdeh Boker, an isolated pioneer farm in the heart of the barren Negev.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Faced with the threat of United States import restrictions, Canada has agreed to limit her shipments of oats to this country to 23,000,000 bushels for the period Dec. 10, 1953, to Oct. 1, 1954.

Six hundred and thirty pints of blood were collected Friday by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Included were 181 pints donated at the Sinclair Oil Company, 600 Fifth Avenue, and 135 pints at Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Beane, 70 Pine Street.
Tuesday, Dec. 15 -- One of the American prisoners of the Korean war who has denounced his country asked to see his mother yesterday and another asked for his Japanese wife.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- King Paul urged the Greek press tonight to work continuously "for greater unity within as well as without our borders."
ATLANTA, Dec. 14 (UP) -- The Colonial Dames reminded the nation tonight of freedom's forgotten man -- George Mason.

The well-named busy bee is important in agriculture in this country. About fifty important crops depend upon it for pollination. It would take a lifetime to discover and sample all the possible varieties of honey that bees distill from the 2,000 species of nectar-bearing plants in this country.

Betty Impellitteri has decided she may as well profit by the knowledge she has acquired as wife of the Mayor. Therefore, on Jan. 1, when her husband vacates City Hall, she will move into her own publicity offices at 30 Central Park South.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon returned today from his world goodwill tour and said Asia was hungry for peace. Unless the Communist leaders accept President Eisenhower's proposals for transforming the world's atomic energy from destructive to peaceful uses, the Communists will lose ground "tremendously" in Asia, he added.

TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County, and two former county detectives must stand trial on charges of malicious prosecution and malicious abuse of legal processes.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 (UP) -Bishop Lloyd C. Wicke of the Methodist Church said today Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Representative Harold H. Velde were adopting "the techniques and practices of our enemies in the name of national defense and patriotic vigilance."
HONG KONG, Dec. 14 -- None of the industries embraced in Communist China's new five-year plan will be situated in South China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board today gave Judge Henry Clay Greenberg of the New York Supreme Court a two-day postponement instead of the ninety-day one he had asked for hearings on the International Workers Order.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 15 -- Arthur H. Dean, special United States envoy, tersely rejected a Communist proposal for resumption today of negotiations for an international conference on Korean affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)--The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today widened its legal battle against segregation in interstate travel to include railroad stations and restaurants.

CROWBOROUGH, England, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Charlie Macey, a golf professional, added another feat to his record today: jumping around in a pub on a pogo stick for more than an hour and a half, to collect a $2.80 bet.
DENVER, Dec. 14 -- Officials of this city today declared that slum conditions were the primary factor in a sharpened juvenile delinquency situation here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -Mrs. Evelyn Cooper, counsel for groups backing a Federal dam in Hell's Canyon, Idaho, today questioned whether the Idaho Power Company's rates have permitted maximum industrial development in the state and whether its three proposed dams in the canyon area would be adequate for future needs.
CAIRO, Dec. 14 -- Robert Hankey, British Charge d'Affaires and negotiator in the Suez dispute with Egypt, paid a farewell call today on President Mohammed Naguib.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, emphatically rejected today the "neutralization" of Germany, which he said the Soviet Union would try to achieve at the proposed four-power talks in Berlin.

Indiana, Kentucky and Duquesne, tabbed as this year's big three of college basketball before the season began, held on to the top positions in the national ratings in the first weekly Associated Press poll yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Following is the text of an address to the National Press Club today by Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff:

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Governor Dewey said today that he had filled two key posts, those of Commissioner of Investigations and president of the Civil Service Commission. However, he declined to give the names of the men chosen for the new jobs.

A fossil bed containing eight "practically perfect" skulls of the Dawn Horse, earliest known ancestor of the horse, has been found in Colorado. The discovery was announced yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History.

Today is the 162d anniversary of the ten amendments to the United States Constitution which are collectively called the Bill of Rights. Without these amendments, which were rushed through to meet the objection that the Constitution did not sufficiently protect the individual, the Union might not have lasted.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its ruling of Nov. 9 that organized baseball is exempt from the anti-trust laws.

The State, County and Municipal Employes, A. F. L., challenged yesterday the legality of the loyalty questionnaire prepared by the Municipal Civil Service Commission for use by eighteen "sensitive" city departments and agencies.

Many seats have been purchased for the performance of "Mademoiselle Colombe" on the night of Jan. 12 at the Longacre Theatre for the benefit of the Greer Children's Community in Dutchess County, N.Y. Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth and Mrs. Simmons Coleman are co-chairmen of the benefit committee, and among their aides is Mrs. Paul E. Peabody.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- West Germany's trade with the Soviet world, including Communist China, increased 44 per cent during the first nine months of this year.

Each year at this time the Bureau of Motor Vehicles makes a valiant effort to get motorists to renew their automobile registration early. Automobile license tabs went on sale Dec. 1. They may not be used before Jan. 1, 1954, but must be used by Feb. 1. In other words, there is still plenty of time to beat the deadline without rush or crush in getting down to the Motor Vehicle Bureau.

Harrison A. Williams Jr., the Democratic Representative - elect from the traditionally Republican Sixth New Jersey District, came here yesterday to tell the New York Young Democratic Club "how to win in a Republican district."
There are two significant factors present in Coach Johnny Bach's current Fordham basketball team that stamp the Ram outfit a more cohesive one than the 1952-53 squad that compiled an 18-4 record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Justice Department retreated today from it position that Indians in Arizona and California had a "prior and superior" right to the use of water from the Colorado River and its tributaries.
On the second day of the forty-second annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, contributions amounted to $106,599.84, of which $18,419.42 was donated yesterday by 302 persons.
A Christmas-time wonderland for Rocket-Age children, aged 4 to 8, opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's informal address today to the White House Conference of Mayors:
A Negro housewife asserted yesterday that a season locker at the Castle Hill Beach Club, at 355 Castle Hill Avenue, the Bronx, had been denied her because of discrimination against her race.

Parents can learn a lot about dealing with their children's behavior by becoming familiar with disciplinary lessons that every teacher is expected to know. This advice is offered in the latest issue of Teacher s Letter, a fortnightly service bulletin for educators.

The iron and steel industry's payroll climbed to a new high of $290,583,000 in October, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday. This compared with $283,773,000 the month before and $282,896,000 in October last year.
The Board of Higher Education approved last night an estimated budget of $22,622,947 for the four city colleges in the 1954-55 fiscal year.

Larry B. Ellentuck, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the five-story apartment house at 204 East Ninetieth Street from the estate of Jacob Sobel. Samuel Sason and Arthur Lichtner were co-brokers with Schimmer, Kerner Feder in the transaction, in which title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Billy Graham of the East Side and Paddy Young of Greenwich Village, main-bout opponents in the feature at Madison Square Garden on Friday, were examined and found fit at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Marquess of Salisbury predicted today that by the year 2000 the greater part of this country's electricity would be generated from atomic energy.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Ormandy, will be heard in weekly one-hour concerts over the C. B. S. radio network beginning Saturday, Jan. 2, at 6 P. M. The commentator during the intermission periods will be Eric Hodgins, author of "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House" and contributing editor of Fortune magazine.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 14 -- Ceylonese Buddhists are objecting to having Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh view the colorful Buddhist procession (perahera) in Kandy, seat of Buddhism, from the octagon attached to the temple unless the Queen pays homage to the sacred tooth of Buddha.

DETROIT, Dec. 14 -- The automobile industry was urged today by Robert Moses to take the lead in pushing through a ten-year $50,000,000,000 road-building program. This, he said, was imperative to relieve traffic congestion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., visited President Eisenhower today and urged repeal of the 20 per cent Federal amusement tax. He asserted that repeal of the tax would create enough new employment to make up the loss of tax revenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today he was "generally very favorably impressed with the career foreign service people with whom I came in contact" on his ten-week round-the-world tour.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 14--A murder indictment charging Mrs. Barbara Jean Hrostoski with the deaths of her two children was dismissed today in Suffolk County Supreme Court.

Floyd Patterson, 1952 Olympic 165-pound champion, of Brooklyn, gained his ninth victory in as many starts as a professional last night when he knocked out Dick Wagner of Toppenish, Wash., in the fifth round of a light-heavyweight test scheduled for eight rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 14 -- An ordinance providing 50 per cent pay increases for the Mayor and the four other members of the City Commission will be introduced at the commission's meeting tomorrow, Mayor John V. Kenny said today.

MEDIA, Pa., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The settlement of a contest over the will of Samuel D. Riddle was announced today by Judge E. LeRoy Van Roden of the Delaware County Orphans Court. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed immediately.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 14 -- South Korean President, Syngman Rhee roundly criticized both the United Nations and United States aid missions here today for excessive traveling and administrative expenses and for the unnecessary and useless purchase of goods in Japan.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Those considered the leading candidates for French President are reluctant about entering the first round of the election to be held Thursday. They want to be the dark horse who cuts over the wire in the lead at the last minute.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- West Germany has been brought into the Atlantic alliances planning for civilian defense, particularly the defense against an air attack.

CORAL GABLES, Dec. 14 (AP)--Hampton Stable's Alerted, one of the "name" horses of the country, failed in his first winter start at Tropical Park today when he could finish no better than seventh in an overnight race of $2,500, called the Vendredi Purse.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 14 -- Sources close to Premier Nguyen Van Tam of Vietnam expected today that he would resign within a few days.
Wilhelm Furtwaengler, German conductor who since 1936 has cancelled four scheduled series in this country, is planning to tour the United States with the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra in 1955.

TRENTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether law enforcement officials could threaten to prosecute potential lawbreakers, particularly sellers of books allegedly obscene.

November, with a decrease of 2.2 per cent from November, 1952, was the fourth consecutive month in which sales declined for leading chain stores and mail order companies, according to a survey of forty-two companies made by The New York Times.

Walter J. Daily, vice president and manager of the vacuum cleaner division of the Lewyt Corporation, at a sales meeting yesterday said the company's 1953 volume was already 31 per cent above 1952 and that he counted on a further 15 per cent increase this year.

Time was when the captains of industry took the stand: "The public be damned." That time has long since passed, with the Sherman Anti-Trust and Hepburn Laws, the S. E. C., the Wagner Labor Law putting them in their place. Nowadays it is obvious that the leaders of the labor unions have been taking the stand: "The public be damned."

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 14 (Reuters)--The new 23,000-ton luxury liner Olympia, flagship of the Greek Line, will go into drydock here early tomorrow after having run aground on a mud bank last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that a "substantial lessening of competition" must be found before it will rule against a concern in anti-trust cases.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Following are the texts of the introduction and the findings and recommendations of the report of the National Security Training Commission as sent to the President today:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Department of the Interior has announced significant changes in its Missouri Basin Power policy, long under fire by the Rural Electric Co-operatives.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- In his annual report to the North Atlantic Council, Lord Ismay, Secretary General, announced today that "important progress" had been made in building up the defense of West Europe.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Diplomatic sources said today that Soviet Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov has made an informal bid to discuss the sale of military equipment to India if the United States should decide to arm neighboring Pakistan.

Election of Frank R. Riesenberger, John Fiske, William B. Carr and Clayton C. Westland as directors of the McCall Corporation was announced yesterday by Marvin Pierce, president. Mr. Riesenberger, president of Van Raalte Company, Inc., is treasurer of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers and a member of the executive committee of the Underwear Institute.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--A new plan to get from the Soviet Union 186 American ships as part settlement of its $11,000,000,000 lend-lease account dating back to World War II apparently had broken down today.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 14 -- The anti-Communist University Students Committee published today a manifesto denouncing the Red upswing in Guatemala.

Two waterfront public loaders were sentenced yesterday to state prison terms by General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente. He described the case as "another striking illustration of the short-sightedness of big business in cuddling up with the underworld."
