William A. Maxwell of Bakersfield, Calif., the national champion, has top ranking in the seniors' singles division of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for 1953. The Californian furnished a big surprise at the West Side Club during the nationals when he turned back the defending ruler, Harry Hopman, non-playing captain of the Australian Davis Cup squad.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Wind - whipped seas swamped and sank a Navy liberty launch today and dumped at least sixty-five officers and men from the cruiser Pittsburgh into the cold waters of Hampton Roads Harbor. Near-by ships sped to the rescue, and later the Navy said it appeared all had been saved.

Lower prices for sugar in the world market, production curtailed by drought and rising taxes reduced the net income of South Porto Rico Sugar Company in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 to $2,690,553 from $6,236,898 in the previous year.

Secretary Dulles appealed yesterday to the ministers' conference of the North Atlantic Alliance to speed ratification of the European Defense Community. A united Europe, Mr. Dulles emphasized, is necessary not only to ward off the Soviet menace. It is equally needed to keep the West from destroying itself by constant strife.
The curent controversy over the best size for New York City taxicabs has focused attention on how the issue of large cab versus small cab is met in other cities.
Is it that the programs of our big symphony orchestras given in the grandest halls have to be invariably of the solemn and traditional kind?
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange eased early yesterday but firmed later and closed 2 points off to 13 points up.
BRISBANE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- If the American Davis Cup team "murders" the Belgians here this weekend and then goes on to do a job on the Australians the explanation should be simple.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 14 -- Strategy was mapped today by the United States Trotting Association to meet the threat to harness racing posed by the decision of a group of pari-mutuel tracks to form their own organization. The move is interpreted here as a prelude to secession.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- A survey of United States public opinion has found that 73 per cent of the people in the United States feel their best hopes for peace rest in the United Nations. By a 2-to-1 majority, they would prefer to have the Soviet Union inside, not outside, the world organization.
Tonnage on the ways of American shipbuilding concerns declined last month.

The Advertising Men's Post 209, American Legion, realized $6,700 at its twenty-sixth annual Christmas auction and luncheon yesterday at the Lexington Hotel. Proceeds will go toward aiding physically handicapped veterans to find jobs.
Deliveries of refined copper to fabricators in this country last month dropped to the lowest level in seventeen months, the Copper Institute reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- The International Airport's new $15,000,000 terminal building was being boomed tonight as a potent factor that might help this city overtake New York in the field of commercial aviation.

A request by the civil rights committee of the New York State Bar Association for permission to file an amicus curia brief with the United States Supreme Court on behalf of the plaintiffs in the case of the French motion picture, "La Ronde," has been refused by State Attorney General Nathaniel Goldstein.

This is the week before Christmas, when children flatten their noses against the cold windowpanes of toy stores and draw up lists of presents for Santa Claus to bring. Perhaps 7-year-old Virginia G. has had time to do these things, perhaps she hasn't. Her days are pretty full and her responsibilities quite large for such a little girl.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- no-raiding agreement, approved by two labor conventions, still is no more than a gesture of hope and intentions.
Among member firms of the New York Stock Exchange that will be dissolved on Dec. 31 are Biddle, Whelen Co; French, Harrison Co.; Mallory, Adee Co.; Newman, Kennedy Co., and J. Schonfeld Co.

Richard W. Krakeur has taken a fancy to "Blaze of Glory," a new play by Leo Lieberman, Hollywood writer. The producer is now on the West Coast with the author seeking to cast it and set it up for Broadway presentation this season.
J. D. Roberts, Oklahoma's All-America guard, was college football's No. 1 lineman without any argument, in the opinion of the nation's sportswriters and broadcasters.

When we saw the Page 1 headline in yesterday's New York Times saying that "Wagner will seek rise of $80,000,000 (per year) in state school aid," we recalled a good speech that Mr. Wagner, before he was Mayor-elect, gave before the Manhattan Planning Council at the Town Hall Club on Feb. 12, 1953.

Christmas would not be Christmas in many European homes without marzipan, shaped into gaily colored fruits, flowers and figures. The North German city of Luebeck has been famous for marzipan for nearly five centuries, but this almond delicacy is not limited to Germany. It is also popular in Italy, Switzerland, the Scandinavian countries, as well as France.

Stockholders of the Farrington Manufacturing Company approved yesterday an increase in the authorized capital stock to $5,000,000 from $2,000,000. The company said the increase was proposed by directors in order to place it in a better position to finance its expanding production of display boxes, jewel cases and industrial and defense components.

AFTER a minimum of arm-twisting, a process abetted by the bright North Carolina weather, which was not at all promising for visiting or for local wild-fowlers, we succumbed to a proposed fox hunt over the rolling "Dunes of Dare," near Nags Head, and our choice proved to be a wise one.

Verne Gagne, 222 pounds, Excelsior, Minn., was declared the winner over Antonino Rocca, 223, Argentina, in the feature exhibition of the non-televised wrestling program at Madison Square Garden last night.

The business year ahead, while "not statistically as good as 1953," can be "fundamentally a year of better, sounder performance," according to Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men.
At least twelve employes of the Griffiss Air Force Base, radar research center in Rome, N. Y., have been suspended on "security and loyalty" charges, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said here yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union is producing a small rocketpropelled fighter plane to provide protection for its industry.

Bronx Democrats have stolen a march on other boroughs by completing a proposed subdivision of their borough into Assembly districts for submission to the City Council today. The subdivision has the unanimous approval of the Bronx Democratic Executive Committee.

It is a pleasure to say "welcome home" and "well done" to Vice President Nixon after his globe-girdling fact-finding and goodwill trip. The journey justified the optimism in which it was planned. Mr. Nixon, as our reports from various parts of the world show, did a good job in representing his country.

The National Security Training Commission has submitted its report on military training and reserve plans to the President under the provocative title that appears above. The reason for the choice of such a framework was obviously to emphasize the need to be on guard in a troubled world and to have at hand those manpower resources that could be quickly utilized.

A pocket of low atmospheric pressure in the West Virginia hills saved New York yesterday from a snowstorm that was forecast Sunday night. As it turned out, the conditions predicted for the seaboard became established about 300 miles inland, and New York yesterday was left with a warm and wet off-sea wind and accompanying fog.

Don Budge will tour with the Jack Kramer professional tennis troupe, which swings into action at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 3 and 4. The 38-year-old Californian will join Frank Sedgman of Australia, Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles and Pancho Segura of Los Angeles in the six-month tour of this country, Canada, Havana, Nassau, Bermuda and Puerto Rico.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Indiana University's basketball team upheld its No. 1 national rating by whipping previously undefeated Notre Dame, 66 -- 55, tonight for its fourth straight victory. Guard Bob Leonard led the Hoosiers with 21 points.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Judge Leahy, in exonerating the du Pont company, said:
DETROIT, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The automotive industry maintained an average employment of 930,000 workers and its payroll reached $3,500,000,000 in 1953.
PARIS, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a statement by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, at the meeting of the North Atlantic Council today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The Government's contention that there was "something sinister" in Pierre S. du Pont taking the presidency of the General Motors Corporation on a temporary basis between 1920 and 1923 was assailed today by John M. Harlan, defense counsel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Adrian S. Fisher, former general counsel to the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that in his opinion President Eisenhower's atomic energy pool plan would have been ruled out by the Bricker amendment as originally introduced.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- The Administrative Tribunal, top legal panel of the United Nations, reduced to $3,500 today the compensation of $10,000 it previously had awarded to Mrs. Jane Reed, a special librarian.
New ramps costing $875,000 will be built in the next few months to join the new South Street Elevated Highway and the network of city streets near City Hall.

THE best written and most interesting historical work about the Civil War I have ever read is "A Stillness at Appomattox"* by Bruce Catton. It is true, of course, that I have never belonged to the enormous brotherhood of Civil War enthusiasts who read everything published about America's Iliad and can tell you whether it was raining on any date between the attack on Fort Sumter and Lee's surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia.

A heroic bronze bust of John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation in 1828-66 and founder in 1934 of Chattanooga, Tenn., was unveiled yesterday in the New York Times Auditorium, 229 West Forty-third Street. The statute, the work of Mrs. Belle Kinney of Boiseville, N. Y., and Chattanooga, will be placed at an entrance of the John Ross Bridge over the Tennessee River in Chattanooga.

The steel industry's operating rate declined 0.8 point last week from the level of the week before to 86.7 per cent of capacity, the year's low, and is scheduled to slip back to 85 per cent this week. Production was 1,955,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last week and is expected to be 1,917,000 tons this week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Although Westchester and Fairfield Counties have their school headaches, they do not present as serious an overcrowding problem as do Long Island communities. Some neighborhoods have clusters of new homes around new schools. But the general picture is one of building restrictions, high construction costs and laws against "look-alike" homes on small plots.
Fear of a new East Coast dock strike is causing shipping companies to refuse to book cargo after Christmas Eve, the National Labor Relations Board was told yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 14 (AP) -Wes Fesler, whose bid to restore University of Minnesota football teams to national stature was frustrated by ordinary material, unexpectedly resigned today after three years as head coach.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and Watling, Lerchen Co. will place on the market today an issue of $10,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent convertible debentures of Fruehauf Trailer Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The National Security Training Commission placed on President Eisenhower's desk today a program for training 18-year-olds concurrently with the drafting of older youths for active duty.

PARIS, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Excerpts from the opening statement and answers to questions by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, at a news conference here today at the close of the first session of the North Atlantic Council:
The taxpayer building with nine stores at 619 East 186th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by a client of Allan S. Feldman Co., brokers, to Saul Schneider for cash above mortgages of $51,959.
PANAMA, Dec. 12 -- The best measure of the kind of government Col. Jose A. Remon has given Panama lies in a recent remark of a United States official here.

An industrial site of 57,132 square feet on Northern Boulevard, 100 feet west of Woodside Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Henry Kelly Importing and Distributing Company to the Ro-Ro Realty Corporation of which Harry Rosen is president.
The Port of New York Authority has completed the steel framework of a new hangar for aircraft maintenance at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
The taxpayer building with nine stores at 619 East 186th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by a client of Allan S. Feldman Co., brokers, to Saul Schneider for cash above mortgages of $51,959.
PANAMA, Dec. 12 -- The best measure of the kind of government Col. Jose A. Remon has given Panama lies in a recent remark of a United States official here.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Mal Whitfield of the American Olympic track team was defended as an amateur today by Larry Houston, regional secretary of the Amateur Athletic Union.

TRENTON, Dec. 15 -- A twelve-member Republican committee set up last month to assume party control as soon as Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll left office on Jan. 19 took steps here today to heal a breach in the ranks of leaders.

It seems to be second nature for Danny Lynch, St. Francis College's basketball coach, to smile. He's been known to break into a big grin even after a particularly disheartening Terrier defeat. So, it was no surprise to find him in a happy state when asked about his team's prospects yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Strenuous efforts by the Government brought today the first glimmer of hope that the nation-wide railway and London subway strike scheduled for midnight Sunday would be averted.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, warned today against Government price fixing in agriculture. He asserted that what the farmers of the United States wanted was opportunity to earn good income and improve rural living.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec 15 -- A nonflammable electric cable described as able to carry current even when subjected to fire was detailed here today at the annual wire and cable symposium sponsored by the United States Army Signal Corps and private companies engaged in making equipment for the armed services.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Grain and soybean futures showed weakness in early trading here today but selling pressure abated after overnight sales orders had been executed. A fairly active commission demand absorbed later offerings quite readily.

The Justice Department is attempting to stop a cartel, backed by the Swiss Government, from dictating how American watchmakers conduct their operations. It is acting under anti-trust statutes to safeguard the skills of the workers, who are considered essential to defense.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- It appeared today that the issue likely to dominate French politics for months to come would be the question of how successfully the United States Government could bring pressure on the French Parliament to ratify the European army treaty.
Faith in the future of New York City's downtown areas as shopping centers was expressed yesterday by the head of the nation's largest under-one-roof department store.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- A member of the United States Cabinet promised today that the Administration would try to have the nation's laws amended to permit the sharing of information on atomic and other top-secret weapons with other members of the North Atlantic Treaty organization.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 15 (UP) -- There are two main forces that "stand to benefit by the weakening of the Protestant free churches," the Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Blake, Stated Clerk of the Presbyterian Church, U. S. A., said last night.

A new collection of lighting fixtures, introduced yesterday by Lightolier, 11 East Thirty-sixth St., emphasizes the current interest in installed fixtures. Eight of these designs, which are available through decorators, are hung from the ceiling; the ninth can be pinned to a wall.

What the "little people" of a great industry think of labor unions and management is recorded in "The Worker Speaks His Mind," by Theodore V. Purcell, which Harvard University Press will issue Jan. 4. Father Purcell Professor of Industrial Psychology at Loyola University, spent a year and a half among the workers of Swift Co. in Chicago in the dual role of psychologist and priest.

Events tonight: "The Marriage of Figaro," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Little Orchestra Society, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Joseph Fuchs, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30; New Music String Quartet, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 14 -- Along with the new policy of friendliness toward the United States. Argentina's President, Juan D. Peron, has instituted in recent months a movement toward internal relations known in Argentina as the policy of "convivencia" or living together.
R. A. Richards has been appointed manager of the bonding materials division of the Bakelite Company, a division of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- An inter-union dispute that led two weeks ago to rioting on the waterfront caused a steamship line today to cancel its plan to begin a twice-monthly "casual" low-fare passenger service between the West Coast and Hawaii.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady and from 3 to 9 points net higher.

SOMEWHERE there may be a small corner of marsh where the wildfowler may spend a happier day and find better canvasback shooting -- but until such a spot has been located we will hold out for Townsend McAlpin's "Cove Blind" on the Nanticoke near Tyaskin, Md.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 15 -- Although the West German Government is not asking for an invitation to the proposed four-power conference in Berlin it will be sitting on the conference doorstep from the beginning to the end.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 15--Bonn officials waited in embarrassed silence today for the reaction of Paris and London to the announcement by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, that the United States would have to reappraise its policies toward Europe if the European Defense Community Treaty was not ratified.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 15 -- Yugoslav Government authorities are considering a new demarche in which they would directly approach Italy for an over-all settlement of the Trieste dispute.
With good roads and improved transportation facilities, New Jersey is now attracting more commuters than ever before. As a result, school problems have increased.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower's Executive Order revamping the information security system went into effect today. A survey indicated that security officers were making a common sense approach to the immense problem.

A field investigator for the New York State Commission Against Discrimination testified yesterday that officials of a Bronx beach club, accused of discriminating against Negroes, had told him the club did not admit Negroes "for fear of violent reaction on the part of white club members."
I agree with Lauren D. Lyman that the American aircraft industry has cause to feel proud that a Stratocruiser was entrusted with the transport of the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh to Bermuda.
From two sources came charges yesterday that the public loading racket -- banned by the bistate waterfront law -- was still flourishing in the Port of New York.

An audience of more than 2,500 gathered at Carnegie Hall last night for the eighth annual Christmas Festival of the Collegiate Chorale. The program contained almost everything under the sun, ranging from Gabrieli to satirical fables by Ernst Bacon, with Christmas carols opening and closing the program and Bach's Magnificat forming the major work.

BRISBANE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The United States champion, Tony Trabert, will play Philippe Washer, Belgium's No. 1 player, in the opening singles match of the interzone Davis Cup tennis final tomorrow.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Stanley, owned and bred by Jim D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, launched his Miami racing schedule with a popular victory in the featured $2,400 Partington Purse at Tropical Park today.

Julian B. Beaty, president of the Granby Consolidated Mining, Smelting and Power Company, Ltd., announced yesterday that the Newmont Mining Corporation had joined Granby in a project to develop a new copper prospect in Northern British Columbia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that banks had oversubscribed nearly 3 to 1 an offering of 450 million dollars of cotton price support loans.

A Moreland Act Commission headed by Archie O. Dawson began yesterday the public hearing phase of its inquiry into why the cost of workmen's compensation in this state is among the highest, if not the highest, in the country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The State of Washington argued today that construction of a Federal Hell's Canyon Dam would be "unsound engineering * * * and wasteful."

Demands for hourly wage increases exceeding the 25 cents sought by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., were received yesterday by the Transit Authority from two more of the six unions that represent its 44,000 employes.
The gas appliance industry will wind up 1953 with sales well ahead of the previous year. This was predicted yesterday by Sheldon Coleman, president of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association.

The five-story store and apartment building accommodating sixteen families at 1065 Boston Road in the Bronx has been purchased by Seymour M. Tannenbaum, real estate operator, from Lillian Ostrow. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.
Two women and a baby were injured and part of a Brooklyn store was demolished yesterday as the result of an accident involving five automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- One of the Administration's principal foreign-policy leaders in Congress declined today to give unqualified support to President Eisenhower in his controversy with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy over Communist China.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization took a major step today toward the standardization of its forces' armaments by adopting a new .30-caliber rimless cartridge for small arms.

In the vast, barren recesses of the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse building, the Museum of Modern Art gave a one-day showing yesterday of what, in this reviewer's opinion, is one of its most significant, coherent and well-thought-through activities: A visual report on the International Circulating Exhibitions Program, made possible through a grant from the Rockefeller Brothers Fund.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, left this afternoon by plane for London, where he will address the United Nations Association Thursday night.

Warren Spahn, the stylish southpaw of the Braves, achieved the lowest earned-run average in the National League last season, according to official figures released at the league offices yesterday. The portsider, who tied with Philadelphia's Robin Roberts for most victories, 23, concluded the 1953 campaign with a 2.10 mark, lowest in the senior circuit since Howie Pollet, then with the Cardinals, won the honors with identical figures in 1946.

Seymour Lipkin, who played at Town Hall last night, is on the very brink of being a major pianist fit to bestride the musical world with the few great ones. If there is any factor that keeps him from moving over, firmly and finally, into this select company, it is perhaps because he is not thoroughly convinced deep in his own heart that the piano is his vocation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Paul H. Nitze, former State Department official and investment banker, has been elected president of the Foreign Service Educational Foundation, Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts, retiring president, announced today.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said yesterday that his aim to was expose "potential espionage" to alert security officers, rather than to "take over the job of the Justice Department and prove espionage cases beyond a reasonable doubt."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A program designed to maintain home building at a pace of more than 1,000,000 units annually, and pave the way for the gradual withdrawal of the Government from home financing, was delivered to President Eisenhower today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- United States cotton farmers favored strict Federal controls of their 1954 production by a margin of almost 20 to 1 today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Eisenhower Administration, well aware of the mood of Congress, is determined that its European Allies must fish or cut bait soon on ratification and creation of the European Defense Community.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- The outcome of the talks between Washington and Karachi on prospective United States military aid to Pakistan is anxiously awaited here. Meanwhile, Indian opinion toward the United States and the rest of the Western bloc trembles on a knife edge.

The Kings County Medical Society amended its constitution last night to allow formal investigations of unethical conduct by its members even before formal charges are brought before its board of censors.

Plugging away at their art, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, an inseparable team, have come up with their tenth joint effort in "The Prescott Proposals," which opens at 8 o'clock tonight at the Broadhurst.

Ferenc Nagy, former Premier of Hungary, yesterday commended United States pronouncements against Communist enslavement of Eastern European nations. He said they contrasted with what he called the indifference of leading Western European powers to the plight of the Soviet satellites.

CHINESE in town, especially those who run eating establishments, are quietly amused at customers who seek out oriental restaurants to order such dishes as chow mein and chop suey, which the Chinese rarely, or never, go for.
The primary importance of President Eisenhower's address to the General Assembly of the United Nations has been largely overlooked in the initial commentaries made upon it.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- The State Motor Vehicle Bureau is on its way toward setting a record for suspending and revoking driving licenses of traffic violators.
Only 254 pints of blood were obtained Monday by the regional Red Cross blood program. In announcing this yesterday officials called for more donors, stressing that the need remained great.

The New York Customs District held its share of general cargo moving in the nation's foreign trade in the first six months of this year, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, reported here yesterday.
The struggle to get a bigger bang for a buck -- or more combat effectiveness for less money -- passes a major milestone this week.
Robert G. Thompson, one of the eleven convicted Communist leaders, was found guilty yesterday of contempt of court.

Christmas bonus checks totaling $728,000 will be distributed today to 4,994 employes of the Horn Hardart Company, E. K. Daly, president, announced yesterday. The bonus is based on length of service with the company, ranging from 2 per cent of the annual salary for those who have completed one year's service to 8 per cent for those who have been with the company for twenty or more years.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- A rebel group of thirty-six Conservative Members of Parliament added to the troubles of their own Government today with a motion opposing withdrawal of British troops from the Suez Canal base.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Bank of England has bolted the door to its silver bullion vaults to enable it to build up the stocks needed to repay the United States the 88,000,000 ounces of silver borrowed during World War II.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean asked tonight for continued peace all over the world and pleaded for aid and assistance to the Korean people.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower has been asked to consider a program to save the United States merchant marine from "virtual exinction."

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 15 -- Having removed the immediate threat of Communist subversion, Premier Fazlollah Zahedi's Government turned today to deal with its non-Communist opposition. It took three important steps to neutralize these elements:
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 15 -- Ronnie Nathanic and Richie Long led Seton Hall University to a 69-46 victory over Providence College before 1,500 last night. The Pirates have won two of three starts.

A program of old and new music was played last evening at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Harpsichord Quartet, Sylvia Marlowe, harpsichord; Claude Monteux, flutist; Harry Shulman, oboist, and Bernard Greenhouse, 'cellist.

Two patrolmen of the Port of New York Authority fought it out with two hold-up men in a bar at 269 West Fortieth Street at 4 A. M. yesterday. One of the patrolmen was wounded and one hold-up suspect was captured.

Kenneth B. Coates has been elected a director of the Michigan Bumper Corporation. Mr. Coates formerly was vice president and treasurer of the Great Lakes Steel Corporation, from which he retired recently after twenty-five years.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 15: -- John V. Kenny, who in 1949 defeated the Democratic machine of former Mayor Frank Hague, stepped down as this city's Mayor today. Mr. Kenny has been in ill health for the last year. He plans to remain as head of the bi-partisan "Freedom Organization" and as nominal head of the Democratic party in Hudson County.

Alterations are planned for a two-story taxpayer building at the railroad station in Crestwood, N. Y., which has been purchased by Irving Enkells, real estate operator, through Albert F. Deichsel as broker. The new owner plans to convert the second floor from its present residential use to business occupancy.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15 -- Yale University opened its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League season tonight by defeating previously unbeaten Brown, 77-69.
The Avenue of the Americas got a new look at itself yesterday evening when 100 new street lights, twice as bright as the old ones, were turned on in the midtown area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower will spend Christmas week with his family in his cottage at the Augusta National Golf Club. There he will work on his "big three" messages -- on the State of the Union, the budget and the national economy.
The City Council adopted yesterday the $510,966,795 capital budget for 1954, a record for the city. The amount was unchanged from that approved by the Board of Estimate on Dec. 3.

The Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth, the world's largest ship, arrived at her Hudson River pier thirty hours behind schedule yesterday after a crossing delayed by both strike and storm. Her skipper will try to sail out to Europe on schedule today, at 2 P. M., which would break the turn-around record held by Cunard.
A professional fund raiser, who impersonated a priest or police representative when it suited his purpose, revealed yesterday some of the tricks worked in the name of charity.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Secretary of States John Foster Dulles' recital in Paris of the "hard, blunt facts" of United States politics and their relation to Europe has won qualified approval in British Government circles.
The state investigation into harness racing rackets turned up yesterday a picture of corruption in the conduct of union welfare funds.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Good dividend statements issued last night by Courtauld and the Hawker Siddeley companies helped to impart a brighter look to industrial shares on the stock markets today. Although buying remained restricted by the prospect of the railroad strike, prices generally recovered yesterday's losses.
Mrs. Gisela K. Gresser scored a sixth consecutive victory to retain the lead in the national women's championship tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.

Stockholders of the American Bosch Corporation voted yesterday to increase from 65,000 to 150,000 the number of common shares available for option under the restricted stock option incentive plan for key employes. The plan is subject to the restriction that 72,000 of these shares not be issued until the company pays four consecutive quarterly dividends.
BERLIN, Dec. 15 -- Bonn and Washington were accused by East Germany today of conspiring to make West German rearmament an actuality before the opening of the proposed four-power conference in Berlin.

Twenty-nine local housing authorities having subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration borrowed $121,225,000 yesterday on bonds maturing overt thirty years to finance the construction of low-rent projects in fifteen states, the District of Columbia, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.

Cotton growers throughout the twenty-state Cotton Belt voted yesterday on the question whether to accept "marketing quotas" for the coming year. Because of the top-heavy supply situation they have automatically become subject to "acreage allotment." But acreage allotment is a voluntary arrangement.

While the over-all trend of the market was recovery when the final gong sounded, stocks drifted lower during most of yesterday. At one point the list, as measured by The New York Times composite average of fifty issues, was at its lowest level since late November.

The first German bonds submitted for validation have been approved, it was announced yesterday. After validation the bonds are eligible for exchange for an equal amount of new bonds issued by the Federal Republic of Germany.

Volume improved yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchanges. Coffee and the domestic sugar contract registered the third highest number of sales of the year with the No. 6 sugar contract showing the best activity since April 10. Zinc had the largest volume since Nov. 20.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The late Harry Dexter White, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was accused today -- as "a Communist agent" -- of having helped Russia print at least $255,000,000 of American currency for her own use.

INDIAN VILLAGE, Korea, Dec. 15 -- Lieut. Gen. K. S. Thimayya, ranking Indian officer here, disclosed today that all prisoners of war in the demilitarized zone would be released Jan. 22 unless both sides agreed they should not be.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The nations of the North Atlantic Alliance will have spent $65,500,000,000 on defense during 1953 and in 1954 the bill will be slightly higher.

Further evidence of what a group of community-minded parents can accomplish in providing pre-school programs for their children will be offered this week. Friday afternoon at a special "open house", community leaders will view the newly opened Lexington Houses Nursery School, a center providing a low-cost program not only for children from within the development but from the neighboring area in lower East Harlem.
WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 15 -- The construction of hotels, apartments, garden apartments, motels, tourist cabins, tenements and more than two-row houses sharing a common roof has been banned here.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 16 -- The United States special envoy, Arthur H. Dean, predicted yesterday that the Communists eventually would seek a resumption of negotiations for an international political conference on Korea, withdrawing the charges of United States "perfidy" that caused the breakoff of the preliminary talks at Panmunjom last week.

Sir Hartley Shawcross. President of the Board of Trade in the Attlee Labor Government, will be one of about forty-five noted lawyers, statesmen, clergymen and others who will participate in a symposium on Jan. 15 and 16 on the problem of guarding national security while preserving the right of public information.

Colonial problems tend to fit a pattern nowadays. Each case seems different on the surface, but when one looks underneath, the driving force is always nationalism, with or without Communist backing. Whether it is the King of Cambodia, the Sultan of Morocco, a fellow-traveling leader in British Guiana or -- now -- the Kabaka of Buganda, the problem is roughly the same.

Sales of the Newport Steel Corporation for the fiscal year ended last October increased $13,488,000 to $63,990,000 from $50,502,854 for the preceding fiscal year, Frank S. Gibson Jr., president, reported yesterday in a preliminary statement.
Two children sent a $4 contribution to the forty-second annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with the remark that it "isn't much."

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15 -- The Tommy Memorial Fund for research in leukemia was established here today when New Britain firemen gave an $8,000 check to Dr. Vernon W. Lippard, dean of the Yale University School of Medicine. The fund was established in memory of Thomas Mozdzierz, a 4-year-old New Britain child who died of leukemia last January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Mayors of the cities that would be the principal targets of an atomic attac called upon the Eisenhower Administration today for a clear outline of responsibilities it expected them to assume in civil defense.

ON Feb. 13, 1822, The Missouri Gazette and Public Advertiser of St. Louis carried an advertisement addressed "To Enterprising Young Men" offering employment to "ONE HUNDRED MEN to ascend the river Missouri to its source, there to be employed for one, two, or three years." The advertisement was signed by William H. Ashley, Brigadier General of the Missouri Militia and Lieutenant Governor of the state.
Round steak is a cut of beef now abundant that is exceptionally high in lean and low in fat. Because it is less tender than certain other steaks, it usually demands long, "tenderizing" cooking.
Methods for starching in the washing machine as well as information on bleaching were given at the recent National Home Laundry Conference here.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 15 -- Bob Schafer, junior forward, scored 23 points and paced Villanova's basketball team to a 68-56 victory over Princeton tonight before a crowd of 1,200 in Dillon Gym. Schafer has averaged 27.5 points in six games.

The Public Service Commission has ordered the New York Central System to restore passenger service at its Wakefield station in the Bronx not later than Jan. 4. The order also directs the road to construct passenger station facilities at Wakefield, which has been without service since last Aug. 15, when fire destroyed a portion of the station.
American importers were assured yesterday of the fullest cooperation and dispatch in the processing of their merchandise for duty purposes.
MILLVILLE, Ind., Dec. 15 (AP) -- With jet planes screaming overhead, this little town of 113 on Thursday will honor its famous son, Wilbur Wright.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Army Corps of Engineers has awarded a contract to a British company for the last two generators for the McNary multi-purpose dam on the Columbia River in Oregon and Washington.

Today the French Parliament will meet at Versailles to elect a new President of the Republic. By the Constitution the President of France is chosen by the legislators rather than by the people, as in the United States, thus increasing the powers of the National Assembly by making the Chief of State the creation of that body.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. is planning to ask the state for the right to substitute a business income tax for the city's present gross business and financial business taxes. At the same time he will urge repeal of the unused state law that gives the city the right to impose a payroll tax payable half by employers and half by employes.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- A motion by the State University of New York was filed in United States District Court here today, to dismiss the suit brought against it by Earl Webb of St. Joseph, Mo., president of Sigma Tau Gamma fraternity. The suit, filed Nov. 25, seeks to prevent the State University from prohibiting national fraternities in its colleges. The motion will be argued Jan. 4 in Albany.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- A twenty-four-hour nationwide industrial strike today, supported by Communist and anti-Communist unions, closed down the greater part of industrial establishments in northern Italy. The walkout was less successful in central Italy and hardly noticed in southern Italy.
The city's Welfare Department, it was learned yesterday, has been paying up to $20 a room a week in some cases to house needy clients.
Timely advice for gift-searching Santas is to steer the straightest course to the many attractive at-home fashions now available.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- After a wild scene in the House of Commons, the vote on commercial television that was scheduled to take place tonight was postponed at least until tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The White House announced today the resignation of Earl D. Johnson as Under Secretary of the Army and the promotion of Assistant Secretary John Slezak of Chicago to succeed him. The change will be made Jan. 25.

It is Oct. 24, 1953. Michigan State's 1952 national football champions were rolling along on a twenty-eight-game winning streak, the country's longest. Purdue had been beaten four times. They met on Purdue's home field. The final score: Purdue 6, Michigan State 0.
Another step in its program to persuade qualified young people to enter the graphic arts industry has been taken by the Education Council of the Graphic Arts Industry, Inc., Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The Government will add millions of pounds of butter, cheese and dried milk to its already heavy stocks next year unless support prices are reduced sharply, experts warned today.

The subway people were recently taking advertising space in their own cars to educate riders about the matter of basic subway courtesy. The public sneezer, the pole leaner, the two-seat-spreader-out-over, and similar wretches were properly displayed and disparaged.

In a resale of a property he bought several months ago, Louis J. Glickman has disposed of the nine-story and penthouse apartment building for thirty-eight families at 40 West Fifty-fifth Street to a syndicate of investors represented by Saul C. Kaufman and Alvin A. Victor, attorneys.

Thirty-three seconds of the overtime period remained when Harry Gallatin caged the free throw that gave the New York Knickerbockers an 80-79 victory over the Minneapolis Lakers last night at Madison Square Garden.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 16 -- President Syngman Rhee, in a policy shift that removed one of the major threats of renewed fighting in Korea, said today he would give a Korean peace conference ninety days to unify the country regardless of the starting date of the parley.
CAIRO, Dec. 15 -- Abdel Khalik Hassouna, Secretary General of the Arab League, has submitted his resignation, a spokesman at the Foreign Ministry said today.

CONSIDERING the fact that he was the best publicized operative in the basketball business, Bevo Francis of Rio Grande College was virtually an invisible man when he made his long-awaited local debut in Madison Square Garden a fortnight ago. Bevo had the misfortune to arrive during the blackout of the newspaper strike. Few knew that he was coming or that he had gone.

The current exposure of fake charities by a State Legislative committee should prove an eye-opener for all of us. It is estimated that some $120 millions contributed by generous Americans during the current year has gone to individuals or organizations whose charitable impulses are directed principally toward themselves.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Former President Hoover said today that there were "billions to be saved to the taxpayers by better organization" of the Executive Branch of the Federal Government.
DETROIT, Dec. 15 -- Optimism for the sale of Ford cars and trucks was expressed today by officials of the company at a preview of its 1954 models. Details of the new cars will be announced on Jan. 4.

WHY must so much of modern popular singing be so utterly depressing? Switch on a radio or TV set these days and the air is filled with the baleful moanings and weird physical gyrations of juvenile baritones and tearful soubrettes.

Edward Grant Barrow, former president of the New York Yankees, who was largely responsible for the victory tradition of the present world baseball champions, died at 8:35 o'clock last night at United Hospital in Port Chester, N. Y., which he had entered last July 7. He was 85 years old.

MANILA, Dec. 15 -- Elpidio Quirino took leave of his people as President tonight in a final intimate radio talk, his last before relinquishing his post to Ramon Magsaysay on Inauguration Day, Dec. 31.

Each baby in the neighborhood means $100 of sales a year to the drugstore of his or her parents' choice. At an indicated 3,890,000 new babies in 1953 -- 70,000 more than last year -- the drugstore business should be good. This is the burden of a report by Irving Quackenboss, director of the baby products division of Johnson Johnson at New Brunswick.

Consumption of new rubber in this country will set a new high of 1,341,000 long tons this year, and 1954 consumption will be only slightly less, the Rubber Manufacturers Association predicted yesterday.
The city began its official observance of the Christmas season yesterday with the lighting of decorated trees in each of the five boroughs.

The Texas International Sulphur Company of Houston has signed an agreement with Central Minera, S. A., of Mexico City for wide-scale development of sulphur properties on the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, Mexico.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 13 -- There are several fundamental reasons for recent United States difficulties with the South Korean Government.
Jim Lee Howell, a resident of Lonoke, Ark., who has been a member of the New York Football Giants coaching staff, was named head coach of the Polo Grounds eleven yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Italy's ratification of the European Defense Community treaty depends on an equitable solution of the Trieste question. Italian Premier Giuseppe Pella was reported to have conveyed this information to British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today.

The city of Milwaukee yesterday sold $6,500,000 of library museum building and street improvement bonds due from 1954 to 1973 to a banking syndicate headed by Guaranty Trust Company at a net interest cost of 1.8518 per cent. The bonds were reoffered as 1 1/2 s and 1 7/8 s at prices to yield from 1.1 per cent to 2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The story was told today of a man quitting a lifetime job as a judge on the Federal Court of Claims because he could not keep a family of seven on his salary.

Christmas is a season of cheerful lights. The Avenue of the Americas celebrated it last night with a ceremony at Rockefeller Center officially turning on the avenue's fine new lights. About a hundred of these graceful, modern fixtures are already in place, from Thirty-second to Fifty-third Street.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- Michael Curtiz and Pat Duggan will serve as director and producer, respectively, in bringing "Angel's Cooking" to the screen for Paramount.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Depot Plaza property valued at $150,000 was given to White Plains today by the New York Central System as the first step in a mutual assistance pact to improve commuter facilities.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Wednesday, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- Sir Godfrey Huggins' "racial partnership" appeared to have won a landslide victory in yesterday's elections for the new Central African Federation's thirty-five-member Federal Parliament.
Jim Tatum, the University of Maryland football coach whose team recently completed a ten-game schedule undefeated and untied, has been named "coach of the year."
A company has been formed to expand Israeli industry through conversion of Israel Government bonds into stock of the new enterprise.
HONG KONG, Dec. 15 -- This little British colony is registering a slow comeback in its trade with the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Government agencies are firmly enforcing rules against their employes receiving Christmas gifts that might influence their official activities, a survey showed today.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Willie Pep, former featherweight champion from Hartford, Conn., had things his own way tonight in gaining the decision over Tony Longo of Baltimore in the ten-round feature attraction at the Auditorium.

CAIRO, Dec. 15 -- Egypt's vigorous application of a two-month-old decree law dispossessing the descendants of Mohammed Ali, founder of this country's lately ousted ruling dynasty, has stirred up a bitter diplomatic quarrel with Turkey.
A fact-finding board studying the wages and hours issues remaining from the recent newspaper strike completed its hearings yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- The voters approved all nine proposed amendments to the state constitution but the one that attracted the largest number of "yes" or "no" votes -- 1,699,732 -- was ignored by 2,987,012 voters who cast blank or void ballots last Election Day. The number of blanks ran as high on one amendment as 3,414,916 out of 4,686,744 eligible voters.

MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Business in the Canadian cotton textile industry in 1953 showed practically no improvement from that in 1952, when domestic mills obtained less than 50 per cent of the home market. J. I. Roy, president of the Cotton Institute of Canada, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Ross Rizley, Solicitor for the Post Office Department and former Republican Representative from Oklahoma, will be named an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture. He will act in liaison capacity for Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture with Congress.

Two new films will open at first run theatres today. "Beneath the 12-Mile Reef," a Twentieth Century-Fox adventure in CinemaScope, will have its premiere tonight at the Roxy. The Technicolor production stars Terry Moore, Robert Wagner and Gilbert Roland, with J. Carrol Naish, Richard Boone and Angela Clarke heading the supporting cast. A. I. Bezzerides wrote the scenario and Robert D. Webb directed.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Approximately 2,000 students who tried to march on the National Assembly today were beaten back by police and some were injured although none seriously. One policeman was hurt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Congressional leaders took a pessimistic view today of the National Security Training Commission's proposal that a six-month training program for 18-year-olds be Started concurrent with the draft.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Because the state was unable to introduce enough of the script for the jury to make a proper judgment, Superior Court Judge Fred B. Perkins dismissed today a criminal complaint that had charged Edward Gould with producing an obscene play, "Tobacco Road," here last Jan. 5.

KITTY HAWK, N. C., Dec. 15 -- Thirteen Marine Corp jet planes flying a special memorial formation with two places vacant -- for Orville and Wilbur Wright -- flashed over the Wright Monument here this morning.

The New York Rangers, hampered by illnesses and injuries to key players, will meet the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. So far this season New York and Boston have split four games, each club winning twice on home ice.

A bill seting up the projected new office of City Administrator was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council. Dr. Luther H. Gulick, president of the Institute of Public Administration, already has been designated by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner. Jr. for the post.

GARFIELD, N. J., Dec. 15 -- The five-day week-end was over tonight for 3,800 pupils of Garfield's nine schools as their 170 teachers agreed to return to work tomorrow morning, calling off their dignified walk-out over wage demands.

" My Inspiration," a hearty white cake baked with two thin layers of melted chocolate and finely chopped nuts inside, won the $25,000 Fifth Grand National Bake-Off prize yesterday for Mrs. Bernard Kanago of Webster, S. D.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- A Government inference that defense witnesses in the du Pont anti-trust trial were honest only part time was assailed today by Ferris E. Hurd, attorney for General Motors Corporation.
The Ohio Edison Company, one of the country's largest independent operating utilities, reported yesterday a net income of $19,026,965 in the twelve months to Nov. 30.
Frank Erickson, bookmaker, surrendered late yesterday afternoon to United States Marshal William E. Smith in Brooklyn to start a six-month penitentiary sentence for income tax evasion.

One of the country's foremost poets, Archibald MacLeish, has been elected president of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, succeeding Paul Manship, sculptor. The election, announced yesterday, followed the resignation of Mr. Manship, who had served as president for five years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Halsey, Stuart Co., Chicago investment banking house, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reject a request of the Chicago Great Western Railroad for authority to market $6,000,000 of its collateral trust bonds without offering them for competitive bidding, as required by I. C. C. rules.
The Appellate Division made a ruling yesterday that had the effect of prohibiting picketing for what the court interpreted to be an illegal objective.

The approval of a divided City Planning Commission on Dec. 9 of the proposed Washington Square Southeast development plan reopens a controversy which has been reflected in the columns of The Times for some months. The proposal has aroused the opposition of area residents and commercial interests, housing experts, leading civic organizations, and two members of the City Planning Commission itself.
A nation-wide appeal for 35,000 Koreans made homeless by fire near Pusan Nov. 27 was started yesterday by Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retired commander of the Eighth Army.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg denied yesterday an application by the International Workers Order, Inc., for an order directing the Superintendent of Insurance to withdraw funds from its treasury to retain counsel to represent it in a hearing before the Subversive Activities Control Board in Washington.

Pan American World Airways will begin service between Chicago, Detroit and London on April 30. Later in the year it will expand the flights to other European capitals and several cities in Scotland and Germany.

The explanation by Professor Lionel Trilling of Columbia College, in his letter published Nov. 26, of the vote of the faculty supporting those members of the teaching profession who refuse to answer questions about Communist involvement on the ground that to do so would require that they testify against themselves is of great interest.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Democratic National Committee asserted today that Democratic Administrations had a better record in effectively fighting communism at home than had the Republicans.
The dispute between City College and New York University over the site of their basketball game next March 4 ended yesterday when the schools agreed to play the contest on a neutral court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- John Lautner, a former Communist, testified today he had been told by a woman party leader that Earl Browder, as head of the Communist party, "took orders" from President Franklin D. Roosevelt and his Cabinet during World War II.
Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan appointed 172 new policeman to the department yesterday, bringing the strength of the force up to 19,970. The budgetary quota is 20,878.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- States' rights advocates are certain to sharpen their campaign for Taft-Hartley amendments next year.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The Air Force now has the planes and atom bombs to rain down in "a single instant" more firepower than has been expended in all wars since the discovery of gunpowder.

The pre-Christmas shopping frenzy and the mechanical failure of a Manhattan-bound I. R. T. train in a Brooklyn subway station conspired to bottle up traffic at the peak of the rush hour late yesterday. Service was slowed for a period of an hour and forty-five minutes.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Wheat and corn futures showed considerable strength at times today, but considerable buying caution again developed on the hard spots.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Eisenhower said today that he did not believe the Administration could give an analysis of the dismissal of 1,456 Federal employes for security reasons. He indicated, however, that he would discuss the question with his advisers.

Local basketball fans will be treated to a star program in Madison Square Garden tonight, with Rice meeting St. John's in the second game of the college doubleheader and Western Kentucky and St. Francis matching shots in the opening game at 7:45 P. M.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Two Negroes, believed the first ever named to the faculty of a white medical school in the South, joined the University of Louisville staff today.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. told the voluntary, nonmunicipal hospitals of the city yesterday that he hoped to be able to ease their burdens in caring for indigent patients for whom the city is responsible.

The wrappings were removed yesterday from a new device that for four years has been a closely guarded military secret. The secret device is a new type of storage battery with a life expectancy of ten to twenty years. It is half the size and will cost perhaps half as much as conventional batteries.

President Eisenhower and Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson commended last night the participants in a two-day forum on the crisis in the Communist agrarian program. Both directed messages to Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, president of the International Peasants Union, the sponsoring organization, at the closing dinner held at the Carnegie Endowment International Center.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The United States, Britain and France today introduced a compromise resolution in the United Nations Security Council regarding Syria's protest against Israel's preparations to divert water from the Jordan River for a power project.
The world champion New York Yankees yesterday took what was judged to be a long step toward insuring a sixth straight American League pennant.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Two civilians employed at the United States Military Academy at West Point have been dismissed within the last six weeks for "loyalty and security" reasons, one of the two men confirmed tonight. The dismissals were ordered by the Army's Security Screening Board.
After opening active and steady, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange eased slightly yesterday, closing barely steady and unchanged to 8 points higher than on Tuesday.

Two women were seriously injured and twenty-eight other persons suffered minor cuts and bruises yesterday morning when a Webster Avenue bus of the Surface Transportation Company hit an elevated pillar in the Bronx.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella declared here today that Italy would be ready to collaborate with Yugoslavia as soon as a "just solution" had been found for the Trieste question.

Knapp Mills, Inc., announced yesterday that two representatives of French machinery and construction concerns had arrived here for a first-hand study of American methods of making lead clad metals for the shielding and handling of radioactive materials.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Air Force confirmed today reports that Maj. Charles E. Yeager had flown an experimental rocket plane more than 1,600 miles an hour, more than twice the speed of sound.
LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet State prosecutor's statement on the case against Lavrenti P. Beria, former secret police chief, as broadcast tonight by the Moscow radio:
The National Labor Relations Board ordered yesterday that a representation election be held on or before next Wednesday among 23,000 dock workers in the Port of New York.

LITTLE FALLS, Minn., Dec. 16 -- By use of new methods, the Hennepin Paper Company here has experimentally produced 1,000 tons of newsprint paper containing 40 per cent of cheap poplar wood pulp, company officials announced today.

Despite the grandeur of its towering office buildings and its showplaces of art and entertainment, New York presents a rather drab sight to many visitors. The brilliance of the city is cloaked in a perpetual haze of smoke, and those who view it first from afar are admiring a beautiful emerald under isinglass.
TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner declared here tonight that former Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, Democratic party leader in Hudson County, had made no requests of him.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The North Atlantic Council concluded its twelfth session today and issued a communique stressing that a European Defense Community including German military units remained an "essential objective" of the alliance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Eisenhower said today the United States should be free to exchange its atomic information and weapons in any way that best served the interests of this country.
For the third successive Christmas season Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society presented a performance of Berlioz' "L'Enfance du Christ," which took place last evening at Carnegie Hall.

There is no disputing the need to highlight the various points of view currently being expressed concerning the possibility of a military alliance between the United States and Pakistan. There can be no question that public attention should be directed toward so important a matter.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16 -- Hussein Makki, reputed leader of the National Resistance Movement, a coalition of Communists and nationalists opposed to the Zahedi regime, has disappeared and is believed to be in hiding.

Jacques Barzun, Professor of History at Columbia University and author of "Teacher in America" and "Romanticism and the Modern Ego," has completed a new work that he calls "God's Country and Mine: A Declaration of Love Spiced With a Few Harsh Words."

In its first change of ownership in more than fifty years, the three-story building at 617 to 627 West 181st Street occupied by Wertheimer's department store has been sold by the Estate of Charles Marshall to Herbert J. Schmitz of Chicago for investment.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Lavrenti P. Beria, overlord of Russia's security services, has confessed to "state crimes" and will be tried for treason with six other high officials of the secret police, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Conservative Government defeated a Labor Party censure motion on its handling of affairs in the African colonies tonight after a turbulent day of debate in the House of Commons.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 17 -- The Peiping radio said today that Communist China had protested to the nations on the neutral commission in Korea against the refusal of that commission to sanction the use of force against Chinese and North Korean prisoners who reject repatriation.

In a gesture that Councilman Quinn says is unprecedented in New York City the City Council of New York has adopted a resolution stating that delegates of the Communist regime in China, if they are admitted to the United Nations, "will never be welcome to reside in or to walk the streets of New York City in the company of decent men and women.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Apprentice Johnny Rotz wore a big grin today when he brought the Duntreath Farm's Hi Billee across the finish line first in the $5,000 Alligator Handicap to complete a double at Tropical Park.
A slender young housewife left her husband entertaining friends and minding their 4-month-old daughter early yesterday morning to chase an automobile thief who had driven off in the family car.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, presented to a special commission studying judicial and Congressional salaries today a series of "shameful illustrations of our treatment of our judges."

Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, is one of the real assets possessed by the farmers, the Government and the country. He is a much greater asset, we believe, than many of the so-called "spokesmen" of the farmer in Congress. Why do we say this? Partly because Mr. Kline knows what farming is all about and has been eminently successful himself as a practitioner in that field.

A shipment to Israel of 1,169,000 pounds of food, including 188,000 pounds of non-kosher meat for distribution to Christian and Arab institutions, was announced yesterday by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

One fireman was killed and five persons were injured last night when a car crashed into a jack-knifed trailer truck and swerved into a group of firemen washing off spilled gasoline at a Staten Island street intersection.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- The annual Christmas overseas airlift entertainment operation will get under way tomorrow morning when forty-two volunteer performers will leave Burbank Airport in Government planes to entertain troops at seventy military installations in Korea, Europe and Alaska.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 15 -- The great unanswered question in South America today is the extent of President Juan D. Peron's ambition to dominate the continent. Is peronismo an export product and how much is it being exported?

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 17 (Thursday) (AP) -- Young Jacques Brichant, playing perhaps the best tennis of his career, enabled Belgium to split the first two singles matches in the interzone Davis Cup final with the United States by crushing Vic Seixas, 6 -- 3, 11 -- 9, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 1, today.

Five New Jersey apartment properties in North Bergen and West New York have been sold in a "package" deal by the New Jersey Realty Company of Newark to the Columbia Development Corporation, represented by Ralph R. Feigelson, attorney.

The American Watch Association, Inc., an organization that represents importers, assemblers and manufacturers of watches here, called yesterday for a study to get the facts on this country's reliance in time of war on the jeweled watch industry.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- The Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco) has protested to the Foreign Ministry and to the United States Embassy against alleged discrimination to its detriment shown by Italian emigration authorities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A woman from New York and a Roman Catholic priest from Cleveland, along with a score of other persons, debated today what should be included in stockholders' proxies. The blonde, Mrs. Wilma Soss, and the priest, the Rev. David C. Baynes, S. J., were among those who urged the Securities and Exchange Commission to scuttle its proposed revision of its proxy rules.
TORONTO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The two biggest canals on the Great Lakes have finished one of the longest and busiest seasons in Great Lakes shipping history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today closed out its large scale beef price support operations after spending $93,700,000 for about 250,000,000 pounds of meat.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Dwight Eisenhower, who is 5 years old, wants a Tinker Toy set for Christmas. His sisters would like to have dolls.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- If the United States Government is required by present laws governing foreign aid to suspend deliveries of military supplies to some of its allies during 1954, it nevertheless plans to continue to procure them and hold them until they can be delivered.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 16 -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo faced a major political crisis today as speakers representing a large majority in Congress rejected his statement that "seditious" elements were incorporated in that body. The majority charged that the President had "an exaggerated concept of his constitutional prerogative."

The North Atlantic is living up to its reputation as the roughest of oceans. A storm of hurricane proportions last week tore away the rudder of the liner Stavangerfjord, and continuing gales and mountainous seas yesterday were battering and delaying at least eight New York-bound passenger liners carrying 5,000 persons.

Despite lack of practice because of mild weather, St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., turned back the Taft School hockey team of Watertown, Conn., 2 to 1, in a charity game at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Edward Chodorov's new comedy, "Oh, Men! Oh, Women!", opens at the Henry. Miller Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock. Franchot Tone is starred in it in the role of a psychoanalyst who unwittingly uncovers information that vitally affects his own life.
Two thousand New York youngsters will keep their faith in Santa Claus this year because of a club of young men and women on the Upper West Side who call themselves his "agents."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A Presidential advisory board warned today that the lumping of our Point Four program with military or economic assistance projects abroad would amount to "a major mistake."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The United Automobile Worker's Union, C. I. O., sent its members back to work producing warplanes today at three North American Aviation, Inc., plants after locals ratified an agreement ending a fifty-three-day strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Navy, said today it was his personal belief United States bases on Okinawa and the Bonin Islands "should remain indefinitely in our control."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 -- Two witnesses from local television circles today appeared before a subcommittee of the House Un-American Activities Committee at a closed hearing and invoked the Fifth Amendment in refusing to answer questions regarding former association with the Communist party.

PARIS, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- Senior diplomats of the United States, Britain and France met here tonight to draft the strategy the West will adopt at the proposed Big Four foreign ministers' meeting with the Soviet Union in Berlin next month.
A gift of $1,000 in memory of John H. Finley, editor of The New York Times, was among the $11,849.49 added yesterday to the forty-second annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 16 -- A general strike of all workers employed in capitalist industrial enterprises appeared imminent here tonight.
Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., had a net profit of $1,575,455 in the six months ended last Aug. 31, according to the consolidated report issued yesterday by Harry M. Warner, president.

Car owners in this city are showing little inclination to shop early for their 1954 registration tabs. The State Bureau of Motor Vehicles reminded them yesterday that mail orders would be welcomed from those who wished to avoid the last-minute rush that developed two years ago.

Anent the tax law suit involving the question whether Bedloe's Island belongs to the State of New York or to New Jersey, the following quotation from "Valentine's City of New York" (1920) is of interest:

Robert G. Thompson, the Communist leader who jumped bail and hid in the California mountains to evade a three-year prison term, received an additional sentence of four years yesterday for contempt of court.

Hearings in Washington this week on the present inadequate pay of federal judges and members of Congress will, we hope, pave the way for a substantial increase in their salaries early in the next session.
HARTFORD, Dec. 16 -- Following is the text of a speech by Governor Dewey at a $100-a-plate Connecticut Republican dinner here tonight:
BONN, Germany, Dec. 16 -- Sir Winston Churchill was quoted in a German newspaper today as having said there was now no room in the world for "violent political maneuvers," and "one must negotiate."
Drivers of private garbage trucks and employer representatives were summoned yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri to meet today in an effort to settle the nine-day-old garbage strike.

A special meeting of stockholders of the American Woolen Company is scheduled for Jan. 29, to act on proposals "to improve operations of the company, better its earning capacity and simplify its capital structure," it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- The passenger ship Aleutian was scheduled to leave for Seattle early tomorrow following unsuccessful efforts by its charterer, the Hawaiian-Pacific Line, to put it in a low-cost, "casual" cruise service to Hawaii.

VIENNA, Dec. 16 -- Three leading members of the Hungarian Jewish community who were arrested months ago have been tried secretly this month in Budapest, according to reports that have reached the Israeli Government. Confirmation of these reports is so far lacking in Vienna.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Henri Laurens, French sculptor, received today the $1,000 grand prize for the best work presented at the International Exhibition of Arts and Architecture, in which thirty-eight countries were represented.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- As Westchester County starts writing the fifth chapter in its evolution as a suburb, it needs immediate planning on an exceptionally big basis, the Family Service of Scarsdale heard last night.
Pierce County, Wash., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Jan. 12 on an issue of $6,000,000 of courthouse bonds dated Feb. 1, 1953 and maturing from Feb. 1 from 1956 to 1974.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 16 -- John (Honey) Russell "didn't know what to expect" after his Seton Hall University team was rudely jolted last week by a smartly drilled Temple five, but the Pirates' picture appears to have cleared considerably.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 16 -- Earl J. Carroll, an American lawyer practicing in Germany, said yesterday it was not true that the 125 alleged Communists whose names he recently gave to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, were employes of the United States High Commission in Germany.

Nomination of candidates for Governor, United States Senator and other statewide offices at a primary election instead of by state conventions was advocated last night by the legislative committee of the Affiliated Young Democrats.

This year's assortment of ornamental objects to trim a Christmas tree, decorate a room or enliven a table setting emphasizes glittery surfaces. The few lusterless decorations on display in the shops show a novelty of design to express holiday joy.

As always, when Joseph Fuchs is the violinist, an evening of stylish playing results. Musically the performances had a blend of virility backed by the operation of a first-rate musical intelligence. Technically they were examples of one of the best bow arms in the business, an exceptionally accurate left hand, and a complete fluidity.
Fish of a wide variety and in substantial quantity forms an important part of the mounting food bounty of the approaching holiday season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Eisenhower made it plain today that his new legislative program would be subject to negotiation with Congress as to detail but not in principle.

Wagner College's unbeaten quintet gained its first success in twelve meetings with Manhattan College, crushing the Jaspers 80 -- 58, last night at Grymes Hill, Staten Island. The Seahawks, who recorded their fifth straight success, went to the fore midway in the opening quarter and held a one-point margin at the end of the third session, 51 -- 50.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Cornell, the coaches' favorite to win the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship, opened its Ivy campaign with a 64-53 victory over Harvard tonight.

Contract demands, which include a 25 per cent wage increase, were served upon the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association yesterday by the representatives of 3,500 local tugboat workers. Local 333, United Marine Division of the independent International Longshoremen's Association, has a one-year agreement that expires on Jan. 31, 1954.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A Syracuse University professor was quoted tonight as saying that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had apologized to him today because he had been erroneously subpoenaed to appear today before the Senate permanent Subcommittee on Investigations in New York City.
Disclosures of irregularities in various charity appeals has hurt the sale of Christmas seals by local tuberculosis associations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board today went into closed session on the strange case of the non-existent International Workers Order and recessed until Jan. 5 on the equally strange case of "Mr. X."

Plagued with a shortage of qualified employes, chain stores are turning to the classified advertising columns. One Philadelphia food chain ran help wanted ads in The New York Times in an effort to get the type of trainee it needed, according to Chain Store Age, Grocery Advance News.

Thousands of people will be glad to know that at last Katharine Cornell has a splendid part, although no one needs to be told that she acts it well. She is cast as a United States representative to the U. N. in "The Prescott Proposals," written by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse and put on at the Broadhurst last evening.

The Department of commerce's estimate that the gross national product dropped $3,500,000,000 in the third quarter this year has not been too upsetting to most Wall Street commentators. In their books it is generally taken to indicate the true mildness of the business decline.

THE Chesapeake seems to be one of the few waterfowl areas where the shooters are less interested in duck shooting generally than in canvasback shooting in particular, and they can provide you with a long and detailed argument for their preference at the drop of a shellbag.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 16 -- South Africa celebrated Thanksgiving Day today. More than four fifths of the population did not participate, seeing no reason to give thanks although all businesses and factories closed because that is the law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Holland Houston, power adviser to Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington State, said today that the movement of aluminum plants to the Pacific Northwest had damaged the economy of the area and threatened "to eliminate labor or lower the standard of living for laborers."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Notre Dame, the nation's No. 2 football power, today presented a trophy to Maryland honoring it as the No. 1 club -- but with a string attached.
The incoming City Administration plans to ask the state for $78,000,000 of additional annual revenue to be derived from sources now entirely within state control.

Ron Murphy's first goal of the season gave the New York Rangers a 4-to-3 victory over the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The youthful right wing skater took a relay from Max Bentley and Aldo Guidolin and caged the puck with a right alley shot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 9:
