WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Post Office Department said today that Christmas mail deliveries will get "the full treatment" this year as in previous years, notwithstanding special Government holidays authorized by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Morton Sobell, convicted with Julius and Ethel Rosenberg of conspiracy to commit wartime espionage for the Soviet Union, asked the Supreme Court today to grant him a new trial.
PARIS, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of the final communique of the North Atlantic Council, which has been meeting here.

In our opinion the National Labor Relations Board has made a fatal error and a shocking decision in directing an election by longshoremen of their choice of a collective bargaining representative on or before Dec. 23. The present atmosphere of intimidation and coercion on the waterfront precludes holding an unhampered election by that time.

In his fifty years in baseball Edward Grant Barrow held down almost every job but bat boy and Baseball Commissioner -- and he was offered the latter post upon the death of Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis. It was Ed Barrow who discovered the immortal Honus Wagner and who turned a left-handed pitcher named Babe Ruth into the greatest home-run hitter that ever lived.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- The Governor's conference on alcoholism, which convened here today, was told by an expert in the field that drinking by young persons might interfere with their growth in emotional balance.

The nation's gasoline stocks were increased last week by 2,411,000 barrels, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 152,509,000 barrels, compared with 150,098,000 a week earlier and 129,582,000 a year ago.

Stock prices leaped yesterday from the springboard of their closing-hour rally on Tuesday and recorded the widest gains since mid-October. Gains ran from 1 to 3 points in chemicals, steels, oils, motors, aircrafts, rails and electrical equipments.

The three-story building on lot 40 by 100 feet at 146-48 East Fifty-sixth Street has been sold by Frederick Brown to Manhattan Importers, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers. It is part of a plot of 45,000 square feet on the east side of Lexington Avenue between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets which Mr. Brown bought from the 657 Lexington Avenue Corporation, R. Baylor Knox, president.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Hopes -- later fulfilled -- that the railroad strike would be averted were reflected in a substantial rise in stock market prices today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Ezra Taft Benson told the nation's farmers today that the Administration would not advocate a rigid, high Government price-support program as a solution to the farm-price problem.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Joseph J. Delaney, who succeeded Joseph S. (Joey) Fay as a labor union vice president, has resigned as a member of a Labor Department advisory committee, Governor Dewey's office said today.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 16 (AP) -- George (Potsy) Clark tonight quit as athletic director at the University of Nebraska.
A mother and her common-law husband were charged yesterday with beating the woman's 11-year-old son with a belt and hanging him by a rope from a clothes hook.

A small-sized electronic brain -- not too large to be carried about and used atop a desk--was put on the market yesterday by Claude Neon, Inc. The device is an analogi computer. Its work is to test automobiles, track the flow of air around a new airplane or chart the curse of a guided missile-- while they are still in the blueprint stage.

The compensating reciprocity of kindness is a truth often noted by the poets. Mrs. Browning wrote that a poor man "served by thee shall make thee rich," and a sick man helped "shall make thee strong." She added that "thou shalt be served thyself" by every service rendered to others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The White House for the first time authorized the radio networks today to broadcast in full a tape recording of President Eisenhower's thirty-five-minute news conference this morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The National Labor Relation Board issued the following order today in the New York waterfront union representation dispute:

Insurance agencies controlled by Thomas F. Lewis, slain labor boss of Yonkers Raceway, were shown yesterday to have drained $275,000 in excessive fees and commissions from the welfare fund that had been set up for the 5,221 members of Lewis' union.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 17 -- Premier Nguyen Van Tam of Vietnam and his Government resigned today after months of opposition from various anti-Communist nationalist factions in this French-sponsored Indo-Chinese state.

V. Frank Coe, former secretary of the International Monetary Fund who was once director of monetary research for the Treasury Department, denied yesterday that he had had any part in the decision to give German currency plates to the Soviet Government.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The secretary of Kiwanis International said today that the National Kids Day Foundation made no financial contribution to Kiwanis clubs and that the clubs "make no contribution whatsoever" to the foundation.
The General Electric Company, the largest electrical manufacturer in the world, has at least one foot in the protectionist camp.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Eisenhower Administration won today a court test of its power to discharge workers in policy-making and other key positions, regardless of Civil Service rules.

TOKYO, Dec. 16 -- Japanese conservative parties have made their first formal move looking to revision of the new constitution and elimination of provisions pledging this nation "never" again to maintain armed forces and to renounce war "forever."

City College came within a basket of scoring the biggest upset of the college basketball, season last night. It took a last-ditch goal by Allan Larkin for undefeated Fordham, a 20-point favorite, to edge the inspired Beavers, 53 -- 51, before 2,500 astonished spectators at Fordham's gymnasium.
Two front-rank city career officials announced yesterday their retirements to enter private business.
A shipload of 2,172 soldiers from Korea, Germany and Austria arrived yesterday. Most of the men, who are here for discharge, had served overseas from a year to a year and a half.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 - President Eisenhower expressed grave concern today because young men of the United States frequently did not understand the fundamental principles for which they fought in World War II and in Korea.
KITTY HAWK, N. C., Dec. 16 -- The speed of sound was exceeded repeatedly here this morning by jet planes diving directly at the Wright Memorial Monument on top of Kill Devil Hill.
An indictment of Soviet policy affecting music as it was laid down by decree of the Central Committee of the Communist party in February, 1948, was published in last month's issue of Soviet Music.

Although power was commonly associated with the Dodgers as having contributed most to bringing Brooklyn its second successive pennant last summer, the Flock, it turned out, wasn't so bad on defense either.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The nationwide railroad and London subway strike scheduled to begin at midnight Sunday was called off tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Eisenhower emphasized today that he was bound by law to reduce drastically United States military aid to Europe if the European Defense Community did not materialize.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Officers of the two major labor federations signed a no-raiding agreement today, but so far it scarcely affects anyone.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Pa., Dec. 16 -- Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania and Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey met in the middle of the Delaware Water Gap Bridge today in ceremonies marking the opening of the $8,500,000 span.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 16 -- The Soviet Navy has added a new type of destroyer to its Baltic fleet. It is the so-called Skory type, of which four have been commissioned, according to official information of the Swedish Navy.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- A Government spokesman said here today that the Soviet bloc countries, not Yugoslavia, were making the concessions in the unusually harmonious meeting of the Danube River Commission in Rumania.
BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- The East German Government asked today that the governments of both parts of Germany be represented at the proposed Berlin conference of the Big Four foreign ministers.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Ezzard Charles took a big step on the comeback trail as he scored a knockout tonight over young Coley Wallace in 2 minutes 43 seconds of the tenth round.

The Princeton University Triangle Club's show, "Malice in Wonderland," came to town last night and gave the faithful perhaps their first opportunity to laugh and cheer since Yale walked off with the gridiron honors last November.

GARFIELD, N. J., Dec. 16 -- The strike of Garfield's teachers, which closed the city's nine public schools last Friday, giving 3,600 children a three-day vacation, ended today as the 170 teachers won the increases promised to them since early this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Three German import concerns and an individual in Germany were banned today from receiving exports from this country under terms of a suspension order issued by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce of the Department of Commerce.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The two Houses of Parliament will meet in a joint session at Versailles tomorrow to elect the next President of the French Republic. They meet under the pressure of a triple crisis -- in domestic, overseas and international affairs.

Small talk, backed by a pistol, can yield crime dividends. In Brooklyn, for instance, a man who has become an expert in disarming conversation about "my precocious boy" has managed to hold up five toy stores since Dec. 10 and stroll off with $2,000.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16 -- A new clash between the Eisenhower Administration and United States labor was believed in the making today over the latter's exclusion from negotiations now under way for a revised United States-Mexican agreement on migratiry farm workers.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 16 -- Navy outclassed an inept Columbia quintet today, beating the Lions, 78 -- 52, for the undefeated Middies fourth straight victory.

" THE machine-lifted from the truck just as it was entering the fourth rail," Orville Wright noted in his singularly calm and matter-of-fact diary fifty years ago today. "Mr. Daniels took a picture just as it left the tracks."

On the advice of Dr. Albert Einstein, a 38-year-old engineer refused here yesterday to tell Senator Joseph R. McCarthy whether he had been a Communist while working for the Army or on Government contracts since 1941. The engineer denied any spying.
HARTFORD, Dec. 16 -- Governor Dewey declared tonight that the Eisenhower Administration had fulfilled "the solemn duty of government" in bringing before the public the Harry Dexter White case.
The casualty insurance industry was accused yesterday of ignoring a request for cooperation in the state investigation of workmen's compensation.

The City Athletic Club continued to lead the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B team tournament by beating the Downtown A. C., 3 -- 2, yesterday. The City A. C., triumphant in its four matches, are setting the pace with a record of twenty-one individual triumphs as against four reverses.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 16 -- Officials of steel companies that are investing more than $500,000,000 in development of the taconite industry on the Mesabi Iron Range predict that 12,000,000 tons of taconite concentrate a year will be shipped from Minnesota by 1958.

Commodity prices moved irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume eased in most markets. Coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, burlap, rubber, lead, tin and zinc were up; cocoa, wool and copper closed lower, and sugar, hides and potatoes ended mixed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A prediction that Congress will raise the national cotton acreage allotment to ease the economic impact on producers, was made here today. The forecast came in the wake of the farmers' overwhelming approval of strict Federal controls on the 1954 crop and was based on Western and Southern growers getting together.

AGANA, Guam, Thursday, Dec. 17 -- A crippled Air Force B-29 bomber went out of control during an emergency landing today and crashed through an Air Force officers' housing area, killing sixteen persons including six children.
ALBANY, Dec 16 (AP) -- New York's motorists are piling up the heaviest toll of traffic deaths since 1941, the State Motor Vehicle Commissioner declared today.
Moscow's publication of detailed charges against Lavrenti P. Beria apparently heralds one of the most sensational trials in Soviet history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today it would issue to Trans-Canada Airlines a permit for Montreal-Mexico City flights making nontraffic stops at Tampa, Fla. Fla.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in November averaged 35,128 bales for each working day. This compared with 38,717 bales daily in the corresponding period a year ago and with 35,237 in October.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation gave high Truman Administration officials dozens of reports linking ten Federal employes with alleged Communist espionage, the Senate Internal Security subcommittee said today.

Jo Stafford, the singer, will be starred in a new weekly program over the C. B. S. television network beginning Tuesday, Feb. 2, from 7:45 to 8 P. M. Paul Weston, her husband, will conduct the orchestra.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The Government's contention that the general purchasing committee of the General Motors Corporation had been created to carry out selfish du Pont interests "does not hang together," Ferris E. Hurd, a G. M. attorney, asserted today.

Despite the stir caused by Secretary Dulles' candid statement on American policy, a statement supported yesterday by President Eisenhower, the twelfth Ministers' Conference of the North Atlantic Alliance has come to an end in Paris with firm agreements. The conference accepted as a fundamental premise that the Soviets have not changed either their policy or their strategy, and that it is therefore necessary to continue to build up Western defenses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The French people either do not believe that the basis of security for the Western World, their own particularly, will be shattered and must be painfully rebuilt on a design even less acceptable to them if they much longer delay or reject the European Defense Community plan, or they hope to avert the peril by shutting their eyes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower received a .38 caliber revolver today -- and the donor jokingly invited the President to use the weapon on him for referring to the President as a Democrat.

As Christmas shoppers thronged the stores in search of gifts for families and friends, many city organizations distributed presents yesterday to the less fortunate. They also gave parties and made plans to brighten the holidays for the homeless, the aged, the ill and the neglected.

Not one dollar of direct aid was given to any veteran or dependent out of the $21,480,000 that the Disabled American Veterans, Inc., raised in the last three years. The organization carried on national campaigns that included mailings of millions of miniature auto tags and ball-point pens.

The Cunard Line's Queen Elizabeth set a company record for express liner turnaround in sailing for Europe at 1:57 P. M., yesterday, nineteen hours and fifty-seven minutes after tieing up at West Fiftieth Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Organization of family and neighborhood councils of parents and adolescents to discuss and reach agreement on standards for teen-age behavior was urged here tonight by Mother M. Berenice, director of the Child Study Center at the College of New Rochelle.
Columbia's 1933 team held its twentieth reunion last night as guest of honor at the annual football dinner of the Columbia Varsity "C" Club at the Men's Faculty Club.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 16 -- Delegates of the Farmers Union Grain Terminal Association from four states voted unanimous opposition today to key sections of farm policies advocated by the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson.

Controller-elect Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday the appointment of Louis Cohen of 1,075 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, as First Deputy Controller in the incoming city administration. Mr. Cohen will succeed Lewis F. Lang, who will revert to civil service status.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Following is the text of a resolution on the Jordan River question that was introduced in the United Nations Security Council today by the United States, Britain and France:
The suit of Lawrence Gerosa, the Controller-elect against the city was settled yesterday for $67,500.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Following is a stenographic transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, released with White House permission:
Directors of Fidelity Deposit Company of Maryland declared yesterday a 33 1/3 per cent stock dividend for payment on March 31, thereby increasing the capital stock to $4,000,000 from $3,000,000.

The City Planning Commission's report on its survey of relocating tenants in slum clearance projects should be made public immediately, Lawrence M. Orton, a member of the commission, declared last night.

Taxwise, it's cheaper to do business in Puerto Rico. A marked acceleration of the already rapid rate at which industrial plants are being established on the island is foreseen as a result of the recent signing by Governor Luis Munoz Marin of the Puerto Rico Industrial Incentive Act of 1954.
Nearly 22,000,000 persons participated in learning about themselves and the world of nature through the American Museum of Natural History last year.
" IF you think you can punch me in the nose, Babe," said Ed Barrow, "I'd like to see you try it."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Eisenhower likes "Ike."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 16 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has ordered his nation-wide Congress party machine to organize demonstrations in all of India's twenty-eight states against proposed United States military aid to Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) The Deartment of Agriculture said today that farm price support losses this fascal year are increasing at three times last year's rate.
The 22-year-old son of a Bronx health officer was arrested early today after the Bronx District Attorney, George B. De Luca, accused him of murdering his parents for their insurance.

In recognition of Columbia University's bicentennial celebration, the Metropolitan Museum is opening to the public today an exhibition entitled "American Painting, 1754-1954." Columbia was founded in 1754. Its experts have been giving lectures at the museum since 1892.

In a complicated transaction involving a purchase price of $6,500,000, Dan Topping and Del Webb have sold Yankee Stadium, home of the world champion baseball club. A companion property, the stadium of the Kansas City (Mo.) Blues, a Yankee farm club, also was included in the deal.
VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 17 -- Two inconclusive ballots for the Presidency of France were taken today. The Socialist candidate, Marcel Naegelen, led Premier Joseph Laniel after the second.

Psychoanalyst, cure thyself! is Edward Chodorov's theme in "Oh, Men! Oh, Women!", which was acted with considerable eclat at Henry Miller's last evening. Everybody in the audience seemed to be having a good time. For psychoanalysis is America's leading hobby, and everybody in the audience seemed to recognize and relish the cliches of the patients Mr. Chodorov exposes on the stage.

How does one select a Christmas gift? Probably by determining roughly what one can afford to spend, then deciding what present in that price-range would mean the most to the recipient. Using this criterion we suggest some Christmas gifts that would mean a great deal and that almost anyone can afford.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Dec. 12, 1953, totaled 651,951 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,084 cars, or 1.5 per cent
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Defense Department, prodded by Congressional objections, today banned the sale of liquor by the bottle on military posts.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Apprentice John L. Rotz, the leading rider at the Tropical Park meeting with eighteen winners, escaped serious injury today when his mount, March Brat, was blinded by the sun during the running of the featured seventh race.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Predictions of flight into space at 25,000 miles an hour or more were made here tonight as leaders in aviation met to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the first powered flight at Kitty Hawk, N. C., by the Wright brothers.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 17 -- Two large Virginia coal companies have bought mines in Tennessee which are among those with contracts to ship coal to the Tennessee Valley Authority steam plants.
The Swedish Lloyd liner Patricia sailed up New York Harbor yesterday morning, the latest addition to an ever-growing fleet of cruise ships working out of this port.
Tuesday was fixed yesterday as the date for a National Labor Relations Board election among 22,000 dock workers in the Port of New York.

Every generation -- and one says, inevitably, this generation in particular -- needs someone to bring it up short by saying, "Look here: your writing and speaking are becoming slovenly; for heaven's sake do something about it!"
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The International League today awarded conditional franchises to Richmond, Va., and Havana.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Two developments today brought peace in disputes connected with the operation of the country's railroad systems and allied activities.

A new one-story facl;ory at! 26-04 Borough Place in Woodside, Queens, has been leased by the Aladdin Produetl Company of New York, converters antl printers of cellophane, glassine and polythene bags for industry. The building, in a' new industrial area, is

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A rough draft of President Eisenhower's budget for the coming fiscal year was laid before key Congressional Republicans at the White House today, and the outlook was for another year of deficit spending.
Capt. Harry N. Sadler was honored yesterday at a luncheon aboard the Moore-McCormack liner Argentina shortly before he took the big ship out on a voyage to South America's east coast.

The Cantata Singers, appearing last night in St. Michael's Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, made an attempt to sing three choral works by Bach under the actual conditions in which the composer had conducted his music.

Horace Ashenfelter, premier United States two-miler, proved himself ready for the indoor track campaign last night by scoring a 9:08.5 victory in a pre-season handicap meet at the 102d Engineer's Armory.
THERE'S nostalgia for New Yorkers pushing through the middle years in old gingerbread Christmas cards on display on the second floor in the House of Cards at 170 Broadway.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation today approved policies that reaffirmed its endorsement of a flexible farm program. But the organization made some concessions to high price supports and Federal controls.

OTTAWA, Dec. 17 -- The Canadian Government, which already has turned down a request from owners of this country's thirty-three-vessel seagoing merchant fleet for a $5,000,000-a-year subsidy, ruled today that the ships could not be sold abroad.
A showdown in the interunion battle over waterfront loading appeared in the making last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- The prospects of putting atomic energy to peacetime uses -- to help farmers restore worn-out land to fertility and produce better crops, to aid medical research and to add virtually unlimited new techniques to industry -- were spelled out today in a United Nations journal.

Placido Gomez, the one-time Rice Institute court and baseball star, who inherited the job of varsity basketball coach at Brooklyn College this season, deplored the lack of height among the Kingsmen yesterday. His tallest starter is only 6 feet 2 inches. Two others are 5-11 and 5-8.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- During the week ended Dec. 16, member bank reserves increased $509,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Voice of America broadcast throughout most of the world yesterday almost the entire press conference held by President Eisenhower at the White House Wednesday. The reporters' questions and the President's answers about atomic energy, the European army and other matters had been recorded on tape.
" Properly formulated" chlorophyll products will retain their share of the market in 1954, it was predicted yesterday by Dr. Robert Heggie, research director of the American Chicle Company.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 18 -- No comment was immediately available at United Nations Command headquarters on reports from New Delhi that the Indian Government might advocate detention after Jan. 22 of the anti-Communist prisoners of the Korean war now in neutral custody.
ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Governor Dewey has told some Republicans privately that he does not plan to seek a fourth term next fall. Instead he has said he will retire from public life and practice law.

Ways that parents can help to bring about coordinated planning of the city's recreation services were outlined yesterday by two leaders in work for children. They agreed that a master plan was urgently needed.

Thomas Hayward, Metropolitan Opera tenor from Kansas City, sang the most important role of his Metropolitan career on short notice last evening when he rushed to the opera house between acts to replace the indisposed Jussi Bjoerling in the title role of "Faust."
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 17 -- Utah's State Senate passed by a vote of 14 to 9 today a controversial bill to transfer three state-owned junior colleges to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture, in its final report of the year, today estimated the 1953 corn crop at 3,176,615,000 bushels and the wheat crop at 1,168,536,000.

Last summer an editorial appeared in The Times regarding the commission which had been established to attempt to alleviate some of the unpleasantness caused by commercial airplanes passing over New York City.

The Indiana Toll Road Commission completed yesterday the permanent financing of the 156-mile, four-lane toll road proposed to run from the Indiana-Illinois line east of Chicago to a connection with the Ohio Turnpike, now under construction.
A system of color television that can be received in black and white on the 27,000,000 existing sets was approved last night by the Federal Communications Commission in Washington.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Lavrenti P. Beria has already been put to death, in the opinion of one group of Government experts on Russia.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 17 -- The statement Tuesday, by the Indian chairman of the neutral nations commission in Korea that the commission would release unrepatriated prisoners Jan. 22 "is his own views and does not reflect that of the Government of India," a spokesman for the Indian Foreign Office said today.

Gordon K. Smith has been elected secetary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, succeeding Henry G. Wood, who has resigned. He formerly was director of the special services division of the company handling estate planning and business insurance.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 17 -- The United States and Britain are considering a plan designed to overcome Yugoslav objections to past proposals for a conference on the Trieste dispute.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy announced yesterday that he would seek a Smith Act indictment against Harry A. Hyman, a Manhattan insurance man who has made hundreds of telephone calls to defense installations in the last two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Eisenhower began outlining today to his Republican Congressional leaders a 1954 legislative program that appeared to be basically conservative. He emphasized that it was a task for the entire Republican party.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The constitutionality of pre-censorship of motion pictures was attacked in a brief filed in the Supreme Court today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Dr. Farid Zeineddine of Syria today attacked a compromise resolution on the Jordan River question introduced yesterday by the United States, Britain and France. He told the United Nations Security Conncil that in the resolution "we are faced with a three-power Israeli point of view."
Creation of a new set of three Albert Lasker Awards was announced yesterday. Winners will be selected every three years for outstanding work in service for the physically disabled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Chief Judge Bolitha J. Laws of the United States District Court here testified today that when he went on the Federal bench in 1938 he was compelled to resign from two private clubs, discharge his maid and take up early morning and Saturday law teaching.
MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The treason trial of Lavrenti P. Beria and six persons accused as his henchmen possibly will be held in private, with the accused themselves absent, legal experts said today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17 -- Hossein Makki, prominent Opposition leader, returned to his home here tonight after more than two days in hiding. He charged that "government officials" had plotted to kill him for his violent attacks on the Government of Maj. Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi, Iranian Premier.
Washington, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's opening and closing statements today at his conference with Republican Congressional leaders and his Cabinet:

Grover A. Whalen has been the embodiment of New York City's warm and gracious welcome to arriving notables for so long that it seems like the end of an era, or several eras, when the new administration changes its greeter. Seven Mayors have sent him down the bay.

Two unbeaten teams from Dixie removed two local quintets from basketball's honor roll at Madison Square Garden last night. First, Western Kentucky overwhelmed St. Francis by 78 -- 55, then Rice edged St. John's, 85 -- 81.

A decision yesterday by Municipal Court Justice Murray T. Feiden in Brooklyn stayed until Jan. 10 the eviction of sixty-seven World War II veterans and their families still living at two state temporary housing projects in Brooklyn.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization believes that maneuvering for position in the Soviet power apparatus probably continues.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 17 -- Jackie Robinson, the Brooklyn Dodger baseball star, and his wife have decided to buy a lakeside home on nearly five acres of land on Cascade Road, two miles north of the Merritt Parkway near the New Canaan town line.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Administration is planning to alert the public that enemy agents now can smuggle compact atomic sabotage bombs into the United States.

Friends of Mayor Impellitteri have suggested that Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. appoint him to the Board of Water Supply. The virtually lifetime post pays $15,000 a year. A vacancy on the board has existed since the retirement of Commissioner Rufus E. McGahen on Dec. 1.

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday a bill passed by the City Council last Wednesday creating the office of City Administrator. The board fixed at $30,000 the annual salary to be paid to Dr. Luther H. Gulick, chosen by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. for the new post.

New agreements setting up schedules for reducing the work week to thirty-five hours without loss of pay for 12,000 persons employed in making corsets, brassieres and children's wear were announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The new White House policy of leveling some of the barriers that have secluded the personality of the President of the United States from the American people has been twice and strikingly revealed in two days. Its first expression was in the release yesterday of the full transcript of President Eisenhower's press conference, with the President's words recorded as he spoke them, in the first person.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The State Department has decided to make its own on-the-spot survey of the key problems in the Far East.
One of the nation's largest retail associations moved yesterday to develop performance standards on all fabrics used in wearing apparel and household furnishings.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- The Greek God Proteus and Alice in Wonderland's Cheshire cat were introduced in the du Pont anti-trust trial today. They were used by a defense attorney to illustrate what he termed "significant changes" in the Government's original charges of illegal trade agreements between E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and General Motors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Grains had a variety of price movements today with wide swings and many cross currents. Wheat and corn were strong, but declined sharply around midday following wide-open breaks in soybeans and oats But both the major grains came back well in later trading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Suggested means by which the Government can streamline its materials controls program to make a more effective instrument for achieving defense goals in either a hot or cold war were advanced here today by an advisory group from the steel industry.

ATLANTA, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Tennessee was reported today to be leading a move to pull powerful members out of the Southeastern Conference because of a newly imposed "ceiling" on scholarships, but the conference commissioner, Bernie Moore, said "It's all news to me."

The heretofore anonymous private donor who will pay for the distribution of 8,000 copies of a pamphlet called "Permit Communist-Conspirators to Be Teachers ?" in the parochial schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn is William Robertson Coe.
Christmas-like weather gripped New York yesterday and early today as the mercury skidded to 16 degrees at midnight -- its lowest mark since last winter. It was still at 16 at 3 A. M.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 18 -- South Korea's Foreign Minister cast doubt yesterday on the statement by President Syngman Rhee that the republic would give an international political conference on Korean affairs ninety days to formulate decisions before taking independent action to unify the peninsula.

Judged by his achievements he must be two or three times 65. Judged by his unbounded energy and continued capacity for getting things done he must be in the mid-thirties. But, as his favorite Governor used to remark, let's look at the record, and that makes him 65, incredible as it may seem.

Skiers, who have been eagerly awaiting freezing temperatures and heavy snows to get their boards humming over the white mountainsides, will have to be more patient. Up to yesterday, only the cold weather had arrived, bringing with it the frost necessary to preserve a base and provide the proper insulation for the snows when they come.
Representatives of the New England states, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania gathered yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel to discuss mutual problems.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a retirement application, effective on Jan. 1, filed by Controller Lazarus Joseph. Mr. Joseph, who has held public office for twenty-three consecutive years, was elected Controller in 1945 and re-elected in 1949. He is 62 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The first guided missile battery to take its place in the air defense of the United States will be installed soon at Fort George G. Meade, Md., twenty-four miles northeast of here. It apparently will be used to guard the Capital, Baltimore and industrial and military targets in the surrounding areas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Excerpts from the official explanation given by the National Labor Relations Board for its decision to hold an election among dock workers here next week follow. In the text the New York Shipping Association is referred to as the "association," the old International Longshoremen's Association as the "independent" and the new American Federation of Labor union of the same name as the "A. F. L.":
Reversing a three-week contraseasonal down trend, loans to business by New York banks rose $42,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.

Yesterday when the mercury reached its lowest point here so far this season Best Co. staged a spirited review of resort fashions. The floral prints, silken cottons and airy crepes offered a thematic prelude to a holiday in the sunny South.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, cautioned tonight against any tendency among its members to bypass its machinery whenever the Charter plainly meant that this machinery should be used.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Five firemen and a civilian died early today when fire destroyed the Reliance Hotel building on West Madison Street, a few blocks beyond that thoroughfare's "skid row."

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The Western Big Three will try to promote a sense of security from aggression in Russian minds when their foreign ministers meet with Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov in Berlin, Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill declared today.

Candy, always an important food item, becomes doubly popular at Christmas. Most of it (about 46.8 pounds a person in 1953) is eaten out of hand. At this season, however, many of the colorful hard candies, wrapped in cellophane, tend charm to gift wrappings, wreaths and table decorations. For the latter, we suggest a pine cone and lollipop tree, directions for which are given today.

SUVA, Fiji Islands, Friday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II was serenaded at 4:30 A.M. today by Fiji Islanders still celebrating yesterday's royal arrival. But she apparently slept through the sing song.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $11,995.003, in the three months ended with October, against $11,942,136 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year, the report disclosed yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 17 -- John J. Kuhn, a Great Neck attorney appointed special guardian for underaged heirs to the $14,000,000 estate of the late Lewis Cass Ledyard Jr., petitioned Nassau County Surrogate's Court here yesterday for an award of $245,400 for legal fees.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 17 -- A sharp division of opinion over the powers of a future All-German National Assembly developed today between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the West German Socialist party. It may affect the united front that the Bonn parties so far have presented to the East on that question.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 17 -- The New South Wales Labor Government enacted today a bill making membership of trade union compulsory for workers and giving preference of employment to trade unionists.

" Julius Caesar," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's film version of the Shakespearean tragedy, has been chosen as the best film of the year by the Committee on Exceptional Films of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.
The cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier in the late trading yesterday and closed 14 to 21 points net lower.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Congressional approval is scheduled for the plan of the Naval Observatory here to move its biggest telescope to Flagstaff, Ariz.

CLINTON, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- The great-great-granddaughter of Alexander Hamilton last night helped Hamilton College place on permanent exhibition the desk on which the early American statesman wrote his part of the Federalist papers.

Harlow Joseph Fraden, 20-year-old New York University graduate, confessed last night, according to the authorities, that he poisoned his parents last August because his mother had always twitted him as a homosexual.

HONG KONG, Dec. 17 -- Ho Chi Minh, chief of the Communist-led Vietminh rebels, repeated his offer to France of an armistice in a statement made last night to mark the seventh anniversary of the war in Indo-China. The statement was received here in a broadcast over the Peiping radio.

Higher international parcel post rates have reduced considerably the number of parcels being sent overseas from this country. They have also driven many personal senders of gift food parcels to commercial establishments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has enlisted the vast resources of the Tennessee Valley Authority in a one-year study of the immediate and long range possibilities of commercial nuclear power production.

Bullet-proof armored vests and hoods, capable of halting slungs from the most powerful hand weapons, were demonstrated and then distributed yesterday to members of the Police Department. They are to be used in apprehending criminals who might be holed-up or barricaded in buildings.
All questions concerning race, color, nationality and religion have been removed from application blanks of the 272 nonsectarian colleges, universities and junior colleges in New York State.
A shifting population has made necessary the enlargement of a Manhattan public school now under construction.

In approaching the problem of the deadlocked prisoner interrogation at Panmunjom the Communists have, perhaps unwittingly, put their finger upon the real issue that divides the free from the slave world. In a Peiping broadcast they have stated that it is the "duty" of the neutral nations commission to "use the means of compulsion" to carry out the program of prisoner "persuasion."

Directors of the Gillette Company increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday with a declaration of 62 1/2 cents a share for payment on March 5. Previously shareholders received 50 cents quarterly.

The textile man's dream of a degree course in textiles given in New York City was encouraged yesterday. Dean Louis M. Hacker, head of the School of General Studies at Columbia University, said informal talks with the heads of the university's other schools led him to believe that such a goal could be achieved.
DETROIT, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Glen Skov scored two goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 1, to move into a first-place tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins snapped Toronto's winning streak at three games tonight with the help of two early goals, defeating the Maple Leafs, 3 -- 2, before 6,722 fans, the smallest Boston Garden hockey crowd of the season.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Britain served notice on Egypt today that she would not back down on two essential conditions for her withdrawal from the Suez Canal base.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Representative George H. Bender, Republican of Ohio, announced today that he was in the race for the Republican nomination for Senator from Ohio.

THE Long Island and Connecticut duck hunters seem to be convinced that the good duck shooting is just beginning, for the drop in temperature and the arrival of good flights of red leg black ducks promise to close the season with more of a flourish than was apparent earlier.

Luxury appointments, including power brakes, power steering and electrically operated front seats and window lifts, are features of the 1954 Chevrolet and Pontiac passenger cars, which will go on display today in dealer showrooms. All of the appliances are optional equipment at extra cost.

About 4,000 cheering members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., agreed last night to a proposal made by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. to avoid a strike threatened for Jan. 1 on the city-owned transit lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Justice Department said today that Mrs. Frederick Vanderbilt Field, wife of the New Yorker often listed as a supporter of left wing causes, had left this country voluntarily to avoid deportation.
Clothing donated for Korean relief was sold by a crooked promoter to the second-hand trade, a joint legislative committee was told here yesterday.

Rough weather in the North Atlantic showed some signs of abating yesterday. The Weather Bureau reported that one storm center near Iceland had moved out of the shipping lanes, that another off the coast of Portugal was shrinking and that winds were dropping to thirty-knot velocity.

ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Moving day for 4,500 persons living in near-by Shanks Village will be Feb. 15. At that time, the Public Housing Administration will sell at public auction the converted Army barracks they now call home.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- An order for the deportation of Joe Adonis, New Jersey gambler and racketeer, was upheld today by the Board of Immigration Appeals.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 17 -- Between 6,000 and 8,000 books "relating to sex" have been withdrawn from circulation in Illinois State Libraries. Developments indicate, however, that many of them will soon be restored to the shelves.

CAIRO, Dec. 16 -- Major Salah Salem of Egypt's Army junta accused the British last night of attempting to exploit his son's case of poliomyelitis to induce him to cease his campaign against British policies.

Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India and Nepal, has written an account of his experiences and observations which Harper will publish Jan. 4 entitled "Ambassador's Report." In an author's note, Mr. Bowles says: "I have attempted to describe the underlying forces which today influence Asian action and thinking, and to suggest a few essential principles on which I believe any constructive American policy must be based."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Greer Garson will be sent to England again by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, this time to star in "The Case of the Journeying Boy."

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter conducting. Erica Morini, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Town Hall, 5:30; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Mount Holyoke Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Governor Dewey is seriously considering the creation of a new post of "czar" for the state's harness racing activities, a position that would be patterned in part after the commissioner who controls professional baseball.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17 -- Iran and the Soviet Union will resume conversations here Tuesday on longstanding financial and frontier disputes. The parleys, interrupted in August by the overthrow of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, will provide the first major test of Moscow's attitude toward the regime of Premier Fazlallah Zahedi.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 17 (UP) -- Halfback Joe Heap confirmed tonight that he and Quarterback Ralph Guglielmi had been suspended from Notre Dame for what Heap called a "violation of a minor rule."

Paddy Young of Greenwich Village and Billy Graham of the East Side will meet in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight, when boxing officially ends at the arena until after the Christmas holidays.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The behavior of stock market prices today disappointed expectations that gains would follow withdrawal of the railroad strike notice. New buying did not materialize and the markets closed on a falling note, although there were many small rises on the day.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Vio Power, the hard-hitting Negro first baseman-outfielder, said today his trade to the Athletics "favors my position."

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, announced today his candidacy for renomination for a second term next year in a statement criticizing Congressional investigations of espionage.

BRISBANE, Australia, Friday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Billy Talbert, 35-year-old captain of the American team, teamed with young Tony Trabert of Cincinnati today to defeat Philippe Washer and Jacques Brichant of Belgium, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 9 -- 7, in the doubles match of the interzone Davis Cup final.

Henri Peyre's interesting letter about the European Defense Community overlooks what is perhaps the main point. E. D. C. was not designed, primarily, as a means of rearming Germany. That could have been done in any number of alternative ways. Those Frenchmen who planned E. D. C. in the first place did so in order to make sure that the new German Army would not be the old Wehrmacht.

There was nothing novel on the program, consisting entirely of compositions by Johannes Brahms, which Bruno Walter and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra gave last night in Carnegie Hall. But this was one of the finest and most inspiring concerts that the Philharmonic-Symphony Society has given this season.

Wall Street voted yesterday to abolish three holidays. The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, meeting in a "special policy session," decided hereafter to have the market remain open for business on Lincoln's Birthday, Feb. 12; Columbus Day, Oct. 12, and Armistice Day, Nov. 11.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- In offering to share its atomic science with other countries the United States was motivated by some practical considerations, according to Western diplomatic sources.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Eisenhower Administration has decided not to try to reach an agreement with key Congressional Republicans on two pressing issues taxes and reciprocal trade, at the White House conferences that began today.
Bob Jones of Atlanta, whose "grand slam" achievement of 1930 still stands as a golfing record, will be honored by the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association in New York on Jan. 21.

If Maj. Charles E. Yeager had been able to sustain the speed he reached last Saturday in a rocket plane over the Mojave Desert, he could have gone around the world at the equator in fifteen hours, beating the sun by quite a wide margin. Of course, Major Yeager's machine could not keep up the appalling speed it reached.
Parents seeking gifts for young craftsmen may be interested in some "work and play" kits available in the second floor shop of the Arts Cooperative Service, Amsterdam Avenue at Seventy-sixth Street.
Practicality and beauty are both served in the collection of fabrics available through decorators in the new showrooms of Jack Lenor Larsen, 60 East Fifty-eighth Street.
A showdown appears to be near on the question of whether the Empire City Racing Association, which has property and blueprints, but no racetrack, will get racing dates for 1954.
LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Churchill's foreign affairs speech in the House of Commons today:
CAMP RUCKER, Ala., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Maj. Harold M. Shorr, assistant chief of medical service at the Camp Rucker Hospital, was found dead in his quarters early yesterday. His age was 36.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 17 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali said today "Pakistan refuses to be bulldozed by challenges to her sovereignty."

Europe's three best-known speed boat champions, forming the most threatening invasion of an American regatta in two decades, arrived yesterday on a Pan American Airlines plane at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. They will compete at Miami on Dec. 27 in the International Grand Prix for the new Palladium Cup.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. was reported yesterday to have decided not to retain Grover A. Whalen as chairman of the Mayor's Reception Committee, a post he has held for thirty-five years. Mr. Whalen could not be reached for comment last night.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 17 -- Israel's first paper mills were dedicated today at Hadera, midway between Tel Aviv and Haifa. The enterprise, sponsored by investors from the United States, Brazil, Australia and Israel, is expected to meet most of Israel's current paper needs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The rise in production at United States factories and mines since World War II has been even greater than it has been believed to be. From early 1947 to early 1953 the increase was not 27 per cent, but 35 per cent.

President Eisenhower started something new Wednesday when he authorized the broadcast of a tape recording of his entire press conference. It wouldn't be too surprising if before long a press conference were to be telecast; and when that happens the progression from the highly restricted press conference of a generation ago to the press conference in every citizen's living room will be complete.
A new drive seeking repeal of the 20 per cent Federal tax on-theatre tickets got under way yesterday with a meeting of representatives of theatrical groups from various parts of the country.
Stocks held about even in a riptide market yesterday.
A warning that too rapid expansion of retirement pension systems could wreck this country's economy was given yesterday to the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging.

The South taught me a lesson today. I sat in a local courtroom this afternoon and saw an all-white jury acquit a young Negro for killing a prominent white business man, on the grounds of self-defense. The acquittal was won by a Negro lawyer, after a trial during which he was accorded precisely the same courtesy and consideration as the white prosecutor by the judge and courtroom attendants.

The eloquence of two one-time candidates for Governor of New York prevailed upon the Board of Estimate yesterday to set aside a site in the Bronx for horse racing over the opposition of 70 per cent of land owners in the area.

The festive pace quickened yesterday in the city. For 60,000 youngsters a program of 100 Christmas parties began under the sponsorship of the Police Athletic League. Other persons, of all ages, also were remembered -- from hospitalized service men and disabled veterans to blind carol singers.

I have great pleasure in putting on paper our experiences with the American Hospital here in Bath during the war. From the commanding officer down they really were a most delightful crew, and we particularly appreciated their generous attitude on the question of air-raid plans.

The North Atlantic Council meeting in Paris has confirmed what has long been apparent -- that the Atlantic Alliance forces, like the United States armed services, are going to be tailored to a stark "new look."
TOKYO, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Rocky Marciano, the world heavyweight champion, impressed 5,000 Tokyo boxing fans tonight with his famous punches.
Frank W. Abrams, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the world's largest petroleum organization, yesterday announced his retirement, effective on Jan. 1.
All live poultry cleared through the New York Live Poultry Industries terminal in Long Island City now carry a brand name identification.

Your editorial anent Mayor-elect Wagner's request for more state aid to education misses, in my opinion, the primary point. That is, so long as the state does distribute tax money in aid of education it should be done on an equitable basis. This it does not do, and as a result New York City and various cities and villages in Westchester and Nassau Counties are discriminated against.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Michigan's hopes of building a bridge across the Straits of Mackinac, between lower Michigan and the Upper Peninsula, moved nearer realization today when a New York-Chicago banking group offered to underwrite the $99,800,000 revenue bond issue.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- Sir Godfrey Huggins tonight hailed his Federal party's decisive victory in the Central African Federation's first elections and promised to move swiftly ahead with a program of territorial integration and development.
Frank W. Abrams, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the world's largest petroleum organization, yesterday announced his retirement, effective on Jan. 1.
All live poultry cleared through the New York Live Poultry Industries terminal in Long Island City now carry a brand name identification.

Your editorial anent Mayor-elect Wagner's request for more state aid to education misses, in my opinion, the primary point. That is, so long as the state does distribute tax money in aid of education it should be done on an equitable basis. This it does not do, and as a result New York City and various cities and villages in Westchester and Nassau Counties are discriminated against.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Michigan's hopes of building a bridge across the Straits of Mackinac, between lower Michigan and the Upper Peninsula, moved nearer realization today when a New York-Chicago banking group offered to underwrite the $99,800,000 revenue bond issue.

N. May Karff, five-time titleholder, gained her fifth consecutive victory in the seventh round of the women's national championship tournament last night at the Manhattan Chess Club and moved to within half a point of Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser, who had the bye.

All sorts of entertaining prospects are being harnessed by Charles Laughton and Paul Gregory, who are bringing in "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial" to the Plymouth on Jan. 20. Their stature as producers already has been certified with such novel presentations as "Don Juan in Hell" and "John Brown's Body."

Wall Street is looking for a resumption of dividend payments by Cudahy Packing Company on its 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock. It will be recalled that the company suspended distributions a year ago because of a reduction in working capital resulting from a $7,290,000 net loss in the fiscal year to Oct. 31, 1952.

IT looks like the biggest steal since the Brink's hold-up. The Yankees plucked Harry Byrd and Eddie Robinson from the Athletics and gave for the two recognized stars a batch of expendable second-line ballplayers. If George Weiss of the Bombers is ever observed in the vicinity of Fort Knox, he should be arrest on sight by Treasury agents.

A New York State trooper and a deputy internal revenue collector. both under suspension, were acquitted in Brooklyn Federal Court last night of extorting $7,000 from a Long Island farmer to "fix" a tax case.

Volume continued light on most commodities on the New York exchanges yesterday but coffee registered its fourth highest sales of the year and hides had their best activity since Oct. 30. Prices closed irregular with coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, burlap, lead and copper higher; cocoa, hides, rubber and zinc lower, and sugar, wool, potatoes and tin mixed.

Through the purchase of the' outstanding stock, Webb Knapp,{ Inc., has become the sole stockholder of the 1407 Broadway Real-i ty Corporation, owner of the forty- two-stor-,y store and office buildingl st 1407 Eroadway. The buildingI occupies the blockfront on the westI s/de of Broadway between Thirty-l eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Friday, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Carl Austin Hall and Mrs. Bonnie Brown Heady were executed early today for the kidnap-slaying of 6-year-old Bobby Greenlease.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- All four of the Civil Service employes involved in the recent West Point security dismissals confirmed today that they had been discharged. They had been accused by Army's security screening board of being sympathetic to the Communists.

A delicate situation that could lead to serious repercussions throughout Asia has arisen as a result of India's growing protest against any American military aid to Pakistan. Conversations concerning such aid have been under way for some time. Prime Minister Ali has explained that Pakistan does not contemplate any formal alliance with the United States or the establishment of any American bases on its soil.

Plans for erecting an apartment building in the Highbridge Park section of lV,lhattan were an. nouneed yesterday by. Lester Taylor,. broker,-rho reported the sale of the southwest corner of Laurel ldl Terrace_ and West 186th Sheet to Sunpark Realty, Inc.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 14 -- The Venezuelan Government would like to grant more oil concessions but it is holding back because of anxiety in the United States over the fact that the free world's production has recently far exceeded its demands.

The Port of New York Authority voted yesterday to construct a $1,300,000 marginal wharf and bulkhead shed to replace Piers 78 and 79 North River at the site of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel. The decision carries out an agreement with the city, to which title to the wharf will be given.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- United States delegates returned today from the conference of the North Atlantic Council in Paris "very much encouraged" about the outlook for peace in Europe.
" Wesolych Swiat!" the young lady in the picture above might be writing on the Christmas card she's making.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The traffic between the Baltimore Orioles and Philadelphia Athletics continued today with three pitchers being exchanged.

The Public Service Commission filed an eighty-five-page plea yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission to dismiss the application of the Pennsylvania Railroad for a 25 per cent increase in commutation fares on its subject line, the Long Island Rail Road.

ALTHOUGH there is an element of autobiography in most kinds of writing, it is particularly noticeable in literary criticism. The values a critic looks for and admires and the opinions he holds about life and letters are personal and based upon his own experience. Any volume of serious literary criticism tells much about its author as well as much about the writers and books discussed.

A sensational murder trial of the last century is the basis of a novel by Phyllis Gordon Demarest entitled "The Naked Risk." The story's main characters are Albert Deane Richardson, war correspondent and author of "Across the Mississippi," a best seller of 1867; Abby MacFarland, actress, and her divorced husband, Daniel MacFarland. MacFarland fatally wounded Richardson in the office of Horace Greeley's New York Tribune.

Plans for converting the five-story apartment building at 24 West Fifty-eighth Street into offices were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by Jack Brause to an investment client of Harold Schwartzberg, attorney. The property is assessed at $81,000 and was sold through the Cruikshank Company. Irving Lester Levitt was the attorney for Mr. Brause.

Point Four, which was so named because it was a part of former President Truman's inaugural address in 1949, could not be expected to keep its old label under the Eisenhower Administration. Technical Assistance, which is the name it goes by at the United Nations, is just as good. It is the idea and policy that matter.
Dramatizations of the story of the Nativity will be given at churches here tomorrow and on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day.

The editorial in The Times of Dec. 9 gives readers a good description of various Blue Cross organizations. However, it does not mention one factor which has contributed immensely to the growth of the Blue Cross. It was organized labor that constantly pressed for some health benefits and indeed succeeded in its efforts to have all or at least part of the health coverage borne by the employer.
BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- East and West Germany signed a treaty today providing for a considerable expansion in barter.
In the "short pants" stage of life boys like to operate egg beaters and girls have a penchant for hammers and saws, according to Miss Florence Monroe of the New York City Board of Education.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16 -- Yugoslavia has suffered a punishing autumn and winter drought. There is every indication of worse consequences to her food supplies than the droughts of 1950 and 1952. In those years the Government was forced to appeal to the outside world for emergency food relief.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- A $300,000,000 to $500,000,000 bond issue to finance an expansion and modernization program for the state's mental institutions is under consideration by Governor Dewey and his advisers.

The aggregate short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange rose 160,945 shares between Nov. 13 and Dec. 15 and reached the highest total since Oct. 15, 1951, the Exchange reported yesterday.

Canadian production of newsprint in the first eleven months of 1953 was 5,247,971 tons, up 0.5 per cent from output in the comparable period of last year, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday.

The concrete of New York City began sprouting tiny, shiny, green forests in scattered parts of town yesterday as Christmas trees by the thousands continued to pour in by train and truck. A census of the evergreens indicated that there would be enough to go around among the city's millions, even if the general quality wasn't exactly A-1.
Harlow J. Fraden, 20 years old, and Dennis Wepman, 22, were indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges of first degree murder in the poisoning of Fraden's parents last Aug. 19.

The State Racing Commission's annual report, covering forty-nine mimeographed pages and including a bucketful of figures, was made public yesterday. It's a routine sum-up of the doings on the JamaicaBelmont-Aqueduct-Saratoga circuit during the 196-day 1953 campaign.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 18 -- The division of opinion in Bonn on the powers of a future all-German national assembly grew wider today. Such an assembly would be formed if the Western Powers and the Soviet Union could agree on all-German elections.
OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 18 -- For the second time this week the Canadian dollar reached a premium today of more than 3 per cent.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Moscow scientists acknowledged today a three-year-old invitation from Columbia University in New York and said it indicated that "progressive Americans" were worried about the freedom of their scientists.

MARYSVILLE, Mich., Dec. 18 -The linking of the power systems of the Detroit Edison Company and the Hydroelectric Power Commission of Canada was celebrated today by officials of Michigan and the Province of Ontario.

It is not my intention to discuss all the aspects of the Palestine question involved in Israel Herman's interpretation of my address to the Security Council concerning the Kibya massacre by the Israeli Army.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A rupture of negotiations between Austria and Jewish representatives for restitution of property taken from Jews by the Nazis was announced here today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Leclaire Stable's Ballydam, an Irish-bred son of Ballogan, raced to a one-sided triumph in the Shanballymore Purse of $2,500 at Tropical Park today before a chilled crowd of 6,638.
In a colorful holiday setting, the annual Mayfair Assembly for debutantes of this and recent seasons was held last night in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

The appointment of Louis Cohen, former Acting Deputy Mayor under William O'Dwyer, as First Deputy Controller by Controllerelect Lawrence E. Gerosa, effective Jan. 1, was criticized yesterday by Walter M. Weis, president of the City Club of New York. Mr. Weis said the club received announcement of this appointment with regret.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- A compromise Western resolution on a dispute over the waters of the Jordan River ran into difficulties today in the United Nations Security Council. A threat by Nationalist China to abstain, or possibly to veto the resolution, may compel the United States, Britain and France to modify their proposal.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 18 -- The Government has decided upon the immediate dissolution of the rump Majlis, the lower House of Parliament, surviving from the Mossadegh regime, and for early elections for a new legislature. Three decrees embodying these objectives have been prepared for the Shah's signature, and are expected to be promulgated Sunday.
Scores of pre-Christmas parties were held yesterday throughout the city for underprivileged children. There were some festivities for adults, too.
TORONTO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A childless Brooklyn housewife may win her nine-month fight for custody of a baby she and her husband tried to smuggle out of Canada.

Cardinal Spellman left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday morning on his fourth Christmas visit to United Nations troops in Korea. He stopped briefly last night at Seattle before flying on to Anchorage, Alaska.

WITH Christmas almost within casting distance and less than a gunshot away, a number of individuals with hunters or fishermen on their lists might find a perfect solution to their gift problems in one of the recent books on hunting or fresh and salt water angling.
BOSTON, Dec. 18 -- Raymond Lynch, 25 years old, plunged five stories to his death today, carrying with him a starling he had caught as a courtesy to two frightened women.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 18 -- The Bundesrat, upper house of the West German Parliament, voted today the budget estimates for fiscal 1954 that had been submitted by Finance Minister Fritz Schaeffer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Republican Congressional leaders and the Eisenhower Administration reached apparent agreement at the White House today on the necessity of increasing the national debt limit. They reportedly were divided, however, on at least two other pressing fiscal issues.

The formation of an eight-team football league within the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association was confirmed yesterday by Brother George of Bishop Loughlin School, Brooklyn, the C. H. S. A. A. president.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Frank Lane, general manager of the Chicago White Sox, said tonight the Sox were not "conceding" the 1954 pennant to the Yankees just because of New York's big - player swap with the Philadelphia Athletics.

Life in New York may be in many ways a good deal less than perfect for children, speakers at a recent meeting of the United Parents Associations agreed. However, several of the parents held, nowhere else in the world can children grow up among so many varied cultures with the opportunity of building understanding and appreciatation of others different from themselves.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Officials of tthe Baltimore Colts said today they were considering whether to remove Keith Molesworth as head coach and move him "upstairs" to management.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Hamilton Watch Company, Lancaster, Pa., received a patent this week on an electric watch designed to run for six months or more on current from a tiny flashlight battery.
VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 18 -- Premier Joseph Laniel forged into the lead today in the election contest for the French Presidency.

Mayor Impellitteri's plan to save a $7,850 job for Herbert L. Brickman, son of his friend, Deputy City Treasurer Harry Brickman, received a serious setback yesterday at the hands of the State Civil Service Commission.

The nation's stock exchanges are moving slowly to emulate the action of the New York Stock Exchange in abolishing the Lincoln's Birthday, Columbus Day and Armistice Day holidays. Although some have announced that they "have no present plans" to follow suit, eventual uniformity seems almost inevitable.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -Emile Littler, London impresario, found a new way last night to stymie first-night balcony hecklers: He threw the balcony open to service men, for free. There wasn't a boo in the Duke of York Theatre when the curtain rang down on "Thirteen for Dinner," a French farce.

Record sales and earnings were made by the Outboard Marine and Manufacturing Company and its subsidiary in the fiscal year ended last September, Joseph G. Rayniak, president, reported in the annual statement yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Grain markets generally had a heavy tone today influenced in part by a sharp setback in soybeans. Wheat and corn had made a partial recovery from the low spots but there was not much snap to buying demand, and offerings tended to increase on moderate rallies.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- Premier Vulko Chervenkov of Bulgaria said tonight his country was ready to re-establish relations with the United States, the Bulgarian news agency reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Eisenhower and the Republican Congressional leaders discussed today -- inconclusively for the most part -- a great complex of national and world issues. It was the second day of the President's exposition of his 1954 legislative program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A Senate Elections subcommittee today recommended that about 30,000 votes cast in the New Mexico Senatorial election last year be thrown out for "lack of secrecy" in the balloting.

MAHWAH, N. J., Dec. 18 (AP) -Miss Josephine Truslow Adams has denied that she ever served as a link between the White House and the former Communist party leader, Earl Browder, as Government witnesses have testified.
The Transit Authority remained silent yesterday on the formula proposed by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. for transit peace.
LONDON, Dec 18 -- Stock market prices moved irregularly today, with a tendency to sag.
Nine bond issues totaling $10,186,000 for new school construction were approved yesterday by the State Board of Regents at a meeting at its headquarters, 2 West Forty-fifth Street.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 19 -- The United Nations Command wrote out today its plea to the United States prisoners of war in Korea who have thus far remained with the Communists.
TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 18 -- A veteran Arizona game warden and a miner were arrested today after Secret Service agents seized $13,200 in contraband gold bars found in the miner's hotel room here.

Rudolph Snider has purchased the four-story twenty-four-family apartment house at 86 Manhattan Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., from the J. M. M. Realty Company. J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the twenty-four-family building at 149 Lincoln Avenue, Newark, for the Lincoln-Delevan Corporation to Jacob and Dora Swerdel.

A double-header at Madison Square Garden pairing New York University with Holy Cross and Manhattan with Texas, Columbia's meeting with undefeated Fordham in the Rams' gymnasium and Seton Hall's clash with St. Francis at South Orange, N. J., will provide the highlights of a busy college basketball program tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 18 -- Dr. Edward G. Bowen, head of the Division of Radiophysics of the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial Research Organization, appears to have established a relationship between days of heavy rainfall and showers of meteors.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it had arranged to sell $16,250,000 par value of a new series of convertible preferred stock to the Kennecott Copper Corporation for investment.

The forty-second annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $2,434.76 yesterday from a trust set up by the late Madge D. Miller of Great Neck, L. I. It also received $1 from Brownie Troop 1-334 in the Bronx. The group, whose average age is 8 1/2, earned the money by selling cookies.
Duke Snider captured the slugging honors in the National League for the 1953 season, according to official averages announced yesterday, but it took four decimal places to determine the winner.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, up 9 to 12 points, after a rather poor start.
The Ralston Purina Company and its domestic subsidiaries had lower sales in the fiscal year ended last September, than the year before, but earnings were larger.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, accused Governor Dewey yesterday of "name-calling in a futile attempt to divert the public's attention from the scandals and corruption within his administration and among his close political associates."

Volume improved on most commodities yesterday on the New York exchanges instead of easing as it normally does prior to the week-end. Burlap registered the highest volume of the year and coffee continued active. Prices moved irregular with hides, coffee, wool and copper mixed; potatoes, burlap, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, lead and tin lower, and cocoa, zinc, sugar and rubber higher.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Gen. Bob Neyland, University of Tennessee athletic director, was quoted today as confirming reports of a proposed split of the Southeastern Conference.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 18 -- William C. De Koning, former American Federation of Labor chieftain on Long Island, and his son and nephew pleaded innocent today in County Court here to three counts of conspiracy and one of grand larceny. Judge Cyril J. Brown released the three in $5,000 bail each.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Sir Winston Churchill's promise of more international conferences, greater secrecy and less news has alarmed Fleet Street, heart of the British newspaper business, and raised anew the issue of the relationship between the press and the Government.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 14 -- Start with a bit of the Klondike, add a touch of Paris and New York, sprinkle liberally with the flavor of old Spain and the mixture comes out present-day Caracas, capital of Venezuela.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The British Transport Commission announced today it was considering increases in passenger fares and freight and dock charges to meet rise in wage and other costs.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Canada will not change her policy of participating in the defense of Western Europe even if the projected European army treaty is abandoned, Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary for External Affairs, said here tonight.

Floyd Patterson, the Brooklyn light heavyweight who was named the rookie of the year recently by the New York Boxing Writers Association, will be inactive for some time, by order of the New York State Athletic Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The danger of a collapse of the military system of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization through a French refusal to join the European Defense Community is much less imminent, Defense Department officials explained today, than has been generally supposed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -Spokesmen for the liquor control authorities of forty-five states today told Congress that the repeal of Prohibition had been partly nullified by high Federal taxes on alcoholic beverages.
A windfall in the form of diamonds worth $5,000 was turned over yesterday to 11-year-old John J. Hayes, whose family needs money for Christmas.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A note by the United Nations Command to General Thimayya, accompanying the Allied letter for the American prisoners, said:
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 18 (AP) --District Judge O. Charles Betts ruled today that a union could not be prohibited from doing business in Texas solely on the ground that it was Communist dominated.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation issued a smog warning tonight over its nationwide network under a new alert system set up after about 4,000 persons died last years as a result of a thick, smothering fog.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, accused the Eisenhower Administration today of attempting to replace Civil Service with the "spoils system." He said he would ask Congress next session to prevent the "wholesale dismantling" of Civil Service and keep it free of politics.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -Robert Aldrich will take on his second Hecht-Lancaster production in February by directing "Vera Cruz," an action melodrama to be filmed in Mexico with Burt Lancaster and Gary Cooper as costars.
