WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Department of Justice cited today five convictions for tax evasion or other tax law violations as evidence of a "stepped up" campaign against tax offenders among racketeers, gamblers and lobbyists:

The two rival longshoremen's unions here stepped up their organizational drives yesterday. They were getting ready for the crucial representation election now scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday. The American Federation of Labor's International Longshoremen's Association charged that the old longshoremen's union was using leaders of the "old mob" in a desperate drive to perpetuate its domination of dock workers.
FORT YATES, N. D., Dec. 18 (UP) -- The ghost of Sitting Bull -including his bones -- arose again today to haunt North and South Dakota.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Federal Judge Winn Knoch entered a formal order today directing the Eastman Kodak Company to turn over to a photographer 8,000 feet of colored movies the company had asserted were indecent.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 18 (UP) -Sweden's Joint Chiefs of Staff pressed their investigation today of a reported supersonic, guided missile sighted over southern Sweden and possibly launched from Soviet Baltic or North Sea rocket bases.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 18 -The 1,000 employes of the New Haven Clock and Watch Company left their posts today to brave the cold and watch the culmination of a spontaneous tribute to the chairman of the corporation.
TOKYO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Japanese Government announced today that the United States would return the Amami Oshima islands [cross on map] to Japan on Christmas Day.
Eddie Robinson, in town yesterday to do some Christmas shopping, paid a social call on the Yankees, who acquired him and Harry Byrd in that thirteen-player trade with the Athletics last Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -The Food and Drug Administration today ordered a hearing to start here Jan. 19 on its proposal to ban three of the most extensively used coal tar dyes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A spokesman for the Argentine Embassy said today that the Buenos Aires decree of Nov. 16 requiring registration of foreign-owned securities of Argentine financial institutions would apply directly or indirectly to everyone receiving interest or dividends from the holdings.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Dec. 18 -Two undaunted mothers dropped their ten children to safety from a porch roof early today as flames rapidly engulfed a two-story frame house.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- A powerful labor union was permanently enjoined today from coercing Westchester County into recognizing it as sole bargaining agent for parkway toll collectors.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (UP) -- La Salle scored its sixth triumph in seven starts by whipping Georgetown, 58 -- 49 tonight, in the second game of a college basketball double-header at Convention Hall before 2,956 fans.
A grand jury investigation into possible fraud, illegal commissions and kickbacks in the administration of union welfare funds was revealed yesterday in General Sessions.
James McCreery Co., the Thirty-fourth Street department store, will close its doors for the last time at 5 P. M. today. It will thus bring an end to a 116-year history of service to shoppers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Oswald Ryan, Republican chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, has asked President Eisenhower to "rotate" the chairmanship, a spokesman for the board said today. Mr. Ryan's present one-year term expires Dec. 31.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 18 -Kentucky's proposed superhighway to form part of a turnpike from the Great Lakes to the Gulf received court authorization today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam said tonight that some committees investigating alleged subversion were "playing into the hands of the Communists."

The Maurice S. Dessau Company, importer of industrial diamonds and manufacturer of diamond cutting equipment, has leased offices in the sixteen-story and penthouse building going up at 589 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of East Forty-eighth Street. The company was founded about 114 years ago and has offices in eightteen cities. Its offices here will be moved from 535 Fifth Avenue.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Cornell trounced Yale, 85 -- 69, in Barton Hall tonight for its second Eastern Inter-collegiate basketball league victory in as many games.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Arthur H. Dean, United States negotiator for a Korean peace conference, told John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today he was convinced the Communists would make the necessary effort to renew the preparatory discussions.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Bob Elliott, 37-year-old third baseman, the National League's most valuable player in 1947, was unconditionally released today by the Chicago White Sox.
The following round-up of new products for Christmas decoration may be of interest to homemakers:
A large selection of new papers and some ingenious containers for packaging gifts make it almost as much fun this year to do up a present as it is to watch the recipient open it.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 18 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Patrolman Elmer Dolan, suspended St. Louis policeman, on perjury charges in its investigation into the missing half of the $600,000 Greenlease ransom.

The thirty-five-year-old Furness Shipbuilding Company, Ltd., at Haverton Hill-on-Tees, England, will set a new high for itself today with the launching of the 32,000-deadweight-ton tanker Melika, the largest vessel ever built at that yard.

The one-millionth ticket to Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park was bought yesterday by Miss Mildred Donnelly, a young Queens secretary who had arrived with two other co-workers in a Manhattan bank.

Moscow newspapers have disclosed that a former secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party who had not been heard from since Stalin's death now holds a big job in the Soviet Far East, according to the Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged for the week ended on Tuesday for the second consecutive week and remained at 110.1, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
A "mechanized" method of loading and unloading airliners has been successfully attempted abroad and will be tested in the United States soon.

ATHENS, Dec. 18 -- Greece stands solidly behind the concept of the European union, Spyros Markezinis, Minister for Economic Planning, assured an audience including the chiefs of mission of several nations here today.
Color television was given an unrestricted go-ahead yesterday when the Federal Communications Commission told networks and stations they might transmit color programs at any time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Brazil received two loans, totaling $22,500,000, from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Fed up with the delay in opening up a larger and more stable market for their industries through existing machinery for European economic cooperation, Norway, Denmark and Sweden are getting ready to do something about it themselves.
The Government may soon buy at least 5,000,000 board feet of lumber in Boston.

A team of three law students from the University of Nebraska won theh fourth annual National Moot Court Competition last night at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

The American Museum of Natural History, as its name implies, deals with nature. And nature, in one sense, includes just about everything available to the five senses. The Museum is not misnamed. Within its halls are skeletons and fossils and trees and animals and fish and birds and weapons and tools and eggs and shells and plants and stars and seeds.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 18 -- Spokesmen for Fitkin Memorial Hospital said here today that a 7-year-old boy had been "restored" to life after his heart had stopped beating for twenty-seven minutes.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 18 -- An Army private, who had waited at home ten months for word of when to report back to his unit in Germany, was back in the Army today -- in the Fort Jay stockade on Governors Island.

Among this week's art exhibitions is one at the Eggleston Gallery (housed in handsome new premises at 969 Madison Avenue) that features the winning canvases and runners-up for the 1953 Emily Lowe Award.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 19 (AP) -- John Landy, the Australian star, failed again today to lower the world mile record when he ran the distance in 4:16.2 in a special race.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The Government opened rebuttal arguments in the du Pont anti-trust trial today by asserting that General Motors Corporation gave United States Rubber Company a tailor-made contract for tires after du Pont family members had invested in the rubber company.

Miss Jane M. Hoey, former director of the Bureau of Public Assistance of the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare, will join the staff of the National Tuberculosis Association on the first of the year.

CARTERET, H. J., Dec. 18 -Rarely have strikers had it as comfortable as those who, for more than a month, have halted production at the Westvaco Chemical Division plant of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 18 -- The equality of the sexes as provided for in the West German Constitution was upheld today by the Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, the Republic's supreme tribunal.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- A strange diplomatic contest has begun within the Atlantic Alliance, mainly between the United States and France. It is dominated by the question of Western European military integration in a particular form and within a fairly limited time.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 18 -- A new report of South Africa's international financial status, covering the first nine months of this year, and a new estimate of the budget surplus show that the country, which apparently is in excellent economic and financial health, is becoming increasingly unattractive to foreign capital.

Ten days after President Eisenhower's address to the United Nations, the Soviet press and radio have still not printed key sections of that speech, in which he proposed an international agency to develop peaceful uses of nuclear energy.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Army newspaper Red Star asserted today that only the Soviet offensives early in 1945 "prevented the defeat of American and British forces and saved France from a renewed Nazi occupation."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- A direct appeal to the people of the United Nations to contribute funds for emergency care for thousands of refugees was made today by Dr. G. J. Van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

Notre Dame's much-discussed "injured player" time-out in its Nov. 21 deadlock with Iowa popped up again yesterday. It was voted college football's "most unusual incident" in an Associated Press poll f sports writer and broadcasters.
The National Association for American Composers and Conductors commemorated the birthday of its founder, Henry Hadley, with a concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

A suspended Manhattan high school teacher who had refused to answer questions concerning alleged membership in the Communist party, declared yesterday that he was taking the advice given to other teachers by Dr. Albert Einstein.

The Cleveland Browns, Detroit Lions and San Francisco Forty Niners posted the best regular season National Football League records and yesterday they filled fifteen of the twenty-two positions on the 1953 United Press two-platoon all-star professional team.
Second sons are traditionally outshone by heirs apparent and the first edition of every book always comes higher on the book stalls even if there be later editions much improved and greatly enlarged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's statements opening the morning and afternoon sessions of today's legislative conference and summarizing the day's proceedings:
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The Warsaw radio reported today that all Polish Roman Catholic Bishops had taken an oath of loyalty to the Communist state in a special ceremony in Warsaw.

Steel-making operations in the Pittsburgh, Chicago, Cleveland and possibly other major production areas are being curtailed for the next two weeks. In some cases an easing of demand for steel is cited as the reason for the cutbacks; in others, producers say they are merely taking advantage of the Christmas holiday period to make alterations and repairs.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 18 -Regular grade gasoline will be reduced from 26.4 to 18.9 cents a gallon at service stations here and in near-by Linden tomorrow in the opening of an all-out price war, the Union County Gasoline Retailers Association announced today.

It will be a great misfortune if the revelation of one case in which an unscrupulous person trafficked in used clothing that was donated for shipment to Korea should cause any misunderstanding or mistrust about gifts for Korea as a whole. Actually, there are quite a number of fine and entirely honorable organizations in the field and their operations have always been fully open to inspection.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Eisenhower said today that Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, had made "certain proposals for an agricultural program" after the present law expired next year.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 18 -- In a furious last-minute surge, the Rutgers basketball team defeated Princeton, 74 -- 72, tonight. Rutgers now has a 4-0 record.

" Bait" advertising was assailed yesterday by a spokesman for the National Better Business Bureau as a practice of "unscrupulous firms." He spoke at the final session of the Eastern Regional Roundup Conference held in the Roosevelt Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A "very good year" of business is in prospect for 1954, Lothair Teetor Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Domestic Affairs, assured a news conference here today.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The British Government announced with "great regret" today that the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland had taken an oath of allegiance to the Communist Government. This news was conveyed to the House of Commons during a debate on a motion protesting against the persecution of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland.

GEORGE WASHINGTON, Herman Melville, Emily Dickinson, Benjamin Franklin and Abraham Lincoln did not go to college and they did well in life; Thomas Jefferson, Daniel Webster, Nathaniel Hawthorne, Eudora Welty, T. S. Eliot, the Roosevelts and Woodrow Wilson did go to college and also have done all right. What does this prove about the values of American university training?

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 18 -- The chairman of the university and scientific organization supporting the South African Nationalists' idea of apartheid or racial separation has declared that the age of white domination is over.
NEWARK, Dec. 18 -- Negotiations between the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and 1,800 striking maintenance workers broke off today for the second time in the month-old work stoppage.
James Reston's article in your Dec. 9 issue covered by the headline "John Paton Davies' Motives Mystery in the 'Tawny Pipit' Case" arouses me to make these comments.
OGDEN, Utah, Dec. 18 (UP) -An Air Force B-29, its pilot apparently confused by heavy smog, crashed and burned today when it landed by mistake at Ogden Municipal Airport.

An investing client of M. L. Leepson, attorney, has purchased the six-story apartment house for sixty-eight families on plot 150 by 100 feet at 666 East 233d Street, in the Bronx, from Fischer-Landis, operators, who bought the building recently. The property contains eight stores and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $230,000. Mrs. Anne Inselstein was the broker.

Billy Graham gave away more than ten pounds to Paddy Young in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden last night, and then proceeded to hand a decisive defeat to the Greenwich Village middleweight. Giving an exhibition of boxing skill that won for him many rounds of applause, Graham earned a unanimous decision before 5,280 spectators.

The feast of St. Lucy, which traditionally opens Sweden's holiday season, was celebrated yesterday by more than 100 young Scandinavians at a party at the AmericanScandinavian Foundation, 127 East Seventy-third Street.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- The State Thruway Authority announced today that it would not award any contracts for construction along the disputed Yonkers section of the cross-state expressway until a suit pending in State Supreme Court had been settled.

Two new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Little Carnegie is "Heidi," with Elsbeth Sigmund in the title role and featuring Heinrich Gretler and Thomas Klameth. Elsie Attenhofer, Margrit Rainer, Fred Tanner and Isa Gunther head the supporting cast.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 18 -Because of difficulties encountered in getting accurate information from nonresident owners of capital in Argentina, representatives of foreign banks have suggested to the Argentine Central Bank that the deadline on its foreign capital census be extended.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- More than half of Italy's 50,000 prison inmates will be set free between Monday and Christmas under a sweeping amnesty bill passed by the Chamber of Deputies today. Antonio Azara, Minister of Justice, described it as the most liberal amnesty in Italian history.

The Hajoca Corporation, manufacturers of plumbing, heating and industrial supplies, has conditionally accepted an offer from the Grinnell Corporation of Providence, R. I., to buy 20,000 shares of Hajoca common stock at $40 a share.

A line of terramycin animal health products, to be sold over the counter in drug stores and heavily advertised to the consumer, will be marketed by Charles Pfizer Co. beginning Jan. 5. Although the remedies will be marketed nationally (they are recommended for treatment of common infections of pets as well as livestock) they will be promoted heaviest in thirteen Farm Belt states.
Although volume was down and much of the business was ascribed to week-end "evening up," the undertone on the New York Stock Exchange was firm yesterday.

BRISBANE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas blasted out straight-set victories over Belgium today to give the United States a 4-1 victory in the interzone Davis Cup final and the right to meet Australia in the challenge round.

The four investment banking houses that made commitment on Thursday to buy $99,800,000 of revenue bonds of the Mackinac Bridge Authority are forming a nation-wide sub-underwriting syndicate to distribute the issue.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 18 -- The Communist guerrillas are increasing their activities in Central Johore State, the government of Malaya announced in Kuala Lumpur, federal capital, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered today an investigation to determine whether the consolidation of Braniff and Continental Airlines would be in the public interest.
Kermit Bloomgarden is back from the West Coast with the news that Albert and Frances Hackett have agreed to dramatize "Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl."

Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, First Army commander, presented yesterday at Governors Island decorations to two officers and an enlisted man stationed there. A Bronze Star medal went to Sgt. 1/c Daniel Hyte and Oak Leaf Clusters for such medals to Lieut. Col. T. H. Metz and Lieut. Col. Arthur E. Cotter.
AMES, Iowa, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Emmett R. (Abe) Stuber, 50, resigned today as head coach of football at Iowa State College. His 1953 team won two games while losing seven.

Negotiators who announced settlement of the dispute between the nation's railroads and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen say that the agreement marks the first major railroad dispute that has been settled by direct negotiations since 1948. It is disconcerting to learn that collective bargaining has been a failure so long on the railroads.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Dr. Howard R. Anderson, chief for social sciences in the Division of Higher Education of the United States Office of Education, has been appointed dean of the University of Rochester's School of Liberal and Applied Studies.

The state investigation into the management of the welfare fund of Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., discloses a shocking state of affairs. Large sums of money have been siphoned off for excessive commissions, fees and administrative expenses.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that a bill was being prepared for Congress that would end gift-tax exemptions for those who supported educational institutions that employed "Fifth Amendment Communists.''
New York's temperature dipped to 14.4 degrees yesterday -- the coldest day of the year -so chilly, in fact, that it froze the midtown traffic lights.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- New York State criticized today the Pennsylvania Railroad's proposal to the Interstate Commerce Commission for the reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road.
Dr. Luther H. Gulick announced yesterday that, upon assuming office as City Administrator on Jan. 1, he would appoint Charles F. Preusse and Dr. John V. Connorton as Deputy City Administrators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -Gov. Edward F. Arn of Kansas urged Congress today to "act at once" to strip the Federal Power Commission of authority to regulate producers' sales of natural gas for interstate movement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, called today for a modernized United States merchant marine to protect the nation's security and handle a "substantial portion" of overseas trade.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- Both major political parties are making their opening moves of the 1954 campaign in Massachusetts.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Dec. 19 -Edward M. O'Gorman Jr., Orange County's special county judge, took his oath of office in the polio ward at St. Luke's Hospital here today. Judge O'Gorman, a Republican, was stricken with polio two months before his election, and now spends almost twelve hours a day in an iron lung.
ON his way to areas of sunshine and mild climate or brisk winds and snow sports, the winter vacationist will find better highways and accommodations than ever before.

IN these two volumes of letters, passages from diaries and extracts from legal testimony, the Wright brothers present a complete history of the way they invented the first practical airplane and an account of the resistance that had to be overcome when they tried to dispose of their invention to governments. The record only partially conforms with the familiar pattern of penury and hardship that inventors have endured.

Brooklyn College's basketball team scored its fifth victory in eight starts last night, defeating Hunter College, 78---66, on the victor's court. Artie Cohen led the I.ingsmen with 19 points and Larry Joseph had 23 for the losers.

IN this, the eighth in her series of musical biographies for younger children. Opal Wheeler is writing the story in two parts, as she did with Chopin. Only volume one has been published. By stopping the narrative with the death of Tchaikowsky's mother.

Beverley Feigelman triumphed in a field of thirty-six yesterday in the twenty-second annual Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association Christmas tournament. Miss Feigelman, 21, a senior at Hunter College, scored 3 -- 0 in the preliminaries, 4 -- 1 in the semi-finals and 7 -- 1 in the finals.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Indications that the Government of Premier Giuseppe Pella in Italy is slowly losing strength have caused the United States Government to consider seriously the effects of an alternative governing coalition in Italy.

Paul Krichell, whose scouting discoveries included Lou Gehrig and many other famous Yankee stars, was named yesterday as the 1954 recipient of the Bill Slocum Memorial Award for long and meritorious service to baseball.

YEAR after year in our troubled postwar world a sense of irony and deception seems to linger in the wings of our Christmas celebrations. Here is the feast of little things -- of families round their own firesides, of little gifts opened by the children, of small gatherings of friends coming together for private happiness, of individual men and women setting out to worship the infant Prince of Peace.

THE British capacity for making a point humorously and without ranting is nicely illustrated in Ann Bullingham's "Penelope." The notion of presenting the merits and defects of the English rural schools entirely through the eyes of a 5-year-old girl may not sound particularly felicitous, but Miss Bullingham has fashioned out of it a delightful story.
The Trapp Family Singers returned to town yesterday with their annual Christmas program. They performed it in the late afternoon at Town Hall and they will give it there again at 3 P. M. today.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- France's new President when he takes office will be faced with three tremendous problems which have been growing steadily more critical throughout the last two years. The gravest part of this French crisis is that it falls upon three fronts at once.
Mocking birds and cardinals have been moving north in increasing numbers during the last twenty years because conservationists say "of crowded living conditions" for birds in the South.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 19 -- ''Walk, do not trot -- $5 fine" once were the painted signs on wooden covered bridges all over Indiana.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 -- One of the biggest public power operations in America -- the Bonneville power administration of the Pacific Northwest -- is about to lose its top man, Dr. Paul J. Raver.

OLD Man River just keeps rolling along and so do books on the subject. The quality of the steady flow of river prose is extremely variable, however, and it is a joyous occasion when one picks up a book like this one which is completely free of phony romanticism, fake enthusiasm and dialect jokes.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 19 -- Dr. Robert A. Millikan, Nobel Prize physicist and authority on cosmic rays, died today at his home. He was 85 years old.

ROME, Dec. 19 -- The Vatican through its newspaper L'Osservatore Romano today confessed itself unable to confirm or deny a report that Polish bishops had taken an oath of faithfulness to the Polish State.

In "The Queen's Job -- and the Queen" (Nov. 22) Drew Middleton is guilty of an error truly egregious for a correspondent of his experience and brilliance. "The Queen will ride out to see the brigade of guards (sic) trooping the colors," he writes.

Just at the time when there is unusual tension between India and Pakistan and India and the United States over the question of our military assistance there comes the good word that a vital railway link between the two countries on the Asian subcontinent has been restored.

APPROPRIATELY for Christmas, The Cloisters yesterday put on view for the first time three recently acquired life-sized statues of Balthasar, Melchior and Caspar. These fifteenth-century German figures have been installed with a full-size photograph of the Virgin and Child whom they originally adored in the convent of Lichtenthal.

Two Hunter College seniors, Carolyn Sara Nussbaum and Susi Deborah Hillburn, have won $300 scholarships toward graduate work. The grants, by the trustees of the college's Graduate Scholarship Fund, were announced yesterday by Prof. Harry L. Levy, chairman of the fund.
This port got its first look at the new Great Lakes-type tanker Chicago Socony last week. The vessel made her initial call here after the close of normal operations on the lakes.

TORONTO, Dec. 19 -- Don Stewart drove an attempted clearance by Goalie Johnny Bower into an open net late in the third period tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a penalty-packed 3-2 victory over the Rangers.

THE railroad, like the river, has played an important role in American folklore. It gave us the exploits of Vanderbilt, Harriman, Jim Hill -- figures now legendary. It provided races against time and rivals, battles -- like those between wagoner and railroader, and the North and South Irish -- now part of the tradition of frontier violence.
Two selected groups of intellectually gifted children from different parts of Manhattan have begun a sociological experiment designed to demonstrate that color is no bar to brotherhood.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- H. Glenn Weber, who was chairman of the Missouri delegation to the Republican National Convention last year, said tonight he was quitting the Republican party because of his "keen disappointment" with the Eisenhower Administration.

THE current deer season seems to have revived the always slumbering controversy concerning the value of the "buck only" regulation both as a conservation measure and as a means of increasing hunter safety.

Fordham outshot, outran and outmaneuvered Columbia in a close-to-the-vest tactical battle last night to keep its basketball slate unsullied. The sixth straight victory of the Rams, accomplished by a 51-24 score, was witnessed by 3,000 spectators at the Fordham Gymnasium and by a Channel 11 television audience.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States Maritime Service training station at Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, largest of the institutions set up by the Government to train personnel for its wartime merchant marine, will close down early next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec., 19 -- The Eisenhower Administration next week will finish polishing a housing program providing for the gradual withdrawal of the Government from the housing field.

IT is unusual for a working parish priest to produce a novel: in this case, a first one of considerable quality. Abbe Daniel Pezeril, who appears to have been well served by his translator, A. Gordon Smith, has a style of grace and skill, together with warmth of spirit and psychological insight.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it would be sponsor at the coming session of the Legislature for a bill for the nonpartisan election of judges in New York City.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The West German Government announced today that victims of Nazi persecution living abroad would be permitted to withdraw the equivalent of 500 Deutsche marks ($119) a month in restitution payments from Germany.
There is something of a rush -- albeit restrained in the traditional British manner -- to sign up makers of American soft drinks with big British brewers, bottlers and other distributors.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Carl Braun scored with a leaping one- hander as the final buzzer sounded tonight, enabling the New York Knickerbockers to defeat the Baltimore Bullets, 65 -- 63, in a National Basketball Association game.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A German war veteran who makes $15 a week as a mechanic gave Christmas presents today to five hospitalized soldiers, four Americans and a Canadian.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Senate investigators disclosed today that they would question Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, in New York next Tuesday about the Harry Dexter White spy case.

THIS is the fourth of five novels, which, under the title "Immortal Memory," will recreate the life of Robert Burns. The author, brought up as a modern Scottish peasant, is piously devoted to Burns and his memory.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 11 -- There is a connection between the 1952 United States airlift of Moslem pilgrims to Mecca and a solution to Beirut's almost unbelievable traffic congestion. For Beirut will soon have a new bus and taxi terminal to be built with funds paid by the pilgrims for their air transport from Beirut to the Holy City.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 19 -- Pakistan told the Soviet Union today she would go her own sovereign way regardless of foreign opposition to her plans for a military alliance with the United States.

THEY gave Robert Lewis one of the choice tables up front in Sardi's when he dropped in there one evening last week for a drink. It was a form of recognition that, as the director of a colossal success, "The Teahouse of the August Moon." Lewis currently belongs among the elite of the theatre.

Holy Cross, which ranks among the top collegiate basketball teams in the East, handed New York University its first setback of the campaign last night at Madison Square Garden. Here and there the Violets caused the visiting Crusaders some anguish, but there was no stopping the Worcester quintet, which sped to a 78-66 victory.

America's largest body of yachtsmen, the United States Power Squadrons, is going into the Midwest to pick its next chief commander. According to the deliberations of the nominating committee, a manufacturer and civic-minded prominent citizen of Findlay, Ohio, Kenneth B. Champ, has been named to succeed Chief Commander Herbert R. Prior of New York and Glen Rock, N. J.

ALTHOUGH Sidney Howard has been dead for a little more than fourteen years, one of his plays has blown the first breath of life into a new theatre organization. The play is "Madam, Will You Walk," a witty pipe-dream about worldly matters.
The community experience program set up two years ago by the Hunter College Department of Education in cooperation with social agencies has had gratifying results.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 19 -- Swift Sword, a 2-year-old bay colt who doesn't seem to mind a few extra pounds, and Jockey Sammy Boulmetis teamed up again today in the $5,000 Coral Gables Purse at Tropical Park and won their third straight race of the meet.

SAIGON, Dec. 19 -- The seventh anniversary, today, of the war in Indo-China found the opposing forces engaged in a struggle that continues to be almost as fluid and uncertain as it was when it started.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla. -- The only place in Florida and possibly in the entire country where winter polo is played is at the Gulf Stream Polo Club, a mile and a half north of Delray Beach on State Road A1A. The season starts late in December, with games three times a week through April.

" Which ship is which pip," long a problem of steamship radar operation where the specific identification of vessels appearing on radarscopes is necessary for safe maneuvering, is now in the process of solution.
More than 11,000 new apartments will become available to New Yorkers within the next two and one-half years in public housing projects being developed on vacant or nearly vacant land.

The theme of Columbia University's bicentennial celebration next year -- "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof" -- was the subject of discussion on the New York Times Youth Forum last night.
RAIL travel to winter resorts got under way in earnest last week when the special seasonal schedules between New York and Florida went into effect.

The fiftieth anniversary of the first powered flight under man's control was celebrated at Kitty Hawk, N. C., this week at the spot near Kill Devil Hill where the two Ohio bicycle manufacturers, Orville and Wilbur Wright, achieved man's dream of travel through the air.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Sharp criticisms of British aircraft manufacture were expressed today by a representative of British European Airways. The company, a major buyer of British planes, carries more passengers than any airline outside the United States.

In the article by Albert H. Morehead -- "Is It Chance? Is It Gambling?" (Nov. 29) -- on games of chance or skill, he writes: "Sometimes the element of skill becomes so heavily predominant that it is beyond human capabilities, whereupon the game or competition paradoxically becomes a matter of chance.

An old soldier who knows what it is like to spend Christmas in uniform sent Yuletide greetings yesterday to all the men and women in the nation's armed forces at home and abroad.

I have read Dr. Daniel A. Poling's letter in your Dec. 13 issue several times and I am still unable to discover wherein I was guilty of inaccuracies in my article, "Guilt -- and Innocence -- by Association" (Nov. 8).

In his article "Tourist Nomura" (Nov. 29) Stewart Bronfeld writes: "He (Admiral Nomura) hasn't eaten at the only Japanese restaurant in New York. He prefers taking his meals at drug stores, because, he says, it is more interesting and the waitresses are pretty."

IN his irritating introduction to this anthology, Editor Milton Lesser announces that "science fiction has come of age" and cites recent TV and Hollywood aberrations to prove it. Of greater concern to the potential buyer of this exorbitantly priced volume is the fact that Lesser further supports his meaningless contention with a collection whose over-all merit is dubious indeed.
President Eisenhower extended his warmest Christmas greeting yesterday to all the men in the American merchant marine.

TORONTO -- Some 100,000 devotees of the ungentle art of skiing scattered across the Province of Ontario would settle for just one thing from Santa this year -- more snow. For the past four years, most of the thickly populated southern portion of the province has experienced unusually mild winters.

THE two books by W. W. Rostow and Maurice Hindus have little in common except the conclusion that the Soviet rulers are not likely to risk a major war now. The "Kremlin leaders," declares Mr. Hindus, "do not want war, cannot afford it, and can only dread it."
In a mood that mingled pleasure and sorrow, Grover A. Whalen yesterday ended thirty-five years as official greeter for the City of New York.
The French liner Flandre docked here yesterday twelve hours late after battling violent seas with fifty-foot waves and winds up to 120 miles an hour.
The Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants had schedule announcements yesterday.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Silver and blue Christmas trees and festoons of evergreens formed a holiday background in the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here tonight for the annual Assembly Ball.

HARTFORD, Dec. 19 -- Warfare within the Republican party in Connecticut, which has had intermittent outbreaks in the three years since Gov. John Davis Lodge began his four-year term, has flared again.

The frankincense and myrrh laid before the Christ Child 1,953 years ago were as precious as the gold that the Magi included in the first Christmas present, or almost so. Today, however, they are ordinary items of commerce, worth 20 to 30 cents a pound, or about 1/2000th the value of gold.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States Armed Services, even at this early stage are discussing plans to put the nation's best foot forward in the 1956 Olympic games.

IN the past month two publications have come to our desk of a type which, frankly, we never expected to see. One was prepared by the early childhood staff of the Campus Elementary School, State Teachers College, New Paltz, N. Y., the other by a parent-teacher association committee in cooperation with the Parent Education Office of the Board of Education, Rochester, N. Y. Both are "guides" for celebrating Christmas happily within the family.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Unbeaten Duquesne, one of the nation's leading basketball teams, rallied in the final two minutes tonight to defeat the University of Toledo, 60 -- 57, before an estimated crowd of 5,500.

BUFFALO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Western Kentucky, tenth ranked among the nation's college basketball teams, survived a second-half scare to retain its unbeaten record with an 82 -- 76 triumph over St. Bonaventure tonight in Memorial Auditorium.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A broiling sun and 101-degree heat ruined John Landy's chances for a four-minute mile today and postponed his pursuit of the elusive time target for several weeks.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 11 -- Saudi Arabia, the ancient "Island of the Arabs," is rapidly losing her immunity to divisive foreign propaganda with the rise of a rootless industrial proletariat in the oil fields.

In the charges against the former Soviet secret police chief Laurenti P. Beria, published in Moscow last week, there seems apparent the same retroactive rewriting of history and biography that characterized the great purge trials of the Nineteen Thirties.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Governor Dewey is planning to balance the 1954-55 state budget without increasing the personal income tax rate. The Governor's advisers reported today that he believed he could effect sufficient economies in operations to present a balanced budget despite the tightest fiscal problem he has faced in his eleven years in office.

The ragged appearance of financial markets last week seemed to indicate that investors were not doing as much Christmas buying of securities as might be expected. Selling and other portfolio adjustments created a lower trend during the early sessions.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Christmas Club savings in Pennsylvania banks soared to $144,854,762 this year, highest in the forty-three-year history of such deposits. A record 1,578,554 Pennsylvanians shared in the distribution of the funds, which were 10 per cent higher than a year ago and nearly 35 per cent higher than in 1951.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Charles Clore, a stock market operator who recently made London headlines with an old-fashioned bull-bites-bear scramble for control of London's swankest hotels, defended himself today against the charge that he is a here speculator.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Head coaches of both the North and South wore satisfied smiles tonight after a first look at the material assembled for the Shrine's collegiate all-star football game Christmas night in the Orange Bowl.

The Blue Jay Class of 13 1/2-foot sloops, which the Larchmont Yacht Club among others uses for junior sailing, is being expanded. Sparkman Stephens, Inc., designer of the vessel, reports that Larchmont has ordered six of them to bring its fleet to nineteen and that the Black Rock Yacht Club of Bridgeport, Conn., is building seven.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 19 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi signed a decree today dissolving the Iranian Parliament and authorizing immediate elections.

Living away from the big city is no longer a handicap for the shopper. Chances are that Mrs. Suburbia can hop into the family car and fill her shopping needs more quickly and more comfortably than can her city cousin.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 19 -- The Mississippi Legislature will have to work three days next week to put finishing touches on its program of public school equalization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A transitional farm plan, designed to start farmers helping themselves and seeking fewer helpings from the Federal table, appears to be the Administration's program for the coming session of Congress.

A series of dinners and musical events will be held this month and next for the twelfth annual campaign of the American Fund for Israel, which maintains educational, cultural and welfare institutions in Israel.

WHAT is meant by "form" in music? Does it mean "binary" or "ternary" structure, exposition, development, recapitulation, and the rest of the rigmarole? Or does it mean the method by which a structure grows from and gives final shape to an initial idea, one which, germinating according to inherent laws of its being, dictates its own inevitable process of development?

A PHOTOFLASH contest for pictures of people and pets is announced by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for March, April and May, 1954. The contest will close at midnight, May 31. The pictures must have been made with Westinghouse flash bulbs.

THE truth that is brought to us by reading or by direct personal encounter has an immediate personal reference: the reader or the listener is called upon to reconstruct, as he reads or listens, the intellectual process that the speaker or the writer has already completed.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I.. Dec. 19 -- Hermann (Gus) Schwab and Johnny Humes of the home club, led the way into the semi-final round of the seventh annual invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 19 (UP) -- Gale Parker rounded out a triple today when he helped set a new track record for a mile and one-sixteenth aboard Mrs. H. D. Menken's Bright Fate in the Berryville Purse.

As the weather turned colder toward the end of the week retail business improved. However, it was not quite able to overcome the obstacle of a poor Monday, resulting from rainy and windy weather, and the department store totals for the week are expected to dip below the same week of last year by about 2 to 3 per cent.

A 15-year-old Bronx boy was fatally wounded last night by what the police believe was a "zip gun." Only a few hours earlier zip guns which are homemade weapons, had been the subject of a special conference on ways to combat them.

FOR years Louise Townsend Nicholl's poetry has won praise from critics of every school. David Daiches expressed the consensus when he wrote of "a purity of contemplation perfectly captured in the quiet run of the verse and the organization of the imagery."

A FEW weeks ago Mr. Winston Churchill had a birthday, and a poetic competition was held in England to celebrate the occasion. I do not think that anybody will be surprised to learn that none of the entries was of the slightest poetic merit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Congress began backing gingerly this week into an issue it has refused resolutely for years to face head-on -- getting itself a pay increase.
WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 19 -The lure of a good fire has proved irresistible to this community's policemen, and the volunteer firefighters charge this is sometimes more of a hindrance than a help.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Eisenhower ended three days of consultations with his Congressional leaders today and proclaimed general Republican agreement on a legislative program that included harder action against subversives in the Government and outside it.
The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation spent $865,000 for medical education during the last year, John M. Russell, executive director, declared in the fund's annual report issued yeesterday.

Hundreds of Christmas shoppers were driven to the street yesterday by a four-alarm fire that swept across the roofs of four adjoining buildings near the intersection of Westchester Avenue, East 165th Street and Fox Street in the Bronx.
Billy Graham, the 31-year-old East Side welterweight, may now be added to the list of outstanding contenders for Carl (Bobo) Olson's world middleweight boxing championship.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -Two top Government officials headed for the Far East today in hopes of halting South Korean threats to wreck the uneasy truce.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Red China announced today the formation of a five-county "Tibetan Autonomous Government" in Western China "under the leadership of the Communist party of China and the People's Government of a higher level."

An increase in the fare of eight private bus lines in the city from 10 cents to 12 or 13 cents was reported yesterday as being strongly indicated in information provided the Board of Estimate by the city's Transit Advisory Commission.

FRIENDS and admirers of Joshua Logan were delighted to learn last week that the celebrated director-author-producer had returned from Louisiana and was nicely on the mend following his recent illness. They should be further cheered this morning with the news that in about a month's time Mr. Logan's doctors are likely to permit him to begin working again.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)--About five of every six taxpayers will wind up with a net gain as a result of two big tax changes taking effect Jan. 1, a survey showed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission disclosed today that it was investigating advertising alleged to be false in the hospitalization, health and accident insurance fields.

NUKUALOFA, Tonga Islands, Sunday, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Four nose-flutists gently awoke Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh with their music today, for the second and last day of the royal visit here.

TODAY'S trend toward informality has led to the increased popularity of buffet service at which many more individuals can be entertained than at a formal seated dinner. Buffet service requires large bowls and other containers. A number of new ones useful during the holiday season are pictured here.

CEDAR KEY, Fla. -- State Route 24 cuts off at a sharp right angle from U. S. 19 about fifty miles north of Homosassa, on Florida's west coast, and leads direct over a short wooden bridge to the small off-shore island called Cedar Key. As one approaches the Key, fish houses flank the road.

THE game of touch-past is ever an exhilarating and reassuring one. To know a man who as a child was kissed by Swinburne takes one magically back through a perspective of handshakes to Chaucer himself. Contracting time, the world becomes cozier.

ARMONK, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Estate and home owners in this central Westchester hamlet have won a temporary victory in a fight against development of a multi-million-dollar office building center by a subsidiary of the City Investing Company of New York.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- A $4,000,000 grade crossing elimination job will be started here in a few days. It will be the largest ever undertaken in Westchester County and will give a new face to this village of 6,000.

A program in teacher education designed to help meet the present national teacher shortage -- expected to become even more critical during the next ten years -- has been established at Northwestern University. The program will be offered for the first time next fall by the School of Education, in cooperation with the Graduate School.

IN THE last few seasons two young choral ensembles have been gaining musical laurels -- the Primavera Singers of the New York Pro Musica Antiqua, under Noah Greenberg, and the Concert Choir, led by Margaret Hillis. Both have made outstanding contributions to the 1953 crop of Christmas recordings.

JACKSONVILLE -- Florida's 1,500 named rivers and streams and its 30,000 named lakes are probably less well known to its millions of tourists than the more than 2,000 miles of shore line on ocean and gulf, yet nearly 100,000 out-of-state visitors took out licenses last year to fish in these waters.

IN twenty-one brief chapters, featuring for the most part historical or legendary figures, May McNeer presents the vast panorama of Mexican life, past and present. The exotic contrasts of Mexico's geography, the drama and excitement of her tempestuous history, the colorful and the bizarre in her civilization -- all are suggested in the events and characters chosen for inclusion.

This Christmas week, amid the canals and temples of Bangkok in the far-off land of "The King and I," some 800 brown-skinned children will go to a plain, three-story, tile-roofed building on Sathorn Road to receive medical care.
Few, if any, industries are more competitive than the manufacture and distribution of toothpaste, of which $104,000,000 worth was sold at wholesale last year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The labor dispute between the country's railroads and the fifteen brotherhoods of non-operating employes appeared today headed for a review by a Presidential fact-finding board soon after the start of the new year.

THE author of "Platoon" obviously has chosen his words so that the reader never really knows if the forty men in this infantry platoon are American or British, if the story occurs in World War I, II or Korea.

A PECULIARLY amorphous book is Bertita Harding's "Magic Fire" which combines without fusing the methods of biography and fiction. The life of Richard Wagner lends itself admirably to dramatic narrative, a form which Mrs. Harding has employed with verve in her "Phantom Crown" and "Amazon Throne," accounts of stormy figures and of equally stormy history.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 19 (UP) -The Calumet Farm's Mark-Ye-Well, seeking to become the first horse ever to win the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap two years in a row, today for the second straight year drew the top weight of 130 pounds for the mile-and-a-quarter classic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -A key Administration policy maker said today that this country probably must carry its multibillion stock of farm surpluses for several years to protect both world and domestic farm prices.

DENVER, Colo. -- The hornets are nesting higher and the aspen bark is thicker, which means deep snow soon -- or such is the ardent hope of Rocky Mountain skiers starting what they believe will be the biggest season in the ski history of this spectacular region.
THIS department's recent "Best" list in THE BOOK REVIEW was restricted to new novels. This week we'll look at some of the high points in other fields of the year's criminous publishing.

TRENTON, Dec. 19 -- The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene Monday its special session begun Dec. 4. High on the agenda will be a measure designed to assure this state of enough potable water for the next fifty years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon returned to Washington this week, his prestige considerably enhanced by his goodwill globe-trotting.

Dock workers in the Port of New York face a crucial choice between two feuding unions in a representation election Tuesday and Wednesday. Whether the result of the balloting will bring peace and stability along the waterfront remains in doubt.

MISS CARRIE, the protagonist of this short novel, lives in her old family house and carries on in the genteel style of better days. Her "guests" are never allowed to forget that she is a Kentucky lady and that they are privileged to live under her roof.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Officials of the Foreign Operations Administration are reviewing Western "strategic" restrictions on trade with the Soviet bloc.

MORE emotionally powerful than spiritually convincing, Beatrix Beck's novel of a religious conversion is a distinguished book. The author, it is worth noting, was Andre Gide's last secretary -- and had been encouraged by him for some time to go on to a writing career.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 8 -- Because "these hotels and clubs indulge in color discrimination with remarkable impunity," the Basutoland Native African Congress has protested to the Basutoland Liquor Licensing Board against the renewal of ten existing liquor licenses in this British-protected territory.

FEW writers have as thorough a knowledge of the Irish red setter as Jim Kjelgaard, coupled with deep love, understanding and admiration. Young readers who enjoyed his earlier yarns about the champion Big Red and his son Mike will need no urging to turn to this truly great story about still another son of the champion setter.

A DELIGHTFUL children's program -- imaginative, gay and wholesome -- is to be found weekday afternoons at 4:45 P. M. over the local DuMont station, WABD. It is called "The Adventures of Danny Dee" and its current Christmas story is as charming a fantasy as there is on the dial.

SET in Minnesota, "Homecoming" is, basically, an account of a Norwegian-American girl who learned to evaluate her European background. The pattern is a familiar one, as any patient novel-reader knows. But the author has handled it with depth and genuine perception, and given it the color of reality observed from the inside.
ATLANTA, Dec. 19 -- A broad program in engineering research activities to utilize the state's natural resources more fully is under way in Georgia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- One of the better known jibes at the provincial New Yorker is a map of the United States that scarcely concedes the existence of land west of the Hudson.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 19 -- An informed diplomat said today that the negotiations for a five-power conference on the Trieste dispute seemed to have become a simple but formidable question of "face."

IMPRESARIO EXTRAORDINARY, in capital letters. is what the jacket blurb called S. Hurok. It is not really an exaggeration. There is scarcely a dancer or company of note that has not come pirouetting unto his ample bosom at one time or another, and it can truthfully be said that ballet in America is a history of Mr. Hurok's interest therein.

Secretary of State Dulles may not have chosen the proper time, the proper place and the proper manner when he lectured the prospective European Defense Community nations in Paris on their failure to ratify the treaty their ministers signed more than a year and a half ago. There is always a question as to what sort of countenance the United States should turn toward the world.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 19 -Tax officials in some fifteen Rhode Island communities have started a search for a uniform method of assessing tangible personal property taxes on fishing boats and pleasure craft.

President Eisenhower's order abolishing the "restricted" category of classified Government documents went into effect this week. A Washington report to this newspaper of the problems that have now arisen from this order gives an illuminating insight into the way in which the mass of classified material has increased.
May I make some comment on the subject of box-office attendants in two capacities -- first, as a theatregoer, and secondly, as a box-office attendant in Toronto?

NOTHING that had happened in the past few hours could equal the terror of floating through a red haze down into the unknown. Earlier that day Johnny Wild and Danny Black, R. A. F. pilots, had been shot down off the Dutch coast.

ONE of the showiest and most colorful flowers that can be grown in the house is the amaryllis. In brilliant shades of red, pink and white (some solid colors, some two-toned) it stands out in any room. It is not difficult to grow and can be brought into bloom for many years to come.

ANY mother suddenly bedridden for a day could put Garel Clark's "Cook-A-Meal Cook Book" into her 12-year-old daughter's hands and drop off to rest in the happy knowledge that her family would eat well that night.

MIAMI BEACH -- They keep building new hotels and north of this city motels rise overnight and still, judging from advance reservations for the coming season, there are people to fill them. Perhaps the question is not so much how can this strictly resort city keep on expanding as where do all the visitors come from?
Not only has the New York Stock Exchange devised a periodical-payment plan for selling stocks in pieces as small as $40; it also is teaching its members how to use it.

Uncertain that a prospective cover for the January issue of its official publication would be approved by the Post Office, the American Museum of Natural History has voluntarily "modified" it, it became known yesterday.

REPORTS from the nation's snowbelts indicate that the 1953-54 winter sports season should be one of the best in years. Not since the mid-Nineteen Thirties, when snow trains hauled record crowds to the open slopes, has the outlook been as promising as for the current campaign. From east to west expansion has been on a large scale. New lifts and new areas continue to mushroom in all sections.
A cogent influence of religion upon the objectives of the United Nations was brought out yesterday morning in a sermon by Rabbi David B. Kahane at the East Fifty-first Street Synagogue.

PRIVATE collections are a convenient and provocative clue to a community's interest in art. The proof of both the newness of cultural awareness and of the vitality of that interest in the Southwest lies in the fact that, on the one hand, there are very few "important" collections and, on the other, that the ones which do exist reflect a personal and lively taste, rather than blind following of accepted and standardized collecting.

NEXT Sunday evening the Ballet Theatre will give its only Manhattan performance of the season for the benefit of the Ballet Theatre Foundation's anniversary fund drive. The program will include the stage premiere of Eugene Loring's ballet, "The Capital of the World," produced first on the Ford Foundation's TV Omnibus program two weeks ago. The music is by George Antheil and the scenery for the stage production, unlike that for TV, is by Esteban Frances.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 19 -California football writers got their first view of Michigan State's Rose Bowl team in action today and received confirmation of all they had heard about the Spartans.

THE death in Paris last month of the Cuban painter Francis Picabia occurred long after the demise of Dada in which he was once a leading spirit. And now, at the Rose Fried Gallery, there is to be found a small selection of his paintings, shown, suitably enough, with some bizarre artifacts by Marcel Duchamp, his onetime collaborator in Dada's attempt to turn the world upside down.

Daniel McKiernan, a stocky mariner, speaks of his closes shaves at sea with a loving, professional pride. Mr. McKiernan, who signs, ship's articles as chief barber of the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth, is rounding out a quarter century of saltwater haircutting.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Indian Custodial Command announced today that the long-stalled Communist explanations to Korean war prisoners would resume tomorrow. But Allied efforts to make "come home" talks to twenty-two Americans, one Briton and seventy-seven South Koreans still were stalled.
The writer of the following article, William L. Ryan, is back in the United States after three months as an Associated Press correspondent in the Soviet Union.

EACH morning, before the breakup of the Korean peace talks at Panmunjom, when U. N. Representative Arthur Hobson Dean made his way across the hard-rutted frozen mud to the meeting hut he always carried in his left hand breast pocket a memorandum from Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison, who negotiated with the Communists for more than a year.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Dec. 19 -- Judge C. Thomas Schettino has entered a judgment in Superior Court clearing Guy Gabrielson, former Republican national chairman, of charges that he illegally acquired $75,000 to $100,000 in stocks from a wealthy widow.

Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick set in motion yesterday the machinery for producing solutions to the problems of player control, the draft and bonus payments. He named a nine-man committee of major and minor league executives to frame new legislation covering those points.
This Tuesday and Wednesday in the Port of New York all longshoremen who worked more than 700 hours during the past year (about 22,000) will mark ballots that read:

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union, A. F. L., struck tonight at the Minneapolis Star and Tribune, leaving this city of more than one-half million population without delivery of a local newspaper.

AFTER seven months away from home, the New York City Ballet Company will return to the City Center for a season of ten weeks beginning Jan. 12. Two premieres are definitely scheduled, and four others are in the works in various stages of certainty.

Christmas is a happy time -- a birthday time -- a time for rejoicing. But sometimes, for its reminders of other Christmases, it can be a sad time too. When last year's Christmas list is unfolded and a name must be crossed off, one's heart sinks. Not a person one knows can take that place. But perhaps an unknown, someone in great need, can act as a stand-in -- a vicarious receiver of that gift.

In many quarters among Western nations the feeling has been growing that the Atomic Energy (McMahon) Act of 1946 which prevents the United States from exchanging atomic information with any of its allies, is as obsolete as the bomb that was dropped on Hiroshima.

With the increasing movement of population from the large cities to the suburbs, a serious school problem has arisen for metropolitan areas in all parts of the country. New housing developments are now shooting up in many suburbs, all too often without adequate thought of educational needs. As a result, school needs become ever more pressing.

ALBANY -- New York State was one of the first to take up the sport of skiing. Back in 1904 a handful of hardy enthusiasts skimmed along the narrow snow-covered paths of Lake Placid. Today there are more than sixty areas which cater to winter sports enthusiasts. The yearly revenue realized by them when conditions are satisfactory is estimated at more than $10,000,000.

ROME, Dec. 19 -- Neo-Fascists banded together with the extreme Left in the Chamber of Deputies today and defeated a Government attempt to appoint Italian representatives to the Council of Europe and the European Coal and Steel Community.

VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 19 -- Partisan and personal rivalries developing during the current joint sessions of Parliament seemed tonight to have made the election of a President of France almost impossible.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 -- Accelerated Christmas shopping in the last two weeks has erased a 7 per cent deficit and Cleveland department store sales now are comparable with 1952 figures. The trend is expected to continue next week and some merchants believe last year's record sales will be eclipsed.

There's no denying that winter isn't what it used to be. Grandfather insists upon it, and grandfather is more right than even he thinks he is. He thinks largely in terms of weather. And whether there is a change in the climate is a matter still under debate; but there is no question about certain other matters.

The second major celebration of the 500th anniversary of the publication of the Gutenberg Bible in the Fourteen Fifties in Europe will be carried on all next year by twenty - four national Protestant Bible societies.

The retail value of Christmas decorations is expected to reach $15,000,000 this year. That would be about 5 per cent over 1952 sales. Improvements in style, color and design have helped make last year's supply obsolete and increase sales.

Economy in school organization through cooperation with citizens' committees and other lay groups is called for in a statement prepared by the New York State Education Department. The statement is now being distributed to superintendents, principals and presidents of boards of education.

ALTHOUGH the London film critics had seen a Cinema- Scope demonstration some months earlier, they did not really let themselves go in judgment of this innovation until recently, when "The Robe" opened here. The majority came down well this side of enchantment.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 11 -- This is the season of the sweating Santa Claus. The South African whites of Dutch or British origin cling grimly to the white Christmas idea in defiance of palm trees and of gardens riotous with summer flowers, of blue skies and a hot sun.

CAIRO, Dec. 19 -- The political wind blowing from London this week has just about extinguished hope here for a settlement of the Anglo-Egyptian dispute over the future of the Suez Canal military base.

Yuletide songs, carols and hymns will be heard Wednesday on the two-hour recorded program at the weekly concert of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The program will begin at noon..

IN this eightieth year of their colorful history, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police would hardly be recognizable to Americans who have learned from Hollywood all that they know about this most famous of law-enforcement organizations.

IN prospect, this last month looked like being the fullest of excitement that the London stage had enjoyed for a long time. Three important openings -- a new play by Terence Rattigan, another by Peter Ustinov and yet another by N. C. Hunter, who in "Waters of the Moon" had given two formidable actresses, Dame Sybil Thorndike and Dame Edith Evans, the chance to act memorably.

IN the perspective of half a century, the period from the Eighteen Nineties to the close of World War I has a pervasive unity. This was the era of protest and reform, the critical period that was to determine whether the American democracy could master the crowding problems of urban life, industrial capitalism, big government and world power.

It is assumed that most of the twenty-two reluctant American prisoners of war in Korea, who have obstructed efforts to meet them in interviews, are actually convinced that they know what they are doing and want to do it. There have been, it is true, some reports of coercion on the part of ring-leaders, but it is not believed that a real majority of these men has been so coerced.

IN pursuance of established custom of selecting outstanding developments in a year about to end, the following -- not necessarily in the order of their importance -- appear to this observer to have been the ten major philatelic highlights during 1953:

It is really difficult to decide for or against on "Wiretapping -- Pro and Con" (Nov. 29) particularly since no one can doubt the integrity and sincerity of both Thurman Arnold and William P. Rogers, and each presents cogent arguments.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- Soviet-bloc countries today observed an "International Day of Solidarity" with the Communist-led Vietminh rebels to mark the seventh anniversary of the start of the Indo-China war, the Reds' radio said today.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Erwin Piscator, theatrical director who fled Germany during the early years of Hitler's regime, will receive a Goethe Plaque in January from the Hessian State Government. It will be given in recognition of his theatrical accomplishments.

A barrel-chested youngster who gives every promise of becoming a top performer. Mike Caraftis of Port Jefferson (L. I.) High, established a meet record for the open 1,000-yard run in the forty-seventh Stuyvesant High School meet last night. The games, at the Third Engineers Group Armory, opened the indoor scholastic track season.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Icy gales swept mile-high Myrdalsjokull Glacier tonight, handicapping efforts to rescue three reported survivors of the crash of a United States Navy Neptune bomber.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 -- A city-wide organization to study the capital fund needs of Detroit's health, welfare and social agencies and then provide for them was announced today.
Presidents of the eight colleges in the informal Ivy football group met here Friday, with plans to formalize the group reportedly high on their agenda.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Dec. 19 -- Long Island's oceanfront erosion problem, long a serious matter, has reached its most critical stage in years since the storm last month, Highway Superintendent Harry T. Tuthill has told the Suffolk Board of Supervisors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Three acts by the President this week were impressive moves in a new and vigorous assertion of his roles as leader of the Republican party and direct spokesman of the United States Government to the American people.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -- While the United States has incurred India's wrath by discussing a military pact with Pakistan, Communist China also has been arousing Indian suspicions, but by overfriendliness.

BILOXI, Miss. -- The Mississippi Gulf Coast from Bay St. Louis to Ocean Springs, long a popular resort both Winter and summer, may now rival any of the famous beach strips of America, including the best of Florida or California.

Books for children that have become collectors' prizes have been brought together from many sources for a special exhibition now open at the Grolier Club, 47 East Sixtieth Street. They will be on view through Feb. 1.

The Metropolitan Vocational High School's maritime department observed last week the seventh anniversary of its establishment aboard the school vessel John W. Brown. The vessel is a Liberty ship permanently tied up at Pier 73. East River.

IT'S about time that someone around here reported the facts on the private life of Public Possum No. 1. Despite a lot of tall talk by bearded philosophers, and short talk by little non-shavers, Pogo did not spring fully half-clothed from Kelly's brow, by Jove.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 19 -- America's undulating Davis Cup fortunes took a sharp turn upward today and Capt. Bill Talbert said he felt "very optimistic" about the chances of wresting the huge silver bowl from Australia.

LOS ANGELES -- The traditional metal Christmas trees having come into bloom on Hollywood Boulevard lamp- posts a full month ago, it is no-wise anticipatory to report that the Southwest is well enmeshed in the holiday season.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The future of Western defense is in a state of confusion. The future of France is in crisis. And the future of United States foreign policy, so intimately concerned with both, is therefore uncertain.

A direct appeal to the various peoples represented in the United Nations has been made by the organization's High Commissioner for Refugees. The Refugee Emergency Fund, made up of a residue from the International Refugee Organization and the contributions of fifteen countries, has run out. The United States, incidentally, was not one of the fifteen contributing nations.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 19 -- A strong finish by Pierre Langlois earned a ten-round draw for the French middleweight against the favored Carmen Basilio, the top welterweight contender, in their nationally televised bout at Syracuse Memorial Stadium tonight.

THIS is the season for making forecasts. The annual guessing game on what the new year will hold is in full swing, and cautious pronouncements are available in quantities. Peppering the optimism in most cases appears a careful phrase, "barring unexpected developments," a qualification that wilts much of the starch in the forecast's backbone.

TOKYO, Dec. 19 -- Business and political leaders have sharply warned Japan that if the spiral of inflation is not checked, it may seriously damage the nation's economy, which is already regarded by domestic as well as foreign observers as shaky.

While the proposed $35,000,000 trans-Atlantic telephone cable was being hailed as a communications milestone, a project of almost equal magnitude was quietly under way only twenty miles from New York Harbor.
Public apathy to the danger of enemy air attack "is gradually disappearing" in New York City.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers swept into a two-point lead at the top of the English Soccer League standings today as West Bromwich Albion lost to the Bolton Wanderers, 2 -- 1.

IF MOVIEGOERS don't flock to "The Best Years of Our Lives" in 1954 as they did in 1947 it won't be due to any lack of effort on the part of Samuel Goldwyn. The producer, who has taught Hollywood many a lesson over the last forty years, now is conducting a post-graduate course in showmanship and the industry is giving it respectful attention.
ALBANY. Dec. 19 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department said today it had received reports of "fair" skiing conditions at three upstate winter sports, centers.

MEXICO CITY -- To attract more tourists (and in the process to have more fun itself) Mexico is reviving its neglected holiday tradition of fairs and fiestas. Christmas, always the most festive season of the Mexican year, will mark the first effort in this new campaign to observe the gaieties of the country's Indian and Spanish cultural heritage and to put on the best possible display for visitors.
Money market uncertainties seem to have ended the prospect of any general increase in interest dividend payments to New York's savings bank depositors.

SAKKARA, Egypt, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- The foundations of a pyramid 6,500 years old emerged today from yellow sands covering this "city of the dead" sixteen miles south of Cairo. [Discovery of the pyramid was reported by the National Geographic Society in October, 1952.]
James H. McCreery Co. ended its career yesterday in an atmosphere as hectic as the day the department store was founded 116 years ago.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- Swiss aviation experts believe that Russia's new rocket-powered fighter can stay in the air no longer than seven minutes.
CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Japanese Government has restored a $12,000 charity fund for needy New Hampshire citizens.
The Long Island Aggies opened their wrestling season yesterday with a 17-11 victory over City College on the losers' mats. It was the third consecutive defeat for City.

AMONG the heart-warming scenes of recent weeks in Korea have been the sights of soldiers, not so long ago fighting in the front lines, now sweating over a broken wheel on a toy wagon or a torn wig on a talking doll.

The Christmas season was celebrated at yesterday morning's Young People's Concert of the Philharmonic - Symphony. Faye Emerson, the "surprise celebrity" of the occasion, narrated the story of the Nativity, in which William Ellis, boy soprano, also participated. The audience joined in several carols.
OMAHA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The University of Nebraska Board of Regents accepted today the resignation of George (Potsy) Clark as athletic director and moved to look into the school's athletic situation.

American Airlines will end its sleeper flights tonight. It considers them to be "casualties" of aviation progress. When the last Mercury sleeper flight departs for Los Angeles the airline's stewardesses will have made their last aerial beds.

TAMPA -- This hard-working industrial city on Florida's central west coast -- a malaria swamp when Teddy Roosevelt and his Rough Riders sailed for Cuba in 1898 and today the state's second largest municipality -- will this winter celebrate its fiftieth pirate festival -- Gasparilla Week.

A TOUCH of spring fever sent Finnegan II, hardy, spunky, MacDougal Alley cat, chasing a sunbeam through a tunnel of drainpipes, with one life "waving carelessly over his shoulder like a banner," until he plunked into a sinkhole.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser, with a score of 7 -- 0, and N. May Karff, 6 1/2 -- 1/2, will meet in the final round of the national women's tournament at the Marshall Chess Club today as the sole contenders for the title each has won before, but which Mrs. Mary Bain captured two years ago.
The deadliest weapon in American history is the family automobile.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Defense Department's long-range program stressing a build-up of air power and continental defenses has been approved by President Eisenhower and the National Security Council.

EASTERN Canada's most highly developed winter sports playground, the picturesque Laurentians, are looking forward to another record-smashing winter like last year's, which brought an estimated revenue of close to $5,000,000 into the cash registers of resort and lift operators.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 19 -- Responsible conservatives on the sidelines of the struggle over cartelization in West Germany are making strenuous efforts to heal the breach between the industrial magnates and the liberal economists of the Federal Government.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The fear of creating a power vacuum in the Middle East with serious, perhaps disastrous, consequences to peace and the position of the North Atlantic alliance in that area is one of the basic reasons for the hardening of responsible opinion in Britain against the proposed withdrawal from the Suez Canal zone.

According to the American Cancer Society, a major penicillin manufacturer is going back to a costly and time-consuming production method of ten years ago in the search for a material which was then found to be effective against cancer in test tubes but which is no longer available.
The men who buy furniture for stores are convinced that the public will get more for its money when it buys furniture next year.
