GENTLY chiding his audience for the relative lack of human interest in their color pictures, Erwin Blumenfeld, prominent Vogue color photographer, reminded the Village Camera Club last week that there is much more to life than the stone walls, houses, doors, etc., which they seemed to favor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Southern-based Democratic leadership in the Senate will be put under pressure from among the younger Democratic Senators to take up a position of fighting partisanship in the new session of Congress.
Bulging catalogues of former King Farouk's palace collections, part of which will be auctioned in Cairo beginning in mid-February, will arrive in New York in a few days.

Although a sizable aggregate of German dollar bonds has received a clean bill of health in the validation procedure under way since September, it is unlikely that public trading in the bonds will begin before early in the new year.

The Times recently carried an article by Michael Clark dealing with the latent problem of "the divergent colonial policies of Britain and France in West Africa." This is a subject that will widen in scope and interest with the passing of time. It cannot, therefore, receive international attention and consideration too early.

NOTHING could be more obvious than the truism that the creative artist must have freedom to follow the promptings of his own instincts and conscience. But the obvious has been significant news in recent days, thanks to the disclosure that this truth has been stated openly in Soviet Russia, where cultural life has been struggling for some years under the blight of repressive decrees.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The American National Red Cross has provided about 5,000,000 cubic centimeters of gamma globulin in the national campaign to protect children from paralytic poliomyelitis.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 19 -- Syracuse University's quintet experienced difficulty with Yale's zone defense in the first period, but finally found the solution and scored an 81-67 victory.

FIRST published in the magazines of 1945, Lewis Padgett's famed series of "Baldy" stories rank today as the classic exploration of all the ramifications of that inevitable conflict between man and -- not superman, but psi-man.
Not without reason did many American Leaguers call Al Rosen, the Indians' third baseman, the "most improved player" in the circuit last season.
BOSTON -- New England ski resort operators, who have been spending the off-season doing a thorough job of Yankee housecleaning, are looking forward optimistically to the 1953 winter vacation season.

ROSALYN TURECK has just completed, for Decca, the entire Well-Tempered Clavier by Bach (two albums, three disks each), and it is difficult to think of a pianist who could do better. What makes her performance especially remarkable is that she is a first-class instrumentalist as well as a first-class stylist.

THE aviation industry at home and abroad quite naturally speaks in glowing terms of its new and forthcoming planes, of turbo-props and pure jet passenger ships, of fantastic speeds and comfort. Only two of these planes are now flying on regularly scheduled routes -- the turbo-propeller Vickers Viscount and the pure jet de Havilland Comet.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond called today for a ban on any political contributions from race track officials, liquor venders and road contractors.
THE stage is the dark forest of the German mind; the time. twenty-seven years of decadence that led to catastrophe; the characters as varied and motley a cast as ever Shakespeare dreamed of.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 19 -Wood and wood products have developed into a $200,000 a year industry in Tennessee, according to State Forester Carl I. Peterson in the December issue of the "Tennessee Conservationist." He also ranked the state second in the south in timber production.
ROME, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Thirty young candidates from all parts of the United States were ordained Roman Catholic priests today in the first such rites held at Rome's new North American College.
President Eisenhower last Wednesday outlined his holiday plans to reporters:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- A Skye terrier from Ridgefield, Conn., the Iradell Kennels' Ch. Ivory Jock of Iradell, became best in show tonight in the fifty-ninth event of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia.
CURITIBA, Parana, Brazil, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A world coffee congress, the first of its kind, is scheduled to take place here from Jan. 14 to 22.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 19 -- But for President Eisenhower's speech here last week. the United Nations would face the New Year in very poor spirits.
JACKSON, Mich., Dec. 19 -- Five convicts seized a 28-year-old housewife and a 31-year-old nurse as hostages tonight in a wild fight following their escape from gigantic Southern Michigan prison.
LIKE many another theatre owner, the Veterans Administration is wrestling with the problems of converting to new film processes and techniques.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The University of Illinois and six other Midwestern educational institutions plan to cooperate in a multi-million dollar atom splitting research project. They hope the project will be financed by the Atomic Energy Commission or private foundations.

IT is Christmas time and once more the city glows with light. It is the time for giving and receiving gifts. And of all the gifts you can receive, the most precious is the feeling that you are wanted, that there is someone who cares.

Resident buying offices are trying to fill last-minute orders or quick - delivery merchandise. The formal wear market is bare and only certain items of lingerie can be found. Other categories in particular demand, such as accessories, children's wear, and many types of sportswear, are obtainable after careful shopping. However, supply is diminishing at a rapid pace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States and France conferred today on preparations for the prospective four-power Berlin conference on Germany. Meanwhile a proposed offer of security guarantees to the Soviet Union developed as the major challenge to agreement among the three Western Allies.

EARLIER last week roses were still blooming and forsythia was flowering in gardens in the vicinity of New York City. Spring, not Christmas, was in the air. How were these mild days affecting the sale of Christmas trees? At least one Long Island nurseryman admitted that business was a bit slow, but he wasn't worried.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 19 -- Seton Hall, last year's National Invitation Basketball Tournament winner, gained its most important victory so far this season by sweeping to an 86-65 triumph over St. Francis College of Brooklyn tonight.

THREE years ago young Mrs. Thomas -- her case is real, though her name isn't -- went to Family Court on East Twenty-second Street in Manhattan, bitter about her "abusive" husband who had left her, and asking that he be made to support her and their two youngsters. The court, after an investigation and hearing, so ordered. It gave the husband the right of periodic visits to his children.
Dr. A. Whitney Griswold's "Liberal Education Is Practical Education" (Nov. 29) clearly recognizes that the struggle between know-how and knowledge is an institutional rather than a necessary one.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The French have achieved a remarkable thing. They have made official Washington almost as irrational about France as the French are about the Germans.

THE late Russell Maloney, commenting on one of Mr. Coward's essays in autobiography (a World War II travel-diary, if memory serves), remarked that there'll always be an England and always a Noel Coward -- but that the two are not necessarily synonymous.

ON Feb. 15, 1934, a stout rope, hitched to a Model T Ford engine, pulled a few boys on skis up Clint Gilbert's hilly, snow-covered pasture outside Woodstock, Vt. Puffing and laboring, that "tin Lizzie" gave birth to a new era in winter sports.

VIENNA, Dec. 19 -- The Austrian Government served notice on the Allied Council in a note published today that Austria intended to make her own arrangements with foreign aircraft companies for flights over her territory.
As she has done every Christmas season for many years a woman entered the Times Tower yesterday and handed a clerk a tiny envelope with her contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

IN the average home or school atlas the Leeward Islands appear as mere flyspecks drifting on a broad ocean of blue. So closely do they cling to each other that it seems the intervening distances must scarcely exceed a few hours in time.

CLANS of Scotland are at each others' tartans again, and all because of Bobby Burns. Or. rather, all because of Englishman William Seymour, a 66- year-old retired bank manager who not only was never there before you.
WINTER, when the tropical vapors ease off to a pleasant breeze and the landscape, freshened by the summer rains, bursts into flower, is the best time to visit Central America.
FRANKFURT, Germany. IF the new season in Germany has offered no novelties of notable quality, it has provided, in the form of Boris Blacher's "Abstrakte Oper No. 1," a first-class scandal.

THE strength of a modern nation depends very largely on its scientists, especially those who do pioneering research on the frontier of knowledge. In the popular mind these key men are rather mysterious. What are they like, and how did they get that way?
The Middle East and Indo-China were again on the "firing line" last week in the struggle for the world.

The bodies of the uncle and aunt of Harlow J. Fraden, confessed poison-murderer of his father and mother, may be exhumed by Sullivan County authorities to ascertain whether their death last August near Monticello was accidental.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- East Germany, disclosing production plans, which in the past have been closely guarded secrets, promised the populace today large numbers of items ranging from shoes to television sets.

There is one strange and forever heartening factor in the thought and aspirations of mankind. It is represented by the one word, peace, which exists in all languages. So we come to solemn celebration this week of One whose very name comes down to us through the centuries as the Great Advocate of Peace.

The communique issued at Bermuda seems to be weaker and considerably less categorical than certain previous statements by Secretary Dulles. Hence the obvious implication is that the two European members of the conference had less understanding and less sympathy for the cause of their fellow-Europeans than the American representative.

ONE rainy afternoon the keeper of a toy shop whistled a strange tune as he put a magic clock to his ear. "It didn't tick, or even tock. It made no sound like any clock." Then the Enchanted Doll began to dance over the piano keys and among the stuffed animals.
TOKYO, Dec. 19 -- Why don't they come home ?

BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- The Massachusetts Department of Natural Resources offered the bodies of three sea hares as evidence this week that New England weather was becoming warmer. The argument fell on frost-bitten ears, however, as temperatures dropped into the twenties.
The Squadron A regulars gave an indoor polo trio called Pittsfield four goals on handicap and defeated it, 14 to 11, in the Squadron A Armory last night.

AUGUST 6, 1945 the day the atom bomb fell on Hiroshima, is usually thought of as the beginning of the atomic age. The atomic era will soon, however, have another, more auspicious, day to count as birthday.

MAYBE hotel managers do have conventions. Or maybe they get so tired of the convention they have to cater to that when they get some time off, they head for isolated caves. But I wish they would get together once in a while and exchange notes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -The following table shows personal income and social security tax payments this year, payments next year under changes scheduled in present law, and the net increase or decrease to taxpayers. The table is based on net income before deductions for dependents, contributions, interest paid, etc.:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Republican National Committee in its annual survey "Women in Public Office" reported last week a record high of forty important women appointments in the first eleven months of the Eisenhower Administration.

WHEN the Dramatists Guild was being reorganized in 1925 -- to correct managerial abuses and to define new boundaries of interests arising out of new mechanical inventions -- it was necessary for the playwrights to present a united front.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, will serve as chairman of a weekly series of thirteen radio lectures on "Man's Right to Knowledge," beginning Jan. 3.
New Yorkers were urged again yesterday to make Christmas donations of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program so that all possible demands during the holidays could be met.

HONG KONG, Dec. 19 -- The pattern and the extent of Communist China's trade are becoming increasingly difficult to determine. In Peiping, Communist secretiveness now conceals all but the most general information on trade: in non-Communist countries where the China trade has become a touchy international issue, clear, up-to-date statistics are in some instances hard to come by.
Proposals for more liberal United States policies on trade and economic relations with friendly nations will be considered in an extensive public information program early in 1954.

NEW ORLEANS -- Just why New Orleans is what it is seems to be harder to learn than its correct pronunciation -- New Or-lee-uns. The city's impact has nothing to do with the biggest and best. although the Crescent City (it lies in a bend of the Mississippi) is a major port and increasingly important in Latin-American trade.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti -- The Caribbean Island of Hispaniola, or as the French later called it, Saint Domingue, was first discovered by Columbus in 1492. And the four and a half exciting centuries that followed have left a rich patina of history that greatly enhances its interest as a tropical vacation resort embracing all of Haiti on the western end of the island and all of the Dominican Republic on the eastern portion.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 19 (AP) -- J. C. Caroline, University of Illinois halfback, whizzed in here today in time for a big homecoming celebration despite an unexpected plane delay.

THIS week thousands of bird watchers will tramp the fields, woods and swamps from Maine to Texas to count the wild birds. This will be the fifty-third annual Christmas Bird Count, a nation-wide survey of our North American birds, conducted each year at this time under the auspices of the National Audubon Society and the Fish and Wildlife Service.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 (UP) -A. K. Anderson's Dr. Moore, a 20-to-1 shot, sprinted in the Fair Grounds stretch today to defeat Just Us Girls by a half-length in the $5,000 Pontchartrain Handicap before a crowd of almost 11,500.
A late Brandeis rally fell one point short last night as City College's basketball team turned back the New Englanders, 77 -- 76, at the Lavender gymnasium.

THE semi-annual members' show at The Camera Club, 121 West Sixty - eighth Street, is part of the club's seventieth anniversary observance. Established in 1883, the club is the oldest such group in the city.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry plans to build nearly 1,700,000 cars in next year's first quarter.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Business volume in the Chicago area slipped during November, compared with October, but profits have been held in line, the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated. The percentages highlighted the marked change in direction.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- Persons traveling over the Florida keys to this southernmost city of the nation this season are finding a new and unexpected point of interest. For the first time since the outbreak of the war in Korea, the large, vital naval base at the end of the Overseas Highway (U. S. 1) is open for public inspection.

MONTREAL, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens went into a first-place tie with the idle Detroit Red Wings tonight by defeating the Boston Bruins, 7 to 3, in a National Hockey League game before 14,037 fans at the Forum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri "very definitely would be a strong candidate" if the Democrats picked him for the 1956 Presidential nomination, Senator George E. Smathers said today.

AMES, Iowa, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Iowa State College Athletic Coun-' cil today set up a sifting committee to aid in selecting a new football coach, following the surprise resignation yesterday of Emmett R. (Abe) Stuber.

The discovery of a fossil bed containing the richest single known collection of mammals of the eocene epoch, between fifty and sixty million years ago, has been announced by the American Museum of Natural History. According to George Gaylord Simpson, chairman of the museum's department of geology and paleontology, the bed has already yielded twenty well-preserved skulls, several complete skeletons and many fragmentary specimens.

Undefeated in eight games and allowing but one draw for a score of 7 1/2 -- 1/2, N. May Karff, of this city, regained the National Women's Chess Championship last night. She defeated Mrs. Gisela K. Gresser of New York after fifty-five moves of the deciding ninth-round game at the Marshall Chess Club.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings staged a three- goal last-period rally, to defeat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 2, tonight and extend their winning streak to five games. The victory, plus Montreal's defeat in New York, put Detroit in sole possession of first place in the National Hockey League. The Wings had been tied with the Canadien's for first.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- A "self-help" price support plan proposed by organized dairy farmers has met a cool reception from Agriculture Department officials.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- By reimbursing last Wednesday twenty billion francs of the 240 billion advanced to it by the Bank of France the Treasury met the commitments made between the state and the bank last July 11.

THE official American League batting averages published yesterday confirmed what the unofficial averages had been saying all along. Mickey Vernon of the Senators beat out Al Rosen of the Indians for the hitting championship by the titanic margin of .001 with .337 to his challenger's .336. It's too bad, in a way, that it happened thus.
Striking hat workers at the plant of the Hat Corporation of America in South Norwalk, Conn., have received a $250,000 loan from David Dubinsky's International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F.L.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella threw down the gauntlet to the Christian Democratic party today. In a statement by his personal spokesman, he made it clear that he intended to resign unless he could count on complete and unconditional support of his own party.

Christmas is a time for carrying on family culinary traditions. But today's employed homemaker finds little time available for the preparation of such family favorites as rich plum pudding and fruit cake. The following recipes, designed for busy people, offer quick substitutes.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Dec. 20 -- H. D'O. Baker and Henry Warren of the Greenwich Field Club defeated Edward Greeff, Nassau, and Peter Van Slyck, Hartford, Conn., 15 -- 7, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 9, 16 -- 15, in the final of the seventh annual Piping Rock invitation squash racquets doubles tournament today.

At least 100 other charity organizations soliciting in this state are as guilty of fraud or objectionable fund-raising practices as the dozen exposed last week. State Senator Bernard Tompkins said yesterday.
One of the most widespread and persistent frailties of human logic is the temptation to assume that things in this world are, if not completely homogeneous and static, at least reasonably so.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced for publication today the election of Eugene Holman as chairman of the board and M. J. Rathbone as president and vice president of the executive committee, effective on Jan. 1.
Members of two newspaper craft unions voted yesterday to accept the $3.75 a week package plus fact-finding -- the formula that ended the recent strike.

I would like to suggest that there is considerable question whether the "consumers have won a round," as stated in a recent Times editorial regarding the failure of the Supreme Court to review the Phillips Petroleum case.
The Samuel H. Kress Foundation has given $1,268,941 to New York University for its Medical Science Building, Chancellor Henry T. Heald announced yesterday.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- There was a let-up in football activity in this Rose Bowl city today, as both Michigan State and U. C. L. A. had the day off from practice. --

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Both East and West Berlin have in the past week been the scenes of intricate trials of alleged conspirators, spies, abductors and enticers to defection. The prosecutors told of plots and counterplots that made Berlin appear totally enmeshed in intrigue.

THE beauty and loveliness of full color television was bestowed last night on Gian-Carlo Menotti's modern Christmas classic, "Amahl and the Night Visitors." The effect was striking in the home, like a succession of Yuletide cards come to life.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 -- Craft workers in Hollywood motion picture studios lost not less than 900 days of work this year because of the making of films in foreign countries by American producers.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 20 -- The Israeli Cabinet discussed today what is called here imperfections in the resolution proposed in the United Nations by Britain, France and the United States concerning the disputed Jordan River power project.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market firmed up last week. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange final prices were 15 cents to $1.15 a bale higher. The only exception in the advance was in the near-by March delivery, which declined 30 cents a bale.

JACKSON, Mich., Dec. 20 -- Jackson City police tonight picked up Harold Rosa, 24 years old, one of the six prisoners at large after yesterday's break from Southern Michigan prison. Rosa was cornered in the coal bin of a hotel basement.

The nation's top-ranking college basketball teams, plus many of the lesser lights, head into the busy holiday campaign with seven of the first ten still unbeaten and only one defeat each charged against the other three, The Associated Press reports.

The National Labor Relations Board is confronted with increasing difficulties in seeking to apply what it believes was the intent of Congress in requiring non-Communist affidavits from union officials under the Taft-Hartley Act. The latest and apparently the most formidable obstacle the board has encountered is the recent decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Richard Skinner, a veteran of the Broadway stage and summer stock as a manager, producer, director and actor, has been appointed general manager of Princeton's McCarter Theatre. The appointment results from the university's newly adopted plan to make the theatre a more integral unit of Princeton's dramatic arts program.

For his debut piano recital last night in Town Hall, Constantine Callinicos selected a program that ranged from Bach to Shostakovich. He dealt with this music honestly, though without the specific pianistic graces that would have raised his playing above the average.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Daniel J. Davies has a deep-seated faith that anything can happen in the United States. He is even convinced that the asthma that has plagued him since the cold winter of 1939 and that often keeps him awake at night would disappear "within ten minutes" if he went back there.

Two Dutch companies, Algemene Kunstzijde Unie, N. V. (United Rayon Manufacturing Corporation) and the Royal Dutch Company have been told that they may not list their common stocks on the New York Stock Exchange. Notification followed the report of a special committee of the Exchange governors on nonvoting stock, headed by W. E. Hutton.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Dec. 21 (UP)--President Syngman Rhee of South Korea said today he was willing to give the United Nations a chance to solve the Korean issues at a political conference, although he was convinced "there is no way around our problems but to fight for survival."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 20 (AP) -- America's tennis team flew back to Melbourne today for the Davis Cup challenge round and discovered Australian confidence shaken by the refound power of Tony Trabert.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 -- Because of the Christmas holiday this week and because of the slow tempo in steel order volume the steel rate is expected to sag. The decline may be substantial although it will be temporary.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Fort Ord's eleven routed the Quantico Marines, 55 -- 19, in the Poinsetta Bowl football game today with a powerful ground attack that sent Ollie Matson, Lawrence Segovia and Dave Mann on long scoring runs.

On Saturday, Communist-ruled states, from Prague to the Pacific, joined in the celebration of an "International Day of Solidarity." The occasion for the rejoicing and the expressions of mutual admiration was the seventh anniversary of the outbreak of the bloody fighting in Vietnam.

The drive to oust racketeers from The the American Federation of Labor will not halt even if the old International Longshoremen's Association wins in the balloting among 22,000 pier workers here tomorrow and Wednesday.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 20 (UP) -- The national debt cannot be reduced until the security of the United States and other free nations "is assured," W. Randolph Burgess, deputy to the Secretary of the Treasury, said tonight.

Two books by Thomas Jefferson and one about him are scheduled for publication during the next four weeks. Next Monday will mark the publication day of two books compiled from Jefferson's writings. They are Volume 8 of "The Papers of Thomas Jefferson, 25 February to 31 October 1785," edited by Julian P. Boyd (Princeton University) and "Thomas Jefferson's Farm Book, With Commentary and Relevant Extracts From Other Writings," edited by Edwin Morris Betts.
In an international gesture of goodwill, Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain has sent $15 to a lonely London laborer for shoveling snow here nearly twenty-eight years ago.
Some toy-buying counsel for parents still confronted with Christmas shopping has been offered by the Play Schools Association.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- Italy completed the withdrawal today from her frontier with Yugoslavia of the equivalent of four infantry divisions. The troops had been sent there at various times since early September, when Italian-Yugoslav relations took a dangerous turn as a result of the Trieste controversy.

Although tradesmen have turned Christmas into a "profit-seeking period," it is not the commercialization of the day that keeps its observance growing, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Church (Methodist) declared yesterday.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Dec. 20 -- South Africa faces the-problem of trying to induce the Central African Federation to adopt a customs union like that between South Africa and Southern Rhodesia. The federation consists of Northern and Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland.

LAMBERTVILLE, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Seven men in an open boat crossed the ice-coated Delaware River today in preparation for a full-dress re-enactment next Friday of George Washington's historic Christmas night crossing 177 years ago.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Airmen saw no signs of life today when they flew over the wreckage of a United States Navy Neptune bomber that crashed atop an Icelandic glacier Thursday with nine men aboard.

One of the tragically dehumanizing conditions of civilization is the way we live in classes apart. Say what one may about his sense of democracy and feeling for equality, a man will likely know little, really, of those in the economic strata beneath and above him. There are exceptions, of course.

Numerous civic, fraternal, religious and other groups gave their annual pre-Christmas parties yesterday for the children of members and for the underprivileged, or to raise funds for charitable works.

Nine undergraduates -- the editorial board of a City College student newspaper on the uptown campus -- have been suspended from their publication jobs for failure to retract an "objectionable" editorial.

Henry Epstein, who will become a Deputy Mayor on Jan. 1, said yesterday that problems affecting schools, traffic and the Police and Fire Departments would be among the most important that the new city administration would face at once.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 20 -- Voters of two Belgian cities balloted overwhelmingly in an unofficial referendum today in favor of closer ties among European countries.
Shortly after the first of the year a debate will arise in Washington over the tariff, a controversial issue for well over a century and a half.
The Mayor's Advisory Committee for the Aged declared yesterday there had been "a truly lamentable lack of sociological studies of the aged" and far too little research in the field generally.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Two annual grants for another alcoholism clinic and research project were made today by the Mental Health Commision. Both will be at the Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 21 -- A Stalin Peace Prize has been awarded to Howard Fast, American author, for "helping to strengthen the cause of peace between the peoples," the Moscow radio said early today.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Mysterious explosions occur nightly on the Communist side of the mountainous boundary between the Reds and the United Nations soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Officials of the Foreign Operations Administration on the policy-making level are considering means by which private capital can replace diminishing United States foreign economic aid.

The New York Americans, leaders in the American Soccer League, yesterday eliminated the New York Germans from the National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Soccer Football Association, 3 -- 0, at Sterling Oval, the Bronx.
TOKYO, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Japan Skating Association today selected its six-member team to participate in the men's world speed-skating championships at Sapporo, Hokkaido, on Jan. 16 and 17.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The Army said today in a hitherto secret report that germ warfare was a "major danger" to the United States but derided the idea it could be used to start mass epidemics.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Ten new fellowships in the humanities and social sciences have been established at Princeton, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced yesterday. Each will carry a stipend up to $2,000, including tuition.
" Foul weather" was still the forecast for shipowners last week as the charter barometer again dipped a few points.

HAMBURG, Germany, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- The roar of lions, the neighing of horses and the crack of the ringmaster's whip will no longer be heard under the big top of one of the most famous circuses in the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- A Harvard University atomic scientist today defended the right of a fellow-professor to refuse to answer questions on communism and said that to his knowledge there were no communists at Harvard.
Children spilled ice cream bars on the floor, played tag, and teased their parents for more cookies or soft drinks.
ZURICH, Dec. 20 -- Allegations by the United States Department of Justice last week that a 1951 law organized the Swiss watch industry into a cartel struck a stunning blow here.

A New Year's Eve performance of Strauss' "Fledermaus" will be given at the Metropolitan Opera House at 8:15 o'clock. It will be a non-subscription performance, and it will mark the Metropolitan Opera debut of Alicia Markova, dance soloist in the second-act ballet. Eleanor Steber will sing Rosalinda for the first time with the company.
The C. I. O. Maritime Committee declared yesterday that it was "appalled" by the Maritime Administration's order to close the Sheepshead Bay training center for unlicensed seamen.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 20 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi asked for mercy for former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today as the court-martial trying the former dictator made ready to hand down a verdict.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $81,529,083,312. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Matinee basketball proved a big hit with the youngsters among the 12.245 tans at Madison Square Garden yesterday when the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Baltimore Bullets, 75 -- 67, and the Boston Celtics downed the Philadelphia Warriors. 101 -- 89.

Ruth and Thomas Martin, who did the New York City Opera's English version of "The Marriage of Figaro" and the Metropolitan Opera's English "Cosi fan tutte," have turned their talents to "La Boheme," and their new English translation of the Puccini opera was presented in abridged form last night at the Lexington Avenue Y. M.-Y. W. H. A. by the "Y" Symphonic Workshop.

It is regrettable that the negotiations going on since June between the Austrian Government and the Jewish Claims organization for some indemnity for the horrors inflicted by the Nazis on the Jews in Austria have broken down over an issue which would not seem to warrant such a drastic development.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Representative Charles B. Brownson charged today that Dr. Syngman Rhee was passing over the needs of South Korea's "hungry, freezing population" to build a luxury hotel at Seoul.

The A string of Erica Morini's violin snapped yesterday afternoon as she was playing the first movement of Brahms' Violin Concerto with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall. Thanks to the presence of mind all around, though, there was no break in the musical continuity and only a note or two were missed.

THERE'S a warm, old-fashioned Bracebridge Hall touch this week to pre-Christmas fuss and bother at Charles Co., which has provided the town's affluent with fancy holiday groceries, tobaccos, sweets, fruits, teas and exotic tidbits the last 105 years.

Activity and a strong undertone in the Canadian dollar was the feature in an otherwise dull foreign exchange market during the past week. British pound sterling fluctuated within a limited range on transactions that were mostly routine.

In a game that was a throwback to the old days in which violence abounded, the New York Rangers defeated the Canadiens of Montreal last night. While a crowd of 13,615 watched their efforts, the Broadway Blues outscored the Flying Frenchmen by 3 to 1.

The responsibility of Christians to improve the community in which they live was emphasized in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Victor E. Beck at the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 155 East Twenty-second Street.
Taking issue with persons who regard alcoholism merely as a "disease,' the Rev. Fedelis Rice declared yesterday that alcoholism was the result of repeated "sins of drunkenness."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- American chestnut trees, virtually wiped out by a fungus blight during the last fifty years, are making a comeback after being crossed with Chinese chestnuts.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 20 -- Utah's junior college system was abandoned and extra funds were found for elementary and high schools during the nineteen-day special session of the Legislature that ended last night.

The Soviet Union has not yet agreed on the date fixed by the Western Powers for the Berlin meeting, but technical preparations are proceeding in the Allied capitals and in Berth the former Control Commission headquakters are being swept and garnished as if the first Four-Power conference in six years were going to be held on Jan. 4.
The job of drafting legislation to carry out the 1954-55 fiscal program prepared by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. and his advisers is nearly completed.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- One young Eastern Airlines stewardess died and the Coast Guard said another was missing and presumed dead as a result of a boating mishap in Biscayne Bay late yesterday. Their escorts were able to swim ashore.

The college and the university are the best sources for new sales personnel. This is the composite view of 140 manufacturing companies taking part in a survey just completed by the National Industrial Conference Board. The findings were announced over the week-end.
The number of school-age children who now attend Jewish all-day schools has more than tripled since 1935.
Ten new films, including importations from England and Italy, constitute the holiday film fare slated to arrive this week in first-run theatres. The programs follow:

VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 20 -- Premier Joseph Laniel's lead in the French Presidential election increased again tonight so that he was within twenty-two votes of the absolute majority required for victory.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 20 -- After several months of stagnation the capital market is beginning to show activity.
Wolfgang Edward Rebner and Wayne Barlow shared the program at the Composers Forum Saturday evening in the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" received a special performance for the benefit of the Yeshiva University Woman's Organization Saturday night at the Metropolitan. At this event Lisa della Casa assumed the role of Donna Elvira for the first time, and George London appeared in the title role.
Milton L. Herzog has been appointed general manager of the film division and C. E. Silk, general manager of the international division of Olin Industries, Inc., East Alton, Ill.
The State Insurance Department has broadened its inquiry into corruption in the administration of union welfare funds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The conferences between President Eisenhower and Congressional leaders produced a mutual understanding on the area staked out for legislative action at the next session of Congress.

The election of Max J. Etra, attorney and communal leader, as chairman of the board of trustees of Yeshiva University, was announced yesterday by Dr. Samuel Belkin, president. Mr. Etra succeeds former Borough President of Manhattan Samuel Levy, who held the post for twenty-three years until his death last March.
A ton of granulated sugar plus a one-ton safe added up yesterday to a novel second-story robbery that cost a Brooklyn bakery $7,000 cash.

Two veteran burglars, caught crouched early yesterday morning before a safe in Germain's Department Store at 550 Fifth Avenue in Brooklyn, leaped from the second story to the sidewalk in a futile attempt to escape. Both broke bones and were captured.

The annual national conference and election of the American Educational Theatre Association, which has a membership of almost 3,000, will be held next Monday through Dec. 30 in the Statler Hotel. Prominent speakers will discuss "problems relating to dramatic education, as well as trends on the Broadway stage and abroad."

THE stage may be a fabulous invalid, continually confronted by new and perilous economic hazards and continually threatened with a dearth of playwriting talent, but those who love it do not falter in their affections. No matter how wonderful motion pictures become (and several every year are quite wonderful) they never can achieve an effect so exciting as that tense moment when a legitimate theatre's lights dim and the curtain begins to rise.

There is an inevitable lull in art activities during Christmas week, but several exhibitions, varied in character, either will open or remain on view. A new gallery for European and American art, the Karnig, opens today at 19 1/2 East Sixty-second Street.

The men's clothing industry operated at 79 per cent of capacity during the first ten months of 1953, a 15 per cent increase over the 69 per cent rate in the preceding year, the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. reported.

The Right Rev. G. Ashton Oldham, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Albany, voiced a Christmas plea yesterday to Christians to emulate the spirit of rejoicing exhibited by the early Christians over the coming of Christ.

When General Eisenhower accepted the nomination at Chicago in July, 1952, he declared that "we must have more Republicans in our state and local offices; mere Republican governments in our states; a Republican majority in the United States House of Representatives and in the United States Senate; and, of course, a Republican in the White House."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- Arthur Knapp's consistent performance with Agony through eight races at the Larchmont Yacht Club earned the top score of 221 points in the frostbite season's seventh championship series regatta today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Administration is facing up to the possibility of a 1954 slide in business and employment. At the same time, Administration sources express confidence that the outlook now is good.
The 15-year-old Bronx boy who was killed Saturday night was shot accidentally by a member of his own teen-age gang while they were plotting an attack on a rival group, the police reported yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 20 -- What are the alternatives for Germany at the forthcoming four-power conference in Berlin? Neutralization? Integration with the West? Or something else again?

CAIRO, Dec. 19 -- The problem of getting the British and Egyptians together for a meeting that might some day produce a compromise settlement of the Suez Canal zone dispute evoked feverish diplomatic activity here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The twenty-six-man committee that conducted the industrial relations study for the N. P. A. was drawn from industry, labor, universities, law and economics.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Dewey will ask the 1954 Legislature to provide financial backing for a new state research program to determine whether there is a relationship between cigarette smoking and cancer of the lung.

" Be prepared to sell shoes, wrap packages, pound the typewriter or file records -- at least for a while," a vocational counselor advises recent college graduates who plan to migrate to New York City for eareers in unusual fields.

Is your Santa Claus list complete? Every woman has countless items she must fill in at the last moment -- things for grown-ups, toys for toddlers, as well as odds and ends that can be put into the stockings that hang by the chimney on Christmas eve.

As a result of research aided by the sale of Christmas seals, progress has been made in preventing fatal complications of tuberculosis in children, the National Tuberculosis Association announced yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 19 -- After spending 15,000,000 ($33,600,000) on a search that has lasted fifty years Australia has struck oil beneath the red dust and spinifex of a lonely place called Rough Range. The site is 650 miles north of Perth, capital of Western Australia.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 21 -- The Communists began a last-minute attempt today to win back a few more of their soldiers now held in neutral custody in Korea's demilitarized zone.
Solely for the purpose of clarifying certain facts would like to comment on the two articles by Sydney Gruson concerning Venezuela.
PARIS, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A stir in the Paris fashion world has been created by the announcement that Gabrielle Chanel will start selling dresses again on Feb. 5.

Seven deacons were elevated to the priesthood, and one ordinand was ordained to the diaconate yesterday by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -Former Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson said today that the ten-year contract for renting New York's pneumatic mail tubes had been necessary to keep the tubes in operation.
Net sales of F. E. Myers .Bro. Company, makers of pumps, sprays, heaters and air-conditioners, rose in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 but net profit fell.

The Security Bureau, Inc., will be headed, effective today, by Jeremiah J. Sullivan, former chief of the Criminal Division of the United States Attorney's Office, Eastern District. This private organization was established by transportation and insurance companies to investigate and prevent thefts and pilferages on the New York waterfront.

In this year's Christmas list of fifty-nine novels recommended by The New York Times Book Review there were only one or two whose titles simply announced the hero's name. Many of us will recall reading, in our younger days, such books as "Jane Eyre," "Peregrine Pickle," "Elsie Dinsmore," "Tom Jones" -- all books that came right out and said what they were about.
Last week's report to the President of the National Security Training Commission is the best and most practical study yet made of the controversial problem of Universal Military Training.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Air transport in France was almost completely tied up today by a strike of control tower weather and radio personnel.
The East European Fund established in 1951 by the Ford Foundation reported yesterday that it was continuing its program to help Soviet refugees become full members of American society.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Avoidance of a railway strike almost at the last minute naturally was received with immense relief throughout the country. It found immediate and marked reflection in the stock markets last week, although to the last the City had been remarkably confident that a settlement would be reached.
Last year, just about this time, a number of hints were dropped to Santa Claus in connection with prep schools. It is surprising how well Santa responded.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Cary, Ill., couple and four of their five children were killed tonight when their car collided with a Soo Line train at the Palatine Road crossing near Wheeling, a suburb of Chicago. Another child was critically injured.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 20 -- More and more segments of the West German industrial and business communities apparently are being convinced that West Germany must gain pre-war Germany's trading position in the markets controlled today by the Soviet Union.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Residents queued up by the thousands to buy The Minneapolis Sunday Tribune today as a trucking strike stopped deliveries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -The Senate Post Office Committee staff has been ordered to "look into" a Government contract leasing at $360,000 a year a pneumatic tube service for the New York post office.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The know-how of successful labor relations as told by thirty companies and unions has been distilled into a single package by the National Planning Association.

Candy is sweetening its advertising budget for 1954 to some $30,000,000, an increase of $5,000,000 over the budget for 1953. The thirty-four leaders in the field will spend almost $20,000,000 as against a little over $17,000,000 this year, according to a survey made public yesterday by the magazine Candy Industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- All that Civil Defense officials want for Christmas is a way to get their lagging program out of the Alphonse - Gaston routine. Federal, state and local governments still are trying to bow each other into the act first.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Two senators agreed today that there was little chance Congress would approve universal military training next year.

The retirement on Dec. 31 of Dr. Donald B. Armstrong, second vice president and director of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's health education campaign, has been announced by Dr. Armstrong. In doing so he predicted that future health gains here and in Canada would result from progress in the fight against chronic diseases, accidents, overweight and mental illness.

There are many tests of greatness. Some men are accounted great because they push forward the boundaries of human knowledge. Others are honored with this title because they have educated and inspired their students, helping these younger men to go forth and revolutionize our understanding and our technology.

Robert and Judy Stern of New York sent $5 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. In a letter written in a fine youthful hand Robert, who is 12, explained that he and his 9-year-old sister wanted the money to go to a needy child.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 19 -- The Chilean Government's position toward two radio stations on the question of broadcasting Peronist propaganda has prompted Liberal and Radical party leaders to promise a campaign of watchfulness against any type of censorship.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Rodney Dee Brodie, who was separated from his Siamese twin a year ago, left the hospital for the first time today to go home for Christmas.

Gaily wrapped Christmas gifts for needy children were given by the congregation at a special service yesterday morning in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Second Avenue and Sixteenth Street. Afterward the church entertained at dinner 200 children and their mothers from the Department of Welfare's Family Shelter for homeless mothers and children, 1 East 104th Street. Each child received a gift -- the boys toy jeeps, the girls cloth dogs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- One of the first things the nine justices of the Supreme Court will do after they return to the bench on Jan. 4 will be to go to the movies.

A Richmond County grand jury will get evidence this week purporting to show that the death of a city fireman and injuries to six other persons in a collision Wednesday night were the result of a $10 barroom bet.

The decision of international airlines to expand tourist air operations across the Pacific next year heightens interest within the American air transport industry on a forthcoming decision by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Lumber production in the week ended Dec. 12 was 8.2 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to the New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 1.1 per cent and orders were up 3.3 per cent.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Shrine's annual college all-star football game in the Orange Bowl Christmas night is shaping up as a contest between the running power of the North and the aerial strength of the South.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- West Coast conservationists opened a fight today against the proposed building of a reclamation dam at Echo Park, Utah, by the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican of New Jersey, proposed today a compromise corporation income tax plan that would avoid any revenue loss in the next fiscal year.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 20 -- An agreement between industry and labor extending the escalator system of pegging wages to the consumer-price index was announced last night. A strike threatened by the General Federation of Labor (Histadrut) earlier this week thus was obviated.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Infantrymen in winter khaki and policemen in navy blue uniforms and capes shivered in the cold this afternoon along the Champs Elysees, the Avenue Foch and the main road through the Bois de Boulogne. They waited to do honor to the next President of the Republic when he should enter Paris from Versailles.

The annual "Messiah" performances by the Oratorio Society of New York have a special quality. It comes from a combination of warmth, enthusiasm and vitality, and that combination was present again at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night when the society sang the famous oratorio for the 130th time.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 20 -- Nation-wide public demonstrations against the reported United States plan for military aid to Pakistan were inaugurated by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party today in the old city of Delhi.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Browns, who haven't Cleveland's won the pro crown in two years, expect to have their favorite weapon -- passing -- in better working order when they meet the Detroit Lions this time in the National Football League's championship play-off.

Audrey Hepburn and Jose Ferrer emerged the year's top movie performers in the annual poll of film critics of the nation's newspapers, magazines, syndicates and radio and television commentators conducted by the trade publication Film Daily.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Free selling of long lines of grains and soybeans for tax purposes put a lot of weight on the cereal markets last week. This selling, combined with straight profit-taking, was hard to digest, especially as there was a tapering off of buying demand.

Allen Wardwell Was a nationally known American lawyer, civic leader and philanthropist, as well as a man of rare goodness with a deep sense of responsibility for the welfare of his fellow-man. He was indeed a loyal friend of the Russian people during his long and notable career and accomplished much for their betterment.
An "unholy relationship" exists among some shipping and stevedoring company executives and "certain of the worst racketeers" on the waterfront, the Brooklyn rackets grand jury charged yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Creation of a new state authority to build the projected $22,000,000 Sprain Brook Parkway as a tool road was proposed today to the Westchester Board of Supervisors.

The disconcerting news that Secretary McKay has approved plans to construct a giant dam that would destroy one of the West's great scenic preserves has produced prompt and adverse reaction that we hope will be effective in stopping an inexcusable blunder. The Sierra Club of California, devoted to protection of the Western mountain country, has denounced the Secretary's decision as "the gravest threat to the national park system since its creation in 1916."
President Eisenhower's plan for the creation of an international atomic energy agency was outlined before the United Nations on Dec. 8 as follows:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate to the United Nations Security Council, threatened today to veto the key paragraph in a compromise Western resolution on a dispute over waters of the Jordan River.

Queens College, outscored by six points from the floor, tallied forty-three times from the foul line to turn back Yeshiva University's basketball team, 81 -- 64, at the Queens College gymnasium in Flushing yesterday.

Fred Gardner of Yale and John Brownell of Williams were among those gaining two victories each yesterday as play in the invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament started at the University Club. They joined fourteen others in reaching the third round.

Local quintets play hosts to squads from the far west tonight as New York University faces Utah State and then St. John's takes on Santa Clara in a double-header at Madison Square Garden. The first of the intersectional duels will get under way at 7:45.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Smithsonian Institution is about to open to public view a collection of rare archaeological finds tracing the history of mankind through 500 centuries. The exhibit provides material support for disputed stories in the Bible.
Following is the report given last night by Arthur H. Dean on the Korean peace conference preliminary talks as recorded by The New York Times:
The forty-second annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $14,913 yesterday in 461 contributions. So far this year the fund has received a total of $199,025.36.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 22 -- Twenty-two American prisoners of the Korean war who have chosen to remain with the Communists refused today to receive a letter from the United Nations Command urging them to come home.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The little Army unit that was struggling against a mountain of World War II secrets two years ago is littler now and so is the mountain.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 21 (AP) -- It will be "secret practice" starting tomorrow for Uncle Sam's Davis Cup tennis team.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 21 -- Sir John Kotelawala, the Prime Minister, charged last night that a large amount of money had been sent to the Communist party in Ceylon by the Soviet Union through Switzerland.

A Queens high school instructor, one of fourteen teachers suspended by the Board of Education for insubordination because of refusal to answer questions concerning Communist party affiliations, declared yesterday at his trial that the charge against him was a "fraud."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Army will clamp down next month on soldiers who have been defrauding the Government of more than $18,000,000 a year through false dependency claims.

Three four-story walk-up apartment buildings at 643 to 647 Franklin Avenue in Brooklyn figured in a quick resale. The properties were purchased from the Java Holding Company by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operator, which immediately conveyed them to Margaret Millus. Arthur Walker as broker negotiated the purchase by the Estate Securities Company.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 20 -- Senator Isauro Torres is leading a crusade in Chile against "justicialismo," the name President Juan Peron of Argentina gives to his political line.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Enrollment in the Air Reserve Officers Training Corps dropped off sharply this fall, from 142,500 in the 1952-53 school year to 120,656 this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -- Dore Schary, vice president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, strongly defended "liberal political philosophy" as a true expression of democratic principles in accepting last night the "Man-of-the-Year" award presented annually by the Beverly Hills B'nai B'rith for outstanding contributions to civic, patriotic and cultural accomplishments.

The world champion New York Yankees will see action in sixteen night games at home in 1954. General Manager George Weiss said yesterday that two Saturday night games had been added to the customary fourteen after-dark clashes.

Coffee prices jumped up the 200-point daily limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in the largest volume since the exchange reopened after World War II. The volume was 163,250 bags.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Anthony (Tony Mike) De Vicenzo, an organizer for the American Federation of Labor's new dock union, lost today his $500,000 suit against three Hoboken police officials who put a twenty-four-hour guard on him.
Three Christmas menus at varying costs have been prepared by the Consumers Service and Research Bureau of the Department of Markets, of which Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon is director.

An American edition of "The Weir," a first novel by a 29-year-old Briton who uses the pseudonym Jane Gillespie, will be published by Coward-McCann on Feb. 19. Set in the Victorian era, the story deals with an adolescent girl who turns to her governess for the understanding and affection she does not receive from her family.

A beautifully decorated Christmas tree is for children as well as grownups a great delight. But often it has been a source of fire and tragedy. This prompts me to write to you about a method of fire-retarding a green tree, be it a spruce or hemlock or fir.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- White and green Christmas trees and pink blossoms made a holiday setting at the Metropolitan Club tonight for the third annual Washington Debutante Ball. Eighteen young women were presented at the fete.
LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The text of a Soviet Government statement on President Eisenhower's atomic energy pool proposals, as distributed today by Tass, official Soviet news agency:

The property at 610 to 614 Eleventh Avenue northeast corner of Forty-fifth Street, has been sold by the Edmere Realty Corporation to George Breslaw. J. P. L. A. Kissling were the brokers in the transaction.

In a glittering holiday decor of silvered smilax, Christmas trees and blue and white crystal stars, the annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Underwritten by Parfums Evyan, the fee was a benefit for the New York Infirmary.

THE wind blew, the waves crashed on the long Clinton Breakwater, spray coated the jagged rocks with sheet ice, and the broadbill were moving up and down the Connecticut shore. In brief, it was perfect weather for breakwater shooting, and most of the shooters were home in their warm beds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that winter wheat growers appeared to have responded to a Government control program for 1954 but that even so they might not make any headway toward reducing the big wheat surplus.

The weather was kind, yesterday noon, as the city gave a typical ticker-tape tribute to 144 convalescing veterans from Korea. The service men included 114 flown here by Navy transport planes from hospitals around the country, and thirty more from hospitals in this area.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 21 -- Mayor Irving C. Freese will meet with executives of the Hat Corporation of America tomorrow to receive their "demand" for greater police protection for workers now employed at the company's plant in the twenty-fourth week of a strike affecting 1,500 regular employes.
ROME, Dec. 21 -- Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce is returning to the United States over the New Year's holidays, having delayed her departure because of the turn taken by political events in Italy.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- Indonesia announced today that she would exchange diplomatic representatives with the Soviet Union and send a delegation to visit Ho Chi Minh, leader of the Communist-led Vietminh fighting the French in Indo-China.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 21 -- A greatly increased use of films and television as "instructional media" was urged here today as a concrete solution to America's critical shortage of teachers. Dr. Henry Chauncey, president of the Educational Testing Service, made the recommendation in his annual report to the organization's trustees.
DENTON, Tex., Dec. 21 (UP) -- W. Jones Hodges, the blind sheriff of Denton County and the Seeing Eye dog he got only ten days ago were struck and killed today by a jeep.
SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 21 (AP) -- A special master recommended today that the Bethlehem Steel Company pay $4,073,124 to past and present stockholders of the Williamsport Wire Rope Company.

" Charley's Aunt," the Brandon Thomas farce, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the City Center with Jose Ferrer in the title role. It will serve as the fourth and final offering of the New York City Theatre Company's current drama season.

" King of the Khyber Rifles." which arrives at the Rivoli, is today's lone film newcomer. The Twentieth Century-Fox period adventure, filmed in the CinemaScope wide-screen process and in Technicolor, features Tyrone Powers, Terry Moore and Michael Rennie.
The Illinois Central Railroad borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday in order to help finance retirement on Feb. 1 of $34,743,000 of 4 3/4 per cent bonds due Aug. 1, 1966.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The State Department announced today the appointment of eighteen new members of the 100-member United States National Commission for UNESCO.
Governor Dewey selected a policeman yesterday to police the state's scandal - tainted trotting tracks. He named New York's Commissioner George P. Monaghan as harness-racing "czar,"
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Kentucky eased by Duke, 85 -- 69, tonight to join La Salle in the final of the first annual University of Kentucky invitation basketball tournament.

Forty-six players from the Dodgers' minor league teams were named to All-Star squads in their respective circuits for 1953, according to Vice President Fresco Thompson. Heading the list of All-Star showings by Brooklyn farmhands were those recorded by members of the Montreal Royals, the Little World Series champions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced tonight the arrest of Thomas E. Dickerson, 30 years old, one of its "ten most wanted men," who is accused of the robbery of a finance company at Bethesda, Md., July 14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Counsel for former Air Force Sgt. Robert W. Toth of Pittsburgh, accused of murdering a South Korean civilian, told the Court of Appeals today that under present law Toth cannot be tried in any court -- military or civilian.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The settlement last week of the nation-wide railroad stirke that was to begin this morning has not brought as much joy in British Government, business and industrial circles as might be expected.

VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 21 -- Premier Joseph Laniel, who has persisted through ten ballots in the French Presidential race, announced tonight that he would withdraw if his supporters could agree on a substitute candidate.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program asked again yesterday for generous gifts of blood in the Christmas season. The donor centers will be closed on Thursday and Christmas Day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Evening-up transactions in December contracts furnished much of the activity on the Board of Trade here today. Irregular trends developed during the session but on the whole trading was orderly.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. announced officially last night the appointment of Richard C. Patterson Jr., a business executive and former diplomat, as chairman of the Mayor's Reception Committee. As had been reported last week, Mr. Patterson will succeed Grover A. Whalen, who has been the city's official greeter for thirty-five years.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- Marshal Tito, the President, declared today that the armies of the Soviet Union and the West were being artificially separated from the people since they were trained "only in a conquering, warring sense."

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 21 -- United States officials have received assurances from Mexico that the recruiting of farm workers will not be halted if the two countries fail to reach a new agreement by the end of the year.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh was sentenced to three years' solitary confinement tonight by a five-man military tribunal for an attempted rebellion against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

Ron Murphy, the Rangers' rookie wingman who was injured in a fracas Sunday night at Madison Square Garden during the New Yorkers' game with the Montreal Canadiens, is out for the season. The team, however, will not be hurt in personnel as much as was at first feared.
Nathan A. Gardner has been appointed manager of air conditioning and refrigeration sales of the export department of Worthington Corporation, Harrison, N. J.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Five Soviet Ministers, including the man reputed now to be in charge of atomic energy development, have been raised to the rank of Deputy Premier, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 21 -- The Mixed Armistice Commission fixed today the blame for the killing last week of two Israeli soldiers on "Jordanian nonregulars," and for the killing of an Arab Legion medical officer on "Israeli nonregulars."

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- J. L. McKnight's Blue Rhymer, a confirmed mudlark, splashed to her first victory of the winter and her fourth of the 1953 season as she annexed the featured seventh race today at Tropical Park.
TRENTON, Dec. 21 -- The New Jersey Legislature today approved and sent to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll for signature a bill designed to assure this state of enough drinking water for the next fifty years.
Following the lead of the American Tariff League, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers has urged the Randall Commission on Foreign Economic Policy to take a stand against trade agreements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The littlest state sued the biggest state and three other king-size commonwealths today to keep them from getting the revenue from oil or other rich resources beneath the marginal waters off their coasts.

VIENNA, Dec. 21 -- The Austrian Government issued tonight a resume of Chancellor Julius Raab's letter to the Committee on Jewish Claims on Austria refusing to pay a lump sum indemnity for heirless property of Jewish victims of nazism.

The National Planning Association's final report in its series of studies on "Causes of Industrial Peace" is an admirable summary of the fundamentals of labor peace. It deserves the attention of everyone who is interested in good labor-management relations. The concluding pamphlet, written after a study of thirty companies and unions, emphasizes that healthy industrial relations involve far more than the absence of conflict.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The official new rules on color television will become effective on Jan. 22, the Federal Communications Commission announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Domestic industrials were fairly firm on the stock markets here today. Main speculative interest was in companies that have declared high dividends and profits recently.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Legislation admitting Hawaii to the Union was assured today of Senate consideration and probable early passage by the shift of a single crucial vote. Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, disclosed that he would vote with the Republicans both in committee and on the floor for the statehood bill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- United States plans to spend about $150,000,000 on construction of four air and naval bases in Spain in the next three years were disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' statement on today's Soviet reply to President Eisenhower's proposal on a pool of atomic-energy resources:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Foreign Operations Administration, said today that industrial and agricultural production in the free nations had reached an all-time high in 1953.
Shipments of steel this year set a new high record for the first ten months of any year.
The Pelham Parkway Jewish Center has given a $125,000 site to Bronx House for a $400,000 community center. The property is at Pelham Parkway South and Bogart and Hone Avenues, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today described the Soviet response to President Eisenhower's atomic proposals as "hopeful."

Bob Feerick of Santa Clara, Frank McGuire of North Carolina and Cecil Baker of Utah State were the chief speakers at the basketball writers' luncheon at Leone's Restaurant yesterday. Each coach presented an informal report of activities in his section.
Governor Dewey gave assurance yesterday that state laws would be passed to make it more difficult for charity racketeers to operate here.

The three Committees for a Free Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania resumed publishing yesterday The Baltic Review, a quarterly that was seized by the Soviet Union when its armies forcibly occupied the three countries in June, 1940.

A syndicate headed by the building firm of Schwartz Karpay has sold the one-story taxpayer at 15-07 122d Street in College Point, Queens, to a client of John Benett, attorney. Sydney M. Siegel Co. were the brokers and Samuel M. Rapps was attorney for the seller.
Indiana came within six points today of being ranked the nation's perfect No. 1 collegiate basketball team in the weekly United Press poll.

TOLEDO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Stockholders of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., have been given until Jan. 15 to decide whether to retain their investment in the company, Ward M. Canaday, president, said today. Physical assets of the company were sold early this year to the Henry J. Kaiser interests.
GENEVA, Dec. 21 -- With a canny eye on the season, the World Health Organization issued a sprightly report today on drinking, drinkers, drinks and drunks.
" Sincere," possibly the most publicized word of advertising jargon, is getting something of a run for its money these days from "QUIET!"

Late shopping Santas are in luck this year. Their packs can be filled to the top with exciting gifts. So wide, varied and imaginative are the assortments in the stores that a last-minute purchase can have the look of a carefully planned gift.

PARIS, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Diplomatic experts of the three Western powers preparing for the Big Four foreign ministers conference in Berlin, still scheduled for Jan. 4, completed their work today. Douglas MacArthur 2d and Sir Frank Roberts, chiefs of the United States and British teams, left for Washington and London.
Fleet Admiral William F. (Bull) Halsey Jr., retired, was admitted last night as a patient to the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.

OTTAWA, Dec. 21 -- Brooke Claxton, Minister of Defense, said today that the North Atlantic Council had decided it would be "unrealistic" to except to build up and maintain increased defense forces in the long run.
VIENNA, Dec. 21 -- That the new economic policy has so far brought chaos rather than order to the agriculture of the Soviet satellites is indicated in Czechoslovakia and Hungary.

A member of the governing committee of the Castle Hill Beach Club in the Bronx testified yesterday before the State Commission Against Discrimination that the club would admit anyone who was "congenial" unless there were specific reasons for rejection.

The recent disclosures of fraud in certain bogus charitable agencies by a committee of the New York State Legislature is a fine and necessary thing. We who participate in the work of the agencies striving to promote worthwhile causes know too well that these charity ghouls make our job so much more difficult.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Stanley V. Smith, 40 years old, left the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary today after looking at the first Christmas tree he had seen in fifteen years. He took with him a souvenir, the white cane he had carried during the time dense cataracts had covered both eyes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has resigned from most of the "several hundred" organizations to which he belonged when he took office.
BEERSHEBA, Israel, Dec. 21 -- A joint program by the United States and Israeli Governments for training technicians for the development of the country was launched here today.

A young Negro Army corporal visiting New York from South Carolina was fatally injured last night in a fight with three men who repeatedly struck him over the head with a baseball bat. The corporal's friend, another Negro, was severely beaten.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- For the fifth consecutive week, the interest rate on the weekly offering of three-month Treasury bills has increased.

Sixty passengers and a crew of five evacuated an American Airlines DC-7 by emergency canvas chute at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday, when one of the craft's engines caught fire on the take-off. None was seriously injured.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Pan American Airways is preparing to take over some of the activities of the Air Force guided missile test program, directed from Patrick Air Force Base, Fla.
Those who receive music records from Santa Claus might bear in mind some reminders, compiled by the R. C. A. Victor concern, on keeping them in good condition.

VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 21 -- Distinguished by his evening dress, with white tie, which only he wore, and seated at the speaker's desk high above the floor, Andre Le Troquer presided today over the two houses of the French Parliament assembled to elect a President of the Republic.

WHEN George Meredith died in 1909 at the age of 81 he was the grand old man of English letters. Young authors had made pious pilgrimages to his home at Box Hill and listened reverently to the glittering conversation of the handsomest old man in England. Publishers squabbled over the rights to his books. Young intellectuals admired him as a matter of conscience and literary young women adored him.
Clarence Henry, Los Angeles heavyweight, gained the unanimous decision over Bob Baker of Pittsburgh in the featured clash of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 21 -- World mine production of tin concentrates in October was 15,500 long tons, compared with 14,900 in September.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Lee Kyung Soo, the Korean war waif adopted by Chief Boatswain's Mate Vincent J. Paladino, came home today in happy wonder.
PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Dec. 21 -- A driver's wrong turn on the road will mean a turn for the better on Christmas morning for a state colony of mentally retarded boys in South Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today that some Democrats in Congress had served notice that they would demand a close check of all postmaster nominations next year to see if vacancies resulted from "undue pressure" on Democratic incumbents.
A collection of jewelry designed by Salvador Dali in both his surrealist phase and his "mystico-nuclear" phase was purchased recently by the Catherwood Foundation of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- The next-to-last phase of the Government's historic anti-trust suit against the du Pont family of Delaware and three of the country's largest corporations was completed today before Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court here.
Flames shooting from the smokestack of a tugboat brought three police launches, a fireboat and Coast Guard craft to its rescue last night in New York Harbor.

Extended holidays in the steel industry and production cutbacks attributed to slackened demand are expected to slash steel-making operations to 66.6 per cent of theoretical capacity this week in the sharpest production curtailment for any Christmas week since 1945.

Senator Charles E. Potter, chairman of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Subcommittee on the Merchant Marine, will introduce in Congress next month a resolution calling for a treaty with Canada to limit shipping between her ports and ours on the Great Lakes to the two nations if the St. Lawrence Seaway should be built.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The theory that the primeval cave pictures of Southwestern Europe were spray-painted at least 10,000 years ago has been put forward here by Dr. Edward Hindle, a fellow of the Royal Society and former director of the London zoo who has been studying the art of the paleolithic man.
CURITIBA, Brazil, Dec. 21 (UP) -- President Getulio Vargas announced today that the Brazilian Government was preparing to establish a national electric power industry.

BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- A United States soldier charged with two successive desertions to the East and attempts to lure others soldiers into defection was sentenced today to thirteen years at hard labor and dishonorable discharge from the United States Army.

An American who returned from the Soviet Union yesterday reported that Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party chief, had told him that the Soviet looked forward to challenging the West economically by becoming increasingly a competitor in world trade and by rapidly improving its domestic industry and standard of living.
DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Heavily armed police, acting on a tip to a newspaper man, today captured three dangerous criminals who broke out of Southern Michigan Prison Saturday night.

The Port of New York Authority urged the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to grant Seatrain Lines, Inc., a permanent certificate to operate between the ports of New York and Savannah, Ga.
