The steamship company, which transports loaded railroad cars, now is operating over the route on a temporary authority.

Business volume in the city next year will be as good as in 1953, or better, particularly in the first six months. This is the consensus of 283 top executives reached in a survey conducted by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

The Indonesian Information Office here reported yesterday that its Government had rejected applications by rubber companies for export licenses on proposed shipments to Communist China. The companies, it was said, sought licenses shortly after receipt of news earlier this month that an Indonesian mission to Peiping had reached preliminary agreement on a China trade treaty.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- United States figures show that free world shipments to Communist China were on the downgrade in the second half of this year.

PARIS, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A French airport strike stopped all United States military transport flights in and out of Paris today and cut into Christmas holiday plans for many American soldiers in Europe.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21 -- A British diplomatic mission arrived in Teheran this afternoon following the repair of the thirteen-month break in relations between Iran and Britain. Upon landing at Mehrabad Airport, Dennis Arthur Wright, the new Charge d'Affaires, pledged "to do everything to promote goodwill and solve our common problems."

Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Stillman of 1 East End Avenue gave a dinner dance last night in the Georgian Suite, 1A East Seventy-seventh Street, for their debutante niece, Miss Kathleen Hodgsdon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard T. Hodgsdon of Guatemala City.
Volume increased on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and the number of issues traded was the largest for any day since Sept. 15.
Dr. and Mrs. Leslie E. Morrissett of Greenwich, Conn., entertained with a dinner dance last nigh in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for their debutante daughter. Miss Clover Ann Morrissett.
John and Alexander Dalessio, brothers known as Johnny Dee and Pope Dee, and seven henchmen, pleaded guilty to gambling conspiracy charges yesterday.
DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A "thinking duel" should add spice to Sunday's pro football championship game in Briggs Stadium.
The young and the old, the healthy and the afflicted and the rich and the poor took part in pre-Christmas activities throughout the city yesterday.

IT was natural for a distant observer to assume that professional foot racing in Australia was completely on the up-and-up. Otherwise, it was felt, it would have died off just as the cash and carry sport died in this country back near the turn of the century. It was so stated in this space. But it ain't necessarily so.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- An increase of as much as 10 per cent in the sales of the Consolidated Grocers Corporation was predicted today for the current fiscal year by Nathan Cummings of Chicago, chairman of the board. The volume in the year ended on June 30 was $212,000,000.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Soviet Union tonight expressed its readiness to negotiate with the United States on the control of atomic materials.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21 -- Yugoslavia has accepted an Albanian bid for the resumption of normal diplomatic relations. The reopening soon of the respective legations in Belgrade and Tirana is expected.

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 21 -- A 19-year-old youth whose automobile killed the father of six small children last August was found innocent today of any criminal negligence by a jury of eight women and four men who deliberated ninety minutes.

Directors of the Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., announced yesterday the election of William H. Draper Jr. as a director. Next April 1 Mr. Draper, former United States Special Representative in Europe with the rank of Ambassador, will succeed George S. Messersmith as chairman and chief executive officer of the utility. Mr. Messersmith, who had requested that he be relieved of his duties, will remain on the board as honorary chairman.

New Lincoln's basketball team outscored Loyola High School, 65 -- 63, on the New Lincoln court yesterday but lost the game, 59 -- 58. A lapse on the part of the officials had permitted play to continue after a lay-up shot by Loyola's John Daly in a "sudden-death" over-time had legally terminated the contest.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 21 (AP) -- After a hearing in United States District Court here, Judge Edward W. Day today took under advisement a Government motion aimed at restraining the merger of the Wallace Tiernan Company, Inc., and Novadel-Agene Corporation, both of Belleville, N. J., until a civil anti-trust suit against them and others has been disposed of.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. predicted yesterday that the 1954 election campaign would be "dirty, demagogic and in the gutter."

Chief Inspector Conrad E. Rothengast ordered a "full investigation" last night into a report that a black limousine escorted by four motorcycle patrolmen sped through a red traffic light, indirectly causing an accident in which four persons were injured, one fatally.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- The French airport strike, in its third day, saw approximately thirty planes arrive or depart at Orly Field out of a normal average of 180. At Le Bourget the normal activity of fifty planes arriving or leaving daily was cut to seven.

The Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency has allocated another $20,000,000 to the city to advance the slum clearance program. The grant brings to $60,000,000 the Federal contribution to Title I projects here.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and closing prices on active months were 4 to 11 points higher than Friday.
John L. Lewis threw his protective mantle yesterday around the orphaned International Longshoremen's Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The White House and the chairman of the Civil Service Commission, Philip Young, declared today that there was nothing new in a plan for each Government agency to appoint its own specialist to handle patronage problems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The last of the thirteen original states to enter the Union, Rhode Island, today asked the Supreme Court to hold invalid the act of Congress which assigned to younger maritime states, notably California, Florida, Louisiana and Texas, the right to revenues from the produce of their submerged lands as far as their historic boundaries.

Councilman Abraham Sussman's bill restricting taxicabs to small stock models is important in the over-all struggle to alleviate the big squeeze. There is no doubt that next to mass transportation and to essential business traffic the taxicab performs the greatest public service in the city and should be given first priority.

There is a disconcerting and odd thing to be found in the mail order catalogues, the advertisements and the lists of gift suggestions for Christmas. It is that while Mother should receive things that stress "labor saving" and "step saving," the gloomy entity known as Dad is subject to gifts that are "handy."

A pleasant and unusual program was offered in Town Hall last evening by a five-voice ensemble called the Carolers. The group consists of Penny Perry, soprano, and a male quartet, Leo Bernache and Russell Hammar, tenors; Jonathan Wilson, baritone, and Eric Carlson, bass-baritone. Paul Ulanowsky was at the piano.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- The Marquette Cement Manufacturing Company announced today the outright purchase, effective Jan. 1, of the Superior Cement Division of the New York Coal Company, Superior, Ohio, and of Southern States Portland Cement Company, Rockmart, Ga. The acquisition, the company said, will rank Marquette among the country's five largest cement companies.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) -- The Rosenberg children, Michael, 10 years old, and Robert, 4, are not wanted by anyone in the United States, Emanuel H. Bloch, defense lawyer for their parents, said yesterday.

Six-year-old Alice Fitzpatrick of 712 108th Street, Brooklyn, accepted yesterday on behalf of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation a check for $250 from the Police Department Charity Fund. The check represented the 25,000th contribution to the foundation, of which Alice, a victim of rheumatoid arthritis, is honorary poster girl.
Triplets were brought into the world by Caesarean section at Fort Jay, Governors Island, shortly before midnight on Sunday.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- Britain's two major liberal newspapers. The Manchester Guardian and The London News Chronicle, welcomed today indications that President Eisenhower's leadership was entering a new and stronger phase.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- Britain's two major liberal newspapers. The Manchester Guardian and The London News Chronicle, welcomed today indications that President Eisenhower's leadership was entering a new and stronger phase.

This country's planners of economic foreign policy were urged yesterday not to lose sight of the economic and military importance of a strong American merchant marine in making their report to the President.

If the maximum capital gains tax rate had been cut to 12 1/2 per cent and the holding period to three months, 1953 Federal tax revenues would have jumped at least $200,000,000, according to the new president of the National Association of Investors Brokers.

North American Aviation, Inc., had a net income of $12,773,361, or $3.72 a share, for the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30, as compared with $7,820,886, or $2.28 a share, in the preceding fiscal year, J. H. Kindelberger, board chairman, reported yesterday.

One of the best methods of successfully selling a foreign country's special products in the United States is through a cooperative ad campaign, says Ehrling Forgaard, vice president of the Norwegian Canners Association.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 21 -- The Bolivian Government announced today an amnesty for 271 political prisoners and forty-seven Bolivian political exiles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Arthur H. Dean, President Eisenhower's special envoy to the talks for arranging a Korean peace conference, reported tonight that the outlook for permanent peace in Korea was "discouraging, but by no means hopeless."

The long and bitter struggle to elect a President has dramatized for the whole world the true gravity of the French situation. France is indeed, in Paul Reynaud's striking attribution, "the Sick Man of Europe."

During the Christmas vacation, children of this city who are denied the winter activities of their country cousins may find exhibits and programs here planned for their entertainment. Although these are all within the distance of a subway ride, they might "transport" a youngster to Alaska, British Columbia, back in time to 1895, or out in space to the moon.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 21 -- This western Massachusetts industrial city of 160,000 is the new home of seven of the eight Czechs who bluffed their way from behind the Iron Curtain in a bogus "tank" last July 28.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board abandoned today a landmark doctrine dealing with "free speech."
S. C. Johnson Son, Inc., wax manufacturers, has announced the election of William N. Connolly as a vice president and Willard G. Aschenbrener as a board member.

One can dismiss the notes of protest against American talks with Pakistan about military aid that came from the Soviet Union and Red China as merely the expected insolence. Pakistan has answered the Soviet Union firmly and properly and will doubtless take the same course with Peiping. One can be patient with the Indian official expression of concern and try to find the proper way to give India reassurance.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 21 (UP) -- A ten-inch strip of cloth that glows in the dark may help reduce the number of pedestrians killed by motor cars. A campaign is spreading in this area to put the ribbons on everyone who goes out after dark.
TRENTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state's Fair Trade Act covered products sold in interstate as well as intrastate commerce.
Mrs. George Herman Ruth, widow of the great Babe, yesterday disclosed that she planned to launch a radio and television show in memory of baseball's home-run king.

The F. L. Jacobs Company, manufacturer of automotive parts and accessories, had a net profit of about $474,000 in the four months ended with last November, in contrast to a loss of $43,125 sustained in the similar period of 1952, F. B. Howard, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

Instructions for the dock balloting to be conducted today and tomorrow by the National Labor Relations Board were issued last night, by Benjamin B. Naumoff, chief examiner in the board's regional office.

Retailers will be scanning the skies this week. Given good weather New York City's stores may come close to meeting last year's record Christmas totals -- guesses range from 2 to 4 per cent below 1952. Rain or heavy snow could increase this deficit. There are few who anticipate meeting last year's totals.

I have had forty-six years' very close connection with India. Since the war each year I have been spending six months in India and six months in America. I would like to register some convictions and make some suggestions.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 21 -- A labor-management committee to campaign against organized gambling in New Jersey industrial plants has been formed here, United States Attorney William F. Tompkins announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- High British officials reacted with guarded optimism tonight to the Soviet Union's offer to engage in conversations with the United States and other nations principally concerned with the manufacture and disposal of atomic and hydrogen materials.
To a great many officers and men in our armed forces, Christmas will not be very merry this year.
Elmer Davis, radio and television news analyst, has been named for the 1953 Lauterbach Award, it was announced yesterday by the Authors Guild of the Authors League of America, Inc.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by Clinton Foods, Inc., and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended with last September, according to the report released yesterday.
Fifteen hundred Sanitation Department employes who have been working overtime as a result of the strike by private refuse collectors called on the city last night to hire extra temporary help.

Twelve Massachusetts municipal housing authorities will receive bids on Dec. 29 on issues of state-guaranteed notes to finance housing projects temporarily. The Boston Authority is borrowing $14,287,000 of the total, $10,887,000 coming due on Jan. 25, 1955, and $3,400,000 on July 26, 1955.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that if it was true that the Soviet Union had agreed to talks on President Eisenhower's proposal to poll nuclear material for peacetime uses the response was "encouraging."
A silent -- almost somber -- mass of men went from the piers to the polls yesterday to vote for a union of their own choosing.

Two young men were arrested early yesterday morning and charged with beating a veteran of Korea to death on Monday night in a quarrel about a trivial automobile accident. A third youth, who had accompanied the defendants but had not joined the fight, was held as a material witness.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Richmond found a manager for its projected entry in the Class AAA International League today and then turned its attention back to the task of assuring him a team to manage.

RIJEKA, Yugoslavia, Dec. 22 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia is launching a ten-year building program to expand her underdeveloped merchant marine and at the same time is considering plans to decentralize her shipping, now concentrated in this northern Adriatic port, known as Fiume under Italian rule until 1945.

News dispatches in recent days have been sounding alarms about the political situation in Italy. There is certainly something to worry about, but the probabilities are that the Christian Democratic party, which dominates governmental politics, will pull itself together and avoid a crisis for the time being.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic priest today told young guests at the annual Christmas party of his parish school there is no Santa Claus.

Dr. C. J. Blanford, market administrator of the New York metropolitan milk marketing area, forecast yesterday a uniform price of $4.59 a hundredweight (46.5 quarts) for December milk deliveries to New York pool-approved plants.

Sparkling silver and glistening glassware set against shiny snow-like plastic create an appropriate holiday atmosphere for an exhibition opening at the Museum of Modern Art today. The thirty-seven objects -- all acquired since June, 1948 -- were selected from 2,500 items in the permanent design collection of the museum.

A MIDDLE-AGED lady, recognized by other passengers on a southbound No. 2 Fifth Avenue bus yesterday as a regular rider, like themselves, came aboard aglow with Christmas spirit. She put her fare in the box, then moved among the passengers collecting contributions for the driver, and triumphantly announced the total -- $7.40, mostly in small coins.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Seventy-five stockholders of Puget Sound Power and Light Company, holding almost 150,000 shares, filed a bill in equity in Suffolk Superior Court today to compel company management to permit their inspection of the stockholders list.

SHIRLEY, L. I., Dec. 22 -- An anonymous letter received at the Westover Air Force Base at Chicopee Falls, Mass., resulted today in the discovery of a man's body in a shallow grave here. The letter indicated that the man, who was not identified immediately, had been the victim of a hunting accident.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 23 -- The twenty-two United States prisoners of the Korean war who have thus far chosen to remain with their Communist captors heard today a final appeal from the United Nations Command to return to their homes and families and apparently rejected it.

The Lodge Shipley Company, Cincinnati, producer of lathes and metal-turning equipment, will acquire through merger the Columbia Machinery and Engineering Corporation of Hamilton, Ohio, producer of shears, brakes and presses.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 22 -- Three border incidents were reported tonight by the Israeli Army. One concerned Israeli fishing boats, an Egyptian warship and an Israeli plane.

MADRID, Dec. 22 -- The United States Economic Mission to Spain, which is supervising the application of defense support aid, has been told by the Spanish Government to abstain from direct contact with business men and to deal directly with Spanish officials.

Seventy-five Department of Sanitation employes assembled in the office of Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain yesterday to receive their promotions to ranks ranging from assistant foreman to district superintendent.

McNair Ilgenfritz did not live to see it, but it is almost certain that one of his operas will have a premiere at the Metropolitan Opera. The American composer, it appeared yesterday, had achieved the dream of a lifetime by means of his will.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Kentucky checked La Salle's Tom Gola and turned loose its own Cliff Hagan tonight to win, 73 -- 60, and gain the championship in the Wildcats' first invitation basketball tournament.

A model is planned for a large parcel of land which has just figured in a real estate transaction in Montauk, L. I. The property, purchased by Mrs. Felcietta Corrado of Jackson Heights, Queens, from the Seacliffs Corporation, is on South Elmwood Avenue, 100 feet west of South Edgemere Street, facing the Montauk Highway. Alan A. Stevenson, vice president of the Montauk Beach Company, was the broker in the transaction.

MIAMI, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Zeke Bratkowski of Georgia will quarterback the South forces and Roy Evans of Purdue will direct the attack of the North team in the Shrine's College All-Star football game Christmas night.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 22 (AP) -Stockholders of the Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company voted overwhelmingly today to approve the sale of the company to the Harrisburg (Pa.) Steel Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Preparations for the Christmas holiday took over at the White House today.

SPOKANE, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Washington Water Power Company reaffirmed its willingness yesterday "to work out any fair merger agreement" with the Puget Sound Power and Light Company if Puget shareholders so desire.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The United States said today it might reverse its position and participate in "a modified program" to maintain a chain of weather ships in the North Atlantic.

Harvard sent two of its representatives into the semi-final bracket of the invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament yesterday at the University Club. Princeton and Williams gained the other positions in the round of four.
The price of coffee is steaming steadily upward.

The police motorcycles whose screaming sirens caused a motorist to lose control of the wheel in a fatal accident on Sunday were escorting a stand-in for a television clown from a children's Christmas party in Queens under police sponsorship to one in Manhattan.

TORONTO, Dec. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Henry Borden, president of the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, said today that it did not surprise him "that the President of Brazil should propose an over-all Federal power program to meet the needs of Brazil as a whole."

NEWARK, Dec. 22 -- Two New York business men "picketed" an Eastern Air Lines plane for thirty-five minutes at the airport today in protest against being denied seats on a Miami-bound plane for which they said they had reservations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Western diplomatic observers doubt that the threat of Premier Giuseppe Pella of Italy to resign will lead to anything "dramatic," at least in the next few weeks.
POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., Dec. 22 (AP) -- An explosion ripped apart an empty petroleum barge at an Ohio River dock today, killing six men.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Congress still may be asked to exempt baseball's broadcast and telecast rules from the Federal antitrust laws, Senator Edwin C. Johnson said today.

During the past twenty years or so I have heard or read many hundreds of political speeches. Never, but never, have I ever been so revolted by a speech as by the one delivered by Gov. Thomas Dewey this week in Hartford. I'm not thin skinned about American politics; I don't expect speeches to be models of objectivity and good manners.
A small but handsome exhibit of home furnishing from Sweden is on view at Modernage, 16 East Thirty-fourth Street. The display was arranged by the design firm of Spencer-Steinhauser.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The nation's hog producers are planning a cautious increase in pork production next year after allowing output to dip this year to the lowest level in five years, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- An Air Force officer who said his loyalty was questioned apparently because of his brother's activities won Air Force clearance today. The action involved Lieut. Thomas Shepard of Cleveland, a 29-year-old veteran of the Korean war.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan moves from one tough job into another with his appointment by Governor Dewey to clean up the harness-racing game. He will take office Jan. 1 as a Moreland Act Commissioner and become a one-man czar of the trotting tracks about Feb. 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- "Carmen Jones," the modernized Oscar Hammerstein 2d adaptation of the opera "Carmen," will be brought to the screen in Cinema-Scope by Otto Preminger, who today completed a production and distribution deal with Twentieth Century-Fox.
RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Bevo Francis scored 34 points as Rio Grande met its toughest test of the season and went down to defeat tonight, 92 -- 77, before North Carolina State College.

The Dec. 30 deadline designated last month by Argentina for foreign-owned investments in enterprises in the South American republic evidently has caused so much apprehension among financial institutions in Argentina and abroad that the authorities are soft-pedaling it, at least so far as its application to non-Argentine banks is concerned.
The New York State Controller's Office resumed yesterday the outright purchase of local school district bond issues by underbidding banking syndicates in the open market.

Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges but only coffee closed lower in all positions. Cocoa, sugar, burlap, copper, tin, lead, wool and potatoes were mixed and hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and rubber were higher.
BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, underwent surgery today for the removal of a cyst from his left kidney.

As a new Christmas approaches the world has again been stirred by hope that the cold war is yielding to a more temperate climate and that the specter of atomic war has begun to recede before a new promise of peace. This hope, still fragile, was born of the armistice in Korea which, however precarious, was nevertheless accepted as a first test of Communist willingness to confer rather than to fight.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Masanobu Tsuji, a former colonel and one of Japan's most brilliant military strategists in World War II, warned the United States today to pull its troops out of Japan as soon as possible or "the day will come when it will regret it."

The office of City Treasurer in the administration of Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. will be filled by George M. Bragalini, former Acting Postmaster of New York and a vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles compared the twenty-two United States prisoners in Korea who have renounced their homeland to the "lost sheep" of the Gospels.

An Air Force light bomber took off early today from the Mitchel Air Force Base at Garden City, L. I., to convey a nerve specialist to Florence, S. C., on a mission of mercy. The flight was ordered by Air Force authorities after efforts to obtain commercial air transportation for the specialist had failed.
Four elderly persons and a dog were found dead early yesterday morning in an apartment at 140 First Avenue. They had been asphyxiated by gas.
Martin Hover, a centenarian from Binghamton, N. Y., visited the Empire State's biggest city yesterday for the first time since 1904.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has made a first mortgage loan of $15,000,000 on the new twenty-five-story office building at 380 Madison Avenue, built and owned by Uris Building, Inc., whose principals are Pery and Harold Uris.
Four liners carried 1,970 Caribbean-bound passengers out of fog shrouded New York harbor yesterday in the busiest day so far of the present cruise season.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- The State Crime Commission is about ready to bow out as a public agency after spending two and a half years and nearly $950,000 in rooting out organized crime and political corruption in the state.

EUGENE, Ore., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A young Oregon State team upset Indiana, the National Collegiate A. A. defender and ranked No. 1 in The Associated Press poll, 67 -- 51, in an intersectional basketball double-header tonight.
A motto for the new armed forces being developed under Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson was furnished in a recent report of an ad hoc Pentagon committee.
DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 22 -- Duke University announced today receipt of a $105,000 grant from the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company "to study anything in relation to the production of tobacco.

FOSTERS, Mich., Dec. 22 (AP) Eugene L. Inman, who felt the hand of God in the battlefields of Korea and through the cold, hungry horror of a Communist prisoner-of-war camp, has decided to dedicate his life to the ministry.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 22 -- The Chilean and Argentine governments began negotiations today to implement the Act of Santiago and the Treaty of Economic Union signed by the Presidents of the two countries earlier this year.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The Soviet Union cannot accept any feasible suggestion for German unity by the Western powers at a foreign ministers' conference, because of military and political considerations in Russia and Eastern Europe, according to a top-level assessment here.
PARIS, Dec. 22 -- The Communist-led Postal Union and an independent group called all Post Office workers out on strike tonight until 8 o'clock Christmas night.

The last appeals are now being made to the twenty-two American prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return home. The time for explanations is running out. For reasons which no one now knows and which perhaps no one will ever know, this little group of G. I.'s is making its "most fateful decision."
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) increased its board membership to fourteen with the election yesterday of Peter T. Lamont and Howard W. Page as directors, effective on Jan. 1.

VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 22 -- Premier Joseph Laniel announced his withdrawal from the long-deadlocked French Presidential race late tonight after a day of acrimonious conferences among party leaders.
Hearts beat faster yesterday and footsteps were accelerated in the pre-Christmas whirl.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Jack Dunn 3d today ended his family ownership of the city's professional baseball team by formally signing legal papers turning over the Baltimore Orioles to a new American League club. The Dunn family had promoted baseball in Baltimore for forty-four years.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 22 -- The Town Council has adopted a resolution asking the end of segregation in local schools. Copies are to be sent to President Eisenhower.

ENCOURAGED, possibly, by the success of the fabulous "chirkendoose," a frowsty fowl formed of equal parts of chicken, turkey duck and goose, biologists of the Ontario Department of Lands and Forests have finally produced the "splake," a hybrid game fish that is a cross between the speckled trout (brook trout) and the togue.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The stock markets here appeared heartened by the Soviet government's agreement to discuss President Eisenhower's proposals on control of atomic energy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The National Football League teams closed the 1953 season with the biggest dollar profit in history, a survey showed today, with television receipts a major factor in a successful season financially.
New York City will have next year a "program budget," which will list the services performed by the various city departments and the cost of each service.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- A Woolaston, Mass., man with a long criminal record was indicted with his wife and son in two counts each today by a Federal grand jury in connection with the $681,000 robbery of an armored truck in Danvers, Mass., March 25, 1952.

Today's new film is "Bad for Each Other," a Columbia drama with Charlton Heston, Lizabeth Scott and Dianne Foster, at the Palace. Irving Rapper directed and William Fadiman served as associate producer of the offering, which Horace McCoy and Irving Wallace adapted from Mr. McCoy's original story.

WOR-TV, now operating from its new antenna atop the Empire State Building, is station not afraid to chart its own course in TV and this season has displayed both common sense and artistic imagination in regularly employing Negro actors for one of its major programs.
Democratic state legislators from New York County approved yesterday a program pledging full support to the plans of Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. for expanded taxing powers and greater state aid.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- A compromise Western proposal on the Jordan question bogged down completely today in the United Nations Security Council. Not only were the Western powers unable to get a vote on their proposal, but they decided that the only hope of getting it approved was to change it to meet Arab objections to the key provision.

The introduction of color in television will step up the use of spot advertising on the nation's stations in community markets, Joseph J. Weed, president of Weed Television, station representatives predicts.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Russell-Miller Milling Company today received letters from company executives saying the surprise offer by F. H. Peavey Co., a grain company, to buy the company's common stock at $36 a share was less than half the book value.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 22 (UP) -- Verne Lewellen, a former Green Bay football player and one of the game's star punters, today was named the first general manager in the Packers' thirty-five years.

J. Francis Gorski, assistant to the president of Intertype Corporation, has been elected secretary effective Jan. 1. He succeeds Frank Hoffmann, who continues as vice president in charge of export sales.

Dock workers swarmed to the polls yesterday to decide whether the old International Longshoremen's Association or its American Federation of Labor rival should speak for pier labor in the Port of New York.
James H. Purdy Jr. has been appointed merchandise manager and Norman S. Bernie sales manager for consumer fabrics of the textile division of the United States Rubber Company.

Jonathan Daniels, author of "The Man of Independence," has a new work on Lippincott's list for May. Entitled "The End of Innocence," the book presents a personal, political and social history of the era in America from the inauguration of Woodrow Wilson to the end of the New Deal.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of United Nations Command broadcast to twenty-two American prisoners who chose communism, made on the final day for repatriation permitted by the Korean armistice:

Employment opportunities for nearly 200,000 Korean war veterans in this state have been so good that only 14,500 have applied for Federal unemployment compensation since it became available to them in October, 1952.

Teen-agers take little party in family money management and have little interest or desire to do so, according to the findings of a pilot study on this subject. The results of the study, conducted among a group of middle-class parents and their junior or senior high-school age children, appear in the latest issue of Marriage and Family Living, a journal published by the National Council on Family Relations.

May I express appreciation and admiration for John N. Popham's excellent story, "School Bias Issue Divides the South," which appeared in the Dec. 14 issue of The Times. Once again Mr. Popham demonstrates that he is one of America's best reporters.

This is a season of knot-tying; many and wondrous are the knots to be seen on parcels being carried to post offices for mailing to relatives and friends and accompanied by the hope that knots, twine, wrapping and parcel itself will arrive together at their destination.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Marron of 322 East Fifty-seventh Street gave a buffet dinner with dancing last night in their home for their debutante niece, Miss Eugenie Marie Krauss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Krauss of Short Hills, N. J.

The "bears" had the better of the argument in Wall Street yesterday. Stocks suffered their widest break since mid-September. Although for a while during the final hour it looked as if there would be a late recovery, the improved sentiment was short lived and prices closed at about their lows of the day.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A 12-year-old local boy soprano who has played leading roles on nationally televised operas performed tonight with his mother and father in the supporting cast.

A contribution of $10,000 from the Arthur Murray Foundation was received yesterday by the forty-second annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The gift was the largest among the 757 that brought $28,643.05 to the campaign for the day.

ROME, Dec. 22 -- The Christian Democratic party directorate declared today that the "regrettable incident" precipitated on Sunday by Premier Giuseppe Pella's complaint that he had not received sufficient support from his own party was now closed.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 22 -- Steps toward reorganization of India's twenty-eight states on the basis of local language and other considerations will begin soon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the United States was willing to talk confidentially with the Soviet Union about any and all proposals for ending the peril of atomic war.

Further evidence that the Dodgers aim to bring down the Yankees, should the pair meet again in next October's world series, came to light yesterday. The Brooks have engaged Ted Lyons to round out Manager Walter Alston's coaching staff for 1954, with special emphasis on handling the pitchers.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Michigan State football squad adhered to its two-a-day drill schedule today but the U. C. L. A. Bruins came up with a mild surprise in their Rose Bowl practice when Coach Red Sanders cut the work to once daily.

With Eddie Lopat, Billy Pierce, Whitey Ford and Mel Parnell sharing mound laurels with such right-handers as Bob Porterfield, Virgil Trucks and Bob Lemon, southpaws took top billing in the junior loop's 1953 parade, according to official American League pitching records released yesterday.

The American Rayon Institute, successor to the Rayon Information Center, will open temporary offices at 350 Fifth Avenue shortly after Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Wood, executive director. The institute, he said, will move into permanent headquarters by May 1.

Reflecting a substantial rise in operating revenues, net income of Middle South Utilities, Inc., for the twelve months ended on last November 30 increased to $14,187,723 from $12,382,249 a year earlier.

George F. Chapline. vice president of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation and general manager of its engine division on Long Island, told yesterday how the division's backlog had been increased from $1,900,000 just after the war to $100,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -The Army Transportation Corps reported today that 6,329 service men and women were arriving by ship from foreign points today and tomorrow to spend the holidays at their homes.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, who retires next week after nearly five years as Commissioner of Hospitals, reports as his "greatest failure" his inability "to obtain adequate salary adjustments for the professional and technical workers of the department."

New York City consented yesterday in Supreme Court to stay until Jan. 13 further action on its proposed loyalty examination of city employes through a "security questionnaire." The case was called for a hearing by Justice Matthew M. Levy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat, of Mississippi, hinted today at a Southern filibuster against Hawaii statehood legislation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations accused the National Labor Relations Board today of writing anti-labor amendments into the Taft-Hartley law.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- A House of Commons committee charged today that efforts to develop a nationwide civil defense program in Britain had been marked by lack of leadership, persistent overestimating of expenditures and "lack of drive."

To celebrate the conclusion of an exhausting drama season, Mr. Ferrer is now romping through "Charley's Aunt," which opened at the City Center last evening. Old and creaky though Brandon Thomas' farce may be, it makes a good holiday on both sides of the footlights.

Some European observers are concerned about the possibility of a 1954 slide in business and employment in this country. This is not particularly surprising, since a setback of even moderate dimensions in the United States could have major consequences to the smaller and for the most part more stratified economies of these countries.

VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- Whether or not the great powers permit Austria to be represented at the forth-coming Berlin conference of foreign ministers, she will send an unofficial delegation of Foreign Office officials there. If the great powers permit, an official delegation headed by members of the Government will be sent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, former Philippine representative to the United Nations, said today that the Soviet response to President Eisenhower's atomic proposal had merely opened the door for "another talkathon."

SAMUEL ELIOT MORISON, retired rear admiral of the United States Navy and Professor of History at Harvard, is one of the most distinguished of living American historians. His many works include the best book yet written on Christopher Columbus, "Admiral of the Ocean Sea," which was awarded a Pulitzer prize, and the first eight volumes of a projected fourteen-volume "History of United States Naval Operations in World War II."
Robert Morris, chief counsel for the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, took the oath of office yesterday as a Municipal Court Justice.

A festive note, and a flavorful one, may be added to holiday meals by serving dishes that include wine and liqueurs. Even the simplest foods often are enhanced by a tablespoon or more of a cooking wine or brandy and the housewife need consider this departure no more mysterious than the addition of vanilla extract.
The Transit Authority was exploring yesterday the possibility of getting an injunction against a strike on the city-owned lines.

Seventy-four sponsors of the National Committee to Repeal the McCarran Acts sent an open letter yesterday to members of the Senate Judiciary Committee assailing a proposed amendment to the Internal Security (McCarran) Act of 1950 that would cover trade unions.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- An important military undertaking has been agreed upon in substance by two North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers, Greece and Turkey, and their neighbor, the independent and anti-Soviet Communist country of Yugoslavia.

FORT MYERS, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Connie Mack, straight as an arrow and looking in tip-top shape, today celebrated his ninety-first birthday. He looked even better than he did at his last birthday here.
The Radio Corporation of America will begin a series of color television clinics next month to instruct receiver manufacturers, distributors and service men in the servicing of color sets.

GARDEN CITY PARK, L. I., Dec. 22 -- Business differences between two former partners who had become competitors resulted late today in a shooting here in which one of the men and his brother were wounded, the police reported.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board declined today to allow the non-scheduled airlines and the all-cargo airlines to carry mail.
Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden, yesterday called for liberalization of regulations governing the present player draft in the National Hockey League.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Inventory adjustments are responsible for an easing in production which has become evident recently.
Widespread dissatisfaction faces the Communist regime in Hungary, Nicholas de Kallay, former Hungarian Premier, said yesterday as he arrived from Italy to take up permanent residence here.
ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- In his annual Christmas gesture of clemency, Governor Dewey commuted the prison sentences of two murderers and one robber today, making them eligible for parole and freedom.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 22 -- The carillon bells of the First Presbyterian Church were heard round the world tonight in a Christmas program beamed by short wave.
William Wyer, trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, said yesterday that the bankrupt railroad had become a victim of "the automobile age."

GENEVA, Dec. 22 -- As if to show their squabbling French neighbors how such things ought to be done, the Swiss Parliament not only elected a new President of the Confederation today but resolved a ministerial "crisis."

IT'S quite possible that Paul Brown, the brooding genius who coaches the Cleveland Browns, has finally produced his masterpiece. There are many sideline observers who are firmly convinced that Cleveland's professional football forces, 1953 vintage, add up to the best team Brown ever has assembled. Maybe we'll know more about it before nightfall Sunday because the Browns face the Detroit Lions for the championship that afternoon.

The Metropolitan entries had to settle for an even break in last night's intersectional basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. New York University came through with an 86-67 victory over Utah State in the opener, but St. John's was outscrambled by Santa Clara, 62 -- 60, in the finale.
New York's first full day of official winter was on the balmy side yesterday, with temperatures in the upper forties, but snow flurries were predicted for this morning.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 22 -- Iran's Military Court of Appeals will review the sentence of three years' solitary confinement passed last night upon Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh. A military tribunal had convicted the former Premier of rebellion against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but steady yesterday and closing prices were 3 points higher to 4 points lower than on Monday.

NEWARK, Dec. 22 -- One of the few facts that all concerned agreed upon was that there was more fuel oil in John Anderson's truck than the tank at the National Newark and Essex Bank Building at 744 Broad Street would hold.

The West German Government's announced increase to 500 Deutsche marks ($119) a month in restitution payments to victims of Nazi persecution living abroad will go, as previously, only to persons certified as qualified to receive them by the German consular force.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 2 -Throughout the seven-state Tennessee Valley the 148 municipal and cooperative distributors of power generated in the Tennessee Valley Authority system now serve 1,300,000 consumers. There were only 275,000 consumers of electricity in the area in 1933, when T. V. A. was cretated.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Commission buying of both grains and soybeans broadened after early weakness today, with a much stronger tone developing. Shorts apparently were encouraged to increase their lines because of the early softness and as commission concerns took up the siack in the pits, the bears took to cover.

For several months before his speech to the United Nations President Eisenhower pondered over the new plan for the control of atomic energy which Prime Minister Churchill characterized as one of the greatest events in history since the end of the war.

At 8 o'clock tonight the Vanderbilt will receive "Dead Pigeon," more or less inspired by the mysterious circumstances surrounding the suicide of Abe Reles, a factotum of Murder Inc., who died while in protective custody in 1941. The melodrama will introduce a new dramatist, Lenard Kantor, an illustrator, who, for this occasion, has dropped the "o" from his first name because he had qualms about having thirteen letters in his full name.
Schenley Industries, Inc., a leading domestic producer and distributor of distilled liquors, had net earnings of $3,229,888 in the three months ended on last Nov. 30.

Only 156 pints of blood were donated Monday to the regional Red Cross program. The organization pointed out yesterday that today would be the last day this week in which blood could be given. It asked that as many as possible give today to make up for the seasonal slump in donations and explained that the great need was unabated.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 22 (AP) -- United States District Judge Alfred E. Modarelli today approved a petition asking that Adolf Gobel, Inc., North Bergen meat packing company, be declared bankrupt and a receiver be appointed to reorganize the company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Eisenhower discussed today with his inner circle of security advisers plans to ease the international exchange of atomic information and materials.

MOLINE, Ill., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A bequest to the community of Moline of more than $1,000,000 is included in the will of a granddaughter of John Deere, inventor of the steel plow. Total value of the estate is estimated at $12,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Three corporations and five individuals were indicted today on charges of conspiracy to defraud and file false statements in the purchasing of surplus Government ships.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, was named head of a ten-member task force today to study problems of Federal service for the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- The birthplace of the talking picture, the old Warner Brothers Studio on Sunset Boulevard, was destined today to become a combination television center and museum for the motion picture industry.

The Coast Guard Auxiliary is now ready to assist Civil Defense authorities here at their request in small craft operations in the event of emergency or disaster, Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, commander of the Third Coast Guard District, said yesterday.
The story of the Nativity will be told and re-told tomorrow and on Christmas Day when the churches of New York pay joyous tribute to the Holy Birth in song, prayer and pageant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The airlines have told the Government that charges proposed for use of Federal airways would be "so onerous and excessive as to endanger the continued development of the industry."

BONN, Germany, Dec. 22 -- With Christmas coming, the West Germans find themselves cast in the role of the good little boys of Western Europe. The French, in rich Uncle Sam's book, are the naughty ones.

The Times for Dec. 12 reports on a meeting held in Chicago recently by the Foreign Oil Policy Committee, a body that advocates the limitation of the "ever-increasing flood" of oil from foreign countries, and particularly from Venezuela.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The great men of the world are talking about a return to "secret diplomacy."

MONTREAL, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Coach Dick Irvin defended his Montreal Canadiens today as Clarence Campbell, president of the National Hockey League, considered a first-hand report on the New York brawl between Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion and Ron Murphy of the Rangers.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York will assist next month in Columbia University's bicentennial celebration. The lawyers' participation will consist of a conference on the conflict between freedom of inquiry and the security of the community.

Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, asserted yesterday that communism could not be eliminated from Latin America until the United States had removed "insidious groups" and "a few thoroughly bad characters" from its State Department.
Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' address to the National Press Club in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 22 (AP) -- American and Australian Davis Cup squads forgot their personal problems today and concentrated on a common worry -- the sickly center court at Kooyong. Here they will fight it out in the challenge round starting next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Benson renewed today his request that Eastern railroads extend to March 31 the present emergency freight rates on hay shipped into designated drought areas.
Christmas main dishes of poultry, beef, lamb or veal will cost the consumer generally less this year than in 1952. Pork is the main exception.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Wednesday, Dec. 23 -- Queen Elizabeth had a spectacular welcome to New Zealand this morning.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Favors extended to "big political figures" by the Yonkers Raceway have consisted only of "a lot of free passes" and numerous jobs for constituents, a labor leader said here today in denying he had made more serious charges.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer, author, educator and lecturer, today proposed a system of Federal aid to the nation's public school system to help combat juvenile delinquency.
Many a little girl will celebrate Christmas this year in a crisp print dress, because prints appropriate for all ages are being revived for around-the-year wear.
The fifteen-day-old strike of employes of 550 private refuse collection companies in the metropolitan area was settled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Representative Jacob A. Javits, Republican-Liberal of New York, said today he would propose legislation when Congress reconvened to regulate charitable fund-raising organizations.

BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- A simmering crisis over the future administration of West Berlin's large sums of United States relief was resolved today. Under a compromise arrangement Dr. Paul Hertz will continue to handle the funds.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The British Government announced today that it had rejected as worthless the promise of loyal cooperation that the deposed ruler of Buganda offered after previously having refused to give it.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 22 -- A wide downtown area of Elizabeth was blanketed early today by a metallic blue precipitant that accompanied a smog attack.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Gold and dollar assets of foreign nations increased by $740,000,000 in the third quarter of this year. This was a gain of $340,000,000 over the preceding quarter, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Twelve rank-and-file Republican members of the House of Representatives pledged President Eisenhower support in and out of Congress after discussing his program with him today.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The London Underground (subway to you), is experimenting on one of its busiest lines with a modified bar stool that, it says, will increase the capacity of each car by sixteen persons.

ROSLYN, L. I., Dec. 22 -- A glass operating room where as as many as seventy-five pairs of trained ears can listen to the flickering pulse sounds of a crippled child's heart has been installed at the St. Francis Hospital and Sanatorium for Cardiac Children here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today that arrangements had been completed for the operation of a $60,000,000 credit authorized by United States commercial banks to finance purchases of American cotton by Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, one-time Deputy Army Chief of Staff, declared today that North Atlantic Treaty Organization troops could not now hold Europe against a Russian attack.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 22 -- The United States is exploring the possibility of bringing the question of Communism in Guatemala before the Organization of American States. Such action would be taken under the 1947 Rio de Janeiro pact pledging the hemisphere's nations to act in concert "for the common defense."

l'Irs. Paul Pryibil of 960 Fifth Avenue and Bogheid, Glen Cove. L. L, gave a reception, cocktail party and dance yesterday afternoon in the Geprgian Suite, 1A East Seventy-seventh Street, for 1V[iss fni Tilney of London, who is visiting her.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson said today after White House conferences, that the Administration had finished work on its military budget for the 1955 fiscal year starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Sentor Hugh Butler, Republican of Nebraska, predicted today that the Senate Interior Committee would approve a bill next month to admit Hawaii to the Union. The committee chairman said further hearings "probably" would be necessary before the committee got around to any action on a similar measure for Alaska.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Form players, for a change, had a field day at Tropical Park this afternoon as Paul L. Kelley's consistent Ignition became the sixth straight successful choice by beating eight rivals in the featured Alcedo Purse.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- There is no sound economic basis for compelling persons to retire at 65 years of age, according to Robert K. Burns, executive officer of the University of Chicago Industrial Relations Center.
DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Government rested its case today against six Michigan Communists charged with conspiracy to advocate and teach violent overthrow of government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- There is a damper on spirits at Federal office Yuletide parties this year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec., 22 -- Forecasting continued heavy outlay for defense purposes, Yugoslavia's defense leader counted this country today among those prepared for war in order that war might be avoided.
MIAMI, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Fifty-seven nominations have been received for the seventeenth running of the $100,000 added Widner Handicap on Feb. 20, officials at Hialeah race course said today.

Plans for an apartment building on a Yorkville site now containing five dwellings have been announced by Thomas Bornstein, operator, who has sold a property measuring 100 by 100 feet at 510 to 518 East Eighty-fifth Street to a syndicate.

East Side detectives arrested last night and early today the four masked and armed robbers who stole $25,000 in jewelry and $500 in cash from the apartment of Arthur Murray, nationally known dance instructor, on Dec. 8.

Directors of the National City Bank of New York yesterday elected as vice presidents J. Ed. Warren, Bernard T. Stott, Nicholas W. Vancil and Edward B. White. The bank also announced the formation of a special industries group for supervision of its business in the petroleum, public utility and transportation industries.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The W. H. Bishop Stable's Miss Revoked, a 12-to-1 shot, beat the second choice, Fancy Gent, by a neck today in the King Arthur Purse at the Fair Grounds, while the 3-1 favorite, Rags to Riches, wound up seventh in the field of eleven.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 22 -- A demand by the Hat Corporation of America for increased police protection for workers employed in the present strike of 1,400 regular employes was rejected today by Mayor Irving C. Freese.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 22 -- More than 100 employes of the temporarily idle Mabbett worsted mill shared today a $24,000 Christmas gift representing accumulated retirement and vacation pay.

Used from necessity in past centuries to illuminate the Yuletide scene, candlelight, with its transfiguring glow, seems today to have become an essential ingredient of a merry Christmas. New versions of the candle and holders for it may be found in several shops.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Signing of an anti-trust consent judgment involving manufacturers of knitted gloves and mittens was announced in Federal Court today before District Judge Stephen W. Brennan.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A cross-country sample shows colleges "in complete agreement on continuing the present football game of the week" on television, reported the liaison an for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the television network and the game's sponsors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Eisenhower said today he considered the European Defense Community the only practical proposal for bringing permanent peace between France and Germany.

Elmer Davis. who discontinued his weekday radio broadcasts last October because of ill health, will return to the air next month to do radio and television commentary on Sundays only. His program will be presented over the A.B.C. radio network beginning Jan. 3 at 10:15 P.M. and over the A.B.C. television network beginning Jan. 17 at 1 P.M.

Without exception, financial and commodity markets throughout the United States and Canada will be closed tomorrow, Christmas, and Jan. 1, New Year's Day. Stock Exchanges in New York will have full sessions on the days before the holidays but commodity markets

Canned tomatoes may be combined in many ways with other foods for quick dishes. Tomatoes are a fragile vegetable and tend to break down under heat processing but this may become an advantage in cooking.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23 -- The tentative agreement yesterday between the big Hollinger gold mine at Timmins and the United Steel Workers of America is the first sign of a break in the costly strikes that have blighted the economy of a two hundred mile area in northern Ontario and northeastern Quebec since last July.

ONLY Harry Hopman knows all the answers and Harry stubbornly refuses to give them away free. The price isn't high. It's no more than a thrupence -- or whatever Australian newspapers cost these days. Hopman is the non-playing captain of the Aussie Davis Cup team. He's also the pro tem sportswriting tennis expert for an Australian newspaper and no one is going to scoop him. He saves his opinions and quotable quotes for his column.
A father's solicitude for his 16-year-old daughter, a narcotics addict, has enabled the police to round up a ring selling heroin at $3 a dose to juveniles in the Bronx.

The misuse of leather terms was condemned yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc. In recent months, the bureau said, coats, jackets and other articles made of fabric-backed vinyl plastic simulating leather have been advertised under a variety of fanciful names suggestive of leather.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Dec., 23 -- Dr. John Hopf Jr., Rockland County District Superintendent of Schools, said today he would take legal action to retain his elected office as trustee of Spring Valley. He was dismissed last night by Mayor William Bohlke, who acted on an opinion from State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

Despite what you may have heard, actors are talented people. In "Dead Pigeon," which opened at the Vanderbilt last evening, three actors treat a verbose, monotonous script as if it were a poetic idyll. The actors are Joan Lorring, as a material witness temporarily released from jail; Lloyd Bridges, as a detective detailed to guard her and James Gregory, as a police lieutenant who is also a part-time assassin.
The Washington retail market, a historic square block of gourmet paradise, offers for the holiday cook rare and robust game items, domestic and foreign.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of the finding of the Supreme Court of the Soviet Union, the sentence and notice of execution of Lavrenti P. Beria, former Minister of Internal Affairs, and his six co-defendants, as published today in Izvestia, Pravda and other Moscow newspapers:
With fair weather and dry roads forecast, railroads, airlines, bus companies and highway authorities in the metropolitan area were preparing yesterday for a record volume of holiday week-end travel.
GRASS VALLEY, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A gallows he had built for a stage play took the life of Richard B. Looser yesterday. Mr. Looser, 34 years old, was director of an amateur theatre group.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. announced officially yesterday that he would reappoint Frederick H. Zurmuhlen as Commissioner of Public Works and would name George M. Bragalini as City Treasurer. Both appointments were expected.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that President Eisenhower's foreign policy program had put the Communists "for the first time * * * on the defensive all over the world."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- During the period ended Dec. 22, member bank reserves decreased $237,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

In the next year Pan American World Airways will increase its cargo-carrying capacity by 50 per cent when three new four-engined Douglas freight carriers are added to its air fleet. This was announced yesterday by Willis G. Lipscomb, vice president in charge of traffic and sales, following Pan American's annual system sales conference.

As we write these words to exhort you not to die this week-end or next our feelings are mixed. On the one hand, we have a certain amount of confidence in our power to persuade you to do the wise thing and avoid the foolish. On the other hand, we realize that statistics take on a certain inevitability after they have turned up time on top of time.
Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., wholly-owned subsidiary of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries, had a net profit of $8,714,733 in the three months ended Oct. 31.

Coffee, cocoa, the domestic sugar contract and zinc were active on the New York exchanges yesterday but other commodities were dull in pre-holiday markets. Prices moved irregular with sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes, tin, lead and copper mixed; cocoa, coffee and burlap higher, and zinc, hides, rubber and wool lower.
Steps designed ultimately to drive the shooting galleries and flea circuses out of midtown Manhattan were taken yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
The award of 188 police citations for heroic conduct was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

The execution of Lavrenti Pavlovich Beria for treason against the Soviet state ends the career of one who came close to becoming dictator of the Soviet Union after a long career as chief secret policeman of Stalin's realm.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- A "firm offer" from Liebmann Breweries, Inc., of New York for purchase of Acme Breweries was submitted this afternoon to shareholders of five corporations that own Acme.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The right of the Federal Power Commission to license New York State's Power Authority to join with the Province of Ontario in a $600,000,000 hydro-electric project in the St. Lawrence River was attacked in the Federal Court of Appeals today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization announced plans today to expand the production of titanium, an indispensable alloy for metal going into jet engines.

Roger Campbell, Princeton star, lived up to advance expectations in capturing the eighteenth annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets singles tournament yesterday at the University Club. The Tiger player, who swept through the preliminary rounds of the three-day event without yielding a game, turned back his semi-final and final opponents with stellar performances.

An off-duty patrolman tangled unsuccessfully last night with three unidentified men at a Brooklyn street intersection. In the exchange of shots, the patrolman was grazed by a bullet on the little finger of his right hand. His attackers fled -- apparently unscathed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Louis S. Rothschild, Chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, said today that in any Government shipbuilding program, commercial ship operators should have a substantial role in deciding vessel designs.
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Lavrenti P. Beria, former Soviet Deputy Premier, and six of his aides were shot today as traitors to the Soviet Union.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- Christmas mail piled up tonight in French railroad stations as Communist-led postal sorters began the second twenty-four hours of their three day "warning" strike for an increase in their year-end bonus.

As a teacher I want to reject most emphatically the slurs which Matthew Shevlin has cast on my profession. His letter in The Times of Dec. 16 implies that teachers have been engaged in "espionage, sabotage or subversion." The latter term has no legal meaning; its dictionary sense is the overturning or overthrow (presumably of the Government), or the undermining of morals, allegiance or faith.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 23 -- The government of Peru refused today to recognize the jurisdiction of the Inter-American Peace Committee here to compose its five-year dispute with the Government of Colombia over the matter of asylum for Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, Peruvian leftist leader, in Lima.

Gasoline stocks last week increased an additional 1,077,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they amounted to 153,586,000 barrels, compared with 152,509,000 a week earlier and 131,017,000 a year ago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Paul Gregory, having made his mark in the legitimate theatre, now is going to step into the field of independent motion-picture production.
DETROIT, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Barring a thaw, the Detroit Lions will wear tennis shoes for their National Football League championship game here Sunday with the Cleveland Browns.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 24 -- Attempts of the Communist and the United Nations Commands to persuade their reluctant prisoners of the Korean war to return ended last midnight [10 A. M., Wednesday, Eastern standard time].
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman has begun his third consecutive Christmas visit to United Nations troops in Korea.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The White House announced today that President and Mrs. Eisenhower would leave for their vacation in Georgia at 9 A. M. on Christmas Day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A Department of Agriculture marketing specialist has returned from Europe with the report of improvement in the demand for raw cotton there.

The Davison Chemical Corporation plans to begin making sulphuric acid early next month at a new plant in Bartow, Fla., which the company believes will be the world's largest sulphuric acid producer. The unit's rated capacity will be 550 tons a day of 100 per cent sulphuric acid.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Representative Dewey Short, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said today that President Eisenhower probably would not even ask Congress to act now on a proposed variation of a universal military training plan.

Steamship operators -- who are in no position to do their Christmas shipping early -- continued to move their vessels in and out of the port in large numbers yesterday in an effort to have them at sea before either the threatened pier strike or the overtime-heavy weekend.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Administration officials and two Republican Senators today challenged the assertion of Senator Douglas that the United States was suffering a "real recession."

BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- Mr. and Mrs. George D. O'Brien of Wollaston, Mass., and their son, George Jr., pleaded innocent in Federal District Court today and were held for trial in connection with the $681,700 Danvers, Mass., robbery of March 25, 1952.

Marshal Ivan S. Konev's role as chairman of the tribunal that condemned Lavrenti P. Beria and his six co-defendants appears to be the clearest public indication to date of the greatly enhanced political power now apparently wielded by the highest Soviet military leaders.
Judy Holliday, who scored both on the stage and screen as Billie Dawn, the not-too-bright blonde with a thirst for knowledge in "Born Yesterday," may succeed Rosalind Russell in "Wonderful Town."

Traditional Christmas cards often depict a small town with the Star of Bethlehem shining down over a little white church. The hamlet perhaps symbolizes the American concept of the Yuletide season as a time of peace and of prayer, for there admittedly is a spirit of good fellowship found in the little towns and villages that is lacking in the big city.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec 23 (AP) -- Press, owned by Abe Levinson of New York, scored one of the biggest upsets of the meeting when he captured the Harinero Purse at Tropical Park today.

The New York State Racing Commission and the presidents of the Empire City Racing Association, the Metropolitan Jockey Club, and the Queens County Jockey Club met here yesterday to discuss dates for next year.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Sale of the assets of Eureka-Williams Corporation to the Henney Motor Company, Freeport, Ill., was approved by stockholders today, the Eureka-Williams office announced.

Jim (Junior) Gilliam of the Dodgers yesterday was named the National League's 1953 rookie of the year. Brooklyn's fleet, switch-hitting second baseman received eleven of the twenty-four votes cast by the Baseball Writers Association of America selection committee.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- A ban on overtime and piecework beginning Jan. 18 was recommended today by the leaders of thirty-nine unions representing 3,000,000 men in the shipbuilding and engineering industries.
MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The United Nations Command today released a semi-official list of American prisoners refusing repatriation.

Red poinsettias arranged against a background of silver and gold southern smilax provided a colorful decor for the second and last Junior Assembly for this season, which took place last night in the ballroom of the Plaza.
France, which since the days of Charlemagne has been a heroic element in the history of Europe, once again dominates the story of tomorrow.
Mathilda, who could not find true love in this great city, was flown to Oklahoma City last night in search of new romance.
A crucial National Labor Relations Board election to pick a barganing agent for 24,000 dock workers in the Port of New York wound up without a decision early this morning.

ALTHOUGH generous quantities of nonsense are uttered by public figures every day, there is room for better nonsense in literature. Why shouldn't what is done inadvertently by some professionals be done advertently by others? After all, the humorists compete pretty successfully with the orators.
The cotton futures market here closed barely steady yesterday, 7 to 14 points net lower.
Coach Frank Boucher's New York Rangers attained two important objectives at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Federal Judge Richmond B. Keech refused today to stop Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. from designating the National Lawyers Guild as a subversive organization.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 23 -- Israel was censured tonight for a raid against a Bedouin encampment four miles inside Jordanian territory in the Hebron hills. One Palestine Arab refugee was reported seriously wounded in the attack Monday night.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Big Jim Trimble was a busy man today. He rushed his wife to the hospital to await delivery of their fifth child and then hurried to the office of the Philadelphia Eagles for his Christmas present -- a new three-year contract as head coach.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The struggle between the radical Left Wing led by Aneurin Bevan and the moderates for control of the Labor party is continuing quietly but bitterly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Americans who sent venture capital abroad earned close to $3,000,000,000 from their investments in 1952, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

PORT JEFFERSON, Dec. 23 -- A group of North Shore commuters has contributed more than $200 as a Christmas gift for their train crew for being "courteus and helpful" in spite of the usual Long Island Rail Road troubles.

VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 23 -- Senator Rene Coty, an Independent, who has held only minor ministerial posts during his long political career, was elected President of the French Republic on the thirteenth ballot today. The election followed a week of battling among the political parties.

RICHMOND, Ind., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The last two of thirteen escaped convicts were trapped before dawn today by the loaves of bread they had been munching for thirty hours. By tonight, they were back in the Michigan prison from which they had escaped last Saturday.

IT would be supposed that a new beagle, to a man already possessing a half-dozen, would be a matter for extremely mild rejoicing, but when we were awakened by a whining and scratching outside the apartment door shortly after 4:30 A. M. we feared the worst -- and our fears were justified.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Soviet gold being shipped to London in considerable quantities is being sold by the Soviet Union to pay for increased purchases of foreign goods, including consumer goods, financial quarters here believe.

The Hospital Council of Greater New York has recommended expansion of Cumberland Hospital, a municipal institution in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn, rather than erection of a new city-owned hospital there.

One of the last chapters in this year's foreign Christmas mail story was written last night at Staten Island Army piers. A crew of 150 postal workers toiled without let-up to take off 20,000 sacks of parcel post from three vessels bringing military mail from Europe.

Several major phonograph record companies reported yesterday that the possibility of a work stoppage at the end of the year by the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., has prompted a step-up of recording sessions.

I regret the need to take serious issue with my good friends of the Inter-American Association for Democracy and Freedom, who, in a letter published on Dec. 15, argued that Peru ought to grant Haya de la Torre safe conduct from his Colombian Embassy refuge.
School contracts totaling $12,507,396, including one for the most costly building in the city system, were awarded yesterday by the Board of Education at its final meeting of the year.

There are a few words of precaution concerning Christmas trees to which we hope all homes will pay heed. Organizations devoted to safety have repeatedly warned us that Christmas tree fires are among the most difficult to extinguish and are responsible for a great many of the tragedies which mar the holiday season.

CARLSBAD, N. M., Dec. 23 (UP) -- Two men with a collapsible nylon sea anchor tonight fished Wimpy, a two-month-old mongrel puppy, out of a thirty-eight-foot well where she had been trapped for ten days.

The New York Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., decided yesterday to ask cloak, suit and skirt manufacturers for immediate contract negotiations to meet problems facing the retirement fund. The present contract does not expire until May.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- New signs of trouble for the Administration's tax program arose today in the wake of last week's White House conferences on legislative proposals for the next session of Congress.
WINNIPEG, Man., Dec. 23 -- Four University of Manitoba researchers may have added 15,000 years to the possible study of prehistoric man and the world in which he lived.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- The United States delegation declined to comment on the suggestion today by Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, that the United Nations General Assembly be reconvened soon to take up the question of Korean prisoners refusing to accept repatriation.

The cleavage of opinion on the most desirable method of funding pensions has changed little in recent years. Discussions at a recent forum here indicated that whether funding should be done through insurance companies or by means of bank trusteed plans remained an open question.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 23 -- Angry opposition erupted here today to the resolution adopted on Monday by the Town Council to recommend the end of segregation in local schools. In at least one case, the wife of the lone Negro member of the Council received a telephone threat directed at her husband.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will open a branch office at Delray Beach, Fla., on Jan. 4.
A gift for the house might make a suitable last-minute choice for a present, since to most homemakers it would be welcome.
When 6-year-old Steven Slawson was asked whether he wanted another toy for Christmas or have the money sent "for the unhappy people," he replied: "I have enough toys. Let's make somebody else happy."
