SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 23 -- President Jose Figueres published today his proposals for purchasing the entire United Fruit Company banana organization here.

For an hour yesterday the stock market seemed a continuation of the toboggan ride of Tuesday, with aircrafts and tobaccos sliding rapidly. Then, with the second hour, strength came into steels, chemicals, oils and rails, and the recovery held in all except the last until the close.

Six Boy Scouts about to pack for a winter camping expedition sixty miles north of New York City made a special trip to the Weather Bureau yesterday to find out what kind of weather to expect next week.
The Security Adjustment Corporation announced yesterday that it has distributed to all employes the regular Christmas bonus of 2 per cent of their yearly salaries.

Business men have a lot of reading to do. Fifteen working hours a week is the estimate for management and supervisory-level personnel just for reading correspondence, reports, memoranda, trade journals and the like that flood their desks, their briefcases and their homes.
Victoria de los Angeles sang the role of Melisande for the first time at the Metropolitan in Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" last night.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- A letter from Guy Burgess, one of the two missing British diplomats, reached his mother here last night. It was presumed that it had been sent across the Iron Curtain from Communist-dominated territory.
NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 23 (AP) -- United States District Judge Alfred E. Modarelli has approved a creditors petition asking for reorganization of Adolf Gobel, Inc. North Bergen meat packing company.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 23 -- Young King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia has again taken the field in a new drive to rid his realm of Communist insurgents.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- The official decision to convert four miles of busy Central Park Avenue in Yonkers into a $27,000,000 segment of the New York-Buffalo Thruway was sustained today in Supreme Court.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Stock market prices strengthened here today on an announcement that British production was set for a record.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Dec. 23 -- The body of a man that was discovered yesterday in a shallow grave near Mastic Acres was identified today as that of Sgt. Joseph Golombek of the Air Force. Identification was made by two former Air Force friends of the dead man.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, called today for a redrafting of the Civil Aeronautics Act, which he helped write fifteen years ago. He said he would introduce legislation to accomplish this soon after Congress reconvened in January.

New York City's department stores continue to lag behind other stores in the Second Federal Reserve District. A report, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board of New York, showed that in November New York City's stores declined 1 per cent in net sales from November, 1952, while the district as a whole was registering a 2 per cent gain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The United States is trying to impress on its Latin American neighbors that its concern over any outcropping of communism in their midst is based on Washington's interest in hemispheric security, not on the political color of national governments.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Damages of $7,000,000 were asked in a suit filed in Federal Court yesterday by three San Bernardino County residents against the Molybdenum Corporation of America as a result of asserted failure to pay promised anticipated profits on mining claims.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 23 -- Denis Arthur Wright, British charge d'affaires, told Abdullah Entezam, Iran's Foreign Minister, today, that Britain hoped for an early solution of the oil dispute with Iran and would "show the utmost goodwill and a spirit of conciliation" in negotiating an agreement.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Dec. 24 -- At midnight last night one of the strangest periods in the history of the United States Army came to an official end with the final renunciation of home and country by twenty-two American soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Studebaker Corporation said today it was "employe loyalty" rather than company or union policy that led to penalties against more than a dozen South Bend, Ind., auto workers last summer for refusing to buy Studebaker cars.
DALLAS, Dec. 23 (UP) -- J. Alvin Gardner of Dallas, president of the Texas League since 1929, and Milton Price, also of Dallas, secretary and vice president, resigned today, effective Jan. 9.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru passionately assailed today the prospective United States military aid to Pakistan as a step conceivably leading to a renewal of the colonial spirit in Asia.
GENEVA, Dec. 23 -- The Swiss Government announced today that under no circumstances would it participate in a political conference for settlement of the Korean war, even as an observer.
Again we are threatened with a strike. This one more crippling than most -- a transit strike.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 23 -- Francis A. Nixon, father of Vice President Richard M. Nixon, remained on the critical list today at St. Joseph's Hospital, where he is under treatment for a gastric hemorrhage.

A 1,200-mile mercy flight yesterday by an Air Force bomber from Mitchel Air Force Base, Garden City, L. I., south across seven states to South Carolina and back again, ended successfully against heavy odds of fleeting time, buffeting head winds and dangerous ceilings.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that the "cost of living" declined between Oct. 15 and Nov. 15 by 0.4 point, or by 0.3 per cent.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican of Newburgh, called today for legislation to bar the state, county or city chairmen of any political party from serving as paid lobbyists while in office and for five years after leaving it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A House committee said today the government should get out of the coffee-roasting business and allow private industry to supply the armed services.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Players and coaches of the Baltimore Colts really believed in Santa Claus today. Each got a $500 bonus check from the club owners, for whom they won only three National Football League games.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Irregular price trends were the rule in the grain market today. Wheat showed some increase in buying, but corn, oats and rye were weak.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- New regulations designed to keep nonessential foreign-owned industries out of Brazil were issued by the Government today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 16, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Hector McNeil, Number two man at the Foreign Office during the Labor Government, said tonight that "Churchill and [John] Foster Dulles, in their obsession with Germany and impatience with France, are paving the way toward Franco-Soviet rapprochement."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Army, after considering the matter for more than two months, has advised Representative Clarence E. Kilburn, Republican of up-State New York, that it will not permit hunting on the idle 107,000-acre Camp Drum (N. Y.) military reservation.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 23 -- The Ceylonese Prime Minister, Sir John Kotelawala has suggested to the Prime Ministers of India, Pakistan, Burma and Indonesia a conference to discuss the question of world peace and connected world problems.

Roy T. Hurley, president and chairman of the board of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, announced yesterday that a higher military rating of 3,700 horsepower had been given the company's turbo-compound aircraft engine. The combination piston and turbine engine is flown in both the new Douglas DC-7 and Lockheed Super Constellation airliners, which are setting transcontinental, and north-south records, and in a variety of military planes.

It is time that Michael J. Quill and the Transport Workers Union were brought face to face with the state law that makes strikes of civil service workers illegal. If the New York Transit Authority is ready for a showdown in the courts we say let's take the plunge and see whether Mr. Quill is willing to take the consequences that law provides.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Administration's difficulties in coming to a decision on the issue of defense assistance to Pakistan arise from these factors:
The Republic Steel Corporation plans to begin exploratory drilling and tunnel work on a 64,220-acre tract in southern Peru to determine whether the area contains iron ore in commercial quantities.

BETHLEHEM, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Pilgrims from faraway lands were streaming into this impoverished little town today to bring momentary prosperity to a population whose chief occupation is maintaining sites reminiscent of the birth and life of Christ.
The $1,000,000.000 Cities Service Company, a major producer of oil and gas, renewed its move yesterday to withdraw from the gas business and confine its operations to the petroleum field.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Service men beyond the Arctic Circle are scheduled to get a Christmas Eve airdrop of Red Cross gifts.

Directors of Montgomery Ward Co. declared an extra dividend of $1.50 a share yesterday for payment to common stockholders on Jan. 30. Excluding this dividend, payments this year were $3. In 1952 shareholders received $3 a share altogether.
PARIS, Dec. 23 -- "Le Pere Noel" has given France a new President for Christmas, fulfilling a recent forecast of retiring President Vincent Auriol.

TELAVIV, Dec. 23 -- The Government and the citrus industry tonight settled their dispute over the rate of exchange at which growers will convert their foreign currency income from exports. Growers will get 1.8 Israeli pounds per dollar, the same as other exporters. However, the Treasury will deduct 150 pruta per dollar on account of the industry's debts to the Government which total 3,000,000 Israeli pounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The United States Consumers' Price Index has taken its first dip in eight months. From mid-October to mid-November, the index dropped from 115.4 to 115. The 1947-49 average equals 100. This decline of 0.4 of a point amounts to about 0.3 per cent.

MONTREAL, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Canadian newsprint industry will operate at close to its expanded capacity in 1954 and its customers will be able to obtain as large supplies as they can buy, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association said today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Ben Moreell, chairman of the board of directors of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, looks for increased competition in 1954 in view of the adjustment in steel market conditions. And he says his company is in a good position to meet the challenge.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 23 (AP) -- America's Davis Cup team scoffed today at a semi-official report that Rex Hartwig might beat out Ken Rosewall for an Australian singles spot in next week's challenge round.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Department of Agriculture asserted today that the price the housewife paid for beef in 1952 and 1953 "reflected" price declines for live cattle.

The approaching Christmas - New Year's period is a time of foreboding for those of us concerned with highway traffic and safety. Last year during the double celebrations 962 persons were killed and more than 31,000 others were injured in highway accidents. In fact, the tragic results of our annual "alcoholidays" have become almost synonymous with Yule time.

Seasoned players captured fielding honors and the Chicago White Sox annexed a major portion of club and individual defensive laurels during the 1953 campaign, according to the official American League fielding records released yesterday.

Mayor-elect Wagner and his advisers are to be congratulated on an important reform in city government through adoption of the modern program-type budget to supplant what has been called an "endless thicket of figures" in the forty-year-old line-item budget. Abraham D. Beame, the Budget Director, announces that the 1954-55 expense budget will carry to completion the experimentation he has already done.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Awards totaling more than $234,000 were handed down today in damage suits resulting from the death of three persons in an Air Force bomber crash at Morning-side, Md., thirty-two months ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of Oscar M. Taylor of New York, executive vice president of the New York Telephone Company, as president of the state's revised Civil Service Commission.

ELKHART, Iowa, Dec. 23 -- Neighbors and friends of Ervin F. Spratt, Elkhart's postmaster, were rallying today in support of the proposition that a man, even in an official position, was entitled to his own opinions. Republicans, too, were among the defenders of Mr. Spratt, a Democrat.

Development and production of new electronic data handying systems, which moved out of the laboratory stage into full-scale manufacturing. was the outstanding achievement of Remington Rand, Inc., during 1953, according to a statement made yesterday by James H. Rand, president.

NEWARK, Dec. 23 -- Three striking Public Service Electric and Gas Company employes were arrested early this morning in Palisades Park after they allegedly had removed ten gas meters from an apartment house.

Since the Christmas tree and other holiday decorations are potential fire hazards, caution should be taken in their selection, placement in the home and maintenance, according to the United States Department of Agriculture, the National Safety Council and the National Board of Fire Underwriters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A hearing examiner of the Federal Trade Commission ordered today that charges of price discrimination against the B. F. Goodrich Company of New York be dismissed.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Bevo Francis made a jump push shot from the foul circle just before the whistle to give little Rio Grande a 67-65 basketball victory tonight over Wake Forest, last year's Southern Conference champions.
James F. Lovett has been appointed defense contract administrator of the Chrysler Corporation, Detroit.
BERLIN, Dec. 24 --East Germany is enjoying its first fully Government-sponsored Christmas tide since World War II. As a result there are more things to buy, although the choice is far from lavish.

Preoccupied with varied American interests, the firm of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d doesn't mind extending its London holdings. Just added to its overseas program is "The Teahouse of the August Moon," a Broadway hit of the first magnitude.
A mother's gratitude for the speed with which her letters reached her sailor son at sea inspired her to burst into poetic tribute to the Fleet Post Office in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -Government experts said today that Federal Reserve Board reports indicated that 1953 Christmas sales by department stores would lag 1 to 2 per cent below last year's record high.
The half-day holiday on the New York commodity exchanges limited volume yesterday. Activity was further curtailed, as it normally is, by the approach of a week-end.
The New York Knickerbockers, eastern division leaders in the National Basketball Association race, will meet the Syracuse Nationals in Madison Square Garden tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, has tightened up, for security reasons, on Air Force disclosure of speed and altitude records.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 24 -- Six young Tennessee singers, members of the University of Tennessee Opera Workshop, will be guests of the Metropolitan Opera Company in New York during the holidays.

The Long Island Rail Road reported yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen incorporating the terms of a national railroad agreement announced last week by virtually all Class I railroads.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 24 -The botanist's vasculum, the can in which he carries plant specimens, is joining the Geiger counter as a tool in the search for uranium, one rsearcher related today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The railroads of the United States will come to a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission on Jan. 6 on the compensation they receive for carrying the mails, willing to accept a 10 per cent increase in lieu of the 45 per cent increase they asked earlier this year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company, Chicago, said today that a program designed to increase transmission capacity of a natural gas pipe line from the Texas Gulf by 130,000,000 cubic feet daily will be completed by mid-January or soon thereafter.
The Chemstrand Corporation made its first shipments of nylon yarn from its new plant in Pensacola, Fla., yesterday, and thus established itself as the second producer of nylon in the United States.

President-Elect of France Rene Coty was quoted as crediting "Pere Noel" for his election on Wednesday. It may well have been true that all the weary Deputies and Senators who were performing with such pugnacity in "the spectacle of Versailles" felt a touch of the peaceful Christmas spirit and a longing for the bosom of their family on this day of goodwill.
The passing of the distinguished scientist Robert Millikan, whom I rejoiced to call my friend for many years, leads me to write this note.
CANANADAIGUA, N. Y., Dec. 24 (AP) -- The First Congregational Church has found a silver communion service that was lost for thirty-four years.

Your editorial "Give, but Give Wisely" of Dec. 16 deserves high praise for its sound approach to the problem of charity rackets. The hundreds of legitimate welfare and health agencies of our city will benefit from the recent exposure of fake charities only if the public understands, as the editorial states, that it had "reference to only a fraction of the total number of charitable organizations in the United States."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Department of Agriculture came up today with a new way to help siphon off its great stock of surplus butter.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The qualified relief that the French felt over the delayed election of a President became still more qualified today when morning newspapers published yesterday's White House statement insisting on the European army treaty, which has split this country from top to bottom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board today proposed a cut from 53 to 45 cents a ton mile in the rate of payment to National Airlines and the domestic system of Northwest Airlines for carrying mail.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. was reported yesterday to have decided to appoint former United States Attorney Francis W. H. Adams as Police Commissioner. The new Commissioner will succeed George P. Monaghan next Friday.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 22 -- West Germany's Government has proposed that, if an all-German national assembly is formed as a result of the four-power conference in Berlin, the assembly should only gradually assume control of the country.

ATLANTA, Dec. 23 -- In the last six years, annual average employment in southern factories has increased by one tenth, indicating an increasing diversification in the regional production facilities, Brunswick A. Bagdon, southern regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, reports.

In a manner fitting in well with the Christmas spirit, Iran and Britain have now formally resumed diplomatic relations and thus taken the first essential step toward settling a conflict the consequences of which might have engulfed the whole Middle East, including the Holy Places to which pilgrims are streaming the days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- This year 1953 was hailed today for world progress in big dams, super-highways and other engineering feats.
MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Was Maryland correctly named the mythical 1953 national football champion, or should the honor have gone to Notre Dame?
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 25 -- The Moscow radio wished the world a merry Christmas today.

MORRISVILLE, Pa., Dec. 24 -Lower Bucks County's phenomenal growth recently has changed the economy and social life as well as the physical face of an area settled by the Quakers in the days of William Penn.

Our Christmas celebration is and in its very nature ought to be primarily our Festival of Peace. It commemorates the birth of the Prince of Peace. The first Christmas greeting, delivered to the shepherds by the "multitude of the heavenly host," was "Peace on earth, goodwill toward men."
ROME, Dec .24 (Reuters) -- Hundreds of Italian convicts freed under a government amnesty preferred to spend Christmas in jail.

" Myth and Ritual in Christianity," by Alan W. Watts, has been scheduled by Vanguard Press for publication in late February. The study shows how the complicated pattern of Christian ritual has evolved from events recorded in the Old and New Testaments and how much of the symbolism of other religions seems to fall "miraculously into place within the over-all scheme of things."

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Dec. 24 -- American soldiers sitting quietly at the front tonight could sing "Peace on Earth, Goodwill Toward Men" with more realism than on any other Christmas Eve in the last four years.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 25 -- The Soviet satellite members of the neutral nations commission pressed futilely again yesterday for more time to explain to Chinese and North Korean prisoners of the Korean war why they should return behind the Iron Curtain.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 23 -- Walter Guevara Arze, Foreign Minister of Bolivia, said today the Bolivian Government was prepared to make a final settlement with the three big tin companies whose property was expropriated last year, but that the companies were holding up matters.

ANDERSON, Ind., Dec. 24 --Wheels are clicking once more along the forty-four-mile route of the Central Indiana Railway -- one of the shortest in the Midwest. Not since the Eighteen Nineties has business been as good for this railroad, which is better known to Hoosiers as the Midland.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 24 -- Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, chief of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in Jerusalem, has been asked by Israel to adjudicate a dispute with Jordan over whether illegal crossing of the armistice lines by unarmed civilians is a breach of the armistice agreement.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The City Civil Service Commission today dismissed charges against Capt. Redmond P. Gibbons, suspended chief of the uniformed police force, and ordered him restored to duty.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The American and Australian Davis Cup tennis teams plan to spend a quiet Christmas tomorrow before final full dress rehearsals for the challenge round.
BOSTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -- Eugene O'Neill left his entire estate to his third wife, purposely excluding his daughter Oona and son Shane, it was disclosed in his will filed for probate.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Mail deliveries were cut sharply today by a three-day-old strike at the postal sorting and trucking centers in Paris and some provincial railroad stations.
Steels led the industrial list in a mild advance yesterday and the stock market closed for the Christmas holiday with a fair gain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -Four natural gas companies today asked the Federal Power Commission for authority to build transmission facilities estimated to cost $168,462,035 -- including a pipeline from Louisiana to Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The United States made it plain today that for the foreseeable future it would retain control of substantially all the Ryukyu Islands, including Okinawa, and the Bonin Islands in the Pacific.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 24 -Plans for a statewide drive to find talented high school students and encourage them to choose careers in science have been made by the Minnesota Academy of Science. The organization hopes to get industrial support for its program, which it estimates will cost $50,000 a year.
QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 24 (AP) -The Government lifted the ban on the newspaper El Comercio tonight and its plant was returned to the publishers by the police.

The long-pending suit by the United States Lines against the Government to recover $8,700,000 in operating subsidy payments has been delayed for another month. The postponement followed the Government's failure to file a reply this week in the Court of Claims in Washington.
Post 6, where shares of the General Electric Company are traded on the New York Stock Exchange floor, has been a busy spot these past few weeks as G. E. has been bid up to its best level since 1929.

In what appears to be an attack on the former Stalinist policy of complete political control over Soviet literature, Ilya Ehrenburg, Soviet writer, has called for greater freedom for Soviet novelists and their release from the shackles of minute Communist direction.

A Dun Bradstreet report on sales in the week ended on Wednesday indicated that dollar sales in the various areas of the country had ranged from 2 per cent lower to 7 per cent higher than those in the same week of last year.

Five stores recently constructed by its Fedway Division have been sold and leased back by Federated Department Stores, Inc. The properties, in Albuquerque, N. M., and in Amarillo, Corpus Christi, Longview and Wichita Falls, Tex., have been acquired by Loomis J. Grossman of New York and Lazarus S. Heyman of Danbury, Conn., through their Mallard Realty Corporation. Robert S. Kline, New York broker, represented the buyers.
ALBANY, Dec. 24 -- The needles may be falling fast from this year's crop of tinseled Christmas trees, but the State Conservation Department isn't worried.

A program especially appropriate to the season was given by Bruno Walter and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 -Hollywood settled down to an uneasy Christmas with the industry's self-governing censorship authority, the Production Code Administration, facing the prospect of being defied for the first time by a major film company.
The Transit Authority accepted conditionally yesterday the proposal by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. for averting a threatened strike next Friday on the city-owned transportation lines.

Louis Schleifer, realty investor and leading hotel trader, has resold the Duane Hotel, a fifteen-story building at 237 Madison Avenue in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan. The building is between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets and is assessed at $1,250,000, including land value.

The current investigations of charity in New York are long overdue and every last one of the rackets should be rooted out. However, the public should not be made to feel that philanthropy is generally unworthy.

MADRID, Dec. 24 -- Faced with a steady rise in the cost of living, the Spanish Government is quietly carrying out a policy of piecemeal wage increases. The upward trend of costs has seriously affected the working classes and the policy of higher wages has covered virtually every segment of industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -President Eisenhower put in effect today, as of Dec. 16, certain tariff concessions originally negotiated with Uruguay in 1949 but withheld pending Uruguay's ratification of the agreement.
WELLINGTON, N. Z., Friday, Dec. 25 (Reuters) -- An unofficial report said 160 persons died in the train wreck.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 24 -- Christmas began to look brighter to members of the Asbury Park Boys Club today although the police were still searching for thieves who made off with the club's safe containing $900 in cash last Monday night.
Nearly all New Yorkers went home for Christmas yesterday, whether home was on the East Side, the West Side, Westchester, Long Island or points North, South or West.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The Indian Government is using a variety of diplomatic channels to prevent the United States from signing a military assistance agreement with Pakistan. This is so even though present negotiations for an accord do not envision air bases.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Out of the Navy's "mothball fleet" the United States will supply seven landing craft to the French in Indo-China and two destroyers to Nationalist China early in 1954.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 24 -The time limit set by four army territorial commanders in their demand that the government rescind the appointment of several General Staff officers expired today. They contend the appointments were made without the knowledge of the Army Chief of Staff and are illegal and political in character.

THIS morning shortly after daybreak, or perhaps earlier, a lot of fathers will be awakened by the delighted shouts from the neighborhood of the family Christmas tree as a youngster tears the wrapping from his first rifle or shotgun.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The British housewife, whether queueing patiently at the crowded counters of Selfridge's in London or scanning the gaily filled shelves of a small country store, is enjoying the most opulent and carefree Christmas since World War II.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 23 -- Johannesburg is trying to cut down the number of murders, other crimes and drunkenness, for which it is notorious at Christmas time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., of New York and Boston, was ordered to stop discriminatory pricing practices, in the sale of radio tubes, under an order handed down today by Webster Ballinger, Federal Trade Commission examiner.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 24 -The board of directors of the Connecticut Milk Dealers Association will recommend next week that the dating of milk bottle caps be restored.

The City Councill passed yesterday the controversial bill to allow taxicabs of the stock car type to operate on an equal footing with purpose-built vehicles. The vote was 21 to 1.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Great Northern Oil Company, in which Woodley Petroleum Company and Southern Production Company, Inc., of Houston are the principal stockholders, plans to build a $20,000,000 refinery in St. Paul, Minn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Patricia (Pat) O'Sullivan, six-time Connecticut women's amateur golf champion and winner of almost every major women's tournament in this country except the national amateur, turned professional today.

NEWARK, Dec. 24 -- Hopes of settling the thirty-four-day-old strike of 1,800 gas maintenance employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company were revive, today when the State Board of Mediation announced a new negotiation session for 10 A. M. on Tuesday.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A helicopter rescue team landed beside the wreckage of a United States Navy bomber on Myrdalsjokull Glacier in southeastern Iceland today and its radio report indicated that all nine of the bomber crewmen were dead.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The President-elect of France, Rene Coty, made his bow today to the citizens of Paris, most of whom had not known his name before yesterday.

Domestic, airline tourist flights and the family-fare plan are expected to account for more than 4,000,000,000,000 passenger miles this year.

The Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America has been informed that its charter of affiliation with the Congress of Industrial Organizations will be terminated Dec. 31.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Paris jewelers introduce their latest designs at this season. Luxurious ingenuity keynotes them all.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 24 -Mayor Irving C. Freese sent a special Christmas message today to the Hat Corporation of America and the five striking locals of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, A. F. L.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -The Federal communications Commission proposed today to increase the limit on the number of television stations in which one individual or company might have an interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -The Washington Star reported today that librarians all over the country were moving to block the possible appointment of W. Reed West, Professor of Political Science at George Washington University here, as Librarian of Congress.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP) -Speedy Georgia Tech may be slowed down in defending its Sugar Bowl title.

Federal Judge David N. Edelstein yesterday sentenced two men who attempted to rob the bank at Fort Jay, on Governors Island, to three years imprisonment. The father of one made a tearful, impassioned plea for clemency. The defendants could have received up to twenty-five years in jail.

ROME, Dec. 24 -- In a Christmas message broadcast to the world, Pope Pius XII strongly urged the nations of Continental Europe today to unite as a bulwark of peace. His plea came only a few days after similar ones by President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 24 -- A woman teller foiled a hold-up of the Second National Bank and Trust Company here today. All she did was duck.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- In an unexpectedly strong pre-holiday market, grain futures registered sharp gains today, following the lead of wheat, which was directly affected by good mill buying which found offers light. Soybeans futures continued to edge up and this also was a bullish influence in grains.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 24 -- Separate but equal school facilities for white and Negro children of Mississippi were voted by the State Legislature that ended a special session last night.

MARLETTE, Mich., Dec. 17 -- The Scotch-descended Boynes have been farming the rich land of Sanilac County near Lake Huron in east central Michigan for eighty-eight years. Come low milk prices, high gasoline costs for their three tractors and taxes, they intend to keep on farming it.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Dec. 10 -- Liberia, though extremely backward, has come a long way in the past few years. Her economy still is gathering momentum, thanks largely to United States technical and financial assistance.

Christians all over the world celebrated the birth of Jesus yesterday with traditional ceremonies, secular as well as religious, and a prayer that the uneasy peace of the moment might be strengthened.

When a man returns a tie the day after Christmas, it usually is not one of his wife's choosing, but when a woman brings back gifts of lingerie, it generally is because she considers her husband's tastes too extravagant, according to Frank R. Carmines, manager of the adjustment service department of Macy's.

" This Is Cinerama," will have grossed $6,500,000 by Jan. 1 in the seven cities where it has been shown and seen by 3,500,000 persons, according to S. H. Fabian, president of the Stanley Warner organization, exhibitor and producer of the wide-screen production.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Christmas was not-what it should have been for Millie Dalton, a 5-year-old curly-head from Charlotte, N. C.
Traffic accidents across the country took the lives of at least 228 persons yesterday.
The father of an emotionally disturbed boy sent $5 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to aid other such children in less fortunate circumstances.
The versatile helicopter is now gaining popularity tracking whales.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Dec. 25 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Queen Elizabeth's Christmas Day broadcast:
Francis W. H. Adams, Police Commissioner-designate, took time out from the observance of Christmas yesterday to talk about the new job he will undertake early next month.
From "society's basement" in the Bowery to an airplane high over Manhattan, New Yorkers joined yesterday in sharing the holiday cheer of Christmas.

Madison Square Garden's second annual Holidays Festival basketball tournament will open today. Afternoon and evening doubleheaders, bringing into action all eight competing teams, are scheduled. The afternoon pairings are Manhattan vs. Brigham Young at 2 P. M. and St. John's vs. Niagara.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today railroad passenger traffic dropped nearly 7 per cent this year, but freight carloadings were up slightly and total income set a new high record.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 25 -- President Eisenhower arrived at his favorite vacation retreat here in midafternoon today to begin a ten-day holiday. He will combine recreation with work on three major addresses he is schedued to make in the weeks just ahead.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 25 -- Yugoslavia's new-fashioned but still Communist-led Parliament elected officers today. Milovan Djilas, a top-ranking Communist leader; Vlada Zecevic, a former Orthodox priest, and Ivan Bozicevic, a trade union leader, got the biggest assignments.
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- The Government's research laboratories at Teddington are giving priority to tannin obtained from the hard and acrid wood of mangrove swamp trees in the hunt for a rust preventive.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 26 -- The Soviet satellite members of the neutral nations commission in charge of the remaining prisoners of the Korean war protested yesterday against the majority decision that ended at midnight Wednesday the "explanations" to the men why they should return home.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 25 -- Earl Wavell, only son of the late Field Marshal Earl Wavell, was shot and killed last night while leading British troops and policemen in a ten-hour battle with Mau Mau terrorists. He was 37 years old and had succeeded to the title in May, 1950.
Traditionally the occasion for the preparation and consumption of much food, the holidays this year have been accompanied by considerable cooking by teen-age groups around town.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Dec. 25 (Reuters) -- The Queen spoke to her own two children, Prince Charles and Princess Anne, by radio telephone to Britain during the day.

The "racket" sale of membership books of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., has resulted in the union's national office taking charge of the New York port headquarters, Joseph Curran, president of the N. M. U., declared yesterday.

EASTERN FRONT, Korea, Dec. 25 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, dismounted from a jeep carrying him through a sleet storm today to help four injured Koreans. The Cardinal joined service men in pulling the Koreans from under their overturned jeep.
Elaborate musical settings, religious devotions and sermons on the birth of Christ and its meaning marked Christmas services in the city's churches yesterday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 24 -- The National Revolutionary Movement now, in power in Bolivia is carrying out the scrutiny of its own party ranks to weed out doubtful members and strengthen its organization.
The opera was somewhat less grand than usual last night.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 25 -- Christmas business in South Africa has been disappointing.

SEATTLE, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The president of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company said the Washington Water Power Company is behind the campaign of a group of Puget stockholders to force a merger of the two utilities.

VIENNA, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The first official announcement made by the Prague radio said "many persons were killed or injured" when the Bratislava-Prague express crashed into another passenger train near the Moravian village of Sakvice.

One of the heartening things about the Christmas season is the way it proves all over again the inherent social conscience of the American people. It is a time when cynics are confounded, when gifts are made out of a desire to share in complete disregard, in many instances, of hope of favors yet to come.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 24 -- Minnesotans who try to escape local high prices on liquor by buying in other states face prosecution by state officials.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Zeke Bratkowski, setting up all three touchdowns with his great passing arm and kicking toe, quarterbacked a smashing Rebel team to a 20-0 victory over the Yankees tonight in the Shrine's annual North-South college all-star football classic.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 25 (UP) -- A legless Korean war veteran, released from a hospital in time to spend the holidays with his family, was beaten and robbed early today by a gang of young hoodlums who stole a Christmas gift and $10 from him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Industrial production, construction activity and retail sales in October and November failed to reach the highs registered earlier this year, the December Federal Reserve Bulletin reported today.
BOSTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins registered their first Christmas night victory in three years tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 1, before 8,839 Boston Garden fans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Home Loan Bank Board announced today election of boards of directors for District Home Loan Banks for two-year terms beginning Jan. 1.

The Civil Aeronautics Board has been holding hearings for some time on the applications of several airlines for changes in their schedules in the midwestern section of the country and the board's decisions in the "Chicago case" will have extensive effects on the financial status of at least one of the major airlines involved.
MORRISVILLE, Pa., Dec. 25 -- Along with undreamed of tax revenues, the municipalities caught in the thick of the lower Bucks County boom have inherited scores of problems.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 25 -- A six-month celebration by Arizona and New Mexico of the Gadsden Purchase will begin on Wednesday. The first Gadsden Purchase commemorative postage stamp will go on sale at the post office here.

PARIS, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Paris-Presse, one of the leading afternoon newspapers here, said today that President Eisenhower's proposal for a United Nations pool of atomic materials for peaceful purposes had been made possible by an amazing new discovery under which atomic materials could be "denatured" to remove their destructiveness.
Georgi N. Zarubin, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, corrected yesterday an error in the unofficial translation of the Soviet reply to President Eisenhower's proposal for an atomic energy pool.

Ervin F. Spratt, postmaster at Elkhart, Iowa, not far from Des Moines, does not make rounds, but if he did we trust that neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night would stay him from their swift completion. Mr. Spratt was appointed postmaster at Elkhart (pop. 249) in 1944. He maint2Jns the post office in what our dispatch describes as his "sundry' shop."

Mindful of the Christmas season, the head of a long-distance moving concern refused yesterday to press burglary charges in Bronx Magistrate's Court against a former employe who had been beset with tribulations since last September. As a result, George Graham, 36 years old, the defendant, was paroled for another hearing next Tuesday.

PORT HENRY, N. Y., Dec. 25 (AP) -- The state police said tonight they had arrested B. Gregory Brewster, son of the late State Supreme Court Justice, O. Byron Brewster, on a charge of forging prominent jurists' names to marriage annulment and divorce papers.

Meyer F. Wiles, attorney and engineer, has been appointed deputy Commissioner of the City Department of Public Work, Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen announced yesterday. Mr. Wiles, who is 46 years old, lives at 595 Crown Street, Brooklyn.

Lee Shubert, one of the theatre's principal figures for more than half a century, died yesterday at 5:24 P. M. in Mount Sinai Hospital. His physician, Dr. Sidney Greenberg, attributed death to "a complete failure of the circulatory system."

When Japanese Premier Yoshida described the return of the Amami island group to the sovereignty of his country as a "big Christmas gift" from the United States he may have been reflecting sentiment in his own country. We think that he reflected also the feelings of the United States. It was pleasant to be able to make this gesture at, .this time.
ATHENS, Dec. 24 -- Greece will preserve an old tradition by not severing a forty-two-year-old link between her Navy and the British Navy.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Thousands of pilgrims worshipped this Christmas Day at the shrines of Christianity, but some were turned back at the barbed-wire barricade dividing the land where Jesus taught peace on earth.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 23 -- A program to restore large scale faming in West Germany is being worked out by the Ministry of Agriculture.

The Syracuse Nationals once were difficult for the Knickerbockers to beat. The situation has changed. Last night at Madison Square Garden the local quintet beat the upstate team in a National Basketball Association test for the third time in three starts this season.
WASHINGTON CROSSING, Pa., Dec. 25 -- Eight Bucks County, Pa., men crossed the Delaware River in a small, unstable boat this afternoon.

This is St. Stephen's Day, the first of the "Twelve Days of Christmas." Perhaps if the trend toward more leisure time continues its already accelerated pace the time may come when all of us will enter more enthusiastically into what we now often think of as the post-Christmas season but what to our forebears was still part -- and a very important part -- of the Christmas season itself.

The Christmas story never ceases to be astonishing. It is not merely that the human family does not tire of being told of the Child of Bethlehem, or that year after year wide-eyed children listen for the first time to the tale of the Infant born in a manger, surrounded by the quiet beasts, the wondering shepherds, the angels singing Hallelujahs, and finally by kings bearing gifts from the East and guided by a star.

Their negotiations for the services of Uta Hagen having collapsed co-producers Alexander H. Cohen and Ralph Alswang now are understood to be seeking Constance Cummings for the principal feminine role in Julian Funt's "Child of Grace."

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Dec. 23 -- The power of a North Atlantic Treaty Organization commander -- that is, how much control he actually has over his international troops -- has never been defined. However, some of the questions raised by the presence of an international headquarters on French soil will be settled by a newly drawn agreement with France.

Retailers are preparing for their usual post-Christmas sales. January is traditionally a period for promotions. Items that did not move during the holiday season must be cleared and fall-winter goods must be moved while a market still exists.

The defense of Asia, for which the United Nations, and in particular the United States, have made great sacrifices in Korea and the French in Indo-China, has run into a strange dilemma. This results from Prime Minister Nehru's challenge to the projected American military aid to Pakistan, which guards the invasion routes to the Indian sub-continent against Communist aggression.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Dec. 25 -- The death roll in the railway disaster in the center of North Island, New Zealand, is now feared to exceed 150.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- The Administration, somewhat reluctantly, is getting up a report on the cost of Congressional junketing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 -- Film studio employes may not show up whistling like the Seven Dwarfs in Walt Disney's "Snow White," but they'll be back at work in the wonderland of Hollywood studios tomorrow.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 23 -- Falling revenue and increasing demands for state services make it virtually certain that Kentucky's General Assembly, convening Jan. 5, will have to find more tax money.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 25 -- The Vietminh attack across Central Laos was described by a French military spokesman here tonight as a full-scale drive to the Mekong River. He said late information showed the drive was bigger than initial evidence had indicated.

The ghost of Christmas advertising whistled through Manhattan's lonely shopping streets yesterday. With 364 more days to Christmas, there will be no need for early resurrection. The city's merchandising experts will, however, look at their recent efforts to determine where they made their mistakes and what to do to correct them.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury, head of the Church of England, and the Dean of St. Paul's, another leading Anglican cleric, commented today on the dilemma involved in the use of power by contending nations or groups to enforce their will.
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Efforts to confine the deadly virus disease of rabbits called myxomatosis to areas in the south of England have failed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The Administration's foreign policy program will meet serious opposition from the Democrats if it adopts a "threatening attitude" in supplying foreign aid, Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A machine that can read any standard type face was patented this week by David H. Shepard, 30-year-old president of the Intelligent Machines Research Corporation, Arlington, Va. It might be called a mechanical clerk, as it performs simple operations formerly done only manually.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Rural Electrification Chief Ancher Nelsen appointed a sixteen-member committee today to advise him "on matters of mutual interest to the R. E. A. and the electric cooperatives."
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Three noted Italian power boat drivers from Milan made satisfactory test runs today in tune-ups for the start of the four-day Orange Bowl regatta tomorrow.
None of the limited military actions that the United States might take to rearm Germany in case the European Defense Community treaty is not ratified, solves the problem of what to do about France.

A drop in work and income for professional carpenters and other craftsmen had been predicted for 1953 because of the boom in production of building materials designed for amateurs. But the drop has failed to materialize, according to Harry Feber, president of the Barclay Manufacturing Company, producer of building materials.
The gypsum industry reached near-top production levels this year and looks for another big year in 1954.

Although the National Labor Relations Board was guided by panic in rushing precipitately into the bargaining agent election of longshoremen in this port, the results vindicate those who stand for decency on the waterfront. The first figures show a vote of 9,060 for the old International Longshoremen's Association, which was expelled from the A. F. L. for failing to rid itself of racketeers, and 7,568 for the new A. F. L.-I. L. A.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A strike of Minneapolis Star and Tribune fleet truck drivers that started six days ago ended today.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 23 -- Old Guard Republicans are bidding for peace in the party's strife torn ranks in this state, but the so-called New Guard is waiting to see how high the price will go.
DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions and Cleveland Browns are set to slug it out "toe-to-toe" in their National Football League championship encounter Sunday in Briggs Stadium.
A commemoration of the first World Parliament of Religions, which took place at the Chicago World's Fair in 1893, will be held at 3 P. M. tomorrow near the site of the fair.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (Reuters) -- West Bromwich Albion took the lead today in British soccer's first division from the Wolverhampton Wanderers. The top two teams now are separated by only Albion's better goal average.

My attention has been drawn to L. D. Lyman's letter in The New York Times of Dec. 12. In it he suggests that the British Government deliberately chose an American-built British Overseas Airways stratocruiser for Her Majesty's recent flight from London to Bermuda, in preference to a British-built aircraft.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 25 -- The most powerful Negro organization in Central and South Africa has, served notice that it intends to fight openly for job equality for Negroes.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Dec. 25 -- Queen Elizabeth II, in her Christmas "fireside chat" to the Commonwealth today, dismissed the British tradition of empire by pledging herself to a "new conception of an equal partnership of races and nations."

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 25 -- One of the world's largest collections of printed matter about the Virgin Mary has been increased by acquisition of the 8,500-item library of the late Leon Clugnet, librarian of the University of Paris.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., requested yesterday a meeting next Monday with Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. to discuss his formula for avoiding a strike New Year's Day on the city's transit lines.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- With President Eisenhower off to Georgia for the holidays, official Washington was in repose today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- For a time today it seemed the children of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Reiter were doomed to a toyless yule.

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 23 -- Lobstering can be a lot of heavy work -- baiting traps, setting them and hauling them in again. But for James F. Cahill Jr., it is merely a matter of plunging overboard and bringing the crustaceans up by hand.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- Though some families are feeling the pinch of high living costs, families on the average are better off than they were ten years ago, Prof. Mabel Rollins, head of the Department of Economics of the Household and Household Management of the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell University, said at a recent conference here.
Completion of a modern truck terminal for the Yale Transport Corporation was announced yesterday by Benjamin Eskow, president of the company.
GLEN ROCK, N. J., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Cars jammed all streets around Carl Loven's controversial Christmas display today.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 25 -- President Chiang Kai-shek expressed hope today that a counter-attack against the Communist-held mainland would come in 1954.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- An "Americanism," the word "fissionable," has become the subject of one of the spirited, half-serious correspondences that periodically enliven the pages of The Times of London.

" The Maugham Enigma," an anthology edited by Klaus W. Jonas, will be published Jan. 25 by Citadel as a tribute to W. Somerset Maugham on his eightieth birthday, The volume contains a biography, personal reminiscences of close friends, discussions of all Maugham's works and a bibliography.

It is high time to make an assessment of the relations between the Argentina of President Juan D. Peron and the United States Administration under President Dwight D. Eisenhower. More than $57,000,000,000 was spent in 1953 in the United States for all kinds of transportation -- to move goods and people by waterways, railroads, highways and airlines and to transport petroleum products by pipelines.

A well-dressed man in his early twenties walked into the neighborhood grocery of Sam and Toby Kober at 403 Howard Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. He ordered cans of peas and beans and a loaf of bread. Before he departed, he produced a pistol, took $156 from the cash register and wished the owner and his wife "A Merry Christmas."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 25 (AP) -- For the love of the sport -- and perhaps a pro contract -- forty-eight college seniors exhibit their talents tomorrow in the annual Blue-Gray football game.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- The rulers of Communist China are sinking deeper into economic, political and ideological difficulties with each passing month, according to reports from China reaching British governmental and other agencies.

THE recent drop in temperature seems to have improved the waterfowl shooting from Connecticut to North Carolina. Although the season is almost over in most of the Atlantic flyway states, the wildfowlers in North Carolina, South Carolina, Delaware, Georgia, Maryland, and Virginia will have until Jan. 9 to make up for wasted time.

Sources of help on sex information for the adolescent are discussed by a physician-father and his daughter in articles appearing in the latest issue of Social Hygiene, a journal published by the American Social Hygiene Association.

The letter of H. G. W. Woodhead in The Times of Dec. 11 regarding "free" Hong Kong deserves serious consideration because of Mr. Woodhead's lifelong acquaintance with China, and because the statements contained in this letter, on the surface, are supported by statistically arranged facts. Through omission of at least equally significant data Mr. Woodhead has presented a one-sided view.
A number of artists who already are familiar to the public or perhaps will be in the future are participating in two of the group shows in the generous holiday program of exhibitions.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 25 (UP) -- Santa Anita Park, with $1,500,000 worth of improvements, including a grass course, will open its seventeenth racing season of fifty days tomorrow with the running of the $20,000 added Palos Verdes Handicap.

Your editorial of Dec. 16 on "Problems of Colonialism" is a concise and clear definition of the issues involved, but I think it fails to suggest or even to point the way to a solution of these problems.

IN 1779 Governor George Clinton reported to Congress on the Revolution's terrible border war in upstate New York. "The Iroquois Confederacy," he wrote, "hung like the scythe of death upon the rear of our settlements. * * * Their deeds are inscribed with the scalping knife and tomahawk in characters of blood in the gentle Cherry Valley and on the banks of the Mohawk."

THE almost unbelievable story that came out of northern Italy a few years ago about an American O.S.S. officer who allegedly had been killed by his own men behind the wartime Nazi lines is matched, with fanciful fictional variations, by Guthrie Wilson's "The Feared and the Fearless."

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- Recently developed methods that make possible the detection of meteors in the daytime, by employing radio waves as a "Jacob's Ladder" to the upper atmosphere, have revealed that the earth is being bombarded by a barrage of 10,000 to 100,000 meteors every second.

As on Christmas Day, the New York Public Library will keep its Main Reading Room and Information Desk open on New Year's Day from 1 to 10 P. M. All other divisions in the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street will be closed, as will all neighborhood branches.
GENEVA, Dec. 26 -- The weight of the United States Administration's influence has been thrown against any early effort by European countries to dismantle their foreign exchange controls.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Several spectacular spills marked the opening of the four-day Orange Bowl regatta today as a brisk north wind and choppy seas made the going rough for outboard racers.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Vince Boryla's 20-foot set shot with twenty seconds remaining tonight gave the New York Knickerbockers their sixth straight National Basketball Association victory -- a 78 -- 77 triumph over the Rochester Royals.
The 1954 budget for the Maritime administration is being awaited by the steamship industry with much trepidation.

David E. Lilienthal, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, proposed last night that the United States proceed immediately with the Eisenhower atomic energy plan among Western nations while continuing negotiations for Russian participation.

MAJOR COLBY, who had so much success with his picture books about planes and jets last year, has four new ones about the Armed Forces. The format is bigger, the pictures excellent, and the total effect should be to convince all boys that life in the Services is a marvelous adventure.
In her story "About Bears on a Rampage" (Nov. 15) Grace Glueck mentions "3,000 shakos" for the Guards--which she calls the Royal Guards--at Queen Elizabeth's coronation.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 26 (UP) -- Michigan State. a one-touchdown favorite, will shift to secret drills on Monday in final preparations for its Rose Bowl game against determined U. C. L. A.
Twenty families were routed last night from their apartments in a Bronx tenement by a fire set off by the explosion of a gas stove.

YONKERS, Dec. 26 -- Martin J. Parkinson, a former construction union official who was convicted of extortion and ordered out of labor activities, was reported today to have been invited to return to his old union post.
Seventeen young women were presented to society last night at the annual Yuletide Ball, given by the Brooklyn Kindergarten Society at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Significant changes in the meaning and application of the Taft-Hartley Law are taking place.

HONOLULU -- A major hotel expansion program that will add three hotels at Waikiki Beach and will increase the capacity of an existing hostelry by 100 rooms is under way here. When completed, the project will add 875 rooms in the heavily booked beach area.

BOMBAY, India, Dec. 26 -- The Communist party of India is expected by authoritative Communist sources here to adopt a new "non-violent" policy at the party's third annual convention which opens tomorrow at Madura in South India.

THE year 1953 has seen no startling developments in contract bridge. By the end of the year it was firmly entrenched as the country's favorite card game, having completely recovered from its, temporary eclipse by canasta, but that merely continued a trend that began in 1952 as the canasta boom receded.

YEATS' letters are in the process of gradual publication. The Irish poet Katharine Tynan led off decades ago by printing, in her first two volumes of reminiscences, a selection from the letters here edited by Roger McHugh.

THE plight of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra has never been better demonstrated than at the recent concert when the guest conductor, Rafael Kubelik, collapsed in the intermission of an exacting program and was unable to conduct the second half.

A HOLLYWOOD writer, Frances Marion, has 300 scenarios, including "The Champ" and "the Big House," to her credit. If that were not known, it might be deduced from this novel of life in a woman's prison, for Miss Marion is a slam-bang action-type writer.
TRENTON, Dec. 26 -- Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner will assume office shortly as the first Democratic Governor of New Jersey in a decade.

ATLANTA, Dec. 26 -- Brisk pre-Christmas business in the Southeast appears to have assured retail merchants of winding up the year with dollar volume exceeding that of 1952 by an estimated 3 per cent. Some stores reported new records in selling during December. Most others who reported trade below the peaks of 1952 said the declines were small.

The combination of good weather in the final week of holiday buying, the inclination of shoppers to put off purchases until the last moment, and the one additional shopping day in the week put sales about 20 per cent above the same week of 1952.

IN her third book Mrs. Coker portrays something of the shadow of the Old South that is reminiscent of Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind." Moving the fictional spotlight from Miss Mitchell's Georgia locale, Mrs. Coker widens her focus a bit and presents a picture of social change in her native South Carolina.

The need for better information among American youth about ways of life in Asia was demonstrated yesterday on the New York Times Youth Forum, at which Lady Rama Rau, Indian woman leader, discussed with six high school students the question "Will Youth Help Unite Free Asia and America?"
PARIS, Dec. 26 -- The population of France was estimated today at close to 43,000,000, the highest in the country's history.

To state, as Major Keyhoe does, that the Air Force knows about a threatened attack from space and is concealing it because of fear of "popular reaction" is to imply that the Air Force is dominated by fools and traitors.

WASHINGTON. NOT since Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth" split Washington theatregoers into two hostile camps has a tryout created such a critical cleavage, such a storm of pros and cons, in this controversial community as Jane Bowles' "In the Summer House," which opens in New York's Playhouse on Tuesday.
A total of 387 contributions -- most of them mailed on Christmas Eve -- brought the forty-second annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to $316,262.30 yesterday.
GORGEOUS color television, incredibly rich in texture and gay in brilliance, truly came into existence last week.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 26 -- Opening attacks in Minnesota's 1954 Congressional campaign indicate Republican intentions to emphasize again allegations of Democratic "softness toward communism."

Probably the two diseases about which the public hears most are cancer and poliomyelitis. The record of achievement in dealing with both in 1953 was brilliant.

NIGHT vision decreases as age increases, the American Automobile Association warns motorists, after a series of tests and studies including drivers from 18 to 68. Resistance to glare after dark becomes progressively poorer with advancing years although the man behind the wheel may not recognize this shortcoming, the tests showed.

USUALLY the first thing brought to mind at the mention of buried treasure is a pirate's chest, filled with gold and jewels, deep in island sands. "The Real Book About Treasure Hunting" reminds us that treasure can be found anywhere, providing the treasure hunter is curious about the world around him and has knowledge enough to recognize treasure when he finds it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 26 -- The decision to withdraw two United States divisions from Korea was reported here to be based on Washington's determination to fight a war of motion if the Communists should attack again.

WHEN the future historians of the movies look back upon 1953, they are not likely to be interested in it because of the exceptional quality of its films. While the year has provided some fine pictures, as this column is aimed to attest, these have been -- and will be -- incidental to excitements of a more aggressive sort.

PRESIDENT EISENHOWER, by his recent innovation of releasing a tape recording of one of his press conferences and allowing himself to be quoted directly, opened a new chapter in the history of Presidential press conferences. New York Times correspondents in the world's principal capitals and areas of tension -- and The Associated Press correspondents in Moscow -- were asked last week to summarize the prevailing mood in their assigned countries. They reported some improvement.

ON this last Sunday of 1953, The New York Times renews its appeal for the Neediest Cases of New York City. Behind the Neediest lies a year which has brought them little but struggle and heartbreak; before them looms another year, dark with uncertainty.

THE end of the year is an appropriate time to look back over the recipes that have aroused the greatest interest among our readers. We reprint five of them today. The variety is great and indicates no definite trend in culinary tastes.

FOR his first novel, laid in Cuba and Florida in the late Eighteen-Nineties and early Nineteen-Hundreds, Francis J. Thompson has chosen rich and exciting material. Voodoo, juju, orgiastic dances, sexual frankness, racial contrasts, an authoritative-seeming knowledge of exotic places and customs -- these provide the reader with excellent local color on every other page.

A forty-eight-page issue of the Exakta quarterly, the largest in its history, inaugurates a new era for this "magazine for Exakta photographers." Edited by George Berkowitz and published by Wolf Wirgin, the new issue, just out, has been designed by Leo Lionni, art director of Fortune Magazine.

As a constant and admiring follower of John Lardner, I would like to express my appreciation for his excellent portrayal of the depths to which big-time college football has sunk. In "The 230-Pound Brain Wins in Football" (Nov. 22) Mr. Lardner has put his satirical finger on the sore spot of our "autumnal madness."
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. is hoping to settle major transit problems before he takes office Friday.

One child of every three in city elementary schools is in a class so large it is impossible for him to get a fair amount of his teacher's time, the National Education Association finds in a study of overcrowding in grade-school classes across the nation.

FOR all those who have followed the triumphs and despairs of the City Center during the last ten years, it should come as heartening news this morning that, as a consequence of the public drive for funds, and the success of the current drama series, the Fifty-fifth Street showcase is in the black again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A proposal that the Democratic party work up its own legislative program was advanced today by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, who was a leading candidate last year for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today he would attack the reasoning of Republican leaders who would delay statehood for Alaska but grant it to Hawaii.

School problems are pretty much the same the world over. Nations everywhere report that they are suffering from teacher shortages, from building needs and from financial difficulties. Economic and social handicaps are limiting the effectiveness of teachers in almost every part of the globe.

On the first payday of the new year, millions of Americans will not -- as they usually do -- tear off the stubs attached to their paychecks and toss them in the nearest waste basket. They will take a long, hard look at the little squares containing the withholdings for income tax and Social Security.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- After building a convincing lead despite a damaged left eye. Livio Minelli, Italian welterweight, lost on a ten-round technical knockout to Wilbur Wilson of Boston in their nationally televised bout tonight at Mechanics Building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, said today he would seek authority early next month for a full-scale, nation-wide investigation of alleged labor racketeerink and misuse of union welfare and insurance funds.

COMPLETE with a glossary of botanical terms, and a "ready identification chart," "Wild Flowers of America" (Crown, $10) is a compilation of full-page color plates guaranteed to lure the most jaded of nature lovers, as well as the wild-flower fan. Mary Vaux Walcott and Dorothy Falcon Platt are the artists; H. W. Rickett has written a detailed description to accompany each painting.

For the second time in a generation Japan is struggling with the problems of "rationalization," which means that she is trying to improve her ability to meet foreign competition by deflating prices and increasing efficiency at home.
Need of free-world nations to develop economic alliances is a subject that is beginning to get increasing attention from leaders in the fields of international trade and investment.
LINCOLN, Mass., Dec. 26 (UP) -Two private planes collided in flight today but the occupants, two men and a woman, escaped with their lives.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers moved ahead of West Bromwich Albion today for the leadership in the first division of the British Football Association as they scored a 2 -- 1 victory over Aston Villa.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today he would ask Congress in the 1954 session to increase personal and dependency exemptions from $600 to $700.

The first American open squash racquets championship to be held with the sponsorship of the United States Association in that sport will get under way on the afternoon of New Year's Day at the University Club, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

When she broadcast from Auckland on Christmas Day, Queen Elizabeth II spoke of being "completely and most happily at home." She was, of course, just as much within her kingdom as she would have been had she remained in London. New Zealand is not a tributary to the home island but it is a free and equal member of what the Queen called "a world-wide fellowship of nations of a type never seen before."

The year 1953 was another year of uncertainty in the struggle between the free and the Communist worlds. Most of the old problems persisted. The great change was in leadership -- with the arrival of a Republican regime in the U. S. after twenty years of the Democrats, and a new Soviet regime after twenty-nine years of the old dictator, Stalin.

BRANDON DE WILDE, who at 7 made a loudly acclaimed Broadway debut in "The Member of the Wedding" and at 9 was co-starred in the popular motion picture "Shane," has at 11 established himself as a triple-threat performer by becoming television's only regularly scheduled juvenile leading man.

Beginning with the first of the year, Cecil Presbrey, Inc., one of the country's leading advertising agencies will be headed by a man of many talents and interests. He is Thomas J. Maloney, who, despite his comparative youth (he is in his forties) has had a career studded with accomplishments in diverse fields.

THE northern anglers, who find little sport in jigging the cold off-shore waters for cod, or in fishing through the ice, are now looking southward. This year the major interest seems to be directed toward the assorted fishing resorts scattered through the Bahamas.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- As this year slips into 1954 there seems to be a reasonable prospect that the great protagonists of the eight-year-old contest fought with politics and propaganda -- and, in Korea, Malaya and Indo-China, with blood -- will meet.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 26 -- President Eisenhower announced today that United States ground forces in Korea would be "progressively reduced," but he warned that any renewal of aggression there would be opposed "with even greater effect than heretofore."

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the old International Longshoremen's Association, issued this public warning yesterday to the New York Shipping Association: Negotiate a contract with us at once or face a strike any time after next Saturday midnight.

A MODERN philatelic mystery of the Nile was solved when the contents of the Egyptian "Palace Collection" of stamps assembled by the late King Fuad I and his successor Farouk, now in exile, were disclosed here last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Public Health Service, an adjunct of the Federal Security Agency, today announced that 155 construction projects to cost $38,000,000 for river and stream purification plants were awarded in the third quarter of this year. Of these, eighty-seven were new plants and sixty-eight were additions.

Real progress was made in 1953 in the development of rehabilitation and services to the handicapped. NEW YEAR'S DAY for other peoples may be the day of hangovers and good resolutions. In Haiti it is Independence Day, punctuated on Jan. 1 by the sssssh of colored rockets, the dry popping of firecrackers, the military bray of brass bands, and a tidal wave of mellifluous French oratory.

Walter Schoenknecht, who developed the Mohawk Mountain Ski area near Cornwall, Conn., announced last week that he plsnned to start work on the Vermont project next spring and would have it ready for use within two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Emmett (Rosy) O'Donnell said today that the Air Force faced "grave problems" in maintaining itself by volunteers, but hoped to meet expanded manpower goals without using the draft.

HOBBIES, in a few words, are not what they used to be Originally, the name itself derived from hobbyhorse, with all its foolish connotations, as though to have a hobby were to pursue a private passion with the frivolous concentration of a child riding a toy animal.

WE are on the threshold of a year that at the beginning of the decade was marked "critical'' on the calendar of Western policy planners. As 1954 opens before us, however, the prospect is of wary negotiations, reappraisals of policy, momentous decisions, but not of war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A single Social Security program combining public assistance for the needy with Federal old age and survivors insurance was proposed today by Representative Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Dec. 10 -The Liberian Republic, now in its 107th year of independence, aspires to be the showpiece of African democracy. However, progress in this respect has been impeded by inner contradictions and weaknesses.

Discoveries in nuclear physics inevitably held the major attention of the world this year in science as well as in other fields. The cotton farmers have approved acreage allotments and marketing quotas on their 1954 crop by an overwhelming majority. While they may have objected to imposition of drastic controls, the growers had no other recourse than to vote as they did.

If you could live your life over again, what would you do? Answers to this question were supplied by forty-three members of the congregation of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. The New York County Lawyers Association asked the Federal Trade Commission yesterday to stop the sale of "Will Form Packages" and "Will Kits" by the Providence Publishing Company of Keene, N. H., as an improper practice of the law.

Bernice Reaser, pianist, and Robert Alden Reaser, painter, appeared in a Debussy program late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. Twenty-six television stations in nineteen cities are scheduled to be equipped this week for transmitting programs in color, according to a year-end statement issued yesterday by David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America.

James Beard, the co-author of "Paris Cuisine" (Little, Brown, 1952), returned from Paris the other day with the glow and enthusiasm of one who has lived high for six weeks. Eight of the thirty-six players competing in the biennial tournament for the national individual championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League at John Jay Hall, Columbia University, emerged yesterday with clean scores of 2 -- 0 each.

The Ballet Theatre, which recently completed an extended tour of Europe, last night gave its only Broadway performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House before departing on a transcontinental tour. JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 27 -- The three principal urban areas of South Africa have had an unusually quiet Christmas, the police report, instead of the usual outbreaks of violence.

After slightly higher prices in initial dealings last week, prices of cotton futures in the domestic market turned easier and closed with irregular price changes Thursday, the last trading session for the period. Looking at 1954 as a "hard selling year," representatives of the Association of National Advertisers, Inc., sat down last week with representatives of the Magazine Advertising Bureau and some of the principal publishers to work out better methods of merchandising magazine advertising at the retail level.

This column's first encounter with Colin Clark, the well-known Australian economist, was in the pages of what is probably his best-known work, "The Conditions of Economic Progress." It struck the reader as a noteworthy venture in economic exploration.
