ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, French West Africa, Dec. 18 -- After years of experimental work, a French concern is ready to construct a plant here to convert the stored-up heat of the sea into electric power.

The New York Pro Musica Antiqua, directed by Noah Greenberg, gave the second of three concerts last night at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. The program, largely seasonal in nature, was devoted to music of the fifteenth century, consisting of English carols and Flemish and French vocal and instrumental works.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Sir Alfred Savage, Governor of this British Colony, named ten members of an Executive Council and twenty-seven members of a Legislative Council today to rule British Guiana as an Interim Government.

JACK WEBB, the earnest entrepreneur of "Dragnet," over-extended himself in his observance of the Christmas season. His special holiday assignment for television's most popular fictional detectives, Joe Friday and Frank Smith, aspired to the status of a Yuletide classic on two different counts and fell short on both.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Although the pre-Christmas stock markets here experienced a natural decline in business, interest was remarkably well sustained and a further fairly general advance occurred last week in security values.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- John Foster Dulles said today that the Soviet rulers were now on a diplomatic defensive, and the free world had the "diplomatic and moral initiative," which it intended to keep.

The National Industrial Conference Board said yesterday that the wide spread between the Consumer Price Index and the index of prices received by farmers did not indicate undue costs of manufacture and distribution of food or that the farmer's share of the food dollar has declined unduly.

WINNIPEG, Man., Dec. 27 (UP) -- Four survivors of a forced landing of a small plane in the snowy wilderness north of here were found alive and safe today, but a baby born to a woman passenger during the second day of their ordeal had died.

There must be something about the Chicago Black Hawks that makes the New York Rangers forget all they ever knew about hockey. Against the other teams in the National League, the Broadway Blues have been doing fairly well of late.

IF two biographies of Jeb Stuart were published in the same week, or two historical romances about Francesca da Rimini on the same day, little stir would be aroused in the world of books. Such coincidences are commonplace. But it still seems surprising that four learned editors, in groups of two, should have produced two large anthologies on an identical subject for publication this season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has started work on the story for a picture that, it is said, will represent a cavalcade of Cole Porter music. Gene Kelly will star in the production, which has no title yet. Betty Comden and Adolph Green are writing the screen play under the supervision of Arthur Freed, who will produce.

The "Tannhaeuser" performance Saturday night, with a cast brilliantly headed by Margaret Harshaw as Elisabeth, and a masterly interpretation of the score by George Szell, the conductor, was on the whole the swiftest and most eloquent rendition of this opera that we have heard in many seasons at the Metropolitan Opera House.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The Government told Oskar J. W. Hansen, a sculptor, today to finish repair work on the Victory Monument at Yorktown, Va., without delay.
UNZEN, Japan, Monday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Golf in this scenic highland country is strictly for the birds.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, Dec. 27 -- There is good evidence today to show that the Gold Coast's Prime Minister was in earnest when he rebuffed his Communist-minded associates two-months ago and pulled his regime away from Communist entanglements.
The American Iron and Steel Institute has established a new index to serve as a yardstick for comparing the nation's steel production in any two or more weekly, monthly or annual periods.

Holiday-weary New Yorkers returned to the city in large numbers yesterday after the three-day Christmas week-end. More came home than left during the day, according to rail, automobile and airline authorities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration, said tonight that a complete blockade of all trade with Iron Curtain countries would "make the prospects of war more likely."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- Bob Wolfe steered his Pamela B to victory in this afternoon's frostbite regatta which completed the fall championship series at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Accompanied by9-year-old Danny Connell through the seven-race session, Wolfe totaled 184 of a possible 210 points against twenty-six rivals.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, the imperturbable Cincinnati youngster, disposed of Ken Rosewall, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4, after Lewis Hoad whipped Vic Seixas, 6-4, 6-2, 6-3, today to give the United States an even break in the opening singles of the Davis Cup challenge round against Australia.

DETROIT, Dec. 27 -- They didn't have a place - kicker like Lou Groza. Nor did they have a runner like Chick Jagade. But the Detroit Lions did have the spirit, the determination and the weapons to come from behind in the closing minutes and upset the Cleveland Browns, 17 -- 16, for the professional football championship at Briggs Stadium today.

The eighth week of opera at the Metropolitan beginning with "La Traviata" on Monday evening, Jan. 4, will present several singers in roles for the first time at the house. In Wednesday's "Don Giovanni," Hilde Gueden will sing her first Zerlina; and in the cast of the following evening's "Il Trovatore" will be Josef Metternich and Norman Scott, heard for the first time as the Count di Luna and Ferrando.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Two Democratic Senators tonight proposed a revised excess profits tax exempting all companies earning less than $100,000 a year.

Continuing their torrid pace, the New York Knickerbockers reeled off their seventh straight National Basketball Association decision by turning back the Philadelphia Warriors, 79 to 76, before 9,227 onlookers at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Dec. 27 -- Mountaineers who climbed the 9,000-foot Ruapehu Volcano found evidence that its' eruption had caused the Christmas Eve raftway disaster feared to have cost 166 lives.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Western swimmers won the annual East-West college meet for the fifteenth straight year today, but the score of 125 -- 122 was the closest in the history of the event. The East never has won.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A recent poll in New Jersey indicates that most of the country's doctors would like to come under the Social Security old age and survivors insurance program, according to Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican of New Jersey.
The crew of the Greenbay Victory was in a stew recently over whether the chief cook had the right to spoil the broth by himself or was entitled to help from the chief steward.
PRINCETON JUNCTION, N. J., Dec. 27 -- Mice with pyromaniacal tendencies were blamed today for the fire that destroyed the station here that had withstood Years of Princeton student exuberance.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Arab League delegates met here today to try to draft a note to the United Nations rejecting Israel's call for direct peace talks.

A series of four weekly lectures for women on "Religion and the Great Issues of the Day" will be held at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, beginning next Monday at 11 A. M. The series has been arranged by the women's committee of the seminary.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- Reaching out into interstellar space with a radio wave tweny-one centimeters long, pulsing with a frequency of 1,420 million cycles per second, man has extended the frontiers of his observed universe to distances several thousand light years beyond those previously studied with the most powerful optical telescope.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The Most Rev. Patrick A. O'Boyle called on the free countries of the world today to seek a formal United Nations investigation of communism's "diabolical attempt to exterminate all religion."

The first atomic-powered submarine and the man who conceived the idea, Rear Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, are the subjects of a book by Clay Blair Jr., Pentagon correspondent of Time magazine. Arthritis, tuberculosis, cerebral palsy, rheumatic fever -- these are but a few of the ailments that afflict the Neediest. CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, said today his party had lost ground in Illinois during 1953 and was hurt generally by the Harry Dexter White controversy.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 27 -- The Netherlands Bank took an important further step last week toward liberalization of restrictions on the movement of capital.

The Soviet Union has been stepping up imports of wool and wool textiles to implement its policy of increasing its supplies of consumer goods.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County was sworn in yesterday at a private ceremony for his fourth four-year term. General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen administered the oath of office to Mr. Hogan in the District Attorney's office in the presence of the prosecutor's wife, Mary, and his brother, Joseph.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Igor Gouzenko, former Soviet code clerk in Ottawa who touched off a Communist spy expose, said today that he believed the parents of some Americans in Communist hands were being "blackmailed" into spying for the Soviet Union.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 27 -- The case of Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, Peruvian revolutionary who on Sunday will complete five years of asylum in the Colombian Embassy here, has become the most controversial issue in South America. The whole question of political asylum is at stake.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas, teaming in perfect unison, swamped Australia's Lewis Hoad and Rex Hartwig, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today in the doubles match to send the United States into a 2-1 lead in the Davis Cup challenge round.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- In a national poll conducted by the American Automobile Association's Contest Board, sports writers today picked Wally Campbell of Trenton as auto racing's rookie of the year and Bill Holland of Indianapolis as the "comeback driver" of the recent campaign.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 28 -- Tighter state control over union finances and elections was recommended here today as a final act of the September Nassau County grand jury investigating labor racketeering at Roosevelt Raceway and in the building trades unions.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad today ordered indefinite furloughs for about 11 per cent of its working force.

Carl Norgauer of Yonkers, second seeded in the junior singles, led the field into the third round yesterday as play began in the Eastern indoor tennis championships for juniors and boys at the 102d Engineers Armory. Norgauer drew a first-round bye and defeated Sheridan Snyder of Sea Cliff, L. I., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.

WHANGAREI, New Zealand, Tuesday, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- A private picnic lunch amid the quiet of the Maori countryside today offered Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh a brief respite from public ceremony.

A total of $10,000,000 has been raised by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in the forty-two annual appeals it has made on behalf of individuals and families in tragic and bewildering circumstances. That mark was reached and passed yesterday, when $4,343.18 was received from 259 donors.

THE art of irrelevant but engaging digression is rarely cultivated by modern writers, who seem to fear that if they paused frequently to say: "And that reminds me of * * *," they would lose their readers' attention altogether. To digress in print requires unusual self-assurance, a serene conviction that anything one has to say is obviously worth saying.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 28 -- Negotiations between representatives of India and Pakistan on conditions for a plebiscite in the disputed State of Jammu and Kashmir ended inconclusively today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Theodore C. Streibert, director of the United States Information Agency, said today that the United States information program in the Far East "must be considerably expanded." He has just returned from a twenty-day tour of the Far East.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 28 -- Pulsating variable stars, keys to many of the mysteries of the universe and long used as yardsticks to distant clusters and galaxies of stars, are themselves as mysterious as ever.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, carried to high Administration officials today his plea for a treaty between the United States and Canada to restrict shipping between Great Lakes ports to vessels owned and operated by citizens of the two countries.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Columbia's Basketball team, with Guard Chuck Brown and Center Frank Thomas hitting in the clutch, defeated Pitt, 75-64, tonight at the Pittfield House.

George Benton, 154 pounds, Philadelphia, gained a split decision over Bobby Jones, 155 1/4, Oakland, Calif., in the ten-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Two years' achievements in the continuing struggle against cancer at the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research were reviewed yesterday in its biennial report.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The upturn that began on Thursday in grain and soybean futures continued today.
GROVE HILL, Ala., Dec. 28 (UP) -- A Sheriff, claiming self-defense, today shot to death a Negro prisoner who three months ago testified against him in a moonshine liquor case.

Some unscrupulous new-car dealers are resorting more and more to unfair advertising and selling practices, says the Better Business Bureau of New York City. Their actions, the bureau points out, are the result of the stiffening of competition in the auto field.

Early spring bookings of children's apparel are running slightly ahead of last year despite the generally poor fall season. Many retailers moved goods before Christmas at cut prices and excellent holiday activity cleared stocks.

The two - story one - family dwelling at 63-27 Seventy-sixth Street in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by Morris W. Feldman to Carl Appel. Title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 28 -- The Lehigh and Wagner College quintets joined Cortland and American University in the semi-finals of the third annual Hofstra College Christmas Invitation Basketball Tournament with victories on the Calkins Gym boards tonight. Wagner defeated Delaware in the opener, 57 -- 47, and Lehigh won the nightcap, 66 -- 50, over Wesleyan.
Yesterday's mail brought a letter from a Texas friend, who wrote:

Since no one critic could handle a play like "Sing Till Tomorrow," unassisted, your correspondent prudently sought the assistance of Alan Dent, critic of The London News-Chronicle. But even though we pooled our knowledge, experience and hopes of a better life, we could not make head or tail of Jean Lowenthal's play, which opened at the Royale last evening.

In a year-end statement Secretary Dulles declares that the Western Powers have chased Soviet Russia across the map of Europe and Asia for the purpose of getting its rulers to negotiate, and that it is beginning to look as if we have caught them. It does begin to look that way, but it is by no means certain.

For the better part of one week each year the nation's professional economists -- or a large percentage of them -- foregather to exchange ideas on the most important current problems in their field. This year's convention opened at Washington with a radio-television discussion of the business outlook and the Administration's plans for dealing with any possible depression.

HENLEY, England, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Capt. Evan John Simpson, author and a leading British intelligence officer in Greece during World War II, was found shot dead near his farm yesterday, a rifle near by Captain Simpson, 52 years old, wrote historical novels, political books, biographies and plays under the name Evan John.

The cotton futures market opened 2 to 4 points up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed strong, 4 to 23 points net higher than on last Thursday, with the strength most pronounced in the near months.

The woman who has raised her family and now wants a job outside her home has a better chance of finding a responsible position than ever before, the Institute of Life Insurance reported recently. Fewer of these women are working today as semi-skilled or unskilled workers, according to a Government analysis cited by the institute; more are in other occupation groups.

THOSE who cannot find the type of shooting they want on local preserves, and are unable to work up enthusiasm for foxes or rabbits, can still enjoy good quail and turkey sport from North Carolina to Florida, but it is advisable to make arrangements for this hunting before leaving home.

HELIOPOLIS, Egypt, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A court hearing on former Queen Narriman's divorce suit was postponed today until Jan. 19 while lawyers for her and former King Farouk try to reach an "amicable settlement."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The State Department withheld official comment today on the new Vietminh invasion of Laos, one of the three Associated States of Indo-China. Henry Suydam, information officer, said officials were awaiting further dispatches before expressing any views.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Charles Silvers of Miami, the leading owner at Tropical Park, won her twelfth race of the current meeting when Biddy Bid scored an impressive triumph in the Summer Lightning Purse.
Casey Stengel will take his annual look at some of the Yankees' outstanding minor league players at the Prospects School from Feb. 2 through 20 at St. Petersburg, Fla.

The Putman Management Company, manager of the George Putman Fund, has issued its annual review of the nation's largest college endowment fund, that of Harvard University. The latest study points out what a tremendous financial undertaking the 300-year-old Harvard fund has become.
The President's week-end announcement that two Army divisions would be withdrawn from Korea "soon" is a logical part of the developing politico-military policy of the Eisenhower Administration.

TRENTON, Dec. 28 -- Six hundred teen-age boys and girls descended on this city today to learn at first hand the operation of government on state,county or municipal levels. The group represented every county in the state and nearly every public high school from Cape May to High Point.

Steelmaking operations slowed even more last week than had been generally anticipated, but were scheduled to pick up somewhat this week despite the imminence of the New Year's holiday. The mills worked at 64.1 per cent of theoretical capacity last week and produced 1,444,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Janet Jagan, United States-born wife of British Guiana's deposed Prime Minister, was given the choice today of a fine of the equivalent of $140 or three months in jail for having held an illegal political meeting disguised as a religious ceremony.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Tim Coss of Swarthmore (Pa.) College, top-seeded player in the young men's division of the Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament, advanced into the semi-finals today with a 7-5, 6-1 victory over John Hiers of the University of Florida.
Columbia Pictures' adaptation of James Jones' best-selling novel, "From Here to Eternity," captured a majority of the annual awards given by the New York Film Critics yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- Experiments shedding light on the fundamental chemical mechanism by which the virus infecting the tobacco plant duplicates and perpetuates itself at the expense of the plant's normal cells were reported today.
The New York City Housing Authority announced plans yesterday for the sale of two issues of loan notes totaling $64,330,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A proposed loyalty - security check-up on all the approximately 1,800 employes of the Senate has bogged down, although it was recommended by a unanimous Senate vote ten months ago.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 28 (UP) -- Dr. William A. Pearl, an egineer-industrialist with experience in Government power, was named today to head the Government's $670,000,000 Bonneville Power Administration.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Directors of the American Woolen Company split six to three on a proposal to retire two classes of preferred stock at a cost of $19,500,000, a board member said today.

MONTREAL, Dec. 28 (AP) -- President Clarence Campbell of the National Hockey League today ordered a seven-game suspension for Bernie (Boom-Boom) Geoffrion of the Montreal Canadiens and a four-game penalty for Ron Murphy of the New York Rangers.
Preliminary reports on violence and intimidation in last week's bitterly contested waterfront election were on their way to Governor Dewey last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- New York State said today its film censorship law was a vital weapon in fighting juvenile delinquency.

The progress that is being made in Latin America in defending freedom of the press is becoming truly impressive. At the same time there is a growing awareness and appreciation of the value of press freedom among governmental leaders in the hemisphere, so it is not entirely a defensive struggle.
MADURA, India, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Hindu religious fervor today swept aside well-laid Communist plans to keep attention focused on the party's first Congress in five years.
Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. announced yesterday he would create a new city Department of Labor. He named Joseph E. O'Grady to head it.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 -- Mexico is going through a new revolution and Mexican men, whose position it threatens, are not altogether happy about it.

Two attorneys turned an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing into a brawl yesterday. When it was over the examiner, Tobias Naftalin, adjourned the hearing indefinitely and said the case "never should haye come before the commission in the first place."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Ambassadors of Syria and Lebanon conferred for forty-five minutes today with John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, but would say afterward only that they had had "a very delightful talk."

Lord Taylor, New York department store, announced yesterday that it would open its fifth out-of-town store in the suburban area west of Philadelphia. According to Miss Dorothy Shaver, president of the firm, the store should be open for business early in 1955.
Tea flowed freely in scattered parts of the city yesterday as students from many parts of the world celebrated the Christmas holidays.
PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Defense Minister Rene Pleven said today that the Government planned a total armed strength in 1954 of 617,000 men, or 11,000 more than this year.
Al Weill, manager of heavyweight champion, Rocky Marciano, said yesterday that he had not agreed to a title match between Rocky and Danny Nardico in Miami, Fla., on Feb. 24.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 29 --The United Nations Command remained silent today on a proposal of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission for further discussion with the Communists regarding the fate of more than 22,000 prisoners of the Korean war.

Your editorial of Dec. 22 on the French Presidential crisis offers an unrealistic and misleading interpretation of the French parliamentary impasse. By ignoring the concrete social and economic problems and the historic idealogical cleavages in which France's political and parliamentary fragmentation is rooted, you unintentionally join the chorus of French anti-democrats and anti-parliamentarians who see in legislative misconduct the sole cause of their country's political troubles.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday that beginning on Friday, it would issue a new medical expense policy with broad and extensive coverage. The policy has a deductible amount of $500, similar to automobile collision insurance, and a $7,500 benefit limit with respect to any one accident or sickness and applies separately to each member of a family.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A high Republican source said today that the bill to authorize the United States to join Canada in building the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project was the likely first order of Senate business in the next session of Congress, starting Jan. 6.
MIAMI, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The key performers in Friday's Orange Bowl football game may be Quarterbacks Charley Boxold of Maryland and Gene Calame of Oklahoma who were second -- stringers in September.

Carl (Bobo) Olson, the Honolulu native who holds the middleweight championship of the world, has been named the Fighter of the Year by The Ring Magazine, a publication devoted to the activities of boxing. Olson, now a resident of San Francisco, became the 160-pound titleholder by defeating Randy Turpin of England last Oct. 21.
Shrewd detective work by a 13-year-old high school girl, anxious to save her mother from heroin addiction, led to the breaking up last night of a Harlem narcotics ring.

Forty-one years ago this month The Times issued its first annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases, receiving on their behalf that year $3,000. Twenty-nine years ago this month the late Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher, was proudly able to announce that during the twelve years between 1912 and 1924 the grand total had reached one million dollars.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Prof. Philip Taft of Brown University said today that employers were more to blame than unions for Communist penetration of labor.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Dillon gave a dinner dance last night in their home at 124 East Eightieth Street for their debutante granddaughter, Miss Christine Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Allen of 760 Park Avenue and Far Hills, N. J.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Yale's Bulldogs defeated Marquette, 66 -- 57, in an intersectional basketball game before a crowd of less than 2,000 at the Milwaukee Arena tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Decreasing winds tonight slowed the progress of a fire that was creeping up the steep wooded slopes toward Mount Wilson and its famed observatory and $4,000,000 television transmitting installations.

A comprehensive plan within the shipping industry to merge competitive trade groups into a single powerful organization has failed, but leading shipping men throughout the country still hope that the rival groups will come together for the industry's own good, they said yesterday.

Unbeaten Duquesne handed Brigham Young its first setback of the season, 69 -- 47, and Niagara repeated an earlier victory over La Salle, this time by 69 -- 50, in the second annual Holiday, Basketball Festival semi-finals last night before 12,135 fans at Madison Square Garden. The Dukes and the Purple Eagles will vie for the top honors tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- When President Eisenhower invited the Democratic leaders of Congress to confer privately with him on Jan. 5 on his State of the Union Message, he recognized the central fact of Executive-Legislative relations in the post-war period.
Two of the eight members of the Board of Estimate who will take office on Friday were sworn in yesterday at separate ceremonies.
Owners of commercial trucks, taxis and buses, who have until Friday to register, obtained 5,000 1954 tabs yesterday at the local office of the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
The following article was written by William L. Ryan, Associated Press correspondent, who recently returned from the Soviet Union, where he traveled more than 6,000 miles:
DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Stockholders of Briggs Manufacturing Company today approved sales of Briggs' seven auto body and aircraft parts plants to Chrysler Corporation for $35,000,000.

A college professor yesterday characterized as "tyranny" the proposal by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. to compel witnesses who seek the protection of the Fifth Amendment to testify if granted immunity from criminal prosecution.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The Soviet Union is expected to present a carefully booby-trapped proposal for German unity and neutrality to the meeting of foreign ministers in Berlin next month.

NEWARK, Tuesday, Dec. 29 -- A former convict and mental institution inmate confessed early today, the police reported, that he had killed a youth whose body he had helped to find early Sunday in the Belleville extension of Branch Brook Park.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. (UP) -- Maj. Charles E. Yeager's rocket test plane went out of control and dropped nearly ten agonizing miles before he regained control on his historic flight Dec. 12.

Close cooperation with Governor Dewey and other officials to uphold "clean and efficient" government was promised yesterday by William B. Herlands, whose appointment as the first State Commissioner of Investigation was announced by the Governor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A. F. Dobrynin, counselor of the Soviet Embassy here, headed a delegation that opened discussions today on the ways and means of returning to United States control 186 naval craft furnished to his Government during World War II under the lend-lease program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Eisenhower Administration has been exploring the possibility of asking Congress to isolate the major portion of surplus farm commodities as a strategic reserve for future emergencies or shortages.

I would refer to the recent publications which have appeared in your newspaper pertaining to the case of asylum which is being discussed between Peru and Colombia. Without analyzing the different aspects touched upon in your editorial of Dec. 12 and also in letters from Norman Thomas and others which you have published in your issue of Dec. 15, I feel obliged to make the following statement:

To get more blood in the customarily unproductive holiday season, the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will establish a special center today and next Tuesday at Federal Hall Museum, Wall and Nassau Streets.
MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 29 -- President-elect Ramon Magsaysay announced ten of his fourteen Cabinet members last night.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced here early today that Charles E. Johnson, one of its ten most wanted men, had been arrested about midnight last night in Central Islip, L. I.

" Times Gone By," an eight-part episodic Italian import, is today's new film, at the Guild Theatre. The eight episodes were written by several scenarists, with Alessandro Blasetti directing the production. Starred in various roles are Aldo Fabrizi, Mario Riva, Andrea Checchi, Alba Arnova, Arnoldo Foa, Folco Lulli, Maurizio di Nardo, Elio Pandolfi, Barbara Florian, Amedeo Nazzari, Elisa Cegni, Gina Lollobrigida and Vittorio De Sica.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Democrats were divided today on whether to attempt to take up a partisan position at once in the coming session of Congress and if so on which issues.

TELEVISION viewers were almost rocked out of their chairs by the furious force of the rib-rattling tackles and blocks that the Detroit Lions and Cleveland Browns hurled recklessly at each other in their championship play-off last Sunday. It was enough to scare a guy, even in his own living room. Professional football rarely has had such a wonderful advertisement as that game.

An authorized account of the conquest of the world's highest mountain, entitled "The Conquest of Everest," will be published by Dutton on Jan. 25. Written by Sir John Hunt, leader of the British Expedition, it describes the preparations for each stage of the climb.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- William B. Herlands, who has been special prosecutor in the Staten Island inquiry into gambling and political corruption for the last two years, will be the state's first Commissioner of

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- West Germany's remarkable and, in some respects, embarrassing expansion of production and exports was the subject of an annual report issued here today by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The United States High Commissioner's office said tonight that Justice Clark could not return to Germany but that his wife, the former Sonia Tomara, who had been a foreign correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, had a valid passport and could return.

A. M. Tenney Associates, Inc., which for more than twenty years has handled the sales of acetate yarn and staple for Tennessee Eastman Company, will relinquish this responsibility to Eastman Chemical Products, Inc., at the beginning of the new year, it was announced yesterday.
The expected court test of the Council-approved bill to permit taxicabs of the smaller stock-car type developed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Many children today are getting a poorer education than their parents received, in the opinion of Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, Federal Commissioner of Education.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -- The motion-picture industry's production code stands in danger of losing its authority as a basic morals yardstick unless it is "brought reasonably up to date," Samuel Goldwyn has declared in a letter to Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Dewey outlined today a broad program to mend Republican fences in preparation for next year's state election.

The piano recital given last night in Town Hall by Miss Monte Hill Davis, 21 years old, was that of a young pianist who has excellent fingers, contagious enthusiasm, an inborn feeling for beauty of tone and phrase, and -- obvious shortcomings as of today, where musicianship and interpretation are concerned.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 28 -- Bastiaan W. Haveman, Netherlands Commissioner for Emigration, took serious exception today to reports that all was not well between the South African Government and Dutch immigrants.
Two men who posed as tax bureau agents and flashed silver badges and gold-sealed "documents'' attesting their authority, robbed a Queens widow of $10,500 in cash and $600 in bonds yesterday.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, in its fiscal year ended with last October, attained the highest sales and the second largest earnings in its history.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 28 (AP) -- North Carolina State, defending champion, rallied in the last three minutes to beat Seton Hall, 72 -- 70, and Navy trounced North Carolina, 86 -- 62, in the opening round of the Dixie basketball classic today.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower has called Congressional leaders of both political parties to a major White House parley Jan. 5 in hopes of arranging a bipartisan approach to national defense and foreign policy legislation in the session opening the following day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Securities Exchange Commission reported today that in the third quarter of this year people in this country had saved about $3,300,000,000 and that more of it had gone into bank accounts than into securities.

Ernie Vandeweghe, who reinjured his left knee in Sunday's game with the Warriors, was placed on the inactive list yesterday by the New York Knickerbockers. In accordance with the National Basketball Association rule, Vandeweghe must stay out of the next five games.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The first demonstration of what cooperation can do for the children of migrant farm workers is about to be launched.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Congress and the American people should be impressed with the authority on the issue raised by the proposed Bricker Amendment of the group headed by Dr. Edward S. Corwin, formed to resist any such change in the treaty-making process of the United States Government.
A buffet supper for New Year's Eve based on European holiday foods is suggested by the new European recipe service of Pillsbury Mills in Paris.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The most active section in a generally quiet stock market today was the South African gold mining group. Elsewhere, prices held last Thursday's levels, although some of the leading industrials lost a few pence on profit taking sales.

" In the Summer House," put on at the Playhouse last evening, is a gifted drama that is brilliantly acted but that never quite breaks loose from its own inhibitions. It is the work of Jane Bowles, who can write with sensitivity and humor about neurotic people in a vulgar world.

THE most curious fellow in the room beforehand was Yogi Berra. He just couldn't wait for the movie to begin. Considerably less eager was Phil Rizzuto. His cinema taste runs much more in the direction of cowboy and Indian pictures. This was only a baseball movie, the gala preview of the official film of the 1953 world series.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- In a retrospective report on the first six months of his stewardship, Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that defense costs probably would remain high "for many years to come."

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 29 -- Iran told Britain today that she recognized the need for foreign managerial experts as well as technical experts in reviving this country's oil industry. This disclosure was made during an interview between Abdullah Entezam, Foreign Minister, and Denis Arthur Wright, British Charge d'Affaires.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Sir Walter Monckton, Minister of Labor, conferred for nearly an hour today with shipbuilding employers in an effort to avert a threatened slowdown in the shipbuilding and engineering industries.

" Less canasta and more community service in 1954" was the recommendation yesterday of the Brooklyn Red Cross. The organization wants women and men with leisure time during the day to make a New Year's resolution to help others less fortunate than themselves.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Government granted rapid tax write-offs for $83,346,000 in defense construction projects between Dec. 3 and 16, the Office of Defense Mobilization announced today.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The premiere showing of "The French Line," a controversial three-di mensional movie starring Jane Russell, went off without a hitch tonight -- although three members of the police morality squad were in the audience.

The Chicago, Ill., Park District borrowed yesterday $6,000,000 in the public market on an issue of bonds due serially on Dec. 1 from 1955 to 1973. The bonds were sold to a syndicate headed by Harris Trust and Savings Bank at a bid of 100.78 for obligations bearing an interest rate of 2 1/2 per cent.

WHEN Robert E. Sherwood, Pulitzer Prize playwright, signed a contract a year ago to deliver nine original dramas to the National Broadcasting Company for a reported figure of $25,000 each, he sagely noted that the first of the series might be the most diffi- cult to do. His premonition was borne out last night with the premiere of "The Backbone America" at 8 o'clock over Channel 4. The play was com- pletely disappointing.

Long games marked the fifth round of the national intercollegiate chess championship tournament at Columbia's John Jay Hall yesterday, with Hans Berliner of George Washington University keeping the lead with a score of 5 -- 0 at the end of play.
General Motors Corporation announced yesterday a major change in its wholesale parts distribution plan.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The farm groups also asked for a cut in license fees for heavy farm trucks. Licenses for farm trucks of 18,000 pounds or less cost $1.75 for each 500 pounds of maximum gross weight. The farm organizations contend that the rate is too high and that the 18,000-pound limit is discriminatory against farmers.

Undefeated Duquesne will oppose once-beaten Niagara tonight in the final of Madison Square Garden's second annual Holiday Festival basketball tournament. The title contest will conclude a triple-header scheduled to start at 6 P. M.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 30 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea said yesterday that he regarded the failure of the preliminary peace conference talks as final. He predicted that Chinese Nationalist troops on Formosa would rise soon and he threatened to annex North Korea "as soon as possible."

Olin Industries, Inc., which recently organized the Olin Oil and Gas Corporation to own its various oil and gas properties, announced yesterday that it plans to distribute the stock of the subsidiary to its own shareholders.
New Yorkers and outlying neighbors can look for a dip in the temperature tonight to somewhere near 20 degrees and sometime during the afternoon cloudy skies are expected to culminate in showers.

Time does not stop with the turn of the year. We carry into 1954 all the unfinished business of 1953 -- and that's quite a holdover! There is no new beginning, personal, national or international; the world must always go on from where it is. Neither is there a last end to the problems that beset mankind.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 29--President Eisenhower elevated to the status of high Administration policy today the former sporadic attempts to channel Federal defense contracts into economically depressed areas.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Yugoslav Communist party newspaper Borba today rebuked party members who organize "spontaneous" parades and cheering sections at political meetings.
City Hall, which has been relatively quiet since the fall election, prepared yesterday for a quadrennial bustle as one Mayor's term ends tomorrow night and another's begins.

Christmas and Hanukkah were jointly celebrated yesterday afternoon by 1,200 children at the new $1,500,000 Brownsville Boys Club, 1555 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn. The party was open to children between the ages of 10 and 12 from the Brownsville, Bedford, Canarsie, East New York and Crown Heights sections of Brooklyn.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The major French unions renewed their pressure on the Government and private employers today for higher minimum wages.

MONTREAL, Dec. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The liability for $205,821.80 against the owners of the Swiss motorship Basilea was set in a Canadian exchequer court judgment today in connection with a sinking last year near Quebec city.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Republican Legislative leaders have agreed to go along with a proposal to out-law the sale of switch-blade knives. Governor Dewey is expected to ask the ban on sale of such knives in his annual message to the Legislature.

THE latest reports on the near-by duck shooting indicate that Long Island and Barnegat Bay have provided excellent bags, with plenty of red leg black ducks and more broadbill in many areas than have been seen in several years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The forecast for a severe cold wave stimulated moderate buying of July and September wheat which were stronger than the old crop futures today. There was some apprehension because of the fact that recently the weather in the winter wheat belt has been mild.

PARAMUS, N. J., Dec. 29 -- The body of Joseph H. Conkle, manager of the Longacre Theatre in New York City, was found this morning in a closed car into which exhaust fumes had been led by rigged pipes. Dr. Gerhard Helden, Bergen County assistant medical examiner, listed the death as suicide.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The fourteen local service airlines have completed their Christmas chore of carrying first-class mail.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Bob Pettit, Louisiana State's All-America candidate, garnered 23 points tonight as the Tigers defeated Fordham, the nation's No. 10 team, 65 -- 49, and gained the final round of the sixteenth annual Sugar Bowl basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, today predicted a "rising tide" of unemployment in 1954 and criticized Administration officials for calling job cutbacks "mere readjustments of the economy."
Flint Horner, 114-year-old home-furnishings store, will open its first branch on Monday on the famed Miracle Mile of Manhasset, L. I.

Pork prices continue to move up sharply as the year draws to a close. The Consumers' Service Bureau of the City Department of Markets reported yesterday retail increases of 4 to 10 cents a pound over last week on popular pork cuts. It attributed the rise to light receipts and wholesale increases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The capital gains tax has acted to narrow the securities market, Sidney B. Lurie, president of the New York Society of Security Analysts, told the American Statistical Association today.

Astrologers, the modern kind, would not like to have their science, as they regard it, described as magic. But perhaps there is a little magic in every science and a little science in every magic. At any rate, the astrologers still exist, for their representatives from ten countries were meeting at the year's end in Paris.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 29 -- Six Arab students who wandered across the armistice lines into Israel on Wednesday were returned tonight to Egyptian authorities at a border rendezvous.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Everybody over 65 years of age would become eligible immediately for Federal pensions of at least $45 a month, regardless of need, under a bill being drafted by Representative Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Chinese Communist radio accused the United States today of having armed Thailand troops for intervention in the war in Indo-China.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Two Army historians said today that Germany had held no aggressive intentions toward the United States before the attack on Pearl Harbor. Japan made the attack upon this country, they added, in the conviction that the Western powers planned the destruction of Japan or her reduction to a minor state.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Dec. 29 -- A challenge to the principle of white privilege in Africa is being made by American business interests. It is an attack on restrictions against whites and Negroes working side by side in industry.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Nineteen-year-old Lewis Hoad powered his way to a 13-11, 6-3, 2-6, 3-6, 7-5 victory over Tony Trabert today to carry Australia into a 2-2 tie with the United States in the Davis Cup challenge round today -- but the deciding singles match between Vic Seixas and Ken Rosewell of Australia was put off until tomorrow because of rain.

That synonym for holiday festivities, the punch bowl, need not be considered an extravagant purchase. Useful the year around, glass ones might be utilized in spring and summer to hold fruits and raw vegetables on ice or cold soups. Ceramic or metal ones may be used as well to hold hot beverages and foods.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 29 -- A carefully baited trap to catch a would-be bank robber failed to spring here today, but the quarry was brought in anyway.

A city financial program calling for $145,000,000 additional income for the 1954-55 fiscal year and $227,100,000 new revenues on a long-range basis was sent to Governor Dewey yesterday by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr.

Now that Christmas is over and the Neediest Cases Fund has been extended for another week we hope that the spirit of charity and generosity has not passed. The afflictions which strike the aged, the ill and the troubled are never limited by the calendar. The ills besetting men are never restricted to the times when care and help are readily and willingly offered.

It has been reported that the Citizens Union is sponsoring a bill to be introduced at the coming session of the Legislature for the nonpartisan election of judges in New York City. The bill provides that the Governor shall nominate the candidate for the Supreme Court, and the Mayor the candidates for the lower courts in New York City.

The Citizens Union's appeal for legislative action during the coming session of the New York City Legislature calls for nonpartisan election regulations for New York City judges. This plan needs an additional provision which will aim beyond the fact that judges should not be favored by any political party.

" But We Were Born Free," by Elmer Davis, has been scheduled for Feb. 5 publication by Bobbs- Merrill. It discusses the forces that threaten American freedom today. Mr. Davis, journalist, news analyst and former director of the Office of War Information, is the recipient of many awards. Last week he received the 1953 Lauterbach Award as the person "who has through his writings made a substantial contribution in the field of civil liberties."

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The New York State Power Authority has borrowed $1,000,000 from five New York City banks to finance initial stages of the $600,000,000 St. Lawrence River Power development.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Liddy of 1000 Park Avenue and Spring Lake, N. J., gave a supper dance last night in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for their debutante daughter, Miss Margaret Mary Liddy.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The British Government reiterated today its desire to maintain "an intimate and enduring association" with the European Coal and Steel Community. However, it hedged on the question of forging more formal links with the organization.
OTTAWA, Dec. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government is planning measures to provide new trades for deep-sea sailors displaced in the transfer of some Canadian ships to the British flag.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Even before the Big Four foreign ministers meet, the United States will try to start negotiations with the Soviet Union on President Eisenhower's plan for a pool of atomic-energy resources.

Sidewalk and roadway paving at Broadway and 125th Street gave way in several places about 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning, when a twenty-inch water pipe broke and caused a brief flooding of a small area. However, a spokesman for the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity said storm drains were adequate to carry off the water without damage to adjoining buildings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, today invited Samuel Goldwyn to submit to him in writing "specific and detailed recommendations" as a "starter" for consideration of the veteran independent producer's proposal that the industry self-regulatory production code be "brought reasonably up to date" for its own good.

A dark little man with a barrel chest and bright black eyes kept Pakistan's ambassador to the United States, Syed Amjed Ali, from attending the final meeting yesterday of the Security Council of the United Nations.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 29 -- The Cortland State Teachers College quintet gained the final of the third annual Hofstra Christmas invitation basketball tournament tonight. The defending champions defeated the Lehigh Engineers, 63-43, at Calkins gymnasium.
The following article was written by William L. Ryan, Associated Press correspondent, who recently returned from Russia.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The chief contractor on Memorial Stadium said today his operations were so hamstrung that the lighting system might not be ready for the Orioles' home night baseball opener next spring. He said he would sue the city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that the American press had "exaggerated" the importance of the Communist Vietminh offensive that cut Indo-China in two.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States warned the Communists today not to be misled by its decision to withdraw two divisions from Korea.
The Estates Securities Company, operators, sold the building with twenty-two apartments and two stores at 1240 Washington Avenue in the Bronx to a client of Segal Segal, lawyers.

The Union Pacific Railroad announced yesterday that it had ordered 205 Diesel-electric locomotive units from the Electromotive Division of the General Motors Corporation. The $35,769,410 order comprises 190 freight and fifteen passenger locomotive units.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Japan's two most active volcanoes erupted within five and a half hours of each other yesterday with great violence, but no casualties were reported.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 29 -- Louis Shoulders, who caught the kidnap-killers of Bobby Greenlease, was indicted by a Federal grand jury for perjury today.
VIENNA, Dec. 29 -- The Soviet satellites' boasts that unemployment is impossible under a Communist system seem to have lost their validity in Czechoslovakia and Hungary.
A huge new whaling factory ship, which will fly the flag of the Netherlands, has been ordered for delivery in the summer of 1955.

Most major carpet makers followed or exceeded yesterday price reductions announced the day before by the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company. The action followed by three months cuts announced by James Lees Sons Company, Artloom Carpet Company and Philadelphia Carpet Company.
The election of Mrs. Samuel A Marx of Chicago to the board of trustees of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, was announced yesterday by John Hay Whitney, chairman.

Directors of the National City Bank named Richard S. Perkins as vice chairman of the board yesterday. He continues as president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, National City's trust affiliate.

President Eisenhower frankly recognizes the need for bipartisan support of his foreign and defense policy in his invitation to Democratic legislative leaders to confer with him the day before the opening of Congress.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Dec. 29 -- Dr. J. M. Coopersmith of the Library of Congress was elected today as one of the two vice presidents and Dr. Otto Albrecht of the University of Pennsylvania was elected treasurer of the American Musicological Society, which is holding its annual meeting at the University of North Carolina.

The Philadelphia Orchestra had two conductors last night when it gave its fourth New York program of the season at Carnegie Hall. The division of duties came about because Igor Stravinsky, weakened by an attack of intestinal influenza over the week-end, was cautioned by his physician to read only half a program.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- The Soviet Union complained today that the United States was trying to use a Syrian-Israeli dispute as a lever to gain control of the Middle East's economy.
Fashions for the young junior were presented at Saks Thirty-fourth Street yesterday. Tuned to warm and spring days, they augur well for the coming season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- During the four years ended last June the United States shipped to its Allies 7,800,000 tons of military equipment valued at $7,000,000,000, Mr. Wilson said today.
BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- Two Americans were returned to United States custody here today after having been held in a prison camp near Moscow.

An evolution and almost a revolution in the looks, fit and function of belts was evident in the collection created by Charles James for Bruno Originals and shown to the press yesterday in the Bruno show rooms.
A new development in metallic yarns will add color and sparkle to textile products.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 29 (UP) -- Jockey Willie Shoemaker added three victories to his sensational record today including one in the $10,000 Monrovia Cup aboard the 3-year-old Berseem at Santa Anita.
Delegates to the Speech Association of America convention were told yesterday that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was entitled to be remembered in history as a "briefcase demagogue."

The world's largest communications enterprise, the $12,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company system, has chalked up another record. Cleo F. Craig, president, reported yesterday that the various companies comprising the Bell System added approximately 2,000,000 telephones to its facilities in the last twelve months.

The third-period miseries overtook the New York Rangers again at Madison Square Garden last night. After waging a good fight against the Boston Bruins for the first two stanzas, the Broadway Blues collapsed in the final and went down to defeat, 6 to 2.

The fifth anniversary of the blockading of Victor Raul Haya de la Torre in the Colombian Embassy in Lima, Peru, occurs on Sunday. There has been nothing in this line more astonishing in the history of Latin America, and because the almost sacred institution of right of asylum is at stake the incident is disturbing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Czechoslovakia, the last Communist satellite country to have membership in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, will be suspended from that organization unless it advances $625,000 in defaulted capital subscription by Thursday afternoon.
A group of three hundred economists, gathered at a meeting in Washington this week, predicted in an informal vote that 1954 would prove to be a year of moderate business recession.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Communist newspaper Pravda today greeted "all men of goodwill" everywhere in a New Year editorial forecasting brighter prospects for peace in 1954.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- The Government opened today a civil proceeding before Federal Judge William F. Smith to invalidate the citizenship of Albert Anastasia. The proceeding is regarded as preliminary to an action to deport him.

With a rush of sanity as startling as it was refreshing the City Council has passed the amended Sussman bill permitting use of the "stock" sedan as a taxicab. The vote was twenty-one to one, an amazing show of near-unanimity in view of the years of stubborn and inexplicable resistance to reform in this matter.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Soviet Union has shipped at least $100,000,000 worth of gold here by plane and ship in the last week.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- A Teachers for Peace conference opened here today with protests against the British Government's action in excluding from the country all foreign delegates who had been planning to take part.

Scoring four goals in the final period, the St. Mark's School hockey team from Southborough, Mass., skated to a 5-3 victory over The Hill School squad from Pottstown, Pa., before 3,000 alumni and friends at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The armed services are remodeling their manpower policies to conform with the slimmer "new look" decreed by the Joint Chiefs of Staff for the next fiscal year.

Hopes that the stock market will end 1953 on a cheery note have just about disappeared in Wall Street. Yesterday's session, which was the broadest since June 9, saw only 17 per cent of the stocks traded on the Big Board ending with net gains.
I read with interest as well as a degree of trepidation your Dec. 24 news report headlined "Reading Speed-up Eyed by Industry."

A brief ceremony at 10:30 o'clock this morning at the General Post Office, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, will mark the completion of the mailing of 2,000,000 March of Dimes cards seeking contributions to help finance the new polio vaccine field tests.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Counter-measures were taken today to meet the menace of Indian arrows on the newly-constructed rail link between Corumba, Brazil, and Santa Cruz, Bolivia.

The persecution of the Catholic Church, that strongest force of resistance in Soviet-occupied Poland, and particularly the unprecedented act of violence against the Cardinal-Primate, Archbishop Stefan Wyszynski, has raised a wave of protest and indignation in the free world.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, scouted yesterday the recent Soviet contention that American scientists were not free and suggested that the Russians visit Columbia and find out for themselves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Prof. Sumner H. Slichter said today that if the public insisted on holding down labor costs and prices it probably could do so by bolstering employer resistance to union demands.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Eisenhower established an emergency board today to try to head off a strike of more than a million railroad employes.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 29 -- Wide attention is being given here to the possibility that the Vietminh's drive across central Laos may be a prelude to a Communist offer of peace on the basis of a divided Indo-China.

The retail price of milk will be reduced one-half cent a quart on Friday in the metropolitan area. The reduction, announced yesterday, was coupled with a similar decline in the price to be paid by milk companies to dairy farmers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged for the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 29 -- The Defense Preparations Act, passed soon after the Menzies Government assumed office to empower the Government to gear the national economy for war and sustain controls against inflation, expires at midnight on Thursday.

" BABIES and language are the essential ingredients of civilization, and speakers of language no more know where it came from than babies know where they come from." This neatly expressed truth is taken from "The Miracle of Language"* by Charlton Laird and was chosen as an example of Mr. Lairds ability to write in a sprightly fashion about a subject generally considered one of the driest academic specialties of college English departments.
Plans for two attacks on the high cost of food distribution were announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- British Government circles are concerned by private reports from Washington and Cairo that the United States Government may soon announced an offer to Egypt of military or economic assistance or both.
MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 30 -- Solemnly pledging the return of the government to the people, Ramon Magsaysay was inaugurated at noon today as the third President of the Philippine Republic.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The United States and Mexico appeared ready today to let their current migrant labor pact expire Dec. 31.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Dec. 29 (AP) -- More than 10,000 United States airmen in Europe will be supplanted by European civilians under the new economy program. The switch will free about $36,000,000 for activation of new Air Force wings in the United States, Air Force headquarters said today.

George Mandel of Astoria, Queens, top-seeded in the junior singles, entered the round of sixteen with an easy victory yesterday in the Eastern indoor tennis championships for juniors and boys at the Third Engineers Group Armory.

OTTAWA, Dec. 29 -- Clarence D. Howe, Canada's Minister of Trade and Commerce, does not share the forebodings of economists in the United States about the danger of "an orthodox recession" in the United States in 1954.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Kenneth Young, State Department Asian expert who now heads the Allied team to arrange the peace conference, said he regarded Dr. Rhee's prediction on the permanent breakdown of the talks as "largely a matter of speculation."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Bijaya Shumshere Jung Bahadur Rana, Nepalese Ambassador to India since 1951, was electrocuted in his bath this morning, apparently by shock from an immersion heater.

Long-term United State Government bonds were bid up again yesterday in one of the market's most substantial advances of the fall and winter. Twenty-four issues of the Treasury's bonds and notes rose to new high levels for the year, the best gains being recorded by the 2 1/2s of 1970-1965, and of June and December, 1972- 1967, each of which gained 3/16 of a point.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- The arsenal of democracy, now being created as the result of research in America's laboratories, has grown so powerful that it should deter Russia from war, Dr. Mervin J. Kelly declared here today.

Presidents of the Philippines are inaugurated on Dec. 30, primarily because that is a great national holiday, Rizal Day. It commemorates the martyrdom of Jose Rizal, the most effective early exponent of Philippine freedom and independence in the pre-American era, who stands to Filipinos in the same relation that George Washington does to us.

Clerical and professional employes of the American Financial and Development Corporation for Israel, Inc., underwriter of the State of Israel bond issue, walked off their jobs yesterday to protest a mangement refusal to arbitrate a wage dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The housekeeping agencies of the Government today asked other Federal departments to determine what real property holdings could be sold as surplus.

A decline, of 5 to 7 per cent is in prospect for the country's gross national product, the value of all goods and services produced, in the year ahead. Further, the situation now is much like that of 1949, when there was a slight downturn, reversed in mid-1950 by the Korean war outbreak.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 29 -- President Eisenhower summoned his top White House aides on political and administrative affairs from Washington today to start work Thursday on a final draft of his message to Congress on the State of the Union. The President plans to deliver the message in person on Jan. 7.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah, whose leadership of Britain's West African Gold Coast colony has been hailed as a brilliant example of colonial self-government, today fought charges that he had taken more than $125,000 in bribes during his three-year rule.

Istvan Racz bought the apartment house for fifteen families at 403 East Ninetieth Street, near First Avenue, from Elizabeth Johnson, who bought the thirteen-family building at 407 East Seventy-seventh Street. Samuel Sason and Arthur Lichtner were the brokers in both deals.

A one-story taxpayer containing five stores at 82-34 and 82-40 Lefferts Boulevard in Kew Gardens, Queens, has been purchased by Daniel Frey. The property, which occupies a plot of 8,200 square feet with a frontage of seventy-five feet, was sold through Sydney M. Siegel Co. as brokers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- An initial expenditure of $40,000 by a United Nations agency added $24,000,000 to the value of Europe's corn crop in 1952.

In the most direct warning given thus far to Peiping Secretary Dulles indicated yesterday that if Communist China renews aggression in Korea or openly intervenes in Indo-China the United States will strike back at the aggressor forces even outside of the attacked countries, which means Communist China itself.

HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Paul Wisdom, the 6-foot 7-inch center, and Capt. Pete Geithner combined to provide Dartmouth's undefeated basketball forces with a 77-69 victory over Harvard tonight in a second- round game of the New England intercollegiate invitation basketball tournament.

Now that Christmas has departed into history, it once again is being made clear that all those games, all those puzzles, did not come with interchangeable parts. It is clear, too, that those games and puzzles did not come with each piece loosely attached to the whole, as, for example, mittens are pinned to a child's coat sleeves.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Fred Kovaleski of Washington smashed his way into the final of the seventeenth annual Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today with a 6-3, 7-5 victory over Archie Henderson of New Orleans.
Two boys were drowned at 3:45 P. M. yesterday when they fell through thin ice on a pond in Forest Park, Queens. The police recovered the bodies an hour later.

Radio and television billings by the top thirty-two ad agencies in 1953 reached $563,600,000, a rise of about 25 per cent over 1952, when thirty agencies were studied. This is reported in the latest issue of Broadcasting-Telecasting magazine.

Elmer Davis, radio and television news analyst, received last night the Lauterbach Award for 1953. The award, which consist of $1,000 in cash, is given annually by the Authors Guild of the Authors League of America, Into a person "who has through his writings made a substantial contribution in the field of civil liberties."

The forty-second annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $10 yesterday from Mrs. Marie A. Nagorski, who wrote that she had sent her gift "to thank my husband and children for another happy Christmas."

Reservations by retail buyers in New York hotels are running slightly behind last years, a check yesterday of mid-town hotels revealed. Hotel officials said that they expected a last-minute rush similar to last year's. However, they felt some disappointment at the pattern of bookings.
Publicity given to the recent investigation of fraudulent charities has caused a slackening in gifts to the New York City Young Men's Christian Association's 1954 fund campaign in the last ten days.
There was a record total of twenty-one boxing fatalities, eleven professional and ten amateur, during 1953, according to a copyrighted article appearing in the February issue of The Ring Magazine.
Sales of the United States Rubber Company are expected to be between $830,000,000 and $835,000,000 for 1953 and earnings will probably equal about $5 a common share.

Two new films open today at first run theatres. At the Palace is "The Wild One," a Stanley Kramer production starring Marlon Brando. Mary Murphy, Robert Keith, Lee Marvin and Jay C. Flippen head the supporting cast. The drama was written by John Paxton from a story by Frank Rooney.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Upsets marked the Orange Bowl junior tennis championships today.

Brought into existence for the express purpose of entertaining everybody, in addition to operating and building theatres, the Producers' Theatre, organized by Robert Whitehead, Roger L. Stevens and Robert W. Dowling, will start its career at 8 o'clock this evening with "The Remarkable Mr. Pennypacker" at the Coronet.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- The strike of 1,800 gas maintenance workers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which began Nov. 20, ended today in its sixth week. Both the company and union agreed to submit the issues to a three-member board of arbitration.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Dewey accepted today on behalf of the state deeds for 400 acres of land on the west shore of Lake Onondaga. The property will be converted into a 16,000-car parking lot for the adjacent State Fair and a local recreation area.

The United States needs to make some lasting New Year's resolutions on foreign economic policies, it was asserted yesterday by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.
Department stores with an annual volume of more than $1,000,000 have not been able to hold down expenses while increasing gross profit margins.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 29 -- Northern New York apparently was the home of a cult of the dead 4,400 years ago, a New York archaeologist told the annual meeting of the American Anthropological Association here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Post Office Department today canceled its contract with the New York Mail and Newspaper Company for leasing the city's pneumatic mail tubes.

Pink balloons and silver leaves formed a colorful decor for the annual Post-Debutante Tiara Ball, given for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Franklin Marion Gentry and Mrs. Frederic H. Rahr were co-chairmen of the executive committee for the event, and Mrs. Lila Tyng was honorary chairman.

RALEIGH, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Trailing by 9 points, Navy uncorked a spirited second-half attack behind the great shooting of John Clune and Don Lange to upset North Carolina State, 85 -- 75, today and end the Wolfpack's four-year reign as Dixie Classic basketball champion.

The American Federation of Labor prepared last night to use John L. Lewis' "adoption" of the old International Longshoremen's Association as an additional lever for upsetting last week's fiercely contested waterfront labor election.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Some 800 fire fighters, using mechanized equipment and aided by a dying wind, were gaining an upper hand tonight in frantic efforts to save Mount Wilson Observatory and seven television transmitter towers from a raging forest fire.

Transocean Air Lines has reversed the world-wide practice of "cannibalizing" aircraft -- stripping individual parts from a crashed plane as they are needed for other planes. The company has compounded from scattered plane components a four-engine airliner that has received Federal certification.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The executive director of the United States Olympic Committee said today it might be possible to hold the equestrian events of the 1956 games in Australia on a limited basis.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The long-drawn-out Saratoga gambling investigation virtually came to a close today with the fining of twenty-seven men and two corporations a total of $28,000. No one among the twenty-seven went to jail.
Sales and earnings of the Harnischfeger Corporation in its sixty-ninth year of operations, were the heaviest on record.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- State Department officials who are studying the recent Soviet sales of gold said tonight that the shipments were a matter of pure necessity.

GROVE HILL, Ala., Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation today stepped into the investigation of the county jail death of a Negro prisoner, the second slaying connected with a moonshine liquor "protection" case against Sheriff Jenkins A. Hill of Clarke County.

Residents of New York State were warned yesterday by Alfred J. Bohlinger, superintendent of the New York State Insurance Department, against purchasing insurance from companies not authorized to do business in the state.

Harris-Seybold Company, Cleveland manufacturer of printing machinery, announced yesterday that it is registering with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of about 50,000 shares of new common stock intended to be offered to company shareholders on or about Jan. 19 on the basis of one new share for each seven shares held.
The major work offered by Winifred Young, pianist, at her Carnegie Recital Hall performance last evening was the odd and rather engaging Third Piano Sonata of George Antheil.

THOMAS ANDREW LEHRER, taken on as comedian at the Blue Angel night club the other day, attained his calling in a rather roundabout way. He prepared for it at Harvard, where he took his M. A. in mathematics in 1947, and then did a turn at Los Alamos, N. M., as a theoretical physicist.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Alerted, one of the rare bargains of the American turf, outclassed seven opponents in the Southern Cross Purse, the featured event witnessed by 9,659 at Tropical Park today.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- South African gold mining shares, particularly those groups with uranium interests, were the most active feature on the stock markets here today. Desptie profit-taking sales that brought early price fluctuations, most of them finished slightly better than yesterday.

Prices of most commodities in the local futures markets moved little yesterday. The only major advance was made by tin futures on the New York Commodity Exchange. These gained 25 to 100 points, or 1/4 to one cent a pound, as a result of the unsettling news in Indo-China.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 29 (UP) -- Bob Cousy, high-scoring backcourt Star of the Boston Celtics who was publicly berated by his coach for his "Fancy-Dan" passing and dribbling, may ask to be traded to another National Basketball Association team, he said today.
PALMA, Majorca, Spain, Dec. 29 (AP)--Rita Hume, 36 years old, an American freelance correspondent in Italy, was killed today in an automobile accident two miles from this Balearic Island city.
There will be no strike New Year's Day on the city-owned transit lines.

Debutantes who will be presented at the annual Yuletide Assembly Saturday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza will participate in a colorful pageant entitled "Une Soiree a la Cour." The fete, arranged under the direction of Miss Bonnie May Murray, will help to raise funds for the Youth Consultation Service.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation introduced its new line of air-conditioning units yesterday at a showing to Eastern distributors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The line contains twenty-nine room, residential, and commercial air-conditioners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Americans for Democratic Action, a political organization with 125 chapters in thirty-nine states, today called on the incoming Congress to enact a sixteen-point legislative program.
Futures on the New York Coton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 1 to 14 points net down, with the near months showing the most pronounced weakness.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 29 -- Astronomers discussed their biggest problem, the structure of the universe, in a symposium at the meeting of the American Astronomical Society here today.

Charles E. Johnson, 46-year-old steel worker described by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as one of the country's top ten criminals, refused yesterday to return to Greensboro, N. C., to face a charge of possessing stolen bank funds.
The text of the letter sent yesterday by Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. to Governor Dewey is as follows:

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Carvings of an axe and a dagger recently found on a thirty-ton monolith at Stonehenge, on Salisbury Plain, are inclining British archaeologists toward the view that the greatest pre-Christian sanctuary in Europe was built by ancient Mycenaeans from the eastern Mediterranean area.
Hot holiday drinks that may be enjoyed by all members of the family and their guests, be they young or old, are offered today for New Year's week-end.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Eight major farm organizations renewed today their opposition to state development of additional hydroelectric power at Niagara Falls. They want this power developed and marketed by private utilities.

TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- Grover C. Richman Jr., Camden lawyer and former United States Attorney for New Jersey, will succeed Theodore D. Parsons as Attorney General of New Jersey on Jan. 19. His appointment to the $18,000-a-year post was announced here today by Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Demands for removing the 1956 Olympic Games from Melbourne, Australia, will be considered Jan. 16 at a meeting of the executive commission of the International Olympic Committee at Lausanne.

Unbeaten Duquesne put on a blazing finish to turn back Niagara, 66 -- 61, in the final of Madison Square Garden's second annual Holiday Festival basketball tournament. And Dick Ricketts, the chief architect of the Iron Dukes' stirring triumph, was voted the outstanding player of the three-day tourney, which gave Dudey Moore's Pittsburghers a sweep of the top honors.

WAUSAU, Wis., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Local 1113 of the United Electrical Workers Union, independent, and twelve persons were found guilty today of contempt of court for violating a restraining order growing out of a long labor dispute at the Marathon Manufacturing Company plant last year.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The campaign of the railroads for repeal of New York State's full-crew law was attacked today by four railroad brotherhoods as a selfish move that "utterly disregards the safety, health and welfare of the public at large."

While passenger ship traffic has been on the upsurge for the last three years and new highs are predicted for 1954, the industry is apprehensive about the future of freight operations -- the real bread and butter of the steamship business.
