ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Dewey appointed Edward H. Case of Gouveneur today as a trustee of the State Power Authority. The appointment fills a vacancy existing since the resignation of Jacob Grumet upon his appointment as Fire Commissioner of New York City in 1951.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Attempts to achieve a negotiated settlement of the labor dispute in the shipbuilding and engineering industries were brought virtually to a standstill today when the employers refused to make any offer to the unions concerned.

CAIRO, Dec. 30 -- About $15,000 in Egyptian and American currency and in jewels were seized today from the Cuban Minister, Don Luis F. de Almagro, as he prepared to board a plane for Beirut, police and customs officials reported.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Soviet-British relations have been marked over Christmas by several signs of courtesy and goodwill but on a simple issue the Kremlin seems to have fumbled the ball.

The Cessna Aircraft Company's 1954 prospects for commercial aircraft sales are very promising, barring any serious changes in the economic situation, D. L. Wallace, president, informed shareholders in the annual report yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, British commander in Malaya, will become in October commander of the Northern Army Group in West Germany.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (UP) -- B. W. Landy's False found the light weight of 105 pounds much to his liking today as he easily prevailed over seven others in the featured Basil O'Connor Purse at the Fair Grounds before a crowd of nearly 8,000.

Although its charter does not require the step, Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., will give its stockholders a chance or Jan. 26 to vote on its proposed acquisition of a minimum of 355,460 of the 438,428 common shares of Benson Hedges.

Oscar Wilde sneered at calendars because, he said, most of them "mar the sweet simplicity of our lives by reminding us that each day that passes is the anniversary of some perfectly uninteresting event."
The extent to which Communist doctrine has infiltrated the ranks of New York City's school teachers cannot be estimated at present, in the opinion of Corporation Counsel Denis M. Hurley.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices had increased 1.2 per cent during the month ended on Dec. 15.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 30 -- The planet Jupiter, while in its formative stage billions of years ago, may have lost one or more satellites, now observed as asteroids or minor planets traveling in unusual orbits around the sun.
ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Harold Keller, state commerce commissioner foresees another good year for New York buhiness.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 30 (UP) -- President Eisenhower's press secretary, James C. Hagerty, said tonight he believed "chances of peace" were a "good deal" better now than they had been when General Eisenhower took office.

SOME folks make a hobby of collecting stamps. Some collect string. There are even characters -- or so it is rumored --who collect money, stacks and stacks of the filthy stuff. But Bob Sieger of The Detroit News, a man of absolutely appalling industry, collects words.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 30 (UP) -- French mobile forces routed a Communist unit today in a sudden victory hailed as signalizing the shakiness of the Red line across Indo-China.
Bendix Co. and Shethar Co., member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, propose to dissolve today.

AQABA, Jordan, Dec. 17 -- When an Egyptian coastal battery at the tip of the Sinai peninsula fired nine shells at an American freighter two weeks ago, considerably more was involved than diplomatic embarrassment.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that either the Australian Government or the I. O. C. would have to relax its rules to stage the 1956 Olympic Games successfully in Melbourne.

In New Year messages to both North and South Korea President Rhee has sought again to strengthen the morale of his sorely tried people and to fortify the faith of both parts of his divided country in ultimate unity and freedom. Unity and freedom are also the proclaimed goals of both the United Nations and the United States.

TRENTON, Dec. 30 -- Dr. Joseph E. McLean, one of Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner's closest advisers, has rejected a position in the latter's Cabinet. Reached by telephone at his home in Princeton, Dr. McLean said that the offer was made to him last week-end and that he had telegraphed his refusal to Mr. Meyner on Monday.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Commercially speaking, New York State does not have quite everything. But it does have 98.5 per cent of everything, according to the State Department of Commerce.

A part of American history that has lain hidden in sealed Government documents for ninety years is the basis of a new work by James D. Horan entitled "Confederate Agent." It is a biography of Capt. Thomas Henry Hines, "master-mind" of the Confederate Underground in the North.

SENO, Laos, Dec. 30 -- Out of the jungle stretching away from this central Laotian air base, the French are building a defense system they feel sure can deal with any further Vietminh advance in this area.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals moved a full game closer to first place in the Eastern Division tonight by defeating the Boston Celtics, 96 -- 89, just before the leading New York Knickerbockers dropped an 86-79 decision to Baltimore in a National Basketball Association double-header.
The Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., commenting on President Eisenhower's announcement, said yesterday it welcomed any steps in that direction.
At least 53,000 workers have been laid off their jobs in industry and railroads throughout the country in recent weeks or face unemployment soon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Otway M. Falkiner, an Australian wool executive, urges quick action by the United States Government to save this country's wool industry.
Three persons, including a 7-week-old boy, were burned late last night in a Christmas tree fire in their living room in Stuyvesant Town.
LAWRENCE, Mass., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Dom DiMaggio, former Boston Red Sox center fielder and now a free agent, today denied rumors he was in training for another season of baseball.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Dewey proposed to a group of Westchester residents today that the toll figure for the New England section of the State Thruway from New Rochelle to Port Chester be set at 25 cents, instead of 10 cents as originally planned.

THE unseasonal lack of snow in many areas where this white, fluffy substance normally is hip-deep by this time of year is deplored not only by skiers, but by Lepus americanus, that small but active animal more familiarly known as the varying hare or snowshoe rabbit.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 31 -- Ken Rosewall, a 140-pound artist of the courts, enabled Australia to win the Davis Cup for the fourth successive year today when he defeated Vic Seixas of the United States, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, in the deciding singles match of the challenge round.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 30 -- The Rhode Island Development Company, a state - authorized agency, made its first loan today, for $50,000, to enable an industry founded in 1882 to begin manufacturing a new product, baseball bats of laminated wood.

Shipments of vinyl fabrics on 1954 should show an over increase over 1953, in the opinion of member companies of the Plastic Coating and Film Association, which produce a major portion of the nation's vinyl-coated material and vinyl sheeting.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The text of Governor Dewey's statement today on the fiscal program of Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. for New York City follows:

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Duke's Blue Devils dropped Navy from the undefeated ranks tonight, 98 -- 83, to win the fifth annual Dixie Classic basketball tournament before a crowd of 12,000 in Reynolds Coliseum.

Suppose, through some catastrophe, you were deprived of the facilities of civilization and found yourself with, say, nine others in a similar basic condition. Suppose that you and seven of the rest had all managed to rescue either enough food or the means to produce enough food to last you the remainder of your lives.
The passing of the old year and the coming of the new will be celebrated with varied programs in churches tonight, starting in mid-evening and running through midnight.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Sweden notified the United Nations Technical Assistance Board today that an additional 500,000 kroner would be added to her 1954 pledge for funds to aid underdeveloped countries.

A vacant plot 150 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Waterbury and Bradford Avenues in the Bronx has been sold by the City of New York to Henry P. Imbress, Carmine Martin Capone was the broker in the sale.

TORONTO, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Rallying after being outskated and outshot for two periods, the Toronto Maple Leafs scored twice in the final period tonight to tie the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 2, and prevent the Canadiens from moving into a tie for the National Hockey League lead with the idle Detroit Red Wings.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30 -- The nation joined today in paying homage to President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines on his sixty-third birthday, but the president characteristically went about his work without fuss or fanfare.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Powerful Democratic Senators are preparing to raise what they expect to be a party-wide challenge to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy early in the new session of Congress that opens a week from today.
An early morning fog caused two tankers to collide and burst into flames yesterday in the Delaware River. Nine crewmen leaped in panic into the icy waters.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Two outsiders who moved in as officers of the Glenn L. Martin Company not quite two years ago acknowledged today they now control the largest block of its stock.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Capt. Richie Guerin passed the 1,000-point mark tonight as Iona College's basketball team recorded its fifth straight triumph by halting Ohio Wesleyan, 76 to 67, at the Westchester County Center.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- United States exports rose and imports dropped during October, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

An announcement from the Philippine Department of Agriculture states that in this year the Philippines will have not only met its domestic rice production needs but will have something for export. This can be one of the more significant developments of the year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- During the period ended Dec. 29, member bank reserves decreased $65,000,000, the federal reserve board reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The volume of business expanded in the securities markets here today and prices improved in nearly all sections until late dealings, when some industrial leaders reacted under profit taking.

A New York public relations counsel who in 1906 was the first student member of the Cum Laude Society was honored yesterday at the group's sixteenth triennial convention in the Commodore Hotel. The society, with 29,829 members, has chapters in 153 preparatory and high schools, mostly in the Eastern part of the country.

Coffee prices continued to climb on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Roaster buying increased following announcement of higher retail prices, which give them a working margin despite the higher price of green coffee.

The old International Longshoremen's Association called on President Eisenhower last night to appoint a special "coordinator" to iron out the waterfront labor muddle and thus ward off a new coast-wide dock strike.

The nation's commercial airlines may go nautical and switch from "statute" miles and "miles an hour" to the more salty and longer distances of "nautical miles" and "knots" if a Civil Aeronautics Board proposal is adopted. The airlines have until Jan. 4 to submit their views on the plan.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- New England reaction to President Eisenhower's order to channel more defense orders into the region was cautiously optimistic, pending more details. The principal "distress" or high unemployment areas are Lowell and Lawrence, Mass., and Providence, R. I.

PEMBROKE, Ont., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Flames swept through a Pullman car today, killing one passenger as a crack Canadian train sped westward. Eighteen other passengers dived through a window that a woman had broken with her traveling case as the train came to a stop. The dead man was Dr. H. A. Collins, 61 years old of Ottawa.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Arthur Napier Magill of Toronto, arrived in New York yesterday after a year in Egypt, with evidence that the implied futility of the phrase "the blind leading the blind" needs reappraisal.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Holy Cross subdued Louisiana State, 66 -- 56, tonight to win the championship of the sixteenth annual Sugar Bowl basketball tournament. The rebounding of Tom Heinsohn and the clutch shooting of Togo Palazzi brought the New Englanders the triumph.

The appointment of Miss Edith W. Conant of this city and Pound Ridge, N. Y., as director of the program department of the National Girl Scout Organization was announced yesterday. It will take effect tomorrow. Miss Conant succeeds Mrs. Lewis A. DeBlois of Chappaqua, N. Y., who is retiring.
Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, protested strongly last night against any United States military pact with Pakistan.

The victor in tomorrow night's listed ten-round main bout between Lulu Perez, Brooklyn featherweight, and Dave Gallardo of Los Angeles at Madison Square Garden will face Willie Pep. former 126-pound champion, on Feb. 26 at the Garden, Matchmaker Billy Brown of the International Boxing Club disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Democratic opposition flared today against the Eisenhower Administration's plan to withdraw two Army divisions from Korea. Minority leaders on both the Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations Committees challenged the wisdom of the action.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 -- The Bocher Award, one of the highest honors in mathematics, today was made to Prof. Norman Levinson of Harvard University for his 'contributions to the theory of linear, nonlinear, ordinary and partial differential equations contained in his papers of recent yaers."
At the turn of another year attention is shifting to Egypt and Pakistan as the United States once again attempts to fill a dangerous vacuum of power -- the Middle East.

The five-story apartment house accommodating twenty-five families at 30-40 Thirty-second Street in Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by the Investors Funding Corporation, real estate operators. Sydney M. Siegel Co. were the brokers in the transaction.

Reactions to the spectacular thrust of the Vietminh Communist forces across Indo-China seem to oscillate between extremes. The first news reports were doubtless too sensational in claiming that Indo-China had been "cut in two," when clearly what had happened was that a small but relatively strong task force had swept from central Laos to the Mekong River on the western border with Thailand.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Hal Haabestad led Princeton to its first basketball victory tonight as the Tigers gained an early lead and drubbed the University of Rochester, 86 -- 54. Haabestad scored 19 points as Princeton rolled up a 24-11 lead at the first quarter and led 43 -- 26 at the half.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 -- The City Board of Education summarily dismissed two substitute schoolteachers and suspended five regular teachers today for refusing to tell whether they ever had been members of the Communist party.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Pre-game tension between Michigan States and U. C. L. A. heightened today as a dispute developed over use of the Rose Bowl "to get the feel of the grass" prior to Friday's football classic.

Hanson Baldwin in The Times of Dec. 22 reviewed the low state of morale in the armed services and the reasons as cited in the report of a Pentagon ad hoc committee. Since this report still another blow at morale in the services has been struck.
The Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation transacted the largest volume of sales in its history in the fiscal year ended last September, but earnings showed only small improvement.

Maj. Sammy Lee of Pasadena, Calif., the diminutive Army Medical Corps doctor who captured the 1948 and 1952 Olympic platform diving titles, yesterday was established as the 1953 winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 20 -- Joseph Sprinzak, Speaker of the Knesset (Parliament), received the American Jewish Congress award for outstanding contribution to the growth and welfare of Israel at a ceremony in Jerusalem today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 30 -- Mrs. Eleanor Butler Roosevelt, who had renounced an $811,247 trust fund early this year "for tax considerations," was reinstated as a beneficiary here today in the State Supreme Court. She is the widow of Theodore Roosevelt Jr.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Premier Joseph Daniel intends to resign next Monday, about two weeks earlier than he planned to do so. It was understood tonight that he would return to office only if the National Assembly decided to give him its full backing.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

First Deputy Police Commissioner Frank Fristensky Jr. submitted his resignation yesterday to end a career of forty-two years in the department. The resignation is effective at midnight tonight when Commissioner George P. Monaghan also will leave the department.
CHICAGO, Dec 30 (AP) -- Hogs recovered a bit today after their sharp price declines on the past two days. Salable receipts at 11,000 head were in line with expcetations.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- Concern about the distrust between France and West Germany as an obstacle to both the reunification of Germany and the integration of Europe was expressed today by West German political leaders.

Reaction to parking meter ads has been spotty throughout the country, says the latest newsletter of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. Chicago has barred meter ads completely. Some cities that have installed them say they are good; others report they are a nuisance.
Barbara Hutton, heiress, and Porfirio Rubirosa, Dominican Republic diplomat, were married here yesterday. It was Miss Hutton's fifth marriage and the fourth for Mr. Rubirosa.

Best Co. has closed its West Hartford, Conn. branch. Philip LeBoutiller, president, said yesterday that the store was closed because it was too small and lacked sufficient parking space. He further indicated that, with the lease scheduled to end shortly, the landlord had sought a heavy rental rise.
Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday that he would leave office tonight with a record of solid achievement and without rancor toward anyone.

Permit me to comment on your editorial entitled "Demonstrations in India." I entirely agree with you that nothing should be done in India to exacerbate feelings either with Pakistan or with the United States, but I feel that your editorial excludes some significant elements in the situation.
The forty-second annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $2 yesterday as a contribution from H. R. Haynes, a taxicab driver in Charleston, W. Va.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Irked by the parade before Communist-hunting Congressional committees of persons who, under cover of the Fifth Amendment, which protects from self-incrimination those testifying in a criminal case, refuse to answer questions pertinent to the inquiry, members of Congress have proposed a statute making provisions for immunity for certain of these witnesses.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 2 points lower to 7 points higher than on Tuesday.
American Woolen Company issued yesterday the names of eleven mills that it seeks to close permanently under a plan of reorganization.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company today dened reports that there had been a secret agreement of international oil companies on settling the oil dispute in Iran.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 2,444,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they were reported at 256,030,000 barrels, compared with 153,586,000 a week earlier and 134,425,000 a year ago.
" Carmen" was given at the Metropolitan last evening with a familiar cast, but with Tibor Kozma conducting the work for the first time this season.

Stocks fought off tax selling and year-end profit-taking yesterday and staged a moderate rally that spread to most sections of the list. Steels, motors, rails, tobaccos, amusements and chemicals were in the lead.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Justice announced today that Frank Orlando of Fulton, N. Y., had been ordered deported to his native Italy, where he faces a life sentence on a murder conviction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Samuel Goldwyn declined today a suggestion from Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, that he put into writing his reasons for urging that the production code be "brought reasonably up to date."

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Louis Shoulders, the former police officer who broke the Greenlease kidnapping case, surrendered today on a Federal indictment charging him with perjury in testimony about his handling of the ransom money.

The Community Chests and Councils of America announced yesterday that more than $280,000,00 had been contributed this year to community chest and other united community campaigns in the United States. This figure did not include the money raised by the Gerater New York Fund, which announced last July that it had raised over $6,000,000 in its 1953 drive, the most successful one it ever had undertaken.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Only one title went out of the state today as Floridians dominated the finals of the Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament.

Christmas shoppers were extra-careful this year. The result was more genuine smiles of pleasure when gifts were opened on Christmas morning and smaller lines before return counters in department stores.

The Government's anti-trust suit against Jacob J. Shubert and the late Lee Shubert on charges of monopolizing the bookings of legitimate theatre attractions was dismissed yesterday by Senior Federal Judge John C. Knox.
Under the alert observation of three officials of the New York State Insurance Department the task of counting more than 250,000 valuable pieces of paper began yesterday.

The building at 549 to 555 Broadway, running through the block to 120-26 Mercer Street, a mercantile landmark of lower Manhattan when it was occupied by Charles Broadway Rouss, has been sold by the Rouss heirs to the 361 Broadway Corporation, Frank Gindoff, president, for investment.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- The Council of the American Association for the Advancement of Science unanimously adopted today a resolution commending President Eisenhower's plan for international cooperation on atomic energy.
OTTAWA, Dec. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Demands for action to ease climbing unemployment, most of it seasonal, but some not, are being received by the Canadian Government.
The incoming and outgoing First Ladies of New York were preoccupied yesterday with packing and plans for moving.

The Pantepec Oil Company, C. A. yesterday resumed the payment of dividends with the declaration of 32 cents a share on the capital stock. Payment of the dividend, which represents on one bolivar in Venezuelan currency, will be made on Jan. 31.

Representative Dean P. Taylor of Troy, N. Y., listed yesterday what he regarded as the principal achievements of the state and Federal Administrations under the leadership of Governor Dewey and President Eisenhower.

Stockholders of the Hajoca Corporation, manufacturers of plumbing, heating and industrial supplies, approved an amendment to the certificate of incorporation which will release 40,000 shares of authorized but unissued capital stock from preemptive rights of present stockholders.

" Admiral Ushakov," a Russian- made film biography of the "father of the Russian Navy" and reportedly the first Soviet production of the post-Stalin era, has been scheduled to open at the Stanley Theatre early next year, following the current offering.

ELKHART, Iowa, Dec. 30 -- A small town Iowa postmaster, who may lose his job because he was alleged to have called President Eisenhower a bad name, said today he believed he had a right, even as a public employe, to express his own opinions.

With holiday excitement still at high pitch, parents might well be interested in encouraging a session of comparatively quiet play. New games and puzzles in this category range from simple block puzzles for the youngest members of the family to games that might hold an adult's attention.

Given a thoroughly improbable situation, the author and actors of "The Remarkable Mr. Pennypacker" have put together an uproarious show. Liam O'Brien is the author. Burgess Meredith and Martha Scott are the actors who are starred, although Glenn Anders as a pickle-puss parson ought to rank at least as a comet.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler left here by air today for the Commonwealth Conference of Finance Ministers, which opens Jan. 8 in Sydney, Australia.

At least 450 expectant mothers and almost as many fathers-to-be have participated in a special pre-natal program at Mount Sinai Hospitals Klingenstein Maternity Pavilion, which completes its first year today.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Marian Anderson, singer, and Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the United Nations Trusteeship Division, headed prominent Americans arriving today for the 150th anniversary of Haiti's independence from France.
NEWARK, Dec. 30 -- The 1,800 gas maintenance employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company who ended their six-week strike yesterday returned to work today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Indian specialists began to get the upper hand today on a forest fire that at times threatened the Mount Wilson observatory near here. Richard Johnson, United States Forest Service fire prevention officer, said the blaze might be controlled by Friday.
Eastern railroads will discontinue at midnight tonight their reduced freight rates on hay shipments to farmers and cattlemen in Government-designated drought areas.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Dewey rejected summarily today those features of the fiscal program of Mayor-Elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. calling for $143,400,000 in additional state aid for the City of New York.

Nineteen fifty-three, full of uncertainty in the struggle between the West and East, will be abandoned to history at 12 o'clock tonight by millions of Americans in hopeful celebration of the birth of a new year.
Two major Manhattan bus companies were warned yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., that they would be struck Sunday unless their employes received higher pay and shorter hours.
Sidney Schwartz of Brooklyn yesterday was ranked No. 1 men's singles player in the East for 1953 in the annual recommendations of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Gary Cooper, who won this year's top Oscar, was named today the box-office king as well.

MONTREAL, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Quebec Film Censorship Board has banned the motion picture "Martin Luther" on the ground that it would antagonize the people of ths predominantly Roman Catholic province. The picture deals with the sixteenth-century reformer who left Roman Catholicism to found a Protestant religion.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday the appointment by Cardinal Spellman of Msgr. John J. Maguire as vicar general. Msgr. Maguire became assistant chancellor of the archdiocese in 1940, vice chancellor in 1945 and co-chancellor in 1947.

One of the most popular paintings by an American artist -- James A. McNeil Whistler's "Portrait of the Artist's Mother," better known merely as "Whistler's Mother" -- has been lent by the Louvre in Paris to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
As the sun sets today for the last time this year on Flatbush, a perusal of the Dodgers' official player roster for 1954, released yesterday, reveals some interesting data.

David Bronstein, one of the two Russians entered in the international chess masters' tournament Hastings, England, was held to a draw by Richard G. Wade of New Zealand in the first round yesterday, according to a new report from London.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Another labor spokesman said "no" today to an appointment under the Foreign Operations Administration -- an appointment he never formally received.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Henry Suydam, State Department public information officer, predicted today that a note would be sent to Moscow in the next twenty-four hours accepting Jan. 25 as the meeting date for the four-power foreign ministers' conference on Germany scheduled for Berlin.
CAIRO, Dec. 30 -- The Egyptian Government has ordered two more ambassadors home for consultation.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The speculation that airliners of the future will be huge atomic-powered flying boats capable of speeds "far in excess of anything imagined today" was made today by the chairman of Britain's trans- oceanic airline.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Thursday, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- The Duke of Edinburgh, solemn-faced and obviously moved, attended today the mass funeral of twenty-one unidentified victims of New Zealand's Christmas Eve railroad disaster at Tangiwai, north of Wellington.

HEMPSTEAD, I. I., Dec. 30 -- The undefeated Wagner Sea Hawks ran their winning streak to nine as they defeated Cortland State Teachers, 60 -- 50, tonight in capturing the third annual Hofstra invitation basketball tournament in Calkins Gymnasium.
Five ships of the newest type of American merchant vessels have been ordered into idle lay-up fleets after little more than a year of service, it was announced yesterday.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 30 (AP) -- P. A. B. (Pete) Widener 3d, wealthy sportsman, today was appointed chief of the Fayette County Patrol, a $300-a-month post.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Deputy Tax Commissioner George P. Klein said today that nonresident income taxpayers -- those persons who work in New York state but live in another state -- could not claim tax credit for compensation received for vacations.

Mrs. Wilfred Crump and her three children, who arrived here by ship yesterday from a visit to England, were on their way to surprise Mr. Crump at home in Canada. They learned, however, that the surprise was on them, though at his expense, as he had flown to England to surprise them for Christmas.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A Boston concern manufacturing scientific instruments announced today it was filling a $1,500,000 Navy order for "disaster" radiation survey meters to measure radiation on ships and shore installations after atomic explosions.

The National Fencing Coaches Association concluded its first annual meeting last night at the New York Athletic Club. Stanley Sieja, Princeton coach and vice president of the organization, presided in the absence of President Charles Schmitter of Michigan State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 23, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Navy's Bureau of Ships today awarded a $4,583,700 contract to the Lynn, Mass., plant of the General Electric Company for turbines and gears for the third Forrestal class aircraft carrier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today rejected a protest by a Kansas City battery additive concern that its product had not been sufficiently tested. Hearings were ordered on the company's advertising.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Grain futures were heavy today, with the weakness in soybeans tending to unsettle the market. Much year-end evening up was in evidence in all pits with some selling of lines carried over six months.

To avoid opening against itself, the Playwrights Company has changed the New York premiere of "Ondine" from Feb. 17 to Feb. 18 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. The earlier date has been reserved by the Playwrights for its presentation of "The Winner," the Elmer Rice script, for which a theatre has not been designated yet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- T. Coleman Andrews likes to point out that ever since man left his neolithic cave to move into a community, he has had a tax collector.

London markets will operate as usual tomorrow, but all financial and commodity markets in this country and in Canada will be closed. Financial markets in this country plan to put in full days of work today but New York commodity markets, the Chicago Board of Trade, the New Orleans Cotton Exchange and the Winnipeg Grain Market will operate a half day only.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Prof. Seymour E. Harris of Harvard University said that the Federal Government had gone out of its way to aggravate the problems of slipping economic regions.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court justice who presided over the ten- week trial of James A. Leary today branded as "a gross miscarriage of justice" Mr. Leary's acquittal three weeks ago on charges of perjury and conspiracy to obstruct justice.

A rain-smudged traffic violation tag issued on Dec. 20 was still on an actor's car still parked yesterday in front of 20 West Eighty-fourth Street. The car had been there since Thanksgiving Night, and the owner, Arthur J. Hammond, was surprised to learn yesterday that the police had singled him out for punishment.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Your stomach trouble, headache, back pain or even an irregular heart might actually be a form of "money sickness" caused by a virus familiarly known as the dollar.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 30 -- Glen Cove's thirty-one-year-old North Country Community Hospital has lost its battle of names against the new North Shore Hospital in Manhasset.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Dec. 30 -- Tuskegee Institute today announced its abandonment of its annual Lynching Letter.

IN a holiday season the advantages of reading a frisky or thoughtful book stand out spectacularly. You never have to pay a scalper's scale to read the most popular books of the moment; the prices remain unchanged. You do not have to shoulder your way through crowds or wait cravenly for the headwaiter to notice you before you can start reading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The Army, always security conscious, erected a tight curtain of secrecy around the proposed locations of its new anti-aircraft guided missile, the Nike. But it failed to take account of local pride -- and local objections.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec, 30 -- The White House gave public assurance today that the Administration's effort to channel defense contracts into labor surplus areas was not intended to take business away from any section.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 30 -- John Collier, former Commissioner of Indian Affairs, charged today that a small minority group in the United States was striving to "shuttle the American Indian into chaos and ruin."

Dr. Clarence C. (Buddy) Combs of Eatontown, N. J., who led his Red Bank Polo Club to the national senior and 12-goal titles last season, remains the lone ten-goal player indoors, according to the official 1954 handicaps released yesterday by the Indoor Polo Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican leader of the Senate, joined the fight late today to upset President Eisenhower's announced policy of channeling defense contracts into areas of high unemployment.
The comments of Harry Schwartz in The New York Times of Dec. 24 on the trial and execution of the Lavrenti Beria group are, as always, expert and interesting.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Willie Shoemaker for the second straight day captured Santa Anita's feature race today as he booted Lucky Martin to a length victory in the $28,500 California Breeders' Trial Stakes for 2-year-olds.

Thomas Wilson, 45 years old, of Garden City, L. I., was held in $20,000 bail yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court because he allegedly threatened to kill Miss Betty Bentz unless she resigned the union organizer's job he formerly held.

HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Art Quimby, the University of Connecticut's 6-foot 7-inch center, was acclaimed as the New England intercollegiate invitation basketball tournament's most valuable player tonight after the unbeaten Huskies defeated Dartmouth's host team, 70 -- 58, in the title game.

A new administration takes office here tomorrow amid hopes of all the people, regardless of politics or pre-election preferences, that New York will now be a better governed city. Some improvement over the regimes that have followed La Guardia should not be too difficult an achievement.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 30 (AP) -- West Virginia University rallied from a third-quarter slump tonight to down Columbia University, 88 -- 81.

State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, a Republican as well as an idealist, wants the New York Legislature to bar state, county or city chairmen of any political party from serving as paid lobbyists while in office or for five years after leaving party office.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., announced yesterday that one of the largest companies in the corset and brassiere industry voluntarily had scheduled a shorter work week, although an agreement with the union permitted operation on a forty-hour week for two more years.

George Mandel of Astoria and Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn gained the quarter-finals in the Eastern indoor tennis championships for juniors and boys at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday. Mandel, first-seeded in junior singles, and Holmberg, No. 1 in boys' singles, form the No. 1 pair in junior doubles and also reached the doubles semi-finals.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 30 -- Progress has been made toward the establishment of national standards for the training of teachers who work with mentally retarded children, leaders of the International Council for Exceptional Children said today.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 30 -- The significance of the Gadsden Purchase lies in the fact that it was the first step in the unification of what is now the State of Arizona, Gov. Howard Pyle said here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Experts in the analysis of national income debated here today key devices for holding the recession they foresaw to what the Eisenhower Administration has called "tolerable" limits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission's new investigation of health insurance companies designed to is "weed out the rotten apples in the industry," Alex Ackerman Jr., secretary of the commission, said today.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Inc., gave more than $3,500,000 to educational, scientfic and charitable institutions in 1951 and 1952, according to a biennial report to be issued today.

TOKYO, Dec. 30 -- The Japanese Government has unveiled its proposed budget for next year but has failed to allay fears in many quarters here that the unchecked inflationary spiral will endanger the rickety national economy.

The letter of Daniel James concerning Haya de la Torre in The Times of Dec. 24 is so full of errors and half-truths that it calls for a reply. He is wrong or badly informed on at least the following points:

Even a professional cook can find new ideas in food, according to Mrs. Irma S. Rombauer, co-author with her daughter of the best-selling cook book, "The Joy of Cooking." A recent trip to Mexico introduced Mrs. Rombauer to a hot, spicy fare entirely new to the expert in robust American and delicate European foods.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 30 -- Communist China and Indonesia have opened long-awaited negotiations on the knotty problem of the future status of Indonesia's 2,000,000 Chinese, three-quarters of whom claim full Indonesian citizenship.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 30 (AP) -Del Flanagan of St. Paul gained a ten-round split decision tonight over Johnny Saxton, third-ranking welterweight, in a dull fight. Each weighed 149 3/4 pounds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Navy announced today that the captain and the crew had been absolved of all blame in the explosion and fire Oct. 16 aboard the aircraft carrier Leyte.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- Soviet firing squads were reported today to have executed 150 leaders of a strike of thousands of prisoners working in Siberian coal mines.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Following are the texts of art analysis of dock reports by George Shapiro, counsel to the Governor, and of a statement on the pier situation by Governor Dewey:
Fares of nine privately operated bus companies in the city will go up today.

A new work by Albert Camus, French author of "The Plague" and "The Stranger," will be published by Knopf on Jan. 11. Titled "The Rebel: An Essay on Man in Revolt," it is an exploration of the causes of totalitarianism as exemplified in the regime of Hitler and Soviet Russia.

PARIS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Judge William Clark, deposed chief justice of the United States court system in Germany, headed home today with a parting blast at American officials whom he accused of tampering with his files.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- The Soviet Union turned over to East Germany today the last thirty-three of the industrial plants it had seized for reparations at the end of World War II, including some of the largest factories in Europe.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 31 -- A 54-year-old ship's steward was held in $25,000 bail here today by Magistrate Morris E. Barison as a fugitive from justice in connection with a $300 swindle in the sale of National Maritime Union membership books in New York City.
MADRID, Dec. 31 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco said today that if there was a Western leader capable of defeating communism and establishing permanent peace, he was President Eisenhower.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 31 -- Territorial Zionist organizations will be established around the world in an effort to broaden the base of the Zionist movement, according to a resolution adopted here tonight by the Zionist General Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Constitutional immunities guaranteed to the press by the First Amendment "extends to such improvements of communication as motion pictures" and should give them immunity from censorship, the Supreme Court was told today.

Robert F. Wagner Jr. announced yesterday the appointment of two women as charter members of his official family as Mayor. At today's swearing-in ceremony Dr. Leona Baumgartner will become Health Commissioner and Magistrate Anna M. Kross will become Commissioner of Correction.
BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- New state machinery for penalizing traffic violators became effective tonight.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 31 -- The largest individual landowner here has challenged the town's policy of applying high exclusive zoning restrictions to more than one-third of Greenwich.

The appeal by Captain Bradley of the old International Longshoremen's Association to President Eisenhower for appointment of a special "coordinator" to deal with the waterfront situation is both belated and premature, as well as impertinent. Appointment of an arbitrator with broad powers to handle disputes on the waterfront is nothing new.

A two-story dwelling on the west side of Valley Road, about 417 feet north of Bayville Avenue, in Bayville, L. I., has been sold by Argio Avazio to Frank S. Mainella. The sale was made through Alphonsa Spaventoy as broker and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 31 -- Elections for a new Iranian Parliament, originally scheduled to open today, will not begin until after Jan. 18, the Government announced this morning. Officials aid heavy snow and rain throughout the northern and eastern part of the country had slowed the preparation for the balloting.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A new mobilization plan designed to draw more army veterans into national guard and reserve units goes into operation tomorrow. It will get a six-month trial.

BOWIE, Ariz., Dec. 31 (UP) -- The "Old Tomahawk" made the last run of its long history this New Year's Eve from Globe to Bowie, where news of the surrender of Apache chief, Geronimo, first was flashed to the world.

HONOLULU, Dec. 31 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, returned to his former Pacific Fleet headquarters today after a Far East tour. He said he felt certain that fighting in Korea had been halted permanently.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 31 -- Petrobras -- Petroleo Brasileiro Corporation -- the Government monopoly controlling the exploitation of petroleum in Brazil, commences operating tomorrow. It is to be a complete monopoly and all residents, including foreigners, must contribute to it.

The value of bonds called in December for redemption before maturity was the highest in five months, but the smallest for any December since 1933. The total of $22,221,000 compared with $9,948,000 in the preceding month and $115,785,000 in December, 1952.

Critics of today's college youth who bemoan what they consider "superficiality" in young people's standards for social relationships would get no support for their carping in findings of a study of "courtship values" recently completed at the University of Colorado.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 1, -- Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, in an interview with an American reporter, has said that there are favorable opportunities for a further relaxation of international tension in 1954.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Sir Winston Churchill said today that the possibility of international conflict had been reduced by the growing strength of the free world and its desire to reach just and honorable agreements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today a 12 per cent increase in store sales in the nation for the week ended Dec. 26. The following table gives the percentage by cities for the week and four weeks, with comparisons:

MIAMI, Dec. 31 -- With a record crowd expected to witness their play in the Orange Bowl classic tomorrow, both the University of Maryland and the University of Oklahoma football teams added final touches to their preparations today.
Futures opened steady yesterday, unchanged to 8 points up on the New York Cotton Exchange, and closed 1 point off to 17 points up.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has on this first day of the New Year a total of $348,918.60 from 8,906 contributors. Of this sum, $6,684.11 was received yesterday from 349 donors.
Membership in the Protestant Episcopal Church increased 75,110 last year to a total of 2,790,935, according to the 1954 Episcopal Church Annual.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Following is the calendar for the second session of the Eighty-third Congress, as prepared by The Congressional Quarterly:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, announced today he would be a candidate for re-election next fall.
A New Year, symbolizing again man's hope that things will be better, arrived last night. People in different parts of the world welcomed or ignored it, according to their fashion.

The Cunard Line announced yesterday the wind-up of a distinguished forty-eight-year career at sea for Capt. Harry Grattidge, senior captain and commodore of Cunard's fleet of superliners and cargo ships.

A few hours before his resignation as Police Commissioner, George P. Monaghan was sworn in yesterday as member of the Moreland Act Commission that is investigating harness racing. He will serve in the unsalaried post until the Legislature creates the post of harness racing "czar," for which he has been designated by Governor Dewey.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UP) -- Jockey Willie Shoemaker, 22-year-old sensation of the turf, closed his record-breaking year with 485 winners, surpassing Tony DeSpirito's old mark of 390 by ninety-five victories.

Greenwich Village's ambitious Circle in the Square now is concentrating on its next offering, "The Girl on the Via Flaminia." Dramatized by Alfred Hayes from his short novel of the same name, the play is listed as an early February entry at the organization's headquarters, 5 Sheridan Square, under the direction of Alfred Saxe.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 31 -- A gross national product for West Germany and West Berlin of 132,000,000,000 to 133,000,000,000 Deutsche marks (about $31,000,000,000) was indicated today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Trade in grains and soybeans on the last day of 1953 became mildly bullish, with the leadership going to soybeans futures. The latter were helped by reported export sales of about 200,000 bushels at the seaboard and Japan taking another cargo.

I wish to thank you sincerely for the editorial which appeared in your Dec. 28 issue concerning my case. It is indeed gratifying to see that there are men in this country who recognize the fact that in some cases justice is not being properly served.

It may be that all of the reported difficulties some members of the Boston Celtics had with the club's management have been patched up. It certainly appeared all was harmony among them again, as the Beantowners gave one of their best all-around performances of the season to post a 95-to-74 National Basketball Association triumph over the Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Senate investigators will leave Saturday for Montreal to question Igor Gouzenko, former Soviet code clerk, about possible Communist espionage in the United States.
Grover A. Whalen, whose task as the city's official greeter already is ended, made his separation from the city's service complete yesterday.

The gifted 23-year-old pianist Leon Fleisher gave an excellent account, of himself, at Carnegie Hall last evening as soloist with George Szell and the Philharmonic-Symphony in Brahms' D minor Concerto.

Vincent R. Impellitteri functioned as Mayor at a rapid pace all day yesterday, virtually up to the closing moments of his three years and two months' term as head of New York City's government. His last day in office, ending at midnight, was one of his busiest.

HANOI, Vietnam, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The French high command, predicting a surge in 1954 toward final victory over the Communist-led Vietminh, announced today a minor success in the campaign near Dienbienphu and a minor defeat in the Red River delta.

DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Hardbitten Rice and dogged Alabama put perfect Cotton Bowl records on the line tomorrow. If Rice doesn't stand alone when the firing ceases it will be one of the biggest upsets in the eighteen-year history of this New Year's Day football game.

SAINT - QUENTIN. France Dec. 31 -- Some Frenchmen write on walls inviting United States soldiers to go home. Others are resentful toward the United States because of the possibility that the soldiers may go home.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Governor Dewey today designated an old golfing companion, Supreme Court Justice Charles E. Murphy of Brooklyn a member of the Appellate Division in the Second Judicial Department. Justice Murphy is a Democrat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A fifteen-day extension of the Migrant Labor Agreement between Mexico and the United States was announced today by the State Department. The agreement was to have expired today.

The ski situation in the Northeastern United States continues to be at a record low for this time of the season but along the Laurentian front of eastern Canada the picture remains bright. Snow-starved skiers have a slightly improved outlook for the next few days.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Auburn and Texas Tech climax spectacular climbs to national football fame tomorrow when they unleash their split T power in the Gator Bowl.

Pope Pius XII has elevated four priests of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to the rank of domestic prelate with the title of Right Rev. Monsignor, according to a message received here yesterday from Cardinal Spellman.
Holiday requirements of sales finance companies raised the volume of business loans from New York City banks $67,000,000 last week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Reports reached United Nations diplomats today that India was planning to call for a February meeting of the General Assembly to take up the Korean situation.

The oldest republic in Latin America celebrates its sesquicentennial today. The annals of freedom have few more thrilling or romantic pages than the successful revolt of a Negro slave people against the strongest power of Europe -- the France of Napoleon I. Only our own country in the Western Hemisphere won its independence sooner than Haiti.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 31 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali and other Moslem League leaders will launch tomorrow the first major political campaign in the country's history.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 31 -- "To work tirelessly for passage by Congress of the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution so that women will be full citizens" is one of five New Year's resolutions for business and professional women suggested here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Plans were laid today to announce tomorrow acceptance of the Soviet Union's proposal of Jan. 25 as the date for a meeting of the Big Four foreign ministers in Berlin. Jan. 4 was originally uggested by the Western powers.
Mid - Manhattan Magistrate's Court was eliminated yesterday as a district court.

Trading came to a halt on the New York Stock Exchange for 1953 with the last transaction in a stock that was higher for the year, despite the over-all decline in market prices in 1953. A sale of ninety shares of Safeway Stores' 4 per cent preferred at 88-1/2, up 1/4 point for the year, was the final transaction on the "Big Board."

Peter Lind Hayes and Mary Healy have been signed to radio and television contracts by the Columbia Broadcasting System, They soon will start their own radio series, the network said, and Mr. Hayes will substitute for Arthur Godfrey whenever the latter is absent from his morning programs.

More than 500 political and personal well-wishers jammed the twentieth-floor Municipal Building offices of the Borough President of Manhattan yesterday to see Hulan E. Jack sworn in as the first Negro to head the borough.

Jack Kramer, professional tennis is player and promoter, told the United Press yesterday he planned to offer berths on his 1955 tour to the Davis Cup stars. Lewis Hoad of Australia and Tony Trabert of Cincinnati.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The State Department requested the Rumanian Legation today to cease publishing and distributing its English-language periodical The Rumanian News and pamphlets similar to it.
SARNIA, Ont., Dec. 31 (Canadian Press) -- The first Alberta Oil to reach Sarnia by pipeline is expected here Tuesday.

Henry Endress, executive secretary of Lutheran Church Productions, declared here yesterday that anyone believing in freedom of conscience "must be shocked" at the banning Wednesday of the film, "Martin Luther," by the Quebec Film Censorship Board.

The stock markets here closed lower on the year for the first time since 1948. Selected rail, motor, tobacco, metal and television issues were at bottom prices of 1953, while steels were between their highs and lows.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The heavy tax burden of about 50,000,000 individuals and 50,000 corporations will be eased somewhat by the expiration tonight of two big tax increases imposed in 1950 and 1951 to help finance the Korean War.
The Ashland Oil and Refining Company lifted its net income in the fiscal year ended on last Sept. 30 to $8,407,616 from $5,700,273 in the preceding year, reflecting increased sales.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell announced yesterday that he had retired after more than seventeen years on the bench in the Southern District of New York. He explained, however, that he would be "back on the job" Monday to take special assignments in civil and non-jury cases.
The churches of New York hailed the New Year last night at traditional Watch Night services and Holy Hours.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 31 -- The Bergen County police announced today the arrest of three men in the sale in the last two years of 30,000 bottles of fraudulent Chanel No. 5. The original is one of the world's most famous perfumes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Film producers can draw reassurance and disappointment in equal measure from the 1953 listing of the ten top money-making stars as determined by The Motion Picture Herald in its twenty-second annual polling of the nation's theatre owners.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- The Electric Storage Battery Company announced a merger today of its domestic subsidiary corporations, effective tomorrow.
On the eve of the New Year, most signs point to a continuing food bounty in 1954 with many of this year's prices carrying on into the new year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The families of more than 3,600 United States soldiers and airmen will be told tomorrow that their sons, missing in Korea for more than one year, must now be presumed dead.
George Asherman has been elected a director and vice president of the Henry J. Eckstein Lumber Corporation. Mr. Asherman has been with the company four years.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Friday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Emil Zatopek, Czechoslovakia's triple Olympic winner, sprinted to an easy victory today in the 7,300-meter (about five miles) San Silvestre race.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 31 -- Hopeful that he might reduce substantially the annual deficit of $5,000,000 for the Jersey City Medical Center, Mayor Bernard J. Berry said today he planned to enlist the aid of Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner in a move to establish a state medical college at the institution.

NOW that it is possible to look back on the hunting and fishing of 1953, the majority of sportsmen find that the over-all picture was colored by a few incidents. One good day afield seemed to wipe out the memory of many blank ones.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Dec. 31 (AP) -- An 18-year-old Navy airman, a bridegroom of one month, was shot to death while on duty as a gate sentry last night at the Glynco Naval Auxiliary Air Station here. He was Arthur W. Schoultz Jr., son of a building contractor at Bayside, Queens, L. I.

TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Japan has suffered a foreign trade deficit this year for the first time since the Korean war began. The Government's year-end report on trade showed an un favorable balance of $934,000,000 for the first ten months of the year. This far outweighed invisible trade receipts such as spending by the United States armed forces and left a net deficit of $136,000,000 for the period.

PASADENA, Calif. Dec. 31 (AP) -- Michigan State, led by a powerful little back named Le Roy Bolden, goes into the Rose Bowl tomorrow favored by one touchdown to defeat the Bruins of U. C. L. A. and their all-America triple-threat star, Paul Cameron.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today made public a ruling that the Detroit Cleveland Navigation Company need not divest itself of its holdings of stock in the Denver-Chicago Trucking Company of Denver.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Georgia Tech, a member of football's royal family, and West Virginia, one of the sport's ambitious relatives, meet tomorrow in one of the Sugar Bowl's most controversial games.

Three and a half centuries ago the sellers of garden seeds evidently did not enjoy the public confidence that now is theirs. We find one Richard Gardiner, a Shropshire linen draper who also sold vegetables and seeds, warning one and all in a seed price list dated 1603 against "the great and abominable falsehoods of those sortes of people which sell Garden seedes."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, jointed Southern opposition today to an Administration plan to ease unemployment by channeling defense contracts into areas like New England.
In The Times of Dec. 28 you printed a letter from David Selden of the New York Teachers Guild about state aid for education.
The central office of the ferry bureau of the city's Department of Marine and Aviation has been moved from the aging ferry station at South Ferry to the new terminal at St. George, Staten Island.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Friday, Jan. 1 -- President Chiang Kai-shek called upon his countrymen in a New Year's message to prepare for "more pains and sacrifices" in 1954. The message, issued last night, described this as likely to be "a more decisive year" than many past.

Lulu Perez, featherweight boxer from the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, will meet Dave Gallardo of Los Angeles in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The contest will be the third between the pair. Each fighter scored a victory in a past encounter.
The Dravo Corporation, one of the nation's largest builders of inland waterway craft, launched 112 craft at its Pittsburgh and Wilmington, Del., shipyards in 1953.
Governor Dewey denounced the old International Longshoremen's Association yesterday as a "ruthless mob" seeking to keep its rule over the harbor by force and strike threats.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- J. H. Nail Jr.'s Seventh Sun, a 10-to-1 shot, thundered to victory in the featured Solar Prince purse at Tropical Park today before a crowd of 9,777 which included Senator Joseph McCarthy of Wisconsin and Clyde Tolson, assistant to J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Wes Santee of Kansas achieved a 55-second final lap in the Sugar Bowl mile run today to finish in 4:04.2, the third fastest mile ever recorded by an American.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Bill Talbert, the American Davis Cup captain, today called upon the United States to institute a tennis development program comparable to Australia's before the Davis Cup becomes Sir Norman Brookes' private punch bowl.

Garson Kanin's first play, "Born Yesterday," brought a note of brightness to Broadway back -- it now seems -- in the long-ago of 1946 when people were still conscious of the aftermath of a great world war. Then, the spectacle of a modern robber baron who took a junk yard, ran it up to $50,000,000, owned a Senator and finally got his come-uppance from a so-called "dumb broad" highly titillated the theatregoers.
In reviewing their activities in the old year and planning for the new, most families probably will give consideration to their annual budget.
Last night, in that quiet time before the New Year's revelry had begun, a bit of little old New York quietly died.
The Waterfront Commission posted "keep out" signs yesterday for three former convicts who sought permits to work on the piers -- two as hiring agents and one as a longshoreman.

David Bronstein and Alexander Tolush, the Russian representatives in the international masters' tournament at Hastings, England, played a second-round draw in twenty-one moves yesterday, according to a report from London.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Cigarette manufacturers have been told informally by the Justice Department that it cannot approve in advance a plan to combat medical assertions that cigarette smoking may be a cause of lung cancer.

Stocks thrashed through an active but inconclusive session yesterday and ended virtually unchanged on the day. On the year, The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks showed a loss of 18.48 points, or 9.4 per cent.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay's third-period goal which deflected off Defenseman Butch Bouchard enabled the Detroit Red Wings to gain a 2-to-2 tie with the Montreal Canadiens tonight before 13,105 fans at Olympia.

Our report of stewardship of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is made on New Year's instead of Christmas Day, the formal closing of the appeal having been delayed, as was the appeal itself, by the newspaper strike. We are happy to say that the results are most heartening.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Railway Progress Magazine said today that the railroads were slashing rates for military passenger traffic to meet "unfair competition of nonscheduled airlines."

New York's millinery industry has met the challenge of changing hat styles and the basic situation in the trade is encouraging. The new year will bring several industry-wide promotions designed to overcome the vogue for hatlessness which has cut into the industry's volume.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor turned his back on his Communist captors today and returned to the American side with the comment that it is "quite possible" other Americans, who were ready for repatriations, would follow him.

An ad campaign to help raise $10,000,000 and win the support of Americans for the counter-propaganda war against communism in Europe will be started today by this country's newspapers. The campaign, known as the Crusade for Freedom, will continue to Feb. 22 and will be conducted by the Advertising Council on behalf of the American Heritage Foundation.

The five Red Cross chapters in the city have elected George H. Coppers of the New York Chapter to be city-wide chairman of the March appeal for funds and members. Mr. Coppers is president of the National Biscuit Company and the New York State Chamber of Commerce.
A total of $1,097,831,000 of new bonds was offered publicly here in December. This was the largest amount for any month in twenty-seven years and the fourth billion-dollar month in the period.

The recent exposure of charity frauds may have frightened some generous contributors more than it should have. The vast majority of philanthropic organizations are honest and sound. Moreover, the fine instinct to give should not be stifled by uncertainty or fear, frustrating both the generous contributor and the intended beneficiary.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Christmas mail volume set a record this year.

Malaya's loss will be Europe's gain when Gen. Sir Gerald Templer is shifted this year from his post in Southeast Asia to the command of NATO's Northern Army Group in West Germany. He has served with unusual success and distinction for two years in one of the world's trouble spots and he rightly receives much credit for the substantial gains that have been made toward peace and stability in Communist-assailed Malaya.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Mike Green, 16-year-old former national boys' champion from Miami Beach, won the Orange Bowl junior boys' singles final today in a 3-hour 10-minute match.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The outlook for 1954 is: Less tension abroad and more economic tension at home.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Sammy Lee, the star diver, learned by telephone today that he had won the 1953 James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy for sportsmanship in amateur athletics and exclaimed:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31 -- The 473,000 Roman Catholics of the St. Louis archdiocese are forbidden "under penalty of mortal sin" to attend "The French Line," a Jane Russell musical film in three-dimension and Technicolor that had its premiere Tuesday at the Fox Theatre.

The nation's chemical industry invested a record of $1,600,000,000 in plant and equipment in 1953, or about 25 per cent more than in 1952, according to William C. Foster, president of the Manufacturing Chemists Association.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 31 -- Charges of possession and exhibition of an obscene motion picture, "The Moon Is Blue," against the Stanley Company of America, operator of the Ritz Theatre here, and Clement P. Murphy, the manager, were referred today to the grand jury by Magistrate John L. McGuire.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 31 -- Rent controls went off tonight at Oak Ridge and an increase in rent for all Oak Ridge housing, effective Feb. 1, was announced by Fred W. Ford, director of the Atomic Energy Commission's community affairs division at Oak Ridge.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- After he had failed in his efforts to bring the opposing factions together, Sir Walker Monckton, Minister of Labor, appointed two courts of inquiry today to look into wage disputes in the shipbuilding and engineering industries.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 31 -- Frank Neale, president of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, announced today that in the last two weeks South African gold stocks had risen in value by about $65,000,000. This reversed a trend of several years of steady decline in gold stocks as a whole.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 31--An advance party of a British-sponsored international expedition to track down the Abominable Snowman, legendary dweller of the Himalayan heights, has arrived in India. The group is making careful and scientific preparations to comb the Mount Everest region in the spring for traces of the unknown creature that made strange footprints which were photographed two years ago by Eric Shipton, leader of the unsuccessful British assault on Everest in 1951.

A Panair do Brasil Constellation landed yesterday at Rio de Janeiro completing the first nonstop airplane crossing of the South Atlantic Ocean from Lisbon, Portugal. The course measured about 4,800 statute miles.

A syndicate represented by Green Ettinger, attorneys, has purchased the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 333 West End Avenue, southwest corner of Seventy-sixth Street, from M. Robert Steel. The Brener Lewis Company, brokers, negotiated the sale of the property, which measures 76 by 100 feet and is assessed at $500,000.
BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- The Navy will usher in 1954 by throwing its heavyweight instead of its middleweight punch in submarine killer-hunter tactics.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Allegations made by the World Federation of Trade Unions that the Saar Government had interfered with the rights of union members were denied in a communication to the Economic and Social Council released today.
SEOUL, Friday, Jan. 1 -- An American prisoner of war held with the pro-Communist group of Allied troops near Panmunjom, asked early today to be sent back home.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- It is planned by the Armed Forces to drop a hydrogen bomb from a B-36 bomber in May to see how the plane and crew survive the shock, an informed source said today.

PARIS Dec. 31 -- The Soviet Government has abandoned two of the most massive engineering projects in the Soviet Union, according to reliable reports received here. Both had been started under the Stalin administration.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- A knighthood was awarded today to Jacob Epstein, sculptor, who was born on New York's lower East Side seventy-three years ago.
PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The excitement of the new French fabric collections centers around cottons.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, declared yesterday that public opinion and crisis conditions had forced Governor Dewey to adopt a housing program and a program for expansion of the state's mental hospitals.

IT was twenty years ago today that Columbia perpetrated as monumental an upset as any bowl football game ever has produced. There may be upsets in some of the various bowl games this afternoon, but none will hit with the impact of that Rose Bowl upheaval of 1934.

JUST before last midnight Tommy Ward and two assistants climbed a narrow stairway from the roof into Times Tower turret high above Times Square. They tested the lanyards that held in place the great lighted globe that drops to symbolize the dying year.

Louis M. Loeb, impartial chairman of the fur industry, has ordered a 10 per cent off-season wage cut for fur workers unless the Associated Fur Manufacturers and the Furrier's Joint Council accept alternative suggestions, it was learned yesterday.

When the bells rang and the horns and whistles blew last night millions of persons throughout the English-speaking world, and groups of exiles in lands where English is a foreign tongue, knew what to do. They rose with glasses in their hands and sang "Auld Lang Syne."

When a family is at the desperate point of breakdown, when it is deserted by a father or a mother or facing divorce, when it is involved with the law because of a willful youngster, or in crucial need of human as well as legal understanding to preserve a marriage -- where else should that family logically look for help and for justice but to the courts?

George Mandel of Astoria, seeded No. 1, and Carl Norgauer of Yonkers, No. 2, gained the junior singles semi-finals yesterday in the Eastern indoor tennis championships for juniors and boys at the 102d Engineers Armory.

In a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, large New York construction concern, proposed to acquire the Newport Steel Corporation of Newport, Ky.
German-flag shipping in the last twelve months accomplished its greatest progress since the war's end and the coming year is expected to be even better.

The Committee for Jewish Claims on Austria announced yesterday that the State Department had pledged continuation of its efforts to resolve the stalemate in negotiations between the Austrian Government and world Jewish organizations concerning Jewish claims against Austria.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 31 -- The Peruvian Government has informed Colombia that it will allow Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, Peruvian political leader, to be moved to quarters outside the Colombian Embassy here without losing the diplomatic protection that has shielded him for five years in the embassy building.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- A United States soldier, recently freed by the Russians, said today ten other Americans and a number of Britons, Canadians and Frenchmen were still in Soviet confinement. The soldier was Private Homer H. Cox, 33 years old, who had been a military policeman stationed in West Berlin.
David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., reported yesterday that 130,000 members of his union had gone on a thirty-five-hour work week since last June.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Pennsylvania told the United States Supreme Court today in a written brief that the Keystone State would continue to fight New York City's efforts to draw additional water from the Delaware River unless several condition were met.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Dec. 31 (AP) -- James A. Leary, Saratoga Republican leader, labeled today as "entirely unwarranted" Justice Leo J. Hagerty's castigation of the jury that acquitted him on perjury and conspiracy charges.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 31 -- Johnson Johnson, manufacturers of medical materials, has deeded to Middlesex County twenty acres along the north bank of the Raritan River in near-by Piscataway Township for the development of Johnson Park.

Facing a battery of television and newsreel cameras and half a dozen newspaper photographers, Robert F. Wagner Jr. was sworn in as Mayor at 7:30 o'clock last night at his home, 520 East Eighty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland, said today that the party's policy makers would "discuss" proposals to replace three red-hunting committees with one when Congress met in January.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today industrial production declined 1 1/2 per cent in November. Construction activity land retail sales were up somewhat.
Jacob Epstein, who was born in the Lower East Side of New York in 1880 of Russian-Polish Jewish parents, has been acclaimed as one of the most distinguished sculptors of the twentieth century.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Tennessee. Valley Authority, criticized last summer by President Eisenhower as an example of "creeping socialism," contended today that its achievements over the last twenty years had made for less rather than more Federal control and responsibility.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The last day of the year found the stock markets firm with prices showing many gains. Early hesitation, particularly by the industrial shares because of the wage dispute in the engineering and ship-building industries, was soon shaken off.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 31 -- A single paragraph in a London magazine has set off a serious wave of protests against Queen Elizabeth's visit to Ceylon which is scheduled for April.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Westchester's third County Executive and a new Board of Supervisors embracing for the first time a state Assemblyman and a village mayor will take office tomorrow.
Raymond Henry McCaw, night managing editor of The New York Times since 1930, retired last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Justice Department records disclosed today that President Eisenhower signed eleven pardons on Christmas Eve, the largest single batch of clemencies granted at one time since he entered the White House.

Despite the half-holiday on the New York commodity exchanges and the approach of the long week-end, coffee, cocoa, potatoes and hides were fairly active yesterday. Prices closed irregular with potatoes, hides, cottonseed oil, copper, burlap and wool fixed; cocoa, coffee and soybean oil higher, and sugar, lead, zinc and tin lower.

The building accommodating eight families at 354 South Fourth Street in Brooklyn has been purchased by Meyer Godinger from Myra Sutter in a transaction negotiated by Lew Tietenberg as brokers. Title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Though some Congressmen may conclude from what follows that they should investigate the smiling cherub who is always pictured as the New Year, their constituents are entitled to the seasonable reminder that in the United States this infant has "done Time" -- he is even younger than he looks and implies.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 31 -- President Eisenhower's message to Congress on the State of the Union, featuring lower individual and corporate income taxes and reduced outlays for national defense and foreign aid, neared the final draft today following the arrival here of top White House aides.
Mayor Impellitteri's last official act before leaving City Hall last night was to pave the way for Robert F. Wagner Jr., his successor, to name him as a justice of the Court of Special Sessions.

THE family quarrel among television manufacturers over their respective contributions to the development of color television is beginning to assume silly proportions insofar as the public is concerned. It is time the name-calling was brought to an end before it leads to more useless confusion.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- The State Health Department announced today that preliminary plans had been completed for administering poliomyelitis vaccine tests in certain public and parochial schools next spring.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation, which produced steel at a record rate in 1953, expects to spend $300,000,000 for new equipment and mill replacements in 1954.
BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- The annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science ended here today with the presentation of the Newcomb Cleveland $1,000 prize.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, will seek to restrain those Democrats who wish to take up an instantaneous and general partisan position in the Congressional session opening Wednesday.
