In connection with the "slack dispute" reported from Warrington, England, in a recent edition, it may be of interest to cite the little-known fact that as far back as the ninth century A. D. the Roman Church had already sanctioned the wearing of trousers by women.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 1 -- The Japanese girl whose letters may have helped convince Claude Batchelor that he should break with communism heard with delight today the news that he had asked for repatriation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- James J. Sunday of Detroit patented this week an invention designed to reduce the high mortality of minnows, caused by the shortage of oxygen and overcrowding in the fisherman's pail. "My combined air pump and cushion," he explains, "aerates the water in the pail by simply getting off the cushion and sitting down on the cushion again."
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 518 of the 1,152 persons who took the October Bar Association examination received passing grades.

The fresh, lively flavor of grapefruit for breakfast or any other meal can now be savored abundantly. Prices are usually the lowest in January and this year's fruit is said to be of particularly high quality.

Dismantling the Christmas tree, removing holly wreaths and restoring pre-holiday sparkle to the home is a task that may be lightened with the aid of several new cleaning appliances and products found in many shops around town.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (UP) -- A big, fast East team, headed by Johnny Lattner of Notre Dame, is a one-touchdown favorite to beat the West in the twenty-ninth annual Shrine charity all-star classic tomorrow.
DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 2 -- The police and the military were alerted today to prevent political campaign violence in advance of the election Feb. 16.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 1 -- New Year's Day is the day of the great carnival in Capetown and Cape Province and of smaller carnivals here and elsewhere in the Union of South Africa.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 1 -- A rise in unemployment in California, the West Coast's leading industrial state, was forecast for the next fiscal year, beginning July 1, by representatives of the State Department of Employment this week.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, Dec. 31 -- The accusations of bribery and corruption being aired before an official Commission of Inquiry here have rocked the fragile and still unfinished edifice of self government in the Gold Coast.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Phil D., a 9-1 shot, captured the seventeenth running of Santa Anita's $25,000 added San Pasqual Handicap today and equaled the track record for the mile and one-sixteenth. The 6-year-old son of War Dog ran the distance in 1:41 3/5 and outgamed Indian Hemp in a thrilling stretch drive. High Scud was third.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- William H. Dovey, police chief, said today a Pomona College student had admitted trying to extort $40,000 from four wealthy families, under threats of death, in an effort to finance his education.

Paul Cranis of Brooklyn, No. 6, routed Carl Norgauer of Yonkers, No. 2, to gain the junior singles final in the Eastern indoor tennis championships for juniors and boys at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday. Cranis played confidently to win, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, whereas Norgauer seemed nervous and made many errors.

C. H. O'D. Alexander of England, a former British champion, moved into first place by defeating D. M. Horne, his fellow countryman, yesterday in the annual Christmas Chess Festival at Hastings, according to a report from London.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Jan. 2 -- Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor of Texas, former pro-Red prisoner of war who chose repatriation yesterday in the first hour of the New Year, said here today that any other Allied captive who wanted to come back could make contact with the Indian guards under present conditions.
ASHLAND, Wis., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Authorities were searching a heavily wooded swamp area about twenty miles southwest of here tonight after a farmer reported he heard a plane crash in a snowstorm.

Those automobile dealers who rent cars, with or without maintenance, instead of selling them, are in a tight squeeze. It has been brought about by a recent Treasury Department ruling and the slow attrition in the used-car market.

The contribution of consumer credit to the country's purchasing power ran its expected course in 1953, according to Dr. Sidney E. Rolfe, economist of C. I. T. Financial Corporation, the nation's fifth largest financial institution.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Michigan State's famed pony backfield, staging a brilliant comeback in the third quarter, went on to topple U. C. L. A. by 28 -- 20 in the Rose Bowl today. The triumph gave the Big Ten its seventh success in eight games of the post-season football series with the Pacific Coast Conference.
The following article was writte by William L. Ryan, Associated Press correspondent, who recently visited the Soviet Union.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 1 -- The Department of Agriculture's elimination of its seven regional soil conservation offices was decried here today as a move that "destroys the most important graduate training facility developed for the welfare of the American farm economy."
DENVER, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Paul Wegeman of Steamboat Springs, Colo., swept top honors today in the New Year ski-jumping meet at Genesee Ridge.
A new device that exposes the Whereabouts of fish has been successfully tested with results that should make the finny creatures wish they could go underground.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Art Devlin of Lake Placid, Art Tokle of Chicago and Keith Wegeman of Camp Hale, Colo., today took the lead in tryouts for the United States world ski-jumping team.
EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Dick Shinaut kicked and passed his six-point underdog Texas Western mates to a 37-14 Sun Bowl victory today over Mississippi Southern before 9,500.

For the third time in two days, and each succeeding time before larger audiences, City Council President Abe Stark took the oath of office yesterday. Two thousand well-wishers and friends watched the re-enacting of the ceremony in the new buildings of the Brownsville Boys Club, 1555 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, at 5:30 P. M.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Dec. 30 -- A proposal that the United States grant corridors in the Alaska Panhandle to Canada for the establishment of deepsea ports and industries on Canadian territory has been made by the British Columbia and Yukon Chamber of Mines.

There are only two books published today, both being plays. They are "Tea and Sympathy" by Robert Anderson and "The Little Hut" by Andre Roussin, adapted by Nancy Mitford. Issued by Random House, they sell for $2.75 each.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The news that more British citizens are being held in Soviet slave camps than had hitherto been realized brought a request from the Foreign Office today to relatives of men who may be imprisoned behind the Iron Curtain. It asked that families communicate with the Foreign Office if they recognized any of the names of fellow inmates that are being given by returning German and American former prisoners.
As a simple, but different and distinctive, dessert for this week-end, we suggest a caramelized custard. It is made with milk and eggs, two of the foods now so reasonable in cost.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 1 -- Gala celebrations took place throughout Haiti today as her citizens, close to 4,000,000, observed the country's 150th anniversary of independence.

Faster airline schedules will increase the amount of leisure time spent at hotels by the airlines' growing number of passengers. Therefore through cooperation and joint promotion, airlines and hotels can join hands in building profits and improving their services.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Camille Henry, bidding for rookie-of-the- year honors, broke a deadlock midway in the third period tonight to give the New York Rangers a 2-1 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.
Manufacturers are going to find retailers very price-conscious in the months to come.

Nine eventful years lie between the first Foreign Ministers' conference, held in London in September, 1945, and the meeting scheduled for the end of this month in Berlin. That first reunion was actually a Five-Power conference, since China was among the participants. Then, as now, Mr. Molotov was the Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union.

Vacant land fronting 197 feet on East 232d Street and 102 feet on Barnes Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the Bronx Heights Development Corporation for cash to an unidentified buyer who will erect an apartment house there. Walter J. Dickerson was the broker in the sale.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 1 -- Taft School of Watertown, Conn., and Deerfield Academy engaged in a tense struggle tonight for a final berth in the sixth annual Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament, the Massachusetts sextet winning by 5 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Senator Jenner charged tonight that high officials of the Administration of former President Truman had prevented the removal of traitors from Government service.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 -- British Commonwealth finance ministers will report in Sydney next week that in almost every case 1953 was economically the best year since World War II.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- New violence in which a band of sixty farm workers attacked two detectives and two farm owners and hanged them from a tree was brought to light by police today. One of the detectives died. The three other victims were in a serious condition.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 1 -- President Eisenhower started the year with a four-and-a-half hour conference before lunch today. His aides said he had made "quite a lot of progress" on his message to Congress on the State of the Union.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1 -- Cornelius Shields Jr. of Larchmont, with Iris, took sixth in the opening race and then finished 2-1-4-2 for 15 points and the lead in the B. O. and I. C. section of the twenty-third annual Manhasset Bay Yacht Club frostbite regatta today.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- The consumption of cigarettes in New York state, which doubled between 1940 and 1953, has begun to decline for the first time since World War II.

It has been hard for Americans to understand the extreme passion of spokesmen for India on the subject of a United States-Pakistani military agreement, but in view of all that has been said one can no longer doubt the sincerity and gravity of Indian feelings.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 1 -- Richard C. Lee was inaugurated as the forty-fourth Mayor here today and called for a "bestirring of our common civic conscience" to combat migration to the suburbs and other municipal problems.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 1 -- Diplomats in Bonn, who are as numerous as lawyers in an ordinary town, have a new parlor game: guessing what the Russians will propose at Berlin. Any number can play, and everybody is playing.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- Children in Pittsburgh, and the surrounding area, will get inoculations this month of the trial polio vaccine developed at the University of Pittsburgh.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Soviet authors have been told they must abandon an aristocratic attitude toward collective farms and dig for rural facts and color to back the drive for increasing farm production.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Net earnings of major Chicago banks increased in 1953 compared with 1952, in some cases sharply, their annual reports showed today.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A nationally known Methodist clergyman suggested today that the Communist infiltrating cell principle might be investigated as a means for Christianizing our culture.
BERLIN, Jan. 1 -- A total of 305,737 refugees from the Soviet zone of Germany were registered in West Berlin in 1953. This means that more than 1.7 per cent of the entire population fled to the West.

We follow, with apprehension the unequal fight waged by the Slovene minorities for their most fundamental rights of national existence and cultural heritage. If the Trieste territory is annexed by Italy the autochthonous Slovenes will be oppressed. Therefore we declare that we can never acquiesce in such a death sentence for the Slovenes of Trieste.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 1 -- India has no desire to manufacture atomic bombs, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared here today. He was laying the foundation stone of the new home of the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research.
Americans ate so much more macaroni last year that the makers estimated yesterday that sales volume in 1953 at nearly $16,000,000 above the 1952 total.

NYACK, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- An all-day search of the Hudson River and of a five-mile stretch along the western shore south of here failed to solve the disappearance of a 43-year-old mother from her home on Orangeburg Road near Pearl River at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. swore in yesterday thirty-six members of his official family. Earlier he delivered an inaugural address in which he pledged himself to provide "a city government dedicated to the best interest of all the people."
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Sir Walter Monckton, the Minister of Labor whose life of late has been particularly strenuous because of widespread labor unrest, has been ordered by his doctors to rest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The Republican party will publish a new magazine soon to aid the party's candidates in the 1954 Congressional elections.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- The Dewey Administration will attempt to keep residential rent control from becoming a political issue at the session of the Legislature that opens Wednesday.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Three climbers marooned last night atop 11,245-foot Mount Hood during a violent storm made their way back to Timberline Lodge at the 6,000-foot level east of here this afternoon.

CAIRO, Jan. 1 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of the British Labor party's left wing, said at a press conference here tonight that the main problem for British and Egyptian negotiators in the Suez Canal base dispute was "to get an agreement with sufficient psychological attractiveness to both nations."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran said today that the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, "has stepped over into a field where it was not intended to function at all."
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- Going to church is an activity enjoyed as much by teen-agers as watching television, swimming, taking in a motion picture or listening to the radio.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The American Medical Association told today of the medical history of a little town in the state of Washington with a death rate one-half the average for the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of a United States note to Moscow accepting Jan. 25 as the date for a Big-Four Foreign Ministers' meeting (parallel notes were sent by Britain and France):

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Halfback Dicky Moegle scored on runs of 79 and 34 yards and had another 95-yard touchdown dash marred by an Alabama benchwarmer's tackle today as Rice crushed the Tide in the Cotton Bowl, 28 to 6.

A Madison Square Garden double-header and an Eastern Intercollegiate League game feature tonight's college basketball program in the East. Iona will face Marshall College of West Virginia and New York University will meet Miami University of Ohio at the Garden. The league contest will bring together Yale and Pennsylvania at the Palestra in Philadelphia.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Pepper Rodgers, 168-pound quarterback, passed Georgia Tech to a 42-to-19 victory over West Virginia today. In winning the twentieth annual Sugar Bowl game the Engineers rewrote much of the classic's record book.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (UP) -- A float entitled "American Heritage," adorned by cupids and embodied with thousands of white orchids and chrysanthemums, won the sweepstakes prize today at the sixty-fifth annual Tournament of Roses parade.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Australia's 19-year-old tennis twins, Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad, and Tony Trabert, the American champion, scoffed today at reports they were being tempted by pro offers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The freighters Permanente Silverbow and Colorado collided tonight off the northern California coast, ripping a gaping hole in the Permanente's No. 4 hold and flooding the forepeak of the Colorado.
Hopes for a low three-day holiday traffic death toll dwindled early today with reports that 132 persons were killed in the first thirty hours of the New Year's week-end.

HOUGHTON, Mich., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A bald eagle, found exhausted on the ice of Chassell Bay in Michigan's Upper Peninsula, took off by plane tonight for Washington, for sanctuary in the National Zoological Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)--Senator Edward Thye, Republican of Minnesota, and Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today they were inclined to vote against any increase in the statutory debt limit of $275,000,000,000.

A steady little man from Pakistan, Hashim Khan, who has never been beaten in competitive squash racquets, added two more victories to his string yesterday as the first United States open tournament got under way at the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Czechoslovakia has underwritten her own suspension from the International Bank of Reconstruction and Development by failing to make good on her defaulted subscription.
BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- New England must provide 15,000 new jobs a year to keep pace with the normal growth of its labor force, it was brought out this week.

The bond market in 1954 should see a continued full supply of tax-exempt state and municipal issues, decline in corporate offerings, and more stable and probably lower interest rates, according to the year-end survey of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Chicago bond house.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The National Safety Council said today the 1953 traffic death toll would approximate the 38,000 in 1952.
Prominent Indians in the United States are putting out warnings that Washington's plans for military aid to Pakistan will produce a backlash of serious military trouble for this country.
THE HAGUE, Jan. 1 (AP) -- World mine production of tin in concentrates in October was 15,500 long tons compared with 14,900 in September.

Every physically handicapped child can be taught some useful activity, but thousands of youngsters in this city are idle and frustrated because there are not enough facilities for training them to overcome their handicaps.

IT was to be expected, in view of the seasonal inactivity of the angler, that there would be a rapid switch from rod to pen following the recent announcement by the Province of Ontario that a new game fish, known as the "splake" had made its entry in sporting circles.
LEAMINGTON, Ont., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Wilfred Crump and his family opened their Christmas packages on New Year's Day this year because of a travel mix-up that put them an ocean apart last week.

Edgar M. Swasey, who had been associated with the Hearst newspapers for the last thirtythree years, died last night shortly after he had been found semiconscious in his gas-filled apartment at 21 West Fifty-eighth Street.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Hasty House Farm's Torch of War, a 4-to-1 shot, led most of the way and easily won the $7,500 New Year's Handicap at Tropical Park today before a morning crowd of 12,733.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Eighty orphan children who were found living in a cave last spring have enjoyed holiday gifts of food, toys and clothing as a result of action by men of the United States Third Bombardment Wing.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- If the equipment and funds are made available, France will be able to raise considerably more divisions than those she intends to maintain for the North Atlantic alliance this year, according to a qualified source.

SEOUL, Saturday, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Corporal Batchelor, who yesterday ended fourth months of voluntary exile in the pro-Red pris oner-of-war compound, told a news conference today the camp where twenty-one other Americans were still held should be searched for weapons and conditions, there should be investigated.

The election of new officers and the expansion of its board of directors on a national basis were some of the things accomplished by the National Association of Community Theatres, which ended a two-day convention yesterday at the Statler.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland of California asserted today that Democrats would have "plenty of opportunity" to propose changes in President Eisenhower's foreign and defense program. He added, however, that some Democrats remained skeptical of bipartisan results.

HANOI, Vietnam, Jan. 1 -- Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre told his French Union forces in Indo-China today that he fully expected victory in the long war against the Communists after six more months of hard fighting.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The stock markets here remained buoyant today despite a fall in turnover caused partly by the closing of many provincial and foreign stock exchanges for New Year's day.

The celebration of the 300th anniversary of Protestantism in Brooklyn will begin tomorrow with a series of evangelistic services ending Jan. 17. The Sponsor will be the Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

The term of Tax Commissioner Jeremiah A. Sullivan, who is chairman of the Richmond County Democratic organization, expired at midnight on Thursday and he was not reappointed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
KHARTUM, the Sudan, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- The Congress of the Sudan met here today for the first time and prepared to set up the nation's first representative government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Universal - International announced today the purchase of "Justice Comes to Tomahawk," an action melodrama of the Old West written in novel form by William MacLeod Raine. The screen play will be written by Teddi Sherman, daughter of the late Harry Sherman, who established the "Hopalong Cassidy" film series with William Boyd.

A ten-day truce in strike plans of the old International Longshoremen's Association expires at midnight tonight. There were no indications yesterday, however, that an organized walkout would be called at the deadline.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (UP) -Sun Tan Gal, a 6-year-old daughter of Sun Again, won the $5,000 New Year Handicap today at the Fair Grounds. She shared honors with jockey Hal Keene, who won the first three races on the nineevent holiday card.
Stocks in retail stores are in good condition, two resident buying office executives reported to their stores in bulletins sent out yesterday.

Higher fares that became effective yesterday for nine private bus companies are expected to yield them $10,000,000 more revenue in 1954. Specialists in the affairs of the private lines also believe that no further change in the fares will be required for at least two years.

The schools and colleges are misbehaving. Set up, as everyone knows, for the purpose of educating youth, they have not done so for what seems like a period of months. Ask any parent about this. Ask any parent what he thinks of the apparently interminable vacations which the schools and colleges substitute for education.

VIENNA, Jan. 1 -- President Antonin Zapotocky of Czechoslovakia asserted in a New Year's speech, broadcast today by the Prague radio, that success of the Czech five-year plan had materially helped to maintain peace in Europe.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Police set up roadblocks and manned roving patrols tonight to halt sneak attacks by rock and paint-throwing vandals in Pittsburgh's thirty-six-day department store strike.
Allan J. Welliver has been appointed manager of the general wholesale department of the Sun Oil Company, Philadelphia. K.E. DeRosay was named manager of the fuel oil department.
A reduction in rates paid for gas by 2,420,000 consumers in the metropolitan area was announced yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Jan. 1 (UP) -- A green coupe with a locker full of security information in the trunk was found abandoned on a San Antonio Street last night when residents complained it had been parked for two weeks.
MIAMI, Jan. 1 -- Oklahoma beat Maryland's football team, ranked No. 1 in the nation, by 7 -- 0 before a record gathering in the annual Orange Bowl game today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Soviet newspapers and broadcasts welcomed the new year today with a burst of messages accenting peace, led by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's declaration that the way to improved relations between the United States and the Soviet Union was clear of obstacles.
A plan for concerted action to clear cigarettes of guilt for causing lung cancer is being mapped by the major cigarette rnanufacturers at highly secret meetings now going on at a midtown hotel daily.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The State Department challenged Premier Malenkov today to back up with deeds his "expressed desire" for peace.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- In 1952 beer was more popular than at any other time in the sixty-odd centuries of its recorded history. That conclusion is inescapable after a glimpse at final figures for the year, now being unscrambled by a United Nations staff in preparation for issuance of the organization's 1953 statistical yearbook.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- The addition of about 75,000 members by labor unions of California during 1953 was announced today by Paul Scarrenberg, State Director of Industrial Relations.

The State Department is to be congratulated on its prompt action in stopping further publication of official Rumanian propaganda in this country in retaliation for the Rumanian Government's suppression of the periodical "News from America." The American periodical, issued in Rumanian by the American Legation in Bucharest, was designed to give propaganda-drugged people behind the Iron Curtain at least a glimpse of what the free world looks like.

In the hope that someone might have "a somewhat better and happier New Year," the staff of the New York office of the Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., whose sponsor is the National Board of Fire Underwriters, sent $97 for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 1 -- Councilman Harry H. Uhlfelder Was elected president of the Long Beach City Council at installation ceremonies today in City Hall. Five Councilmen, the city judge and Supervisor were sworn in.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Larry Couture scored two goals, both from more than fifty feet out, and they proved to be the winning margin as the last-place Chicago Black Hawks beat the league-leading Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 2, tonight.

GUTTENBERG, N. J., Jan. 1 -- An epoch was marked in this four-block-wide town today. John Mangano, a Republican, became the first member of his party to be seated on the Town Council since the turn of the century, and Carl F. Dieffenbach, the last lay magistrate in Hudson County, ended a nineteen-year tenure as the presiding official in the Guttenberg Municipal Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan 1 -- The United States, Britain and France accepted today the proposal of the Soviet Union to defer the projected Berlin meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers until Jan. 25. The three Western powers had originally proposed Jan. 4 as the opening date.

The creation of the Thomas Jefferson Fellowships in the humanities at the University of Virginia, which Mr. Jefferson founded in 1819, is a piquant development of higher education. The fellowships are being created by the Alumni Board of Trustees of the university, which the founder designed to be the "capstone" of public education in his state.

A Greek family, separated for five years by visa problems, began the New Year together yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The reunion was witnessed by an impressive gathering of United States Immigration Service and State Department officials.

Sales volume of Burlington Mills Corporation in the 1953 fiscal year amounting to $360,839,000, set a record high for the third successive year, according to the ninety-ninth annual report, issued yesterday by J. Spencer Love, chairman.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1 -- St. Louis made great strides in 1953 toward solving its traffic snarls, according to its Traffic Commissioner, Charles G. Gonter.
The Soviet Union lost many distinguished citizens in 1953 through death, arrest and "disappearance," according to a summary released yesterday by The Associated Press.

A substantial backlog of demand for industrial Power installations has arisen in the last twelve years, it was reported yesterday by G. E. DeSiena, vice President of Superior Combustion Industries, Inc., boiler and oil burner manufacturers of New York and Pennsylvania.
The following a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to the homemaker:

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Considerable quantities of penicillin tablets sold in British drug stores are partially or wholly inactive, according to inquiries conducted by the Birmingham Public Health Department.

The Metropolitan Opera presented "Don Giovanni" last evening with three singers performing roles for the first time this season. They were Genevieve Warner as Zerlina, Lawrence Davidson as Masetto and Deszo Ernster as the Commendatore.
Lawrence E. Gerosa of the Bronx, the city's new Controller, began his four-year term yesterday day with a reception for 400 guests in his Municipal Building offices.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -The British research station that developed the country's first atomic bomb is working to develop an anti-submarine rocket capable of steering itself onto a target.

A newspaper is as good as the people who make it, and one of the people who have helped The Times for the last quarter-century is Raymond H. McCaw. With his retirement as night managing editor we will miss a stalwart associate and a top news executive who has been an architect of this newspaper since 1930.

Your correspondent Sydney Gruson's recent cable from Tegucigalpa on the political situation in Honduras apropos of the forthcoming Presidential election campaign conveys the false impression that there exists a Communist party in Honduras which has infiltrated the Liberal party -- one of the chief contenders in the forthcoming campaign.
The Society of British Aircraft Constructors reported last week that eighteen airlines had placed orders for British-made turbine-powered airliners.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Fort Ord, Calif., shook off a first-half lethargy to overwhelm a Great Lakes Naval Training Center eleven, 67 to 12, before 10,000 Salad Bowl fans today.
Following is the text of the inaugural address of Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr.:

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Texas Tech broke Auburn's back with a 53-yard scoring pass in the third quarter and a record-breaking 59-yard touchdown run by Bobby Cavazos in the fourth today and won the ninth annual Gator Bowl football game, 35 -- 13.
James H. Hoffnagle's recent letter asks in what respects the provisions of the State Constitution on legislative apportionment should be changed.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A review of 1953 and a look into 1954 today by the Peiping People's Daily, official organ of Red China's Government, hinted at troubles both past and present in changing over the nation's sprawling millions to communism.

THE movies' literary sleuths as well as their bosses, who control the purse strings, are still willing to part with sizable sums for prose they deem proper for their purposes. One of the latest notable transactions involved the buyers at Twentieth Century-Fox, who paid approximately $100,000 for screen rights to "Katherine," a novel by Anya Seton which will not be published until next fall by Houghton Mifflin.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll went on record today as favoring the Army Corps of Engineers' plan for deepening the Delaware River. The proposal calls for a forty-foot channel from Philadelphia northwar to Newbold Island, and a thirty-five-foot channel from that point to Trenton.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, may be safely depicted as agreeing with Robert Burns, the Scottish bard, that "the bestlaid schemes o' mice an' men gang aft agley."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Italy's domestic and foreign policy problems came under scrutiny here today as key diplomatic, defense and intelligence officials conferred with Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Rome.

This week the Eisenhower Administration is going into its second -- and testing -- year. Last week the President was deeply immersed in the preparations for the central role he will play as the Second Session of the Eighty-third Congress gets under way.

The New York Athletic Club trio, with Herb Pennell showing the way, turned back Squadron A, 12 -- 10, in the feature match of the weekly indoor polo double-header at the Squadron A armory last night. Pennell, a fine No. 1, whipped in eight goals for the Winged Footers.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Walter T. Margetts Jr., a Wall Street lawyer turned public official, has earned about $6,000,000 for New Jersey in three years by investing idle operating funds and money borrowed for capital improvements.

The Tennessee Valley Authority in its annual report at the end of twenty years of operation is able to point to some great material achievements in the region it serves. The consumption of electricity has risen from 1.5 billion kilowatt hours annually to 24 billion kilowatt hours -- several times more rapidly than the nation-wide increase.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The British Government expects to continue its present close and friendly military cooperation with Burma in one form or another, provided Burma is willing.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Thirtysix communities, with approximately 10 per cent of New York State's population, have approved fluoridation programs designed to combat tooth decay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Treasury and Congressional staff experts have agreed on major points in a sweeping tax revision proposal that would provide for almost $1,500,000,000 annually in tax cuts in a wide variety of fields.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 2 -- One hundred and fifty almanacs of the more than 3,000 Rutgers University has been collecting for a quarter of a century, have been put on display at the university library.

During the last four years apartment house construction in New York has been greatly stimulated by more than 1,000 amendments to the city's building code, according to Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn Democrat and City Council majority leader.

Herman Romine, 28-year-old veteran of World War II, who threatened to jump off the George Washington Bridge last Dec. 9, was reunited yesterday with his Dutch wife, Lenny, and 3-year-old adopted daughter, Marja. The reunion took place at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, when his wife and daughter arrived from Amsterdam.
Leon Kilbert has been a busy man since he entered this country in 1948. In that time he has received high school and college education and worked full time to support a family.

This band had things all its own way in Bannack and Virginia City, Mont., until late in 1863, when a hastily organized but highly efficient Vigilance Committee brought law to the lawless territory and within five weeks hanged twenty-one outlaws.

A 500-foot, 16mm color film with sound on tape, "The Old House," the story of a friendship between a man and a boy, won for Keith F. Hall of Brisbane, Queensland, Australia, the Hiram Percy Maxim Memorial Award for 1953, it was announced last week.
Mayor Wagner will make a "high level" speech this week in reply to Governor Dewey's recent criticism of the city's $145,000,000 fiscal program for 1954-55 and a long-range one involving $227,100,000.

Surrounded as we are in this city by lights we take for granted their friendly, and sometimes almost overwhelming, glow. But on leaving them, as when we go on a journey, we find that lights we unthinkingly accept en masse become, individually, points of no small interest and importance.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- President Mohammed Naguib issued today a new basic law for Gaza, in southern Palestine, giving permanent residents and Arab refugees increased self-government under Egyptian military rule.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Russia, like the rest of the world, is "sick and tired of the cold war", Ilya Ehrenburg, a leading Soviet author, said today. But he indicated that the price of peace was negotiations with Communist China.

The Federal Reserve System's relaxed monetary policy is now being hailed by some business groups as a new program designed to insure a constantly growing money supply. New York's tangled waterfront situation grew even more confused and technical yesterday.

THE essays in "The Church and Mental Health" are by fourteen of the most distinguished psychiatrists, psychologists and ministers in the country. Each essay is interesting and worthwhile. When the second session of the Eighty-third Congress convenes on Wednesday the party division in both houses will be closer than it has been in more than twenty years. Academy sextet turned in an inspired performance, but fell before the more consistent play of Trinity College School of Port Hope, Ont., 5 -- 3, as the sixth annual Lawrenceville School hockey tourney ended today. From worker on sausage casings to benefactor of motion picture producers * * * that's the story of Walter E. Heller, president of the largest industrial finance company in America.

THE second biennial international exhibition of modern art, which will be current here through February, is not only the largest one of its kind, but, the majority of its international visitors agreed, the best of its kind.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Miss Rebecca F. Gross, editor of The Lock Haven Express, was in "satisfactory" condition today following the amputation of both her legs.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- A pair of sharp-shooting sophomores, Penn's Joe Sturgis and Yale's Ellsworth Morgan, stole the show tonight as Penn opened defense of its Ivy League title with an 86-65 victory over the Elis at the Palestra.

THE only trouble with Alvin Tresselt and Roger Duvoisin's picture book, "Follow the Road," is that it is likely to give young stay-at-homes a severe case of wanderlust. It is true that the little boy who sets out to travel the road stops to play, but the reader goes on -- through cool woods, little towns, into a great city and out again onto a Superhighway Throughway Turnpike.

In the current issue of the "American Scientist," journal of Sigma Xi and the Research Society of America, a prominent psychiatrist and psychoanalyst warns that young scientists are not being given the proper emotional preparation for a tedious, unprofitable and frequently disappointing life as research scientists.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- Factory employment in Pennsylvania fell off by about 22,000 workers from mid-October to mid-November, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank reports. This represents a 2 per cent decline in employment, and was accompanied by decreases of 3 per cent in wage payments and working time.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 2 -- William H. Mortensen of Hartford, chairman of the Connecticut Development Commission, said today he was "convinced" that Connecticut cities and towns could "never solve" their local problems unless they engaged in regional planning.

The hockey game that many local fans have been awaiting will take place tonight when the Canadiens of Montreal oppose the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden. Because of the rivalry that exists between the sextets, it is likely that a crowd of 15,000 will watch the action.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex. -- For the 70 per cent of this nation's population living east of U. S. 77, the shortest and quickest way to drive to Mexico City is through Brownsville. Most tourists can save a day of travel by this route.

ROME, Jan. 2 -- Pope Pius XII has proposed the creation of special committees of ecclesiastics and laymen to elaborate and direct television programs of a purely religious nature. All stations should devote part of their time to such programs, he said.

A FEW years ago, seated in his circular office in the Shubert Theatre overlooking his domain in the heart of the New York theatre district, Lee Shubert, a slightly built youthful-looking man, although then in his early seventies, informed me that he and his brother had just purchased the large Majestic Theatre in Chicago, which had been closed for sixteen years, and on which they were spending over $400,000 for renovations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Eisenhower Administration was pledged today to "continue its policy of encouraging economic stability and growth and of preparing measures for prompt use * * * to help maintain a high level."

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 2 -- Gov. C. Elmer Anderson has laid a political foundation for declining run against Democratic Senator Hubert H. Humphrey in 1954. The Governor has given no public answer to Republicans who wish him to oppose Senator Humphrey, but he has quietly gathered support from other party leaders who feel he should seek another term in the Governorship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- With Congress in recess for five months, globe-trotting by members intended to familiarize them with world conditions as well as, in some instances, to get in a bit of vacation touring at public expense, achieved a tremendous vogue in the last half of 1953.

BUSINESS of both the domestic and overseas airlines of the United States continued to make notable increases last year. There was no leveling off in sight, but the last two months have brought evidence that passenger volumes may not continue to grow as they have during the past three years. In fact, in November and December the domestic airlines experienced what they termed "some softening" in passenger traffic.

YOU encounter all kinds of people at the race track: the cultured and the uncouth, people who are out for fun and people who are intent on striking it rich, some who are fond of horses and some who are so busy trying to pick a winner that they never have time to see the horses.

THE editor of this symposium, Father John A. O'Brien, observes in his opening sentence that: "Nothing in recent centuries is so puzzling or so challenging as the strange phenomenon being enacted before our eyes: the fading away of the once great and populous nation of Ireland."

A REVIEW of conservation high spots during the past year calls to mind some notable advances and also some adverse developments. The growth of understanding in America of the need for conservation of our seemingly limitless natural resources has never been smooth -- even if it has been fairly steady.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2 (AP) -- How to get rid of money has been one of the toughest problems faced in Lebanon by the United States Point Four program of technical aid.

ROME, Jan. 2 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella is like the man who came to dinner. Everyone considered him great when it was thought that he would stay only a short time; everyone would like to see the last of him now that it is clear he has no intention of going.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The two-year-old Board of Regents' proposal that all the state's public schools open the day with a non- denominational prayer has met with mixed response, a survey indicated today.

WITH the new year just a few days old, the garden world finds a full schedule of activities ahead of it. A stream of conferences, symposiums, courses and annual meetings starts this week and continues through the month.

FRESH herbs are certainly a treat in winter, and what could be more fun than growing them in a strawberry jar? Pottery editions of these containers have become quite popular of late and, actually, are ideal for herbs, which seem to adapt themselves to the size of the container.

An 11-month-old black and tan cocker spaniel named Heyday Hopscotch began a new dog show year on the right foot yesterday by becoming the winner of the puppy futurity at the national event of the American Spaniel Club.

THE management of the Terminus Hotel in Dijon, in the heart of France's great wine-producing region of Burgundy, annoyed by American pride in the ice-water tap common in American hotels, has arranged to pipe running red and white wine to each of its bedrooms.
TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 3 -- A throng that had gone to wish Emperor Hirohito a happy New Year trampled to death nearly a score of persons yesterday when guards tried to close the palace gates.

Hashim Khan, that unbeatable squash racquets man from Pakistan, gained the final round of the first United States open championship at the University Club yesterday afternoon. His victim this time was America's No. 1 ranking amateur, G. Diehl Mateer Jr. of Philadelphia.

Johnson Johnson, said to be the world's largest manufacturer of surgical dressings and related items, declared last week it has little difficulty in maintaining its legally set minimum store prices without frequent lawsuits.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 -- Tropical Park's biggest crowd of the season -- 14,984 -- saw River Divide Farm's Andre run off with the $15,000 added Robert E. Lee Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth by three and a half lengths today.

THE program of the public sessions of the International Congress of Art History and Museology, which will meet in New York in honor of the reopening of the Metropolitan Museum's Picture Galleries and in conjunction with the bicentennial of Columbia University, is as follows:

FIFTY years ago nearly all our best criticism was being written by university professors and dons or by men who had easy jobs in the public service or enjoyed private means. Most of them were in fact subsidized men. They could afford to write criticism, which might involve years of reading and research, because they had not to worry about rent, taxes and the grocer's bills.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today told 1,000 widly cheering Germans -- just back from Soviet prison camps -- that the people of West Germany were now "purified" of the taint of Adolf Hitler.

Loyola University, Chicago, has established an Office of Law Development. A $20,000 grant from the Field Foundation will help support research into the relationship between the philosophical bases of law and the applications of such principles to various aspects of race relations.

In "Clues to Theatre Magic" (Nov. 29) Brooks Atkinson writes that "responses to art are highly personal." Such was not always the case with the art of the drama. Over the years the gradual substitution of criticism of the performed play for criticism of the printed play has spawned a school of critics who stress the event rather than its basis.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- It is possible to argue that the year 1953 wound up not far from stalemate in what is called "the cold war," hot though it was in some places.

PARIS, Jan 3 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's Government of the Soviet Union has embarked on a new course of Communist "human engineering" by reversing the Stalinist labor policy and sponsoring a back-to-the-land movement to meet the challenge of an agricultural crisis.
With all media, even radio, sharing in the gains, advertising expenditures during 1953 totaled about $7,900,000,000, or approximately 10 per cent above the 1952 figure.

Lead and zinc producers fought a bitter battle against imports of foreign metals in 1953. The net results for the domestic industry were price cuts, curtailment of mine and smelter output, lower earnings and repeated pleas for greater tariff protection.
LOS ANGELES -- Compared with the senior professions of medicine, law and engineering, the profession of industrial design is a johnny-come-lately indeed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -Republican Senate leaders were reported today to be considering an unusual plan of seniority "insurance" in an effort to fill the party's membership on the Labor Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -Braniff Airways has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for subsidy mail pay for its domestic operations, something it has not required since Oct. 1, 1951.

Toronto, Jan. 3 -- Oil and gas production in Canada for 1953 rose 32 per cent to 81,000,000 barrels which sold for a record $188,000,000, statistics showed today. In addition, proven oil reserves were boosted by 400,000,000 barrels and natural gas reserves by 4,000,000,000,000 cubic feet.

New York State needs a "fair procedure" code for state investigations that will differ in practically every essential respect from the code -- or lack of code -- followed by certain Congressional investigating committees. Governor Dewey will recommend such a code to the 1954 Legislature.
Three 25-year-old men -- two of them British, the other an American -- served notice on the Western Hemisphere yesterday that they personally planned to subdue it in 1954.

R. L. Prain, chairman of Roan Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., and of Rhodesian Selection Trust, Ltd., has invited the companies' stockholders in this country to informal meetings here Jan. 26 and 27 for a first-hand report on the firms' activities.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Representative Dean P. Taylor, Republican State Chairman, today described the Democratic legislative program as representing "an all-time low in demagogery" and "blatant fakery."

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 3 -Stephen A. Kezerian has been named director of the Yale University News Bureau, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale, announced today. Richard Banks has been named associate director. Both men have been serving as assistant directors.

The plastics industry produced and sold more raw materials in 1953 than ever before, and this year even higher output and sales figures are expected, it is stated in a year-end review and forecast by George C. Miller, president of the Bakelite Company, a division of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.
GUATEMALA, Jan.3 -- Reports have reached here of clashes in Escuintla stemming from attempts to install a Communist in the Mayor's office.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Purchase for more than $4,000,000 of the Moraga Land Company, the principal asset of which was an area of 5,020 acres in Contra Costa, east of San Francisco Bay, has been announced by the Utah Construction Company.
DETROIT -- Highways, like the weather, apparently are something about which nearly everyone talks but about which little is done.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -The University of Maryland football team got a quiet reception today when it returned by plane from Miami.

The Library of Congress is one of the foremost research libraries in the world. It has been in the forefront of the movement toward the international exchange of information and the development of an effective International Copyright Convention. It has been the hub of a nation-wide system of inter-library loans, making its materials available to libraries and scholars needing them and borrowing in exchange materials to serve its own needs.
The United States "lost" more than $1,000,000,000 of gold last year -- and that's good.

From "Deep in the Heart of Texas" come our patterns today. They are by a young woman, born and schooled there. But, even though she lives there, coming north only occasionally to show her fashions, she is well known not only in New York but also throughout the country.

The National City Bank of New York's letter on business and economic conditions this month celebrates its fiftieth year of uninterrupted publication and does so with the dictum that 1953 was the most prosperous year in the nation's history.
So far as the bond market is concerned, the inflation-depression enigma confounding the postwar world was more perplexing in 1953 than ever before.
LOS ANGELES -- For the Pacific Southwest, 1953 is going down in the books as an economic year that was very good, but could have been better. The outlook: generally fair, with possible clouds.
ROME, Jan. 3 -- Premier Giuseppi Pella was still uncertain tonight that he could reshuffle his Cabinet and avoid resigning. An open Cabinet crisis thus remained possible.

Earl G. Orleman Jr., 21 years old, of Mariners Harbor, S. I., confessed early today, the police said, that he was a hit-and-run driver who had been sought since Christmas Eve when John M. Birmingham, 64, of New Brighton, S. I., was killed by a blue automobile.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Two Democrats ousted from membership on the War Claims Commission have invoked an ancient Anglo-Saxon legal procedure to challenge President Eisenhower's constitutional right to replace them with Republicans.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- If the stock markets did not exactly wind up 1953 in a blaze of glory, they were at least in a very cheerful mood.

The City Planning Commission, under John J. Bennett's chairmanship, is making progress on various fronts, and we are pleased to note one more evidence of this in its zoning revision that will hold the line against honkytonk invasion of the Times Square area.

The rate of production, generally regarded heretofore as determining this nation's prosperity, is being used less as an indication of the state of the economy. A newer school of thought holds that the rate of consumption is a greater factor in measuring the future economic well-being of the country.
Columbia University Press will publish thirty-two books this year, in addition to its regular list, in connection with the bicentennial celebration of the university.
The long-predicted adjustment in the domestic steel market finally arrived in the waning part of 1953, but the mills nevertheless established a new world production record for a single year.
The nation's savings and loan associations, which broke all previous growth records in assets, mortgage lending and savings last year, expect even larger gains in 1954.
DETROIT -- Automobile factories, already the most mechanized in any industry, are becoming more so.

The Greek Orthodox Church of the Annunciation, West End Ave-I nue and Eighty-fifth Street, has purchased the building of the Fourth Presbyterian Church, WestI End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Four top detectives have resigned in the last fortnight from Scotland Yard, which in theory is headquarters of London's police force but in practice is the nerve center for crime detection throughout Britain.

An apartment and store building, factory and parking lot occupying about 15,750 square feet on South Fourth and South Third Avenues in Mount Vernon, N. Y., have been sold by the Harpol Corporation to Galard Estates, an investment firm.

The cotton industry in the United States again is faced with a surplus problem. This stems mainly from the increase in production, which last year was the fourth largest on record, and a sharp decline in exports. The price-support activities of the Federal Government, however, prevented any serious price drop.
American manufacturers of rubber goods had a record year in 1953. They consumed more rubber than ever before and reached a new high peak in dollar sales, estimated at about $5,500,000,000.

Hashim Khan, 37-year-old Pakistan Air Force officer, met his match yesterday in Henri R. Salaun of Boston. Khan lost the first tournament match of his career as he bowed to Salaun in the final round of the first United States open squash racquets championship at the University Club.

BALTIMORE -- Buoyed by their 1953 levels, Baltimore business and industry are confidently expecting a busy and prosperous 1954 -- which seems virtually assured, if it only approximates the 1953 marks, the Baltimore Association of Commerce said in the December issue of its magazine Baltimore.
PARIS, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Tony Trabert, United States champion from Cincinnati, today was ranked first among the world's amateur players by Jacques Kauffman, French tennis expert.

TRENTON, Jan. 3 -- Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner today confirmed reports that he had asked Augustus C. Studer, Newark attorney, to make a surwey of the state's position in the Bergen County scandals.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Budgetary and financial problems, including the controversial subject of state aid to New York City and other local, subdivisions, are expected to be the principal points of contention in the legislative session that opens here on Wednesday.

The revenues of the nation's railroads reached a new high level last year. Despite the sharp slump in traffic in the last two months, operating revenue exceeded the previous peak of $10,581,418,000 in 1952 by an estimated $100,000,000.
A vast job remains to be done in the field of protecting the health of workers. An assertion to this effect is made in a report issued over the week-end by the American Institute of Management.
Bonds redeemed in 1953 before maturity dropped to $406,651,000 from $750,989,000 in 1952 and to the lowest total for any year since 1933, when $337,973,000 was redeemed.

Jet airliners of the British Overseas Airways Corporation will make a series of survey flights over the North Atlantic this year in preparation for trans-Atlantic jet service the company hopes to begin in the next two years.
OTTAWA, Jan. 3 -- The questioning of Mr. Gouzenko by members of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee under Canadian rules got off today to a bad start.

No new contracts in prospect for shipbuilding yards, employment rolls at vessel repair yards still on the decrease, and no concrete Government plans for relief for either of these industries -this is the dreary picture for 1954 that faces the country's private shipyards, L. R. Sanford declared yesterday.
Organized industry closed ranks yesterday for an all-out fight against any Administration moves to liberalize the TaftHartley Act.

DALLAS, Texas. -- Despite signs of moderate economic readjustment in the Dallas area and over the whole Eleventh Federal Reserve District, Dallas County closed the year 1953 with overall business activity at nearrecord levels.

The booming trend of "do-ityourself" sent paint sales to homeowners to near record totals in 1953. Emphasis on consumer selling in 1954 primarily will be to service the individual requirements of homeowners who are tackling the paint chore themselves, E. Albert Eckert, president of Sapolin Paints, Inc., declared.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -Lawmakers returning for the opening of Congress Wednesday will find the capitol spotlessly clean -- including the marble nose of Harry S. Truman, the former President.
A group of fourteen major tobacco distributors, growers and producers announced yesterday the formation of a Tobacco Industry Research Committee to study all phases of tobacco use.

As year-end figures were assembled, particularly those for the Christmas buying, it seemed certain that 1953 would be the second biggest in the alcoholic beverage business. Most production leaders believed that 1954 would be even better.
A birth rate almost up to the 1952 level helped bring the city's population to a new peak of 8,115,000, the Department of Health estimated in its annual report for 1953, issued last night.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- A political battle broke out today between California's principal liquor control "czar," William G. Bonelli, and the corporate interests headed by Norman Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times and The Los Angeles Mirror.

IT may be a long, long time before the United States again is faced with as glorious an opportunity in sports as confronted us last week. The Davis Cup was ours, wrenched from Australian hands. But the Aussies yanked it back again and so firm is their grip on it now that there is little chance of our regaining the treasured mug in the foreseeable future.

WASHINGTON -- The first New Year's Day under the new Republican Administration gave taxpayers something to celebrate, at least in a modest sort of way, but the outlook for additional relief in 1954 was cloudy.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 3 -French Union and Vietminh forces have begun to come to grips on the new Mekong River front. Flare-ups were reported today at three points as rival vanguards clashed about half-way between the French lines in the Savannakhet area and Vietminh positions south and east of Thakhek.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- State Department officials waited for word from Moscow today on how the Soviet Union wanted to start discussion of President Eisenhower's proposal for an international atomic energy pool.

United States foreign trade reached new highs in 1953. With imports and military aid the main factors, the value of goods exchanged reached $28,000,000,000. Commercial exports continued the downtrend of the previous year. This branch of trade faced further adjustment in 1954 to a situation that might be summed up with "less aid, less trade."

All aliens in the United States are required to register this month under the provisions of the Internal Security Act. The registration gets under way officially this morning, with forms available at all post offices and immigration branches.
William J. Mulligan, veteran city detective, is retiring after twenty-seven years on the force and will take a policing job on the waterfront.

The textile industry showed substantial production gains in 1953 in all categories except wool. But the steady decline in prices at the primary market level and sharp competition among sellers held profits in check.

HOUSTON, Tex. -- Although major business indexes showed significant declines in the last six months, Texas enjoyed a record business volume during 1953. However, the factors that brought about the declines are expected to remain throughout the early part of 1954.

The nation's aluminum industry, which established last year a production record that was 33 per cent higher than the previous one, has its sights trained on another record-shattering performance in 1954.

Cotton futures prices on the local market showed little activity last week. Final listings in uneventual dealings were 55 cents to $1.50 a bale higher. The hoilday-shortened session tended to keep traders on the sidelines.

HAVANA, Jan. 3 -- A trial of strength became evident today in the top echelon of El Mundo, one of Cuba's leading newspapers. The protagonists are Amadeo Barletta, president of the paper, a naturalized Cuban and formerly an Italian citizen, who is well known in Latin America, and Dr. Luis J. Botifoll, editor in chief.

The United States is not the only country where people are looking for help with marital problems. Throughout much of the world, Dr. David Mace said in an interview last week, people are "crying out for guidance."

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 2 (AP) -William G. Smith said today he plans to send out proxies to some 17,000 American Woolen Company stockholders asking for a vote against a company proposal to retire two sets of preferred stock and sell a number of inoperative mills.

Your Texas friend whose letter you quote in an editorial of Dec. 29 was lucky in that he was only a visitor to conditions he describes as existing in New York City. We who live and pay taxes in this community are no less impressed by the growing dirt and disorder and the apparent lack of concern on the part of those, Police and Sanitation, who are supposed to look after it.

M. Roger Auboin, managing director of The Bank for International Settlements (B. I. S.) at Basle, Switzerland, delivered a special lecture recently at St. Gall in which he lifted the curtain perceptibly on the affairs of that "bank for central banks" for the first time since the end of World War II.
PHILADELPHIA -- As expected, 1953 passed into history as a good year in the Philadelphia metropolitan district and no serious setback is expected this year, barring a severe nationwide recession.
PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., Jan. 3 (AP) -- A buffalo that roamed, but not far, was found today after a three-day search.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The economy of the West Coast moved to new high ground during 1953. This was despite the effects, which became more apparent toward the end of the year, of such developments as a tighter Federal spending policy, a growing resistance by consumers to buying, a low rate of mortgage commitments and, in some lines, the overaccumulation of inventories.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Officers of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers reversed their stand today and said that they would bargain on a national basis with 139 railroads for 30 per cent wage increases. The bargaining will start Wednesday in Chicago.
The famines and persecutions in some parts of the world are creating doubts in the minds of some churchgoers about the existence of God, the Rev. Dr. Ralph C. Walker said yesterday.

The first of a series of "spiritual awakening" meetings to celebrate the tercentenary of the beginning of Protestantism in Brooklyn was held yesterday afternoon at the South Bushwick Reformed Church, Bushwick Avenue and Himrod Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Robert Marjolin, Secretary General of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, warned Europe today against constant preoccupation with the possibility of a recession in the United States.
Tokyo, Monday, Jan. 4 (AP) -Cardinal Spellman left Tokyo today after relaying to the service men of the Far East a cabled message of blessing just received from Pope Pius XII.

CONGERS, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- An 11-year-old girl and her 16-yearold step-aunt drowned today when they broke through thin ice while skating on Swartout Lake. Ten persons who tried to rescue them had to be pulled one by one from the freezing water.
Calory-counting is often forgotten when holiday feasts offer temptations too great.

Reports from Tokyo indicate that Japan will, during the forthcoming year, make fresh efforts to reach an accommodation with some of her Asiatic neighbors. There is an increasing realization in Japan that the goals of recovery, even with large American assistance, are far from reached.
Scoring a 3-1 victory over the Trenton (N. J.) Americans at Sterling Oval yesterday, the New York Americans strengthened their hold on first place in the American Soccer League race.

Profits this year will not match the $20,300,000,000 earned by United States corporations in 1953. Third highest in American business history, this extraordinary result was achieved despite a tax bill of $24,600,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A State Department official said today that thousands who took part in the East German uprisings last June -- including women and children -- were reported to "have been seen loaded aboard trains headed for the Soviet Union."

The ferrous scrap metal industry furnished steel mills and foundries 32,000,000 gross tons of scrap metal last year, second only to the record 33,800,000 tons in 1951, yet ended the year in a state of depression not equaled since 1938.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Big Four High Commissioners in Germany or their representatives will meet here this week to select a site for the Jan. 25 conference of United States, British, Soviet and French Foreign Ministers, a United States spokesman said today.
DES MOINES, Iowa -- Business activity in the Missouri Basin states continued at record high levels during 1953, but there were signs that a buyer's market was developing.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 3 -- Jack Sutphen's Rum Dum from Larchmont finished sixth and second in the final two races today to win the three-day Manhasset Bay Yacht Club frostbite dinghy regatta with a score of 55 points for thirteen races, Sutphen captured the Sam Wetherill Trophy, the over-all prize in the Class B one-design and Interclub Classes.
The plastics industry set a record in 1953. It produced some 3,000,000,000 pounds of raw materials, an all-time high.
SEATTLE -- Alaska's military construction program was slowed during a crucial period last spring, when the Bureau of the Budget temporarily "froze" all major projects for restudy.
Three children from Alexandria, Va., were able to give the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund three extra dollars this year by going without a Christmas tree.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Eisenhower returned to Washington from Georgia tonight and re-established his headquarters at the White House. He will try to open a second front among the warring tribes of the new session of Congress Thursday.
Last January many gloomy prophets predicted nothing but disaster for the household electrical appliance industry in 1953. They were wrong.

The "idol" of objectivity and "a pale demon," of indifference standing behind it pose threats to the concept of a Christian college, the Rev. Gerald B. O'Grady, chaplain of Trinity College, Hartford, Conn., declared yesterday. He was guest preacher at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Eisenhower ended a ten-day working vacation at the Augusta National Golf Club and arrived in Washington tonight from Georgia in time for supper at the White House.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, announced today that the Water Pollution Control Board had approved plans for reducing water pollution in the Peconic River-Flanders Bay area just east of Riverhead, L. I.
Speedy action by the state to provide funds to help the city build sorely needed schools was urged yesterday by top officials of the Board of Education.

Fridrik Olafsson, 19-year-old player from Reykjavik, won his adjourned third-round game from Dr. S. G. Tartakower of France in seventy moves in the international chess masters' tournament at Hastings yesterday. According to a report from London, three sessions were needed to reach this result.
Sales of automobiles accounted for the major increase in consumer credit outstanding in 1953.
Investors bought and held more United States Savings bonds last year than at any time since the start of the Korean War in 1950.

The world's best-dressed woman in 1953 was Mrs. William Paley of New York, wife of the head of the Columbia Broadcasting System, according to an annual poll of fashion authorities by the New York Dress Institute. The results of the poll were announced yesterday.
Richard (Pancho) Gonzales returned to Madison Square Garden yesterday for the first time since he made his professional tennis bow there in October of 1949 and defeated Frank Sedgman of Australia.
Business courses for adults were more popular than ever in 1953 and the outlook is for the trend to continue.

Signet Key Books, a new imprint in the non-fiction pocket-sized book field, will appear Jan. 30 when it issues Louis Fisher's new approach to India's great leader, "Gandhi: His Life and Message for the World." The new imprint, being brought out by New American Library of World Literature, Inc., is designed to bring to the general reader low-priced books in the non-fiction field about the world and its peoples.

The Meal Alone It may be granted at once that during the eating of most meals it is good to have company. This is not at all the case of misery wishing to share with another, for meals obviously are among the greater pleasures of an all too worrisome life.
The Times of Dec. 29 carried a lead article featuring the forecasts of "top economists."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The United States is reported discussing military aid agreements with Iraq and Saudi Arabia as well as Pakistan and also a step-up in the flow of American weapons to Iran.

Jack Evans of the Ranger defense forces could not have picked a better time to develop his shooting eye than last night, when the Broadway Blues opposed the Canadiens of Montreal in Madison Square Garden.

An apartment house for twentyfour families on plot 125 by 100 feet at 136-16 222d Street, Laurelton, Queens, was sold by Laurelton Properties, Inc., to the Melarn Realty Corporation for investment in a deal negotiated by S. A. Shakin, broker.

Coaches and members of the tournament committee were at the Nassau Club in Princeton the other night talking about the week-end's games in the Lawrenceville School's invitation hockey tournament at Princeton's Hobey Baker Rink.

Credit men see stormy times ahead. The last four months of 1953 brought a definite rise in the number of financial embarrassments and bankruptcies, and paying experience in the retail, wholesale and manufacturing trades indicated that numerous small and medium-size companies were having difficulties in meeting their credit terms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- New facts about the profit experience and the investment practices of American business show that the Eisenhower Administration will have powerful leverage to sustain business investment and therefore total output and employment this year.

COLOR television's most exacting test came with the National Broadcasting Company's outdoor pick-up of the Tournament of Roses parade in Pasadena, Calif. The New Year's Day program was the first prolonged presentation of color video under circumstances where, unlike a studio show, neither lighting nor movement could be controlled. All things considered, the results were exceedingly good.
Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange increased last year, for 354,851,325 shares were traded, against 337,805.179 in 1952 and 443,504,076 in 1951. The 1950 total was 524,799,621 shares.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 4 -- Gen. John E. Hull, United Nations commander, said today he would not accept any proposal aimed at holding prisoners of the Korean war in neutral custody after Jan. 22.

The old International Longshoremen's Association announced last night that it would file formal charges with the National Labor Relations Board accusing Governor Dewey of unfair labor practices in the battle between rival waterfront unions here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- For the benefit of tidy people who like to know what day and week of the year it is, the United States Government and the United States Chamber of Commerce have produced a "calendar of special days, weeks and months of 1954."
The nation's paper and pulp industry reached new high production levels in 1953.

PAUL SMITHS, N. Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Robert Pidacks of Rumford, Me., led the contestants in the Federation Internationale de Ski cross-country tryouts today over a course at Paul Smith's College. Pidacks' time was 1 hour 11 minutes 1.3 seconds for 15 kilometers.
The return to competitive selling in one field after another is stressing the need for expanded market testing this year, says John E. Flynn, president of Selling Research, Inc.
" St. Andrew," a painting by El Greco that was brought to this country only recently, will be on public view in an exhibition opening Jan. 12 at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The largest dollar volume of business in its history was recorded in 1953 by the Blaw-Knox Company, equipment manufacturers, it was reported in a yearend statement by W. Cordes Snyder Jr., chairman and president.

LISBON, Portugal, Monday, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Nearly 27 per cent of Portugal's total budget this year will be allocated to defense, according to an official report issued by the Finance Ministry today.

Former Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri will be inducted as an associate justice of the Court of Special Sessions Thursday at noon in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street. Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper will preside.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 3 -- The press this morning carried full-page advertisements pleading for white men to go to work for good wages and good housing in a new area in the Orange Free State Province.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Football fans across the nation will be able to view the fourth annual Pro Bowl allstar game in Memorial Coliseum on Jan. 17, it was announced today.

In a new guise, "The ThreePenny Opera," based on the Bert Brecht version that emanated from the venerable "Beggar's Opera" of 1728, will come to life again. With a new book as well as lyrics provided by Marc Blitzstein, composer-librettist, the celebrated musical of a bygone era will arrive March 2 at the Theatre de Lys in Greenwich Village.
A judge's objection to sporting group show dogs that are beautiful but "soft" received exceptional emphasis at the specialty of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.

Aided by the discontinuance of wage and salary controls earlier in the year, profit-sharing plans rose substantially in 1953. Many concerns that had held plans in abeyance until controls were ended adopted them in the year.
A manufacturer who backed fair trade to the limit last year came up with the greatest profit in the history of his company. He is Emanuel Katz, president of Doeskin Products, Inc.

The United States extended its superiority in the production of electricity last year. This nation moved forward to the point where it now turns out more than 42 per cent of all electricity generated throughout the world.
The police agreed last night that it would be a long time before three New Jersey residents forgot their one-day spree here, which came to a climax in a police chase in the Times Square area.
ALTA, Utah, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Six Olympic skiers form a strong nucleus for a nine-member Alpine team selected today to represent the United States in the world championships at Are, Sweden, next month.

Plans for improving a blockfront on Eighth Avenue, just west of Times Square, with a large business building have been announced in connection with the sale of four four-story buildings on a plot 90 by 80 feet at the southeast corner of the avenue and West Forty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON -- Not long after Stanley N. Barnes became head of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice a lawyer asked him when he was "going to start dismissing cases."

The economic state of the nation is healthy. Some of the ills that had been predicted for 1953 never appeared till the latter part of the year. Business leaders, it would seem, scored a higher rating than the academic forecasters. It was a record-breaking year in many respects -- 61,900,000 persons working and saving $24,000,000,000. But it was the spenders that kept the economy rolling.
The nation's 5,200 manufacturers of women's and children's outer apparel, with sales volume in excess of $3,500,000,000, came through 1953 with no major mishap.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 3 -- A trade war has started between 1,600 chain grocery stores and the Association of Textile Retailers.
Secretary of State John Foster Dulles declared in a recorded radio broadcast last night that "peace and justice" would be "more secure" in 1954.

Shoe production in the United States during 1953 amounted to about 500,000,000 pairs, a decline from the 508,534,000 in 1952. This compares with the peak of 529,000,000 reached in 1946. Last year military shoe production reached 3,000,000 pairs, a drop of 70 per cent from the preceding twelve months.

Ambassador Bohlen's call on Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov to ask how the Soviet Union wishes to begin negotiations with regard to atomic energy stresses once again the urgency the Eisenhower Administration attaches to this matter. It is now almost a month since the President delivered his historic address to the United Nations and two weeks since the Soviet reply, but apparently no negotiations have taken place.

Ernest Ansermet conducted the C. B. S. Radio Orchestra yesterday afternoon in the first concert of the Columbia Broadcasting System's Twentieth Century Concert series, given in connection with bi-centennial of Columbia University, in the McMillin Theatre.
