CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Trading in grain futures last week was of the usual holiday character, many of the transactions being made for income tax purposes. There was much selling by operators who had held their grain futures six months or more, and also much evening up by shorts.
" Clear sailing" is the outlook for the sulphur industry in 1954.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- Several thousand persons crowded into the Philadelphia Museum of Art today for the first day of a two-month exhibition of 200 oils and drawings of the renowned Dutch artist, Vincent Van Gogh.
Last year was one of victories for fair trade.

WASHINGTON -- The Eisenhower Administration, after scoring appreciable gains in its first eleven months and eleven days in office, was still pursuing the elusive goal of a balanced budget as the new year came into being.

DANVILLE, Va. -- Tobacco growers in the flue-cured district of Virginia and North Carolina are closing the most disastrous season in many years. The auction season has closed in what is known as the Old Belt, where is produced the cream of cigarette tobaccos and mahogany wrappers used by the cigar trade.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 3 -- (UP) -- Russian skiers took one surprised look at the chairlifts and hilltop bars of this winter sports paradise today and said skiing in the capitalist western world seems to be "nothing but an amusement."

The seasonal pattern of business-loan volume was reversed last year. The normal seasonal decline of the early spring months failed to develop and conversely, the usual fall expansion was less than expected.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -Senator William F. Knowland today welcomed constructive discussion of economic conditions in the coming Congress but warned against talking "ourselves into an economic sag."
ZURICH, Jan. 3 -- The Bank Deutscher Laender last week made a number of unexpected concessions to pre-war foreign creditors whose claims were not included in the London debt agreement for settlement.

Records were set last year in the domestic oil industry. Crude oil output reached a new peak and the demand for oil products was 5 per cent above the record established in 1952. Refinery operations were at a new high level.

Seymour Bernstein, young Newark pianist whose career was interrupted by a term of military service, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. It was a debut that sometimes flashed brilliantly and yet was often disappointing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Congressional hunt for spies in Government got a shot in the arm today on the basis of a report that a former high functionary of the Communist party in the United States was "about ready to talk."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -The House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities indicated today it might turn its investigators loose on Communist propaganda publications in the United States.

The threat of communism in the Far East must be met at the "grass roots level with food, health, faith and youth," Dr. Paul Rusch, director of the Kiyosato Educational Experiment Project in Japan, declared yesterday.

New Year's Eve observances by ship charter experts assumed the proportions of a wake, although 1953, with its declining rates, was not mourned except in comparison with the gloomy future forecast for 1954.
Theatre representatives joined last night in paying tribute to Jose Ferrer for his achievements during the drama season of the New York City Center.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 -- Mme. Aruna Asaf Ali, widow of free India's first Ambassador to the United States, was elected to the Central Committee of the Indian Communist party today. She is the only woman member of the party's high command.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- European economic circles are considering the prospects of the new year as an mmense question mark. Especially they wonder what 1954 will bring regarding trade relations between the East and the West.

This department turns with pleasure to Darrell Huff's delightful "How to Lie With Statistics."* It is hard to think of a form of statistical skull duggery that he has not laid bare. And he names the culprits.

In a world sharply divided between the free and the enslaved, partitioned by an opaque, impervious curtain against passage of men or ideas, Columbia University is opening a year-long celebration of its 200th anniversary, built around the theme of "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof."

Labor pushed hourly wage rates up in 1953, but weekly pay envelopes got thinner under the impact of skidding work schedules at the end of the year. Union leaders entered 1954 with fear that unemployment would double or triple before the year was out.
The easier money market that developed late in 1953 is likely to continue well into 1954.

HONG KONG, Monday, Jan. 4 -- A 44-year-old China-born American business man, lame and near-sighted from beri-beri, arrived yesterday from three years in a Shanghai jail. He said other Americans still were held there He did not know how many.
BOSTON -- New England closed the books on 1953 at a high level of industrial activity but with definite signs of a period of belttightening ahead.
The basic problem of savings banks in 1953 and in prospect during 1954 is that of equalizing competitive conditions among the various thrift institutions.
CHICAGO -- Middle West business and financial leaders found no justification at the close of 1953 for earlier fears of an abrupt end of expansion following the Korean war boom.
The Rev. Hugh McCandless decried yesterday the "religious segregation" of Puerto Ricans in New York and called it "dangerous expensive, un-Christian and unnecessary."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The wrangle over Theodore Roosevelt Island grew hotter as a former Ambassador questioned today the right of the District of Columbia to build a bridge over the island.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Navy's leaders believe the United States is still years away from an atomic-powered submarine with true offensive capabilities.

The United States badly needs a program of highway safety based on improving the ability to drive, rather than on a technological advancement of vehicles and roads, Paul H. Blaisdell, director of the traffic safety division of the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies, said in a year-end statement.

Insurance men can be optimistic about the long-range prospects for service to the American public, John A. Diemand, president of the Insurance Company of North America, said in a year-end review of his company's business.
Air transportation, the scheduled lines and the business flier, seem definitely in 1953 to have solved the old dilemma that long perplexed management.

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- John G. W. Husted, a retired banker, declared war today upon a pack of dogs, apparently "Alsatians," which he said attacked and "tore to ribbons" his 11-yearold cocker spaniel last Tuesday. The incident occurred while he was walking the pet on the rolling 100 acres of his estate, David's Brooks, on Bedford Centre Road.

Shareholders of General Dynamics Corporation were notified by a letter from John Jay Hopkins, president and chairman, over the week-end, that consolidated sales and earnings for 1953 were the largest in history. He said that sales approximated $190,000,000, a gain of 40 per cent over 1952, and earnings should top those of the year before.
Never before was the division between blue chips and white chips, between popular favorites and wallflowers, more pronounced than in the 1953 stock market.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings moved into sole possession of first place in the National Hockey League standing tonight as they battled the Toronto Maple Leafs to a scoreless deadlock before 12,959 fans at the Olympia.

DETROIT -- The automobile industry produced 7,370,000 cars, trucks and buses in 1953 for the second best Production year in its history. It was exceeded only by 1950 when 8,003,056 units were produced.
Schuyler Forbes Baldwin makes the familiar but inaccurate charge of tax subsidy against T. V. A. in his letter published in The Times Dec. 23.

Guido Cantelli made his third appearance of the season conducting the N. B. C. Symphony yesterday at its regular 6:30 to 7:30 concert, which was broadcast from Carnegie Hall. The program consisted of Three Pieces by Frescobaldi and the Franck Symphony.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Premier Joseph Laniel asked today for a special session of the National Assembly Wednesday either to give him a vote of confidence or to put his resignation into effect. There was uncertainty in French political circles on how the National Assembly would react.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -The major motion picture companies and the Screen Extras Guild have agreed to a 5 per cent increase in daily wage scales, it was announced today jointly by the union and the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

Public offerings of new bonds by underwriters here rose sharply in 1953 over recent years, while equity financing declined. Bond flotations of $8,909,400,000 were the largest in twenty-seven years. Stock offerings of $695,570,000 were the smallest since 1950.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Foyle's of Charing Cross Road, called the biggest bookshop in the world, celebrates its fiftieth anniversary this week. At a luncheon Thursday, Foyle's, which is known to thousands of United States tourists as a fascinating place to browse in London, will commemorate its origin as a two-man part-time enterprise.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association, which nearly fell apart a few years ago because of an effort to put "teeth" into its regulations, will try to sprout a few new incisors this week.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- The 1954 Legislature will be asked to expand an experimental state program that has transformed into law-abiding citizens more than 200 boys who were previously considered hopeless juvenile delinquents.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. -- For the South, last year was marked by one major soft spot -- a decline in farm income -- but the maintenance of record-breaking factory employment and steady gains in consumer savings helped round out generally a good year for the section's burgeoning economy.

The nation's railroads financed the acquisition of more than $600,000,000 of new equipment last year, according to a survey by Salomon Bros. Hutzler, a bond house which specializes in such investments.
A fourteen-point legislative program geared to the slogan "Victory in '54" was announced yesterday by Richard H. Balch, chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 3 -The Government of Ceylon plans to put an end to foreign subsidizing of Communist propaganda by tightening exchange controls. This will prevent Communists in Ceylon from receiving money from Communist sources abroad.

THE Golden Age for mineralogists in the city has passed but you still find in this delightful cult men who mined Manhattan's rich deposits before pavements, skyscrapers and soaring dwellings buried most of their quarrying grounds.
WASHINGTON -- The record spoke volumes in 1953. Such as:

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- The French Navy must put 33,000 tons of fighting ships into service annually until 1960 to maintain its present strength, the Ministry of the Navy estimated today in its annual report on the French fleet.
The nation's Cinderella fuel -natural gas -- maintained its position in 1953 as one of the fastestgrowing industries.
The nation's copper industry, with four highly prosperous years behind it, faced some disquieting trends as the new year began.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Senator William E. Jenner, chairman of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, arrived in Canada today for a much-publicized secret interview with Igor Gouzenko.
The beginning of 1954 finds most of the strategic metals in adequate supply for present defense and civilian needs. Outstanding exceptions are nickel and titanium.

Arnold Toynbee, British historian, warned yesterday that the modern world was progressing toward its own extinction by following the ancient Greek devotion to the state as the highest form of human organization.

The year 1953, which opened the second decade of the Atomic Age, marked a transition from military to peaceful application of atomic energy. The current decade should achieve successful power plants for running the wheels of industrial civilization.
Group and one-man shows, some thirty in all, are opening the new year in local art galleries.

SEATTLE -- The Pacific Northwest states -- Washington, Oregon, Idaho and Montana -- continued to grow in population and business activity during 1953. However, some lines were adversely affected by local and national conditions.
Investments of the nation's $78,600,000,000 life insurance industry in 1953 continued to follow the trend of recent years, in contrast with holdings at the end of World War II.

In its anxious concentration on France, American public opinion tends to overlook the other threats to the European Defense Community. It should be borne in mind that the program for European unity, though originally a French plan and believed to be supported by the majority of the people in the member nations, is regarded in Europe as essentially American policy.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- D. C. Keisacker of Miami won the international freefor-all in the Venice of America regatta today when the three Italian favorites were plagued with motor trouble.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Eisenhower's official steel engraving now is on sale, and for once this project did not cause the Bureau of Engraving and Printing at the Treasury any trouble.

The expanded activities of the New York Tow Boat Exchange and the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York have resulted in the creation of the new post of executive vice president in each of these trade organizations.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter from Gen. John E. Hull, United Nations Commander, to Lieut. Gent. K. S. Thimayya of India, chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission:
When the temperature in the living room drops the automatic clock thermostat clicks on and the furnace goes into action. The temperature rises, the thermostat clicks off and the furnace stops.

Because most banks are up to their limits on extending credit to the specialized finance industry, the latter's 1954 loans to business are apt to show only small gains, according to Theodore H. Silbert, president of the Standard Factors Corporation.
Last year the New York Stock Exchange heeded Thomas Jefferson's behest not to wait too long between revolutions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A person who makes a genuine escape from persecution behind the Iron Curtain can count on a warm welcome and physical care in the West and a good chance to emigrate to the United States.

For those who chose leg of lamb for their week-end roast, lamb-stuffed green peppers will provide a pleasant "second helping." Lamb is among the good buys now listed by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The novel features of the Philharmonic-Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall Saturday evening, conducted by Franco Autori, were the first performance in this city of a movement from Tadeusz Kassern's Concerto for String Orchestra, and the performance by Jacob Lateiner, the pianist, then making his first public appearance since his return from three years' service in the Army, of the Prokofieff Third Concerto.

Coal gas killed a 71-year-old man and sickened ten other tenants at 378 East 165th Street, near Clay Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday. The police reported that gas from a defective basement heating system had seeped through a wing of the five-story apartment house.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 3 -- Seven hundred Haitian dignitaries, foreign diplomats and distinguished guests dined tonight at Sans Souci Palace, where Haiti's Negro King, Henri Christophe, dreamed 150 years ago of world power and a great Negro civilization.

Pension planning went forward to new heights in 1953, with the number of plans in effect reaching a new high record, and the number of employes covered by them setting a new peak. Progress was made also in revision of long-established programs, to give participants in them greater benefits.

Retail sales volume in 1954 should be about 5 per cent below 1953, according to B. R. Gordon, executive vice president and secretary of Rich's, Inc., in Atlanta. Profit percentage could be better because of the increased emphasis on expense control, he felt.

There was a lively controversy last year on the question whether the old-age and survivors' insurance tax should be increased in 1954. Agreement was general, however, that social security benefits should be extended to persons not already covered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had dropped charges against three major soap manufacturers accused of price discrimination and favoritism in the use of advertising allowances.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Arthur Longsjo Jr., of Pittsfield, Mass., today won his second Glens Falls Winter Carnival speed-skating championship in a skate-off against Alex Goguen, also of Pittsfield.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The economy-minded Eisenhower Administration faces the prospect of asking Congress for more money to support farm prices.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 3 -- Although President Eisenhower's announcement of Dec. 26 that two United States infantry divisions would soon be withdrawn from Korea has been temporarily overshadowed by the unexpected return of an American pro-Communist prisoner of war, the issue has remained very much alive here in the local press.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 3 (AP) -Hjalmar Andersen, Norway's Olympic triple champion of 1952, captured the Norwegian speedskating championship for the fourth time today by winning the final race on the program.

Railroad and bus terminals here were thronged with travelers yesterday as the ten-day holiday period ended. There were crowds in the station concourses and waiting rooms, and in the surrounding streets automobiles moved bumper-to-bumper.
Two new films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Alert professional money management will be able to serve investors more efficiently under a progressive return to a "more realistic economy" in 1954, according to Robert W. Purcell, chairman of Investors Diversified Services. Inc.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 3 -- A 7-year-old girl died here last night in a fire started in her home by a playmate of her older sister.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Carl Braun's two quick baskets in the last minute gained a 74-72 victory for the New York Knickerbockers over Fort Wayne in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

Dollarwise, 1954 will be the biggest yet for industrial advertising with an estimated total of $800,000,000, Blaine G. Wiley, executive secretary of the National Industrial Advertisers Association, predicts. About 46 per cent of this total, he estimates, will be expended for space in business papers. The 1953 total was $760,000,000.

From "start to finish" the New Testament proves that man can "break away from his past," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken said yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
March of Dimes checks totaling $328,562 have been sent to nine iron lung centers in eight states as the first portion of their 1954 allotments from the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

All signs indicate a recordbreaking year for the men's wear field in 1954. Stocks at the yearend were in excellent shape, the consumer demand was expected to be large because the soft goods field was neglected during 1953 and new fibers were creating a stir in the industry.

Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov"; Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," and Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" will receive their first performances of the season during the Metropolitan Opera's ninth week. Lily Pons will be heard in the title role of the Donizetti work.
This country's steel industry started 1954 with an annual production capacity of 124,330,410 net tons -- a new record high and an increase of 6,782,940 during 1953.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -Two organizations challenged today the effectiveness of a Government housing program recommended by President Eisenhower's special advisory committee last month.

New York was a generally healthy place to live in 1953, and the news as to tuberculosis was extraordinarily good. Dr. John F. Mahoney, who moves out of the post of Health Commissioner but is remaining in the department, notes a 21 per cent drop in the death rate from tuberculosis in the last year.

Business of the American Stock Exchange -- which changed its name from New York Curb Exchange on Jan. 5, 1953 -- faded slightly in the year just ended. Stock volume was 102,378,937 shares, against 106,237,657 in 1952 and 111,629,218 in 1951.

In a rebuke to persons who "make free and easy use of the sacred name of Jesus," Msgr. William T. Greene charged yesterday that this occurred "particularly on the stage and in novels to achieve a bogus realism."
DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 3 -- The emergence of practical political freedom, with a subsequent decline in Islamic influence in political life, has begun in Pakistan.

NEW DELHI, -- India, Jan. 3 -- Diplomatic circles here believe that Indian envoys in all Asian, Middle Eastern and British Commonwealth countries are actively stirring up propaganda against the projected United States military aid to Pakistan.
Here is the time schedule under which the Government plans to dispose of its twenty-seven synthetic rubber producing facilities to private industry:

EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan 3 (AP) -- Michigan State's triumphant Rose Bowl football team received a thunderous welcome tonight as more than 5,000 persons crowded the Lansing Airport to welcome the squad plane which set down at 8:10 P. M. The Spartans beat U. C. L. A., 28 -- 20.
DES MOINES, Iowa -- The nation's farmers during 1953 were subjected to rising operating costs, a 10 per cent decline in crop prices, and a drought.

Harry Zaratzian, one of the viola players in the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, gave his second Town Hall recital late yesterday afternoon. Artur Balsam was his accompanist; for Handel's Concerto Grosso in G minor, the soloist also had the assistance of a string quartet.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Britain's sea defenders stood on the alert tonight as a combination of gales and high tides threatened a possible repetition of last winter's flood disasters on the English east coast.
The home furnishings industry, excluding its dynamic electronic and appliance segments, did rather better than expected last year.

ROME, Jan. 4 -- The office of Clemente Cardinal Micara, the Pope's vicar for Rome, ordered Roman Catholic bookshops and libraries in his diocese today to remove from their shelves the successful new Italian book, "The Devil."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- An acute shortage of capital, caused mainly by the drying up of foreign investment and a further fall in the profitability of gold mining, hampered both the internal development and foreign trade of the Union of South Africa last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP)-- Four Washington State Representatives protested today against a Foreign Operations Administration decision to allow Canadian mills to bid on an order for 10,000,000 board feet of lumber.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court, in its action today, turned back the three-year-old "housewives' revolt."

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 4 -- The Hudson County Grand Jury noted with regret today that a state statute requiring competitive bidding in municipalities for contracts exceeding $1,000 had been flouted but that nothing could be done about it because the law "lacks teeth."

The report of the fact-finding committee in the dispute between the Publishers Association of New York City and Local 1 of the Photo - Engravers Union, A.F.L,. has been delayed by the illness of the panel chairman, Ralph T. Seward.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- In the United States Supreme Court today, the following proceedings were had:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Treasury showed an extra, unexpected deficit of $160,000 today and charged it to a thief, identity unknown.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, indicated today that Britain would like to increase her trade with Communist China after the Berlin four-power conference and settlement of a Korean peace.
PARIS -- France succeeded in 1953 in increasing the rhythm of building and reconstruction which had lagged since the liberation. The faster trend is expected to gather momentum in 1954.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., outlined today a program which, it predicted, would set the pattern for a C. I. O.-wide drive throughout heavy industry for a guaranteed annual wage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Institute of Life Insurance today announced approval by the Internal Revenue Service of a plan under which employers may invest part of the funds of tax-exempt profit-sharing retirement plans in ordinary life insurance policies.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Dewey will urge the 1954 Legislature to establish a new program for detecting and treating mental illness. It would go far beyond any mental health services provided by the state in the past.

Directors of the Missouri Public Service Company have approved a dividend of 45 cents a share on the common stock, payable on March 12, it was announced yesterday. This was an increase of 50 per cent.

ROME -- Italian industrial production in 1952 was barely able to maintain the positions it had achieved in the boom year of 1951. In the first nine months of 1953 production jumped to the highest level in Italian history.
BONN, Germany -- West German agriculture had another record year in 1953 but it is still confronted with serious problems, according to Dr. Heinrich Luebke, Federal Minister for Food and Agriculture.

MONROVIA, Liberia -- Ever since 1926 when the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company came to this little African republic and planted the largest single rubber plantation in the world, Liberia's fortunes have tended to bounce with the rubber market. Last year was no exception.

VIENNA -- It always has been difficult to estimate the economic progress of post-war Bulgaria. Even when her five-year plan was first adopted at the beginning of 1949 no specific goals were mentioned, except that the relation between industry and agriculture was to be changed from 30-70 at the end of 1948 to 47-53 in 1953, and the relation between light and heavy industry from 70-30 at the end of 1948 to 55-45.

ROME -- In 1953, Italian foreign trade had its second bad year in succession. The outlook improved slightly in the third quarter and at the beginning of fourth quarter. In October total exports reached $137,600,000, the highest monthly figure of 1952 and 1953.

Winter has come to Main Streets everywhere in these latitudes, bringing with it winter twilights. Twilight, the dictionary says, is the light from the sky when the sun is below the horizon, especially in the evening.

TOKYO -- An able economist recently took a long, hard look at Japan's economy and came up with the conclusion that the Japanese were living in a "fool's paradise." His observation coincides substantially with those of both foreign and Japanese experts concerned with this nation's financial well-being.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Harry J. O'Donnell, Governor Dewey's executive assistant, accused Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, today of attempting to "smear" the Republican State Administration by innuendo.

TOKYO -- The textile industry has been one of the most important in Japan for the last twenty-eight years, mostly because of exports to Southeast Asia. The industry reached its peak just prior to World War II. It declined sharply after Japan's defeat and then built up to another very high level after the outbreak of war in Korea. But the industry seems once again on a down-grade.

The police averted on Sunday night a fight involving a hundred boys and girls that had been started by two girls, members of rival clubs, over a boy friend. Partisans of each girl's club gathered on a Brooklyn street corner, some armed with bottles, when the police stopped hostilities.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Two University of Toronto students detained by Immigration authorities since Saturday for investigation of Communist activities were ordered released today. An Immigration official said it was "a case of mistaken identity."

In a letter you published Dec. 23 the writer, a Eustace Mullins, protests "the latest proposed atrocity, the destruction of Patchin Place in Greenwich Village," as part of what he calls "the steady decline of New York City in recent years."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 4 -- Pushing out northeast of Luang Prabang, French Union troops have launched a new clean-up drive against Vietminh-led guerrilla groups in the forested hills and valleys of Laos between the Namhou Valley and the Tranninh Plateau.

From all indications, 1954 should be a big year for prints. Many designers have emphasized them in showings of resort lines, which usually give a forecast of what will be offered in the spring. A brief look around the fabric market showed many varied prints on display.

Three events dominated Russian economic development in 1953 the coming to power of the first post-Stalin Government, the explosion of the first Soviet hydrogen bomb and the introduction of a new economic policy aimed at giving consumers a little more of the national product.

Abolition of the public school system in the South, would bring "racketeers" into education, Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, declared yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 4 -- Ronald Friedman, 13 years old, who admitted setting a fire that killed a girl neighbor in her lakeview, L. I., home late Saturday night, was arraigned here this afternoon in Nassau County Children's Court. Meanwhile, the victim, Doris Kane, 7, was being buried at a Long Island cemetery.

PARIS -- For the period beginning July 1, 1953, and up to the end of 1954, United States aid to the French balance of payments has been estimated to amount to more than a billion dollars, not including receipts from exports or the funds obtained from tourists of the dollar zone.

CAIRO, Jan. 4 -- The Egyptian Government has given the Turkish Ambassador to Cairo twenty-four hours in which to leave the country because of actions and statements hostile to Egypt attributed to him.
Kentucky held its No. 1 spot in the United Press basketball ratings yesterday, but both Indiana and Duquesne were closing in on Coach Adolph Rupp's Wildcats.
Avco Manufacturing Corporation announced yesterday that a sale of appliances on a large scale will begin on Thursday.

CAIRO, Egypt -- By a policy of self-denial and retrenchment Egypt surmounted serious economic difficulties last year and entered 1954 in search of means and methods to produce the general economic development that is imperative for survival.
Spring, in the form of a colorful wallpaper exhibition, has arrived early this year in the gallery of America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was reported tonight to have given private assurances to highly placed Administration officials that he would reduce his concentration on alleged subversive persons in Government and reach into other fields of investigative activity this year.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Jan. 4 -- This city, the hope and the reflected image of all Israel, is floundering in a financial quagmire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The current efforts of the Administration, and its supporters in opposing the Bricker Amendment, to reach a "compromise" with the backers of the proposal are badly constricted by the fact that the principal point at issue cannot be compromised.

MANILA -- The California Texas Oil Company is investing about $30,000,000 in a refinery that is under construction in Batangas province, Luzon, south of Manila. It is expected to be completed in the autumn or early winter of 1954.

BONN, Germany -- Sometime in the late spring of 1954 West Germany will have replaced the 2,500,000 homes destroyed during World War II. With the completion of 475,000 housing units in 1953 -- 25,000 units more than in 1952 -- the total number of housing units built or rebuilt since 1945 will be 2,375,000, just 125,000 short of closing the gap cut by the war.
In your issue of Dec. 13 there was a report on the situation of the Jews in Damascus.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- Sweden's economy was relatively stable in 1953. The comparatively high wage level in industry did not have the adverse effect on exports feared in business circles at the end of 1952.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- President Eisenhower and his Republican Congressional leaders today had a final discussion of the legislative program that he will ask of the second session of the Eighty-third Congress. The session opens Wednesday.
One group of New Year's celebrants found it fitting to mark the good time they had by sending a gift to the forty-second annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Mayor Wagner gave the City's Certificate of Merit to Jose Ferrer yesterday in recognition of the actor-director's contributions to the successful drama season of the New York City Center that ended on Sunday night.
Events tonight: "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera; Earl Wild, pianist, Town Hall, both at 8:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted five individuals and five corporations today on charges of conspiracy to defraud in the purchase of surplus cargo ships from the Government after World War II.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The per annum interest date on the ninety-one-day Treasury bills offered each week dropped tonight to 1.314 per cent.

DUBLIN, Ireland -- Two important factors in Ireland's fiscal position at the end of 1953 give cause for satisfaction. The first is the reduction of the external payments deficit from 62,000,000 ($174,220,000) in 1951 to 9,000,000 ($25,290,000) in 1952, an improvement maintained throughout 1953.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Free world controls on trade in strategic items with the Soviet Union have been tightened in general in the last five months. At the same time, control of certain items no longer considered strategic has been relaxed, Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration, said today.

The Italian national Legislature will be asked by A.N.I.C.A. (the National Association of Motion Picture and Allied Industries of Italy) to pass a bill requiring film houses to increase the minimum playing time allocated to Italian films, from the present eighty days to 120 days, according to information received here by Italian Films Export.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- This year may provide a preliminary double test in Yugoslavia of her Socialist policies and a number of practical free-marketing measures adopted from the Western democracies.

TEL AVIV, Israel -- The artificial boom of the first four years of Israel's statehood was only a memory in 1953. Unemployment reached a record, retail turnovers slumped and everyone felt the impact of a money shortage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that buying on credit increased only $86,000,000 during November. That was the smallest increase since last February. It was the fifth month in a row when the public cut its credit buying sharply.
CAIRO -- The return of West Germany to a position among the leading trading nations in the Middle East was the most noteworthy development in the economic life of the area in 1953.
The following is the text of Governor Dewey's address yesterday at the formal opening of Columbia University's Bicentennial on the university campus:
Former President Harry S. Truman will make two television appearances within the next few days.

ALTHOUGH no statistics are available that tabulate the number of modern novels about the growing pains of sensitive adolescent boys, no one who tries to keep abreast of the current of new fiction would doubt that such novels outnumber all others except reworkings of the stories of Cinderella and Jack the Giant Killer. They are so common that novelists who refrain from writing them ought to be rewarded with a special citation.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- With her remarkable resilience, the Netherlands has overcome the effects of the flood of last February.

TRENTON, Jan. 4 -- Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner disclosed here today that he was having difficulty in selecting a Cabinet of "capable men" willing to serve in the new Democratic Administration. For this reason, he explained, it is quite likely that his Cabinet will not be completed until after his inauguration on Jan. 19.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- Northern Ireland's recovery from the linen trade's slump in 1952 was sustained, and, though the shadow of under-development remained, the general level of industrial activity was high. Unemployment fell month by month to 30,000, about 6 per cent of the working population, but rose seasonally in November.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles undoubtedly will discuss President Eisenhower's proposal for an international atomic energy pool with the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, Britain and France when he meets them in Berlin Jan. 25.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- It should be possible, in theory, to furnish a home by confining selections to those shown in an exhibit here. The exhibit, which opened yesterday, is called "Good Design" and is sponsored by (and housed in) the Merchandise Mart.
PARIS, Jan. 4 -- At the forthcoming Berlin conference of the Big Four foreign ministers, the Soviet Union will insist that a unified Germany be neutral and not "involved in any military bloc."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- As in the Union of South Africa, a keen demand for capital developed in the new British Central Africa Federation, where considerable economic development is planned. The first federal elections, on Dec. 15, were fought largely on creating a racial pattern that would encourage investment from Britain and the United States.
BERLIN -- Stimulated by massive injections of United States aid, West Berlin's economy leaped ahead in 1953, although it lagged far behind that of the German Federal Republic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that domestic cotton use is showing a 5 per cent decline from last year and predicted a post-World War II record of about 9,600,000 surplus bales will be left over at the end of the season.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- The Soviet Union cleared the way for a Big Four conference in Berlin with a brief note today acknowledging the West's agreement to a meeting on Jan. 25 of foreign ministers on the German question.

On various occasions through the years, in editorial or special article, Anna M. Kross has been described in this newspaper as a "unique and distinguished woman jurist, whose ability, example and integrity have made her a civic symbol" and as an appointee honored by three city administrations.

James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, returned yesterday from Florida and is expected to meet here this week with Al Weill, manager of heavyweight champion Rocky Marciano, to select an opponent for Rocky in a match during the winter.

REYJKAVIK, Iceland -- Iceland's imports surpassed the billion kronur mark for the first time in 1953, and the value of the country's export's were about equal to the 1951 record of 726,000,000 kronur ($44,576,400).
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- World production in key raw materials added up in 1953 to what experts here call a "big year."

Most college basketball coaches frown upon the zone defense. Johnny Bach, the young Fordham mentor, is not an exception. However, when he deemed it a "must," Bach ordered his Rams to discard the man-for-man type of guarding against New York University at the Maroon gymnasium last night and what had been a close battle developed into a runaway, 87-60 victory over the Violets.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Governor Dewey will hold a hearing Jan. 12 on applications for clemency for three men condemned to die for the hold-up murder of a Reader's Digest magazine messenger.
The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation increased its sales in the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30 to a new high of $478,697,891 from the previous year's volume of $358,400,502.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver charged tonight that Administration officials and lobbyists were "working hand-in-glove" to undermine the public power program.
Columbia University formally opened yesterday the year-long celebration of its 200th birthday.

An increase of one-third in commutation fares is being sought by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. The line filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Com mission in Washington yesterday, asking for the rise on all interstate and New York State commuter tickets.

LONDON -- Strikes and other labor difficulties massed like storm clouds on the horizon as last year ended, but the over-all economic result of 1953 in Britain was one of expanding economic freedom and a rise in general prosperity.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark -- Last year was a good one for the Danish economy, but toward the year-end unfavorable indications began to appear.
LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 4 -- The Linden High School, a junior high school and a primary grade school were closed here at noon today as a result of a wage dispute.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Floods and wind-whipped blizzards pounded northern Germany. Parts of Scandinavia, England and the lowlands today in winter's worst onslaught of the season.

Forty-seven local housing authorities with subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration will receive bids next Tuesday on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $207,106,000. The notes will mature variously from Feb. 4 to Nov. 5.

International advertising during 1953 totaled about $200,000,000 and a number of factors now existing portend a continuance of this high level in 1954. In fact, some quarters feel that billings will increase by about 25 per cent this year.

New York City is welcoming an invasion of retail buyers in numbers far above expectations. In the first two days of the week more than 2,300 poured into the metropolis, according to a tabulation by the arrival of buyers department of The New York Times.

Starting next Saturday, thirty mentally retarded children from 7 to 16 years old will take part in a recreation program each Saturday from 9 A. M. to 4 P. M. at the Allegro Day School, 718 West 178th Street. The program is under the sponsorship of the Parents Association for Children with Retarded Mental Development and is the first program of its kind for children who attend such classes in the public schools.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 5 -- The South Korean Government today hailed the decision of the United Nations commander, Gen. John E. Hull, that all prisoners of the Korean war who have refused repatriation must be set free after Jan. 22.

LONDON, Jan 4 -- Prices moved aimlessly on the stock markets here today, the continuing threat of labor trouble making for some hesitancy. However, small gains outnumbered losses and most groups were basically firm.
Engines of advanced design and of increased horsepower and a new hardtop car with transparent roofing are among the improvements in the Ford Motor Company's 1954 line.

NEW DELHI, India -- Although still lagging behind her ambitious targets and beset by a new problem of widespread unemployment, India made encouraging economic and financial progress last year. The most significant achievement was an unusually favorable food position, largely as the result of good weather.

ALTHOUGH there is a wide interest in shooting game birds introduced from Europe and Asia, many sportsmen are now stressing the importance of increasing native game birds, such as the wild turkey, rather than spending large sums on experiments with new exotic breeds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Navy plans to keep the world's first atomic submarine submerged for two months or more at a time in tests. The research will cover underwater speed and pressure problems.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Richmond tonight nailed down a berth in the class A. A. A. International League when the City Council agreed to make municipally owned Parker Field available as a home park for the team.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand -- New Zealand had continued prosperity in 1953 and there was every prospect the condition would go on in 1954. But it will be a period of intense preparation for big marketing changes that will profoundly affect the country's future.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- One of the most debated questions in the new legislative session that will start Wednesday will be whether the state should turn over more of its tax revenue to cities and other local government units.

MADRID -- Spain ended the 1953 calendar year with a fiscal deficit of $260,000,000 as the result of floating new Government securities and state-guaranteed bonds for autonomous entities, and for municipalities and provinces.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's radio and television report to the nation last night as recorded by The New York Times:

Logic and consistency do not appear to be the strong points of the old International Longshoremen's Association. Otherwise its leadership would not minimize the racket problem and at the same time announce a plan to engage a "crime buster" to clean up the union.

CINCINNATI Jan. 4 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association executive committee today approved in principle a plan to reorganize its baseball tournament along the lines used in the basketball championships.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Sir James Robertson, former civil secretary of the Sudan who is chairman of the newly created British Guiana Commission of Inquiry, left here by air today for Georgetown, capital of the British territory on South America's northeast coast. The commission will recommend to the Colonial Secretary any changes that may be needed in the colony's constitution.
lfany tickets have been purchard for the performance of "Mademoiselle Colombo" on Mon-i day night at the Logacre The-, atre for the benefit of the Child Study Association of America.

BONN, Germany -- Although West German business and industry are booming, management complains of the difficulties of finding capital for further development and blames Government policy for that handicap.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- In an attempt to head off a compulsory automobile liability insurance law, three groups of insurance agents and executives proposed today an alternative plan. Under it motorists could obtain protection against uninsured drivers by paying a surcharge on their premiums.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 -- Countess Dorothy di Frasso, international society figure, was found dead in her compartment on a train from Las Vegas, Nev., this morning. She was 65 years old.
TEHERAN, Iran -- Iran's economy this year will have no where to go but up from the rock bottom state of near bankruptcy it reached in 1953.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- Mayor John B. Hynes of Boston called today for a complete revaluation of the city's taxes. He said that this was necessary to keep present businesses and to attract new ones.

David Bronstein, one of the two Russians competing in the international tournament at Hastings, England, went into the lead yesterday with a score of 4-1 after winning his fifth-round game from D. M. Horne of England and also his fourth-round adjourned game with Dr. S. G. Tartakower of France, according to a report from London.
A gift of $258,200 has been made to the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases by the Charles A. Dana Foundation to finance the new recovery pavilion for patients requiring special care.

QUANTICO, Va., Jan. 4 (UP) -- Nineteen marines say they have seen a mysterious reddish "blinking or revolving" light over the base here, several times in the last week, the Public Information Office reportedutoday.
Walter Cartier, 161, Greenwich Village, scored a unanimous decision over Randy Sandy, 158 1/2, Harlem, in a ten-round middleweight feature bout at Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

Net sales of the Minneapolis-Moline Campany and Canadian subsidiary for the year ended Oct. 31 were 14 per cent above the 1952 volume, although net income was 53 per cent below the results posted for the year ended on Oct. 13, 1952.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- National conservation interests rallied today to fight the proposed Echo Park Dam within the confines of the Dinosaur National Monument.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor, who renounced his Communist captors for freedom, said today that the North Korean and Chinese Reds had wrecked the program of Allied explanations to the prisoners by ordering the twenty-two American captives not to attend.

Federal Maritime Board hearings on the proposed establishment of a dual rate system by the Trans-Pacific Freight Conference of Japan got under way in Washington yesterday before A. L. Jordan, hearing examiner.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Scotland Yard is being reorganized. A long-term plan for the Metropolitan Police made major progress today when 200 senior officers in both the Uniformed and Criminal Investigation Department branches assumed new duties.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Oscar (Battling) Nelson, a pathetic little man of eighty pounds, poverty stricken and his mind a complete blank, today was ordered committed to the Chicago State Hospital.

The National City Bank of New York had resources of $6,049,021,671 and deposits of $5,538,214,433 at the close of 1953, according to an annual statistical summary of the bank's operations and position.

When Senator McCarran (Democrat) of Nevada publicly reproves Senator McCarthy (Republican) of Wisconsin we may be sure that something grave is at stake. It must be really important, like the prestige of rival Congressional committees or, even more earthshaking, the publicity of rival investigators.
MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Soviet Union disclosed today another move to erase from the public records the name of Lavrenti P. Beria, former secret police chief executed for treason.

This year's Hall of Fame baseball game, an annual attraction at Cooperstown, N. Y., will send the Yankees against the Cincinnati Redlegs on Aug. 9. The net proceeds of the program, which draws many thousands of fans to the birthplace of the national pastime, will go toward the erection of new stands there.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Tommy Lewis of Alabama, who jumped from the bench to tackle a touchdown-bound Rice football player in the Cotton Bowl game Friday, brought memories of an incident at the Naval Academy in 1918.
ROME, Jan. 4 -- Personal accounts of Lucrezia Borgia have been discovered in Ferrara, where she reigned for fourteen years as Duchess and spent the last seventeen years of her turbulent life.

In his book, "1984," the late George Orwell sketched briefly the technique used by a perfected totalitarian thought-control apparatus for turning a person into an "unperson." His hero is ordered to eradicate from the record the memory of one "Comrade Withers," a high party official who some time earlier had been fulsomely lauded by the dictator but who had later been purged.

GENEVA, Jan. 4 -- Twenty countries have agreed to give Japan's exports nondiscriminatory tariff treatment, the secretariat of the Contracting Parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (G. A. T. T.) announced here today.

NEW DELHI, India -- A possible new direction for Indian trade opened in December, 1953, when New Delhi concluded a five-year bilateral trade pact with the Soviet Union. The agreement specifies commodities that may be exchanged -- the list is to be revised annually -- and provides for cash payment in rupees or sterling.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- A doctor who refused to answer an Army loyalty questionnaire and who is serving as a private sued in Federal District Court today to regain his civilian status.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 4 -- Neil H. Swanson resigned today as executive editor of the Baltimore Sunpapers, a post he has held since 1941.
WITH FIRST MARINE DIVISION in Korea, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Two United States marines stationed along Korea's demilitarized zone said today they had denied asylum to a Communist horse.

ROME -- Ezio Vanoni, Minister of Finance, has been declaring for three years that taxes have reached a level beyond which they cannot go without harm to the economy. The index of revenue from taxation in relation to the gross national income has, nevertheless, been increasing from year to year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The State Department said today it was discussing the question of military aid with individual countries in the Middle East but had reached no final decision.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Straight Face, Greentree Stable's hopeful to succeed Tom Fool as handicap champion, made his first start since the Kentucky Derby today and won a six-furlong sprint in easy fashion at Tropical Park.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Officials of the Canadian Shipowners' Association said today further talks would be held, possibly within a week, with Government officials in connection with Canada's deep-sea ships.

The first 1954 issue of Pravda has reported that a bronze bust of Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Deputy Minister of Defense and World War II hero, was formally unveiled before a mass meeting in the village of Ugodsky Zavod, near the city of Kaluga.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya -- Last year was a critical one for the economy of the Malayan Federation, which is largely dependent on two products -- rubber and tin. The rubber price averaged only about 68 cents Malayan (22.37 cents United States) a pound, compared with 96 1/2 cents Malayan in 1952.

Operations of the steel mills are scheduled this week at 75 per cent of capacity for an expected production of 1,788,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This is the first time the industry's ingot production rate is figured on the basis of the new weekly capacity rate of 2,384,549 tons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Charles M. Kaman, inventor of the intermeshing-rotor helicopter that bears his name, was elected chairman of the Helicopter Council today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today that Czechoslovakia, its only Iron Curtain member, had been suspended for failure to pay $625,000 owing on its capital subscription.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Hog prices tumbled sharply today in response to heavy receipts, both at Chicago and other terminals.

PARIS -- The attention of political and economic experts was forcibly turned to the position of the laboring classes in French national life when the most powerful strike wave in seventeen years engulfed France's economy in August.
DAKAR, French West Africa, Nov. 24 -- France is engaged in a supreme effort to lift her West African territories out of their immemorial indigence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia had no authority to approve a proposal for cancellation of United Corporation's stock option warrants.

Playing with an injured right ankle during most of the match, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales defeated Francisco (Pancho) Segura in the featured professional tennis match at Madison Square Garden last night, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

Legumes -- beans, peas and lentils -- are among nature's most nourishing and inexpensive foods. They have held a position of importance down through the ages as a mainstay of the people and the gourmet's delight.

SEOUL, Korea -- The three-year Korean war wrecked the Korean economy, leaving the country's meager industrial plant a hulking ruin. Transportation facilities were kept in repair because of the military needs. The rich and important rice fields often became battlegrounds and were therefore unproductive.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 4 -- West Germany's Government will proceed with a constitutional amendment to authorize rearmament without regard to the coming Big Four conference in Berlin, leading members of the Government coalition in Parliament stated today.
NEW DELHI, India -- India is doing a booming trade in monkeys in spite of stiff opposition from the orthodox Hindus, who hold the simian order in high veneration as an incarnation of deity.
A test case of the powers on the Moreland Act Commission now investigating harness racing, will be heard today by Justice James B. M. McNally in Supreme Court.
PARIS -- There are three distinct aspects and standards of measurement of the process that has come to be called European "integration."
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President in 1952, offered his party some advice today in the form of New Year's resolutions.

The Russians are still at least two years ahead of the United States in understanding how to carry out military operations under the extreme weather conditions near the North Pole, it was reported here last night.

PARIS -- Some new means of financing the extensive social security system in France must be found in 1954 because of the growing deficit. The Government is talking of a subsidy of 100,000,000,000 francs ($290,000,000) to supplement workers' and employers' contributions.
DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 3 -- The time-for-a-change political slogan is worrying the Moslem League party, whose control of Pakistan is threatened by the united strength of five opposition parties.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- Before some 400 business, government and civic leaders of this area, the Penn Fruit Company broke ground today for a $3,500,000 food distribution center for its chain of supermarkets. In keeping with the times, officials used a bulldozer instead of the traditional spade to turn the first earth of the land on which the new plant will rise at Grant Avenue and Roosevelt Boulevard.

ROME -- In 1953 the Parliamentary Tremelloni Committee, named after its chairman, Roberto Tremelloni, right-wing Socialist, issued a report of its inquiry into unemployment in fifteen large volumes. Its findings may be summarized as follows:

OTTAWA, Monday, Jan. 5 -- Igor Gouzenko, who seven years ago disclosed a Soviet spy ring in North America, yesterday told United States Senators William E. Jenner and Pat McCarran all he knew about Soviet espionage. He also gave his expert advice on how to convert the subversives.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- Australia's most pressing problem as an international trader is the vulnerability of her production and manufacturing costs to imports. Until lately licensing of imports has protected her industry from the competitive pressure of free world supplies, but now that licensing has been eased, Australian factories are facing the most intensive competition they have experienced since the war, and while the prices of imports have been falling, domestic costs have been rising.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 4 -- Reserve Bill Slattery, a 6-foot-1-inch junior from Freeport, Illinois, stole the ball and sank a one-hander from the foul line with ten seconds left to give Navy's basketball team a 67-66 victory over Princeton today.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- Since 1945 the Australian cost of living has risen more than 100 per cent and it is now two and one-half times what it was in 1939. In the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada the rise has been on the order of 50 per cent since 1945.

Early relaxation of the Government monopoly in atomic energy is called for in a report issued yesterday by the Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc. The stated objective is to stimulate competition and speed technological development in the field for industrial purposes.

For the fourth successive time John J. Mann has been nominated to be chairman of the board of governors of the American Stock Exchange. The former page boy shares this honor with only one other man, the late Fred Moffatt.
WASHINGTON -- Achievement of the International Monetary Fund's central objective for 1954 -- bringing about convertibility of major European currencies -- seemed to be in sight as 1953 ended.

ATHENS -- Despite earthquakes in the Ionian Islands last August that caused a death toll of nearly 500 and widespread devastation, 1953 may be reckoned as a year of prosperity for Greece. The year's yield in many essential foods was higher than ever before.

When Congress decides to subsidize certain classes of mail delivery in the interests of public welfare, it should say so and pay for it, according to a report yesterday by the Magazine Publishers Association, Inc. The report, written by Prof. Jules Backman, New York University economist and corporation consultant, opposed the inclusion of subsidies for such services in the deficit of the postal system at large.
The new session of Congress, which convenes tomorrow, may plan the strategy of future wars.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions agreed today to postpone a slowdown it had asked its 3,000,000 remembers to begin Jan. 18.

The trial of eight men and one woman, who are accused of conspiracy to violate the bookmaking and lottery statutes, opened yesterday in Special Sessions. The defendants were among ninety persons rounded up in mass gambling raids last July 7.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Marilyn Monroe failed to report at Twentieth Century-Fox for work this morning and the studio announced this afternoon that the star had been suspended from salary. Miss Monroe, crowned as the box office queen in The Motion Picture Herald's 1953 poll of the ten top money-making stars, was to have joined Dan Dailey and Frank Sinatra in rehearsals for the musical "Pink Tights."
True social progress depends on a sound economy, Dean Kenneth D. Johnson of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia' University, declared yesterday in his annual report to the board of trustees.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Sweden's important shipping has been hard hit by a slump brought on by a combination of high costs and strong foreign competition.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 -- Chet Huntley, a radio-television news commentator, received $10,000 and a public apology today from a woman who had accused him of being a Communist.
Retail department store business in New York in December was 2 per cent less than in December, 1952.
PARIS -- France improved her trade balance notably last year

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Led by its radical left wing, the British Labor movement is urging the Conservative Government to adopt a policy of give and take in the negotiations with the Soviet Union later this month.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 4 (UP) -- One of Yugoslavia's top Red leaders condemned the Yugoslav Communist party's operation today as outmoded and proposed that the present system of strict party discipline be dropped.
The States Marine Corporation is seeking an operating differential subsidy for service on six ocean routes.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, Jan. 4 -- The Gold Coast expects to achieve full self-government within a matter of months and so emerge as the first African colony in a position to demand complete independence.

More manufacturers of work clothes are going into the lucrative field of men's sportswear. This was apparent, yesterday, following a study of lines at the annual Work Clothes Sportswear Show, Inc., at the New Yorker. To an increasing degree sportswear is moving into prominence.

Four policemen attached to the Glendale precinct in Queens will face departmental trial for "failing to take proper police action" in the finding of the body of a Queens grocer in his automobile on New Year's Day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- If the International Workers Order is declared a Communist front the New York State Superintendent of Insurance will not have to register with the State Department.

ALTON, Ill., Jan. 4 (AP) -- All river freight traffic through the busy Alton Locks on the Mississippi River, which has been averaging more than a million tons a month, has been blocked by a barge accident.

The next Walker Cup golf match, an international amateur competition between the United States and Great Britain, will be played in Britain on May 20 and 21, 1955. The United States Golf Association, which disclosed the dates yesterday, said the matches would be held at St. Andrews, Scotland.

GUS DORAIS died last Sunday at the age of 62, some forty-one years after he and Knute Rockne revolutionized the game of football. They revolutionized it in two directions, one deliberate and the other inadvertent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Supreme Court dusted off today what one of its members called "the ancient writ of coram nobis" to give Robert Patrick Morgan, a New York mail robber, a rehearing.

VIENNA -- Austrian foreign trade in 1953 was marked by a moderate increase in the volume of exports and a sharp decrease in imports compared with 1952. These tendencies were accentuated by the currency devaluation in May, and by the fact that imports under the Marshall Plan tapered off sharply.

Listening to the variations of the 17-year-old Chopin on "La ci darem la mano" last night at the Little Orchestra Society concert in Town Hall, one duly credited Robert Schumann with prophetic perspicacity when he hailed this composition with the historic salute: "Hats off, gentleman, a genius." By all means!

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- Suggestions from Japan that Asia create its own payments union, on the style of the European Payments Union, are not taken seriously here. Indonesia believes such a system would retard war reparation payments to Burma, the Philippines and this country.
PARIS -- France's merchant marine, which totaled 2,750,000 tons in 1939 and was almost half destroyed in wartime, had been built to 3,514,000 tons in 1953.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- So far as the Supreme Court is concerned, employers of domestic servants must continue to withhold Social Security taxes from their wages.

ZURICH, Switzerland -- In the first ten months of 1953, the total value of the exports of the Swiss watch industry was 888,000,000 francs (nearly $207,000,000), or 24,000,000 francs greater than in the first ten months of 1952.

BRUSSELS, Belgium -- The Benelux Union plan was imbued with fresh vigor in 1953 on encouraging indications that mutual trade between the three member countries had been stabilized at about the pre-war proportions.

MADRID -- Spain's economy suffered during 1953 from a severe drought that caused a considerable drop in agricultural output compared with 1952. Industrial production, normal for the first six months, fell drastically toward the end of the year.

Years and years ago Emma Lazarus wrote an inscription for the Statue of Liberty in which she spoke in moving words of the "huddled masses yearning to breathe free" and pictured Liberty as lifting her "lamp beside the golden door." The passage of time has changed the form of tyranny.

In replying to General Thimayya, chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea, General Hull, the United Nations commander, said just what we would have expected a forthright person to say. The Indian chairman had joined with the Communist members of the commission in a report that recommended that the matter of the release of reluctant prisoners be subject to further "consideration" because of the failure to achieve a political conference.

Although the popular market averages dropped only 9 per cent last year, the decline in stock prices was considerably worse than that. Two-thirds of the common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange went down.

PARIS -- The French financial and economic year has ended better than it started. However, three key problems, of wages, currency and the rigidity of the economic structure are still unsolved. On other points, such as business recovery, unemployment, budgetary balance, and the development of exports, some progress has been made, thanks in large measure to continued price stability.

A good deal of newspaper space has been devoted in the last few days to the carefully guarded predictions concerning the business outlook for 1954 by the nation's economists and the less guarded observations by our politicians on the same subject. If it is too early to know what is in store for us during the coming year, we are at least in a position now to appraise the results of the year 1953.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Emil Zatopek's New Year's Eve feat in Brazil of running 7,300 meters (about 5 miles) in 20 minutes and 30.4 seconds had track and field statisticians re-checking their slide rules today.

LISBON, Portugal -- Although Dr. Ulisses Cortes, Portuguese Minister of Economy, recently issued an optimistic review of the condition of the country's economy, business men were disheartened in 1953 and are pesimistic about the future.
TANGIER, Morocco -- Building, chief industry in Tangier since the war, had a severe slump in 1953, with construction permits dropping to $5,000,000 from the $10,000,000 level of 1952.

LONDON -- An important factor in the rise of Britain's dollar earnings is the personal export project under which tourists are allowed to buy goods in this country minus purchase tax provided the goods bought are sent direct to their ship or plane, or to an address in the United States.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Treasury announced today that the sterling area had a gold and dollar deficit of $43,000,000 during December and that nevertheless the area's gold and dollar reserves at the end of the year amounted to $2,518,000,000 compared with $1,846,000,000 at the end of 1952.

All coffee options on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange reached a record high yesterday. There was support across the board, but especially in the distant months, by Brazilian interests. Offerings were tight with hedging and profit-taking supply ing the contracts.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Lawrence H. Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart, predicted today that 1954 would be one of the four best years for the home furnishings industry.

County and district political leaders are unlikely to be appointed to commissionerships and other "top jobs" in the city government under Mayor Wagner. The leaders are considered to be "busy enough" with their political obligations.

BERLIN -- Communist policy in East Germany did a somersault half way through 1953. The program of high-speed industrialization, of rushing headlong toward socialism, was abandoned in a day. The new effort centers on raising the standard of living.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The first trading session of the new year favored the bears in grain and soybean futures.

MADRID -- Official statistics for the first seven months of 1953, which are the latest available, indicated that, as in 1952, Spain's foreign trade would show considerable deficit in spite of a slight increase in value.

OSLO -- Norway's economic situation was not good at the close of 1953. Signs of stagnation in production and exports were apparent from midyear. The position worsened with every succeeding month, and a sharp drop in exports occurred in October and November.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Ernie Harwell, formerly an announcer of New York Giants and Brooklyn Dodgers games, will call all 154 games on radio and fifty-six on television for the new Baltimore Orioles next summer. The air schedule and new announcer were disclosed today.

Earle G. Orleman Jr., 21 years old, of 79 Davidson Street, Mariners Harbor, S. I., was arraigned in the Stapleton, S. I., Felony Court yesterday on charges of vehicular homicide and leaving the scene of an accident, after he had confessed, according to the police, to having been involved in a hit-and-run case on Christmas Eve.

Dick Hemric, a 6-foot 6-inch junior from Jonesville, N. C., who last season was the sixth highest scorer in the nation, will be in the Wake Forest line-up when the Deacons face Seton Hall at Madison Square Garden tonight. The curtain-raiser in the collegiate basketball double-header will send St. John's against West Virginia at 7:45 P. M.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Federal Judge James T. Foley reserved decision today on a state motion to have a suit aginst the State University thrown out of court.

The production of oil last year in foreign fields again was at a record rate despite the meager flow from the prolific wells of Iran. Consumption increased in virtually every area, but requirements were met fully. For the first full year of the post-war period no shortage of petroleum products was reported from any area in the free world.

It is welcome news reported in The Times that a program for the children of migratory workers who move with the crops along the Atlantic seaboard is being launched jointly by the Federal Children's Bureau, the Office of Education and the Public Health Service in cooperation with state and private volunteer agencies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The motion-picture industry got a Supreme Court approval today to limit first-run pictures to downtown theatres with the biggest ticket sales.

WASHINGTON -- The United States' technical assistance program abroad suffered a series of convulsions last year. Whether it has recovered its health or even become healthier is a matter of considerable debate.

The factory and salesrooms property at 2339-2357 Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by the Flatbush Motors, Inc., to Louis Lakretz. The City Title Insurance Company insured title to the parcel, which was sold subject to a mortgage of $67,500.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Jan. 5 (AP) -- An American business man freed from three years of "really hell" in a Shanghai prison said yesterday that Western nations might obtain the release of many foreigners imprisoned in Communist China by working "at the prison warden level."
PARIS -- A spectacular fall in the price of gold took place during 1953, and in France, where gold is often hoarded, the drop was a major feature of the financial year.

Operational programs of retail grocers this year are based on a sales volume that is expected to be better or at least as good as that of 1953, according to the National Association of Retail Grocers, Chicago.
The 1954 March of Dimes may become a march of victory in the fight against paralytic poliomyelitis, speakers told a meeting outside City Hall yesterday opening the New York fund campaign.

NEWARK, Jan. 4 -- A 25-year-old inmate of State's Prison in Trenton won the first round in his fight for freedom today as the former police magistrate who committed him in 1947 pleaded in court on his behalf.
The cotton futures market here opened with gains of 1 to 8 points yesterday and closed 11 to 17 points higher than on Thursday, with trading somewhat more active than in last month's sessions.

BONN, Germany -- Western Germany, rising from defeat of 1945 to become once more an economic force in Western Europe, grew stronger still in 1953. Economic recovery and development kept pace with -- or set the pace for -- the steady improvement in the Bonn Republic's position on the European political scene.
Stock market volume faded to 1,310,000 shares, the lowest level since Dec. 24, but more issues rose yesterday than on any previous day since Oct. 16.

PARIS -- France's tourist industry was badly shaken by nation-wide strikes during August, 1953. However, a quick recovery during the following months enabled it to make an over-all showing only slightly below that of 1952.

HONG KONG -- The economic position of this little Far Eastern entrepot continues to suffer from restrictions imposed on trade with Communist China. In accordance with British observance of United Nations resolutions, Hong Kong prohibits the export to Red China of a comprehensive list of strategic goods.
TANGIER, Morocco -- World currency stabilization is playing hob with two of Tangier's chief activities, speculation in currency and gold.
DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 4 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali denounced today India's "hypocritical indirect approach" to the question of military aid from the United States.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The United Air Lines said today that it was constructing a test "airdock" in Denver that might revolutionize loading and unloading of aircraft.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- The London grain market opened today for the first time in 14 years. It was closed at the outbreak of war when the Government took over grain buying.

GENEVA -- During 1953 all of the larger national economies of Western Europe except France, and most of the smaller ones, got off the dead center on which they seemed to be in danger of sticking in 1952.

Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to minimize violence and interference with commerce if interunion rivalry erupts into a new waterfront strike. He called fifteen New York and New Jersey law-enforcement officials to an "emergency" conference at City Hall tomorrow afternoon to make plans for safeguarding life and trade in the event of a dock strike.
VIENNA -- Austria held her own in industrial production, increased agricultural output and achieved a remarkable improvement in her financial position, internally and externally, in 1953.

LONDON -- The importance of income from tourists in Britain's economy is emphasized by the rise in the number of visitors from 391,000 in 1947 to nearly 750,000 in 1953, and the consequent increase in receipts of foreign currencies from 33,000,000 to 125,000,000 ($92,400,000 and $350,000,000, respectively).

The leasehold on the new six-story store and office building at 55 East Thirty-fourth Street has been sold by Henry Goelet to an investing syndicate represented by Gerdes Montgomery, attorneys. The Wallace J. Grove Company was the broker and Margolin Feldman were attorneys for the seller.

RANGOON, Burma -- Paced by an increase in rice production and large-scale Government expenditures for new developments, economic activity in Burma for 1953 showed marked expansion. The country progressed along the road to recovery from the effects of Japanese war and the damage of Communist and other rebellions.
TEL AVIV, Israel -- Israel's water yield in 1953 increased by 100,000,000 cubic meters, to 800,000,000 cubic meters, of which 700,000,000 was for irrigation.

NEW DELHI, India., Jan. 4 -- The Soviet Union's prolonged cultural offensive in India will reach hitherto unscaled heights this month with the assistance of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Government.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- The Coast Guard at a hearing today sought an answer to why two freighters were involved in a collision in clear weather Friday night off the northern California coast.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Eisenhower Administration's farm program and how to make it acceptable to Congress was the topic of a meeting at the Department of Agriculture today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- At the close of a day spent announcing opinions and listening to arguments, eight justices of the Supreme Court went to the movies this afternoon.

Morgan Stanley Co. has announced the admission as general partners of William Ewing Jr., Frank A. Petito and H. Edward Vollmers. Mr. Ewing, son of one of the founders, has been with the concern since 1940, Mr. Petito since 1937 and Mr. Vollmers since 1945.
