WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- President Eisenhower sought tonight to calm fears of an economic recession by looking forward to "a new year more fruitful to the security of the nation and the welfare of its people."

BONN, Germany -- West Germany's remarkable economic recovery is perhaps best illustrated by the development of her foreign trade. Although this country started last in the post-war recovery race, progress has been notably fast and today there is a booming economy and a steady demand for German products at home and abroad.

ROME -- Both industry and agriculture did well in the first nine months of 1953. Industry overcame the stagnation that set in during 1952 and reached new over-all production levels. Agriculture, which provides above 30 per cent of the national income, had bumper crops and the highest wheat yield in Italian history.
HELSINKI, Finland -- The Finnish economy has deteriorated steadily since late 1951.
TORONTO, Jan. 4 -- Both students are prominent in Progressive Conservative circles in Toronto.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- President Eisenhower called on Federal employes today to support the Red Cross and asked department and agency heads to form Red Cross units within their organizations.
ZURICH, Switzerland -- Evidence that business in Switzerland was at a peak level throughout 1953 and promises to continue so in 1954 is provided by the country's high rate of employment.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- A major gold-and-uranium field came into production last year in the Orange Free State and in the Western Transvaal. In the Orange Free State actual mining disclosed better values than the bore holes that had originally traced the field deep below the corn lands of this once stagnant province.

" Lady Into Woman: A History of Women from Victoria to Elizabeth II," a new book by Vera Brittain, will be published Jan. 26 by Macmillan. It is a survey of the last fifty years in politics, education, labor and sex morals, during which the "sheltered" lady of the Victorian epoch became the "self-sufficient" woman of today "not only in English-speaking countries but throughout the world."
Japan in 1953 stood head and shoulders above all other countries in the export of cotton textiles, according to estimates of the Textile Export Association of the United States.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- By calling a special session of Parliament for Wednesday afternoon, Premier Joseph Laniel has opened the way to avoid a Cabinet crisis just before the four-power Berlin conference. A vote of confidence in the present Cabinet so it could carry on until after the pending international negotiations would suffice.

MANILA -- Year's end in the Philippines coincides with a change of government. President Ramon Magsaysay's new Administration inherited a host of knotty problems from the Quirino regime -- political, economic and financial problems. However, the means are said to be at hand to solve the worst of them in the predictable future.
Last month was the warmest December in thirty years and set a record for the warmest ten consecutive days, the Weather Bureau reported yesterday.

PARIS -- The fourteen nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization reached in 1953 what is generally regarded as about the maximum economic effort that their peacetime financial structures can bear. They spent $65,500,000,000 on their aggregate defenses.

On the basis of sales for the first nine months of 1953, British cars made a moderate yet satisfactory gain in the United States market, according to Sir William Welsh, North American representative of the (British) Society of Motor Manufacturers and traders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland of California threatened today to take "whatever steps necessary" to break filibusters against Hawaiian statehood, the St. Lawrence Seaway bill or any other legislation proposed by the Administration.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- A State Supreme Court justice upset today the constitutionality of a New York law providing for chemical tests for drunken drivers.
BONN -- Free convertibility of the Deutsche mark in 1954 has become one of the primary aims of the West German economic policy.
LONDON -- Very much like a man on a tightrope juggling with Indian clubs, Britain is trying to keep a balance between the need to rearm and to export. Those needs are complementary.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- A record-breaking net profit of $55,461,617 for 1953 was reported today by the Bank of America, the world's largest privately owned bank.
Five industrial companies will receive awards today for industrial landscaping and beautifying of their grounds.
BRUSSELS, Belgium -- The industrial production of Belgium rose to a record high in October, 1953, confounding once again the critics of her high wages and standard of living.

While world attention has been focused on the Korean war prisoners comparatively little heed has been paid to many other prisoners from many nations who languish in Communist jails or are being worked to death in Communist slave labor camps.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Daily Sketch today launched a campaign to keep Gordon Pirie, Britain's great distance runner, in England.
BONN -- Compared with other European countries, West Germany had relatively little labor trouble in 1953. The prospects for labor peace in 1954 were considered good.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Edward M. Curran, United States District Judge, today dismissed a suit for the release of a United States soldier sentenced to five years in prison by a French civil court.
BERLIN, Jan. 5 -- Britain, France and the United States invited the Soviet Union today to begin preparatory talks Thursday morning for the coming Big-Four foreign ministers conference in Berlin.

A mercy flight by an Air Force bomber through dense fog failed to save the life of Harry A. Ganser of 15 Clent Road, Great Neck, L. I., who was injured in an automobile accident near Florence, S. C., on Dec. 22.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on two issues of notes totaling $25,680,000 for the temporary financing of two-state-aided projects -- Carver Houses in Manhattan and Forest Houses in the Bronx.

HAVANA -- A sharp decline in national income was suffered by Cuba during 1953 largely as the result of a sugar surplus and the consequent falling off of prices. This republic now faces a period of economic readjustment in 1954, the severity of which will depend to a major degree on world conditions.
OTTAWA (AP) -- Petroleum became Canada's No. 1 mineral during 1953 and led total mineral production to a record annual value of $1,331,000,000.

Westchester County and Connecticut officials began banding together yesterday to organize protests against the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's petition for an increase of one-third in commutation fares.
OTTOWA, (Canadian Press) -- Finance Minister Douglas Abbott has ordered the Canadian Tariff Board to open a new anti-freeze inquiry with a view to suggesting possible changes in import duties.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A set of rich velvet draperies today stood solid as an iron curtain between Leopold Stokowski and the Daughters of the American Revolution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Attorneys for Myron Wiener of New York said today that Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, had rejected a request that he help Mr. Wiener get back his place on the War Claims Commission.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- The vast water power potential in British Columbia and the Yukon gives the region a promising future, according to James S. Eckman, chairman of the Greater Vancouver Metropolitan Industrial Development Commission.

A student from India sent $1 yesterday for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. He wrote that his gift was "not much at all considering what the people and the Government of the U. S. A. have done for the people of India in the emergencies such as the food shortage and what not."

WINNIPEG (Canadian Press) -- On many Manitoba farms fishing nets rank side by side with threshing machines as standard equipment. A combination of summer farming and winter fishing makes the province both wheat producer and fishing ground.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Sir Edward Benthall, leader of a British trade mission that recently visited the Middle East, told a meeting of industrialists today the British were being beaten all the time on price in that area.
Business activity of Nicaragua reached a record level in 1953. Gold and foreign exchange reserves rose to $23,600,000 last June, but showed a small seasonal drop through September.

CAYENNE, French Guiana -- The initial stages of exploratory work in bauxite mining in Guiana are nearly ended and preliminary plans for mining and transporting the ore are under consideration. An engineer from the Bureau of Mines for Overseas France recently visited Cayenne to draw up preliminary working plans.

Conacher, Wilson, Mortson Big Threats to Blues' Third Straight in Garden Game Looking for their third straight triumph, the New York Rangers will skate against the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight at Madison Square Garden. The Broadway Blues have not put together three successes in a row since January, 1952.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Duke of Roxburghe today married Mrs. Margaret Elizabeth Church in a nine-minute civil ceremony at the Caxton Hall Registry.
The year just ended was a constructive one for the public market for foreign dollar bonds and 1954 promises to be even better.

CAIRO, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- Yemen accused Britain today of "intimidating" the population of the Aden protectorates and aimling at the establishment of a federation of these protectorates against the wishes of the people.

OTTAWA, Jan. 5 -- A statement protesting the ban of the religious film "Martin Luther" in Quebec Province was sent from Toronto today to Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent and other political leaders in the capital.
With the exception of those countries behind the Iron Curtain the world's communications facilties made major advances last year.

OTTAWA -- Canada's phenomenal post-war development continued unchecked last year. Barring the outbreak of general war or a severe business recession in the United States, leaders of her Government, industry and business are confident that 1954 will bring even greater achievement, and prosperity.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- After two years of debate Congress enacted a law creating the Government- controlled corporation Petroleo Brasileiro, S. A., better known as the Petrobraz. The law gives Petrobraz an absolute monopoly in the oil industry that covers drilling, refining, research, transportation and sales in the national territory.

Purchase contracts with the United States Government, and development aid loans of various types, are bolstering the ambitious expansion programs of several nickel producers in Canada -- source of about 85 per cent of the free world's nickel supply last year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Producers cut marketing of hogs sharply today, following two days of severe price markdowns, and the market responded with rises of from 75 cents to $1.25 a hundred pounds. Most offerings were up $1 or more.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- Although industry in British Columbia is developing "beyond our expectations," according to one authority, there is some concern among business men in this province about the outlook for 1954, especially in the basic industries, lumbering, fishing and mining.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- About those $20 bills that were stolen from the United States Bureau of Engraving and Printing and are still in circulation:

BOGOTA, Colombia -- The atmosphere of security following the change of Government has made itself felt in the economic life of Colombia. Agricultural production has increased and along with it consumer demand, causing the cost of living to rise abnormally in recent months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson will recommend tomorrow that Congress increase immediately the acreage allotment on the 1954 cotton crop to ease the economic impact of a cutback on the cotton belt.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 5 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies said tonight no real approach to making the pound and dollar more readily convertible could be effective without United States cooperation.

MONTREAL -- Production of aluminum in Canada last year rose about 8 per cent over the 1952 level to 539,000 tons, or 1,078,000,000 pounds, Nathanael V. Davis, president of Aluminium Limited, reported in a year-end statement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- John M. Leddy, Director of the State Department's Office of Economic Defense and Trade Policy, has been granted a leave of absence to cooperate with the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy on a study of United States foreign trade policy since 1932.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 6 -- The official Peiping radio charged today that the South Korean Government planned to "abduct" 22,000 anti-Communist Chinese and North Korean prisoners of the Korean war after Jan. 22, the date set for their liberation under the armistice agreement.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 5 -- The churches of America are putting up a bold new front, architecturally speaking.
VIENNA, Jan. 5 -- The Austrian Government urgently appealed today to the Big Four to deal with the Austrian state treaty when they meet in Berlin, starting Jan. 25.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 5 -- The Oldsmobile division of General Motors Corporation foresees a market of 400,000 cars for itself this year, J. F. Wolfram, general manager of Oldsmobile and a vice president of General Motors, said today at the press review of the 1954 models. This would mean producing 25 per cent more cars than the 319,414 turned out by Oldsmobile in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.5 per cent in the week ended Dec. 29, to 110.6, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. All of the major groupings participated in the advance.

BING CROSBY, who had been about the last of Hollywood's major holdouts against television, crossed over into the new medium on Sunday evening with the first of an irregular series of presentations over C. B. S.

W. R. Grace Co., the big international trading, investment and shipping organization, still lives in the tradition of level-head venturesomeness handed down from its founder, the runaway Irish boy who a century ago became a premier merchant of Peru before he was 30.

CANTON, N. Y., Jan. 5 (AP) Robert C. McEwen, Ogdensburg Republican, today was elected state Senator from the Thirty-ninth district, composed of St. Lawrence and Franklin Counties, in a special election.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti -- Business in the Republic of Haiti was considerably below par during the fiscal year 1952-53 (ended Oct.), with a dead season that extended from June to October. But the economic picture has been brightened for 1954 in a better coffee crop, with continued high prices and a rapidly-growing tourist trade.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 5 -- Minor engagements marked the fighting in Indo-China yesterday as both sides continued grouping and other preparations for intensified action.
SAO PAULO, Brazil -- This bustling industrial center, glorying in the title of the "world's fastest growing city," was badly hampered all through 1953 by a shortage of electric power.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Bent on firmly maintaining the long-standing policy of not allowing foreign companies to step into the local oil industry, Chile continues to develop in slow, but what are termed "well planned" strides, schemes for production and progressive expansion.

MEXICO CITY -- To add to Mexico's general trade troubles last year, tourism which is the country's biggest single dollar earner, showed a drop. Complete figures are not yet in, but the Government Tourist Bureau estimates a decline of about 7 per cent from 1952's record of 417,214 visitors whose spending covered Mexico's trade deficit. There were 338,951 in the first ten months of last year.

TORONTO -- For the second successive year, Ontario's manufacturing industries have invested nearly $500,000,000 in plants and equipment, the Provincial Government's trade and industry branch reported.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Earl H. (Dutch) Clark, a brilliant collegiate and professional player twenty years ago, has quit football for the second time and Wally Fromhart was named today to succeed him as head coach of the University of Detroit.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- Tourist dollars and the "green gold" of bananas, sugar and other tropical crops still are the economic mainstays of this island of vanished splendor. However, bauxite, the raw material from which aluminum is derived, is threatening to challenge their position.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Vic Seixas played listlessly, losing to Australia's Rex Hartwig in four sets today, as the American threat in the South Australian tennis championships was reduced to one man -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati.
An attorney for Winthrop Rockefeller announced last night that his client's estranged wife had repudiated a $5,500,000 settlement and now was demanding $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Delaware company contended today before the Supreme Court that the United States Constitution banned Maryland from collecting its 2 per cent use tax from out-of-state concerns.

Seton Hall staged a second-half rally to defeat Wake Forest, 89 -- 78, at Madison Square Garden last night. The victory of the Pirates over last year's Southern Conference champions followed an 87-74 triumph over West Virginia by St. John's.
BOSTON, Jan. 5 -- A court test of the right of a public employe to invoke his constitutional privileges against self-incrimination opened today in Boston.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Substantial bipartisan support of the Administration foreign policy was assured today as President Eisenhower gave Democratic and Republican leaders a preview of the foreign and national security proposals he will lay before Congress Thursday.

Walter B. Devereux of New York was elected president of the National Horse Show Association here yesterday. succeeding Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman. Devereaux, who becomes the twelfth president of the organization. held the position of secretary from 1948 to 1950.
The plastics industry acted yesterday to guarantee the quality of its product.

HAVANA -- The mining industry is becoming increasingly more important to Cuba's economy. Production is rising steadily and there is considerable activity in exploration and preparations for new developments. Cuba's income from minerals in 1952 was $40,000,000.

LIMA, Peru -- An anxious year of foreign exchange shortage, internal price inflation and difficulty in selling exports all through South America has ended on a note of optimism, with conditions showing appreciable improvement everywhere.
A city study of the desirability of legalizing off-track betting in New York State is a distinct possibility.

A charge that Governor Dewey had failed to act on information concerning the killers of Carlo Tresca, Socialist editor, was made public here yesterday by the Tresca Memorial Committee and promptly denied by a representative of the Governor in Albany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Unhappy Republicans still sought a way tonight to convert their tenuous majority in the Senate into firm control of Senate committees.

The reconvening of Congress after a few months' recess is always reminiscent of the reopening of school at the beginning of a new term. There is an air of suppressed excitement, a bustling about in the halls and corridors, plenty of back-slapping and hand-shaking, and then a gradual settling down to the serious business at hand.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The Brazilian Government is planning to renovate its merchant shipping fleet with the aid of the United States Export-Import Bank and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The project was prepared by the technical aid division of the Brazil-United States Economic Development Commission.
Tonight's Premiere: "Mademoiselle Colombe," co-starring Julie Harris and Edna Best, at the Longacre.

Colombia, a large exporter of crude oil, still must import considerable quantities of by-products because of insufficient refining capacity and inadequate transportation. With a view to remedying this situation, the Government created a temporary Petroleum Planning Board early in 1953, including in its membership the manager of a foreign petroleum company.

The year-end survey of Latin-American economy which we publish this morning is a baffling blend of good and bad, optimism and pessimism. Nature, on the whole, was kind enough, but a combination of political unrest exasperated by nationalism and -- to a lesser extent -- communism, along with a fall in commodity prices, has thrown some dark shadows on the picture.

THERE is always tomorrow, the day after, or even next season for the salmon fisherman, who by the very nature of his sport must be immune to the disappointments that affect other anglers, and those who are planning to fish the reserve waters on New Brunswick's Restigouche or Upsalquitch may now apply for reservations.
MADRID, Jan. 5 -- The Spanish Government was reported today to have submitted to the United States a request for $20,000,000 in raw materials needed in many industrial sectors.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 5 -- The Government announced today that it had ordered all Provincial Governors to set machinery in motion for the pending legislative elections by setting up special committees to supervise the balloting.

Coffee prices continue upward. Safeway Stores announced yesterday price increases of 3 and 4 cents a pound on two of its three coffee brands. The Knob Hill brand went from 87 cents to 90 cents a pound and the Airway blend from 85 cents to 89 cents. The Edwards brand remained unchanged at 95 cents.
The raising of twenty glasses of champagne in a toast yesterday evening at Gracie Mansion brought $10,000 into the coffers of the 1954 Greater New York March of Dimes campaign.

MEXICO CITY -- The Mexican Government has announced its intention to revamp its tax system for 1954. The new law sent to Congress last month was devised, according to officials, to achieve a better distribution of income, encourage reinvestment in industry and to reduce unproductive speculation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A defensive alliance of Pakistan, Turkey and Iraq is in the process of being forged, with United States encouragement. It would strengthen the defenses along the southern frontier of the Soviet Union.

The position of Librarian of Congress, vacant since Dr. Luther H. Evans assumed the Directorship-General of UNESCO, will shortly be filled by Presidential nomination. Drew Pearson reports that the late Senator Robert A. Taft urged on the President the appointment of a friend from outside the library field, but that the nomination has been withheld in the face of protests from the library associations.

The Soviet press has always evidenced a lively, though perverted, interest in American race relations. We are pleased to direct its attention to the announcement just made by Tuskegee Institute that it is abandoning publication of the forty-one-year-old Lynching Letter.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Establishment of a United Nations commission to assist governments in curbing violent price fluctuations in the world raw materials markets was proposed here today.
TETERBORO, N. J., Jan. 5 -- A private plane crashed and burned at Teterboro Airport today but all four of its occupants escaped unhurt.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Two diametrically opposed views on the meaning, and the end uses of "design" were presented today to editors and designers attending the wholesale home furnishings markets now in progress here.
TORONTO -- Aggressive exploration opened important new frontiers for Canadian mining in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine received today Chi Omega Sorority's national achievement award from President Eisenhower. "In my opinion it never went to a worthier person," the President said as he bestowed the gold medal on behalf of the sorority.

MONTREAL, Jan. 5 (Canadian Press) -- The Gouzenko hearing also was attended by D. W. Munde of the Canadian Justice Department, representing the Attorney General of Canada, and representatives of the External Affairs Department and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The United States was represented by R. Douglas Stuart, Ambassador to Canada, who met the Senators on their arrival here, and J. G. Sourwine, an official of the investigating committee.
MEXICO CITY -- A combination of three adverse factors during 1952 threw Mexican trade and payments considerably out of balance for the first time since devaluation in 1948.
UNITED NATIONS, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Thirty-one museum officials and authorities on art history from many parts of the world visited United Nations headquarters today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Eisenhower Administration's farm program will provide recommendations for the disposal of surplus commodities now in Federal storage.

Larger brims were a new note in the industry's presentation of spring millinery last night at the Astor Hotel. Other highlights were the use of sheer fabrics such as chiffon or organdy for trim, employment of pleats or pleat-like folds, popularity of a brilliant hot shade of pink, prominence of forward movement expressed in tilt or jut of brim and the continuing favor of jeweled ornamentation.

A banking syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $55,000,000 of twenty-five-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures of the Atlantic Refining Company at a price of 101 to yield 3.19 per cent to maturity in 1979.
New York City drivers who are believed to be intoxicated will still be asked to take a chemical test to determine their sobriety.

The Detroit Harvester Company and its subsidiaries achieved a record sales volume of $37,403,354 in the fiscal year ended last September, an increase of 44.4 per cent above the $25,905,126 sales in the preceding fiscal year. Net profit improved to $1,292,819, or $2.52 a share, from $1,070,606, or $2.08 a share, earned in the previous year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -- A collision of two freighters off Fort Bragg on the Northern California coast Friday evening was attributed today to a sudden change in course by one of them.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- There will be no drop, or even leveling off, in air conditioning equipment sales this year, industry spokesmen said today at the annual winter home furnishings market.

Mrs. Reginald B. Lanier will give a tea and cocktail party this afternoon in her home at 123 East Thirty-fifth Street. The guests will include members of the executive committee in charge of the plans for the entertainment known as the "Hour of Music" to be give in behalf of young musicians on the night of Jan. 29 in the ballroom of the Colony Club. Mrs. Lanier is chairman of the executive committee.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Philadelphia's Dan Bucceroni punched effectively at short range to gain a unanimous ten-round decision over Germany's Hein Ten Hoff tonight.

Problems of coffee growers, traders and processors, principally those of the Western Hemisphere, will be threshed out by representatives of the coffee trade from the main coffee-growing and consuming countries at a world coffee congress in Curitiba, Brazil, Jan. 14-19, according to Horacio Cintra Leite, representative in the United States of the Brazilian Coffee Institute, which will be a host to congress visitors.

HAVANA -- For the first time in Cuba's history, the farmer and small business man are receiving financial assistance from the Government. This is being done through the Agricultural and Industrial Development Bank, founded in 1950 by the Prio Socarras administration.

Despite some weak spots Western Europe has continued to grow in strength during the past year to a point at which two new steps can now be contemplated. One is a gradual reduction of American foreign aid, which last year amounted to $6.7 billions, of which some 75 per cent went to Western Europe.

In the next two years Brazil will have to pay nearly half of her $830,542.560 dollar-loan debt outstanding at the close of 1953, according to an analysis made by the New York Trust Company. The obligations, for which Brazil will need dollars, include loans from the International Monetary Fund, the Export-Import Bank, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and commercial banks.
VANCOUVER, B. C. (Canadian Press) -- The fishing industry of Ceylon is being modernized with the aid of Canadian fishermen and fishing boats.

MEXICO CITY -- The five Central American republics, stretching from the southern Mexican border to Panama, enjoyed their greatest prosperity in 1953. The reason was easy to find: coffee crops were large and coffee prices remained at peak levels.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- In recent years there has been an annual inflow of $30,000,000 of foreign capital into Latin American agriculture, according to estimates of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

YELLOWKNIFE, North West Tarritories -- There are three major producing gold mines in Canada's North West Territories, all in the vicinity of this town on the northern shore of Great Slave Lake. But exploration for new ore bodies and preliminary development of new mines are virtually at a standstill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Evidence mounted today that important Senate Republicans as well as Democrats might be getting ready to curb the investigative authority of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
GENEVA, Jan. 5 -- A senior official of the United Nations will go to Moscow at the end of this month for consultations with the Soviet Government on European economic problems.
A vast project to obtain sulphur in Mexico is being pushed by American and Mexican interests.
White, spiced with color, was the theme of the Irene of New York spring hat collection, presented yesterday in her salon at 16 East Fifty-second Street.

Van Wyck Brooks, one of the great American men of letters, has a new book on Dutton's list entitled "Scenes and Portraits: Memories of Childhood and Youth." In it Mr. Brooks discusses the background of his youth from 1886 until the eve of World War I, presenting a picture of the intellectual America of the period and a record of the ideas, personalities and surroundings that influenced his life.

Justice William Clark unloaded a cargo of verbal brickbats for the State Department yesterday morning on his return from Europe, where he had been deposed as Chief Justice of United States courts in West Germany.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- "Jupiter's Darling," a new musical based remotely on Robert E. Sherwood's 1926 play, "The Road to Rome," was announced today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for Esther Williams and Howard Keel. Dorothy Kingsley fashioned the new screen play to be directed by George Sidney and produced by George Wells.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The 177th regular annual session of the State Legislature will start at noon tomorrow in an atmosphere heavy with partisan politics.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- An air force that will equal in atomic striking power the 143-wing program discarded last year has been blueprinted and approved by President Eisenhower.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light with only cocoa, wool, coffee and soybean oil active. Coffee, cocoa, wool, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, lead and hides moved higher; sugar, potatoes, burlap, zinc and tin ended mixed and rubber and copper were lower.
A "realistic" Federal policy in making depreciation allowances on capital goods -- heavy machinery and the like -- was urged yesterday by the Machinery and Allied Products Institute.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Be cause of the conservative emphasis that Puerto Rico places on municipal debt management and municipal expenditures, many capital improvements are financed from current revenue. The result is that relatively little municipal financing is done by Puerto Rican cities.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- Pakistan announced today that she had freed Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan, the Pathan leader, who became known as the "frontier Ghandi" during India's long struggle for freedom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A young workman who had resisted billions of dollars' worth of temptation at his job was arrested today for the New Year's Eve theft of $160,000 from the Government's paper money factory.

BUENOS AIRES -- The recuperative powers of Argentina's economy were ably demonstrated last year. For the first time in three years Government statistical offices were able to point to a favorable balance of trade for a period of nine months.
PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- With a roar that could be heard for blocks, a roof of the Rainbow Finishing Corporation's plant here collapsed today. No one was hurt.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Richmond cleared the last hurdle in its efforts to become a member of the Class AAA International League tonight when four men raised $200,000 to make improvements of municipally-owned Parker Field.
Eleven R. K. O. productions, all but two in Technicolor and three in third dimension, will be released during the early part of the new year, according to an announcement made by the company.

A month-old strike of 14,000 employes of the Continental Can Company was settled yesterday with agreement between the company and the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., on a 15-cent-an-hour "package."
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- Uruguay, "the Switzerland of the Western Hemisphere," was beset in 1953 by many of the ills that afflicted countries all over the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- "La Ronde," a French motion picture that was banned by New York censors as immoral, was shown to members of the United States Supreme Court in their conference room this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Harry A. Barbour, 61-year-old former California public housing official who was believed to have committed suicide five years ago, was found today living with his wife and two daughters in Glassmanor, Md., a suburb of Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A Federal hearing was told today that Josephine Truslow Adams had "negotiated" with the late President Roosevelt to release Earl Browder from prison during World War II.
The movement of oceangoing vessels in the Port of New York reached a five-year high in 1953 when 25,210 vessels entered or left.
OTTAWA, Jan. 5 -- Alleged slaughter by United States hunters of many thousands of Canada Wild Geese, which this country is trying so hard to protect, has alarmed Canadian conservationists.
BOSTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and lists of winter sports conditions:

Winter meetings, the official averages and awards and the usual holiday interval having had their moments, baseball now moves into that period which, at least to club owners and general managers, quite often is regarded as the most difficult and critical of the year.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- The impressive industrialization of Puerto Rico now taking place is possible largely because the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority in the past few years has greatly extended the island's power facilities.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 5 -- Iran is prepared to compensate the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company for the nationalization of its properties here by payment of a lump sum, but would prefer that a settlement on compensation be deferred until the marketing of Iranian oil by an international consortium of oil companies has been agreed upon.
ROME, Jan. 5 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella and his Cabinet resigned this evening.

Latin America's air transport potential is one of the world's greatest. Road and rail networks are relatively underdeveloped Mountains, vast jungles and great distance between major population centers make expansion of surface transport costly.
The Whirlpool Corporation has contracted to purchase the Avco Manufacturing Corporation's Bendix Home Appliances laundry manufacturing buildings at Clyde, Ohio. The purchase price was not disclosed.
PRINCE ALBERT, Sask. (Canadian Press) -- Indians of Saskatchewan's Far North have discarded storage methods used by their forefathers in favor of the white man's deep freeze.

In your most recent plea for a rewriting of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act the ease of Ignatz Mezei is cited as an example of a non-citizen who, although acting in good faith, suddenly became entangled in a legal web from which he could not extricate himself.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Marty Marshall, Detroit light-heavyweight, won two ways tonight -- by a knockout and by a decision -- in a fight that was interrupted to permit another bout to finish.
An examiner of the Federal Martime Board has recommended approval of an agreement between the American Export Lines and the Italian Line for reciprocal agency representation in the two countries.

Robert Morris, former counsel of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, who was elected to the Municipal Court's Ninth District in Manhattan in November, was inducted as a justice yesterday. The ceremony was attended by a throng, including Senators William E. Jenner and Pat McCarran. Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr. presided.
New records may be set in twelve of the fifteen events in the sixty-fourth annual senior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships here Saturday.

WINNIPEG, Man. -- The year 1953 closed with terminal, facilities in Canada almost completely filled with grain. Elevators are plugged and millions of bushels of grain are stored in granaries or in the open on prairie farms.
HAVANA -- The infant kenaf industry of Cuba is learning to walk alone since withdrawal of the United States financial aid and promises to become a fair sized industry within the next few years.

It would be a pity if the recent state investigation into spurious philanthropies were to hurt in any way the fund campaigns of genuinely worthy organizations. There should be no doubt, certainly, of the high purpose and excellent community standing of the Young Men's Christian Association of the City of New York.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Early in 1954 Chile will launch a "revolutionary" agrarian plan that will require an investment of nearly $300,000,000 over a period of eight years. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is expected to provide $125,000,000 of the capital.
OTTAWA (Canadian Press) -- One of the most important freight rate decisions in Canada's history will be delivered by the Board of Transport Commissioners early this year.

Leaders and rank-and-filers in the advertising and marketing fields shudder when a new promotional contest is announced. But the apathy should evaporate with the news about an event to be held by the Mail Pouch Tobacco Company, Wheeling, W. Va., makers of Kentucky Club pipe tobacco.
Rocky Marciano may not defend his world heavyweight boxing title until June.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- A bold advocacy of German reunification, resulting in the departure of the Soviet army from Central Europe, appears to be gaining favor here as Britain prepares for the foreign ministers' conference with the Soviet Union.
MEXICO CITY -- Drought, floods and frosts made last year one of the most difficult Mexican agriculture ever has undergone, and the damage to crops was communicated to other segments of the economy.

TRENTON, Jan. 5 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced today that he had offered to help expedite State Senate confirmation of appointments, some of Cabinet rank, now being made by his Democratic successor, Robert B. Meyner.

CASTRIES, St. Lucia, B. W. I. -- The United Kingdom Secretary of State for the colonies has approved a grant of $26,579 and a loan of $33,600 from Colonial Development and Welfare funds for the development of the timber industry in St. Lucia.

REGINA, Saskatchewan -- Economic developments in this western province of Canada last year saw dramatic achievements in opening new fields of endeavor from uranium mining to large-scale use of natural gas.

PANAMA -- Panama put her financial house in order in 1953. The fact that President Jose A. Remon was able to do so in the first year of his Administration gave considerable hope that a marked improvement could be achieved in the country's economic situation in 1954.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -- An attempt is to be made to establish a free trade zone at the San Francisco airport so that articles sent in by foreign shippers may be left in customs there until there is a market for the products. The shippers would not have to pay charges until buyers were found.

BUENOS AIRES -- United States shipping registered a sharp decline in visits to Argentine ports during the first eleven months of 1953. United States carriers were displaced by Italy from the former position they held as the third most important flag represented in Argentine ports.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- Admired by his friends and respected by his foes as a living symbol and leader of Germany's post-war revival, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Republic, celebrated his seventy-eighth birthday today.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 5 -- The college football coaches of the country today took a position strongly in favor of the restrictive substitution rule that put an end in 1953 to the use of offensive and defensive platoons.
City Budget Director Abraham D. Beame took the first soundings yesterday on the cost of operating the city through the fiscal year 1954-1955.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The Advertising Council announced today that President Eisenhower and several Cabinet officers would speak at its tenth annual conference here on Tuesday.
Increased visibility, added horsepower and improved styling are included in the 1954 Buick line of cars, which will go on display Friday in dealer showrooms.
PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., Jan. 5 -- A single, well-aimed rifle bullet brought to an end today a six-day hunt for a bull bison that had escaped from the near-by Lanark Stables last Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The United States and the Chinese Communists have been discussing through "intermediaries" the possibility of resuming negotiations for a Korean peace conference.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil seemed by the end of 1953 to be working her way out of an anomalous situation in which her large cotton crop was a burden rather than an asset because it was so overpriced that it could not be sold.

By stimulating children's thinking, encouraging their curiosity and helping them find answers to their questions, children's museums are doing a valuable service both for the youngsters and for the community at large, Dr. Francis H. Horn said yesterday. Dr. Horn, president of Pratt Institute, spoke at the annual luncheon of the Friends of Children's Museums, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

From an enthusiastic pioneer in the European movement Italy in recent months has become a mere "also-ran," her voice weak and her course wavering. From being a point of stability in the Western alliance, in happy contrast to the precarious position of France, she has become a source of anxiety, another doubtful quantity in a still uneasy balance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The right of the American military commander in Berlin to call in pre-war Germany currency and exchange it for Deutsche marks, a new currency set up by the Allied Control Council, was upheld today by the United States Court of Claims.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to permit railroads to offer a special cut rate on mixed freight moving in carload lots to Dallas, Fort Worth and Waco, Tex., from the Texas port cities of Galveston, Houston and Texas City.
The program selected by the pianist Earl Wild for his Town Hall recital last evening was a fairly staggering one.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Seven cities including New York and Yonkers registered their opposition today to the $68,850,000 rate increase the New York Telephone Company is seeking from the Public Service Commission.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Spectacular advances in lard and an announcement of a Foreign Operations Administration grant of $26,000,000 to Great Britain for the purchase of cottonseed oil and other American farm products gave grain buyers more confidence today than they have had recently.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- A complete and concrete proposal for European security is understood to have been prepared by Allied diplomatic experts for presentation to the Soviet Union at the coming Big Four meeting in Berlin.
Senators William E. Jenner and Pat McCarran of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee reported yesterday that their interview with Igor Gouzenko had been long and productive.

Guaranty Trust Also Cites Decline in Total Resources -- Other Reports Listed Guaranty Trust Company of New York, in its year-end statement of condition issued for publication today, shows slight declines in deposits, loans and total resources.
The Citizens Budget Commission's annual awards for service to New York City will be formally presented at the organization's twenty-second annual dinner at the Plaza Hotel tomorrow night.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil has launched a new and ambitious plan to conquer the Amazon jungle and make that great area a source of riches, as it was in the days of the rubber boom at the end of the last century and until about 1910.

Free enterprise held its own against statism and nationalism in most of the Latin-American republics during 1953. This was largely the result of the foresight of a group of business men who met at Montevideo in 1941 and organized free enterprise on a hemispheric scale.

NO electioneering near the polls, please. That may be a wise provision in an ordinary election where a secret ballot is still the hallmark of a viable and true democracy. But the rule does not apply to choosing candidates for baseball's Hall of Fame. A ballot arrived in the mail yesterday from Kenesaw Mountain Smith, the indefatigable secretary of the Baseball Writers Association.

The steel shell of the country's most modern passenger and cargo steamship terminal, Pier 57, North River, will be up by Feb. 15, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. reported yesterday. The steel framework is nearly two-thirds completed.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- Coffee accounted for 82 per cent of Colombia's exports in 1953. The volume -- 6,300,000 bags (of 132 pounds) -- was a record, exceeding the 1952 figure by more than 1,000,000 bags and representing an income of $460,000,000, or $75,000,000 more than in 1952.
An assertion that there is "only one chance in ten" of a depression in 1954 was made yesterday by Leo Cherne, executive director of the Research Institute of America, Inc.

SINGAPORE -- Malaya's tin industries employ about 45,000 workers in the mines. The industry is about 60 per cent European-owned, although many Asians are among the shareholders; the other 40 per cent is Chinese-owned.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan 5 (AP) -- Charles F. Carpentier, Secretary of State, announced today that all books withdrawn recently by the State Library were being restored to adult circulation.
MEXICO CITY -- The Government's careful controls resulted in a slight drop in the over-all cost of living for workers in Mexico last year despite crop failures.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- For its size and population, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico is the best per capita customer of the mainland. In fiscal 1952-53, the island bought $452,260,000 of mainland products, or roughly 10 per cent more than in the preceding twelve months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The United States Army listed today as "presumed dead" the names of 498 men who have been missing in action in Korea for more than a year.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The Ministry of Fuel and Power said today that 1953 coal production had declined 1,267,000 tons compared with 1952.

The latest claimant to the title of world's largest tanker -- as yet unnamed -- will be launched Feb. 9 from the Bethlehem Steel Company's Quincy, Mass., shipyard, it was announced yesterday. The ship is being constructed for Stavros S. Niarchos, operator of one of the world's largest independent tanker fleets. Its name will be announced at the launching.
A gold medal for outstanding contribution to the betterment of race relations and human welfare was presented yesterday to Paul G. Hoffman.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 5 -- The presidents of the eight Ivy colleges have approved a round-robin schedule in football and in all other sports in which it is found to be practicable.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic -- While sugar is the backbone of the Dominican Republic's economy, the Government's tax holiday for new industry has attracted more than 2,000 new establishments to this island during the last ten years. Against the $200,000,000 investment in sugar, at the end of 1953 there were in operation 3,720 businesses worth an estimated total of $175,000,000.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Form players had a miserable time of it at Tropical Park today, as T. C. Melrose's What Sir became the seventh straight losing choice in the featured Diego Valdez purse, won by Shawmut Stable's Gainsboro Girl.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Jan. 5 -- The debate here over the opinion of former Prime Minister David Ben Gurion that Zionists should move to Israel focuses attention on the fact behind the debate: This nation needs a new wave of immigrants with the pioneering spirit that established it.
A price war may be in the making in the synthetic fiber industry.

This is not a Happy New Year for Italy. It is unfortunate that Premier Giuseppe Pella should have had to resign now, and doubly unfortunate that the trouble should have been a rift in the Christian Democratic party to which he belongs. Had the party been able to retain its unity there would have been no crisis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Military Air Transport Service said today its transports carried more than half a million passengers and patients last year without a fatality.
MONTREAL, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs, warned the Western world tonight not to expect too much from negotiations with the Russians in 1954.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- The West German Social Democratic party, principal opposition to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government, reiterated today its assertion that the Allied - West German conventions were unconstitutional.

Fire losses throughout the United States last year cost the insurance industry and the public approximately $925,000,000. This is $40,000,000 more than the year before. The nation's staggering fire losses resulted from more than a million fires of all sizes -- from rubbish piles to spectacular multi-million dollar ones.

Aircraft manufacture, only fifty years old on Dec. 17, marked its place among the nation's industrial giants in 1953 with a gross of $9,000,000,000 indicated and a place as the second largest factory employer. Automobile manufacturing was first.

MEXICO CITY -- Shortly after he took office in December, 1952, President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines announced that his Government would seek no new foreign loans. Although this announcement has been repeated several times during 1953, outsiders are still skeptical.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Premier Joseph Laniel, according to plans approved by the Cabinet today, will ask for the shelving of all interpellations on foreign and domestic policy at the special session of the National Assembly tomorrow.

Because Brazil's export industries have not kept pace with the growth in the rest of the economy since the war, new emphasis is being placed on export production. This means basically more encouragement for agriculture, less for industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Unemployment in December rose 400,000 above November's figures and stood at 1,850,000 at the close of the year, the Department of Commerce announced today. At the end of December, 1952, the total was 1,425,000.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- East many battled the worst Baltic Sea floods in forty years today as gale-driven seas pounded Europe's coastal defenses and snowstorms coated the Continent white as far south as the toe of Italy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold decided today against making public a reply from the Jordan Government indicating Jordan's unwillingness to meet with Israel for high-level talks on their continuing disputes.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 5 -- This resort opened its centennial year at dusk today with the dedication of ultra modern boulevard lighting along the Boardwalk.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska -- The Territory of Alaska which has enjoyed "boom" economic conditions for more than twelve years, faced adjustment to a contracted but more stable economy during 1953. A reduction in appropriations for defense installations and Federal improvement projects forced Alaskans to turn to private business development to replace tile lost income.
OTTAWA (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government this week will start to bring together two companies in a joint project on a gas pipeline from Alberta to the East.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The case of the wayward bus was marked closed, or almost closed, at Cheshire Quarter Sessions yesterday, when William John Podmore pleaded guilty to driving under the influence of drink.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The one certain factor of Brazil's economic situation last year was continued uncertainty. Numerous corrective measures to overcome critical development, fiscal and trade problems were applied during 1953. The main question was: would they work in time?

Now that the holidays are out of the way, underwriters committed to buy $99,800,000 of Mackinac Straits Bridge revenue bonds are promoting the fiancial transaction among investment dealers invited to share in the sub-underwriting.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Although the 1953 football season resulted in nearly twice as many fatalities as 1952, there was no conclusive evidence that the change from double-platoon to single-platoon had any bearing upon the increase.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Chile is confronted as 1954 opens with the fact that her copper production has dropped from 20.37 per cent of world output in 1945 to under 13 per cent and may decline further unless conditions are improved.
LIMA, Peru --- Activity in the petroleum industry here reached such a high pitch that it surpassed that of Venezuela in the number of participating companies and extent of the area under exploration.

OTTAWA -- Canada is budgeting for an expenditure of $2,100,000,000 on defense in the next fiscal year. Half this sum, or nearly $1,000,000,000, is to be ear-marked for the development of the Air Force.

LIMA, Peru -- Last year proved to be a test of Peru's free trade system. But in spite of a sharp drop in the value of the Peruvian sol the economic situation here is still one of the soundest in South America.

About a year ago we remarked that a good many sensible people must wonder why casualty insurance companies, whose agents spend their working days trying to convince motorists that every car owner ought to be insured, were trying to convince the New York Legislature to the contrary.

OTTAWA -- Work will start next summer on the construction of the long-planned St. Lawrence seaway if United States courts dispose readily of legal actions to prevent the hydro - electric power part of the project.
Outdoor productions of the plays of Shakespeare may be seen next summer at Stratford, Conn., a historic town settled in 1639, twenty-three years after the death of the Bard.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic -- Despite the most discouraging crop-growing conditions in many years, 1953 was a satisfactory one for the Dominican Republic.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru appeared today to be attempting to check the landslide of anti- American and anti-Pakistani sentiment that has swept India since rumors of an arms pact between Washington and Karachi began.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Sugar still is king, but Gov. Luis Munoz Marin is working to turn this island from a one-crop economy to a balance between farming and manufacturing.

David Bronstein of Russia and C. H. O'D Alexander of England, held the first and second positions, respectively, yesterday in the international chess tournament at Hastings, according to a report from London.

MONTREAL -- Production in the newsprint mills of Canada increased during 1953 and there is every indication today that both consumption of and demand for Canadian newsprint are likely to be maintained or increased during the new year.
TORONTO -- In 1953 the Toronto Stock Exchange was once again North America's busiest market.

UNITED NATIONS, N, Y. -- Latin-American countries seeking the establishment of vastly expanded pulp and paper industries in the area have decided to hold their first regional conference in Buenos Aires this fall.

Buyers of infants' and children's wear for retail stores are not permitting forecasts of a downturn in business this year to affect their optimism. At two resident buying office meetings yesterday stores were advised to plan for sales gains.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- A combination of circumstances helped the stock markets to keep firm today. Prices rose slightly under the influence of the machinists' decision to postpone the ban on overtime, President Eisenhower's reference to the industrial outlook, good gold and dollar reserve figures, and cuts in the purchase tax.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- A gift of 100,000,000 francs ($285,700) from the Rockefeller brothers' fund for the restoration of the great chateau of Versailles was gratefully acknowledged today by the French Government.

The reports of the hearings before the Commission on Judicial Salaries indicate that we have learned very little in the course of the history of this country. The subject-matter of judicial salaries was considered in the first Senate of the United States. The report of the debate on the matter contained in the diary of William Maclay, who was a Senator from Pennsylvania, is illuminating.
NEW ORLEANS -- Business in the Deep South established many new records in 1953, and observers expect it to remain on a high plateau for at least six months longer.

MEXICO CITY -- That recession that some United States businessmen foresee this year in their country developed in Mexico last year. Most Mexicans attributed it to the Ruiz Cortines Government's anti-inflationary policies of curbing expenditures and cutting down on public works in line with earlier pledges to reduce the cost of living.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- The Bolivian Government fought a losing battle all through 1953 against monetary inflation and still does not seem to have conquered it. A foreign exchange shortage, as elsewhere in South America, added to the problem.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 5 -- The motion picture comedy "The Moon Is Blue," which was banned from this city last Oct. 14 as an "obscene" film, will be shown tomorrow despite continued opposition from Mayor Bernard J. Berry.

GENEVA, Jan. 5 -- Three countries of the thirty-four that signed the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade have not agreed to the continuation of the tariff truce that has prevailed among most nations of the free world since 1947.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 5 -- The smuggling of arms into South Africa and regular traffic of educated South African Negroes to and from Communist centers in the northern part of the hemisphere were reported today.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Cornell's basketball team won its third straight Eastern Intercollegiate League game tonight by defeating Columbia, 81 -- 73, in overtime.

HAVANA -- Efforts are being made by the Government to alleviate the growing unemployment brought about by the rapid increase in population and the lack of new industries. The situation also has been aggravated by the present downward trend of the island's economy.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston, whose resignation as Majority Leader of the State Senate came about last Dec. 16 because of his visits in prison to a convicted labor czar, will seek legislation to prevent others from being "entrapped" as he was.
A new Administrative Cabinet will be formed to meet weekly with Mayor Wagner on questions of top public policy and management.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Two Queens legislators will renew their fight at this session of the Legislature to give the Borough of Queens, and incidentally the Bronx and Richmond, equal representation with Manhattan and Brooklyn on the New York City Board of Estimate.

HAVANA -- Private capital is being invited to go into partnership with the Cuban Government in the operation of the United Railways of Havana. The line was purchased Dec. 1, 1953, by the Batista regime from its British owners and founders.

MONTREAL -- Discussions between the United States and Canada resulting in the decision to start work on at least one phase of the St. Lawrence River seaway project have lent new importance to the Richelieu River as a deep-sea waterway.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Great Lakes fleets don't expect to be in any hurry next spring to open the 1954 iron ore shipping season. Business probably will not demand it.
The world supply of newsprint reached virtually a return to normal last year. Real demand, representing ability to buy as well as consumption capacity, was met with adequate supply.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Irrigation programs in Latin American countries in the next four years cannot be expected to produce more than 2,471,000 acres for cultivation, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has estimated.

The Moreland Act Commission investigating harness racing was accused yesterday of embarking on "fishing expeditions" and violating constitutional rights by demanding extensive personal financial records from stockholders in the tracks.

Jerry Gilden's collection of resort designs, shown yesterday at Russeks, is nearly as gay and spirit-lifting as a trip to a sunny clime. The colors are fresh, the fabrics crisp in pretty cottons and crease-resistant imported linens and the prices temptingly low.

PRINCE ALBERT, Sask. -- Saskatchewan's commercial fish production for 1952-53 was the fourth biggest in the history of the industry here, although it declined from the previous year. The total of 10,612,095 pounds, valued at $1,440,000, was a drop of nearly 1,000,000 pounds in production and $308,500 in value from the 1951-52 fiscal year.
LONDON -- The tender solicitude with which the Government attempted to nurse Britain's export trade to robust health last year rivaled that given by a conscientious mother to a sickly child.

BUENOS AIRES -- Paraguay passed an economic milestone during 1953 when she signed a trade agreement with Argentina that may do much to keep her going, but also may prove to have put her in economic bondage.
MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's 1954 budget reflects plans for a vigorous public construction program, slightly larger than the program budgeted last year.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Jan. 5 (AP) -- The General Electric Company said today that it had protested the Government's award of a $3,651,476 contract to a British concern for building two giant electric power generators.

Some new investment money undoubtedly went into securities yesterday as a result of President Eisenhower's promise of action to avert economic troubles this year. But most folk in Wall Street attributed the rise, which early in the session went to about 2 points in key areas, to normal January reinvestment demand.

WHEN there are only south-wall tables for customers in the old La Fayette Restaurant in Pearl Street south of Wall, the gentleman at the counter asks new patrons to surrender their watches before they sit to dine.

HAVANA -- The establishment of a national fishing institute to control both commercial and sport fishing in Cuba has been recommended to President Fulgencio Batista by the National Board of Economy. The President and Council of Ministers will consider the project in the next few weeks.
Borrowers in Latin-American countries continued to have access to the credit of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development during 1953.

Of the $3,200,000,000 increase in United States private foreign investments from 1950 to mid-1953, more than two-thirds was concentrated in the Western Hemisphere. This continuing trend was noted in a report issued recently by the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Latin America with its soaring population rate must step up agricultural production by at least 25 per cent in the next ten years or risk further deterioration of an already precarious food supply.

Chancellor Henry T. Heald of New York University said yesterday that some of the opposition to the Washington Square Southeast slum clearance project, where rents are to be $48 a room, was "irresponsible and false."

LIMA, Peru -- An important new export for Peru, and one that is highly welcome in view of reduced returns from other metals, was begun in May when the first iron ore shipments were made from the Marcona deposits, 340 miles south of Lima. An
Stockholders of the United States Trust Company of New York yesterday approved a series of changes in the bank's 100-year-old charter.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 5 -- A complete economic survey of this city's Medical Center was ordered today by Mayor Bernard J. Berry. The major named John Shaver, business manager of the Jersey City Board of Education, to conduct the survey.

EDMONTON, Alberta -- Sparked by oil and gas developments, Alberta, long a predominantly agricultural province, made great new strides toward a more balanced economy in 1953. The year's developments in the economic picture have been:

WASHINGTON -- A Uruguayan biologist has isolated from several species of spiders an apparently powreful antibiotic against both microscopic disease-causing plants -- bacteria -- and microscopic animals -- protozoa.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador -- Last year was a disappointing one for Ecuador's business men and farmers. Agriculture production, as a result of the most disastrous spring rains in three decades, declined and for the first time in three years the nation's imports exceeded its exports.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua (AP) -- President Anastasio Somoza is also Nicaragua's biggest landowner. So it may be only natural that he is pushing an agricultural revolution in the country he has ruled for twenty years.

Dr. Leona Baumgartner's first assignment as Commissioner of Health will be to review the organization of the department to see where changes recommended in the Gulick Report two years ago are applicable today.

MEXICO CITY -- Soft world market conditions and dropping prices were the main headaches of the Mexican mining and petroleum industries last year. When final statistics are in, both are expected to show production declines from 1952.

The old International Long- shoremen's Association got another $50,000 yesterday from John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers. The contribution brings to $100,000 the help the union has received from the miners' head in the fight to hold control of the piers against an American Federation of Labor challenge.

The major news in the world sugar situation last year was the approval of the International Sugar Agreement in London. The pact established a maximum and a minimum price for the commodity and fixed an export quota for each producing country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Sharp criticism of the Federal Government was expressed by the United States Court of Claims today in an opinion that gave Norton Clapp a $7,500 judgment against the United States.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii's economy, which is built on military spending, sugar, pineapples and tourists in about that order as far as dollar income goes, enjoyed a relatively healthy year in 1953. Prospects are good for sound conditions to continue in 1954.

Historical exhibits in connection with the 200th anniversary of the founding of Columbia University were placed on view yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York and the New York Historical Society.

The C. B. S. television network is considering the initiation of an afternoon wrestling program on Saturdays and has set a tentative starting date of Feb. 6 from 4 to 5 o'clock. The program would originate at Legion Stadium in Hollywood.
Mexico, Cuba, Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela were named at the recent National Foreign Trade Convention in New York as countries where television advertising is both available and practical.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Manufacturers sold $24,200,000,000 worth of goods in November, the Department of Commerce reported today.
LONDON -- The long-sought goal of freely convertible currencies was brought a step nearer during 1953.

Ibargaruera Park in Sao Paulo, Brazil, is being transformed in preparation for the city's celebration of its 400th anniversary. The festivities, which will start July 9, 1954, and continue for three months, will be marked by an international trade fair, the main buildings of which are being erected.

Hilde Gueden, who sang her first Zerlina at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, is evidently no stranger to this role in Mozart's "Don Giovanni." She undoubtedly has sung it at the Vienna Opera, and her performance last night had the assurance and poise she brings to everything she does.

Opposition to the proposed Washington Square Southeast slum clearance project flared anew yesterday. It was in response to a statement Tuesday by Chancellor Henry T. Heald of New York University that the position taken by some opponents of the development was "irresponsible and false."
Three major employer associations in the women's coat and suit industry will increase their contributions to an employe pension fund.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The State Department announced tonight that the Soviet Union was willing to "exchange views" in Washington on preparations for a proposed conference on atomic energy.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The French decision on the European Defense Community treaty is expected to depend largely on the results of the four-power Berlin conference and of negotiations between France on one side and the United States and Britain on the other.
The continued public pronouncements by financial leaders concerning the coming recession can easily accelerate the harm our Administration in Washington is trying to prevent.

Leading art historians and critics, museum directors and archeologists from twenty-seven countries attended yesterday the opening session of an international art congress arranged by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein upheld today the constitutionality of the plan for redrawing the State's Senate district lines that was enacted by a special session of the Legislature last November.

The dogged campaign led by Senator Bricker and the dominant elements of the American Bar Association to hobble the President's treaty-making powers will soon be fought out on the floor of the Senate. It seems incredible that this proposal, at once so revolutionary and so retrogressive, should have received enough support to make it the major issue it has now become.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Eisenhower and other officials of the Government prayed for divine guidance this morning at the traditional worship on the opening of Congress.

The appointment of David A. Shepard as chairman of the 1954 campaign of the Greater New York Fund was announced yesterday by John A. Coleman, board chairman. Mr. Shepard is a director of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and former board chairman of the Anglo-American Oil Company (now Esso Petroleum Company, Ltd.) of London. He succeeds C. Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange and 1953 chairman.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 6 -- Premier Fazlollah Zahedi conferred with Denis Arthur Wright, the new British Charge d'Affaires, today on alternative proposals for settling Iran's oil dispute with Britain. The meeting, which lasted more than an hour, was attended by Abdullah Entezam, Foreign Minister.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, refused to comment today on the next step to be taken against R. K. O. Radio Pictures for violating the production code by exhibiting "The French Line" without benefit of a code seal.
The concept of the economy-sized yacht for the millions came a bit closer yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's Annual Message to the Legislature, delivered at a joint session today:

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 6 -- A police raid halted "The Moon Is Blue" today, but the raiders joined 434 adult patrons in watching the controversial movie at the Stanley Theatre before taking the manager to police headquarters and banning further viewings.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- Plans for a ten-story $6,000,000 office building on the northeast corner of Fourth and Chestnut Streets, facing the new National Historical Park project at Independence Hall, were announced today.
The sun had been up only forty minutes yesterday morning when a thousand persons sat down to the thirteenth annual "dawn patrol" breakfast of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America.

WESTOVER AIR BASE, Mass., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Sixteen Civil Air Patrol wings and the police in eight states today were alerted to search for a yellow biplane, unheard from since yesterday while flying from Bradley Field, Conn., to Richmond, Va.

The main store of Abraham Straus in Brooklyn and its branches in Garden City and Hempstead, L. I., set a sales record in 1953 -- "just a whisker under 100 million dollars," according to Walter Rothschild, president.

Coffee and cocoa continued upward yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices ended irregularly higher with cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber, potatoes and copper also stronger. Sugar, wool, hides and lead moved lower and burlap and zinc closed mixed.
Concerning your Jan. 1 editorial "Justice for the Family":

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to set aside Ohio's motion picture censorship laws as violative of the guarantees of freedom of speech and the press embodied in the First Amendment to the Constitution.

With the effective date of the New York Stock Exchange's monthly payment plan for the purchase of stocks little more than two weeks off, an educational drive is in progress among member firms. The Exchange has sent out its sales kit. Exchange officers are trying to make sure that every customer's broker understands the plan before Jan. 25.

Howard Fast, Stalin Peace Prize winner, and Frank V. Coe, former secretary of the International Monetary Fund, appeared last night, as "prosecution witnesses" at a mock trial of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Senator Austin W. Erwin of Geneseo, Livingston County, today was appointed chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, the second most important post in that body.

A fact little stressed in the comments on the French Presidential election is that the new President, Rene Coty, has been chairman of the federalist group of the, Senate and a deputy member of the Assembly of the European Union. Thus, while not a conspicuous advocate, he has proved himself in favor of European integration.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The resignation of Premier Giuseppe Pella's Government has suddenly exposed Italy as the weak link in the North Atlantic alliance's chain of defenses of free Europe between Turkey and Norway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Extension of a liberalized reciprocal trade program for at least ten years is expected to be recommended to Congress about Jan. 16. The seventeenmember Randall Commission on foreign economic policy is slated to complete its report at sessions Saturday and Monday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Leopold Stokowski bowed tonight to a decree of the Daughters of the American Revolution, and conducted a scheduled concert in Constitution Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Congressional and Treasury experts have agreed on a change in United States tax laws that could make additional hundreds of millions of dollars of private funds available for investment abroad.

The American Fund for Israel Institutions announced last night the donation of $250,000 from Fredric R. Mann, president of the Robin Hood Dell Concerts in Philadelphia, for the building of the Tel Aviv Cultural Center in Israel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A suggestion that farmers be permitted to choose their own farm programs by law came today from Representative Clifford R. Hope, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Seaboard and Western Airlines of New York be certified to operate a scheduled trans-Atlantic air freight service.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 7 -- The United Nations ground forces commander in Korea warned the South Korean Government yesterday against violent action to free the 22,000 anti-Communist prisoners of war. He also promised protection to the Indian guard force.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- The Soviet Union accepted today the Western proposal that preparatory talks for the Big Four foreign ministers' conference begin tomorrow morning at British headquarters in West Berlin.

Although "Mademoiselle Colombe" is the most interesting of the Jean Anouilh plays done in New York, he is still a perplexing author. Perplexing to us, that is: in Paris he is wholly understood and admired. The new play, put on at the Longacre last evening in an idiomatic adaptation by Louis Kronenberger, is a backstage play about the pangs of love.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The opposition has conceded privately that the Senate will approve a bill authorizing the United States to join Canada in construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway project.
Women headed by Mrs. Henry G. Hay have been holding meetings recently at the Ambassador to further plans for two theatre benefits for the North Country Community Association.

No travel folder for southern vacations has more lure than Bergdorf Goodman's collection of resort fashions. Shown yesterday at the store, they put the onlooker in a haze with the many charming rosebud prints, almost endless shades of delectable pastel pinks, and completely refreshing individuality and prettiness of the clothes.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The stock markets were uneven today, closing prices showing both falls and rises.

Canada's prosperity, zest and material expansion provide a bright spot in the world today. One gets a positive glow of pleasure in the contemplation of a young nation coming to a rich maturity so quickly and honorably. To see such progress in a nation devoted to democracy and free enterprise is a double satisfaction.

The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company has dropped its sponsorship of the various Arthur Godfrey television and radio programs. Through Cunningham Walsh, Inc., its advertising agency, the company said "we were unable to arrive at a satisfactory agreement" with the Columbia Broadcasting System for continuation of sponsorship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Dr. Farid Zeineddine of Syria has been called home for consultations involving his Government's complaint to the United Nations Security Council against Israel. The case concerns Syria's protest last October that an Israeli hydroelectric project on the Jordan River would divert the waterway in violation of the Syrian-Israeli armistice agreement of 1949.
