MANILA, Jan. 6 -- Oscar Castelo, a top man in former President Elpidio Quirino's Cabinet, was indicted for murder yesterday. He was accused in the slaying six months ago of Manuel Monroy, the principal witness against him in disbarment proceedings brought during the recent political campaign.

The "dean" of passenger traffic managers will retire on Feb. 15. He is Leo E. Archer, general passenger traffic manager of the Moore-McCormack Lines, whose many friends in the shipping industry toasted his half-century career at a luncheon yesterday aboard the liner Uruguay at Pier 32, Hudson River.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senate Republican leaders decided today to give high priority to the Bricker amendment limiting Federal treaty-making powers, following a new attempt by the Ohio sponsor of the measure and the Administration to reach a compromise.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission tightened its proxy rules today to curb publicity-seeking stockholders.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- An issue of $61,005,000 in state housing serial bonds was sold today by State Controller J. Raymond McGovern to a banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank of New York. The net interest cost under the bid was 2.3659 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Congress will get President Eisenhower's Taft-Hartley message next Monday, but informed belief is that:

Leonardo da Vinci made important contributions to it, Count Rumford and Sir Humphry Davy studied it, two Frenchmen are credited with the basic invention, but it remained for an American medical school professor working on a roof-top in Washington Square to employ photography for the first time in making a successful portrait of a human face.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A national allotment of 21,374,000 acres for the 1954 cotton crop was agreed upon today by the Senate Agriculture Committee.

"His and Hers," a new comedy by Fay and Michael Kanin, costarring Celeste Holm and Robert Preston, opens at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock. The producers are Albert Selden and Morton Gottlieb.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Governor Dewey called upon the Legislature today to write into law a series of measures to raise the moral and ethical standards of Government officials and political party leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Bernard Lonctot, Washington Statee's Chief Deputy Attorney General, said today that Gov. Arthur B. Langlie need not worry about a "recall threat" made by Senator Warren B. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, over the state's participation in the Hell's Canyon case.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The perennial issue of New York City's financial problems got much friendlier treatment from Governor Dewey in his annual message to the Legislature today than he has been giving it in recent years.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The French National Assembly gave Premier Joseph Laniel a substantial vote of confidence tonight so that France could have strong representation at the four-power conference at Berlin. The tally was 319 to 249.

For a time last night it appeared as if the New York Rangers were about to stumble over the jinx that the Chicago Black Hawks have worked on them several times this season. As the sextets exchanged pokes and checks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden though, the New Yorkers gradually asserted their superiority and managed to win by the score of 4 to 3.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 6 -- French Union and Vietminh troops clashed in central Laos yesterday in the biggest battle since the Vietminh forces advanced to the Mekong River ten days ago.
Ben Hogan was named the "male athlete of the year" for 1953 yesterday in the twenty- third annual Associated Press poll.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The United States Army and the Air Force released today additional lists of personnel who have been missing in action in Korea for more than one year and in whose cases a presumptive finding of death now has been made. The lists included the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

A twelve-story loft building on lot 28.6 by 92 feeet at 9 West Twentieth Street has been purchased by Abraham Fingerhut and Elliott H. Robinson, investing clients of Jacob Shapiro, attorney, through J. P. and L. A. Kissling, brokers.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 6 -- The modern trend in church architecture was hailed here today by top-flight church designers. But they took a very dim view of "freak" edifices that violate the basic tenets of church building.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday that his administration would seek to forestall delays in school construction by advance purchase of sites in areas where schools might be needed in the future.
The Bach Aria Group presented its second concert last night in Town Hall. One entire cantata -- No. 114 -- was presented, in addition to a number of solo and concerted arias.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6 -- Led by a sophomore guard, Elsy Morgan, who scored 21 points, Yale University ruined Dartmouth's Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League opener by beating the Indians, 60--58, tonight.
BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- Prof. Maurice Halperin, chairman of Latin American Regional Studies at Boston University, was dismissed today by the Board of Trustees.
The Robert Gair Company has sold the factory property it formerly occupied in Bogota, N. J., to Alford Cartons, a subsidiary of the Continental Paper Company. J. L Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
After four successive days of advances, the stock market appeared to take a recess yesterday. Many traders were waiting for the President's State of the Union address today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 6 (UP) -- Greentree Stable's Straight Face, currently campaigning in Florida, today headed twenty-one nominees for the Santa Anita Maturity kept eligible by 1954 payments of $200, Frank E. Kilroe, racing secretary, disclosed.

Today's new film is "Knights of the Round Table," a Metro- Goldwyn-Mayer adventure in Technicolor with Robert Taylor, Ava Gardner and Mel Ferrer, at the Radio City Music Hall. It will be the first CinemaScope presentation there. Richard Thorpe directed and Pandro S. Berman produced the offering, which is based on Sir Thomas Malory's "Le Morte D'Arthur."

LONDON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- A flood alert was broadcast along the low-lying British coasts tonight. Northwest winds lashed the North Sea on the eve of peak tides like those that breached seawalls last year and killed 1,700 persons.

St. Francis outhustled and outfought Fordham last night to score one of the basketball season's most notable upsets. A second-half rally gave the Terriers a well-earned 53 -- 49 decision over the Rams before 3,000 jubilant onlookers at the Second Corps Artillery Armory in Brooklyn which serves as St. Francis' home court.

Chase National Bank's resources, deposits and loans at the end of last year were higher than at the close of the previous quarter, but below the 1952 year-end figures, according to the bank's statement of condition published today.
Gustavo, who recently started his own millinery salon at 57 West Fifty-sixth Street, showed his second collection yesterday. It was one of great originality.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 6 -- The television committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association virtually let it be known today that it would recommend a continuation of the controlled telecasting of college football games on a national basis in 1954.

VIENNA, Jan. 6 -- Chancellor Julius Raab said today that if the Berlin conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers did not bring a satisfactory result for Austria his Government would demand that the United States and the Soviet Union reduce their occupation garrisons to "symbolic occupation forces."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The second session of the Eighty-third Congress opened today in a genial hubbub that shortly will become a dogged partisan test in an election year.

Canned meats will be advertised and promoted this year in the largest industry-wide program ever undertaken, according to the National Meat Canners Association, Chicago. The campaign will be supported by brand advertising of individual producers.
Directors of the Ingersoll-Rand Company voted a dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock yesterday, payable on March 3.
DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The nation's highways are being used by more than 50,000,000 motor vehicles.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 -- West Germany is proceeding with plans to increase imports and reduce taxes in 1954.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Grain futures and soybeans made an effort to extend the advance which got under way yesterday, but buying support faded and there were sharp recessions from the early tops in all pits. March and May wheat deliveries showed relative strength, but July and September were weak and sharply lower before the end of the session.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 6 -- Australia expects to export an appreciable quantity of uranium oxide before the end of 1954 from a new treatment plant at Rum Jungle in Northern Territory, which will be in production in August. Uranium from the Rum Jungle field comes from pitchblende, which yields uranium 235, most highly prized source of atomic power.

Houghton Mifflin will receive today the twelfth annual Carey-Thomas Award for the editorial planning, production and handling of "The History of the Second World War" by Sir Winston Churchill, now brought to completion in six volumes. The presentation will be made at a luncheon at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- An undercover informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation conceded today under cross-examination that it was not necessary to be a Communist party member to hold office in the Labor Youth League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today he doubted that the Canadian Government would agree to release the transcript of the secret interview he and Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, had with Igor Gouzenko.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- The board of directors of the Guidance Center of New Rochelle, Inc., unanimously affirmed tonight their confidence in Dr. Goodwin Watson, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

A Canadian nurse severely crippled by angina pectoris, who had been warned that she might not live to reach New York for an operation, is now recovering at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital. On Dec. 21 she had undergone what is popularly known as the "talcum powder" operation on the heart, and is expected to return shortly to her job.

RABBIT MARANVILLE was about as big as a leprechaun and had all of a leprechaun's elfin instinct. And he added a few refinements of his own, those that no self-respecting leprechaun ever would countenance. In his sudden death yesterday, baseball lost one of its most colorful and most remarkable operatives. The Rabbit was definitely a character, a well-intentioned performer who never harmed anyone but himself.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Countess Dorothy di Frasso, international society figure, bequeathed property worth more than $1,000,000 almost entirely to a niece, Miss Mary Taylor, under a will filed for probate today in Superior Court. The document was dated March 2, 1941

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts proposed today a 25 per cent cut in personal income taxes. He asked the Legislature for speedy action to make the reduction retroactive for 1953 incomes.

Although business activity has slowed, "conditions which would be expected to bring on a major business decline are not generally evident," The National City Bank of New York observes in its annual report to stockholders.

THIS week marks the end of another waterfowl season along the Atlantic flyway, and according to guides and shooters, the waterfowl population approximated that of last year and the shooting conditions were only slightly better.

Murray (Muzz) Patrick came to terms with Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick yesterday, and will become the coach of the New York Rangers on Saturday. Although the matter had been under discussion for several weeks, it became an actuality yesterday when General Kilpatrick announced the agreement after a phone conversation with Patrick in Seattle.

Boston's Ed Macauley was the only unanimous choice of the basketball writers and broadcasters who selected the rosters for the National Basketball Association's fourth annual All-Star game that will be played in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 21.
KHARTUM, The Sudan, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- Ismail el Azhari, leader of the majority National Unionist party in the Sudan's new Parliament, was elected the country's first Prime Minister today.
Mayor Wagner named a panel of three members yesterday to find the facts in the dispute over a new contract between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Members of the House of Representatives, where bills were admitted on the opening day of the new session, introduced some 200 measures today.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Sir Thomas Sopwith critized the Government today for complacency and lack of leadership in developing high-speed and high-altitude research and in applying atomic and nuclear power to aircraft propulsion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The nation's debt increased by $9,060,984,648.80 in the first half of this fiscal year.
Mrs. Winthrop Rockefeller declared yesterday that the charge that she had made a $10,000,000 demand on her estranged husband was "real nonsense."
The new City Council held its first meeting yesterday with a personal blessing from Mayor Wagner and a 100 per cent increase in Republican membership.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Federal Trade Commission served notice today that the change in national administration would not serve as a means for reopening cases on which the commission dominated by President Truman's appointees had already acted.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Tony Trabert carried America's hopes in the semi-finals of the South Australia tennis championships today as the fans continued to talk about the disputed doubles in the recent Davis Cup challenge round.

Many persons of Russian descent living here will celebrate Christmas today. The Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church follows the older Julian calendar, which observes Christmas thirteen days after the Dec. 25 date of the Gregorian calendar.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A tanker collision on the Delaware River that took nine lives last Wednesday is attributed by Philadelphia maritime interests to "inadequate" channel facilities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Western observers here said today that the talks in Washington, if they were fruitful, would lead back to detailed consideration of the President's plan at the United Nations.

A. G. Spalding Bros., Inc., leading domestic manufacturer of sporting goods, improved its consolidated net earnings in the fiscal year ended with last October to $677,092 from $134,199 the year before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed alarm today about the recent "sharp increase" in unemployment -- 688,000 more jobless in two months -- and called on Congress to do something about it.

Pink roses in varying hues transformed the main ballroom of the Plaza and the adjoining foyer into a rose garden for the entertainment and dinner dance known as the Ball of the Roses held there last night for the benefit of the Roosevelt Hospital School of Nursing Building Fund. Proceeds will be used for the construction of a dormitory floor in the hospital's new building for the School of Nursing.

Designed to flatter a woman's face, accent classic suits and harmonize with dressier clothes, the Laddie Northridge millinery collection, presented yesterday morning in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel, included hats for all occasions.

Attractive fabrics, wearable designs and moderate prices were noted in the collection of Nelly Don fashions previewed by Macy's. Starting next Monday, informal showings will take place in the new Nelly Don department on the store's fourth floor, Seventh Avenue building.

The Soviet reply to President Eisenhower's proposal for an atomic energy pool makes a damaging admission in its clumsy attempt to propagandize. The statement, in speaking of the usefulness of the Geneva Protocol of 1925, says that "the fact that in the Second World War not a single Government decided to use chemical and bacteriological weapons shows that the aforementioned agreement * * * was of positive importance."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 6 -- Canadian and Australian civil aviation authorities began conferences here today to review competitive rights to operate air services between the two countries. The conference decisions will be embodied in an agreement between the two governments.
A gift of $10 for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund came yesterday from Harold C. Many, who hoped the money might help keep together the couples in Cases 4 and 9.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman, the Australian star, took the lead in The Philadelphia Inquirer Masters' round- robin professional tennis tournament tonight by defeating Don Budge, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, for his second straight victory.

Ernie Howard of the University Club, top-seeded in the New York State singles squash racquets tournament at the Downtown A. C., eliminated Charley Mattman, Downtown A. C., in the second round yesterday.

CAIRO, Jan. 6 -- The Egyptian Government has been informed that its current tactical flirtation with a policy of neutralism endangers its chances of obtaining United States economic and diplomatic assistance.
Mayor Wagner reported yesterday that law enforcement agencies in this port were ready to cope with any violence that might grow out of the tense waterfront labor situation.
The Queens District Attorney began a new effort yesterday to prosecute nine men and a corporation for alleged conspiracy and fraud in the construction of faulty sewers in Laurelton.
The following is the text of Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams' introductory talk and directions to 400 ranking officers at Police Headquarters yesterday:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Small home and estate owners between Elsmford and Rye are anxiously awaiting the scheduled announcement within a week of the route of a crossWestchester link between the main New York-Buffalo Thruway and the independent New England Thruway.
"A further modest cutback" in production is planned for this month by the Studebaker Corporation, but, just the same, the company plans to sell more cars in 1954 than in 1953.

An increase of 4,045,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 160,075,000 barrels, compared with 156,030,000 a week earlier and 137,016,000 a year ago.
Academic freedom in this country will continue under attack because many Americans fail to understand the basic purpose of a university, the president of Princeton University declared last night.

VIENNA, Jan 6 (AP) -- Poland's movie fans are fed up with their diet of tedious Communist propaganda productions. A Polish press comment reaching here says they want to see Charlie Chaplin--and some of those French and Italian beauties.

ROME, Jan. 6 -- Several leaders of the Christian Democratic party decided today not to propose Premier Giuseppe Pella to President Luigi Einaudi as a suitable candidate to form a new Italian Government.
An agreement on a contract covering recording musicians for the next five years was reached yesterday.

John L. Lewis is reported to have promised sufficient financial aid to the old International Longshoremen's Association to enable it to pay benefits to its members if they go on strike. We wonder. Even if such benefits amounted to no more than $40 a week per individual it would add up to $2,000,000 a week for 50,000 longshoremen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The conflicting briefs submitted to the Supreme Court in the submerged lands dispute are falling "thick as autumnal leaves that strow the brooks in Vallombrosa." Among them is the Attorney General of Louisiana's frontal assault on the legal position of his opposite number in Alabama.

I'm a native New Yorker thus have never bought a New York "souvenir." However, on Fifth Avenue recently my eye was caught by a five-and-ten window crowded with what looked like a collection of junk. On closer study, this turned out to be an infinite variety of souvenirs of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Upper Colorado River Commission started a counterattack today on groups seeking to block construction of Echo Park Dam as a unit of the Upper Colorado Basin reclamation project.

At the close of play in the seventh round of the international chess masters tournament in Hastings, England, the two Russian masters, David Bronstein and Alexander Tolush, occupied first and second places, respectively, according to a report from London yesterday.

Seventy-nine public school teachers in this city have been dismissed or have given up their jobs after having been called for questioning in the Board of Education's inquiry into subversive influences in the schools. Seventeen others, out of the total of 151 questioned, admitted past membership in the Communist party and retained their positions.

Although another week remains before the National Motor Boat Show opens in Kingsbridge Armory on Jan. 15, the first of a long succession of preliminaries yesterday virtually could be regarded as belonging to the Show excitement.

Textile research achieved hundreds of improvements in synthetic and natural fibers in 1953 as well as advances in weaving, spinning and dyeing methods, J. B. Goldberg, consulting textile and chemical engineer, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, declared today that he favored giving to a single Senate committee exclusive jurisdiction to investigate communism and subversion.
DETROIT, Jan. 6 -- Solution of the shotgun shooting on April 20, 1948, of Walter P. Reuther was announced today by Wayne County Prosecutor Gerald K. O'Brien.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- Details of collective bargaining election among 6,000 West Coast stewards' department members, should an election be ordered, were discussed today by union leaders, shipowners and officials of the National Labor Relations Board.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly, a veteran of many political wars, sidetracked today before it got under way a rumor that his association with Governor Dewey had fallen on evil days.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Jan. 6 -- The touchy subject of the production and consumption of pork in Israel came before the Knesset (Parliament) today.

A topsy-turvy picture of voting procedures in the old International Longshoremen's Association went on view in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday as sidelights to the contempt trial of Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia and the I. L. A.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Legislature moved rapidly at its opening session today to implement Governor Dewey's proposal to establish a code of ethics for government and party officials.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- "I have a cow, a lot of work, a lot of worries and I am hungry," a Russian peasant mother wrote to her soldier son to explain why she was selling her cow.
Unemployment in December increased by 400,000 over the month previous, to 1,850,000, according to the monthly figures of the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Two top-ranking United States officials, returning from the Far East, expressed confidence today that the release of Korean war prisoners on Jan. 23 would be accomplished without trouble and that peace negotiations would be resumed.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 -- Mexican authorities indicated today that the assassin of Leon Trotsky would have to serve out his full twenty-year prison sentence.

The James Room, the first student social center at Barnard College, was officially opened yesterday when Mrs. Gavin MacBain, chairman of the college's development committee, presented a key to the room to Miss Sue Nagelberg, president of the Undergraduate Association. A reception followed.

A sealed bid for outright purchase of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway Company, was submitted yesterday to Federal Judge Edward A. Conger. He also granted a prospective bidder until Jan. 13 the right to submit his offer for the road appraised in 1942 by the Interstate Commerce Commission at $42,000,000.
A Federal judge refused yesterday to issue an injunction limiting the scope of an investigation by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The Secret Service made three more arrests in the $160,000 Government money vault theft today.

SAIGON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Informants reported today that Prince Buu Loc, chosen by Chief of State Bao Dai to form a new Vietnam Government, had been turned down by almost all the political parties. These sources said the prince was about ready to give up.

Thomas E. Dewey enters upon his twelfth year of duty as Governor of New York with an annual message thoughtful in its discussion of the problems of public and party office, prudent in its fiscal policy and constructively forward-looking in new program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The railroads of the United States today told the Interstate Commerce Commission that they would be willing to accept a 10 per cent increase in their compensation for carrying the United States mails, in lieu of the 45 per cent boost they asked last June. The increase would be, at their request, retroactive to last Oct. 1.

The two four-story buildings containing thirty-two apartments at 1051 and 1057 Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn have been purchased by the Tulman Realty Corporation. Lennard Sons, Inc., were the brokers in the transaction and title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Jan. 7 -- Akira Shiraishi, a Japanese cameraman employed by United Press Movietone News, was convicted by a Korean court here today on charges of assault. He was sentenced to pay a fine of 10,000 whon (about $55) or a prison term to be served at the rate of one day for each 100 whon.

The Salvation Army's 1954 fund appeal here was begun yesterday at a reception at the Metropolitan Club given by Burl S. Watson, president of the Cities Service Company and general campaign chairman. The goal is $1,250,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Congress opened today, and was sized up by the younger generation. Thus:
Six investment banking syndicates competed yesterday for the underwriting of two new issues of public utility securities valued at about $60,000,000.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 6 -- Ceylonese political and press circles are expressing grave concern over the growing division between India and Pakistan as a result of the proposed United States military aid to Pakistan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers will not settle for the 5-cent-an-hour pay rise accepted by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen last month, Guy L. Brown, grand chief engineer, said today.
The Communists are trying to organize a propaganda "trial" around the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, executed American atom spies.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Two college athletic officials told the sports division of the American College Public Relations Association today that college football was facing a fight for survival against the pro game.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Bobby Dykes stepped into the middleweight title picture tonight when he pounded out a unanimous decision over Joey Giambra, the fifth-ranking contender, in a fast 10-round event.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Three Westerners won places today on the Nordic squad that will represent the United States in next month's world ski championships in Falun, Sweden.

Plans for an apartment development in the Sutton Place area on the East Side that will cost $1,000,000, including the value of the land and the proposed improvement, were announced yesterday by Frank Grasso, builder, who has enlarged the site for the project.

Professional basketball will take over the Madison Square Garden court tonight. The Baltimore Bullets will meet the New York Knickerbockers there in the second game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 30, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- A Treasury agent disclosed today that $165,000 in currency and bank drafts destined for Communist China had been seized in the mails here since Dec. 19.
The curtain seems about to be rung down on the Vanderbilt Theatre at 148 West Forty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Retailers attending the annual winter home furnishings market picked out lamps and carpets today as two items that should sell particularly well this year. Freezers, driers and waste disposal units are expected to be especially strong among the appliances.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A rookie in the House of Representatives set out on an experiment today.

William G. Smith of Trenton, N. J., chairman of a stockholders' committee opposed to the present management of American Woolen Company, said yesterday that almost 200 stockholders have given him proxies to vote "no" on the proposed reorganization of the company.
Burglar alarm companies in the city complained yesterday that the New York Telephone Company was discriminating against them and hurting their business.
Organized baseball's first step toward "cleaning house," so to speak, is set for today when a nine-man committee opens a two-day session with Commissioner Ford C. Frick at the Hotel Biltmore.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams called together yesterday 400 ranking officers who constitute the police "brass" and directed them to rub off the tarnish of a succession of scandals.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Following is an English translation of the Soviet communique announcing Russian agreement to procedural talks on negotiations in Washington on atomic energy:
The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday that it would experimentally introduce food vending machines in a dining car on the New York-Washington run tomorrow.
A public demonstration of what is believed to be the first successful use of a machine to translate meaningful texts from one language to another took place here yesterday afternoon.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 7 -- Optimism as to the future was expressed today by Edgar F. Kaiser, president of Kaiser Motors and its subsidiary, Willys Motors.
OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- Two Canadians were put to death at Sing Sing prison here tonight for the murder last May 2 of a Buffalo, N. Y. jeweler.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- The Screen Writers Guild has informed Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, that it desires to play an active part in any contemplated revision of the production code.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, announced today three moves that may provide a clear-cut court test of his subcommittee's jurisdiction and its right to inquire into personal beliefs and associations.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 7 -- Church construction is headed for its biggest Yeas in history.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Daniel J. Davies, the London laborer who recently billed New York for $5 owed him for shoveling snow one night in 1926, has received a number of letters, some containing cash, from well-wishers in the United States.

The Long Island Rail Road won a respite yesterday from a strike threat by trainmen. Simultaneously, the railroad clashed with the state Public Service Commission over the line's campaign for higher passenger tariffs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The constitutional right of New York to censor motion pictures in advance of public exhibition was debated in the Supreme Court today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 7 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies explained today that the reasons for Australia's failure to sign the declaration extending the operation of tariff concession under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) had been completely misunderstood by overseas commentators.
Despite wishful thinking to the contrary, the battle against poliomyelitis has not yet been won, Basil O'Connor reiterated yesterday.
The best protein buys for main dishes this weekend will be found in popular cuts of beef and lamb and in small broiling and frying chickens.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message on the State of the Union delivered to Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

Directors of the Cudahy Packing Company deferred action again yesterday on the quarterly dividend on the 4 1/2 per cent preferred stock, normally payable Jan. 15, "until such date as may later be determined by directors." The last payment was $1.12 1/2, in October, 1952.
BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Musicians and artists were back in harmony tonight in Boston night clubs after an apparent out-of-court settlement of a local dispute.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Except for compulsory automobile insurance, most of Governor Dewey's legislative program today appeared assured of approval by the Republican controlled Legislature.
The New York Young Republican Club called on Governor Dewey yesterday to run for election to a fourth term.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Three leading Chicago mail-order houses said today that their December gross sales had been down from those of a year earlier.

President Eisenhower's State of the Union address failed to have its expected bullish effect on the stock market yesterday. Prices; soft and hesitant before the speech, continued their gradual decline afterward and closed irregularly lower.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower's declaration in his State of the Union Message that Hawaii was "ready for statehood" was challenged today in Senate hearings.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 -- Dr. Leo F. Rettger, Professor Emeritus of Bacteriology at Yale University, was found dead today in his car in a closed garage in the rear of his home.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower proposed today a future farm program built on flexible Federal price supports to keep agricultural products out of storage and in consumers' hands.
Two children were burned to death and four adults injured yesterday afternoon when a three-alarm fire wrecked the three top floors of two Harlem tenements.

Your reporter Clayton Knowles has been the victim of misinformation in his story in The Times of Jan. 4 when he indicates that perhaps I am the "high former Red" who is expected to expose subversion before the Jenner committee.

I do not object to the three-cent increase in the fare for the Fifth Avenue buses, but I do object to the type of "service" that patrons of the line have been getting -- or should I say have been inflicted with -- for lot these many years.
Television acquired an electronic split personality yesterday.

Beethoven is the composer who still packs them in. This may be old-fashioned and conservative on the part of the public, but it likes few things better than a program such as the one that George Szell and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with the help of Isaac Stern as violinist, played at Carnegie Hall last night.
The many ways in which a big city affects its inhabitants were debated yesterday at the opening sessions of Columbia University's first bicentennial conference.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Department of the Army today released additional names of personnel who have been missing in action in Korea for more than a year and who are now presumed to be dead. The lists included the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Echoes of the bitterness and controversy that arose here from the Munich pact negotiated by Hitler and Neville Chamberlain in 1938 were heard today as a memorial service was held for Viscount Norwich.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 7 -- White miners at the American-controlled Roan Antelope Mine in Northern Rhodesia have shaken the mining and industrial world of southern Africa by voting for removal of the color bar.

In meeting problems that may lie ahead, business will be aided and encouraged by the knowledge that it is operating in the "most wholesome economic climate that has existed in two decades," the, Guaranty Trust Company of New York asserts in its annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Arguments began in the Supreme Court today in a legal fight by Serge Rubinstein, Russian-born financier, to escape arrest and detention pending final determination of deportation proceedings started by the Department of Justice.

" Il Trovatore" was presented at the Metropolitan last evening with two newcomers in the cast, Josef Metternich, singing his first Count di Luna at the Metropolitan, and Norman Scott in a first appearance as Ferrando.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A military formula based on increased atomic firepower and less reliance on foot soldiers was developed by President Eisenhower in his State of the Union message to Congress today. It was offered in support of the President's promise of more defense for less money.

Joey Giardello, Philadelphia middleweight, will oppose Garth Panter of Salt Lake City in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. A card of five six-round contests and one four-rounder will support the top attraction.

A 44-year-old field agent for the Controller's office was arrested yesterday, accused of taking $300 in a $600 shakedown of a building contractor. The accused, Sidney I. Bruckman, a city employe for fifteen years, was charged with accepting a bribe and attempted extortion.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 7 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's Chancellor, reacted hotly today against a Socialist charge that he was trying to "sabotage the Berlin Big Four conference."

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Reductions in the list prices, ranging from $50 to $522, on four of its 1954 model cars, were announced today by Buick motors. List prices on all other models remain unchanged.

Organized baseball made its first move yesterday to set "its house in order" so that henceforth not even the most exacting may point a finger at the national pastime and accuse it of infringing upon the country's anti-trust laws or other Federal regulations.

Maurice H. Matzkin, first deputy commissioner of hospitals, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Wagner to serve as Acting Commissioner until the Mayor selected a medical man for the permanent post as head of the Department of Hospitals.

THE New York Conservation Department reports that the 1953 deer season was generally successful. Although not all of the returns have been tallied, the kill is expected to be lower than 1952 in some areas, with 22,000 bucks reported to date.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower withdrew today his request for cancellation of the Social Security tax increase that took effect Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Controversy over the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act began anew on Capitol Hill today because President Eisenhower failed to include the issue in his State of the Union message.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania already has drawn up tentative schedules through 1959 for the new round-robin Ivy group agreement, Athletic Director Jerry Ford said tonight.

The Fidelity-Union Trust Company of Newark, N. J., reported as of Dec. 31, 1953, total deposits of $429,989,521 and total assets of $467,904,800, compared, respectively, with $427,819,513 and $46,514,531 on Dec. 31, 1952. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $83,801,183 against $89,446,435; holdings of United States Government securities to $166,110,327 against $163,696,936; and loans and discounts to $157,935,509 against $155,256,885. Capital was increased to $5,000,000 from $4,500,000.
Following are editorial comments by the country's newspapers on President Eisenhower's State of the Union message, as gathered by The New York Times:
The speech of Mayor Wagner at the Citizens Budget Commission dinner at the Plaza Hotel last night follows:

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Lord Dunsany, 75-year-old poet and author, told off modern poets in an address last night. They are "bells of lead," he said. They should tinkle melodiously, but usually they just "klunk."
The cry of "Track!" will reecho throughout the Northeastern mountains this week-end.

Philadelphia's famous waterfront priest, the Rev. D. J. Comey, will speak at the twenty-first annual meeting of the National Association of Stevedores, it was announced yesterday by H. E. Rieckewald, administrative secretary of the organization. The meeting will convene Monday, morning in the Downtown Athletic Club.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Russian women dominated the cross-country race in the women's international ski tournament today, but the giant slalom race was won for the second straight year by Erika Mahringer of Austria.
LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Fifty-six nominations were accepted today for the 108th Grand National Steeplechase -- a field loaded with quality jumpers, but woefully Short on quantity.
The Washington Square Association endorsed last night the City Planning Commission's proposed Washington Square Southeast slum clearance project.

WINOOSKI, Vt., Jan. 7 (AP) -- A Vermont state legislator quotes American Woolen Company president Francis White as saying the company will keep open its big mill here if the workers "cut production costs" to meet Southern competition.
Three Cunard executives have been promoted, two in management and one in the passenger department.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 -- Vincent W. Hallinan, Independent Progressive party candidate for President in 1952, boarded a plane for Seattle today to begin service of an eighteen-month prison sentence for income tax evasion.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 7 (ap)-- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami easily won two matches today in opening his defense of the Dixie tennis championship. He beat Don Hanna of Tampa, 6--2, 6---4, and Ray Summers of Canada, 6---2, 6--1.

President Eisenhower appealed yesterday to "both of our great parties" to support the objectives defined in his State of the Union message. Some of these objectives he described in terms of specific recommendations. Others he will make the subject of subsequent messages. There will be time later, particularly as these additional messages come along, for a detailed consideration of the President's program.

A banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $35,000,000 of Consolidated Edison Company of New York first and refunding mortgage 3 3/8 per cent bonds due Jan. 1, 1984, at a price of 102.77 to yield 3.23 per cent to maturity. The bankers bought the bonds on Wednesday at competitive sale at a bid of 102.18.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 7 -- The Yale-in-China Association has named George D. Vaill executive secretary, the Rev. Luther A. Weigle, dean emeritus of the Yale Divinity School and president of Yale-in-China, announced today.

VIENNA, Jan. 7 -- About 200 lawyers from twenty-five countries concluded tonight a three-day meeting of the International Lawyers Conference for Defense of Democratic Rights with a resolution endorsing democratic rights, freedom and peace.

Fred Coe, the N. B. C. producer, has organized the Television Playwrights Company for the purpose of presenting a weekly half-hour drama series. The writers in the group are Horton Foote, Paddy Chayefsky. Tad Mosel, Sumner Locke Elliott, David Shaw and Robert Alan Aurthur, all of whom contribute to N. B. C.'s hour-long "Television Playhouse" series on Sunday evenings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Congress responded with wild yells of approval today to President Eisenhower's promise of harder action against communism but was largely unmoved by his general legislative program.

THERE is something symbolic in the news that Murray (Muzz) Patrick is returning to the New York Rangers, this time as their coach. The name of Patrick is inextricably woven into that of the Rangers and forms the gaudiest part of the Ranger pattern.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 7 -- Essencially the same program of controlled telecasting of college football games as was carried out in 1953 was recommended for 1954 to the National Collegiate Athletic Association today. But the door was left open for any such departures as are deemed advisable under changing conditions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Maurice Fischer of Chicago, the only newspaper man at the formation of the Labor Youth League in 1949, testified today that he had called the organization Communist at the start.

The National Steeplechase and Hunt Association will stage an international jumping race at Belmont Park this spring. Entries for the event, the first of its kind to be held in this country, will be sought from England, Ireland and France.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Grain and soybean futures yesterday displayed marked strength following early dips, wheat prices moving up to the highest levels in weeks.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in Europe, said today that the Soviet Union was stronger in military ground forces than the Western powers, despite the progress in the build-up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization defenses. He described this progress in the Atlantic alliance build-up as "out of this world."

MONTREAL, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard scored his second three-goal hat-trick of the season tonight as the Montreal Canadiens trounced the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7 -- 3, before 14,452 fans at the Forum.

Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kanin, who have just been writing a play together, have written a play about a married couple who are writing a play together. "His and Hers," they call it. Celeste Holm and Robert Preston appeared in it at the Forty-eighth Street last evening.

ROME, Jan. 7 -- A deep impression was created in political circles today when the Vatican expressed appreciation and support of Premier Giuseppe Pella, who was obliged by his party to resign two days ago.
NEWARK, Jan. 7 -- Eight boys arrested as juvenile offenders last Monday were accused today by the police of damaging or looting 380 parking meters in the downtown area here since last November.
BERLIN, Jan. 7 -- Representatives of the Big Four powers met here today to select a site in Berlin for the Foreign Ministers' conference scheduled for Jan. 25.

Mayor Wagner offered last night to join with Governor Dewey in the appointment of a commission to consider the advisability of giving the city a "proper share" of the unlimited taxing powers now exercised by the state.

Generally favorable conditions that prevailed in the real estate securities market last year are expected to continue during 1954, according to H. R. Amott, president of Amott, Baker Co., who attributes the basically good tone of the market to high income and occupancy rates and the firmness of underlying property values.

The Federal Maritime Board approved yesterday the proposed dual rate system of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference under which a 10 per cent differential is given to contract shippers. The board said the rate system was not, as had been charged, "arbitrary, unreasonable or unjustly discriminatory," and also found that the dual rate system did not violate the Shipping Act of 1916.

A tense finish between C. H. O'D. Alexander, former British champion, and David Bronstein of Russia, whose seventh-round encounter in the international chess tournament in Hastings is still adjourned after eighty-four moves in ten hours, is promised for the week-end, according to a report from London yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Employers in the electrical contracting industry threatened today to impose penatlies on workers who join in Communist-inspired guerrilla strikes threatened for next week and in a one-day token walkout announced for Jan. 18.

A spade was called a spade, then draped with the olive branch and the laurel of accolade at the induction yesterday of former Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri as a Justice of the Court of Special Sessions.

President Eisenhower's proposal in his State of the Union Message to Congress yesterday to keep the present liquor tax at $10.50 a gallon was criticized by the distilled spirits industry, which called it "contrary to the general public welfare."

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Jan. 7 -- Israel is deeply concerned about recent reports that the United States will give military assistance to some Arab nations to strengthen the Middle East against communism.
FORT DIX, N. J., Jan. 7 -- A young Regular Army sergeant who had fought in three battles in Korea without injury was killed accidentally today while instructing recruits in grenade practice here.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Eight former employes of the Duane Jones Company, .Inc., an advertising agency at 570 Lexington Avenue, New York City, were directed by the Court of Appeals today to pay the company $300,000 for having diverted accounts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The Commonwealth Edison Company on behalf of its proposed subsidiary, Northern Illinois Gas Company, registered today $60,000,000 of twenty-five-year first mortgage bonds with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. An application for authority to issue the bonds was filed earlier with the Illinois Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower's message to Congress today set forth the following legislative program on which he proposed last month that the Republican party be returned to office or defeated at the polls in this bi-election year:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- During the week ended Jan. 6, member bank reserves increased $118,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

When he was chosen, President Eisenhower's mandate was to reunite the American people. Hence it was right for him to call into consultation Republican Congressional leaders in an effort to replace indecision and division with unity and direction, and to follow this with, a friendly gesture to the Democratic leadership.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Personal income in the United States dropped $2,000,000,000 in November to an annual rate of $285,500,000,000, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower enunciated today his concept of the human side of government.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Jan. 8 -- Korean Foreign Minister Pyun Yung Tai retracted yesterday his threat to use armed force against Indian troops in Korea's demilitarized zone.

Colorful and imaginative, Tom Brigance's collection of resort designs was presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel by Lord Taylor. Never one to follow the usual, Mr. Brigance enlivened his beach and sundress fashions with all manner of gay and novel details.

Sir Leigh Ashton, director of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, said yesterday that "we are on the eve of startling new ideas, and if the atomic age goes on and if anyone is left to look at anything, museums may become startlingly different."
Instead of sending flowers to a hospitalized colleague, the English Department of Grover Cleveland High School sent $5 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Authoritative sources here say the success of the Foreign Ministers' Conference is threatened by differences between the Soviet Union and the West over its aims and scope.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 8 -- The Communist Command in Korea officially demanded today that the 22,000 anti-Communist Chinese and North Korean war prisoners remain in neutral custody until an international political conference determined their fate.

For "extraordinary heroism" on "Pork Chop Hill," near Sokkogae, Korea, last July 8, former 2d Lieut. Steven H. Wood of Locust, N. J., received the Distinguished Service Cross at Governors Island yesterday. Maj. Gen. E. B. Sebree, deputy commander of the First Army, presented the medal to the 24-year-old ex-soldier, who was released recently from active duty.
In New York, Mr. Lamont issued the following statement yesterday:
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The diversity of today's trends in traditional furniture was highlighted in an exhibition that opened at the Merchandise Mart here this morning.

The New York Knickerbockers defeated the Baltimore Bullets at Madison Square Garden last night, 82 -- 70, and increased their lead in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association to three games.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower, in his second State of the Union Message, today asked the almost evenly divided Eighty-third Congress to moderate but sustain the foreign and welfare policies of the New Deal era.
Three armed thugs held up five employes of a Brooklyn personal loan office yesterday morning and escaped with $2,000 and a diamond ring valued at $3,000.

Gardens of every kind figured in Sally Victor's spring and summer hat collection presented yesterday. Flowers in miniature were banked on hat "terraces" or in neatly planted 'beds" and little leaves made "hedges." All the "gardens" were on hats of delicate shape and size.

The most widely held corporate security in the world is the $100 par value common stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and management of that concern doesn't look favorably on suggestions for further widening it if it means splitting the stock.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Beset by an Adriatic flood that laid waste six villages in the Po River delta, Italy braced today for new peril from the north. Wind-whipped blizzards, swirling across western Europe, isolated dozens of Alpine hamlets.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The United States Government tonight reopened investigation of the unsolved $1,219,000 Brink's hold-up. Earlier six persons who balked at answering questions before a Federal grand jury were cleared of contempt.

A memoral exhibition of work by the late John Taylor Arms is current through January at the Kennedy Gallery. The selection includes 100 examples of Mr. Arms' meticulous craftsmanship, and the etchings are supplemented by a group of drawings.

On the eve of the opening of the new galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, emphasized there last night the essential unity of political and artistic freedom.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League said tonight that if the Canadian League wanted a war over players he would be glad to oblige it.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- British public opinion, as expressed through two of its greatest newspapers, reacted with unmistakable repugnance to President Eisenhower's recommendation to Congress that American citizens convicted in courts of conspiring to overthrow the Government be deprived of American citizenship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Republicans and Democrats joined today in introducing legislation to carry out President Eisenhower's recommendation that 18-year-olds be allowed to vote.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 (UP)--Marty Pavelich and Metro Prystai tallied less than two minutes apart in the third period tonight to enable the Detroit Red Wings to score a 3-to-1 victory over the Boston Bruins before 9,223 fans at Olympia.

Robert McDowell, a young pianist from Chicago, played a debut recital last night in Town Hall. At the start, with the performance of a pair of Scarlatti Sonatas, it was evident that Mr. McDowell had a decided keyboard talent. The scales were clean and neat, there was a forward rhythmic impetus and a thoroughly musical outlook.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Sweet Naomi, a 6-year-old gray mare owned by Mrs. Ella K. Bryson of Bel Air, Md., furnished one of the biggest surprises of the Tropical Park race meeting today when she raced home first in the Viator Purse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Albert C. Beeson, an industrial relations expert of San Jose Calif., was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be a member of the National Labor Relations Board.

ATLANTA, Jan. 7 -- The Fair Trade Act passed by the recent Georgia Legislature to replace one held unconstitutional by the Georgia Supreme Court has been signed by Gov. Herman Talmadge, it was announced today.
Plans have been furthered at recent luncheon meetings for the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Association to be held on Jan. 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 7 -- The 45,000-ton aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt, a veteran of nine Mediterranean cruises, departed from Norfolk this morning on the first leg of a 15,600-mile trip to Bremerton, Washington, by way of Cape Horn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- A bill increasing the 1954 national cotton allotment to 21,379,274 acres was approved today by the Senate Agriculture Committee.

A collection of essays about Sir Winston Churchill, who observes his eightieth birthday this year, has been edited by Charles Eade. The volume, entitled "Churchill -- By His Contemporaries," combines an assessment of the man, his achievements, his personality and his public and private life
FOUNTAIN HOUSE at 412 West Forty-seventh Street is like no other club on earth. The men and women who pass through its little dark door are almost all former patients of state hospitals.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday for the temporary financing of the Bayview Houses, a city no-cash-subsidy project in Brooklyn. The best bid for an issue of $19,000,000 of notes dated Feb. 1 and due Oct. 11 was an interest rate of 1.22 per cent, with $191 premium, submitted by Chase National Bank, C. J. Devine Co. and Salomon Bros. Hutzler.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 -- In the first expansion of an East Coast brewery into production in the mushrooming West Coast market, Liebmann Breweries, Inc., of Brooklyn has bought Acme Breweries, California's oldest and largest concern in the field.

KELSO, Scotland, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Isabella Patino, 18-year-old Bolivian tin heiress, and James Goldsmith, 20, her British fiance, were married in this picturesque border village tonight seven hours after her father, Antenor Patino, had withdrawn a court ban in Edinburgh against the marriage.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 7 (AP) -- America's Tony Trabert and Australia's Lewis Hoad, today advanced to the final of the South Australia tennis championships to set up a Saturday rematch of their exciting five-set duel in the Davis Cup challenge round.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- In what the President said to Congress today, and the assured way in which he said it, there was ample awareness of the great and yet unsolved problems that confront the Government and the people of the United States, among them many that are also the vital concerns of all mankind.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad has been called in Chicago on Feb. 8 to approve a plan through which the Class A stock would be exchanged on a par-for-par basis for debentures. The plan is designed to bring about a savings in income tax payments.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Management of Puget Sound Power and Light Company denied today in a court answer that it contemplated merger with Washington Water Power Company, and charged that a committee set up by opposition stockholders is financed by the latter concern.

A suggestion that the liquor industry, in framing its policies, act on a regional basis instead of a national one was made here last night. The proposal was advanced by Morris O. Alprin, general counsel of the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The United States prepared today to begin within the next few days the talks with the Soviet Union on an approach to the pooling of atomic-energy resources.

Where Is the Snow? The Christmas vacation ended on a note of sadness, and sadness continues now that again there is school. Each day during vacation, and even now, hopeful glances were cast upon passing clouds, and secular prayers were offered to the Weather Bureau to send on some snow.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 7 -- Robert Mr. Reindollar of Baltimore, president of the American Road Builders Association, said here today that "a bold, realistic national program of action to improve the country's highways is imperative."

Daniel Kalter has been named sales promotion manager and given merchandise responsibilities at Namm Loeser, Inc., Brooklyn department store. The move was part of a realignment of merchandising responsibilities and followed the resignations of Edwin Cavanagh and Bernard Pincus, vice presidents.
HASTINGS, N. Z., Jan. 7 (AP) Queen Elizabeth II went whistle stopping through New Zealand today to show herself and the Duke of Edinburgh to the New Zealand countryfolk.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- The United Nations is sending a high official on a mission to Moscow to try to untie the strings attached to the Soviet Union's offer of $1,000,000 in rubles for the organization's technical assistance program.

Items as diverse as a 49-cent knitters' aid and a blanket that could be used as a stole were shown yesterday in an exhibition at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. All were winners in the Hess Brothers third annual competition in versatility of design and use.
Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries increased their net profit for the September-November quarter to $6,594,484 from $5,779,578 in the corresponding three months of 1952.

The intimate Avon Theatre at 251 West Forty-fifth Street is being torn down. In the absence of word from the owners, Abraham and Frederick Dreier, who operate a chain of hotels, investigation disclosed that the land would be used temporarily as a parking lot. Its future disposition has not been determined, it was reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The President's message on the State of the Union was long, 7,000 words, but it was a mere shadow of its former self.

CHICAGO. Jan. 7 (AP) -- Some of the hogs which had been held back the last two days turned up on the livestock market today. Salable receipts were 4,000 more than expected, and prices of butchers dropped 23 to 75 cents while sows were mostly 50 to 75 cents down.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 7 -- A redistribution of big rural land holdings and condemning of landlords is under way in Communist Vietminh-ruled areas of Vietnam. The program, which went into effect last Friday, is similar to the land reform program carried out in Communist China.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Isaac Stern, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, duo-pianists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "Faust," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Paul Tortelier, 'cellist, Town Hall, 8:30; Juilliard String Quartet, Juilliard School, 8:30; "Israel in Egypt," Prospect Heights High School, Brooklyn, 8:30; "The Barber of Seville," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- A British officer described today his nineteen months' imprisonment by the Communists in North Korea.

Grover A. Whalen, who retired as chairman of the Mayor's Reception Committee last Friday, received a certificate of appreciation for patriotic service to the Army at a ceremony at First Army Headquarters on Governors Island yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Rome, will return to her post ahead of schedule because of the Italian Government crisis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Army generals, after months of indecision over a new uniform for soldiers, decided today to ask G. I. Joe what he would like to wear.
Loans to business by New York banks dropped $231,000,000 last week, the largest single weekly reduction on record.

Despite a large increase in the population and an even greater percentage increase in the number of children under 16, the number of youngsters now cared for by community agencies outside their own homes has decreased dramatically in the last twenty years.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers reached into the collegiate football coaching ranks today for a successor to Gene Ronzani and came up with Lisle (Liz) Blackbourn, who recently completed his fourth year as head coach at Marquette University.
Mayor Wagner has called a special meeting at City Hall today in an effort to settle a labor dispute between coal and fuel oil truck drivers and their employers.
Shipping employers sought court help yesterday to halt the spread of Brooklyn pier strikes before they exploded into a port-wide shutdown.
There was no break yesterday in the steady climb of cocoa and coffee prices on the New York commodity exchanges. Both items continued fairly active and the spot prices also went to new highs.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The breakdown of discussions on electricians' wage demands brought further profit-taking in industrial shares on the Stock Exchange here today and caused some prices to fall. But the undertone of the markets was described as firm on the whole and closing prices again showed many more gains than losses.
In recognition of her achievements as production coordinator for the successful drama season at the City Center, Jean Dalrymple has been named permanent director of the New York City Theatre Company.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 7 (UP) -- School teachers were told today that they had a legal right to slap school children "in a reasonable manner."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower met tonight with Republican Congressional leaders and Administration officials seeking to work out a compromise on a controversial proposal to limit the President's treaty-making powers.
Retailers are more optimistic about the outlook for their own business than they are for the economy as a whole.
Americans like eggs and are eating them at the rate of 400 a person a year -- a pace we have maintained since 1950.

Needham, Louis Brorby, Inc., Chicago, has acquired a large part of the account of Wilson Co., Inc., meat packer. The items involved include hams and bacon sausages, smoked meats and poultry. No change is being made in the assignment of other Wilson product advertising, now being handled by Ewell Thurber Associates, it was said by Mark Cox, Wilson's ad manager.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower proposed today to strip United States citizenship from Communists convicted in the future of conspiring to advocate the overthrow of Government by force and violence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that the St. Lawrence Seaway was needed for the defense of the United States and Canada. Many in Congress felt the President's action made certain approval of United States participation in the project.

ARTHUR GODFREY'S loss of his cigarette sponsor, announced on Wednesday, points up a fresh danger to television stars who step out of character and turn pitchman. The humorist has been identified with the tobacco concern for so long -- more than seven years -- that it is not likely that a rival cigarette company would want him to peddle its wares.

It is disheartening to me to note that The New York Times, usually temperate and factual, is repeating the irresponsible allegations of some wilderness zealots regarding the proposal to build Echo Park dam.

For fifteen minutes yesterday a window washer dangled by his safety belt thirty-five feet above the sidewalk at 602 West Twenty-seventh Street, between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues. He was rescued by five truck drivers.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Financial experts said today that the figures would show that in 1953 the French currency zone had come close to balancing its accounts with the rest of the world for the first time since the liberation of France in 1944. The experts were explaining Premier Joseph Laniel's optimistic report to the National Assembly.
Joel Andrews sent $5 yesterday to help further the education of a teen-ager who is among the troubled persons whose plight will be made less severe through the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

With more than 3,000 early arrivals in attendance, Mayor Wagner formally opened "The 1954 Career Show" last night. The admission-free event, a project of the Private Vocational Schools Association of New York, will continue from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. today at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.4, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The decline was limited to the index of prices of arm products, as the index for processed foods advanced fractionally and the average for all other commodities remained unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Unemployment is still on the rise.

Two-piano recitals are not as popular as they used to be; at least, the number of such events has considerably fallen off during the last two seasons. Last night two of the veterans of the art, Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, took over Carnegie Hall and showed a large audience what it has been missing.

Nathan Wilson, operator, in partnership with Melvin Kaufman, purchased the sixteen-story office and showroom building on plot 48 by 100 feet at 42 to 46 West Forty-eighth Street, between Filth and Sixth Avenues, near Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Commission on Foreign Economic Policy was in something of a dither today over what some members called the "high-handed" tactics of its chairman, Clarence B. Randall of Chicago.
Prices of active cotton futures in the New York Cotton Exchange eased 4 to 14 points yesterday.

In his State of the Union message President Eisenhower noted that more than 2,200 employes have been separated from the federal service under the new security program that went into effect last May. This is the procedure whereby federal employes can be discharged as "security risks" for a wide variety of offenses ranging from disloyalty to talkativeness.

After a day of legalistic bickering through statements issued to the press, one of which was read to reporters assembled on the sidewalk outside an apartment house, the Winthrop Rockefellers appeared last night to have reached agreement on a $5,500,000 divorce settlement.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Two paraplegic veterans were ejected from Kennedy Veterans Hospital in their wheelchairs today.
Pravda, the most authoritative newspaper in the Soviet Union, has called for more Communist party control over the work of practitioners of the arts.
The American Institute of Pacific Relations has received enough donations and pledges from members to enable it to continue to operate this year, it was declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Former President Truman denied tonight that he had originated the "red herring" label that has been a prominent topic in Washington politics since 1948. The record shows, however, that he adopted the term when it was used by a reporter and repeatedly used it.
Does Congress have the power to take away a person's citizenship? Or does it have only the right to draw a line over which he cannot pass without voluntarily surrendering his allegiance?

THE wavy watered-silk images of television don't do half as well at bringing the theatre into the living room as books have been doing for years and years and years. This morning's volumes are convincing cases in point. One is Tom Prideaux' "World Theatre in Pictures,"* a brilliant gallery of stage photographs, mainly from Life magazine, that have none of the Birth-of-a-Nation-print blurring of video.

A jury in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday acquitted Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront union leader, and the old International Longshoremen's Association on charges of criminal and civil contempt.

Probably no age other than ours could witness such a variety of styles in painting as is to be found in one week at New York galleries. Six such diverse exhibitions deserve special attention this week.
The five Republican county chairmen in New York City announced yesterday that they would act as a "watchdog committee" to work and fight for an effective city program.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 9 -- The Swiss and Swedish members of the Korean war-prisoner repatriation commission at Panmunjom riticized yesterday the memorandum sent a week ago by the Indian chairman to the United Nations and Communist commands.

A color television signal will be transmitted over Channel 11 Mondays through Fridays from 11 A. M. to 12:30 P. M. beginning next week. The facilities to be used are those of station WPIX. The experimental call letters, KE2XNK, will be employed during the tests.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 8 -- More than 100 members of the National Farmers Union from four states assembled here today for a trek to Washington by bus.

TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, who will retire Jan. 19 after two terms as New Jersey's chief executive, has been offered "at least three or four" top executive positions with nationally known corporations.

The work done by the Boy Scouts of America serves to build better boys, to teach them physical skills and to provide wholesome outdoor activities. Scouting offers fun and training through dedicated volunteer leaders. It builds finer citizens and serves all boys regardless of race or creed. Scouting teaches leadership and love of country.
