POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Jan. 8 (AP) -- George P. Leadbitter, Poughkeepsie police chief, today confirmed reports that he had filed an application for retirement with the New York State Employes Pension System.

CORNING, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- Showings of "family life" films for employes of the Corning Glass Works and for the public here were not a success, but the sponsors said that they had learned some valuable things about procedure.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 8 -- This capital of 30,000 population shows few outward signs of the war crisis that grips Laos.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 8 -- A streamlining of its enforcement machinery for punishing transgressors was effected today as the National Collegiate Athletic Association ended its forty-eighth annual convention here.

In behalf of the Fresh Air Association of St. John, Inc., a loan exhibition of paintings from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, to be known as "A Collector's Taste," will open with a preview Monday night at the Knoedler Galleries.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- The North Atlantic Alliance powers have agreed to construct two pipelines to carry petroleum products from French ports to serve airfields in Northwestern Europe.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 8 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, expressed today agreement in part with Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts on the subject of subversives.
Maybe the lemmings decided against mass suicide this year, or maybe the snowy owl decided to skip the United States this year -- no one knows for sure.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator George D. Aiken named today a special subcommittee to investigate food prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A Justice Department report to the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee today listed eleven special Federal Bureau of Investigation reports made in 1946 and 1947 on Edward J. Fitzgerald, a former Federal economist.
The teen-aged daughter of a Queens physician was fatally injured and a schoolmate critically hurt yesterday when they were thrown from horses that bolted, apparently in fear of a passing train.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Jan. 8 (AP) -- A man who described himself as a Yugoslavia-born engineer with designs for a "revolutionary" jet plane engine was charged today with entering the United States from Canada illegally.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Communist-dominated Electrical Trades Union announced today that, despite the threats of retaliation by the employers, it would stage sporadic strikes next week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A "flexible shell suit" was patented this week by Avo R. Mianulli of Philadelphia primarily for military use. It has a tough layer of plastic or rubber sheeting and a soft lining of latex, with tight collar and cuffs and shoes made integrally with the suit.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 8 (AP) -- F. H. Peavey Co. has been offered "more than enough" Russell-Miller Milling Company common stock for control of the nation's fourth largest flour producer.

Contributions to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program amounted to 625 pints on Thursday. Of this amount, 187 pints came from the New York State Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, and 115 pints from a community donation at Theodore Korony Post 253 of the American Legion, 4111 East 177th Street, the Bronx.
Executives of Station WOR-TV offered the States of New York and New Jersey yesterday the use of the company's auxiliary television transmitter in North Bergen, N. J., for educational telecasts.

TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- The New Jersey Legislature gave final approval today to a bill to increase the annual salaries of its members from $3,000 to $5,000. It also adopted and sent to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll a measure appropriating $100,000 for the New York - New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

Has Chicago replaced Pittsburgh as the nation's steel capital? The Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry says it has -- that Chicago area mills produced 20,628,100 tons of steel last year, compared with 19,848,800 tons for the Pittsburgh district.

The Eastern railroads have agreed on rate reductions ranging from 18 to 20 per cent on many iron and steel products, Edgar V. Hill, chairman of the Traffic Executive Association of the Eastern Railroads announced yesterday. He said the new rate schedules, which will be filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission around Feb. 1, are designed to put the railroads on a competitive basis with motor carriers.

A dispatch from Accra on the Gold Coast reminds us that Communist infiltration of trade unions in colonial areas is part of the Kremlin's worldwide policy aiming to tie workers and farmers the world over to its chariot wheels. Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, the Gold Coast Prime Minister (educated at Lincoln University, Pennsylvania, the University of Pennsylvania and London University), has withdrawn his regime from Communist entanglements.

Hans E. Inslerman, brother of a witness in the Alger Hiss perjury trial, was disclosed yesterday to have been suspended as a Fort Monmouth, N. J., electronics engineer. His lawyer said the charges "follow the familiar pattern of guilt by 'blood-tie.'"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The White House is pleased by the reaction to President Eisenhower's message on the State of the Union, but it has no illusions about the task of getting his program through Congress.

BONN, Germany Jan. 8 -- The leader of West Germany's Social Democrats affirmed today that his party thought the chances of success for the Berlin Big Four conference would be diminished if Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government persisted in its present policy.

In 1897 the city agreed to pay the cost of maintenance and repair of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Since that time, the library complains, the city has provided repairs, but not maintenance.

Wasteful employe practices and privileges were blamed yesterday by the Transit Authority for excessive operating costs as high as $50,000,000 a year on the city-owned lines. In a series of proposals delivered to fourteen unions and associations that represent its 44,000 workers, the authority insisted that it have complete freedom to eliminate the waste by making broad changes in working conditions on the transit system.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Moscow Radio declared tonight that President Eisenhower's message on the State of the Union tried to sell the idea that solution of the atomic problem "depended solely on the Soviet Union."
A Federal Court jury acquitted three persons last night on charges that they had conspired to obstruct justice in an investigation of the attempted assassination of President Harry S. Truman in 1950.

RAHWAY, N. J., Jan. 8 -- Management and union representatives agreed today on terms to settle a strike that has kept 1,500 production workers here idle since Nov. 24 at the pharmaceutical plant of Merck Co., Inc. The settlement terms are subject to ratification by the union membership.

When a boy hits 20 he is packed with physical and moral confidence. At 30 he begins thinking time-wise about what went before and what is left to come, about the hours of sleep he is getting, how much he smokes and weighs. At 40 he wears scarfs on cold days, considers diets and heart strain, and if he is an athlete he casts about for another living.

Spices and herbs, which so often make the difference between a memorable meal and just another meal, are continuing to gain in popularity. Statistics reveal a marked rise in the use of spices and herbs in this country in the last few years.
The Rev. Achille Deodato of Rome, moderator of the Waldensian Church, has arrived here for a six-week visit.
BOSTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and lists of winter sports conditions:
Calvin MacCracken of the Princeton Club will be one of the semi-finalists in the New York State squash racquets singles championship at the Downtown Athletic Club on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The controversial bill to grant Hawaii statehood moved a step nearer enactment today. The Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee voted by a show of hands to end its public hearings.

Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Martindell of 125 East Thirty-eighth Street and Princeton, N. J., gave a reception and tea yesterday afternoon in the small ballroom of the Colony Club to introduce Mrs. Martindell's daughter, Miss Marjory Blair Scott, to older friends of the family.

The Commonwealth is a bit like the ghost of Hamlet's father: "Hic et ubique!" It is here, there and everywhere, and one is sometimes tempted to say that it is nowhere. Nothing could seem more nebulous than seven completely sovereign and independent nations literally scattered all over the world.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 8 (AP) -- It would cost the International Olympic Committee nearly $4,500,000 to take the 1956 Olympic Games from Melbourne at this late date, a high Olympic official said today.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Jan. 9 -- South Korea fired a broadside of criticism at the United States yesterday for its attitude toward the Communists and Japan.

WASHINGTON, Jan 8 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, today suggested a $1,000,000,000 Government program to help people buy homes on fifty to sixty-year mortgages with little or no down payment.

DETROIT, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A high-ranking police official announced today that the shotgun blast that seriously wounded Walter Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in 1948 had been traced to gangster elements. They were the same elements, he said, that tried to seize control of the United Auto Workers Union, C. I. O., which Mr. Reuther also heads.

The nine-man committee of major and minor league executives appointed by Commissioner Ford C. Frick to iron out various kinks in baseball's complicated laws, held its second and concluding session at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday, then adjourned again without making any announcements.

Dr. Corliss Lamont, leftist author and teacher, and Abraham Unger, lawyer for some organizations allegedly Communist-dominated, asked yesterday for hearings before the full Senate Committee on Government Operations.

Civil Air Patrol fliers thought yesterday they had found the wreckage of an airplane that disappeared Tuesday on a flight from Bradley Field, Conn. By coincidence it was the same unusual type of plane, but it was not the one they were looking for.

Interhandel, Swiss investment corporation, yesterday filed an appeal from the recent dismissal of its lawsuit against the Alien Property Office for return of Interhandel's 90 per cent stock interest in the General Aniline and Film Corporation. John J. Wilson, attorney for Interhandel, made the announcement. The stock has been held by the Alien Property Office since 1942.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- R. A. Butler, 51, Chancellor of the Exchequer, has been made a Companion of Honor. The award was recommended by Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, and approved by Queen Elizabeth.
College basketball today in the metropolitan area will start with an afternoon clash between Fordham and Army at the Ram gymnasium.

Despite inevitable dissents and reservations on some specific points, President Eisenhower's State of the Union message has been interpreted generally throughout the free world as a hopeful message which pairs firmness with moderation. The dissents vary with the dissenters' own interests: the reservations make promise dependent on Congressional performance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced plans tonight for another series of tests for atomic and probably hydrogen weapons at the Government's Pacific proving grounds.

The four-story apartment house at 612 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn has been purchased by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, from Rose M. Rochford in a transaction negotiated by M. C. O'Brien as broker. With the acquisition last May of the property at 608 and 610 Flatbush Avenue, the buyers now control three buildings containing twenty-one four-room apartments and three stores on a plot 57 by 100 feet.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Dave J. Schneider's Elixir, left at the post in the Robert E. Lee Handicap last Saturday, ran off with the Electioneer Purse at Tropical Park today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 9 -- The State Highway Department is conducting an experiment in the interests of night driving safety. The test area is a five-mile stretch of the Merritt Parkway between Long Ridge Road here and North Street in Greenwich.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 8 (AP) -- State Attorney General Louis C. Wyman said today that Paul W. Sweezy, a former assistant professor at Harvard University, had denied under oath that he was or ever had been a member of the Communist party.

Three years ago the Metropolitan Museum of Art embarked upon a vast and complicated program of rebuilding and rehabilitation. The first rewards to be reaped from this venture for the public benefit will be visible today with the opening of forty-four completely modernized picture galleries.

Your editorial of Jan. 4 "Important Vacancy" moves me -- as I am sure it must move all librarians -- to warm commendation for the insight it showed into a vital situation. Intelligent, trained leadership is particularly in demand these days, and is of special consequence in the library field, whose influence reaches innumerable individuals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Department of the Army released today additional names of personnel who have been missing in action in Korea for more than a year and who are now presumed to be dead. The lists included the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:...
C. H. O'D. Alexander of England took first place in the international chess masters tournament at Hastings, England, by scoring two victories yesterday, according to a report from London.

The Romarco Realty Corporation, D. J. Arnold, president, sold the thirty-family apartment house at 2107 Harrison Avenue in the Bronx to Emil Leepson. It is assessed at $95,000. John J. Reynolds, Inc., was the broker in the sale.

A committee of four customs officers and five steamship line officials has been formed by the Collector of Customs, Robert W. Dill, to study methods of further speeding up the clearance of inbound passengers and their baggage on luxury liner piers.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Leonid Utyosov, the Soviet "King of Jazz," dropped his baton for a pen to write an impassioned defense of jazz in a country where jitterbugging is taboo and the saxophone is regarded with suspicion as a capitalistic invention.

Two five - story apartment houses accommodating forty-two families at 37-16 and 37-32 Eightieth Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, have been sold by Hannah Farber to the Bisk Realty Corporation. Walter Scott Co. and the Advance Realty Company were co-brokers in the sale.

LEXINGTON, Mass., Jan. 8 -- Dr. Wallace E. Howell, the noted "rainmaker" who was hired by New York City in 1950 to replenish its low reservoirs, confirmed reports tonight that negotiations nearly had been completed for him to try to supply snow to Manchester, Vt.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Governor Dewey will ask that $25,000,000 more revenue be obtained from harness tracks and devoted to schools.

Events today: "Tannhaeuser." Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; New Music String Quartet, Turtle Bay Music School, 2:30; "The Marriage of Figaro," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Philharmonic - Symphony, Franco Autori conducting, Jacques Abram, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

ALTHOUGH the foxhunters have been disappointed in the weather, there seems to be no complaint on the matter of fox populations, and reports from the Catskills and upstate counties, as well as from northern Connecticut, indicate excellent hunting.

Prices of both coffee and cocoa again shot up yesterday on the New York exchanges. The spot price of both also soared. Santos 4's were at 69 3/4 cents, up 1 1/2 cents from the previous day and 5 1/3 cents over the 1953 record set on Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Army cut by more than half today its outstanding orders for jeeps and light trucks. Production schedules for military trailers were reduced by one-third.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Germany's Ossie Reichart won the slalom race by one-tenth of a second today and Russia's formidable distance skiers finished one-two in the cross-country relay event of the international women's ski tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Supreme Court heard today that the Immigration and Naturalization Act of 1952, known as the McCarran-Walter Act. provided for judicial review of deportation proceedings.

Only a small proportion of the President's message was devoted to foreign affairs. This is not a sign of lack of interest but a proof that on the essentials of foreign policy there is little dispute. Despite all the arguments about details and methods the broad principles of this policy have been fixed by events, and neither party can greatly alter them.
